src: Anger's my meat; I sup upon myself, And so shall starve with feeding. Come, let's go: Leave this faint puling and lament as I do, In anger, Juno-like. Come, come, come.
trg: Fie, fie, fie!

src: Were not you then as cruel as the sentence That you have slander'd so?
trg: Ignomy in ransom and free pardon Are of two houses: lawful mercy Is nothing kin to foul redemption.

src: but nature should bring forth, Of its own kind, all foison, all abundance, To feed my innocent people.
trg: No marrying 'mong his subjects?

src: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.
trg: In God's name, what art thou?

src: Come, my sweet wife, my dearest mother, and My friends of noble touch, when I am forth, Bid me farewell, and smile. I pray you, come.
trg: While I remain above the ground, you shall Hear from me still, and never of me aught But what is like me formerly.

src: Who meets us here?  my niece Plantagenet Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester? Now, for my life, she's wandering to the Tower, On pure heart's love to greet the tender princes.
trg: Daughter, well met.

src: I yield all this; But for some other reasons, my grave sir, Which 'tis not fit you know, I not acquaint My father of this business.
trg: Let him know't.

src: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?
trg: I told him that your father was at Venice, And that you look'd for him this day in Padua.

src: Ay, just; perpetual durance, a restraint, Though all the world's vastidity you had, To a determined scope.
trg: But in what nature?

src: Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms, Of their own choice: one's Junius Brutus, Sicinius Velutus, and I know not--'Sdeath!
trg: The rabble should have first unroof'd the city, Ere so prevail'd with me: it will in time Win upon power and throw forth greater themes For insurrection's arguing.

src: Villains, set down the corse; or, by Saint Paul, I'll make a corse of him that disobeys.
trg: My lord, stand back, and let the coffin pass.

src: Can heaven be so envious?
trg: Romeo can, Though heaven cannot: O Romeo, Romeo! Who ever would have thought it? Romeo!

src: It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?
trg: Not having that, which, having, makes them short.

src: Why let it strike?
trg: Because that, like a Jack, thou keep'st the stroke Betwixt thy begging and my meditation. I am not in the giving vein to-day.

src: Wrong not her birth, she is of royal blood.
trg: To save her life, I'll say she is not so.

src: We have not yet set down this day of triumph. To-morrow, in mine opinion, is too sudden; For I myself am not so well provided As else I would be, were the day prolong'd.
trg: Where is my lord protector? I have sent for these strawberries.

src: a lantern, slaughter'd youth, For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes This vault a feasting presence full of light. Death, lie thou there, by a dead man interr'd.
trg: How oft when men are at the point of death Have they been merry! which their keepers call A lightning before death: O, how may I Call this a lightning? O my love! my wife!

src: Dear sir, ere long I'll visit you again.
trg: Most holy sir, I thank you.

src: And therefore is he idle?
trg: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.

src: This is the rascal; this is he I spoke of.
trg: Why, thou unreverend and unhallow'd friar, Is't not enough thou hast suborn'd these women To accuse this worthy man, but, in foul mouth And in the witness of his proper ear, To call him villain?

src: What's the matter?
trg: You are sent for to the Capitol. 'Tis thought That Marcius shall be consul: I have seen the dumb men throng to see him and The blind to bear him speak:

src: I do constantly believe you. The time is come even now. I shall crave your forbearance a little: may be I will call upon you anon, for some advantage to yourself.
trg: I am always bound to you.

src: Look you bring me in the names of some six or seven, the most sufficient of your parish.
trg: To your worship's house, sir?

src: In, in, in, in!
trg: We hear not of him, neither need we fear him; His remedies are tame i' the present peace And quietness of the people, which before Were in wild hurry.

src: and leaves nothing undone that may fully discover him their opposite.
trg: Now, to seem to affect the malice and displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he dislikes, to flatter them for their love.
Now, messenger, what letters or what news From France?

src: O, if thine eye be not a flatterer, Come thou on my side, and entreat for me, As you would beg, were you in my distress A begging prince what beggar pities not?
trg: Look behind you, my lord.

src: That's my noble master! What shall I do? say what; what shall I do?
trg: Go make thyself like a nymph o' the sea: be subject To no sight but thine and mine, invisible To every eyeball else. Go take this shape And hither come in't: go, hence with diligence!

src: For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part; Being tasted, slays all senses with the heart. Two such opposed kings encamp them still In man as well as herbs, grace and rude will;
trg: And where the worser is predominant, Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.

src: They choose their magistrate, And such a one as he, who puts his 'shall,' His popular 'shall' against a graver bench Than ever frown in Greece. By Jove himself! It makes the consuls base:
trg: and my soul aches To know, when two authorities are up, Neither supreme, how soon confusion May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take The one by the other.

src: our countrymen are gone and fled, As well assured Richard their king is dead.
trg: Ah, Richard, with the eyes of heavy mind I see thy glory like a shooting star Fall to the base earth from the firmament.

src: I must eat my dinner. This island's mine, by Sycorax my mother, Which thou takest from me.
trg: When thou camest first, Thou strokedst me and madest much of me, wouldst give me Water with berries in't, and teach me how To name the bigger light, and how the less, That burn by day and night:

src: Your grace mistakes; only to be brief Left I his title out.
trg: The time hath been, Would you have been so brief with him, he would Have been so brief with you, to shorten you, For taking so the head, your whole head's length.

src: These letters at fit time deliver me The provost knows our purpose and our plot. The matter being afoot, keep your instruction, And hold you ever to our special drift;
trg: Though sometimes you do blench from this to that, As cause doth minister. Go call at Flavius' house, And tell him where I stay:

src: O Harry's wife, triumph not in my woes! God witness with me, I have wept for thine.
trg: Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge, And now I cloy me with beholding it. Thy Edward he is dead, that stabb'd my Edward: Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;

src: A crutch, a crutch! why call you for a sword?
trg: My sword, I say! Old Montague is come, And flourishes his blade in spite of me.

src: Peace, both, and hear me speak.
trg: Cut me to pieces, Volsces; men and lads, Stain all your edges on me. Boy! false hound!

src: the serving-men in their new fustian, their white stockings, and every officer his wedding-garment on? Be the jacks fair within, the jills fair without, the carpets laid, and every thing in order?
trg: All ready; and therefore, I pray thee, news.

src: Lord mayor,--
trg: Look to the drawbridge there!

src: Sirrah, bring Barnardine hither.
trg: Master Barnardine! you must rise and be hanged. Master Barnardine!

src: O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities:
trg: For nought so vile that on the earth doth live But to the earth some special good doth give, Nor aught so good but strain'd from that fair use Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse:

src: And let Bianca take her sister's room.
trg: Shall sweet Bianca practise how to bride it?

src: the leanness that afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an inventory to particularise their abundance; our sufferance is a gain to them Let us revenge this with our pikes, ere we become rakes:
trg: for the gods know I speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.

src: For this last, Before and in Corioli, let me say, I cannot speak him home: he stopp'd the fliers; And by his rare example made the coward Turn terror into sport:
trg: as weeds before A vessel under sail, so men obey'd And fell below his stem: his sword, death's stamp, Where it did mark, it took;

src: Where's Cotus? my master calls for him. Cotus!
trg: A goodly house: the feast smells well; but I Appear not like a guest.

src: Sir, he may live: I saw him beat the surges under him, And ride upon their backs; he trod the water, Whose enmity he flung aside, and breasted The surge most swoln that met him;
trg: his bold head 'Bove the contentious waves he kept, and oar'd Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke To the shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bow'd, As stooping to relieve him:

src: Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.
trg: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.

src: I go: and towards three or four o'clock Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.
trg: Go, Lovel, with all speed to Doctor Shaw; Go thou to Friar Penker; bid them both Meet me within this hour at Baynard's Castle.

src: Why, so hath this, both by the father and mother.
trg: Better it were they all came by the father, Or by the father there were none at all; For emulation now, who shall be nearest, Will touch us all too near, if God prevent not.

src: Most mighty liege, and my companion peers, Take from my mouth the wish of happy years: As gentle and as jocund as to jest Go I to fight: truth hath a quiet breast.
trg: Farewell, my lord: securely I espy Virtue with valour couched in thine eye. Order the trial, marshal, and begin.

src: There is a sickness Which puts some of us in distemper, but I cannot name the disease; and it is caught Of you that yet are well.
trg: How! caught of me! Make me not sighted like the basilisk: I have look'd on thousands, who have sped the better By my regard, but kill'd none so.

src: And we, in pity of the gentle king, Had slipp'd our claim until another age.
trg: But when we saw our sunshine made thy spring, And that thy summer bred us no increase, We set the axe to thy usurping root;

src: Prithee, son, do; for we must be gentle, now we are gentlemen.
trg: Thou wilt amend thy life?

src: Her cause and yours I'll perfect him withal, and he shall bring you Before the duke, and to the head of Angelo Accuse him home and home.
trg: For my poor self, I am combined by a sacred vow And shall be absent. Wend you with this letter: Command these fretting waters from your eyes With a light heart;

src: Ay, to the proof; as mountains are for winds, That shake not, though they blow perpetually.
trg: How now, my friend! why dost thou look so pale?

src: Scandal'd the suppliants for the people, call'd them Time-pleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.
trg: Why, this was known before.

src: Thou concludest like the sanctimonious pirate, that went to sea with the Ten Commandments, but scraped one out of the table.
trg: 'Thou shalt not steal'?

src: An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.
trg: A vengeance on your crafty wither'd hide! Yet I have faced it with a card of ten. 'Tis in my head to do my master good:

src: asks thee the son forgiveness, As 'twere i' the father's person; kisses the hands Of your fresh princess; o'er and o'er divides him 'Twixt his unkindness and his kindness;
trg: the one He chides to hell and bids the other grow Faster than thought or time.

src: I will wish her speedy strength, and visit her with my prayers; but I cannot go thither.
trg: Why, I pray you?

src: I know not, mighty sovereign, but by guess.
trg: Well, sir, as you guess, as you guess?

src: Unless our halberds did shut up his passage.
trg: Ay, wherefore else guard we his royal tent, But to defend his person from night-foes?

src: And I this.
trg: A murrain on't! I took this for silver.

src: I, measuring his affections by my own, That most are busied when they're most alone, Pursued my humour not pursuing his, And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.
trg: Many a morning hath he there been seen, With tears augmenting the fresh morning dew. Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs;

src: Why look you so upon me? I am but sorry, not afeard; delay'd, But nothing alter'd: what I was, I am; More straining on for plucking back, not following My leash unwillingly.
trg: Gracious my lord, You know your father's temper: at this time He will allow no speech, which I do guess You do not purpose to him; and as hardly Will he endure your sight as yet, I fear:

src: Give me excuse, good madam; I will obey you in every thing hereafter.
trg: Let her alone, lady: as she is now, she will but disease our better mirth.

src: Nine changes of the watery star hath been The shepherd's note since we have left our throne Without a burthen: time as long again Would be find up, my brother, with our thanks;
trg: And yet we should, for perpetuity, Go hence in debt: and therefore, like a cipher, Yet standing in rich place, I multiply With one 'We thank you' many thousands moe That go before it.

src: Being i' the war Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they show'd Most valour, spoke not for them:
trg: the accusation Which they have often made against the senate, All cause unborn, could never be the motive Of our so frank donation. Well, what then?

src: Patience is for poltroons, such as he: He durst not sit there, had your father lived. My gracious lord, here in the parliament Let us assail the family of York.
trg: Well hast thou spoken, cousin: be it so.

src: Right well, dear madam. By your patience, I may not suffer you to visit them; The king hath straitly charged the contrary.
trg: The king! why, who's that?

src: which if you, or stupefied Or seeming so in skill, cannot or will not Relish a truth like us, inform yourselves We need no more of your advice:
trg: the matter, The loss, the gain, the ordering on't, is all Properly ours.

src: He shall know you better, sir, if I may live to report you.
trg: I fear you not.

src: I am the provost. What's your will, good friar?
trg: Bound by my charity and my blest order, I come to visit the afflicted spirits Here in the prison.

src: These news I must confess are full of grief; Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may: Warwick may lose, that now hath won the day.
trg: Till then fair hope must hinder life's decay. And I the rather wean me from despair For love of Edward's offspring in my womb:

src: Well, he in time may come to clear himself; But at this instant he is sick my lord, Of a strange fever.
trg: Upon his mere request, Being come to knowledge that there was complaint Intended 'gainst Lord Angelo, came I hither, To speak, as from his mouth, what he doth know Is true and false;

src: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.
trg: To take is not to give.

src: I have: but what of him?
trg: Knows he of this?

src: Do not repent these things, for they are heavier Than all thy woes can stir; therefore betake thee To nothing but despair.
trg: A thousand knees Ten thousand years together, naked, fasting, Upon a barren mountain and still winter In storm perpetual, could not move the gods To look that way thou wert.

src: false, fleeting, perjured Clarence, That stabb'd me in the field by Tewksbury; Seize on him, Furies, take him to your torments!
trg: No marvel, my lord, though it affrighted you; I promise, I am afraid to hear you tell it.

src: or if your knowledge be more it is much darkened in your malice.
trg: Sir, I know him, and I love him.

src: I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not Out three years old.
trg: Certainly, sir, I can.

src: Come, sister,--cousin, I would say--pray, pardon me. Go, fellow, get thee home, provide some carts And bring away the armour that is there. Gentlemen, will you go muster men?
trg: If I know how or which way to order these affairs Thus thrust disorderly into my hands, Never believe me. Both are my kinsmen: The one is my sovereign, whom both my oath And duty bids defend;

src: O, who can hold a fire in his hand By thinking on the frosty Caucasus? Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite By bare imagination of a feast?
trg: Or wallow naked in December snow By thinking on fantastic summer's heat? O, no! the apprehension of the good Gives but the greater feeling to the worse:

src: Go, then my mother, to thy daughter go Make bold her bashful years with your experience; Prepare her ears to hear a wooer's tale Put in her tender heart the aspiring flame Of golden sovereignty;
trg: To whom I will retail my conquest won, And she shall be sole victress, Caesar's Caesar.

src: I hope so, sir; for I have about me many parcels of charge.
trg: What hast here? ballads?

src: Even so, or with much more contempt, men's eyes Did scowl on gentle Richard; no man cried 'God save him!' No joyful tongue gave him his welcome home: But dust was thrown upon his sacred head:
trg: But heaven hath a hand in these events, To whose high will we bound our calm contents. To Bolingbroke are we sworn subjects now, Whose state and honour I for aye allow.

src: Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days; Compare dead happiness with living woe; Think that thy babes were fairer than they were, And he that slew them fouler than he is:
trg: Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse: Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.

src: but I, with blowing the fire, shall warm myself; for, considering the weather, a taller man than I will take cold. Holla, ho! Curtis.
trg: Who is that calls so coldly?

src: What you can make her do, I am content to look on: what to speak, I am content to hear; for 'tis as easy To make her speak as move.
trg: It is required You do awake your faith. Then all stand still; On: those that think it is unlawful business I am about, let them depart.

src: We have been down together in my sleep, Unbuckling helms, fisting each other's throat, And waked half dead with nothing. O, come, go in, And take our friendly senators by the hands;
trg: Who now are here, taking their leaves of me, Who am prepared against your territories, Though not for Rome itself.

src: Alas, poor duke! the task he undertakes Is numbering sands and drinking oceans dry: Where one on his side fights, thousands will fly. Farewell at once, for once, for all, and ever.
trg: Well, we may meet again.

src: O, hear me breathe my life Before this ancient sir, who, it should seem, Hath sometime loved!
trg: I take thy hand, this hand, As soft as dove's down and as white as it, Or Ethiopian's tooth, or the fann'd snow that's bolted By the northern blasts twice o'er.

src: I have too few to take my leave of you, When the tongue's office should be prodigal To breathe the abundant dolour of the heart.
trg: Thy grief is but thy absence for a time.

src: And these external manners of laments Are merely shadows to the unseen grief That swells with silence in the tortured soul; There lies the substance:
trg: and I thank thee, king, For thy great bounty, that not only givest Me cause to wail but teachest me the way How to lament the cause. I'll beg one boon, And then be gone and trouble you no more.

src: March on, my fellows: Make good this ostentation, and you shall Divide in all with us.
trg: So, let the ports be guarded: keep your duties, As I have set them down. If I do send, dispatch Those centuries to our aid: the rest will serve For a short holding:

src: It is required You do awake your faith. Then all stand still; On: those that think it is unlawful business I am about, let them depart.
trg: Proceed: No foot shall stir.

src: Well said, Hermione.
trg: To tell, he longs to see his son, were strong: But let him say so then, and let him go; But let him swear so, and he shall not stay, We'll thwack him hence with distaffs.

src: Northumberland, thou ladder wherewithal The mounting Bolingbroke ascends my throne, The time shall not be many hours of age More than it is ere foul sin gathering head Shalt break into corruption:
trg: thou shalt think, Though he divide the realm and give thee half, It is too little, helping him to all;

src: Give me thy hand. Thus high, by thy advice And thy assistance, is King Richard seated; But shall we wear these honours for a day? Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?
trg: Still live they and for ever may they last!

src: Faith, sir, if you had told as many lies in his behalf as you have uttered words in your own, you should not pass here; no, though it were as virtuous to lie as to live chastely. Therefore, go back.
trg: Prithee, fellow, remember my name is Menenius, always factionary on the party of your general.

src: Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak; And speak I will; I am no child, no babe: Your betters have endured me say my mind, And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.
trg: My tongue will tell the anger of my heart, Or else my heart concealing it will break, And rather than it shall, I will be free Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.

src: So long as heaven and nature lengthens it.
trg: So long as hell and Richard likes of it.

src: Only fair speech.
trg: I think 'twill serve, if he Can thereto frame his spirit.

src: ' puts him off, slights him, with 'Whoop, do me no harm, good man.'
trg: This is a brave fellow.

src: Yet, were there but this single plot to lose, This mould of Marcius, they to dust should grind it And throw't against the wind. To the market-place!
trg: You have put me now to such a part which never I shall discharge to the life.

src: He hath songs for man or woman, of all sizes; no milliner can so fit his customers with gloves: he has the prettiest love-songs for maids; so without bawdry, which is strange;
trg: with such delicate burthens of dildos and fadings, 'jump her and thump her;

src: Lucentio shall make one, Though Paris came in hope to speed alone.
trg: What! this gentleman will out-talk us all.

src: that away, Men are but gilded loam or painted clay. A jewel in a ten-times-barr'd-up chest Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast. Mine honour is my life; both grow in one:
trg: Take honour from me, and my life is done: Then, dear my liege, mine honour let me try; In that I live and for that will I die.

src: Why have you not proclaim'd Northumberland And all the rest revolted faction traitors?
trg: We have: whereupon the Earl of Worcester Hath broke his staff, resign'd his stewardship, And all the household servants fled with him To Bolingbroke.

src: I bless the time When my good falcon made her flight across Thy father's ground.
trg: Now Jove afford you cause! To me the difference forges dread; your greatness Hath not been used to fear. Even now I tremble To think your father, by some accident, Should pass this way as you did:

src: Since what I am to say must be but that Which contradicts my accusation and The testimony on my part no other But what comes from myself, it shall scarce boot me To say 'not guilty:
trg: ' mine integrity Being counted falsehood, shall, as I express it, Be so received. But thus:

src: Draw near, ye people.
trg: List to your tribunes. Audience: peace, I say!
O cheerful colours! see where Oxford comes!

src: and having now provided A gentleman of noble parentage, Of fair demesnes, youthful, and nobly train'd, Stuff'd, as they say, with honourable parts, Proportion'd as one's thought would wish a man;
trg: And then to have a wretched puling fool, A whining mammet, in her fortune's tender, To answer 'I'll not wed; I cannot love, I am too young; I pray you, pardon me.

src: Chaplain, away! thy priesthood saves thy life. As for the brat of this accursed duke, Whose father slew my father, he shall die.
trg: And I, my lord, will bear him company.

src: But one, poor one, one poor and loving child, But one thing to rejoice and solace in, And cruel death hath catch'd it from my sight!
trg: O woe! O woful, woful, woful day! Most lamentable day, most woful day, That ever, ever, I did yet behold! O day! O day! O day! O hateful day! Never was seen so black a day as this:

src: Shall we thither and with our company piece the rejoicing?
trg: Who would be thence that has the benefit of access? every wink of an eye some new grace will be born: our absence makes us unthrifty to our knowledge. Let's along.

src: Then, executioner, unsheathe thy sword: By him that made us all, I am resolved that Clifford's manhood lies upon his tongue.
trg: Say, Henry, shall I have my right, or no? A thousand men have broke their fasts to-day, That ne'er shall dine unless thou yield the crown.

src: My lord the king, the king!
trg: What is the business?

src: Lay her a-hold, a-hold! set her two courses off to sea again; lay her off.
trg: All lost! to prayers, to prayers! all lost!

src: Here pitch our tents, even here in Bosworth field. My Lord of Surrey, why look you so sad?
trg: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.

src: and till we call'd Both field and city ours, he never stood To ease his breast with panting.
trg: Worthy man!

src: Give me my boots, I say.
trg: Why, York, what wilt thou do? Wilt thou not hide the trespass of thine own? Have we more sons? or are we like to have? Is not my teeming date drunk up with time?

src: Read the indictment.
If so, then be not tongue-tied: go with me. And in the breath of bitter words let's smother My damned son, which thy two sweet sons smother'd. I hear his drum: be copious in exclaims.
trg: Who intercepts my expedition?

src: one girth six time pieced and a woman's crupper of velure, which hath two letters for her name fairly set down in studs, and here and there pieced with packthread.
trg: Who comes with him?

src: but my fair name, Despite of death that lives upon my grave, To dark dishonour's use thou shalt not have.
trg: I am disgraced, impeach'd and baffled here, Pierced to the soul with slander's venom'd spear, The which no balm can cure but his heart-blood Which breathed this poison.

src: He consul!
trg: No, no, no, no, no.

src: To do them good, I would sustain some harm.
trg: Then get your husband's lands, to do them good.

src: I speak not this as doubting any here For did I but suspect a fearful man He should have leave to go away betimes, Lest in our need he might infect another And make him of like spirit to himself.
trg: If any such be here--as God forbid!-- Let him depart before we need his help.

src: Hast thou, spirit, Perform'd to point the tempest that I bade thee?
trg: To every article. I boarded the king's ship; now on the beak, Now in the waist, the deck, in every cabin, I flamed amazement: sometime I'ld divide, And burn in many places;

src: Lord mayor, the reason we have sent--
trg: Look back, defend thee, here are enemies.

src: Yes, Caliban her son.
trg: Dull thing, I say so; he, that Caliban Whom now I keep in service. Thou best know'st What torment I did find thee in; thy groans Did make wolves howl and penetrate the breasts Of ever angry bears:

src: What! threat you me with telling of the king? Tell him, and spare not: look, what I have said I will avouch in presence of the king: I dare adventure to be sent to the Tower. 'Tis time to speak;
trg: my pains are quite forgot.

src: Where is he, hear you?
trg: Nay, I hear nothing: his mother and his wife Hear nothing from him.

src: therefore follow me, and I direct you how you shall go by him.
trg: Content, content.

src: A gentler judgment vanish'd from his lips, Not body's death, but body's banishment.
trg: Ha, banishment! be merciful, say 'death;' For exile hath more terror in his look, Much more than death: do not say 'banishment.'

src: Welcome, good Clarence; this is brotherlike.
trg: O passing traitor, perjured and unjust!

src: O, good! convey? conveyers are you all, That rise thus nimbly by a true king's fall.
trg: On Wednesday next we solemnly set down Our coronation: lords, prepare yourselves.

src: Be thou a prey unto the house of York, And die in bands for this unmanly deed!
trg: In dreadful war mayst thou be overcome, Or live in peace abandon'd and despised!

src: Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone. Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way? Welcome! one mess is like to be your cheer: Come, sir; we will better it in Pisa.
trg: I follow you.

src: For I am he am born to tame you Kate, And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate Conformable as other household Kates. Here comes your father: never make denial;
trg: I must and will have Katharina to my wife.

src: Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says He used us scornfully: he should have show'd us His marks of merit, wounds received for's country.
trg: Why, so he did, I am sure.

src: My lord!
trg: 'Zounds! who is there?

src: She will not.
trg: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

src: the king unto the queen; Lord George your brother, Norfolk and myself, In haste, post-haste, are come to join with you: For in the marches here we heard you were, Making another head to fight again.
trg: Where is the Duke of Norfolk, gentle Warwick? And when came George from Burgundy to England?

src: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace, And offer me disguised in sober robes To old Baptista as a schoolmaster Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca;
trg: That so I may, by this device, at least Have leave and leisure to make love to her And unsuspected court her by herself.

src: I cannot stay to hear these articles.
trg: Nor I.

src: How long shall I be patient? ah, how long Shall tender duty make me suffer wrong? I am the last of noble Edward's sons, Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, was first:
trg: In war was never lion raged more fierce, In peace was never gentle lamb more mild, Than was that young and princely gentleman.

src: Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.
trg: Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune! Why strew'st thou sugar on that bottled spider, Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about? Fool, fool! thou whet'st a knife to kill thyself.

src: Yes, madam: yet I cannot choose but laugh, To think it should leave crying and say 'Ay.' And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow A bump as big as a young cockerel's stone; A parlous knock;
trg: and it cried bitterly: 'Yea,' quoth my husband,'fall'st upon thy face? Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age; Wilt thou not, Jule?' it stinted and said 'Ay.'

src: For I cannot be Mine own, nor any thing to any, if I be not thine. To this I am most constant, Though destiny say no. Be merry, gentle;
trg: Strangle such thoughts as these with any thing That you behold the while. Your guests are coming:

src: I know't too well. Give me the boy: I am glad you did not nurse him: Though he does bear some signs of me, yet you Have too much blood in him.
trg: What is this? sport?

src: I wish you now, then; Pray you, take note of it: and when you have A business for yourself, pray heaven you then Be perfect.
trg: I warrant your honour.

src: that thou mayst prove To shame unvulnerable, and stick i' the wars Like a great sea-mark, standing every flaw, And saving those that eye thee!
trg: Your knee, sirrah.

src: therefore pardon me, And not impute this yielding to light love, Which the dark night hath so discovered.
trg: Lady, by yonder blessed moon I swear That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops--

src: And I, as I love Hastings with my heart!
trg: Madam, yourself are not exempt in this, Nor your son Dorset, Buckingham, nor you; You have been factious one against the other, Wife, love Lord Hastings, let him kiss your hand;

src: Exeter, thou art a traitor to the crown In following this usurping Henry.
trg: Whom should he follow but his natural king?

src: Exeter, so will I.
trg: Nay, go not from me; I will follow thee.

src: I'll swear for 'em.
trg: This is the prettiest low-born lass that ever Ran on the green-sward: nothing she does or seems But smacks of something greater than herself, Too noble for this place.

src: between which time of the contract and limit of the solemnity, her brother Frederick was wrecked at sea, having in that perished vessel the dowry of his sister.
trg: But mark how heavily this befell to the poor gentlewoman: there she lost a noble and renowned brother, in his love toward her ever most kind and natural;

src: The sorrow that I have, by right is yours, And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.
trg: And God, not we, hath plagued thy bloody deed.

src: Bad news, by'r lady; seldom comes the better: I fear, I fear 'twill prove a troublous world.
trg: Neighbours, God speed!

src: His princess, say you, with him?
trg: Ay, the most peerless piece of earth, I think, That e'er the sun shone bright on.

src: Where is my mother! why, she is within; Where should she be? How oddly thou repliest! 'Your love says, like an honest gentleman, Where is your mother?'
trg: O God's lady dear! Are you so hot? marry, come up, I trow; Is this the poultice for my aching bones? Henceforward do your messages yourself.

src: The gods be good to us! Come, masters, let's home. I ever said we were i' the wrong when we banished him.
trg: So did we all. But, come, let's home.

src: say to thyself, From their abominable and beastly touches I drink, I eat, array myself, and live. Canst thou believe thy living is a life, So stinkingly depending? Go mend, go mend.
trg: Indeed, it does stink in some sort, sir; but yet, sir, I would prove--

src: How now, noble Pompey! What, at the wheels of Caesar? art thou led in triumph?
trg: What, is there none of Pygmalion's images, newly made woman, to be had now, for putting the hand in the pocket and extracting it clutch'd? What reply, ha?

src: This is a happier and more comely time Than when these fellows ran about the streets, Crying confusion.
trg: Caius Marcius was A worthy officer i' the war; but insolent, O'ercome with pride, ambitious past all thinking, Self-loving,--

src: Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper, Thy head, thy sovereign; And craves no other tribute at thy hands But love, fair looks and true obedience; Too little payment for so great a debt.
trg: Such duty as the subject owes the prince Even such a woman oweth to her husband;

src: Plantagenet! I come, Plantagenet! And this thy son's blood cleaving to my blade Shall rust upon my weapon, till thy blood, Congeal'd with this, do make me wipe off both. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: The army of the queen hath got the field: My uncles both are slain in rescuing me;

src: If you can, pace your wisdom In that good path that I would wish it go, And you shall have your bosom on this wretch, Grace of the duke, revenges to your heart, And general honour.
trg: I am directed by you.

src: Alas, it hath been great pains to you. They do you wrong to put you so oft upon 't: are there not men in your ward sufficient to serve it?
trg: Faith, sir, few of any wit in such matters: as they are chosen, they are glad to choose me for them; I do it for some piece of money, and go through with all.

src: I go; and if you plead as well for them As I can say nay to thee for myself, No doubt well bring it to a happy issue.
trg: Go, go, up to the leads; the lord mayor knocks. Welcome my lord; I dance attendance here; I think the duke will not be spoke withal. Here comes his servant: how now, Catesby, What says he?

src: At my request he would not. Hermione, my dearest, thou never spokest To better purpose.
trg: Never?

src: We are not, sir, nor are we like to be; The stars, I see, will kiss the valleys first: The odds for high and low's alike.
trg: My lord, Is this the daughter of a king?

src: I cannot blame her: by God's holy mother, She hath had too much wrong; and I repent My part thereof that I have done to her.
trg: I never did her any, to my knowledge.

src: What, with five thousand men?
trg: Ay, with five hundred, father, for a need: A woman's general; what should we fear?

src: Whither?
trg: O, whither?

src: I am disgraced, impeach'd and baffled here, Pierced to the soul with slander's venom'd spear, The which no balm can cure but his heart-blood Which breathed this poison.
trg: Rage must be withstood: Give me his gage: lions make leopards tame.

src: What, resists he? Help him, Lucio.
trg: Come, sir; come, sir; come, sir; foh, sir! Why, you bald-pated, lying rascal, you must be hooded, must you? Show your knave's visage, with a pox to you!

src: There have been, Or I am much deceived, cuckolds ere now; nay, there's comfort in't Whiles other men have gates and those gates open'd, As mine, against their will.
trg: Should all despair That have revolted wives, the tenth of mankind Would hang themselves. Physic for't there is none; It is a bawdy planet, that will strike Where 'tis predominant;

src: My love till death, my humble thanks, my prayers; That love which virtue begs and virtue grants.
trg: No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.

src: thou wilt, if Warwick call.
trg: Father of Warwick, know you what this means? Look here, I throw my infamy at thee I will not ruinate my father's house, Who gave his blood to lime the stones together, And set up Lancaster.

src: O how that name befits my composition! Old Gaunt indeed, and gaunt in being old: Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast; And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt?
trg: For sleeping England long time have I watch'd; Watching breeds leanness, leanness is all gaunt: The pleasure that some fathers feed upon, Is my strict fast; I mean, my children's looks;

src: What, must our mouths be cold?
trg: The king and prince at prayers! let's assist them, For our case is as theirs.

src: There's nothing ill can dwell in such a temple: If the ill spirit have so fair a house, Good things will strive to dwell with't.
trg: Follow me. Speak not you for him; he's a traitor. Come; I'll manacle thy neck and feet together: Sea-water shalt thou drink;

src: if there be any of him left, I'll bury it.
trg: That's a good deed. If thou mayest discern by that which is left of him what he is, fetch me to the sight of him.

src: It's supper-time, my lord; It's nine o'clock.
trg: I will not sup to-night. Give me some ink and paper. What, is my beaver easier than it was? And all my armour laid into my tent?

src: But did you not request to have it cut?
trg: Thou hast faced many things.

src: 'Twill make me think the world is full of rubs, And that my fortune rubs against the bias.
trg: Madam, we'll dance.

src: Should I do so, I should belie my thoughts: Comfort's in heaven; and we are on the earth, Where nothing lives but crosses, cares and grief.
trg: Your husband, he is gone to save far off, Whilst others come to make him lose at home: Here am I left to underprop his land, Who, weak with age, cannot support myself:

src: Who made thee, then, a bloody minister, When gallant-springing brave Plantagenet, That princely novice, was struck dead by thee?
trg: My brother's love, the devil, and my rage.

src: But passion lends them power, time means, to meet Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.
trg: Can I go forward when my heart is here? Turn back, dull earth, and find thy centre out.

src: Sirrah, leave us to ourselves: we must confer.
trg: So flies the reckless shepherd from the wolf; So first the harmless sheep doth yield his fleece And next his throat unto the butcher's knife. What scene of death hath Roscius now to act?

src: By heaven, I'll hate him everlastingly That bids me be of comfort any more. Go to Flint castle: there I'll pine away; A king, woe's slave, shall kingly woe obey. That power I have, discharge;
trg: and let them go To ear the land that hath some hope to grow, For I have none: let no man speak again To alter this, for counsel is but vain.

src: Fie, fie, fie!
trg: I know you well, sir, and you know me: your name, I think, is Adrian.

src: Hold, Richard, hold; for we have done too much.
trg: Why should she live, to fill the world with words?

src: Ay, now begins a second storm to rise; For this is he that moves both wind and tide.
trg: From worthy Edward, King of Albion, My lord and sovereign, and thy vowed friend, I come, in kindness and unfeigned love, First, to do greetings to thy royal person;

src: And so doth mine: I muse why she's at liberty.
trg: I cannot blame her: by God's holy mother, She hath had too much wrong; and I repent My part thereof that I have done to her.

src: A lack, how may I do it, having the hour limited, and an express command, under penalty, to deliver his head in the view of Angelo? I may make my case as Claudio's, to cross this in the smallest.
trg: By the vow of mine order I warrant you, if my instructions may be your guide. Let this Barnardine be this morning executed, and his head born to Angelo.

src: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news, Because they have been still mine enemies:
trg: But, that I'll give my voice on Richard's side, To bar my master's heirs in true descent, God knows I will not do it, to the death.

src: What's the matter, That in these several places of the city You cry against the noble senate, who, Under the gods, keep you in awe, which else Would feed on one another? What's their seeking?
trg: For corn at their own rates; whereof, they say, The city is well stored.

src: Slain, sir, doubtless.
trg: Following the fliers at the very heels, With them he enters; who, upon the sudden, Clapp'd to their gates: he is himself alone, To answer all the city.

src: Will't please your honour taste of these conserves?
trg: What raiment will your honour wear to-day?

src: O that I were a mockery king of snow, Standing before the sun of Bolingbroke, To melt myself away in water-drops!
trg: Go some of you and fetch a looking-glass.

src: Here's goodly gear!
trg: A sail, a sail!

src: Believe me, I speak as my understanding instructs me and as mine honesty puts it to utterance.
trg: Sicilia cannot show himself over-kind to Bohemia. They were trained together in their childhoods; and there rooted betwixt them then such an affection, which cannot choose but branch now.

src: The augurer tells me we shall have news to-night.
trg: Good or bad?

src: at which name I started, Because a bard of Ireland told me once I should not live long after I saw Richmond.
trg: My Lord!

src: Thou seest what's past, go fear thy king withal.
trg: Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly, I'll wear the willow garland for his sake.

src: Inter their bodies as becomes their births: Proclaim a pardon to the soldiers fled That in submission will return to us:
trg: And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament, We will unite the white rose and the red: Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction, That long have frown'd upon their enmity!

src: Nathaniel's coat, sir, was not fully made, And Gabriel's pumps were all unpink'd i' the heel; There was no link to colour Peter's hat, And Walter's dagger was not come from sheathing:
trg: There were none fine but Adam, Ralph, and Gregory; The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly; Yet, as they are, here are they come to meet you.

src: if ever fearful To do a thing, where I the issue doubted, Where of the execution did cry out Against the non-performance, 'twas a fear Which oft infects the wisest:
trg: these, my lord, Are such allow'd infirmities that honesty Is never free of. But, beseech your grace, Be plainer with me; let me know my trespass By its own visage:

src: One raised in blood, and one in blood establish'd; One that made means to come by what he hath, And slaughter'd those that were the means to help him;
trg: Abase foul stone, made precious by the foil Of England's chair, where he is falsely set; One that hath ever been God's enemy:

src: I will be mild and gentle in my speech.
trg: And brief, good mother; for I am in haste.

src: What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse? Or shall we on without a apology?
trg: The date is out of such prolixity: We'll have no Cupid hoodwink'd with a scarf, Bearing a Tartar's painted bow of lath, Scaring the ladies like a crow-keeper;

src: Say, then, my peace is made.
trg: That shall you know hereafter.

src: Where is my lord protector? I have sent for these strawberries.
trg: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth to-day; There's some conceit or other likes him well, When he doth bid good morrow with such a spirit.

src: Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.
trg: Who sets me else? by heaven, I'll throw at all: I have a thousand spirits in one breast, To answer twenty thousand such as you.

src: Father of Warwick, know you what this means? Look here, I throw my infamy at thee I will not ruinate my father's house, Who gave his blood to lime the stones together, And set up Lancaster.
trg: Why, trow'st thou, Warwick, That Clarence is so harsh, so blunt, unnatural, To bend the fatal instruments of war Against his brother and his lawful king? Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath:

src: And yet not so, for with a kiss 'twas made. Part us, Northumberland; I toward the north, Where shivering cold and sickness pines the clime; My wife to France:
trg: from whence, set forth in pomp, She came adorned hither like sweet May, Sent back like Hallowmas or short'st of day.

src: Why, my sweet lord?
trg: You'll kiss me hard and speak to me as if I were a baby still. I love you better.

src: Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat And made our footstool of security. Come hither, Bess, and let me kiss my boy.
trg: Young Ned, for thee, thine uncles and myself Have in our armours watch'd the winter's night, Went all afoot in summer's scalding heat, That thou mightst repossess the crown in peace;

src: marry, she had a better love to be-rhyme her; Dido a dowdy; Cleopatra a gipsy; Helen and Hero hildings and harlots; Thisbe a grey eye or so, but not to the purpose. Signior Romeo, bon jour!
trg: there's a French salutation to your French slop. You gave us the counterfeit fairly last night.

src: Now, mistress, profit you in what you read?
trg: What, master, read you? first resolve me that.

src: Sweetly in force unto her fair life's end.
trg: But how long fairly shall her sweet lie last?

src: Perhaps you have learned it without book: but, I pray, can you read any thing you see?
trg: Ay, if I know the letters and the language.

src: Come, son, away; we may not linger thus.
trg: Poor queen! how love to me and to her son Hath made her break out into terms of rage!

src: Worthy sir, thou bleed'st; Thy exercise hath been too violent for A second course of fight.
trg: Sir, praise me not; My work hath yet not warm'd me: fare you well: The blood I drop is rather physical Than dangerous to me: to Aufidius thus I will appear, and fight.

src: for I have no more doublets than backs, no more stockings than legs, nor no more shoes than feet; nay, sometimes more feet than shoes, or such shoes as my toes look through the over-leather.
trg: Heaven cease this idle humour in your honour! O, that a mighty man of such descent, Of such possessions and so high esteem, Should be infused with so foul a spirit!

src: But here is Carlisle living, to abide Thy kingly doom and sentence of his pride.
trg: Carlisle, this is your doom: Choose out some secret place, some reverend room, More than thou hast, and with it joy thy life; So as thou livest in peace, die free from strife:

src: I did, my lord.
trg: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?

src: Which she shall purchase with still lasting war.
trg: Say that the king, which may command, entreats.

src: No doubt, my lord.
trg: O Ratcliff, I fear, I fear,--

src: do no stain to your own gracious person; and much please the absent duke, if peradventure he shall ever return to have hearing of this business.
trg: Let me hear you speak farther. I have spirit to do anything that appears not foul in the truth of my spirit.

src: I am a-weary, give me leave awhile: Fie, how my bones ache! what a jaunt have I had!
trg: I would thou hadst my bones, and I thy news: Nay, come, I pray thee, speak; good, good nurse, speak.

src: I have great comfort from this fellow: methinks he hath no drowning mark upon him; his complexion is perfect gallows. Stand fast, good Fate, to his hanging:
trg: make the rope of his destiny our cable, for our own doth little advantage. If he be not born to be hanged, our case is miserable.

src: He--to give fear to use and liberty, Which have for long run by the hideous law, As mice by lions--hath pick'd out an act, Under whose heavy sense your brother's life Falls into forfeit:
trg: he arrests him on it; And follows close the rigour of the statute, To make him an example. All hope is gone, Unless you have the grace by your fair prayer To soften Angelo:

src: An't please your honour, players That offer service to your lordship.
trg: Bid them come near. Now, fellows, you are welcome.

src: Yet,--
trg: Yet,--

src: There are pretty orders beginning, I can tell you: it is but heading and hanging.
trg: If you head and hang all that offend that way but for ten year together, you'll be glad to give out a commission for more heads:

src: A pox o' your throat, you bawling, blasphemous, incharitable dog!
trg: Work you then.

src: Either forbear, Quit presently the chapel, or resolve you For more amazement. If you can behold it, I'll make the statue move indeed, descend And take you by the hand;
trg: but then you'll think-- Which I protest against--I am assisted By wicked powers.

src: See, see; what a man you are now! There is no other way but to tell the king she's a changeling and none of your flesh and blood.
trg: Nay, but hear me.

src: I pray you do. I will attend her here, And woo her with some spirit when she comes. Say that she rail; why then I'll tell her plain She sings as sweetly as a nightingale:
trg: Say that she frown, I'll say she looks as clear As morning roses newly wash'd with dew: Say she be mute and will not speak a word;

src: Let me have open means to come to them, And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them.
trg: Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel Go, by this token: rise, and lend thine ear: There is no more but so: say it is done, And I will love thee, and prefer thee too.

src: Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renown'd For hardy and undoubted champions; Two Cliffords, as the father and the son, And two Northumberlands;
trg: two braver men Ne'er spurr'd their coursers at the trumpet's sound;

src: It is in mine authority to command The keys of all the posterns: please your highness To take the urgent hour. Come, sir, away.
trg: Take the boy to you: he so troubles me, 'Tis past enduring.

src: You are a lover; borrow Cupid's wings, And soar with them above a common bound.
trg: I am too sore enpierced with his shaft To soar with his light feathers, and so bound, I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe: Under love's heavy burden do I sink.

src: I will kiss thy lips; Haply some poison yet doth hang on them, To make die with a restorative. Thy lips are warm.
Who have we here? We'll make an instrument of this, omit Nothing may give us aid.
trg: If they have overheard me now, why, hanging.

src: Here, here, sir; here, sir.
trg: Here, sir! here, sir! here, sir! here, sir! You logger-headed and unpolish'd grooms! What, no attendance? no regard? no duty? Where is the foolish knave I sent before?

src: And, for that dowry, I'll assure her of Her widowhood, be it that she survive me, In all my lands and leases whatsoever:
trg: Let specialties be therefore drawn between us, That covenants may be kept on either hand.

src: and well could wish You had not found me here so musical: Let me excuse me, and believe me so, My mirth it much displeased, but pleased my woe.
trg: 'Tis good; though music oft hath such a charm To make bad good, and good provoke to harm. I pray, you, tell me, hath any body inquired for me here to-day?

src: Pray now, no more: my mother, Who has a charter to extol her blood, When she does praise me grieves me. I have done As you have done; that's what I can; induced As you have been;
trg: that's for my country: He that has but effected his good will Hath overta'en mine act.

src: but I am sent to find those persons whose names are here writ, and can never find what names the writing person hath here writ. I must to the learned.--In good time.
trg: Tut, man, one fire burns out another's burning, One pain is lessen'd by another's anguish; Turn giddy, and be holp by backward turning; One desperate grief cures with another's languish:

src: Say, what's thy name? Thou hast a grim appearance, and thy face Bears a command in't; though thy tackle's torn. Thou show'st a noble vessel: what's thy name?
trg: Prepare thy brow to frown: know'st thou me yet?

src: but the wisest beholder, that knew no more but seeing, could not say if the importance were joy or sorrow; but in the extremity of the one, it must needs be.
trg: Here comes a gentleman that haply knows more. The news, Rogero?

src: Good even to my ghostly confessor.
trg: Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.

src: Ay, that the king is dead.
trg: Bad news, by'r lady; seldom comes the better: I fear, I fear 'twill prove a troublous world.

src: Who shall hinder me? I will despair, and be at enmity With cozening hope:
trg: he is a flatterer, A parasite, a keeper back of death, Who gently would dissolve the bands of life, Which false hope lingers in extremity.

src: Marry, that with no man here he is offended; For, were he, he had shown it in his looks.
trg: I pray God he be not, I say.

src: At thy good heart's oppression.
trg: Why, such is love's transgression. Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast, Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest With more of thine:

src: What's that, I pray?
trg: Marry, sir, to get a husband for her sister.

src: 'Tis now dead midnight, and by eight to-morrow Thou must be made immortal. Where's Barnardine?
trg: As fast lock'd up in sleep as guiltless labour When it lies starkly in the traveller's bones: He will not wake.

src: Forslow no longer, make we hence amain. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Now, Clifford, I have singled thee alone: Suppose this arm is for the Duke of York, And this for Rutland; both bound to revenge, Wert thou environ'd with a brazen wall.

src: O, that must be I' the virtue of your daughter: one being dead, I shall have more than you can dream of yet; Enough then for your wonder. But, come on, Contract us 'fore these witnesses.
trg: Come, your hand; And, daughter, yours.

src: None that I more love than myself. You are a counsellor; if you can command these elements to silence, and work the peace of the present, we will not hand a rope more; use your authority:
trg: if you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long, and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap. Cheerly, good hearts! Out of our way, I say.

src: we say the king Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous;
trg: We say that Shore's wife hath a pretty foot, A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue; And that the queen's kindred are made gentle-folks: How say you sir? Can you deny all this?

src: I'll not believe but they ascend the sky, And there awake God's gentle-sleeping peace. O Buckingham, take heed of yonder dog! Look, when he fawns, he bites;
trg: and when he bites, His venom tooth will rankle to the death: Have not to do with him, beware of him; Sin, death, and hell have set their marks on him, And all their ministers attend on him.

src: ' If he be slain, say 'I'; or if not, no: Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe.
trg: I saw the wound, I saw it with mine eyes,-- God save the mark!--here on his manly breast: A piteous corse, a bloody piteous corse; Pale, pale as ashes, all bedaub'd in blood, All in gore-blood;

src: If thou more murmur'st, I will rend an oak And peg thee in his knotty entrails till Thou hast howl'd away twelve winters.
trg: Pardon, master; I will be correspondent to command And do my spiriting gently.

src: What, what, what! I shall be loved when I am lack'd. Nay, mother.
trg: Resume that spirit, when you were wont to say, If you had been the wife of Hercules, Six of his labours you'ld have done, and saved Your husband so much sweat. Cominius, Droop not; adieu.

src: Then whither he goes, thither let me go.
trg: So two, together weeping, make one woe. Weep thou for me in France, I for thee here; Better far off than near, be ne'er the near. Go, count thy way with sighs; I mine with groans.

src: I think, or in any religion.
trg: Ay, why not? Grace is grace, despite of all controversy: as, for example, thou thyself art a wicked villain, despite of all grace.

src: I know they do; and I have well deserved it. Come on, come on; where is your boar-spear, man? Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?
trg: My lord, good morrow; good morrow, Catesby: You may jest on, but, by the holy rood, I do not like these several councils, I.

src: then he compassed a motion of the Prodigal Son, and married a tinker's wife within a mile where my land and living lies; and, having flown over many knavish professions, he settled only in rogue:
trg: some call him Autolycus.

src: It is for you we speak, not for ourselves: You are abused and by some putter-on That will be damn'd for't; would I knew the villain, I would land-damn him.
trg: Be she honour-flaw'd, I have three daughters; the eldest is eleven The second and the third, nine, and some five; If this prove true, they'll pay for't: by mine honour, I'll geld 'em all;

src: Speak like a subject, proud ambitious York! Suppose that I am now my father's mouth;
trg: Resign thy chair, and where I stand kneel thou, Whilst I propose the selfsame words to thee, Which traitor, thou wouldst have me answer to.

src: She eat no meat to-day, nor none shall eat; Last night she slept not, nor to-night she shall not; As with the meat, some undeserved fault I'll find about the making of the bed;
trg: And here I'll fling the pillow, there the bolster, This way the coverlet, another way the sheets: Ay, and amid this hurly I intend That all is done in reverend care of her;

src: Seize on the shame-faced Henry, bear him hence; And once again proclaim us King of England. You are the fount that makes small brooks to flow: Now stops thy spring;
trg: my sea sha$l suck them dry, And swell so much the higher by their ebb. Hence with him to the Tower; let him not speak.

src: And thou unfit for any place but hell.
trg: Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.

src: Be brief, lest that be process of thy kindness Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.
trg: Then know, that from my soul I love thy daughter.

src: Come, lay aside your stitchery; I must have you play the idle husewife with me this afternoon.
trg: No, good madam; I will not out of doors.

src: And, madam, I must be present at your conference.
trg: Well, be't so, prithee. Here's such ado to make no stain a stain As passes colouring. Dear gentlewoman, How fares our gracious lady?

src: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.
trg: O no, my reasons are too deep and dead; Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their grave.

src: Look, how this ring encompasseth finger. Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart; Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.
trg: And if thy poor devoted suppliant may But beg one favour at thy gracious hand, Thou dost confirm his happiness for ever.

src: Good morrow, neighbour Baptista.
trg: Good morrow, neighbour Gremio. God save you, gentlemen!

src: King Henry and the prince his son are gone: Clarence, thy turn is next, and then the rest, Counting myself but bad till I be best.
trg: I'll throw thy body in another room And triumph, Henry, in thy day of doom. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: I will about it straight; No longer staying but to give the mother Notice of my affair. I humbly thank you: Commend me to my brother: soon at night I'll send him certain word of my success.
trg: I take my leave of you.

src: Teach her the way. O heavens! Why does my blood thus muster to my heart, Making both it unable for itself, And dispossessing all my other parts Of necessary fitness?
trg: So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons; Come all to help him, and so stop the air By which he should revive:

src: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.
trg: Welcome home, Grumio!

src: They do me wrong, and I will not endure it: Who are they that complain unto the king, That I, forsooth, am stern, and love them not?
trg: By holy Paul, they love his grace but lightly That fill his ears with such dissentious rumours.

src: How? the best? What wert thou, if the King of Naples heard thee?
trg: A single thing, as I am now, that wonders To hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me; And that he does I weep:

src: What, in the midst of the street?
trg: What, art thou ashamed of me?

src: They that stabb'd Caesar shed no blood at all, Did not offend, nor were not worthy blame, If this foul deed were by to equal it: He was a man; this, in respect, a child:
trg: And men ne'er spend their fury on a child. What's worse than murderer, that I may name it? No, no, my heart will burst, and if I speak: And I will speak, that so my heart may burst.

src: Why, here's a change indeed in the commonwealth! What shall become of me?
trg: Come; fear you not: good counsellors lack no clients: though you change your place, you need not change your trade; I'll be your tapster still. Courage! there will be pity taken on you:

src: He has a son, who shall be flayed alive; then 'nointed over with honey, set on the head of a wasp's nest; then stand till he be three quarters and a dram dead;
trg: then recovered again with aqua-vitae or some other hot infusion; But what talk we of these traitorly rascals, whose miseries are to be smiled at, their offences being so capital?

src: Yes. Has he affections in him, That thus can make him bite the law by the nose, When he would force it? Sure, it is no sin, Or of the deadly seven, it is the least.
trg: Which is the least?

src: What makes this change?
trg: The matter?

src: Rumour it abroad That Anne, my wife, is sick and like to die: I will take order for her keeping close. Inquire me out some mean-born gentleman, Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter:
trg: The boy is foolish, and I fear not him. Look, how thou dream'st! I say again, give out That Anne my wife is sick and like to die: About it;

src: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.
trg: Well, in that hit you miss: she'll not be hit With Cupid's arrow; she hath Dian's wit; And, in strong proof of chastity well arm'd, From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.

src: Say, Henry, shall I have my right, or no? A thousand men have broke their fasts to-day, That ne'er shall dine unless thou yield the crown.
trg: If thou deny, their blood upon thy head; For York in justice puts his armour on.

src: It is your husband mock'd you with a husband. Consenting to the safeguard of your honour, I thought your marriage fit;
trg: else imputation, For that he knew you, might reproach your life And choke your good to come;

src: now the ship boring the moon with her main-mast, and anon swallowed with yest and froth, as you'ld thrust a cork into a hogshead.
trg: And then for the land-service, to see how the bear tore out his shoulder-bone; how he cried to me for help and said his name was Antigonus, a nobleman.

src: Let this be done. Put them in secret holds, both Barnardine and Claudio: Ere twice the sun hath made his journal greeting To the under generation, you shall find Your safety manifested.
trg: I am your free dependant.

src: How would you be, If He, which is the top of judgment, should But judge you as you are? O, think on that; And mercy then will breathe within your lips, Like man new made.
trg: Be you content, fair maid; It is the law, not I condemn your brother: Were he my kinsman, brother, or my son, It should be thus with him: he must die tomorrow.

src: Yet, Derby, notwithstanding she's your wife, And loves not me, be you, good lord, assured I hate not you for her proud arrogance.
trg: I do beseech you, either not believe The envious slanders of her false accusers;

src: Brother, though I be youngest, give me leave.
trg: No, I can better play the orator.

src: Are you content to stay?
trg: I am content you shall entreat me stay; But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.

src: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.
trg: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads?

src: By heaven, I think there's no man is secure But the queen's kindred and night-walking heralds That trudge betwixt the king and Mistress Shore.
trg: Heard ye not what an humble suppliant Lord hastings was to her for his delivery?

src: Sirrah, come hither: 'tis no time to jest, And therefore frame your manners to the time.
trg: Your fellow Tranio here, to save my life, Puts my apparel and my countenance on, And I for my escape have put on his; For in a quarrel since I came ashore I kill'd a man and fear I was descried:

src: True! pow, wow.
trg: True! I'll be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded? God save your good worships! Marcius is coming home: he has more cause to be proud. Where is he wounded?

src: My father Capulet will have it so; And I am nothing slow to slack his haste.
trg: You say you do not know the lady's mind: Uneven is the course, I like it not.

src: This liberty is all that I request, That, upon knowledge of my parentage, I may have welcome 'mongst the rest that woo And free access and favour as the rest:
trg: And, toward the education of your daughters, I here bestow a simple instrument, And this small packet of Greek and Latin books: If you accept them, then their worth is great.

src: What? I say, My foot my tutor? Put thy sword up, traitor; Who makest a show but darest not strike, thy conscience Is so possess'd with guilt:
trg: come from thy ward, For I can here disarm thee with this stick And make thy weapon drop.

src: thou keep'st me from the light: But I will sort a pitchy day for thee; For I will buz abroad such prophecies That Edward shall be fearful of his life, And then, to purge his fear, I'll be thy death.
trg: King Henry and the prince his son are gone: Clarence, thy turn is next, and then the rest, Counting myself but bad till I be best.

src: And when the king comes, offer no violence, Unless he seek to thrust you out perforce.
trg: The queen this day here holds her parliament, But little thinks we shall be of her council: By words or blows here let us win our right.

src: You kiss by the book.
trg: Madam, your mother craves a word with you.

src: Gardener, for telling me these news of woe, Pray God the plants thou graft'st may never grow.
trg: Poor queen! so that thy state might be no worse, I would my skill were subject to thy curse. Here did she fall a tear; here in this place I'll set a bank of rue, sour herb of grace:

src: The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'd The shadow or your face.
trg: Say that again. The shadow of my sorrow! ha! let's see: 'Tis very true, my grief lies all within;

src: Poor queen! so that thy state might be no worse, I would my skill were subject to thy curse. Here did she fall a tear; here in this place I'll set a bank of rue, sour herb of grace:
trg: Rue, even for ruth, here shortly shall be seen, In the remembrance of a weeping queen.

src: Was it not she and that good man of worship, Anthony Woodville, her brother there, That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower, From whence this present day he is deliver'd?
trg: We are not safe, Clarence; we are not safe.

src: The king hath on him such a countenance As he had lost some province and a region Loved as he loves himself: even now I met him With customary compliment;
trg: when he, Wafting his eyes to the contrary and falling A lip of much contempt, speeds from me and So leaves me to consider what is breeding That changeth thus his manners.

src: But say, my lord, it were not register'd, Methinks the truth should live from age to age, As 'twere retail'd to all posterity, Even to the general all-ending day.
Were half to half the world by the ears and he. Upon my party, I'ld revolt to make Only my wars with him: he is a lion That I am proud to hunt.
trg: Then, worthy Marcius, Attend upon Cominius to these wars.

src: Was this the face that faced so many follies, And was at last out-faced by Bolingbroke? A brittle glory shineth in this face: As brittle as the glory is the face;
trg: For there it is, crack'd in a hundred shivers. Mark, silent king, the moral of this sport, How soon my sorrow hath destroy'd my face.

src: I have already.
trg: Tush, that was in thy rage: Speak it again, and, even with the word, That hand, which, for thy love, did kill thy love, Shall, for thy love, kill a far truer love;

src: My lord, cheer up your spirits: our foes are nigh, And this soft courage makes your followers faint. You promised knighthood to our forward son: Unsheathe your sword, and dub him presently.
trg: Edward, kneel down.

src: All's well; and might have been much better, if He could have temporized.
trg: Where is he, hear you?

src: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.
trg: Away with the dotard! to the gaol with him!

src: Ah, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline. Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.
trg: Tybalt, the kinsman of old Capulet, Hath sent a letter to his father's house.

src: You said so much before, and yet you fled.
trg: 'Twas not your valour, Clifford, drove me thence.

src: Who for Bohemia bend, to signify Not only my success in Libya, sir, But my arrival and my wife's in safety Here where we are.
trg: The blessed gods Purge all infection from our air whilst you Do climate here! You have a holy father, A graceful gentleman; against whose person, So sacred as it is, I have done sin:

src: Mount you, my lord; towards Berwick post amain:
trg: Edward and Richard, like a brace of greyhounds Having the fearful flying hare in sight, With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath, And bloody steel grasp'd in their ireful hands, Are at our backs;

src: Not my deserts, but what I will deserve: Urge the necessity and state of times, And be not peevish-fond in great designs.
trg: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?

src: And thou usurp'st my father's right and mine.
trg: Take that, thou likeness of this railer here.

src: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies,
trg: Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting? In his tail.

src: If you see this in the map of my microcosm, follows it that I am known well enough too? what barm can your bisson conspectuities glean out of this character, if I be known well enough too?
trg: Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.

src: ' There, take the crown, and, with the crown, my curse; And in thy need such comfort come to thee As now I reap at thy too cruel hand! Hard-hearted Clifford, take me from the world:
trg: My soul to heaven, my blood upon your heads!

src: So that my speed to Mantua there was stay'd.
trg: Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?

src: one Lucio As then the messenger,--
trg: That's I, an't like your grace: I came to her from Claudio, and desired her To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo For her poor brother's pardon.

src: Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail, Ties up my tongue, and will not let me speak.
trg: Come, is the bride ready to go to church?

src: Nay then, I will not: you shall have the mustard, Or else you get no beef of Grumio.
trg: Then both, or one, or any thing thou wilt.

src: Beseech you, give me leave to retire myself.
trg: Indeed, you shall not. Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum, See him pluck Aufidius down by the hair, As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him:

src: Well, he is gone; and with him go these thoughts.
trg: Now for the rebels which stand out in Ireland, Expedient manage must be made, my liege, Ere further leisure yield them further means For their advantage and your highness' loss.

src: Reproach and dissolution hangeth over him.
trg: He hath not money for these Irish wars, His burthenous taxations notwithstanding, But by the robbing of the banish'd duke.

src: Might you dispense with your leisure, I would by and by have some speech with you: the satisfaction I would require is likewise your own benefit.
trg: I have no superfluous leisure; my stay must be stolen out of other affairs; but I will attend you awhile.

src: Not a soul But felt a fever of the mad and play'd Some tricks of desperation. All but mariners Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel, Then all afire with me:
trg: the king's son, Ferdinand, With hair up-staring,--then like reeds, not hair,-- Was the first man that leap'd; cried, 'Hell is empty And all the devils are here.'

src: Say then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?
trg: Even he that makes her queen who should be else?

src: Why?
trg: They say she's mad.

src: O, they are at it!
trg: Their noise be our instruction. Ladders, ho!

src: Pray, sir, in what?
trg: In the delaying death.

src: Ay, and for an assault too.
trg: O slaves, I can tell you news,-- news, you rascals!

src: who has not only his innocence, which seems much, to justify him, but a handkerchief and rings of his that Paulina knows.
trg: What became of his bark and his followers?

src: The weeds which his broad-spreading leaves did shelter, That seem'd in eating him to hold him up, Are pluck'd up root and all by Bolingbroke, I mean the Earl of Wiltshire, Bushy, Green.
trg: What, are they dead?

src: Why, what a ruthless thing is this in him, for the rebellion of a codpiece to take away the life of a man! Would the duke that is absent have done this?
trg: Ere he would have hanged a man for the getting a hundred bastards, he would have paid for the nursing a thousand: he had some feeling of the sport:

src: The duke! Why, Warwick, when we parted, Thou call'dst me king.
trg: Ay, but the case is alter'd: When you disgraced me in my embassade, Then I degraded you from being king, And come now to create you Duke of York. Alas!

src: Then is my sovereign slain?
trg: Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner, Either betray'd by falsehood of his guard Or by his foe surprised at unawares:

src: And, like a traitor to the name of God, Didst break that vow; and with thy treacherous blade Unrip'dst the bowels of thy sovereign's son.
trg: Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.

src: Nay, good my lord, be not afraid of shadows.
trg: By the apostle Paul, shadows to-night Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers Armed in proof, and led by shallow Richmond.

src: I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife With wealth enough and young and beauteous, Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman:
trg: Hortensio, peace! thou know'st not gold's effect: Tell me her father's name and 'tis enough; For I will board her, though she chide as loud As thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.

src: Hadst thou groan'd for him As I have done, thou wouldst be more pitiful. But now I know thy mind; thou dost suspect That I have been disloyal to thy bed, And that he is a bastard, not thy son:
trg: Sweet York, sweet husband, be not of that mind: He is as like thee as a man may be, Not like to me, or any of my kin, And yet I love him.

src: Gentlemen, importune me no farther, For how I firmly am resolved you know; That is, not bestow my youngest daughter Before I have a husband for the elder:
trg: If either of you both love Katharina, Because I know you well and love you well, Leave shall you have to court her at your pleasure.

src: O, fie, fie, fie! Thy sin's not accidental, but a trade. Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd: 'Tis best thou diest quickly.
trg: O hear me, Isabella!

src: Cannot be! We have record that very well it can, And three examples of the like have been Within my age.
trg: But reason with the fellow, Before you punish him, where he heard this, Lest you shall chance to whip your information And beat the messenger who bids beware Of what is to be dreaded.

src: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say: Your plainness and your shortness please me well.
trg: Right true it is, your son Lucentio here Doth love my daughter and she loveth him, Or both dissemble deeply their affections:

src: This day's black fate on more days doth depend; This but begins the woe, others must end.
trg: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.

src: You must, sir, change persons with me, ere you make that my report: you, indeed, spoke so of him; and much more, much worse.
trg: O thou damnable fellow! Did not I pluck thee by the nose for thy speeches?

src: Now thou'rt troublesome.
trg: Are you so brave? I'll have you talked with anon.

src: You might have been enough the man you are, With striving less to be so;
trg: lesser had been The thwartings of your dispositions, if You had not show'd them how ye were disposed Ere they lack'd power to cross you.

src: My conscience hath a thousand several tongues, And every tongue brings in a several tale, And every tale condemns me for a villain.
trg: Perjury, perjury, in the high'st degree Murder, stem murder, in the direst degree; All several sins, all used in each degree, Throng to the bar, crying all, Guilty! guilty! I shall despair.

src: What, is my Richard both in shape and mind Transform'd and weaken'd? hath Bolingbroke deposed Thine intellect? hath he been in thy heart?
trg: The lion dying thrusteth forth his paw, And wounds the earth, if nothing else, with rage To be o'erpower'd;

src: With Angelo to-night shall lie His old betrothed but despised; So disguise shall, by the disguised, Pay with falsehood false exacting, And perform an old contracting.
trg: MARIANA: Break off thy song, and haste thee quick away: Here comes a man of comfort, whose advice Hath often still'd my brawling discontent. I cry you mercy, sir;

src: Let specialties be therefore drawn between us, That covenants may be kept on either hand.
trg: Ay, when the special thing is well obtain'd, That is, her love; for that is all in all.

src: You have often Begun to tell me what I am, but stopp'd And left me to a bootless inquisition, Concluding 'Stay: not yet.'
trg: The hour's now come; The very minute bids thee ope thine ear; Obey and be attentive. Canst thou remember A time before we came unto this cell?

src: You have paid the heavens your function, and the prisoner the very debt of your calling. I have laboured for the poor gentleman to the extremest shore of my modesty:
trg: but my brother justice have I found so severe, that he hath forced me to tell him he is indeed Justice.

src: But shall I live in hope?
trg: All men, I hope, live so.

src: Sir, I cannot tell: We must proceed as we do find the people.
trg: The people will remain uncertain whilst 'Twixt you there's difference; but the fall of either Makes the survivor heir of all.

src: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart. I am in your debt for your last exercise; Come the next Sabbath, and I will content you.
trg: What, talking with a priest, lord chamberlain? Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your honour hath no shriving work in hand.

src: How, sir! do you meddle with my master?
trg: Ay; 'tis an honester service than to meddle with thy mistress. Thou pratest, and pratest; serve with thy trencher, hence!

src: Ha! let me see her: out, alas! she's cold: Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff; Life and these lips have long been separated:
trg: Death lies on her like an untimely frost Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.

src: Carthage?
trg: I assure you, Carthage.

src: I read that I profess, the Art to Love.
trg: And may you prove, sir, master of your art!

src: York is too far gone with grief, Or else he never would compare between.
trg: Why, uncle, what's the matter?

src: Let me hear you speak farther. I have spirit to do anything that appears not foul in the truth of my spirit.
