trg: Virtue is bold, and goodness never fearful. Have you not heard speak of Mariana, the sister of Frederick the great soldier who miscarried at sea?

src: in few, bestowed her on her own lamentation, which she yet wears for his sake; and he, a marble to her tears, is washed with them, but relents not.
trg: What a merit were it in death to take this poor maid from the world! What corruption in this life, that it will let this man live! But how out of this can she avail?

src: Yes, Warwick, I remember it to my grief; And, by his soul, thou and thy house shall rue it.
trg: Plantagenet, of thee and these thy sons, Thy kinsman and thy friends, I'll have more lives Than drops of blood were in my father's veins.

src: And therefore I yield thee my free consent.
trg: And I choose Clarence only for protector.

src: Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to deny him.
trg: We may, sir, if we will.

src: What, are you busy, ho? need you my help?
trg: No, madam; we have cull'd such necessaries As are behoveful for our state to-morrow: So please you, let me now be left alone, And let the nurse this night sit up with you;

src: What! has your king married the Lady Grey! And now, to soothe your forgery and his, Sends me a paper to persuade me patience? Is this the alliance that he seeks with France?
trg: Dare he presume to scorn us in this manner?

src: take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient honest witnesses: If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell for ever and a day.
trg: Hearest thou, Biondello?

src: Sit, Coriolanus; never shame to hear What you have nobly done.
trg: Your horror's pardon: I had rather have my wounds to heal again Than hear say how I got them.

src: those whom you curse Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound And lie full low, graved in the hollow ground.
trg: Is Bushy, Green, and the Earl of Wiltshire dead?

src: God-den to you all, god-den to you all.
trg: Ourselves, our wives, and children, on our knees, Are bound to pray for you both.

src: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.
trg: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.

src: Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as soon moody to be moved.
trg: And what to?

src: Be absolute for death; either death or life Shall thereby be the sweeter. Reason thus with life: If I do lose thee, I do lose a thing That none but fools would keep:
trg: a breath thou art, Servile to all the skyey influences, That dost this habitation, where thou keep'st, Hourly afflict: merely, thou art death's fool;

src: The gain I seek is, quiet in the match.
trg: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch. But now, Baptists, to your younger daughter: Now is the day we long have looked for: I am your neighbour, and was suitor first.

src: A murderous villain, and so still thou art.
trg: Poor Clarence did forsake his father, Warwick; Yea, and forswore himself,--which Jesu pardon!--

src: Though thou speak'st truth, Methinks thou speak'st not well. How long is't since?
trg: Above an hour, my lord.

src: Not I, believe me: thus I'll visit her.
trg: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.

src: I pray you, daughter, sing; or express yourself in a more comfortable sort:
trg: if my son were my husband, I should freelier rejoice in that absence wherein he won honour than in the embracements of his bed where he would show most love.

src: Now we have shown our power, Let us seem humbler after it is done Than when it was a-doing.
trg: Bid them home: Say their great enemy is gone, and they Stand in their ancient strength.

src: O woful day, O woful day!
trg: Beguiled, divorced, wronged, spited, slain! Most detestable death, by thee beguil'd, By cruel cruel thee quite overthrown! O love! O life! not life, but love in death!

src: Meantime, God grants that we have need of you: Your brother is imprison'd by your means, Myself disgraced, and the nobility Held in contempt;
trg: whilst many fair promotions Are daily given to ennoble those That scarce, some two days since, were worth a noble.

src: Good time of day unto your royal grace!
trg: God make your majesty joyful as you have been!

src: Prithee now, Go, and be ruled: although I know thou hadst rather Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf Than flatter him in a bower. Here is Cominius.
trg: I have been i' the market-place; and, sir,'tis fit You make strong party, or defend yourself By calmness or by absence: all's in anger.

src: He that is strucken blind cannot forget The precious treasure of his eyesight lost:
trg: Show me a mistress that is passing fair, What doth her beauty serve, but as a note Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair? Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.

src: To-morrow then belike shall be the day, If Warwick be so near as men report.
trg: But say, I pray, what nobleman is that That with the king here resteth in his tent?

src: Ay, all of them at Bristol lost their heads.
trg: Where is the duke my father with his power?
No.

src: Ay, sir; whom, I thank heaven, is an honest woman,--
trg: Dost thou detest her therefore?

src: His own impatience Takes from Aufidius a great part of blame. Let's make the best of it.
trg: My rage is gone; And I am struck with sorrow. Take him up. Help, three o' the chiefest soldiers; I'll be one. Beat thou the drum, that it speak mournfully: Trail your steel pikes.

src: Sir, I hope My words disbench'd you not.
trg: No, sir: yet oft, When blows have made me stay, I fled from words. You soothed not, therefore hurt not: but your people, I love them as they weigh.

src: This is a merry ballad, but a very pretty one.
trg: Let's have some merry ones.

src: Then list to me:
trg: This follows, if you will not change your purpose But undergo this flight, make for Sicilia, And there present yourself and your fair princess, For so I see she must be, 'fore Leontes:

src: if the encounter acknowledge itself hereafter, it may compel him to her recompense:
trg: and here, by this, is your brother saved, your honour untainted, the poor Mariana advantaged, and the corrupt deputy scaled. The maid will I frame and make fit for his attempt.

src: it was thought she was a woman and was turned into a cold fish for she would not exchange flesh with one that loved her: the ballad is very pitiful and as true.
trg: Is it true too, think you?

src: He had rather see the swords, and hear a drum, than look upon his school-master.
trg: O' my word, the father's son: I'll swear,'tis a very pretty boy. O' my troth, I looked upon him o' Wednesday half an hour together: has such a confirmed countenance.

src: 'Tis a lucky day, boy, and we'll do good deeds on't.
trg: I, that please some, try all, both joy and terror Of good and bad, that makes and unfolds error, Now take upon me, in the name of Time, To use my wings.

src: Would they were basilisks, to strike thee dead!
trg: I would they were, that I might die at once; For now they kill me with a living death. Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears, Shamed their aspect with store of childish drops:

src: I shall be, if I claim by open war.
trg: I'll prove the contrary, if you'll hear me speak.

src: O, ho! entreat her! Nay, then she must needs come.
trg: I am afraid, sir, Do what you can, yours will not be entreated. Now, where's my wife?

src: ' O, a kiss Long as my exile, sweet as my revenge! Now, by the jealous queen of heaven, that kiss I carried from thee, dear; and my true lip Hath virgin'd it e'er since. You gods!
trg: I prate, And the most noble mother of the world Leave unsaluted: sink, my knee, i' the earth; Of thy deep duty more impression show Than that of common sons.

src: Preposterous ass, that never read so far To know the cause why music was ordain'd! Was it not to refresh the mind of man After his studies or his usual pain?
trg: Then give me leave to read philosophy, And while I pause, serve in your harmony.

src: And from my soul too; Or else beshrew them both.
trg: Amen!

src: which if I have not enough considered, as too much I cannot, to be more thankful to thee shall be my study, and my profit therein the heaping friendships.
trg: Of that fatal country, Sicilia, prithee speak no more; whose very naming punishes me with the remembrance of that penitent, as thou callest him, and reconciled king, my brother;

src: Say that again. The shadow of my sorrow! ha! let's see: 'Tis very true, my grief lies all within;
trg: And these external manners of laments Are merely shadows to the unseen grief That swells with silence in the tortured soul; There lies the substance:

src: Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven, Having some business, do entreat her eyes To twinkle in their spheres till they return. What if her eyes were there, they in her head?
trg: The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars, As daylight doth a lamp; her eyes in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night.

src: O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody prison, Fatal and ominous to noble peers! Within the guilty closure of thy walls Richard the second here was hack'd to death;
trg: And, for more slander to thy dismal seat, We give thee up our guiltless blood to drink.

src: Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen, Only for saying he would make his son Heir to the crown; meaning indeed his house, Which, by the sign thereof was termed so.
trg: Moreover, urge his hateful luxury And bestial appetite in change of lust;

src: Thy grief is but thy absence for a time.
trg: Joy absent, grief is present for that time.

src: Provost, a word with you.
trg: As many as you please.

src: No; I will to Ireland to his majesty. Farewell: if heart's presages be not vain, We three here art that ne'er shall meet again.
trg: That's as York thrives to beat back Bolingbroke.

src: Good morrow, neighbour Gremio. God save you, gentlemen!
trg: And you, good sir! Pray, have you not a daughter Call'd Katharina, fair and virtuous?

src: be bestrid An o'er-press'd Roman and i' the consul's view Slew three opposers: Tarquin's self he met, And struck him on his knee:
trg: in that day's feats, When he might act the woman in the scene, He proved best man i' the field, and for his meed Was brow-bound with the oak.

src: You holy clergymen, is there no plot To rid the realm of this pernicious blot?
trg: My lord, Before I freely speak my mind herein, You shall not only take the sacrament To bury mine intents, but also to effect Whatever I shall happen to devise.

src: It shall be speeded well.
trg: I thank thee, Varrius; thou hast made good haste: Come, we will walk. There's other of our friends Will greet us here anon, my gentle Varrius.

src: Marry, sir, by my wife; who, if she had been a woman cardinally given, might have been accused in fornication, adultery, and all uncleanliness there.
trg: By the woman's means?

src: I do beseech your majesty, impute his words To wayward sickliness and age in him: He loves you, on my life, and holds you dear As Harry Duke of Hereford, were he here.
trg: Right, you say true: as Hereford's love, so his; As theirs, so mine; and all be as it is.

src: Nor never by advised purpose meet To plot, contrive, or complot any ill 'Gainst us, our state, our subjects, or our land.
trg: I swear.

src: All the charms Of Sycorax, toads, beetles, bats, light on you! For I am all the subjects that you have, Which first was mine own king:
trg: and here you sty me In this hard rock, whiles you do keep from me The rest o' the island.

src: Set down, set down your honourable load, If honour may be shrouded in a hearse, Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament The untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster. Poor key-cold figure of a holy king!
trg: Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster! Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood!

src: Patience, I pray you; 'twas a fault unwilling.
trg: A whoreson beetle-headed, flap-ear'd knave! Come, Kate, sit down; I know you have a stomach. Will you give thanks, sweet Kate; or else shall I? What's this? mutton?

src: This is the prettiest low-born lass that ever Ran on the green-sward: nothing she does or seems But smacks of something greater than herself, Too noble for this place.
trg: He tells her something That makes her blood look out: good sooth, she is The queen of curds and cream.

src: And very welcome. Look, signior, here's your sister.
trg: Provost, a word with you.

src: What's the news?
trg: Good news, good news; the ladies have prevail'd, The Volscians are dislodged, and Marcius gone: A merrier day did never yet greet Rome, No, not the expulsion of the Tarquins.

src: 'Shall'! O good but most unwise patricians! If he have power Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd, Be not as common fools;
trg: if you are not, Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians, If they be senators: and they are no less, When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste Most palates theirs.

src: They're busy within; you were best knock louder.
trg: What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?

src: What, do I love her, That I desire to hear her speak again, And feast upon her eyes? What is't I dream on? O cunning enemy, that, to catch a saint, With saints dost bait thy hook!
trg: Most dangerous Is that temptation that doth goad us on To sin in loving virtue: never could the strumpet, With all her double vigour, art and nature, Once stir my temper;

src: I prithee, Remember I have done thee worthy service; Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served Without or grudge or grumblings: thou didst promise To bate me a full year.
trg: Dost thou forget From what a torment I did free thee?

src: A sad tale's best for winter: I have one Of sprites and goblins.
trg: Let's have that, good sir. Come on, sit down: come on, and do your best To fright me with your sprites; you're powerful at it.

src: Good night, good Captain Blunt. Come gentlemen, Let us consult upon to-morrow's business In to our tent; the air is raw and cold.
trg: What is't o'clock?

src: His pupil age Man-enter'd thus, he waxed like a sea, And in the brunt of seventeen battles since He lurch'd all swords of the garland.
trg: For this last, Before and in Corioli, let me say, I cannot speak him home: he stopp'd the fliers; And by his rare example made the coward Turn terror into sport:

src: Here were the servants of your adversary, And yours, close fighting ere I did approach: I drew to part them:
trg: in the instant came The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared, Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears, He swung about his head and cut the winds, Who nothing hurt withal hiss'd him in scorn:

src: Here is a friar, and slaughter'd Romeo's man; With instruments upon them, fit to open These dead men's tombs.
trg: O heavens! O wife, look how our daughter bleeds! This dagger hath mista'en--for, lo, his house Is empty on the back of Montague,-- And it mis-sheathed in my daughter's bosom!

src: not a counterfeit stone, not a ribbon, glass, pomander, brooch, table-book, ballad, knife, tape, glove, shoe-tie, bracelet, horn-ring, to keep my pack from fasting:
trg: they throng who should buy first, as if my trinkets had been hallowed and brought a benediction to the buyer: by which means I saw whose purse was best in picture;

src: thence I have follow'd it, Or it hath drawn me rather. But 'tis gone. No, it begins again. Full fathom five thy father lies; Of his bones are coral made; Those are pearls that were his eyes:
trg: Nothing of him that doth fade But doth suffer a sea-change Into something rich and strange. Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell Hark! now I hear them,--Ding-dong, bell.

src: 'Tis done by me, and ends in 'Margaret.'
trg: Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.

src: To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.
trg: What is the city but the people?

src: Ay, ay, a scratch, a scratch; marry, 'tis enough. Where is my page? Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.
trg: Courage, man; the hurt cannot be much.

src: While you, sweet dear, prove mistress of my heart!
trg: Quick proceeders, marry! Now, tell me, I pray, You that durst swear at your mistress Bianca Loved none in the world so well as Lucentio.

src: Thou villain Capulet,--Hold me not, let me go.
trg: Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.

src: Who does infect her?
trg: Why, he that wears her like a medal, hanging About his neck, Bohemia:

src: Ay, and have been so any time these four hours.
trg: And so have I, boy.

src: The commons hath he pill'd with grievous taxes, And quite lost their hearts: the nobles hath he fined For ancient quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.
trg: And daily new exactions are devised, As blanks, benevolences, and I wot not what: But what, o' God's name, doth become of this?

src: Had I a glass, I would.
trg: What, you mean my face?

src: But I'ld say he had not, And I'll be sworn you would believe my saying, Howe'er you lean to the nayward.
trg: You, my lords, Look on her, mark her well; be but about To say 'she is a goodly lady,' and The justice of your bearts will thereto add 'Tis pity she's not honest, honourable:

src: As we paced along Upon the giddy footing of the hatches, Methought that Gloucester stumbled; and, in falling, Struck me, that thought to stay him, overboard, Into the tumbling billows of the main.
trg: Lord, Lord! methought, what pain it was to drown! What dreadful noise of waters in mine ears! What ugly sights of death within mine eyes! Methought I saw a thousand fearful wrecks;

src: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?
trg: And be a happy mother by the deed.

src: let myself and fortune Tug for the time to come. This you may know And so deliver, I am put to sea With her whom here I cannot hold on shore;
trg: And most opportune to our need I have A vessel rides fast by, but not prepared For this design. What course I mean to hold Shall nothing benefit your knowledge, nor Concern me the reporting.

src: Come your way, sir. 'Bless you, good father friar.
trg: And you, good brother father. What offence hath this man made you, sir?

src: We'll have this song out anon by ourselves: my father and the gentlemen are in sad talk, and we'll not trouble them. Come, bring away thy pack after me. Wenches, I'll buy for you both.
trg: Pedlar, let's have the first choice. Follow me, girls.

src: He that no more must say is listen'd more Than they whom youth and ease have taught to glose; More are men's ends mark'd than their lives before:
trg: The setting sun, and music at the close, As the last taste of sweets, is sweetest last, Writ in remembrance more than things long past:

src: God bless thee; and put meekness in thy mind, Love, charity, obedience, and true duty!
And I, to make thee mad, do mock thee thus. Stamp, rave, and fret, that I may sing and dance. Thou wouldst be fee'd, I see, to make me sport: York cannot speak, unless he wear a crown.
trg: A crown for York! and, lords, bow low to him: Hold you his hands, whilst I do set it on. Ay, marry, sir, now looks he like a king!

src: All the contagion of the south light on you, You shames of Rome!
trg: you herd of--Boils and plagues Plaster you o'er, that you may be abhorr'd Further than seen and one infect another Against the wind a mile!
I'll wait upon your lordship.

src: Fear not, my lord, I'll play the orator As if the golden fee for which I plead Were for myself: and so, my lord, adieu.
trg: If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard's Castle; Where you shall find me well accompanied With reverend fathers and well-learned bishops.

src: And yet I know not how to get the crown, For many lives stand between me and home:
trg: And I,--like one lost in a thorny wood, That rends the thorns and is rent with the thorns, Seeking a way and straying from the way;

src: No, my good Lord; he hath forsook the court, Broken his staff of office and dispersed The household of the king.
trg: What was his reason? He was not so resolved when last we spake together.

src: welcome, Bolingbroke!' Whilst he, from the one side to the other turning, Bareheaded, lower than his proud steed's neck, Bespake them thus: 'I thank you, countrymen:
trg: ' And thus still doing, thus he pass'd along.

src: Of honourable reckoning are you both; And pity 'tis you lived at odds so long. But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?
trg: But saying o'er what I have said before: My child is yet a stranger in the world;

src: No, no, men living flatter those that die.
trg: Thou, now a-dying, say'st thou flatterest me.

src: hence shall we see, If power change purpose, what our seemers be.
trg: And have you nuns no farther privileges?

src: for never gazed the moon Upon the water as he'll stand and read As 'twere my daughter's eyes: and, to be plain. I think there is not half a kiss to choose Who loves another best.
trg: She dances featly.

src: Alas, poor soul!
trg: O, good sir, softly, good sir! I fear, sir, my shoulder-blade is out.

src: Our sighs and they shall lodge the summer corn, And make a dearth in this revolting land. Or shall we play the wantons with our woes, And make some pretty match with shedding tears?
trg: As thus, to drop them still upon one place, Till they have fretted us a pair of graves Within the earth; and, therein laid,--there lies Two kinsmen digg'd their graves with weeping eyes.

src: Give me a torch: I am not for this ambling; Being but heavy, I will bear the light.
trg: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.

src: So other foes may set upon our backs. Stand we in good array; for they no doubt Will issue out again and bid us battle:
trg: If not, the city being but of small defence, We'll quickly rouse the traitors in the same.

src: Ay, to be murder'd by his enemies.
trg: When I return with victory from the field I'll see your grace: till then I'll follow her.

src: 'Farewell:' And, for my heart disdained that my tongue Should so profane the word, that taught me craft To counterfeit oppression of such grief That words seem'd buried in my sorrow's grave.
trg: Marry, would the word 'farewell' have lengthen'd hours And added years to his short banishment, He should have had a volume of farewells; But since it would not, he had none of me.

src: the matter, The loss, the gain, the ordering on't, is all Properly ours.
trg: And I wish, my liege, You had only in your silent judgment tried it, Without more overture.

src: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl. The secret mischiefs that I set abroach I lay unto the grievous charge of others.
trg: Clarence, whom I, indeed, have laid in darkness, I do beweep to many simple gulls Namely, to Hastings, Derby, Buckingham;

src: Why he's a devil, a devil, a very fiend.
trg: Why, she's a devil, a devil, the devil's dam.

src: Then speak at once what is it thou demand'st.
trg: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant's life; Who slew to-day a righteous gentleman Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolk.

src: Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary Then fiery expedition be my wing, Jove's Mercury, and herald for a king! Come, muster men: my counsel is my shield;
trg: We must be brief when traitors brave the field.

src: No, take more: What may be sworn by, both divine and human, Seal what I end withal! purpose so barr'd, it follows, Nothing is done to purpose. let them not lick The sweet which is their poison:
trg: your dishonour Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state Of that integrity which should become't, Not having the power to do the good it would, For the in which doth control't.

src: Be York the next that must be bankrupt so! Though death be poor, it ends a mortal woe.
trg: The ripest fruit first falls, and so doth he; His time is spent, our pilgrimage must be. So much for that. Now for our Irish wars:

src: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?
trg: Ay, boy.

src: Thou canst help time to furrow me with age, But stop no wrinkle in his pilgrimage; Thy word is current with him for my death, But dead, thy kingdom cannot buy my breath.
trg: Thy son is banish'd upon good advice, Whereto thy tongue a party-verdict gave: Why at our justice seem'st thou then to lour?

src: See here these movers that do prize their hours At a crack'd drachm!
trg: Cushions, leaden spoons, Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves, Ere yet the fight be done, pack up: down with them!

src: But as successively from blood to blood, Your right of birth, your empery, your own.
trg: For this, consorted with the citizens, Your very worshipful and loving friends, And by their vehement instigation, In this just suit come I to move your grace.

src: Go to; I say you shall.
trg: This afternoon, sir? well, she shall be there.

src: I' the commonwealth I would by contraries Execute all things; for no kind of traffic Would I admit; no name of magistrate; Letters should not be known; riches, poverty, And use of service, none;
trg: contract, succession, Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none; No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil; No occupation; all men idle, all; And women too, but innocent and pure; No sovereignty;--

src: -- O, if I wake, shall I not be distraught, Environed with all these hideous fears? And madly play with my forefather's joints? And pluck the mangled Tybalt from his shroud?
trg: And, in this rage, with some great kinsman's bone, As with a club, dash out my desperate brains? O, look!

src: for it stands me much upon, To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me. I must be married to my brother's daughter, Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.
trg: Murder her brothers, and then marry her! Uncertain way of gain! But I am in So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin: Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye. Is thy name Tyrrel?

src: Is it new and old too? how may that be?
trg: Why, is it not news, to hear of Petruchio's coming?

src: Angelo hath seen them both, and will discover the favour.
trg: O, death's a great disguiser; and you may add to it. Shave the head, and tie the beard; and say it was the desire of the penitent to be so bared before his death: you know the course is common.

src: My brother did love Juliet, And you tell me that he shall die for it.
trg: He shall not, Isabel, if you give me love.

src: for the selfsame heaven That frowns on me looks sadly upon him.
trg: Arm, arm, my lord; the foe vaunts in the field.

src: Brother, the time and case requireth haste: Your horse stands ready at the park-corner.
trg: But whither shall we then?

src: Madam, we'll play at bowls.
trg: 'Twill make me think the world is full of rubs, And that my fortune rubs against the bias.

src: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.
trg: Withdraw you hence, my lord, I'll follow you.

src: Is this done?
trg: The custom of request you have discharged: The people do admit you, and are summon'd To meet anon, upon your approbation.

src: Well; the matter?
trg: I have a brother is condemn'd to die: I do beseech you, let it be his fault, And not my brother.

src: They tend the crown, yet still with me they stay.
trg: Are you contented to resign the crown?

src: See, where he stands between two clergymen!
trg: Two props of virtue for a Christian prince, To stay him from the fall of vanity: And, see, a book of prayer in his hand, True ornaments to know a holy man.

src: That he was never trained up in arms.
trg: He said the truth: and what said Surrey then?

src: But that I do not.
trg: Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since, Thy father was the Duke of Milan and A prince of power.

src: Upon his place, And with full line of his authority, Governs Lord Angelo; a man whose blood Is very snow-broth;
trg: one who never feels The wanton stings and motions of the sense, But doth rebate and blunt his natural edge With profits of the mind, study and fast.

src: And if thy poor devoted suppliant may But beg one favour at thy gracious hand, Thou dost confirm his happiness for ever.
trg: What is it?

src: If I may have your daughter to my wife, I'll leave her houses three or four as good, Within rich Pisa walls, as any one Old Signior Gremio has in Padua;
trg: Besides two thousand ducats by the year Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure. What, have I pinch'd you, Signior Gremio?

src: Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen: And, princely peers, a happy time of day!
trg: Happy, indeed, as we have spent the day. Brother, we done deeds of charity; Made peace enmity, fair love of hate, Between these swelling wrong-incensed peers.

src: Here, madam: 'Hic ibat Simois; hic est Sigeia tellus; Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.'
trg: Construe them.

src: Be certain what you do, sir, lest your justice Prove violence; in the which three great ones suffer, Yourself, your queen, your son.
trg: For her, my lord, I dare my life lay down and will do't, sir, Please you to accept it, that the queen is spotless I' the eyes of heaven and to you; I mean, In this which you accuse her.

src: I'll undertake 't: I think he'll hear me. Yet, to bite his lip And hum at good Cominius, much unhearts me. He was not taken well; he had not dined:
trg: The veins unfill'd, our blood is cold, and then We pout upon the morning, are unapt To give or to forgive;

src: My Lord Aumerle, is Harry Hereford arm'd?
trg: Yea, at all points; and longs to enter in.

src: My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon, And you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me. The Earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment:
trg: Good Captain Blunt, bear my good night to him And by the second hour in the morning Desire the earl to see me in my tent:

src: Theretake it to you, trenchers, cups, and all; You heedless joltheads and unmanner'd slaves! What, do you grumble? I'll be with you straight.
trg: I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet: The meat was well, if you were so contented.

src: And toil'd with works of war, retired himself To Italy;
trg: and there at Venice gave His body to that pleasant country's earth, And his pure soul unto his captain Christ, Under whose colours he had fought so long.

src: Sir, most heedfully.
trg: Being once perfected how to grant suits, How to deny them, who to advance and who To trash for over-topping, new created The creatures that were mine, I say, or changed 'em, Or else new form'd 'em;

src: and then rejourn the controversy of three pence to a second day of audience.
trg: When you are hearing a matter between party and party, if you chance to be pinched with the colic, you make faces like mummers; set up the bloody flag against all patience;

src: Do not deny to him that you love me.
trg: I will confess to you that I love him.

src: And, though unskilful, why not Ned and I For once allow'd the skilful pilot's charge?
trg: We will not from the helm to sit and weep, But keep our course, though the rough wind say no, From shelves and rocks that threaten us with wreck. As good to chide the waves as speak them fair.

src: Come, come; let's see him out at gates; come. The gods preserve our noble tribunes! Come.
trg: Come, leave your tears: a brief farewell: the beast With many heads butts me away. Nay, mother, Where is your ancient courage? you were used To say extremity was the trier of spirits;

src: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow. I have been long a sleeper; but, I hope, My absence doth neglect no great designs, Which by my presence might have been concluded.
trg: Had not you come upon your cue, my lord William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part,-- I mean, your voice,--for crowning of the king.

src: Ay, by and by; But we will drink together; and you shall bear A better witness back than words, which we, On like conditions, will have counter-seal'd. Come, enter with us.
trg: Ladies, you deserve To have a temple built you: all the swords In Italy, and her confederate arms, Could not have made this peace.

src: One, gentlewoman, that God hath made for himself to mar.
trg: By my troth, it is well said; 'for himself to mar,' quoth a'? Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I may find the young Romeo?

src: And therefore, if you say no more than this, That like a father you will deal with him And pass my daughter a sufficient dower, The match is made, and all is done:
trg: Your son shall have my daughter with consent.

src: In choosing for yourself, you show'd your judgment, Which being shallow, you give me leave To play the broker in mine own behalf; And to that end I shortly mind to leave you.
trg: Leave me, or tarry, Edward will be king, And not be tied unto his brother's will.

src: And when the morning sun shall raise his car Above the border of this horizon, We'll forward towards Warwick and his mates; For well I wot that Henry is no soldier. Ah, froward Clarence!
trg: how evil it beseems thee To flatter Henry and forsake thy brother! Yet, as we may, we'll meet both thee and Warwick. Come on, brave soldiers:

src: I' fecks! Why, that's my bawcock. What, hast smutch'd thy nose? They say it is a copy out of mine. Come, captain, We must be neat; not neat, but cleanly, captain:
trg: And yet the steer, the heifer and the calf Are all call'd neat.--Still virginalling Upon his palm!--How now, you wanton calf! Art thou my calf?

src: Why came I hither but to that intent? Think you a little din can daunt mine ears? Have I not in my time heard lions roar?
trg: Have I not heard the sea puff'd up with winds Rage like an angry boar chafed with sweat? Have I not heard great ordnance in the field, And heaven's artillery thunder in the skies?

src: What good is this to England and himself!
trg: Base, fearful and despairing Henry!

src: it is so very very late, That we may call it early by and by. Good night.
trg: Wilt thou be gone? it is not yet near day: It was the nightingale, and not the lark, That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear; Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate-tree:

src: Nay, but it is not so.
trg: It is no other: show your wisdom, daughter, In your close patience.

src: To serve me well, you all should do me duty, Teach me to be your queen, and you my subjects: O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!
trg: Dispute not with her; she is lunatic.

src: That thou hast wronged in the time o'erpast; For I myself have many tears to wash Hereafter time, for time past wrong'd by thee.
trg: The children live, whose parents thou hast slaughter'd, Ungovern'd youth, to wail it in their age;

src: What, is there a maid with child by him?
trg: No, but there's a woman with maid by him. You have not heard of the proclamation, have you?

src: For this ungentle business Put on thee by my lord, thou ne'er shalt see Thy wife Paulina more.' And so, with shrieks She melted into air.
trg: Affrighted much, I did in time collect myself and thought This was so and no slumber. Dreams are toys: Yet for this once, yea, superstitiously, I will be squared by this.

src: meagre were his looks, Sharp misery had worn him to the bones: And in his needy shop a tortoise hung, An alligator stuff'd, and other skins Of ill-shaped fishes;
trg: and about his shelves A beggarly account of empty boxes, Green earthen pots, bladders and musty seeds, Remnants of packthread and old cakes of roses, Were thinly scatter'd, to make up a show.

src: That's worthily As any ear can hear. Come, let's not weep. If I could shake off but one seven years From these old arms and legs, by the good gods, I'ld with thee every foot.
trg: Give me thy hand: Come.

src: And all my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay And follow thee my lord throughout the world.
Yea, but not change his spots: take but my shame. And I resign my gage. My dear dear lord, The purest treasure mortal times afford Is spotless reputation:
trg: that away, Men are but gilded loam or painted clay. A jewel in a ten-times-barr'd-up chest Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast. Mine honour is my life; both grow in one:

src: So did we all. But, come, let's home.
trg: I do not like this news.

src: Why, may one ask?
trg: I dream'd a dream to-night.

src: The younger then is free and not before.
trg: Sir, you say well and well you do conceive; And since you do profess to be a suitor, You must, as we do, gratify this gentleman, To whom we all rest generally beholding.

src: Indeed, I never shall be satisfied With Romeo, till I behold him--dead-- Is my poor heart for a kinsman vex'd. Madam, if you could find out but a man To bear a poison, I would temper it;
trg: That Romeo should, upon receipt thereof, Soon sleep in quiet. O, how my heart abhors To hear him named, and cannot come to him. To wreak the love I bore my cousin Upon his body that slaughter'd him!

src: I take thy hand, this hand, As soft as dove's down and as white as it, Or Ethiopian's tooth, or the fann'd snow that's bolted By the northern blasts twice o'er.
trg: What follows this? How prettily the young swain seems to wash The hand was fair before! I have put you out: But to your protestation; let me hear What you profess.

src: I told you, I, he was a frantic fool, Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behavior:
trg: And, to be noted for a merry man, He'll woo a thousand, 'point the day of marriage, Make feasts, invite friends, and proclaim the banns; Yet never means to wed where he hath woo'd.

src: Out on you, owls! nothing but songs of death? Take that, until thou bring me better news.
trg: The news I have to tell your majesty Is, that by sudden floods and fall of waters, Buckingham's army is dispersed and scatter'd; And he himself wander'd away alone, No man knows whither.

src: O you beast! O faithless coward! O dishonest wretch! Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice? Is't not a kind of incest, to take life From thine own sister's shame? What should I think?
trg: Heaven shield my mother play'd my father fair! For such a warped slip of wilderness Ne'er issued from his blood. Take my defiance! Die, perish!

src: I shall forget, to have thee still stand there, Remembering how I love thy company.
trg: And I'll still stay, to have thee still forget, Forgetting any other home but this.

src: Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.
trg: It may not be.

src: This is that very Mab That plats the manes of horses in the night, And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs, Which once untangled, much misfortune bodes:
trg: This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs, That presses them and learns them first to bear, Making them women of good carriage: This is she--

src: The white sheet bleaching on the hedge, With heigh! the sweet birds, O, how they sing! Doth set my pugging tooth on edge; For a quart of ale is a dish for a king.
trg: The lark, that tirra-lyra chants, With heigh! with heigh! the thrush and the jay, Are summer songs for me and my aunts, While we lie tumbling in the hay.

src: Though he hath fallen by prompture of the blood, Yet hath he in him such a mind of honour.
trg: That, had he twenty heads to tender down On twenty bloody blocks, he'ld yield them up, Before his sister should her body stoop To such abhorr'd pollution.

src: Most sure, the goddess On whom these airs attend! Vouchsafe my prayer May know if you remain upon this island; And that you will some good instruction give How I may bear me here:
trg: my prime request, Which I do last pronounce, is, O you wonder! If you be maid or no?

src: Slandering a prince deserves it. She, Claudio, that you wrong'd, look you restore. Joy to you, Mariana! Love her, Angelo: I have confess'd her and I know her virtue.
trg: Thanks, good friend Escalus, for thy much goodness: There's more behind that is more gratulate. Thanks, provost, for thy care and secrecy: We shill employ thee in a worthier place.

src: O dear father, Make not too rash a trial of him, for He's gentle and not fearful.
trg: What? I say, My foot my tutor? Put thy sword up, traitor; Who makest a show but darest not strike, thy conscience Is so possess'd with guilt:

src: What comfortable hour canst thou name, That ever graced me in thy company?
trg: Faith, none, but Humphrey Hour, that call'd your grace To breakfast once forth of my company. If I be so disgracious in your sight, Let me march on, and not offend your grace. Strike the drum.

src: We thank your honour.
trg: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

src: But yesternight, my lord, she and that friar, I saw them at the prison: a saucy friar, A very scurvy fellow.
trg: Blessed be your royal grace! I have stood by, my lord, and I have heard Your royal ear abused.

src: she that makes dainty, She, I'll swear, hath corns; am I come near ye now? Welcome, gentlemen!
trg: I have seen the day That I have worn a visor and could tell A whispering tale in a fair lady's ear, Such as would please: 'tis gone, 'tis gone, 'tis gone: You are welcome, gentlemen!

src: I am the greatest, able to do least, Yet most suspected, as the time and place Doth make against me of this direful murder;
trg: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge Myself condemned and myself excused.

src: And seem a saint, when most I play the devil. But, soft! here come my executioners. How now, my hardy, stout resolved mates! Are you now going to dispatch this deed?
trg: We are, my lord; and come to have the warrant That we may be admitted where he is.

src: And yonder is the wolf that makes this spoil. You fight in justice: then, in God's name, lords, Be valiant and give signal to the fight. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Now here a period of tumultuous broils. Away with Oxford to Hames Castle straight: For Somerset, off with his guilty head. Go, bear them hence; I will not hear them speak.

src: To him, and to his substitutes.
trg: You will think you have made no offence, if the duke avouch the justice of your dealing?

src: Noting this penury, to myself I said 'An if a man did need a poison now, Whose sale is present death in Mantua, Here lives a caitiff wretch would sell it him.
trg: ' O, this same thought did but forerun my need; And this same needy man must sell it me. As I remember, this should be the house. Being holiday, the beggar's shop is shut. What, ho! apothecary!

src: For, ere the six years that he hath to spend Can change their moons and bring their times about My oil-dried lamp and time-bewasted light Shall be extinct with age and endless night;
trg: My inch of taper will be burnt and done, And blindfold death not let me see my son.

src: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.
trg: Then in plain terms tell her my loving tale.

src: 'Zounds! who is there?
trg: Ratcliff, my lord; 'tis I. The early village-cock Hath twice done salutation to the morn; Your friends are up, and buckle on their armour.

src: Give me thy hand: Come.
trg: Bid them all home; he's gone, and we'll no further. The nobility are vex'd, whom we see have sided In his behalf.

src: but you have found, Scaling his present bearing with his past, That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke Your sudden approbation.
trg: Say, you ne'er had done't-- Harp on that still--but by our putting on; And presently, when you have drawn your number, Repair to the Capitol.

src: My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently. The worst is this, that, at so slender warning, You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.
trg: It likes me well. Biondello, hie you home, And bid Bianca make her ready straight;

src: What sayest thou to this tune, matter and method? Is't not drowned i' the last rain, ha? What sayest thou, Trot? Is the world as it was, man? Which is the way? Is it sad, and few words? or how?
trg: The trick of it?

src: As I bethink me, you should not be king Till our King Henry had shook hands with death.
trg: And will you pale your head in Henry's glory, And rob his temples of the diadem, Now in his life, against your holy oath? O, 'tis a fault too too unpardonable!

src: -- And breathed such life with kisses in my lips, That I revived, and was an emperor. Ah me! how sweet is love itself possess'd, When but love's shadows are so rich in joy! News from Verona!
trg: --How now, Balthasar! Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar? How doth my lady? Is my father well? How fares my Juliet? that I ask again; For nothing can be ill, if she be well.

src: The chopping French we do not understand. Thine eye begins to speak; set thy tongue there; Or in thy piteous heart plant thou thine ear;
trg: That hearing how our plaints and prayers do pierce, Pity may move thee 'pardon' to rehearse.

src: Who knew of Your intent and coming hither?
trg: One that I would were here, Friar Lodowick.

src: He hath paid you all he promised you; may be, he has paid you more, which will shame you to give him again.
trg: Is there no manners left among maids? will they wear their plackets where they should bear their faces?

src: How dost thou know that, constable?
trg: Marry, sir, by my wife; who, if she had been a woman cardinally given, might have been accused in fornication, adultery, and all uncleanliness there.

src: Not at all, good lady: You might have spoken a thousand things that would Have done the time more benefit and graced Your kindness better.
trg: You are one of those Would have him wed again.

src: but rather tell me, When I, that censure him, do so offend, Let mine own judgment pattern out my death, And nothing come in partial. Sir, he must die.
trg: Be it as your wisdom will.

src: And, being angry, does forget that ever He heard the name of death. Here's goodly work!
trg: I would they were abed!

src: Now, in good time, here comes the Duke of York.
trg: Richard of York! how fares our loving brother?

src: First, an it like you, the house is a respected house; next, this is a respected fellow; and his mistress is a respected woman.
trg: By this hand, sir, his wife is a more respected person than any of us all.

src: Hear me speak: As I do know the consul's worthiness, So can I name his faults,--
trg: Consul! what consul?

src: Down, down I come; like glistering Phaethon, Wanting the manage of unruly jades. In the base court? Base court, where kings grow base, To come at traitors' calls and do them grace. In the base court?
trg: Come down? Down, court! down, king! For night-owls shriek where mounting larks should sing.

src: I thank you, sir. Where then do you know best We be affied and such assurance ta'en As shall with either part's agreement stand?
trg: Not in my house, Lucentio; for, you know, Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants: Besides, old Gremio is hearkening still; And happily we might be interrupted.

src: Ask Marian Hacket, the fat ale-wife of Wincot, if she know me not: if she say I am not fourteen pence on the score for sheer ale, score me up for the lyingest knave in Christendom. What!
trg: I am not bestraught: here's--

src: It must needs be of subtle, tender and delicate temperance.
trg: Temperance was a delicate wench.

src: This deserves death.
trg: Or let us stand to our authority, Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce, Upon the part o' the people, in whose power We were elected theirs, Marcius is worthy Of present death.

src: O the gods!
trg: I'll follow thee a month, devise with thee Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us And we of thee:

src: thou dost here usurp The name thou owest not; and hast put thyself Upon this island as a spy, to win it From me, the lord on't.
trg: No, as I am a man.

src: Why have those banish'd and forbidden legs Dared once to touch a dust of England's ground? But then more 'why?
trg: ' why have they dared to march So many miles upon her peaceful bosom, Frighting her pale-faced villages with war And ostentation of despised arms? Comest thou because the anointed king is hence?

src: How came it that the absent duke had not either delivered him to his liberty or executed him? I have heard it was ever his manner to do so.
trg: His friends still wrought reprieves for him: and, indeed, his fact, till now in the government of Lord Angelo, came not to an undoubtful proof.

src: 'True is it, my incorporate friends,' quoth he, 'That I receive the general food at first, Which you do live upon; and fit it is, Because I am the store-house and the shop Of the whole body:
trg: but, if you do remember, I send it through the rivers of your blood, Even to the court, the heart, to the seat o' the brain;

src: O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio's dead! That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds, Which too untimely here did scorn the earth.
trg: This day's black fate on more days doth depend; This but begins the woe, others must end.

src: Now, if the help of Norfolk and myself, With all the friends that thou, brave Earl of March, Amongst the loving Welshmen canst procure, Will but amount to five and twenty thousand, Why, Via!
trg: to London will we march amain, And once again bestride our foaming steeds, And once again cry 'Charge upon our foes!' But never once again turn back and fly.

src: But now the blood of twenty thousand men Did triumph in my face, and they are fled; And, till so much blood thither come again, Have I not reason to look pale and dead?
trg: All souls that will be safe fly from my side, For time hath set a blot upon my pride.

src: The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the beginning.
trg: All things in common nature should produce Without sweat or endeavour: treason, felony, Sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine, Would I not have;

src: offer me no money, I pray you; that kills my heart.
trg: What manner of fellow was he that robbed you?
I come, anon.--But if thou mean'st not well, I do beseech thee--

src: but one of these-- As he hath spices of them all, not all, For I dare so far free him--made him fear'd, So hated, and so banish'd: but he has a merit, To choke it in the utterance.
trg: So our virtues Lie in the interpretation of the time: And power, unto itself most commendable, Hath not a tomb so evident as a chair To extol what it hath done. One fire drives out one fire;

src: Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon, Who is already sick and pale with grief, That thou her maid art far more fair than she: Be not her maid, since she is envious;
trg: Her vestal livery is but sick and green And none but fools do wear it; cast it off. It is my lady, O, it is my love! O, that she knew she were! She speaks yet she says nothing: what of that?

src: Whiles we have struck, By interims and conveying gusts we have heard The charges of our friends. Ye Roman gods!
trg: Lead their successes as we wish our own, That both our powers, with smiling fronts encountering, May give you thankful sacrifice. Thy news?

src: And came I not at last to comfort you?
trg: No, by the holy rood, thou know'st it well, Thou camest on earth to make the earth my hell. A grievous burthen was thy birth to me; Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy;

src: Wife, we scarce thought us blest That God had lent us but this only child; But now I see this one is one too much, And that we have a curse in having her: Out on her, hilding!
trg: God in heaven bless her! You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.

src: where you may Enjoy your mistress, from the whom, I see, There's no disjunction to be made, but by-- As heavens forefend!--your ruin;
trg: marry her, And, with my best endeavours in your absence, Your discontenting father strive to qualify And bring him up to liking.

src: Signior Baptista, will you be so strange? Sorry am I that our good will effects Bianca's grief.
trg: Why will you mew her up, Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell, And make her bear the penance of her tongue?

src: And says a wizard told him that by G His issue disinherited should be; And, for my name of George begins with G, It follows in his thought that I am he.
trg: These, as I learn, and such like toys as these Have moved his highness to commit me now.

src: A' will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.
trg: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, Whither away, or where is thy abode? Happy the parents of so fair a child; Happier the man, whom favourable stars Allot thee for his lovely bed-fellow!

src: O slow-wing'd turtle! shall a buzzard take thee?
trg: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.

src: our general himself makes a mistress of him: sanctifies himself with's hand and turns up the white o' the eye to his discourse.
trg: But the bottom of the news is that our general is cut i' the middle and but one half of what he was yesterday; for the other has half, by the entreaty and grant of the whole table.

src: May they perceive's intent! He will require them, As if he did contemn what he requested Should be in them to give.
trg: Come, we'll inform them Of our proceedings here: on the marketplace, I know, they do attend us.

src: She may help you to many fair preferments, And then deny her aiding hand therein, And lay those honours on your high deserts. What may she not? She may, yea, marry, may she--
trg: What, marry, may she?

src: So flies the reckless shepherd from the wolf; So first the harmless sheep doth yield his fleece And next his throat unto the butcher's knife. What scene of death hath Roscius now to act?
trg: Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind; The thief doth fear each bush an officer.

src: I know she is an irksome brawling scold: If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.
trg: No, say'st me so, friend? What countryman?

src: Why should you sigh, my lord?
trg: Not for myself, Lord Warwick, but my son, Whom I unnaturally shall disinherit. But be it as it may: I here entail The crown to thee and to thine heirs for ever;

src: Which, at more leisure, I will so excuse As you shall well be satisfied withal. But where is Kate? I stay too long from her: The morning wears, 'tis time we were at church.
trg: See not your bride in these unreverent robes: Go to my chamber; Put on clothes of mine.

src: Very well: Could he say less?
trg: I offer'd to awaken his regard For's private friends: his answer to me was, He could not stay to pick them in a pile Of noisome musty chaff:

src: Is whispering nothing? Is leaning cheek to cheek? is meeting noses? Kissing with inside lip? stopping the career Of laughing with a sigh?--a note infallible Of breaking honesty--horsing foot on foot?
trg: Skulking in corners? wishing clocks more swift? Hours, minutes? noon, midnight? and all eyes Blind with the pin and web but theirs, theirs only, That would unseen be wicked? is this nothing?

src: Now, afore God, 'tis shame such wrongs are borne In him, a royal prince, and many moe Of noble blood in this declining land. The king is not himself, but basely led By flatterers;
trg: and what they will inform, Merely in hate, 'gainst any of us all, That will the king severely prosecute 'Gainst us, our lives, our children, and our heirs.

src: Being once perfected how to grant suits, How to deny them, who to advance and who To trash for over-topping, new created The creatures that were mine, I say, or changed 'em, Or else new form'd 'em;
trg: having both the key Of officer and office, set all hearts i' the state To what tune pleased his ear; that now he was The ivy which had hid my princely trunk, And suck'd my verdure out on't.

src: Go, counsellor; Thou and my bosom henceforth shall be twain. I'll to the friar, to know his remedy: If all else fail, myself have power to die.
trg: On Thursday, sir? the time is very short.

src: Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet: Procure me music ready when he wakes, To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound;
trg: And if he chance to speak, be ready straight And with a low submissive reverence Say 'What is it your honour will command?

src: Commend me to thy brother, Edmund York. Lo, this is all:--nay, yet depart not so; Though this be all, do not so quickly go; I shall remember more. Bid him--ah, what?
trg: -- With all good speed at Plashy visit me. Alack, and what shall good old York there see But empty lodgings and unfurnish'd walls, Unpeopled offices, untrodden stones?

src: Give me leave, I'll go to him, and undertake to bring him Where he shall answer, by a lawful form, In peace, to his utmost peril.
trg: Noble tribunes, It is the humane way: the other course Will prove too bloody, and the end of it Unknown to the beginning.

src: Peace be with you! He who the sword of heaven will bear Should be as holy as severe; Pattern in himself to know, Grace to stand, and virtue go;
trg: More nor less to others paying Than by self-offences weighing. Shame to him whose cruel striking Kills for faults of his own liking! Twice treble shame on Angelo, To weed my vice and let his grow!

src: And shall the figure of God's majesty, His captain, steward, deputy-elect, Anointed, crowned, planted many years, Be judged by subject and inferior breath, And he himself not present?
trg: O, forfend it, God, That in a Christian climate souls refined Should show so heinous, black, obscene a deed! I speak to subjects, and a subject speaks, Stirr'd up by God, thus boldly for his king:

src: Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.
trg: O slow-wing'd turtle! shall a buzzard take thee?

src: By that fair sun which shows me where thou stand'st, I heard thee say, and vauntingly thou spakest it That thou wert cause of noble Gloucester's death. If thou deny'st it twenty times, thou liest;
trg: And I will turn thy falsehood to thy heart, Where it was forged, with my rapier's point.

src: There shall your swords and lances arbitrate The swelling difference of your settled hate: Since we can not atone you, we shall see Justice design the victor's chivalry.
trg: Lord marshal, command our officers at arms Be ready to direct these home alarms.

src: Which to maintain I would allow him odds, And meet him, were I tied to run afoot Even to the frozen ridges of the Alps, Or any other ground inhabitable, Where ever Englishman durst set his foot.
trg: Mean time let this defend my loyalty, By all my hopes, most falsely doth he lie.

src: Grace to boot! Of this make no conclusion, lest you say Your queen and I are devils: yet go on;
trg: The offences we have made you do we'll answer, If you first sinn'd with us and that with us You did continue fault and that you slipp'd not With any but with us.

src: and here Have I, thy schoolmaster, made thee more profit Than other princesses can that have more time For vainer hours and tutors not so careful.
trg: Heavens thank you for't! And now, I pray you, sir, For still 'tis beating in my mind, your reason For raising this sea-storm?

src: And you may marvel why I obscured myself, Labouring to save his life, and would not rather Make rash remonstrance of my hidden power Than let him so be lost.
trg: O most kind maid, It was the swift celerity of his death, Which I did think with slower foot came on, That brain'd my purpose. But, peace be with him!

src: Sir, my lord, I could do this, and that with no rash potion, But with a lingering dram that should not work Maliciously like poison:
trg: but I cannot Believe this crack to be in my dread mistress, So sovereignly being honourable. I have loved thee,--

src: He says so, Tranio.
trg: Faith, he is gone unto the taming-school.

src: And she was wean'd,--I never shall forget it,-- Of all the days of the year, upon that day: For I had then laid wormwood to my dug, Sitting in the sun under the dove-house wall;
trg: My lord and you were then at Mantua:-- Nay, I do bear a brain:
Lives my sweet son?

src: He hath no friends but who are friends for fear. Which in his greatest need will shrink from him.
trg: All for our vantage. Then, in God's name, march: True hope is swift, and flies with swallow's wings: Kings it makes gods, and meaner creatures kings.

src: And bad'st me bury love.
trg: Not in a grave, To lay one in, another out to have.

src: Rescue, my Lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue! The king enacts more wonders than a man, Daring an opposite to every danger:
trg: His horse is slain, and all on foot he fights, Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death. Rescue, fair lord, or else the day is lost!

src: No more of this; it does offend my heart: Pray now, no more.
trg: Look, sir, your mother!

src: Go see this rumourer whipp'd. It cannot be The Volsces dare break with us.
trg: Cannot be! We have record that very well it can, And three examples of the like have been Within my age.

src: The valiant heart is not whipt out of his trade.
trg: Come hither to me, Master Elbow; come hither, Master constable. How long have you been in this place of constable?

src: And thou, brave Oxford, wondrous well beloved, In Oxfordshire shalt muster up thy friends.
trg: My sovereign, with the loving citizens, Like to his island girt in with the ocean, Or modest Dian circled with her nymphs, Shall rest in London till we come to him.

src: O excellent motion! Fellows, let's be gone.
trg: The motion's good indeed and be it so, Petruchio, I shall be your ben venuto.

src: Nay, stay, Sir John, awhile, and we'll debate By what safe means the crown may be recover'd.
trg: What talk you of debating? in few words, If you'll not here proclaim yourself our king, I'll leave you to your fortune and be gone To keep them back that come to succor you:

src: Against all sense you do importune her: Should she kneel down in mercy of this fact, Her brother's ghost his paved bed would break, And take her hence in horror.
trg: Isabel, Sweet Isabel, do yet but kneel by me; Hold up your hands, say nothing; I'll speak all. They say, best men are moulded out of faults;

src: Gives not the hawthorn-bush a sweeter shade To shepherds looking on their silly sheep, Than doth a rich embroider'd canopy To kings that fear their subjects' treachery? O, yes, it doth;
trg: a thousand-fold it doth. And to conclude, the shepherd's homely curds, His cold thin drink out of his leather bottle.

src: I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him; I had a Rutland too, thou holp'st to kill him.
trg: Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard kill'd him. From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept A hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death:

src: And when I mount, alive may I not light, If I be traitor or unjustly fight!
trg: What doth our cousin lay to Mowbray's charge? It must be great that can inherit us So much as of a thought of ill in him.

src: the nuptial finish'd, Let him be whipt and hang'd.
trg: I beseech your highness, do not marry me to a whore. Your highness said even now, I made you a duke: good my lord, do not recompense me in making me a cuckold.

src: To be a make-peace shall become my age: Throw down, my son, the Duke of Norfolk's gage.
trg: And, Norfolk, throw down his.

src: What?
trg: She will not.

src: -- In our remove be thou at full ourself; Mortality and mercy in Vienna Live in thy tongue and heart: old Escalus, Though first in question, is thy secondary. Take thy commission.
trg: Now, good my lord, Let there be some more test made of my metal, Before so noble and so great a figure Be stamp'd upon it.

src: I never heard of such another encounter, which lames report to follow it and undoes description to do it.
trg: What, pray you, became of Antigonus, that carried hence the child?

src: I'll have no halves; I'll bear it all myself. How now! what news?
trg: Sir, my mistress sends you word That she is busy and she cannot come.

src: This is the palace of the fearful king, And this the regal seat: possess it, York; For this is thine and not King Henry's heirs'
trg: Assist me, then, sweet Warwick, and I will; For hither we have broken in by force.

src: A crack, madam.
trg: Come, lay aside your stitchery; I must have you play the idle husewife with me this afternoon.

src: Your grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.
trg: Who, I, my lord I we know each other's faces, But for our hearts, he knows no more of mine, Than I of yours; Nor I no more of his, than you of mine. Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.

src: Mass, and well said; a merry whoreson, ha! Thou shalt be logger-head. Good faith, 'tis day: The county will be here with music straight, For so he said he would: I hear him near. Nurse! Wife!
trg: What, ho! What, nurse, I say! Go waken Juliet, go and trim her up; I'll go and chat with Paris: hie, make haste, Make haste; the bridegroom he is come already: Make haste, I say.

src: the green Neptune A ram, and bleated; and the fire-robed god, Golden Apollo, a poor humble swain, As I seem now.
trg: Their transformations Were never for a piece of beauty rarer, Nor in a way so chaste, since my desires Run not before mine honour, nor my lusts Burn hotter than my faith.

src: No doubt the murderous knife was dull and blunt Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart, To revel in the entrails of my lambs.
trg: But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame, My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys Till that my nails were anchor'd in thine eyes;

src: She speaks: O, speak again, bright angel!
trg: O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo? Deny thy father and refuse thy name; Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love, And I'll no longer be a Capulet.

src: Peace!
trg: Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt With modest warrant.

src: My lord, her wits, I fear me, are not firm: She hath been a suitor to me for her brother Cut off by course of justice,--
trg: By course of justice!

src: The more fool you, for laying on my duty.
trg: Katharina, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.

src: You are too absolute; Though therein you can never be too noble, But when extremities speak. I have heard you say, Honour and policy, like unsever'd friends, I' the war do grow together:
trg: grant that, and tell me, In peace what each of them by the other lose, That they combine not there.

src: I strike quickly, being moved.
trg: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

src: His name is Barnardine.
trg: I would thou hadst done so by Claudio. Go fetch him hither; let me look upon him.

src: ' Insisting on the old prerogative And power i' the truth o' the cause.
trg: I shall inform them.

src: Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery, And give them friendly welcome every one: Let them want nothing that my house affords.
trg: Sirrah, go you to Barthol'mew my page, And see him dress'd in all suits like a lady: That done, conduct him to the drunkard's chamber; And call him 'madam,' do him obeisance.

src: And then I ran away to call the watch.
trg: This letter doth make good the friar's words, Their course of love, the tidings of her death:

src: Spakest thou of Juliet? how is it with her? Doth she not think me an old murderer, Now I have stain'd the childhood of our joy With blood removed but little from her own? Where is she?
trg: and how doth she? and what says My conceal'd lady to our cancell'd love?

src: Menenius ever, ever.
trg: Give way there, and go on!

src: Let's take leave of him.
trg: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground, long heath, brown furze, any thing. The wills above be done! but I would fain die a dry death.

src: It is true. I would not--though 'tis my familiar sin With maids to seem the lapwing and to jest, Tongue far from heart--play with all virgins so: I hold you as a thing ensky'd and sainted.
trg: By your renouncement an immortal spirit, And to be talk'd with in sincerity, As with a saint.

src: No news so bad abroad as this at home; The King is sickly, weak and melancholy, And his physicians fear him mightily.
trg: Now, by Saint Paul, this news is bad indeed. O, he hath kept an evil diet long, And overmuch consumed his royal person: 'Tis very grievous to be thought upon. What, is he in his bed?

src: Help Marcius, help, You that be noble; help him, young and old!
trg: Down with him, down with him!

src: and is he a man to encounter Tybalt?
trg: Why, what is Tybalt?

src: Their sacred wills be done! Go, get aboard; Look to thy bark: I'll not be long before I call upon thee.
trg: Make your best haste, and go not Too far i' the land: 'tis like to be loud weather; Besides, this place is famous for the creatures Of prey that keep upon't.

src: and about his shelves A beggarly account of empty boxes, Green earthen pots, bladders and musty seeds, Remnants of packthread and old cakes of roses, Were thinly scatter'd, to make up a show.
trg: Noting this penury, to myself I said 'An if a man did need a poison now, Whose sale is present death in Mantua, Here lives a caitiff wretch would sell it him.

src: or, if love be blind, It best agrees with night. Come, civil night, Thou sober-suited matron, all in black, And learn me how to lose a winning match, Play'd for a pair of stainless maidenhoods:
trg: Hood my unmann'd blood, bating in my cheeks, With thy black mantle; till strange love, grown bold, Think true love acted simple modesty. Come, night; come, Romeo; come, thou day in night;

src: Now is the sun upon the highmost hill Of this day's journey, and from nine till twelve Is three long hours, yet she is not come.
trg: Had she affections and warm youthful blood, She would be as swift in motion as a ball; My words would bandy her to my sweet love, And his to me: But old folks, many feign as they were dead;

src: What likelihood of his amendment, lords?
trg: Madam, good hope; his grace speaks cheerfully.

src: And so was I: I'll bear you company.
trg: Last night, I hear, they lay at Northampton; At Stony-Stratford will they be to-night: To-morrow, or next day, they will be here.

src: To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.
trg: To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.

src: But, more of thy news?
trg: Why, he is so made on here within, as if he were son and heir to Mars; set at upper end o' the table; no question asked him by any of the senators, but they stand bald before him:

src: The king's grown bankrupt, like a broken man.
trg: Reproach and dissolution hangeth over him.

src: And often up and down my sons were toss'd, For me to joy and weep their gain and loss: And being seated, and domestic broils Clean over-blown, themselves, the conquerors. Make war upon themselves;
trg: blood against blood, Self against self: O, preposterous And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen; Or let me die, to look on death no more!

src: What then remains, we being thus arrived From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York, But that we enter, as into our dukedom?
trg: The gates made fast! Brother, I like not this; For many men that stumble at the threshold Are well foretold that danger lurks within.

src: So that, betwixt their tides and low names, There's nothing differs but the outward fame.
trg: Ho! who's here?

src: So, let the ports be guarded: keep your duties, As I have set them down. If I do send, dispatch Those centuries to our aid: the rest will serve For a short holding:
trg: if we lose the field, We cannot keep the town.

src: And those that you'll procure from King Leontes--
trg: Shall satisfy your father.

src: I tell you, 'tis incredible to believe How much she loves me: O, the kindest Kate! She hung about my neck;
trg: and kiss on kiss She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath, That in a twink she won me to her love. O, you are novices!

src: she may perhaps call him half a score knaves or so: why, that's nothing; an he begin once, he'll rail in his rope-tricks.
trg: I'll tell you what sir, an she stand him but a little, he will throw a figure in her face and so disfigure her with it that she shall have no more eyes to see withal than a cat.

src: No; For we were subjects but while you were king.
trg: Why, am I dead? do I not breathe a man? Ah, simple men, you know not what you swear!

src: A vengeance on your crafty wither'd hide! Yet I have faced it with a card of ten. 'Tis in my head to do my master good:
trg: I see no reason but supposed Lucentio Must get a father, call'd 'supposed Vincentio;' And that's a wonder: fathers commonly Do get their children;

src: was't not at Hallowmas, Master Froth?
trg: All-hallond eve.

src: for his possessions, Although by confiscation they are ours, We do instate and widow you withal, To buy you a better husband.
trg: O my dear lord, I crave no other, nor no better man.

src: Ay, forsooth.
trg: Well, he may chance to do some good on her: A peevish self-will'd harlotry it is.

src: And till the tears that she hath shed for thee Like envious floods o'er-run her lovely face, She was the fairest creature in the world; And yet she is inferior to none.
trg: Am I a lord? and have I such a lady? Or do I dream? or have I dream'd till now? I do not sleep: I see, I hear, I speak; I smell sweet savours and I feel soft things:

src: and then I lost-- All mine own folly--the society, Amity too, of your brave father, whom, Though bearing misery, I desire my life Once more to look on him.
trg: By his command Have I here touch'd Sicilia and from him Give you all greetings that a king, at friend, Can send his brother:

src: Though fortune's malice overthrow my state, My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.
trg: Then, for his mind, be Edward England's king: But Henry now shall wear the English crown, And be true king indeed, thou but the shadow.

src: I am directed by you.
trg: This letter, then, to Friar Peter give; 'Tis that he sent me of the duke's return: Say, by this token, I desire his company At Mariana's house to-night.

src: That's true enough; Through 'tis a saying, sir, not due to me.
trg: You will not own it.

src: Hail, royal prince!
trg: Thanks, noble peer; The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear. What art thou? and how comest thou hither, Where no man never comes but that sad dog That brings me food to make misfortune live?

src: Your own desert!
trg: Ay, but not mine own desire.

src: We'll all assist you; he that flies shall die.
trg: Thanks, gentle Norfolk: stay by me, my lords; And, soldiers, stay and lodge by me this night.

src: Let them hang.
trg: Ay, and burn too.

src: A gentle cousin, were it light enough.
trg: O, then, I see, you will part but with light gifts; In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.

src: This swears he, as he is a prince, is just; And, as I am a gentleman, I credit him.
trg: Northumberland, say thus the king returns: His noble cousin is right welcome hither; And all the number of his fair demands Shall be accomplish'd without contradiction:

src: Northumberland, I hold thee reverently. Break off the parley; for scarce I can refrain The execution of my big-swoln heart Upon that Clifford, that cruel child-killer.
trg: I slew thy father, call'st thou him a child?

src: Ancient damnation! O most wicked fiend! Is it more sin to wish me thus forsworn, Or to dispraise my lord with that same tongue Which she hath praised him with above compare So many thousand times?
trg: Go, counsellor; Thou and my bosom henceforth shall be twain. I'll to the friar, to know his remedy: If all else fail, myself have power to die.

src: Three, my most gracious lord.
For shame, bring Juliet forth; her lord is come.
trg: She's dead, deceased, she's dead; alack the day!

src: What will you read to her?
trg: Whate'er I read to her, I'll plead for you As for my patron, stand you so assured, As firmly as yourself were still in place:

src: Heavy matters! heavy matters! but look thee here, boy. Now bless thyself: thou mettest with things dying, I with things newborn. Here's a sight for thee;
trg: look thee, a bearing-cloth for a squire's child! look thee here; take up, take up, boy; open't. So, let's see: it was told me I should be rich by the fairies. This is some changeling: open't.

src: I am for thee straight: take thou the bill, give me thy mete-yard, and spare not me.
trg: God-a-mercy, Grumio! then he shall have no odds.

src: Therefore take with thee my most heavy curse; Which, in the day of battle, tire thee more Than all the complete armour that thou wear'st! My prayers on the adverse party fight;
trg: And there the little souls of Edward's children Whisper the spirits of thine enemies And promise them success and victory. Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end;

src: If she dares trust me with her little babe, I'll show't the king and undertake to be Her advocate to the loud'st. We do not know How he may soften at the sight o' the child:
trg: The silence often of pure innocence Persuades when speaking fails.

src: I'll tell you what sir, an she stand him but a little, he will throw a figure in her face and so disfigure her with it that she shall have no more eyes to see withal than a cat.
trg: You know him not, sir.

src: Yonder man is carried to prison.
trg: Well; what has he done?

src: Come, come, we'll prompt you.
trg: I prithee now, sweet son, as thou hast said My praises made thee first a soldier, so, To have my praise for this, perform a part Thou hast not done before.

src: Warwick, these words have turn'd my hate to love; And I forgive and quite forget old faults, And joy that thou becomest King Henry's friend.
trg: 'Tis not his new-made bride shall succor him:

src: We can: my royal liege, He is not guilty of her coming hither.
trg: You're liars all.

src: It is my fashion, when I see a crab.
trg: Why, here's no crab; and therefore look not sour.

src: Madam, the guests are come, supper served up, you called, my young lady asked for, the nurse cursed in the pantry, and every thing in extremity. I must hence to wait; I beseech you, follow straight.
trg: We follow thee. Juliet, the county stays.

src: if once I find thee ranging, Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing.
O, then I see that madmen have no ears.
trg: How should they, when that wise men have no eyes?

src: You weary those that refresh us: pray, let's see these four threes of herdsmen.
trg: One three of them, by their own report, sir, hath danced before the king; and not the worst of the three but jumps twelve foot and a half by the squier.

src: My husband and my lord, my lord and husband; I am your wife in all obedience.
trg: I know it well. What must I call her?

src: No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.
trg: Why, that's all one.

src: O, ye're well met: the hoarded plague o' the gods Requite your love!
trg: Peace, peace; be not so loud.

src: Be thou revenged on men, and let me live.
trg: In vain thou speak'st, poor boy; my father's blood Hath stopp'd the passage where thy words should enter.

src: Not sleeping, to engross his idle body, But praying, to enrich his watchful soul: Happy were England, would this gracious prince Take on himself the sovereignty thereof:
trg: But, sure, I fear, we shall ne'er win him to it.

src: This is the fruit of rashness! Mark'd you not How that the guilty kindred of the queen Look'd pale when they did hear of Clarence' death? O, they did urge it still unto the king! God will revenge it.
trg: But come, let us in, To comfort Edward with our company.

src: Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting? In his tail.
trg: In his tongue.

src: That Mowbray hath received eight thousand nobles In name of lendings for your highness' soldiers, The which he hath detain'd for lewd employments, Like a false traitor and injurious villain.
trg: Which blood, like sacrificing Abel's, cries, Even from the tongueless caverns of the earth, To me for justice and rough chastisement;

src: Let's ha't, good Grumio.
trg: Lend thine ear.

src: As merry as you will.
trg: A sad tale's best for winter: I have one Of sprites and goblins.

src: In all which time you and your husband Grey Were factious for the house of Lancaster; And, Rivers, so were you. Was not your husband In Margaret's battle at Saint Alban's slain?
trg: Let me put in your minds, if you forget, What you have been ere now, and what you are; Withal, what I have been, and what I am.

src: Wherein the king stands generally condemn'd.
trg: If judgement lie in them, then so do we, Because we ever have been near the king.

src: But saying o'er what I have said before: My child is yet a stranger in the world;
trg: She hath not seen the change of fourteen years, Let two more summers wither in their pride, Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.
