src: My mind will never grant what I perceive Your highness aims at, if I aim aright.
trg: To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.

src: I care not.
trg: Nay, hear you, Kate: in sooth you scape not so.

src: I minded him how royal 'twas to pardon When it was less expected: he replied, It was a bare petition of a state To one whom they had punish'd.
trg: Very well: Could he say less?

src: Shall we give o'er and drown? Have you a mind to sink?
trg: A pox o' your throat, you bawling, blasphemous, incharitable dog!

src: Thou stern, obdurate, flinty, rough, remorseless. Bids't thou me rage? why, now thou hast thy wish: Wouldst have me weep? why, now thou hast thy will:
trg: For raging wind blows up incessant showers, And when the rage allays, the rain begins. These tears are my sweet Rutland's obsequies:

src: Come, Montague; for thou art early up, To see thy son and heir more early down.
trg: Alas, my liege, my wife is dead to-night; Grief of my son's exile hath stopp'd her breath: What further woe conspires against mine age?

src: The liquid drops of tears that you have shed Shall come again, transform'd to orient pearl, Advantaging their loan with interest Of ten times double gain of happiness.
trg: Go, then my mother, to thy daughter go Make bold her bashful years with your experience; Prepare her ears to hear a wooer's tale Put in her tender heart the aspiring flame Of golden sovereignty;

src: To help King Edward in his time of storm, As every loyal subject ought to do.
trg: Thanks, good Montgomery; but we now forget Our title to the crown and only claim Our dukedom till God please to send the rest.

src: True; save means to live.
trg: Of that there's none, or little.

src: Look back, defend thee, here are enemies.
trg: God and our innocency defend and guard us!

src: In war was never lion raged more fierce, In peace was never gentle lamb more mild, Than was that young and princely gentleman.
trg: His face thou hast, for even so look'd he, Accomplish'd with the number of thy hours; But when he frown'd, it was against the French And not against his friends;

src: I have not deserved it. But, worthy lords, have you with heed perused What I have written to you?
trg: We have.

src: Hath been! is it ended, then? Our state thinks not so: they are in a most warlike preparation, and hope to come upon them in the heat of their division.
trg: The main blaze of it is past, but a small thing would make it flame again:

src: I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword, Or manage it to part these men with me.
trg: What, drawn, and talk of peace! I hate the word, As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee: Have at thee, coward!

src: Your virtue is To make him worthy whose offence subdues him And curse that justice did it. Who deserves greatness Deserves your hate;
trg: and your affections are A sick man's appetite, who desires most that Which would increase his evil. He that depends Upon your favours swims with fins of lead And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye!

src: Have I thought long to see this morning's face, And doth it give me such a sight as this?
trg: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day! Most miserable hour that e'er time saw In lasting labour of his pilgrimage!

src: Does your worship mean to geld and splay all the youth of the city?
trg: No, Pompey.

src: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now. My lord, we must entreat the time alone.
trg: God shield I should disturb devotion! Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye: Till then, adieu; and keep this holy kiss.

src: You are one of those Would have him wed again.
trg: If you would not so, You pity not the state, nor the remembrance Of his most sovereign name;

src: Faith, as cold as can be.
trg: Pluck up thy spirits; look cheerfully upon me. Here love; thou see'st how diligent I am To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee: I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.

src: Mine boy? not till King Henry be dead.
trg: Your right depends not on his life or death.

src: Why, then he is alive.
trg: Nay, he is dead; and slain by Edward's hand.

src: Humbly complaining to her deity Got my lord chamberlain his liberty. I'll tell you what; I think it is our way, If we will keep in favour with the king, To be her men and wear her livery:
trg: The jealous o'erworn widow and herself, Since that our brother dubb'd them gentlewomen. Are mighty gossips in this monarchy.

src: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed; Why or for what these nobles were committed Is all unknown to me, my gracious lady.
trg: Ay me, I see the downfall of our house! The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind; Insulting tyranny begins to jet Upon the innocent and aweless throne: Welcome, destruction, death, and massacre!

src: And his offence is so, as it appears, Accountant to the law upon that pain.
trg: True.

src: Be merry, for our time of stay is short
trg: Well, lords, the Duke of Lancaster is dead.

src: Show me a mistress that is passing fair, What doth her beauty serve, but as a note Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair? Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.
trg: I'll pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.

src: A herald, Kate? O, put me in thy books!
trg: What is your crest? a coxcomb?

src: We must supplant those rough rug-headed kerns, Which live like venom where no venom else But only they have privilege to live.
trg: And for these great affairs do ask some charge, Towards our assistance we do seize to us The plate, corn, revenues and moveables, Whereof our uncle Gaunt did stand possess'd.

src: The day serves well for them now. I have heard it said, the fittest time to corrupt a man's wife is when she's fallen out with her husband.
trg: Your noble Tullus Aufidius will appear well in these wars, his great opposer, Coriolanus, being now in no request of his country.

src: Sometime the flood prevails, and then the wind; Now one the better, then another best; Both tugging to be victors, breast to breast, Yet neither conqueror nor conquered:
trg: So is the equal of this fell war. Here on this molehill will I sit me down. To whom God will, there be the victory! For Margaret my queen, and Clifford too, Have chid me from the battle;

src: Of you, my noble cousin, Lord Aumerle; Not sick, although I have to do with death, But lusty, young, and cheerly drawing breath.
trg: Lo, as at English feasts, so I regreet The daintiest last, to make the end most sweet:

src: Then shall we hear their 'larum, and they ours. Now, Mars, I prithee, make us quick in work, That we with smoking swords may march from hence, To help our fielded friends! Come, blow thy blast.
trg: Tutus Aufidius, is he within your walls?

src: The tears have got small victory by that; For it was bad enough before their spite.
trg: Thou wrong'st it, more than tears, with that report.

src: But when they shall see, sir, his crest up again, and the man in blood, they will out of their burrows, like conies after rain, and revel all with him.
trg: But when goes this forward?

src: If you refuse it,--as, in love and zeal, Loath to depose the child, Your brother's son; But we will plant some other in the throne, To the disgrace and downfall of your house:
trg: And in this resolution here we leave you.-- Come, citizens: 'zounds! I'll entreat no more.

src: That Romeo should, upon receipt thereof, Soon sleep in quiet. O, how my heart abhors To hear him named, and cannot come to him. To wreak the love I bore my cousin Upon his body that slaughter'd him!
trg: Find thou the means, and I'll find such a man. But now I'll tell thee joyful tidings, girl.

src: Well, well see't. Come, madam wife, sit by my side and let the world slip: we shall ne'er be younger.
trg: Tranio, since for the great desire I had To see fair Padua, nursery of arts, I am arrived for fruitful Lombardy, The pleasant garden of great Italy;

src: Why, trow'st thou, Warwick, That Clarence is so harsh, so blunt, unnatural, To bend the fatal instruments of war Against his brother and his lawful king? Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath:
trg: To keep that oath were more impiety Than Jephthah's, when he sacrificed his daughter. And so, proud-hearted Warwick, I defy thee, And to my brother turn my blushing cheeks.

src: As near as I could sift him on that argument, On some apparent danger seen in him Aim'd at your highness, no inveterate malice.
trg: Then call them to our presence; face to face, And frowning brow to brow, ourselves will hear The accuser and the accused freely speak:

src: Come, Grey, come, Vaughan, let us all embrace: And take our leave, until we meet in heaven.
trg: My lords, at once: the cause why we are met Is, to determine of the coronation. In God's name, speak: when is the royal day?

src: Ha, banishment! be merciful, say 'death;' For exile hath more terror in his look, Much more than death: do not say 'banishment.'
trg: Hence from Verona art thou banished: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.

src: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting; it is a most sharp sauce.
trg: And is it not well served in to a sweet goose?

src: And shall have your will, because our king: Yet hasty marriage seldom proveth well.
trg: Yea, brother Richard, are you offended too?

src: Now Warwick, tell me, even upon thy conscience, Is Edward your true king? for I were loath To link with him that were not lawful chosen.
trg: Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.

src: What doth she say, my Lord of Buckingham?
trg: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.

src: i' the people's name, I say it shall be so.
trg: It shall be so, it shall be so; let him away: He's banish'd, and it shall be so.

src: therefore they do not give us the lie.
trg: Your worship had like to have given us one, if you had not taken yourself with the manner.

src: Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front;
trg: And now, instead of mounting barded steeds To fright the souls of fearful adversaries, He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.

src: I stabb'd your fathers' bosoms, split my breast.
trg: Now breathe we, lords: good fortune bids us pause, And smooth the frowns of war with peaceful looks.

src: O shut the door! and when thou hast done so, Come weep with me; past hope, past cure, past help!
trg: Ah, Juliet, I already know thy grief; It strains me past the compass of my wits: I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it, On Thursday next be married to this county.

src: How canst thou woo her?
trg: That would I learn of you, As one that are best acquainted with her humour.

src: Why, what's a moveable?
trg: A join'd-stool.

src: My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days Which here you urge to prove us enemies, We follow'd then our lord, our lawful king: So should we you, if you should be our king.
trg: If I should be! I had rather be a pedlar: Far be it from my heart, the thought of it!

src: for the gods know I speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.
trg: Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius?

src: He who shall speak for her is afar off guilty But that he speaks.
trg: There's some ill planet reigns: I must be patient till the heavens look With an aspect more favourable. Good my lords, I am not prone to weeping, as our sex Commonly are;

src: Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou wilt have The leading of thine own revenges, take The one half of my commission;
trg: and set down-- As best thou art experienced, since thou know'st Thy country's strength and weakness,--thine own ways;

src: and if it be in man besides the king to effect your suits, here is man shall do it.
trg: He seems to be of great authority: close with him, give him gold; and though authority be a stubborn bear, yet he is oft led by the nose with gold:

src: My prettiest Perdita! But O, the thorns we stand upon! Camillo, Preserver of my father, now of me, The medicine of our house, how shall we do?
trg: We are not furnish'd like Bohemia's son, Nor shall appear in Sicilia.

src: Noble lady! Come, go with us; speak fair: you may salve so, Not what is dangerous present, but the loss Of what is past.
trg: I prithee now, my son, Go to them, with this bonnet in thy hand;

src: Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives, Even where his lustful eye or savage heart, Without control, listed to make his prey. Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person:
trg: Which well appeared in his lineaments, Being nothing like the noble duke my father: But touch this sparingly, as 'twere far off, Because you know, my lord, my mother lives.

src: Nay, look you, sir, he tells you flatly what his mind is: Why give him gold enough and marry him to a puppet or an aglet-baby;
trg: or an old trot with ne'er a tooth in her head, though she have as many diseases as two and fifty horses: why, nothing comes amiss, so money comes withal.

src: O heinous, strong and bold conspiracy! O loyal father of a treacherous son!
trg: Thou sheer, immaculate and silver fountain, From when this stream through muddy passages Hath held his current and defiled himself!

src: 'Twere well We let the people know't.
trg: What, what? his choler?

src: Music, awake her; strike! 'Tis time; descend; be stone no more; approach; Strike all that look upon with marvel. Come, I'll fill your grave up:
trg: stir, nay, come away, Bequeath to death your numbness, for from him Dear life redeems you. You perceive she stirs: Start not; her actions shall be holy as You hear my spell is lawful:

src: Look you, sir, here is the hand and seal of the duke: you know the character, I doubt not; and the signet is not strange to you.
trg: I know them both.

src: Not having that, which, having, makes them short.
trg: In love?

src: Alas, that love, so gentle in his view, Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!
trg: Alas, that love, whose view is muffled still, Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will! Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here? Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.

src: Go, get you home, you fragments!
trg: Where's Caius Marcius?

src: You tempt him over-much.
trg: Unless another, As like Hermione as is her picture, Affront his eye.

src: Do so, and after two days I will discharge thee.
trg: That's my noble master! What shall I do? say what; what shall I do?

src: I, that kill'd her husband and his father, To take her in her heart's extremest hate, With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes, The bleeding witness of her hatred by;
trg: Having God, her conscience, and these bars against me, And I nothing to back my suit at all, But the plain devil and dissembling looks, And yet to win her, all the world to nothing! Ha!

src: Hortensio, hark: This gentleman is happily arrived, My mind presumes, for his own good and ours.
trg: I promised we would be contributors And bear his charging of wooing, whatsoe'er.

src: It may be so, for it is not mine own. Are you at leisure, holy father, now; Or shall I come to you at evening mass?
trg: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now. My lord, we must entreat the time alone.

src: Young Ned, for thee, thine uncles and myself Have in our armours watch'd the winter's night, Went all afoot in summer's scalding heat, That thou mightst repossess the crown in peace;
trg: And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain.

src: Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report
trg: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king's fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.

src: My master is grown quarrelsome. I should knock you first, And then I know after who comes by the worst.
trg: Will it not be? Faith, sirrah, an you'll not knock, I'll ring it; I'll try how you can sol, fa, and sing it.

src: Why, sir, he comes not.
trg: Didst thou not say he comes?

src: Noble Marcius!
Who's that which calls?
trg: It is a man's voice. Gentle Isabella, Turn you the key, and know his business of him; You may, I may not; you are yet unsworn.

src: A plague o' both your houses! 'Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat, to scratch a man to death! a braggart, a rogue, a villain, that fights by the book of arithmetic!
trg: Why the devil came you between us? I was hurt under your arm.

src: As fast lock'd up in sleep as guiltless labour When it lies starkly in the traveller's bones: He will not wake.
trg: Who can do good on him? Well, go, prepare yourself. But, hark, what noise? Heaven give your spirits comfort! By and by. I hope it is some pardon or reprieve For the most gentle Claudio.

src: The contents of this is the return of the duke: you shall anon over-read it at your pleasure; where you shall find, within these two days he will be here. This is a thing that Angelo knows not;
trg: for he this very day receives letters of strange tenor; perchance of the duke's death; perchance entering into some monastery; but, by chance, nothing of what is writ.

src: Yet one thing more, good Blunt, before thou go'st, Where is Lord Stanley quarter'd, dost thou know?
trg: Unless I have mista'en his colours much, Which well I am assured I have not done, His regiment lies half a mile at least South from the mighty power of the king.

src: How now, sir! What's your name? and what's the matter?
trg: If it Please your honour, I am the poor duke's constable, and my name is Elbow: I do lean upon justice, sir, and do bring in here before your good honour two notorious benefactors.

src: Now the condition. The King of Naples, being an enemy To me inveterate, hearkens my brother's suit;
trg: Alack, for pity! I, not remembering how I cried out then, Will cry it o'er again: it is a hint That wrings mine eyes to't.

src: Fear not thou, man, thou shalt lose nothing here.
trg: I hope so, sir; for I have about me many parcels of charge.

src: Nay, faith, I'll see the church o' your back; and then come back to my master's as soon as I can.
trg: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.

src: By my troth, I'll go with thee to the lane's end: if bawdy talk offend you, we'll have very little of it. Nay, friar, I am a kind of burr; I shall stick.
trg: Every letter he hath writ hath disvouched other.

src: And I will turn thy falsehood to thy heart, Where it was forged, with my rapier's point.
trg: Thou darest not, coward, live to see that day.

src: I wish no better Than have him hold that purpose and to put it In execution.
trg: 'Tis most like he will.

src: How may likeness made in crimes, Making practise on the times, To draw with idle spiders' strings Most ponderous and substantial things! Craft against vice I must apply:
trg: With Angelo to-night shall lie His old betrothed but despised; So disguise shall, by the disguised, Pay with falsehood false exacting, And perform an old contracting.

src: Till then fair hope must hinder life's decay. And I the rather wean me from despair For love of Edward's offspring in my womb:
trg: This is it that makes me bridle passion And bear with mildness my misfortune's cross;

src: If she deny to wed, I'll crave the day When I shall ask the banns and when be married. But here she comes; and now, Petruchio, speak. Good morrow, Kate; for that's your name, I hear.
trg: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing: They call me Katharina that do talk of me.

src: The blood is hot that must be cool'd for this: Yet can I not of such tame patience boast As to be hush'd and nought at all to say:
trg: First, the fair reverence of your highness curbs me From giving reins and spurs to my free speech; Which else would post until it had return'd These terms of treason doubled down his throat.

src: Above an hour, my lord.
trg: 'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums: How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour, And bring thy news so late?

src: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch. But now, Baptists, to your younger daughter: Now is the day we long have looked for: I am your neighbour, and was suitor first.
trg: And I am one that love Bianca more Than words can witness, or your thoughts can guess.

src: No, sir.
trg: Thou hast. Where was she born? speak; tell me.

src: which raised in me An undergoing stomach, to bear up Against what should ensue.
trg: How came we ashore?

src: You have of these pedlars, that have more in them than you'ld think, sister.
trg: Ay, good brother, or go about to think.

src: we will fetch thee straight Adonis painted by a running brook, And Cytherea all in sedges hid, Which seem to move and wanton with her breath, Even as the waving sedges play with wind.
trg: We'll show thee Io as she was a maid, And how she was beguiled and surprised, As lively painted as the deed was done.

src: A heavy sentence, my most sovereign liege, And all unlook'd for from your highness' mouth:
trg: A dearer merit, not so deep a maim As to be cast forth in the common air, Have I deserved at your highness' hands. The language I have learn'd these forty years, My native English, now I must forego:

src: His face thou hast, for even so look'd he, Accomplish'd with the number of thy hours; But when he frown'd, it was against the French And not against his friends;
trg: his noble hand Did will what he did spend and spent not that Which his triumphant father's hand had won; His hands were guilty of no kindred blood, But bloody with the enemies of his kin. O Richard!

src: Ah, Warwick! Montague hath breathed his last; And to the latest gasp cried out for Warwick, And said 'Commend me to my valiant brother.
trg: ' And more he would have said, and more he spoke, Which sounded like a clamour in a vault, That mought not be distinguished;

src: Good news or bad, that thou comest in so bluntly?
trg: Bad news, my lord: Ely is fled to Richmond; And Buckingham, back'd with the hardy Welshmen, Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.

src: What, in my sight? Bianca, get thee in.
trg: What, will you not suffer me? Nay, now I see She is your treasure, she must have a husband; I must dance bare-foot on her wedding day And for your love to her lead apes in hell. Talk not to me:

src: For selfsame wind that I should speak withal Is kindling coals that fires all my breast, And burns me up with flames that tears would quench. To weep is to make less the depth of grief:
trg: Tears then for babes; blows and revenge for me Richard, I bear thy name; I'll venge thy death, Or die renowned by attempting it.

src: Let him die for't.
trg: 'Tear him to pieces.' 'Do it presently.' 'He kill'd my son.' 'My daughter.' 'He killed my cousin Marcus.' 'He killed my father.'

src: You'll think it strange if I should marry her.
trg: To whom, my lord?

src: Then I must not say no.
trg: What sport shall we devise here in this garden, To drive away the heavy thought of care?

src: A torch for me: let wantons light of heart Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels, For I am proverb'd with a grandsire phrase; I'll be a candle-holder, and look on.
trg: The game was ne'er so fair, and I am done.

src: when thou didst not, savage, Know thine own meaning, but wouldst gabble like A thing most brutish, I endow'd thy purposes With words that made them known.
trg: But thy vile race, Though thou didst learn, had that in't which good natures Could not abide to be with; therefore wast thou Deservedly confined into this rock, Who hadst deserved more than a prison.

src: We do, sir; tell us what hath brought you to't.
trg: Mine own desert.

src: What, man! 'tis not so much, 'tis not so much: 'Tis since the nuptials of Lucentio, Come pentecost as quickly as it will, Some five and twenty years; and then we mask'd.
trg: 'Tis more, 'tis more, his son is elder, sir; His son is thirty.

src: No, my good lord; Nor wish'd to hold my peace.
trg: I wish you now, then; Pray you, take note of it: and when you have A business for yourself, pray heaven you then Be perfect.

src: And most opportune to our need I have A vessel rides fast by, but not prepared For this design. What course I mean to hold Shall nothing benefit your knowledge, nor Concern me the reporting.
trg: O my lord! I would your spirit were easier for advice, Or stronger for your need.

src: I thank you, good friend Lucio.
trg: Within two hours.

src: Thou art deceived: 'tis not thy southern power, Of Essex, Norfolk, Suffolk, nor of Kent, Which makes thee thus presumptuous and proud, Can set the duke up in despite of me.
trg: King Henry, be thy title right or wrong, Lord Clifford vows to fight in thy defence: May that ground gape and swallow me alive, Where I shall kneel to him that slew my father!

src: What said the wench when he rose again?
trg: Trembled and shook; for why, he stamp'd and swore, As if the vicar meant to cozen him. But after many ceremonies done, He calls for wine: 'A health!

src: They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.
trg: Come, cousin, canst thou quake, and change thy colour, Murder thy breath in the middle of a word, And then begin again, and stop again, As if thou wert distraught and mad with terror?

src: Tush, that was in thy rage: Speak it again, and, even with the word, That hand, which, for thy love, did kill thy love, Shall, for thy love, kill a far truer love;
trg: To both their deaths thou shalt be accessary.

src: How far off is our brother Montague? Where is the post that came from Montague?
trg: By this at Daintry, with a puissant troop.
Why, master mayor, why stand you in a doubt? Open the gates; we are King Henry's friends.

src: O, widow Dido! ay, widow Dido.
trg: Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it? I mean, in a sort.

src: By love, who first did prompt me to inquire; He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes. I am no pilot;
trg: yet, wert thou as far As that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea, I would adventure for such merchandise.

src: The law that threaten'd death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile; there art thou happy: A pack of blessings lights up upon thy back; Happiness courts thee in her best array;
trg: But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench, Thou pout'st upon thy fortune and thy love: Take heed, take heed, for such die miserable.

src: Now, to seem to affect the malice and displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he dislikes, to flatter them for their love.
trg: He hath deserved worthily of his country:

src: And I wish, my liege, You had only in your silent judgment tried it, Without more overture.
trg: How could that be? Either thou art most ignorant by age, Or thou wert born a fool. now from the oracle They will bring all; whose spiritual counsel had, Shall stop or spur me. Have I done well?

src: It is a reeling world, indeed, my lord; And I believe twill never stand upright Tim Richard wear the garland of the realm.
trg: How! wear the garland! dost thou mean the crown?

src: O, I will to him and pluck out his eyes!
trg: You shall not be admitted to his sight.

src: Amen, amen! but come what sorrow can, It cannot countervail the exchange of joy That one short minute gives me in her sight:
trg: Do thou but close our hands with holy words, Then love-devouring death do what he dare; It is enough I may but call her mine.

src: What tongueless blocks were they! would not they speak?
trg: No, by my troth, my lord.

src: That which in mean men we intitle patience Is pale cold cowardice in noble breasts. What shall I say? to safeguard thine own life, The best way is to venge my Gloucester's death.
trg: God's is the quarrel; for God's substitute, His deputy anointed in His sight, Hath caused his death: the which if wrongfully, Let heaven revenge;

src: indeed, of all. I do not know that Englishman alive With whom my soul is any jot at odds More than the infant that is born to-night I thank my God for my humility.
trg: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter: I would to God all strifes were well compounded. My sovereign liege, I do beseech your majesty To take our brother Clarence to your grace.

src: He said he had wounds, which he could show in private; And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn, 'I would be consul,' says he: 'aged custom, But by your voices, will not so permit me;
trg: Your voices therefore.' When we granted that, Here was 'I thank you for your voices: thank you: Your most sweet voices: now you have left your voices, I have no further with you.

src: For shame, my liege, make them your precedent! Ah, what a shame were this! Look on the boy;
trg: And let his manly face, which promiseth Successful fortune, steel thy melting heart To hold thine own and leave thine own with him.

src: The silence often of pure innocence Persuades when speaking fails.
trg: Most worthy madam, Your honour and your goodness is so evident That your free undertaking cannot miss A thriving issue: there is no lady living So meet for this great errand.

src: Mine own desert.
trg: Your own desert!

src: But in your daughter's womb I bury them: Where in that nest of spicery they shall breed Selves of themselves, to your recomforture.
trg: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?

src: This is clean kam.
trg: Merely awry: when he did love his country, It honour'd him.

src: That's enough.
trg: Madam, he hath not slept tonight; commanded None should come at him.

src: To-morrow, then, I judge a happy day.
trg: Who knows the lord protector's mind herein? Who is most inward with the royal duke?

src: Yet since I see you fearful, that neither my coat, integrity, nor persuasion can with ease attempt you, I will go further than I meant, to pluck all fears out of you.
trg: Look you, sir, here is the hand and seal of the duke: you know the character, I doubt not; and the signet is not strange to you.

src: No, mighty liege; therefore mistrust me not.
trg: Where is thy power, then, to beat him back? Where are thy tenants and thy followers? Are they not now upon the western shore. Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships!

src: No.
trg: Then have you lost a sight, which was to be seen, cannot be spoken of.

src: Nay, good goose, bite not.
trg: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting; it is a most sharp sauce.

src: Ay, Marcius, Caius Marcius: dost thou think I'll grace thee with that robbery, thy stol'n name Coriolanus in Corioli?
trg: You lords and heads o' the state, perfidiously He has betray'd your business, and given up, For certain drops of salt, your city Rome, I say 'your city,' to his wife and mother;

src: Whose house?
trg: My master's.

src: Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave?
trg: A deadly groan, like life and death's departing.

src: Nor I, nor any But one that's here, and that's himself, for he The sacred honour of himself, his queen's, His hopeful son's, his babe's, betrays to slander, Whose sting is sharper than the sword's;
trg: and will not-- For, as the case now stands, it is a curse He cannot be compell'd to't--once remove The root of his opinion, which is rotten As ever oak or stone was sound.

src: What should I do?
trg: Only make trial what your love can do For Rome, towards Marcius.

src: Resign thy chair, and where I stand kneel thou, Whilst I propose the selfsame words to thee, Which traitor, thou wouldst have me answer to.
trg: Ah, that thy father had been so resolved!

src: Nay, let them follow: The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thither To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutiners, Your valour puts well forth: pray, follow.
trg: Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius?

src: Go, call the people: in whose name myself Attach thee as a traitorous innovator, A foe to the public weal: obey, I charge thee, And follow to thine answer.
trg: Hence, old goat!

src: besides you know Prosperity's the very bond of love, Whose fresh complexion and whose heart together Affliction alters.
trg: One of these is true: I think affliction may subdue the cheek, But not take in the mind.

src: Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss, That would not bless our Europe with your daughter, But rather lose her to an African;
trg: Where she at least is banish'd from your eye, Who hath cause to wet the grief on't.

src: Come, sir: did you set these women on to slander Lord Angelo? they have confessed you did.
trg: 'Tis false.

src: How but well, sir? how but well? It were impossible I should speed amiss.
trg: Why, how now, daughter Katharina! in your dumps?

src: I talk not of your soul: our compell'd sins Stand more for number than for accompt.
trg: How say you?

src: Tybalt, the kinsman of old Capulet, Hath sent a letter to his father's house.
trg: A challenge, on my life.

src: But O, the noble combat that 'twixt joy and sorrow was fought in Paulina! She had one eye declined for the loss of her husband, another elevated that the oracle was fulfilled:
trg: she lifted the princess from the earth, and so locks her in embracing, as if she would pin her to her heart that she might no more be in danger of losing.

src: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London, Were jocund, and supposed their state was sure, And they indeed had no cause to mistrust; But yet, you see how soon the day o'ercast.
trg: This sudden stag of rancour I misdoubt: Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward! What, shall we toward the Tower? the day is spent.

src: My quarrel and this English queen's are one.
trg: And mine, fair lady Bona, joins with yours.

src: Why with some little train, my Lord of Buckingham?
trg: Marry, my lord, lest, by a multitude, The new-heal'd wound of malice should break out, Which would be so much the more dangerous By how much the estate is green and yet ungovern'd:

src: with twenty such vile terms, As had she studied to misuse me so.
trg: Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench; I love her ten times more than e'er I did: O, how I long to have some chat with her!

src: When I have most need to employ a friend, And most assured that he is a friend Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile, Be he unto me! this do I beg of God, When I am cold in zeal to yours.
trg: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham, is this thy vow unto my sickly heart. There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here, To make the perfect period of this peace.

src: Do not draw the curtain.
trg: No longer shall you gaze on't, lest your fancy May think anon it moves.

src: Look, what I will not, that I cannot do.
trg: But might you do't, and do the world no wrong, If so your heart were touch'd with that remorse As mine is to him?

src: I had forgot myself; am I not king? Awake, thou coward majesty! thou sleepest. Is not the king's name twenty thousand names? Arm, arm, my name! a puny subject strikes At thy great glory.
trg: Look not to the ground, Ye favourites of a king: are we not high? High be our thoughts: I know my uncle York Hath power enough to serve our turn. But who comes here?

src: Look where he comes.
trg: Always obedient to your grace's will, I come to know your pleasure.

src: Why, very well; I hope here be truths. He, sir, sitting, as I say, in a lower chair, sir; 'twas in the Bunch of Grapes, where indeed you have a delight to sit, have you not?
trg: I have so; because it is an open room and good for winter.

src: All-hallond eve.
trg: Why, very well; I hope here be truths. He, sir, sitting, as I say, in a lower chair, sir; 'twas in the Bunch of Grapes, where indeed you have a delight to sit, have you not?

src: ' And since, methinks, I would not grow so fast, Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.
trg: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold In him that did object the same to thee;

src: Indeed, la, 'tis a noble child.
trg: A crack, madam.

src: She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio. This bird you aim'd at, though you hit her not; Therefore a health to all that shot and miss'd.
trg: O, sir, Lucentio slipp'd me like his greyhound, Which runs himself and catches for his master.

src: Stop there, stop there.
trg: Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hair.

src: No; then he will say 'twas done cowardly, when he wakes.
trg: When he wakes! why, fool, he shall never wake till the judgment-day.

src: But youth in ladies' eyes that flourisheth.
trg: Content you, gentlemen: I will compound this strife: 'Tis deeds must win the prize; and he of both That can assure my daughter greatest dower Shall have my Bianca's love.

src: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slander'd it.
trg: It may be so, for it is not mine own. Are you at leisure, holy father, now; Or shall I come to you at evening mass?

src: Why, this is a passing merry one and goes to the tune of 'Two maids wooing a man:' there's scarce a maid westward but she sings it; 'tis in request, I can tell you.
trg: We can both sing it: if thou'lt bear a part, thou shalt hear; 'tis in three parts.

src: Right gracious lord, I cannot brook delay: May it please your highness to resolve me now; And what your pleasure is, shall satisfy me.
We are all frail.
trg: Else let my brother die, If not a feodary, but only he Owe and succeed thy weakness.

src: Welcome, my lord, to this brave town of York. Yonder's the head of that arch-enemy That sought to be encompass'd with your crown: Doth not the object cheer your heart, my lord?
trg: Ay, as the rocks cheer them that fear their wreck: To see this sight, it irks my very soul. Withhold revenge, dear God! 'tis not my fault, Nor wittingly have I infringed my vow.

src: if he think it fit to shore them again and that the complaint they have to the king concerns him nothing, let him call me rogue for being so far officious;
trg: for I am proof against that title and what shame else belongs to't. To him will I present them: there may be matter in it.

src: whether defect of judgment, To fail in the disposing of those chances Which he was lord of;
trg: or whether nature, Not to be other than one thing, not moving From the casque to the cushion, but commanding peace Even with the same austerity and garb As he controll'd the war;

src: Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end of this controversy.
trg: Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?

src: for I did kill King Henry, But 'twas thy beauty that provoked me. Nay, now dispatch; 'twas I that stabb'd young Edward, But 'twas thy heavenly face that set me on.
trg: Take up the sword again, or take up me.

src: Put them not to't: Pray you, go fit you to the custom and Take to you, as your predecessors have, Your honour with your form.
trg: It is apart That I shall blush in acting, and might well Be taken from the people.

src: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and all foul ways! Was ever man so beaten? was ever man so rayed? was ever man so weary?
trg: I am sent before to make a fire, and they are coming after to warm them.

src: The people will remain uncertain whilst 'Twixt you there's difference; but the fall of either Makes the survivor heir of all.
trg: I know it; And my pretext to strike at him admits A good construction. I raised him, and I pawn'd Mine honour for his truth:

src: If judgement lie in them, then so do we, Because we ever have been near the king.
trg: Well, I will for refuge straight to Bristol castle: The Earl of Wiltshire is already there.

src: In the devotion of a subject's love, Tendering the precious safety of my prince, And free from other misbegotten hate, Come I appellant to this princely presence.
trg: Now, Thomas Mowbray, do I turn to thee, And mark my greeting well; for what I speak My body shall make good upon this earth, Or my divine soul answer it in heaven.

src: This, here before you.
trg: Thank you, sir: farewell. O world, thy slippery turns!

src: That honourable day shall ne'er be seen.
trg: Many a time hath banish'd Norfolk fought For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field, Streaming the ensign of the Christian cross Against black pagans, Turks, and Saracens:

src: Wither one rose, and let the other flourish; If you contend, a thousand lives must wither.
trg: How will my mother for a father's death Take on with me and ne'er be satisfied!

src: What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see thy master's father, Vincentio?
trg: What, my old worshipful old master? yes, marry, sir: see where he looks out of the window.

src: humbly on my knee I crave your blessing.
trg: God bless thee; and put meekness in thy mind, Love, charity, obedience, and true duty!

src: Yon light is not day-light, I know it, I: It is some meteor that the sun exhales, To be to thee this night a torch-bearer, And light thee on thy way to Mantua: Therefore stay yet;
trg: thou need'st not to be gone.

src: For Edward will defend the town and thee, And all those friends that deign to follow me.
trg: Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery, Our trusty friend, unless I be deceived.

src: Now, afore God, I am so vexed, that every part about me quivers. Scurvy knave! Pray you, sir, a word: and as I told you, my young lady bade me inquire you out;
trg: what she bade me say, I will keep to myself: but first let me tell ye, if ye should lead her into a fool's paradise, as they say, it were a very gross kind of behavior, as they say:

src: Go about it. Put him to choler straight: he hath been used Ever to conquer, and to have his worth Of contradiction: being once chafed, he cannot Be rein'd again to temperance;
trg: then he speaks What's in his heart; and that is there which looks With us to break his neck.

src: Reason; because they then less need one another. The wars for my money. I hope to see Romans as cheap as Volscians. They are rising, they are rising.
trg: In, in, in, in!

src: And, for the most, become much more the better For being a little bad: so may my husband. O Isabel, will you not lend a knee?
trg: He dies for Claudio's death.

src: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify
trg: Read it.

src: Will it not be? Faith, sirrah, an you'll not knock, I'll ring it; I'll try how you can sol, fa, and sing it.
trg: Help, masters, help! my master is mad.

src: I would he had.
trg: 'I would he had'! 'Twas you incensed the rabble: Cats, that can judge as fitly of his worth As I can of those mysteries which heaven Will not have earth to know.

src: Why, then 'tis time to arm and give direction. More than I have said, loving countrymen, The leisure and enforcement of the time Forbids to dwell upon:
trg: yet remember this, God and our good cause fight upon our side; The prayers of holy saints and wronged souls, Like high-rear'd bulwarks, stand before our faces;

src: A join'd-stool.
trg: Thou hast hit it: come, sit on me.

src: If God will be revenged for this deed. O, know you yet, he doth it publicly, Take not the quarrel from his powerful arm;
trg: He needs no indirect nor lawless course To cut off those that have offended him.

src: Report of fashions in proud Italy, Whose manners still our tardy apish nation Limps after in base imitation.
trg: Where doth the world thrust forth a vanity-- So it be new, there's no respect how vile-- That is not quickly buzzed into his ears?

src: A marvellous poor one.
trg: True, so I am.

src: I am a woeful suitor to your honour, Please but your honour hear me.
trg: Well; what's your suit?

src: The fear of that withholds my present aid. But, tell me, where is princely Richmond now?
trg: At Pembroke, or at Harford-west, in Wales.

src: Thou dost, and think'st it much to tread the ooze Of the salt deep, To run upon the sharp wind of the north, To do me business in the veins o' the earth When it is baked with frost.
trg: I do not, sir.

src: He is, and feasts the nobles of the state At his house this night.
trg: Which is his house, beseech you?

src: Most noble sir, That which I shall report will bear no credit, Were not the proof so nigh. Please you, great sir, Bohemia greets you from himself by me;
trg: Desires you to attach his son, who has-- His dignity and duty both cast off-- Fled from his father, from his hopes, and with A shepherd's daughter.

src: The wanton Edward, and the lusty George? And where's that valiant crook-back prodigy, Dicky your boy, that with his grumbling voice Was wont to cheer his dad in mutinies?
trg: Or, with the rest, where is your darling Rutland? Look, York: I stain'd this napkin with the blood That valiant Clifford, with his rapier's point, Made issue from the bosom of the boy;

src: by your patience, If 'gainst yourself you be incensed, we'll put you, Like one that means his proper harm, in manacles, Then reason safely with you.
trg: Therefore, be it known, As to us, to all the world, that Caius Marcius Wears this war's garland: in token of the which, My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him, With all his trim belonging;

src: I would do more than that, if more were needful. Look, here comes one: a gentlewoman of mine, Who, falling in the flaws of her own youth, Hath blister'd her report: she is with child;
trg: And he that got it, sentenced; a young man More fit to do another such offence Than die for this.

src: Or ill-beseeming beast in seeming both! Thou hast amazed me: by my holy order, I thought thy disposition better temper'd. Hast thou slain Tybalt? wilt thou slay thyself?
trg: And stay thy lady too that lives in thee, By doing damned hate upon thyself? Why rail'st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?

src: I know not, sir.
trg: O, she doth teach the torches to burn bright! It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope's ear; Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear!

src: 'Tear him to pieces.' 'Do it presently.' 'He kill'd my son.' 'My daughter.' 'He killed my cousin Marcus.' 'He killed my father.'
trg: Peace, ho! no outrage: peace! The man is noble and his fame folds-in This orb o' the earth. His last offences to us Shall have judicious hearing. Stand, Aufidius, And trouble not the peace.

src: How now, good fellow! why shakest thou so? Fear not, man; here's no harm intended to thee.
trg: I am a poor fellow, sir.

src: is it not an easy matter To make William Lord Hastings of our mind, For the instalment of this noble duke In the seat royal of this famous isle?
trg: He for his father's sake so loves the prince, That he will not be won to aught against him.

src: Done. The wager?
trg: A laughter.

src: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning: I mean, that with my soul I love thy daughter, And mean to make her queen of England.
trg: Say then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?

src: First, hear me speak.
trg: Well, say. Peace, ho!

src: We may, sir, if we will.
trg: We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a power that we have no power to do; for if he show us his wounds and tell us his deeds, we are to put our tongues into those wounds and speak for them;

src: Not a dump we; 'tis no time to play now.
trg: You will not, then?

src: Please you to do't, I'll take it as a peril to my soul, It is no sin at all, but charity.
trg: Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul, Were equal poise of sin and charity.

src: Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen, Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self! Long mayst thou live to wail thy children's loss;
trg: And see another, as I see thee now, Deck'd in thy rights, as thou art stall'd in mine! Long die thy happy days before thy death;

src: Under this thick-grown brake we'll shroud ourselves; For through this laund anon the deer will come; And in this covert will we make our stand, Culling the principal of all the deer.
trg: I'll stay above the hill, so both may shoot.

src: What's this? what's this?
trg: A rhyme I learn'd even now Of one I danced withal.

src: Dispose of her To some more fitter place, and that with speed.
trg: Here is the sister of the man condemn'd Desires access to you.

src: O, thou wilt speak again of banishment.
trg: I'll give thee armour to keep off that word: Adversity's sweet milk, philosophy, To comfort thee, though thou art banished.

src: but if she be obdurate To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid We should infringe the holy privilege Of blessed sanctuary! not for all this land Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.
trg: You are too senseless--obstinate, my lord, Too ceremonious and traditional Weigh it but with the grossness of this age, You break not sanctuary in seizing him.

src: What, doth she swoon? use means for her recovery.
trg: Clarence, excuse me to the king my brother; I'll hence to London on a serious matter: Ere ye come there, be sure to hear some news.

src: the winds, thy sighs; Who, raging with thy tears, and they with them, Without a sudden calm, will overset Thy tempest-tossed body. How now, wife! Have you deliver'd to her our decree?
trg: Ay, sir; but she will none, she gives you thanks. I would the fool were married to her grave!

src: We have.
trg: And grieve to hear't. What faults he made before the last, I think Might have found easy fines:

src: All places that the eye of heaven visits Are to a wise man ports and happy havens. Teach thy necessity to reason thus; There is no virtue like necessity.
trg: Think not the king did banish thee, But thou the king. Woe doth the heavier sit, Where it perceives it is but faintly borne. Go, say I sent thee forth to purchase honour And not the king exiled thee;

src: Heavens thank you for't! And now, I pray you, sir, For still 'tis beating in my mind, your reason For raising this sea-storm?
trg: Know thus far forth. By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune, Now my dear lady, hath mine enemies Brought to this shore;

src: I long to hear him call the drunkard husband, And how my men will stay themselves from laughter When they do homage to this simple peasant. I'll in to counsel them;
trg: haply my presence May well abate the over-merry spleen Which otherwise would grow into extremes.

src: Tut, tut! Grace me no grace, nor uncle me no uncle: I am no traitor's uncle; and that word 'grace.' In an ungracious mouth is but profane.
trg: Why have those banish'd and forbidden legs Dared once to touch a dust of England's ground? But then more 'why?

src: He approaches: you shall hear him.
trg: Hail, lords! I am return'd your soldier, No more infected with my country's love Than when I parted hence, but still subsisting Under your great command.

src: Myself I throw, dread sovereign, at thy foot. My life thou shalt command, but not my shame: The one my duty owes;
trg: but my fair name, Despite of death that lives upon my grave, To dark dishonour's use thou shalt not have.

src: And the rarest that e'er came there.
trg: Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.

src: Think upon me! hang 'em! I would they would forget me, like the virtues Which our divines lose by 'em.
trg: You'll mar all: I'll leave you: pray you, speak to 'em, I pray you, In wholesome manner.

src: it was a torment To lay upon the damn'd, which Sycorax Could not again undo: it was mine art, When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape The pine and let thee out.
trg: I thank thee, master.

src: These English woes will make me smile in France.
trg: O thou well skill'd in curses, stay awhile, And teach me how to curse mine enemies!

src: Error i' the bill, sir; error i' the bill. I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again; and that I'll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.
trg: This is true that I say: an I had thee in place where, thou shouldst know it.

src: But this I know, they have demean'd themselves Like men born to renown by life or death. Three times did Richard make a lane to me. And thrice cried 'Courage, father! fight it out!
trg: ' And full as oft came Edward to my side, With purple falchion, painted to the hilt In blood of those that had encounter'd him: And when the hardiest warriors did retire, Richard cried 'Charge!

src: to the Capitol!
trg: Come, come.

src: Away with the dotard! to the gaol with him!
trg: Thus strangers may be hailed and abused: O monstrous villain!

src: Do, and be witness to 't.
trg: And this my neighbour too?

src: I cheer'd them up with justice of our cause, With promise of high pay and great rewards: But all in vain; they had no heart to fight, And we in them no hope to win the day; So that we fled;
trg: the king unto the queen; Lord George your brother, Norfolk and myself, In haste, post-haste, are come to join with you: For in the marches here we heard you were, Making another head to fight again.

src: Well, forward, forward! thus the bowl should run, And not unluckily against the bias. But, soft! company is coming here. Good morrow, gentle mistress: where away?
trg: Tell me, sweet Kate, and tell me truly too, Hast thou beheld a fresher gentlewoman? Such war of white and red within her cheeks!

src: Belike the elder; Clarence will have the younger. Now, brother king, farewell, and sit you fast, For I will hence to Warwick's other daughter;
trg: That, though I want a kingdom, yet in marriage I may not prove inferior to yourself. You that love me and Warwick, follow me.

src: Murder her brothers, and then marry her! Uncertain way of gain! But I am in So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin: Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye. Is thy name Tyrrel?
trg: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

src: O passing traitor, perjured and unjust!
trg: What, Warwick, wilt thou leave the town and fight? Or shall we beat the stones about thine ears?

src: Not with fond shekels of the tested gold, Or stones whose rates are either rich or poor As fancy values them;
trg: but with true prayers That shall be up at heaven and enter there Ere sun-rise, prayers from preserved souls, From fasting maids whose minds are dedicate To nothing temporal.

src: As many vouched rarities are.
trg: That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water.

src: Look, the unfolding star calls up the shepherd. Put not yourself into amazement how these things should be: all difficulties are but easy when they are known.
trg: Call your executioner, and off with Barnardine's head: I will give him a present shrift and advise him for a better place. Yet you are amazed; but this shall absolutely resolve you. Come away;

src: They are at hand, and you shall quickly know.
trg: Go, trumpet, to the walls, and sound a parle.

src: You worthy tribunes,--
trg: He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock With rigorous hands: he hath resisted law, And therefore law shall scorn him further trial Than the severity of the public power Which he so sets at nought.

src: And leave out thee? stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me. The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul! Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou livest, And take deep traitors for thy dearest friends!
trg: No sleep close up that deadly eye of thine, Unless it be whilst some tormenting dream Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils! Thou elvish-mark'd, abortive, rooting hog!

src: I am for you.
trg: Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.

src: Barely in title, not in revenue.
trg: Richly in both, if justice had her right.

src: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.
trg: Hast thou that holy feeling in thy soul, To counsel me to make my peace with God, And art thou yet to thy own soul so blind, That thou wilt war with God by murdering me?

src: You may go to the devil's dam: your gifts are so good, here's none will hold you. Their love is not so great, Hortensio, but we may blow our nails together, and fast it fairly out:
trg: our cakes dough on both sides. Farewell: yet for the love I bear my sweet Bianca, if I can by any means light on a fit man to teach her that wherein she delights, I will wish him to her father.

src: Nay, bear three daughters: by your leave I speak it, You love the breeder better than the male. But what art thou, whose heavy looks foretell Some dreadful story hanging on thy tongue?
trg: Ah, one that was a woful looker-on When as the noble Duke of York was slain, Your princely father and my loving lord!

src: for, as you know, Master Froth, I could not give you three-pence again.
trg: No, indeed.

src: Our archers shall be placed in the midst John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey, Shall have the leading of this foot and horse.
trg: They thus directed, we will follow In the main battle, whose puissance on either side Shall be well winged with our chiefest horse. This, and Saint George to boot! What think'st thou, Norfolk?

src: Rise up, good aunt.
trg: Not yet, I thee beseech: For ever will I walk upon my knees, And never see day that the happy sees, Till thou give joy; until thou bid me joy, By pardoning Rutland, my transgressing boy.

src: Relent, and save your souls.
trg: Relent! 'tis cowardly and womanish.

src: It is not yet near day. Come, go with me; Under our tents I'll play the eaves-dropper, To see if any mean to shrink from me.
trg: Good morrow, Richmond!

src: What might I have been, Might I a son and daughter now have look'd on, Such goodly things as you!
trg: Most noble sir, That which I shall report will bear no credit, Were not the proof so nigh. Please you, great sir, Bohemia greets you from himself by me;

src: You are a pair of strange ones.
trg: Come, come, you are well understood to be a perfecter giber for the table than a necessary bencher in the Capitol.

src: I love no chiders, sir. Biondello, let's away.
trg: Well begun, Tranio.

src: What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night So stumblest on my counsel?
trg: By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am: My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself, Because it is an enemy to thee; Had I it written, I would tear the word.

src: Darraign your battle, for they are at hand.
trg: I would your highness would depart the field: The queen hath best success when you are absent.

src: Stanley, look to your wife; if she convey Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.
trg: What says your highness to my just demand?
The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabour More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue From every meaner man.

src: How far off lie these armies?
trg: Within this mile and half.

src: but that our feasts In every mess have folly and the feeders Digest it with a custom, I should blush To see you so attired, sworn, I think, To show myself a glass.
trg: I bless the time When my good falcon made her flight across Thy father's ground.

src: Thou wast never with me for any thing when thou wast not there for the goose.
trg: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.

src: Go to, go to: no matter for the dish, sir.
trg: No, indeed, sir, not of a pin; you are therein in the right: but to the point. As I say, this Mistress Elbow, being, as I say, with child, and being great-bellied, and longing, as I said, for prunes;

src: Where? at the senate-house?
trg: There, Coriolanus.

src: Now thy proud neck bears half my burthen'd yoke; From which even here I slip my weary neck, And leave the burthen of it all on thee. Farewell, York's wife, and queen of sad mischance:
trg: These English woes will make me smile in France.

src: God and our innocency defend and guard us!
trg: Be patient, they are friends, Ratcliff and Lovel.

src: As many as you please.
trg: Bring me to hear them speak, where I may be concealed.

src: Well you deserve: they well deserve to have, That know the strong'st and surest way to get. Uncle, give me your hands: nay, dry your eyes; Tears show their love, but want their remedies.
trg: Cousin, I am too young to be your father, Though you are old enough to be my heir. What you will have, I'll give, and willing too; For do we must what force will have us do.

src: Hag-seed, hence! Fetch us in fuel; and be quick, thou'rt best, To answer other business. Shrug'st thou, malice?
trg: If thou neglect'st or dost unwillingly What I command, I'll rack thee with old cramps, Fill all thy bones with aches, make thee roar That beasts shall tremble at thy din.

src: Thou'rt i' the right, girl; more o, that.
trg: That in the captain's but a choleric word, Which in the soldier is flat blasphemy.

src: Yours, if you talk of tails: and so farewell.
trg: What, with my tongue in your tail? nay, come again, Good Kate; I am a gentleman.

src: Hence from Verona art thou banished: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.
trg: There is no world without Verona walls, But purgatory, torture, hell itself. Hence-banished is banish'd from the world, And world's exile is death: then banished, Is death mis-term'd:

src: Very well met, and well come. What is the news from this good deputy?
trg: He hath a garden circummured with brick, Whose western side is with a vineyard back'd; And to that vineyard is a planched gate, That makes his opening with this bigger key:

src: Just opposite to what thou justly seem'st, A damned saint, an honourable villain!
trg: O nature, what hadst thou to do in hell, When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend In moral paradise of such sweet flesh? Was ever book containing such vile matter So fairly bound?

src: I' the shoulder and i' the left arm there will be large cicatrices to show the people, when he shall stand for his place. He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts i' the body.
trg: One i' the neck, and two i' the thigh,--there's nine that I know.

src: Your heart is full of something that does take Your mind from feasting. Sooth, when I was young And handed love as you do, I was wont To load my she with knacks:
trg: I would have ransack'd The pedlar's silken treasury and have pour'd it To her acceptance; you have let him go And nothing marted with him.

src: Then have at you with my wit! I will dry-beat you with an iron wit, and put up my iron dagger. Answer me like men:
trg: 'When griping grief the heart doth wound, And doleful dumps the mind oppress, Then music with her silver sound'-- why 'silver sound'? why 'music with her silver sound'? What say you, Simon Catling?

src: True; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels, are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push Montague's men from the wall, and thrust his maids to the wall.
trg: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.

src: If thou do pardon, whosoever pray, More sins for this forgiveness prosper may. This fester'd joint cut off, the rest rest sound; This let alone will all the rest confound.
trg: O king, believe not this hard-hearted man! Love loving not itself none other can.

src: for I saw her, As I thought, dead, and have in vain said many A prayer upon her grave. I'll not seek far-- For him, I partly know his mind--to find thee An honourable husband.
trg: Come, Camillo, And take her by the hand, whose worth and honesty Is richly noted and here justified By us, a pair of kings. Let's from this place. What! look upon my brother:

src: What stratagems, how fell, how butcherly, Erroneous, mutinous and unnatural, This deadly quarrel daily doth beget!
trg: O boy, thy father gave thee life too soon, And hath bereft thee of thy life too late!

src: Then strike up drums: God and Saint George for us!
trg: How now! what news?

src: Your ships are stay'd at Venice, and the duke, For private quarrel 'twixt your duke and him, Hath publish'd and proclaim'd it openly:
trg: 'Tis, marvel, but that you are but newly come, You might have heard it else proclaim'd about.

src: I thought, by your readiness in the office, you had continued in it some time. You say, seven years together?
trg: And a half, sir.

src: His name that valiant duke hath left with thee; His dukedom and his chair with me is left.
trg: Nay, if thou be that princely eagle's bird, Show thy descent by gazing 'gainst the sun: For chair and dukedom, throne and kingdom say; Either that is thine, or else thou wert not his.

src: Mark his condition and the event; then tell me If this might be a brother.
trg: I should sin To think but nobly of my grandmother: Good wombs have borne bad sons.

src: A beggar, brother?
trg: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give; And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

src: Mark'd you his lip and eyes?
trg: Nay. but his taunts.

src: Nay! prithee, woman,--
trg: Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome, And occupations perish!

src: That I must yield my body to the earth And, by my fall, the conquest to my foe.
trg: These eyes, that now are dimm'd with death's black veil, Have been as piercing as the mid-day sun, To search the secret treasons of the world:

src: having both the key Of officer and office, set all hearts i' the state To what tune pleased his ear; that now he was The ivy which had hid my princely trunk, And suck'd my verdure out on't.
trg: Thou attend'st not.

src: You are pleasant, sir, and speak apace.
trg: Why, what a ruthless thing is this in him, for the rebellion of a codpiece to take away the life of a man! Would the duke that is absent have done this?

src: No, indeed.
trg: Very well: you being then, if you be remembered, cracking the stones of the foresaid prunes,--

src: Comfort, my liege; why looks your grace so pale?
trg: But now the blood of twenty thousand men Did triumph in my face, and they are fled; And, till so much blood thither come again, Have I not reason to look pale and dead?
Who's that which calls?

src: It shall be so, it shall be so; let him away: He's banish'd, and it shall be so.
trg: Hear me, my masters, and my common friends,--

src: Thanks, brave Montgomery; and thanks unto you all: If fortune serve me, I'll requite this kindness. Now, for this night, let's harbour here in York;
trg: And when the morning sun shall raise his car Above the border of this horizon, We'll forward towards Warwick and his mates; For well I wot that Henry is no soldier. Ah, froward Clarence!

src: I prithee, hear me speak.
trg: You speak too bitterly.

src: Thy mother was a piece of virtue, and She said thou wast my daughter; and thy father Was Duke of Milan; and thou his only heir And princess no worse issued.
trg: O the heavens! What foul play had we, that we came from thence? Or blessed was't we did?

src: one fruitful meal would set me to 't. But they say the duke will be here to-morrow. By my troth, Isabel, I loved thy brother:
trg: if the old fantastical duke of dark corners had been at home, he had lived.

src: Ay, that Petruchio came.
trg: No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.

src: In common worldly things, 'tis call'd ungrateful, With dull unwilligness to repay a debt Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent;
trg: Much more to be thus opposite with heaven, For it requires the royal debt it lent you.

src: His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.
trg: You'll leave his lecture when I am in tune?

src: Away! let's go learn the truth of it.
trg: Thus, what with the war, what with the sweat, what with the gallows and what with poverty, I am custom-shrunk. How now! what's the news with you?

src: It is a kind of history.
trg: Well, well see't. Come, madam wife, sit by my side and let the world slip: we shall ne'er be younger.

src: nothing but cross'd!
trg: Say as he says, or we shall never go.

src: What have you to do here, fellow? Pray you, avoid the house.
trg: Let me but stand; I will not hurt your hearth.

src: Ay, this is he that took King Henry's chair, And this is he was his adopted heir. But how is it that great Plantagenet Is crown'd so soon, and broke his solemn oath?
trg: As I bethink me, you should not be king Till our King Henry had shook hands with death.

src: Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous, By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams, To set my brother Clarence and the king In deadly hate the one against the other: Dive, thoughts, down to my soul:
trg: here Clarence comes. Brother, good day; what means this armed guard That waits upon your grace?

src: Why, that's my fortune too; therefore I'll stay.
trg: Be it with resolution then to fight.

src: O, sir, you are deceived.
trg: 'Tis not possible.

src: O thou damnable fellow! Did not I pluck thee by the nose for thy speeches?
trg: I protest I love the duke as I love myself.

src: I pray thee, good Camillo, be no more importunate: 'tis a sickness denying thee any thing; a death to grant this.
trg: It is fifteen years since I saw my country: though I have for the most part been aired abroad, I desire to lay my bones there. Besides, the penitent king, my master, hath sent for me;

src: Sir, understand you this of me in sooth:
trg: The youngest daughter whom you hearken for Her father keeps from all access of suitors, And will not promise her to any man Until the elder sister first be wed:

src: Take not, good cousin, further than you should. Lest you mistake the heavens are o'er our heads.
trg: I know it, uncle, and oppose not myself Against their will. But who comes here? Welcome, Harry: what, will not this castle yield?

src: In that you brook it in, it makes him worse: Therefore, for God's sake, entertain good comfort, And cheer his grace with quick and merry words.
trg: If he were dead, what would betide of me?

src: No longer Earl of March, but Duke of York: The next degree is England's royal throne; For King of England shalt thou be proclaim'd In every borough as we pass along;
trg: And he that throws not up his cap for joy Shall for the fault make forfeit of his head.

src: Your temples burned in their cement, and Your franchises, whereon you stood, confined Into an auger's bore.
trg: Pray now, your news? You have made fair work, I fear me.--Pray, your news?-- If Marcius should be join'd with Volscians,--

src: Speak briefly then; For we are peremptory to dispatch This viperous traitor: to eject him hence Were but one danger, and to keep him here Our certain death: therefore it is decreed He dies to-night.
trg: Now the good gods forbid That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude Towards her deserved children is enroll'd In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam Should now eat up her own!

src: I think I have done myself wrong, have I not?
trg: Yes, that thou hast, whether thou art tainted or free.

src: That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water.
trg: If but one of his pockets could speak, would it not say he lies?

src: O place, O form, How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit, Wrench awe from fools and tie the wiser souls To thy false seeming! Blood, thou art blood: Let's write good angel on the devil's horn:
trg: 'Tis not the devil's crest. How now! who's there?

src: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in. Where is the life that late I led-- Where are those--Sit down, Kate, and welcome.-- Sound, sound, sound, sound! Why, when, I say?
trg: Nay, good sweet Kate, be merry. Off with my boots, you rogues! you villains, when? It was the friar of orders grey, As he forth walked on his way:-- Out, you rogue! you pluck my foot awry:

src: I am glad at heart To be so rid o' the business.
trg: Come, poor babe: I have heard, but not believed, the spirits o' the dead May walk again: if such thing be, thy mother Appear'd to me last night, for ne'er was dream So like a waking.

src: The cruelty and envy of the people, Permitted by our dastard nobles, who Have all forsook me, hath devour'd the rest; And suffer'd me by the voice of slaves to be Whoop'd out of Rome.
trg: Now this extremity Hath brought me to thy hearth;

src: calling death banishment, Thou cutt'st my head off with a golden axe, And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.
trg: O deadly sin! O rude unthankfulness! Thy fault our law calls death; but the kind prince, Taking thy part, hath rush'd aside the law, And turn'd that black word death to banishment:

src: O, belike it is the Bishop of Carlisle.
trg: Noble lords, Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle; Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley Into his ruin'd ears, and thus deliver:

src: I have so; because it is an open room and good for winter.
trg: Why, very well, then; I hope here be truths.

src: What he cannot help in his nature, you account a vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.
trg: If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations; he hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition. What shouts are these? The other side o' the city is risen: why stay we prating here?

src: Not of this country, though my chance is now To use it for my time: I am a brother Of gracious order, late come from the See In special business from his holiness.
trg: What news abroad i' the world?

src: Farewell, sweet lords: let's meet at Coventry.
trg: Here at the palace I will rest awhile. Cousin of Exeter, what thinks your lordship? Methinks the power that Edward hath in field Should not be able to encounter mine.

src: My brother had but justice, In that he did the thing for which he died: For Angelo, His act did not o'ertake his bad intent, And must be buried but as an intent That perish'd by the way:
trg: thoughts are no subjects; Intents but merely thoughts.

src: Call them forth.
trg: Do you hear, ho? you must meet my master to countenance my mistress.

src: Who taught you this?
trg: I learnt it out of women's faces. Pray now What colour are your eyebrows?

src: Farewell! God knows when we shall meet again. I have a faint cold fear thrills through my veins, That almost freezes up the heat of life: I'll call them back again to comfort me: Nurse!
trg: What should she do here? My dismal scene I needs must act alone. Come, vial. What if this mixture do not work at all? Shall I be married then to-morrow morning? No, no: this shall forbid it:

src: Merely awry: when he did love his country, It honour'd him.
trg: The service of the foot Being once gangrened, is not then respected For what before it was.

src: God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, Nearer in bloody thoughts, but not in blood, Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, And yet go current from suspicion!
trg: A boon, my sovereign, for my service done!

src: Weeping and wailing over Tybalt's corse: Will you go to them? I will bring you thither.
trg: Wash they his wounds with tears: mine shall be spent, When theirs are dry, for Romeo's banishment. Take up those cords: poor ropes, you are beguiled, Both you and I; for Romeo is exiled:

src: My good Camillo, She is as forward of her breeding as She is i' the rear our birth.
trg: I cannot say 'tis pity She lacks instructions, for she seems a mistress To most that teach.

src: My Lord of Norfolk,--
trg: Here, most gracious liege.

src: Not since widow Dido's time.
trg: Widow! a pox o' that! How came that widow in? widow Dido!

src: Hark, hark, my lord! what shouts are these?
trg: Seize on the shame-faced Henry, bear him hence; And once again proclaim us King of England. You are the fount that makes small brooks to flow: Now stops thy spring;

src: Call it so.
trg: Away, sir! you must go.

src: Sweet York, sweet husband, be not of that mind: He is as like thee as a man may be, Not like to me, or any of my kin, And yet I love him.
trg: Make way, unruly woman!

src: No, madam.
trg: Nay, but you will?

src: Do they still fly to the Roman?
trg: I do not know what witchcraft's in him, but Your soldiers use him as the grace 'fore meat, Their talk at table, and their thanks at end; And you are darken'd in this action, sir, Even by your own.

src: Not unlike, Each way, to better yours.
trg: Why then should I be consul? By yond clouds, Let me deserve so ill as you, and make me Your fellow tribune.

src: Not in a grave, To lay one in, another out to have.
trg: I pray thee, chide not; she whom I love now Doth grace for grace and love for love allow; The other did not so.

src: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.
trg: What, in the midst of the street?

src: Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.
trg: Some dungeon.

src: I say, thou liest, And will maintain what thou hast said is false In thy heart-blood, though being all too base To stain the temper of my knightly sword.
trg: Bagot, forbear; thou shalt not take it up.

src: More light and light; more dark and dark our woes!
trg: Madam!

src: Would you enforce me to a world of care? Well, call them again. I am not made of stone, But penetrable to your. kind entreats, Albeit against my conscience and my soul.
trg: Cousin of Buckingham, and you sage, grave men, Since you will buckle fortune on my back, To bear her burthen, whether I will or no, I must have patience to endure the load:

src: Then know, that from my soul I love thy daughter.
trg: My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.

src: Whereto we are bound, together with thy victory, Whereto we are bound? alack, or we must lose The country, our dear nurse, or else thy person, Our comfort in the country.
trg: We must find An evident calamity, though we had Our wish, which side should win: For myself, son, I purpose not to wait on fortune till These wars determine:

src: Hast thou read truth?
trg: Ay, my lord; even so As it is here set down.

src: Brother of Gloucester, at Saint Alban's field This lady's husband, Sir Richard Grey, was slain, His lands then seized on by the conqueror: Her suit is now to repossess those lands;
trg: Which we in justice cannot well deny, Because in quarrel of the house of York The worthy gentleman did lose his life.

src: A Bohemian born, but here nursed un and bred; one that is a prisoner nine years old.
trg: How came it that the absent duke had not either delivered him to his liberty or executed him? I have heard it was ever his manner to do so.

src: as I have seen a swan With bootless labour swim against the tide And spend her strength with over-matching waves. Ah, hark! the fatal followers do pursue; And I am faint and cannot fly their fury:
trg: And were I strong, I would not shun their fury: The sands are number'd that make up my life; Here must I stay, and here my life must end.

src: No, sir: yet oft, When blows have made me stay, I fled from words. You soothed not, therefore hurt not: but your people, I love them as they weigh.
trg: Pray now, sit down.

src: Only their ends You have respected; stopp'd your ears against The general suit of Rome; never admitted A private whisper, no, not with such friends That thought them sure of you.
trg: This last old man, Whom with a crack'd heart I have sent to Rome, Loved me above the measure of a father; Nay, godded me, indeed. Their latest refuge Was to send him;

src: And yet we should, for perpetuity, Go hence in debt: and therefore, like a cipher, Yet standing in rich place, I multiply With one 'We thank you' many thousands moe That go before it.
trg: Stay your thanks a while; And pay them when you part.

src: And what hear there for welcome but my groans? Therefore commend me; let him not come there, To seek out sorrow that dwells every where. Desolate, desolate, will I hence and die:
trg: The last leave of thee takes my weeping eye.

src: Ay, and old York, and yet not satisfied.
trg: For God's sake, lords, give signal to the fight.

src: They call for dates and quinces in the pastry.
trg: Come, stir, stir, stir! the second cock hath crow'd, The curfew-bell hath rung, 'tis three o'clock: Look to the baked meats, good Angelica: Spare not for the cost.

src: Then leave me not, my lords; be resolute; I mean to take possession of my right.
trg: Neither the king, nor he that loves him best, The proudest he that holds up Lancaster, Dares stir a wing, if Warwick shake his bells. I'll plant Plantagenet, root him up who dares:

src: By and by, I come:-- To cease thy suit, and leave me to my grief: To-morrow will I send.
trg: So thrive my soul--

src: Come, we'll inform them Of our proceedings here: on the marketplace, I know, they do attend us.
trg: Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to deny him.

src: Nay, if there be no remedy for it, but that you will needs buy and sell men and women like beasts, we shall have all the world drink brown and white bastard.
trg: O heavens! what stuff is here

src: So.
trg: Either thou wilt die, by God's just ordinance, Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror, Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish And never look upon thy face again.

src: Why, very well, then; I hope here be truths.
