trg: This will last out a night in Russia, When nights are longest there: I'll take my leave. And leave you to the hearing of the cause; Hoping you'll find good cause to whip them all.

src: I think so. Kill'd! She I kill'd! I did so: but thou strikest me Sorely, to say I did; it is as bitter Upon thy tongue as in my thought: now, good now, Say so but seldom.
trg: Not at all, good lady: You might have spoken a thousand things that would Have done the time more benefit and graced Your kindness better.

src: Why that way?
trg: To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return for conscience sake, to help to get thee a wife.

src: Good morning to you, fair and gracious daughter.
trg: The better, given me by so holy a man. Hath yet the deputy sent my brother's pardon?

src: Tends that thou wouldst speak to the Duke of Hereford? If it be so, out with it boldly, man; Quick is mine ear to hear of good towards him.
trg: No good at all that I can do for him; Unless you call it good to pity him, Bereft and gelded of his patrimony.

src: as cunning in Greek, Latin, and other languages, as the other in music and mathematics: his name is Cambio; pray, accept his service.
trg: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio. Welcome, good Cambio. But, gentle sir, methinks you walk like a stranger: may I be so bold to know the cause of your coming?

src: Fear not, my lord: that Power that made you king Hath power to keep you king in spite of all. The means that heaven yields must be embraced, And not neglected;
trg: else, if heaven would, And we will not, heaven's offer we refuse, The proffer'd means of succor and redress.

src: That Shall be when your first queen's again in breath; Never till then.
trg: One that gives out himself Prince Florizel, Son of Polixenes, with his princess, she The fairest I have yet beheld, desires access To your high presence.

src: I have seen them in the church together: God send 'em good shipping! But who is here? mine old master Vincentio! now we are undone and brought to nothing.
No, by my troth, my lord.
trg: Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?

src: but I know thou art no tall fellow of thy hands and that thou wilt be drunk: but I'll swear it, and I would thou wouldst be a tall fellow of thy hands.
trg: I will prove so, sir, to my power.

src: For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.
trg: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?

src: 'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, When men are unprepared and look not for it.
trg: O monstrous, monstrous! and so falls it out With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: and so 'twill do With some men else, who think themselves as safe As thou and I;

src: Where is the king?
trg: What means our cousin, that he stares and looks So wildly?

src: Believe me, on mine honour, My words express my purpose.
trg: Ha! little honour to be much believed, And most pernicious purpose! Seeming, seeming! I will proclaim thee, Angelo; look for't:

src: Hear a little further And then I'll bring thee to the present business Which now's upon's; without the which this story Were most impertinent.
trg: Wherefore did they not That hour destroy us?

src: Thyself thyself misusest.
trg: Why then, by God--

src: Heaven grant us its peace, but not the King of Hungary's!
trg: Amen.

src: My gracious lord, I'll tell him what you say.
trg: Many good morrows to my noble lord!

src: yet look up, behold, That you in pity may dissolve to dew, And wash him fresh again with true-love tears.
trg: Ah, thou, the model where old Troy did stand, Thou map of honour, thou King Richard's tomb, And not King Richard;

src: Then all too late comes counsel to be heard, Where will doth mutiny with wit's regard. Direct not him whose way himself will choose: 'Tis breath thou lack'st, and that breath wilt thou lose.
trg: Methinks I am a prophet new inspired And thus expiring do foretell of him: His rash fierce blaze of riot cannot last, For violent fires soon burn out themselves;

src: Norfolk, for thee remains a heavier doom, Which I with some unwillingness pronounce: The sly slow hours shall not determinate The dateless limit of thy dear exile;
trg: The hopeless word of 'never to return' Breathe I against thee, upon pain of life.

src: Whoever gave that counsel, to give forth The corn o' the storehouse gratis, as 'twas used Sometime in Greece,--
trg: Well, well, no more of that.

src: So thrive I, as I truly swear the like!
trg: Take heed you dally not before your king; Lest he that is the supreme King of kings Confound your hidden falsehood, and award Either of you to be the other's end.

src: For aught I know, my lord, they do.
trg: You will be there, I know.

src: Having waste ground enough, Shall we desire to raze the sanctuary And pitch our evils there? O, fie, fie, fie! What dost thou, or what art thou, Angelo?
trg: Dost thou desire her foully for those things That make her good? O, let her brother live! Thieves for their robbery have authority When judges steal themselves.

src: How now! which of your hips has the most profound sciatica?
trg: Well, well; there's one yonder arrested and carried to prison was worth five thousand of you all.

src: Sir Thomas Lovel and Lord Marquis Dorset, 'Tis said, my liege, in Yorkshire are in arms. Yet this good comfort bring I to your grace, The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest:
trg: Richmond, in Yorkshire, sent out a boat Unto the shore, to ask those on the banks If they were his assistants, yea or no; Who answer'd him, they came from Buckingham. Upon his party:

src: Curse not thyself, fair creature thou art both.
trg: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.

src: You gods, look down And from your sacred vials pour your graces Upon my daughter's head! Tell me, mine own. Where hast thou been preserved? where lived? how found Thy father's court?
trg: for thou shalt hear that I, Knowing by Paulina that the oracle Gave hope thou wast in being, have preserved Myself to see the issue.

src: A bloody deed, and desperately dispatch'd! How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my hands Of this most grievous guilty murder done!
trg: How now! what mean'st thou, that thou help'st me not? By heavens, the duke shall know how slack thou art!

src: ' And thus I took the vantage of those few, 'Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,' quoth I; 'This general applause and loving shout Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard:
trg: ' And even here brake off, and came away.

src: this satisfaction The by-gone day proclaim'd: say this to him, He's beat from his best ward.
trg: Well said, Hermione.

src: If I had a mind to be honest, I see Fortune would not suffer me: she drops booties in my mouth. I am courted now with a double occasion, gold and a means to do the prince my master good;
trg: which who knows how that may turn back to my advancement? I will bring these two moles, these blind ones, aboard him:

src: We still have known thee for a holy man. Where's Romeo's man? what can he say in this?
trg: I brought my master news of Juliet's death; And then in post he came from Mantua To this same place, to this same monument.

src: Had I been any god of power, I would Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere It should the good ship so have swallow'd and The fraughting souls within her.
trg: Be collected: No more amazement: tell your piteous heart There's no harm done.

src: Go play, Mamillius; thou'rt an honest man. Camillo, this great sir will yet stay longer.
trg: You had much ado to make his anchor hold: When you cast out, it still came home.

src: Farewell, my Hector, and my Troy's true hope.
trg: In sign of truth, I kiss your highness' hand.

src: Say, you ne'er had done't-- Harp on that still--but by our putting on; And presently, when you have drawn your number, Repair to the Capitol.
trg: We will so: almost all Repent in their election.

src: I'll not be by the while: my liege, farewell: What will ensue hereof, there's none can tell; But by bad courses may be understood That their events can never fall out good.
trg: Go, Bushy, to the Earl of Wiltshire straight: Bid him repair to us to Ely House To see this business. To-morrow next We will for Ireland; and 'tis time, I trow:

src: while life upholds this arm, This arm upholds the house of Lancaster.
trg: And I the house of York.

src: When steel grows soft as the parasite's silk, Let him be made a coverture for the wars! No more, I say! For that I have not wash'd My nose that bled, or foil'd some debile wretch.
trg: -- Which, without note, here's many else have done,-- You shout me forth In acclamations hyperbolical; As if I loved my little should be dieted In praises sauced with lies.

src: To see his nobleness! Leave me solely: go, See how he fares. Fie, fie! no thought of him: The thought of my revenges that way Recoil upon me: in himself too mighty, And in his parties, his alliance;
trg: let him be Until a time may serve: for present vengeance, Take it on her. Camillo and Polixenes Laugh at me, make their pastime at my sorrow:

src: Nay, I will give thee a kiss: now pray thee, love, stay.
trg: Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate: Better once than never, for never too late.

src: Throng our large temples with the shows of peace, And not our streets with war!
trg: Amen, amen.

src: The hour's now come; The very minute bids thee ope thine ear; Obey and be attentive. Canst thou remember A time before we came unto this cell?
trg: I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not Out three years old.

src: As so defend thee heaven and thy valour!
trg: My name is Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk; Who hither come engaged by my oath-- Which God defend a knight should violate! And as I truly fight, defend me heaven!

src: Catesby, o'erlook the walls.
trg: Lord mayor, the reason we have sent--

src: Well have we pass'd and now repass'd the seas And brought desired help from Burgundy:
trg: What then remains, we being thus arrived From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York, But that we enter, as into our dukedom?

src: And so in me; and so, I think, in all: Yet, since it is but green, it should be put To no apparent likelihood of breach, Which haply by much company might be urged:
trg: Therefore I say with noble Buckingham, That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.

src: Name it, fair cousin.
trg: 'Fair cousin'? I am greater than a king: For when I was a king, my flatterers Were then but subjects; being now a subject, I have a king here to my flatterer. Being so great, I have no need to beg.

src: Were it better, I should rush in thus. But where is Kate? where is my lovely bride? How does my father? Gentles, methinks you frown:
trg: And wherefore gaze this goodly company, As if they saw some wondrous monument, Some comet or unusual prodigy?

src: Draw near, Queen Margaret, and be a witness That Bona shall be wife to the English king.
trg: To Edward, but not to the English king.

src: 'Cucullus non facit monachum:' honest in nothing but in his clothes; and one that hath spoke most villanous speeches of the duke.
trg: We shall entreat you to abide here till he come and enforce them against him: we shall find this friar a notable fellow.

src: Well, he may chance to do some good on her: A peevish self-will'd harlotry it is.
trg: See where she comes from shrift with merry look.
Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.

src: Therefore I say with noble Buckingham, That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.
trg: And so say I.

src: Romeo, the hate I bear thee can afford No better term than this,--thou art a villain.
trg: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee Doth much excuse the appertaining rage To such a greeting: villain am I none; Therefore farewell; I see thou know'st me not.

src: A witty mother! witless else her son.
trg: Am I not wise?

src: these, my lord, Are such allow'd infirmities that honesty Is never free of. But, beseech your grace, Be plainer with me; let me know my trespass By its own visage:
trg: if I then deny it, 'Tis none of mine.

src: Well, well, we'll leave you.
trg: Why stay we to be baited With one that wants her wits?

src: Bring forth the gallant, let us hear him speak. What! can so young a thorn begin to prick?
trg: Edward, what satisfaction canst thou make For bearing arms, for stirring up my subjects, And all the trouble thou hast turn'd me to?

src: Come, come, you mock me; this is not the way To win our daughter.
trg: There is no other way Unless thou couldst put on some other shape, And not be Richard that hath done all this.

src: How?
trg: Little.

src: Gentle my lord, turn back.
trg: I will bethink me: come again tomorrow.

src: Why, then he will say we stabbed him sleeping.
trg: The urging of that word 'judgment' hath bred a kind of remorse in me.

src: But how long fairly shall her sweet lie last?
trg: So long as heaven and nature lengthens it.

src: That's a day longer than a wonder lasts.
trg: By so much is the wonder in extremes.

src: Construe them.
trg: 'Hic ibat,' as I told you before, 'Simois,' I am Lucentio, 'hic est,' son unto Vincentio of Pisa, 'Sigeia tellus,' disguised thus to get your love;

src: Now put it, God, in the physician's mind To help him to his grave immediately! The lining of his coffers shall make coats To deck our soldiers for these Irish wars.
trg: Come, gentlemen, let's all go visit him: Pray God we may make haste, and come too late!

src: Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs, And thou shalt reign in quiet while thou livest.
trg: I am content: Richard Plantagenet, Enjoy the kingdom after my decease.

src: Thanks, good Montgomery; but we now forget Our title to the crown and only claim Our dukedom till God please to send the rest.
trg: Then fare you well, for I will hence again: I came to serve a king and not a duke. Drummer, strike up, and let us march away.

src: let their heads be sleekly combed their blue coats brushed and their garters of an indifferent knit:
trg: let them curtsy with their left legs and not presume to touch a hair of my master's horse-tail till they kiss their hands. Are they all ready?

src: Death, that hath suck'd the honey of thy breath, Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty: Thou art not conquer'd;
trg: beauty's ensign yet Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks, And death's pale flag is not advanced there. Tybalt, liest thou there in thy bloody sheet?

src: If your lass Interpretation should abuse and call this Your lack of love or bounty, you were straited For a reply, at least if you make a care Of happy holding her.
trg: Old sir, I know She prizes not such trifles as these are: The gifts she looks from me are pack'd and lock'd Up in my heart; which I have given already, But not deliver'd.

src: This letter he early bid me give his father, And threatened me with death, going in the vault, I departed not and left him there.
trg: Give me the letter; I will look on it. Where is the county's page, that raised the watch? Sirrah, what made your master in this place?

src: Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news!
trg: Be of good cheer: mother, how fares your grace?

src: I cannot weep; for all my body's moisture Scarce serves to quench my furnace-burning heart: Nor can my tongue unload my heart's great burthen;
trg: For selfsame wind that I should speak withal Is kindling coals that fires all my breast, And burns me up with flames that tears would quench. To weep is to make less the depth of grief:

src: What were you snarling all before I came, Ready to catch each other by the throat, And turn you all your hatred now on me? Did York's dread curse prevail so much with heaven?
trg: That Henry's death, my lovely Edward's death, Their kingdom's loss, my woful banishment, Could all but answer for that peevish brat? Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven?

src: I never heard any soldier dislike it.
trg: I believe thee; for I think thou never wast where grace was said.

src: Here, noble lord: what is thy will with her?
trg: Are you my wife and will not call me husband? My men should call me 'lord:' I am your goodman.

src: A bridegroom say you? 'tis a groom indeed, A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.
trg: Curster than she? why, 'tis impossible.

src: I tell thee, We have a power on foot; and I had purpose Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn, Or lose mine arm fort:
trg: thou hast beat me out Twelve several times, and I have nightly since Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me;

src: Look he's winding up the watch of his wit; by and by it will strike.
trg: Sir,--

src: But is this true, sir?
trg: Ay; and you'll look pale Before you find it other. All the regions Do smilingly revolt; and who resist Are mock'd for valiant ignorance, And perish constant fools. Who is't can blame him?

src: I tell you, friends, most charitable care Have the patricians of you. For the dearth, The gods, not the patricians, make it, and Your knees to them, not arms, must help.
trg: Alack, You are transported by calamity Thither where more attends you, and you slander The helms o' the state, who care for you like fathers, When you curse them as enemies.

src: Madam, his majesty doth call for you, And for your grace; and you, my noble lords.
trg: Catesby, we come. Lords, will you go with us?

src: Now, sir, is your name Menenius?
trg: 'Tis a spell, you see, of much power: you know the way home again.

src: I pray the gods she may with all my heart!
trg: Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone. Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way? Welcome! one mess is like to be your cheer: Come, sir; we will better it in Pisa.

src: Accept of him, or else you do me wrong: His name is Licio, born in Mantua.
trg: You're welcome, sir; and he, for your good sake. But for my daughter Katharina, this I know, She is not for your turn, the more my grief.

src: Come, bloody Clifford, rough Northumberland, I dare your quenchless fury to more rage: I am your butt, and I abide your shot.
trg: Yield to our mercy, proud Plantagenet.

src: Ay, my lord; even so As it is here set down.
trg: There is no truth at all i' the oracle: The sessions shall proceed: this is mere falsehood.

src: There's not a soldier of us all, that, in the thanksgiving before meat, do relish the petition well that prays for peace.
trg: I never heard any soldier dislike it.

src: How now! what news with you?
trg: My lord, I hear the Marquis Dorset's fled To Richmond, in those parts beyond the sea Where he abides.

src: Why force you this?
trg: Because that now it lies you on to speak To the people;

src: A man, as you are.
trg: But not, as I am, royal.

src: Alas! sir, it is worse for me than so; For I have bills for money by exchange From Florence and must here deliver them.
trg: Well, sir, to do you courtesy, This will I do, and this I will advise you: First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?

src: Alas poor Romeo! he is already dead; stabbed with a white wench's black eye; shot through the ear with a love-song; the very pin of his heart cleft with the blind bow-boy's butt-shaft:
trg: and is he a man to encounter Tybalt?

src: Come, my captain knows you not.
trg: I mean, thy general.

src: A most unworthy and unnatural lord Can do no more.
trg: I'll ha' thee burnt.

src: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.
trg: Now, by my George, my garter, and my crown,--

src: Ay, my good lord; and no one in this presence But his red colour hath forsook his cheeks.
trg: Is Clarence dead? the order was reversed.

src: In bed asleep, while they do dream things true.
trg: O, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.

src: Peace, ho, for shame! confusion's cure lives not In these confusions. Heaven and yourself Had part in this fair maid; now heaven hath all, And all the better is it for the maid:
trg: Your part in her you could not keep from death, But heaven keeps his part in eternal life. The most you sought was her promotion; For 'twas your heaven she should be advanced:

src: Poor heart, adieu! I pity thy complaining.
trg: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.

src: but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him. I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man;
trg: but, I'll warrant you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal world. Doth not rosemary and Romeo begin both with a letter?

src: I warrant, an I should live a thousand years, I never should forget it: 'Wilt thou not, Jule?' quoth he; And, pretty fool, it stinted and said 'Ay.'
trg: Enough of this; I pray thee, hold thy peace.

src: What then?
trg: He is coming.

src: 'Tis this slave;-- Go whip him, 'fore the people's eyes:--his raising; Nothing but his report.
trg: Yes, worthy sir, The slave's report is seconded; and more, More fearful, is deliver'd.

src: And in conclusion she shall watch all night: And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawl And with the clamour keep her still awake. This is a way to kill a wife with kindness;
trg: And thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humour. He that knows better how to tame a shrew, Now let him speak: 'tis charity to show.

src: What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?
trg: That he was never trained up in arms.

src: Not so well apparell'd As I wish you were.
trg: Were it better, I should rush in thus. But where is Kate? where is my lovely bride? How does my father? Gentles, methinks you frown:

src: Accursed and unquiet wrangling days, How many of you have mine eyes beheld! My husband lost his life to get the crown;
trg: And often up and down my sons were toss'd, For me to joy and weep their gain and loss: And being seated, and domestic broils Clean over-blown, themselves, the conquerors. Make war upon themselves;

src: Isabel, Sweet Isabel, do yet but kneel by me; Hold up your hands, say nothing; I'll speak all. They say, best men are moulded out of faults;
trg: And, for the most, become much more the better For being a little bad: so may my husband. O Isabel, will you not lend a knee?

src: Happily we met; the happier for thy son. And now by law, as well as reverend age, I may entitle thee my loving father: The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman, Thy son by this hath married.
trg: Wonder not, Nor be grieved: she is of good esteem, Her dowery wealthy, and of worthy birth; Beside, so qualified as may beseem The spouse of any noble gentleman.

src: So come to you and yours, as to this Prince!
trg: Where's Richard gone?

src: If ancient sorrow be most reverend, Give mine the benefit of seniory, And let my woes frown on the upper hand. If sorrow can admit society, Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine:
trg: I had an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him; I had a Harry, till a Richard kill'd him: Thou hadst an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him; Thou hadst a Richard, till a Richard killed him;

src: The brother blindly shed the brother's blood, The father rashly slaughter'd his own son, The son, compell'd, been butcher to the sire:
trg: All this divided York and Lancaster, Divided in their dire division, O, now, let Richmond and Elizabeth, The true succeeders of each royal house, By God's fair ordinance conjoin together!

src: He's a disease that must be cut away.
trg: O, he's a limb that has but a disease; Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy. What has he done to Rome that's worthy death?

src: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I warrant, a virtuous,--Where is your mother?
trg: Where is my mother! why, she is within; Where should she be? How oddly thou repliest! 'Your love says, like an honest gentleman, Where is your mother?'

src: And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament, We will unite the white rose and the red: Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction, That long have frown'd upon their enmity!
trg: What traitor hears me, and says not amen? England hath long been mad, and scarr'd herself;

src: Why, how now, long-tongued Warwick! dare you speak? When you and I met at Saint Alban's last, Your legs did better service than your hands.
trg: Then 'twas my turn to fly, and now 'tis thine.

src: If I thought that, I tell thee, homicide, These nails should rend that beauty from my cheeks.
trg: These eyes could never endure sweet beauty's wreck; You should not blemish it, if I stood by: As all the world is cheered by the sun, So I by that; it is my day, my life.

src: If ever I was respected with her, or she with me, let not your worship think me the poor duke's officer. Prove this, thou wicked Hannibal, or I'll have mine action of battery on thee.
trg: If he took you a box o' the ear, you might have your action of slander too.

src: The heavens give safety to your purposes!
trg: Lead forth and bring you back in happiness!

src: Let's to the Capitol; And carry with us ears and eyes for the time, But hearts for the event.
trg: Have with you.

src: To London, all in post; and, as I guess, To make a bloody supper in the Tower.
trg: He's sudden, if a thing comes in his head. Now march we hence: discharge the common sort With pay and thanks, and let's away to London And see our gentle queen how well she fares:

src: Apollo's angry; and the heavens themselves Do strike at my injustice. How now there!
trg: This news is mortal to the queen: look down And see what death is doing.

src: If that shepherd be not in hand-fast, let him fly: the curses he shall have, the tortures he shall feel, will break the back of man, the heart of monster.
trg: Think you so, sir?

src: For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long, But send him back.
And, as my fortune ripens with thy love, It shall be still thy true love's recompense: My heart this covenant makes, my hand thus seals it.
trg: How far is it to Berkeley? and what stir Keeps good old York there with his men of war?

src: Good morrow to you both. What counterfeit did I give you?
trg: The ship, sir, the slip; can you not conceive?

src: Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.
trg: But thine doth fry. Skipper, stand back: 'tis age that nourisheth.

src: First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnished with plate and gold; Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry;
trg: In ivory coffers I have stuff'd my crowns; then, at my farm I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail, Sixscore fat oxen standing in my stalls, And all things answerable to this portion.

src: Knows he of this?
trg: He neither does nor shall.

src: Was never widow had so dear a loss!
trg: Were never orphans had so dear a loss!

src: It is a man's voice. Gentle Isabella, Turn you the key, and know his business of him; You may, I may not; you are yet unsworn.
trg: When you have vow'd, you must not speak with men But in the presence of the prioress: Then, if you speak, you must not show your face, Or, if you show your face, you must not speak. He calls again;

src: I did not, sir: These lords, my noble fellows, if they please, Can clear me in't.
trg: We can: my royal liege, He is not guilty of her coming hither.

src: Farewell, sweet masters both; I must be gone.
trg: Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.

src: How far is it, my lord, to Berkeley now?
trg: Believe me, noble lord, I am a stranger here in Gloucestershire:

src: What?
trg: Well, thou hast comforted me marvellous much. Go in: and tell my lady I am gone, Having displeased my father, to Laurence' cell, To make confession and to be absolved.

src: Farewell, ancient lady; farewell, 'lady, lady, lady.'
trg: Marry, farewell! I pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this, that was so full of his ropery?

src: Depress'd he is already, and deposed 'Tis doubt he will be: letters came last night To a dear friend of the good Duke of York's, That tell black tidings.
trg: O, I am press'd to death through want of speaking! Thou, old Adam's likeness, set to dress this garden, How dares thy harsh rude tongue sound this unpleasing news?

src: Nor you, as we are, loyal.
trg: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.

src: The service of the foot Being once gangrened, is not then respected For what before it was.
trg: We'll hear no more. Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence: Lest his infection, being of catching nature, Spread further.

src: Forewarn him that he use no scurrilous words in 's tunes.
trg: You have of these pedlars, that have more in them than you'ld think, sister.

src: Come, come, have with you. Wot you what, my lord? To-day the lords you talk of are beheaded.
trg: They, for their truth, might better wear their heads Than some that have accused them wear their hats. But come, my lord, let us away.

src: In what enormity is Marcius poor in, that you two have not in abundance?
trg: He's poor in no one fault, but stored with all.

src: 'Tis a spell, you see, of much power: you know the way home again.
trg: Do you hear how we are shent for keeping your greatness back?

src: Where's Richard gone?
trg: To London, all in post; and, as I guess, To make a bloody supper in the Tower.

src: Rouse up thy youthful blood, be valiant and live.
trg: Mine innocency and Saint George to thrive!

src: Of Pisa, sir; son to Vincentio.
trg: A mighty man of Pisa; by report I know him well: you are very welcome, sir, Take you the lute, and you the set of books; You shall go see your pupils presently. Holla, within!

src: This is another prisoner that I saved. Who should have died when Claudio lost his head; As like almost to Claudio as himself.
Yet in this life Lie hid moe thousand deaths: yet death we fear, That makes these odds all even.
trg: I humbly thank you. To sue to live, I find I seek to die; And, seeking death, find life: let it come on.

src: Why, so you are, my thrice renowned liege.
trg: Ha! am I king? 'tis so: but Edward lives.

src: Why, then thou shalt not have thy husband's lands.
trg: Why, then mine honesty shall be my dower; For by that loss I will not purchase them.

src: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee, Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.
trg: Look, what is done cannot be now amended: Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes, Which after hours give leisure to repent.

src: Deposed he shall be, in despite of all.
trg: Thou art deceived: 'tis not thy southern power, Of Essex, Norfolk, Suffolk, nor of Kent, Which makes thee thus presumptuous and proud, Can set the duke up in despite of me.

src: And you, good sir! Pray, have you not a daughter Call'd Katharina, fair and virtuous?
trg: I have a daughter, sir, called Katharina.

src: I shall be reconciled to him again.
trg: Never, my lord; therefore prepare to die.

src: To bide upon't, thou art not honest, or, If thou inclinest that way, thou art a coward, Which hoxes honesty behind, restraining From course required;
trg: or else thou must be counted A servant grafted in my serious trust And therein negligent; or else a fool That seest a game play'd home, the rich stake drawn, And takest it all for jest.

src: I see this is the time that the unjust man doth thrive. What an exchange had this been without boot! What a boot is here with this exchange!
trg: Sure the gods do this year connive at us, and we may do any thing extempore. The prince himself is about a piece of iniquity, stealing away from his father with his clog at his heels:

src: You knew of his departure, as you know What you have underta'en to do in's absence.
trg: Sir, You speak a language that I understand not: My life stands in the level of your dreams, Which I'll lay down.

src: 'tis too horrible! The weariest and most loathed worldly life That age, ache, penury and imprisonment Can lay on nature is a paradise To what we fear of death.
trg: Alas, alas!

src: Like doth quit like, and MEASURE still FOR MEASURE. Then, Angelo, thy fault's thus manifested; Which, though thou wouldst deny, denies thee vantage.
trg: We do condemn thee to the very block Where Claudio stoop'd to death, and with like haste. Away with him!

src: After I have done what I promised?
trg: Ay, sir.

src: Ay, therein Clarence shall not want his part.
trg: But, with the first of all your chief affairs, Let me entreat, for I command no more, That Margaret your queen and my son Edward Be sent for, to return from France with speed;

src: In any proportion or in any language.
trg: I think, or in any religion.

src: I have a head, sir, that will find out logs, And never trouble Peter for the matter.
trg: Mass, and well said; a merry whoreson, ha! Thou shalt be logger-head. Good faith, 'tis day: The county will be here with music straight, For so he said he would: I hear him near. Nurse! Wife!

src: Alas, poor man! a million of beating may come to a great matter.
trg: I am robbed, sir, and beaten; my money and apparel ta'en from me, and these detestable things put upon me.

src: Mine honour lives when his dishonour dies, Or my shamed life in his dishonour lies: Thou kill'st me in his life; giving him breath, The traitor lives, the true man's put to death.
Here burns my candle out; ay, here it dies, Which, whiles it lasted, gave King Henry light. O Lancaster, I fear thy overthrow More than my body's parting with my soul!
trg: My love and fear glued many friends to thee; And, now I fall, thy tough commixture melts. Impairing Henry, strengthening misproud York, The common people swarm like summer flies;

src: What news abroad i' the world?
trg: None, but that there is so great a fever on goodness, that the dissolution of it must cure it: novelty is only in request;

src: For you must know, we have with special soul Elected him our absence to supply, Lent him our terror, dress'd him with our love, And given his deputation all the organs Of our own power:
trg: what think you of it?

src: will his majesty Give Richard leave to live till Richard die? You make a leg, and Bolingbroke says ay.
trg: My lord, in the base court he doth attend To speak with you; may it please you to come down.

src: Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress. I protest unto thee--
trg: Good heart, and, i' faith, I will tell her as much: Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.

src: Masters of the people, Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter-- That's thousand to one good one--when you now see He had rather venture all his limbs for honour Than one on's ears to hear it?
trg: Proceed, Cominius.

src: Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move And with her breath she did perfume the air: Sacred and sweet was all I saw in her.
trg: Nay, then, 'tis time to stir him from his trance. I pray, awake, sir: if you love the maid, Bend thoughts and wits to achieve her. Thus it stands:

src: O Ratcliff, I have dream'd a fearful dream! What thinkest thou, will our friends prove all true?
trg: No doubt, my lord.

src: Have you inform'd them sithence?
trg: How! I inform them!

src: fourteen they shall not see, To bring false generations: they are co-heirs; And I had rather glib myself than they Should not produce fair issue.
trg: Cease; no more. You smell this business with a sense as cold As is a dead man's nose: but I do see't and feel't As you feel doing thus; and see withal The instruments that feel.

src: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?
trg: He's within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.

src: I pray you, do not push me; I'll be gone. Look to your babe, my lord; 'tis yours: Jove send her A better guiding spirit! What needs these hands?
trg: You, that are thus so tender o'er his follies, Will never do him good, not one of you. So, so: farewell; we are gone.

src: When presently through all thy veins shall run A cold and drowsy humour, for no pulse Shall keep his native progress, but surcease: No warmth, no breath, shall testify thou livest;
trg: The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade To paly ashes, thy eyes' windows fall, Like death, when he shuts up the day of life;

src: My lord of Salisbury, we have stay'd ten days, And hardly kept our countrymen together, And yet we hear no tidings from the king; Therefore we will disperse ourselves: farewell.
trg: Stay yet another day, thou trusty Welshman: The king reposeth all his confidence in thee.

src: for his best friends, if they Should say 'Be good to Rome,' they charged him even As those should do that had deserved his hate, And therein show'd like enemies.
trg: 'Tis true: If he were putting to my house the brand That should consume it, I have not the face To say 'Beseech you, cease.' You have made fair hands, You and your crafts! you have crafted fair!

src: Choler! Were I as patient as the midnight sleep, By Jove, 'twould be my mind!
trg: It is a mind That shall remain a poison where it is, Not poison any further.

src: Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that: for the defence of a town, our general is excellent.
trg: Ay, and for an assault too.

src: How fares my Kate? What, sweeting, all amort?
trg: Mistress, what cheer?

src: I speak no more than every one doth know.
trg: Nimble mischance, that art so light of foot, Doth not thy embassage belong to me, And am I last that knows it? O, thou think'st To serve me last, that I may longest keep Thy sorrow in my breast.

src: Should we be silent and not speak, our raiment And state of bodies would bewray what life We have led since thy exile. Think with thyself How more unfortunate than all living women Are we come hither:
trg: since that thy sight, which should Make our eyes flow with joy, hearts dance with comforts, Constrains them weep and shake with fear and sorrow;

src: For so I have strew'd it in the common ear, And so it is received. Now, pious sir, You will demand of me why I do this?
trg: Gladly, my lord.

src: Thou dost advise me Even so as I mine own course have set down: I'll give no blemish to her honour, none.
trg: My lord, Go then; and with a countenance as clear As friendship wears at feasts, keep with Bohemia And with your queen. I am his cupbearer:

src: What is this? sport?
trg: Bear the boy hence; he shall not come about her; Away with him! and let her sport herself With that she's big with; for 'tis Polixenes Has made thee swell thus.

src: To-morrow will it please you to be crown'd?
trg: Even when you please, since you will have it so.

src: I think it well: And from this testimony of your own sex,-- Since I suppose we are made to be no stronger Than faults may shake our frames,--let me be bold; I do arrest your words.
trg: Be that you are, That is, a woman; if you be more, you're none; If you be one, as you are well express'd By all external warrants, show it now, By putting on the destined livery.

src: He loves your people But tie him not to be their bedfellow. Worthy Cominius, speak. Nay, keep your place.
trg: Sit, Coriolanus; never shame to hear What you have nobly done.

src: But since he hath Served well for Rome,--
trg: What do you prate of service?

src: Hear me one word; Beseech you, tribunes, hear me but a word.
trg: Peace, peace!

src: We will meet them, And help the joy.
trg: Behold our patroness, the life of Rome! Call all your tribes together, praise the gods, And make triumphant fires; strew flowers before them:

src: No, good sir; He has his health and ampler strength indeed Than most have of his age.
trg: By my white beard, You offer him, if this be so, a wrong Something unfilial:

src: No matter: get thee gone, And hire those horses; I'll be with thee straight. Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee to-night. Let's see for means:
trg: O mischief, thou art swift To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!

src: Noble lords, Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle; Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley Into his ruin'd ears, and thus deliver:
trg: If not, I'll use the advantage of my power And lay the summer's dust with showers of blood Rain'd from the wounds of slaughter'd Englishmen:

src: This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings; Which in a set hand fairly is engross'd, That it may be this day read over in Paul's. And mark how well the sequel hangs together:
trg: Eleven hours I spent to write it over, For yesternight by Catesby was it brought me; The precedent was full as long a-doing:

src: My mother, you wot well My hazards still have been your solace:
trg: My first son. Whither wilt thou go? Take good Cominius With thee awhile: determine on some course, More than a wild exposture to each chance That starts i' the way before thee.
Condemn the fault and not the actor of it? Why, every fault's condemn'd ere it be done:

src: It is determined, not concluded yet: But so it must be, if the king miscarry.
trg: Here come the lords of Buckingham and Derby.

src: For your broken shin.
trg: Why, Romeo, art thou mad?

src: You are most welcome home.
trg: I have not deserved it. But, worthy lords, have you with heed perused What I have written to you?

src: Follow your function, go, and batten on cold bits.
trg: What, you will not? Prithee, tell my master what a strange guest he has here.

src: God, I pray him, That none of you may live your natural age, But by some unlook'd accident cut off!
trg: Have done thy charm, thou hateful wither'd hag!

src: Ay, sir; well, well.
trg: 'Though all at once cannot See what I do deliver out to each, Yet I can make my audit up, that all From me do back receive the flour of all, And leave me but the bran.' What say you to't?

src: for thou shalt hear that I, Knowing by Paulina that the oracle Gave hope thou wast in being, have preserved Myself to see the issue.
trg: There's time enough for that; Lest they desire upon this push to trouble Your joys with like relation. Go together, You precious winners all; your exultation Partake to every one.

src: and kiss on kiss She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath, That in a twink she won me to her love. O, you are novices!
trg: 'tis a world to see, How tame, when men and women are alone, A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew. Give me thy hand, Kate: I will unto Venice, To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding-day.

src: If they have overheard me now, why, hanging.
trg: How now, good fellow! why shakest thou so? Fear not, man; here's no harm intended to thee.

src: You will be schoolmaster And undertake the teaching of the maid: That's your device.
trg: It is: may it be done?

src: My lord, I have from Oxford sent to London The heads of Brocas and Sir Bennet Seely, Two of the dangerous consorted traitors That sought at Oxford thy dire overthrow.
trg: Thy pains, Fitzwater, shall not be forgot; Right noble is thy merit, well I wot.

src: Proceed: No foot shall stir.
trg: Music, awake her; strike! 'Tis time; descend; be stone no more; approach; Strike all that look upon with marvel. Come, I'll fill your grave up:

src: Care for us! True, indeed! They ne'er cared for us yet: suffer us to famish, and their store-houses crammed with grain; make edicts for usury, to support usurers;
trg: repeal daily any wholesome act established against the rich, and provide more piercing statutes daily, to chain up and restrain the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will;

src: Neighbours and friends, though bride and bridegroom wants For to supply the places at the table, You know there wants no junkets at the feast. Lucentio, you shall supply the bridegroom's place:
trg: And let Bianca take her sister's room.

src: Come then, away; let's ha' no more ado.
trg: Bishop, farewell: shield thee from Warwick's frown; And pray that I may repossess the crown. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: This, by his voice, should be a Montague. Fetch me my rapier, boy. What dares the slave Come hither, cover'd with an antic face, To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?
trg: Now, by the stock and honour of my kin, To strike him dead, I hold it not a sin.

src: Saw'st thou not, boy, how Silver made it good At the hedge-corner, in the coldest fault? I would not lose the dog for twenty pound.
trg: Why, Belman is as good as he, my lord; He cried upon it at the merest loss And twice to-day pick'd out the dullest scent: Trust me, I take him for the better dog.

src: Then, thrice-gracious queen, More than your lord's departure weep not: more's not seen; Or if it be, 'tis with false sorrow's eye, Which for things true weeps things imaginary.
trg: It may be so; but yet my inward soul Persuades me it is otherwise: howe'er it be, I cannot but be sad;

src: Some word there was, worser than Tybalt's death, That murder'd me: I would forget it fain; But, O, it presses to my memory, Like damned guilty deeds to sinners' minds:
trg: 'Tybalt is dead, and Romeo--banished;' That 'banished,' that one word 'banished,' Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts. Tybalt's death Was woe enough, if it had ended there:

src: One seven-night longer.
trg: Very sooth, to-morrow.

src: You will be welcome with this intelligence, Nicanor.
trg: The day serves well for them now. I have heard it said, the fittest time to corrupt a man's wife is when she's fallen out with her husband.

src: Clubs, bills, and partisans! strike! beat them down! Down with the Capulets! down with the Montagues!
trg: What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!

src: O, sir, sir, sir, I would have had you put your power well on, Before you had worn it out.
trg: Let go.

src: And, that I love the tree from whence thou sprang'st, Witness the loving kiss I give the fruit.
trg: Now am I seated as my soul delights, Having my country's peace and brothers' loves.

src: Slave, I have set my life upon a cast, And I will stand the hazard of the die: I think there be six Richmonds in the field; Five have I slain to-day instead of him. A horse! a horse!
trg: my kingdom for a horse!

src: Come, come, my son, I'll bring thee on thy way: Had I thy youth and cause, I would not stay.
trg: Then, England's ground, farewell; sweet soil, adieu; My mother, and my nurse, that bears me yet! Where'er I wander, boast of this I can, Though banish'd, yet a trueborn Englishman.

src: I do believe thee: I saw his heart in 's face. Give me thy hand: Be pilot to me and thy places shall Still neighbour mine. My ships are ready and My people did expect my hence departure Two days ago.
trg: This jealousy Is for a precious creature: Fear o'ershades me: Good expedition be my friend, and comfort The gracious queen, part of his theme, but nothing Of his ill-ta'en suspicion! Come, Camillo;

src: My gracious father, by your kingly leave, I'll draw it as apparent to the crown, And in that quarrel use it to the death.
trg: Why, that is spoken like a toward prince.

src: Now you are heir, therefore enjoy it now: By giving the house of Lancaster leave to breathe, It will outrun you, father, in the end.
trg: I took an oath that he should quietly reign.

src: Take special care my greetings be deliver'd.
trg: A gentleman of mine I have dispatch'd With letters of your love to her at large.

src: I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.
trg: Now He that made me knows I see thee ill; Ill in myself to see, and in thee seeing ill. Thy death-bed is no lesser than thy land Wherein thou liest in reputation sick;

src: What is his name?
trg: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

src: Neighbours, God speed!
trg: Give you good morrow, sir.

src: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.
trg: Then is he more beholding to you than I.

src: I would dissemble with my nature where My fortunes and my friends at stake required I should do so in honour: I am in this, Your wife, your son, these senators, the nobles;
trg: And you will rather show our general louts How you can frown than spend a fawn upon 'em, For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard Of what that want might ruin.

src: Marry, that 'marry' is the very theme I came to talk of. Tell me, daughter Juliet, How stands your disposition to be married?
trg: It is an honour that I dream not of.

src: Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.
trg: Why, this was moulded on a porringer; A velvet dish: fie, fie! 'tis lewd and filthy: Why, 'tis a cockle or a walnut-shell, A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby's cap: Away with it!

src: I swear to do this, though a present death Had been more merciful. Come on, poor babe: Some powerful spirit instruct the kites and ravens To be thy nurses!
trg: Wolves and bears, they say Casting their savageness aside have done Like offices of pity. Sir, be prosperous In more than this deed does require!

src: Do me the common right To let me see them and to make me know The nature of their crimes, that I may minister To them accordingly.
trg: I would do more than that, if more were needful. Look, here comes one: a gentlewoman of mine, Who, falling in the flaws of her own youth, Hath blister'd her report: she is with child;

src: Suppose the singing birds musicians, The grass whereon thou tread'st the presence strew'd, The flowers fair ladies, and thy steps no more Than a delightful measure or a dance;
trg: For gnarling sorrow hath less power to bite The man that mocks at it and sets it light.

src: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed! But be thou arm'd for some unhappy words.
trg: Ay, to the proof; as mountains are for winds, That shake not, though they blow perpetually.

src: O boy, thy father gave thee life too soon, And hath bereft thee of thy life too late!
trg: Woe above woe! grief more than common grief! O that my death would stay these ruthful deeds! O pity, pity, gentle heaven, pity!

src: As by strange fortune It came to us, I do in justice charge thee, On thy soul's peril and thy body's torture, That thou commend it strangely to some place Where chance may nurse or end it.
trg: Take it up.
Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much, Which mannerly devotion shows in this; For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch, And palm to palm is holy palmers' kiss.

src: How! gone!
trg: Is dead.

src: Now, brother of Clarence, how like you our choice, That you stand pensive, as half malcontent?
trg: As well as Lewis of France, or the Earl of Warwick, Which are so weak of courage and in judgment That they'll take no offence at our abuse.

src: My dear?
trg: At what o'clock to-morrow Shall I send to thee?

src: I am too sore enpierced with his shaft To soar with his light feathers, and so bound, I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe: Under love's heavy burden do I sink.
trg: And, to sink in it, should you burden love; Too great oppression for a tender thing.

src: Which is the least?
trg: If it were damnable, he being so wise, Why would he for the momentary trick Be perdurably fined? O Isabel!

src: Whither you will, so I were from your sights.
trg: Go, some of you convey him to the Tower.

src: Caius Marcius Coriolanus!
trg: I will go wash; And when my face is fair, you shall perceive Whether I blush or no: howbeit, I thank you.

src: To God, the widow's champion and defence.
trg: Why, then, I will. Farewell, old Gaunt. Thou goest to Coventry, there to behold Our cousin Hereford and fell Mowbray fight:

src: Our lands, our lives and all are Bolingbroke's, And nothing can we call our own but death And that small model of the barren earth Which serves as paste and cover to our bones.
trg: For God's sake, let us sit upon the ground And tell sad stories of the death of kings; How some have been deposed; some slain in war, Some haunted by the ghosts they have deposed;

src: At this same ancient feast of Capulet's Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lovest, With all the admired beauties of Verona: Go thither;
trg: and, with unattainted eye, Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.

src: Here comes your father; tell him so yourself, And see how he will take it at your hands.
trg: When the sun sets, the air doth drizzle dew; But for the sunset of my brother's son It rains downright. How now! a conduit, girl? what, still in tears? Evermore showering?

src: That I would have spoke of: Being banish'd for't, he came unto my hearth; Presented to my knife his throat: I took him; Made him joint-servant with me; gave him way In all his own desires;
trg: nay, let him choose Out of my files, his projects to accomplish, My best and freshest men; served his designments In mine own person; holp to reap the fame Which he did end all his;

src: Here at the palace I will rest awhile. Cousin of Exeter, what thinks your lordship? Methinks the power that Edward hath in field Should not be able to encounter mine.
trg: The doubt is that he will seduce the rest.

src: There is no world without Verona walls, But purgatory, torture, hell itself. Hence-banished is banish'd from the world, And world's exile is death: then banished, Is death mis-term'd:
trg: calling death banishment, Thou cutt'st my head off with a golden axe, And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.

src: SAMPSON: Gregory, o' my word, we'll not carry coals.
trg: No, for then we should be colliers.

src: Oh, that deceit should steal such gentle shapes, And with a virtuous vizard hide foul guile! He is my son; yea, and therein my shame; Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.
trg: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?

src: It is too heavy for your grace to wear.
trg: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

src: Sir, if it please your honour, this is not so.
trg: Prove it before these varlets here, thou honourable man; prove it.

src: That were some love but little policy.
trg: Then whither he goes, thither let me go.

src: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.
trg: How?

src: Come, your hand; And, daughter, yours.
trg: Soft, swain, awhile, beseech you; Have you a father?

src: My tongue will tell the anger of my heart, Or else my heart concealing it will break, And rather than it shall, I will be free Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.
trg: Why, thou say'st true; it is a paltry cap, A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie: I love thee well, in that thou likest it not.

src: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may. Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come, Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?
trg: Where it seems best unto your royal self. If I may counsel you, some day or two Your highness shall repose you at the Tower:

src: 'tis all as easy Falsely to take away a life true made As to put metal in restrained means To make a false one.
trg: 'Tis set down so in heaven, but not in earth.

src: What, talking with a priest, lord chamberlain? Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your honour hath no shriving work in hand.
trg: Good faith, and when I met this holy man, Those men you talk of came into my mind. What, go you toward the Tower?

src: O comfortable friar! where is my lord? I do remember well where I should be, And there I am. Where is my Romeo?
trg: I hear some noise. Lady, come from that nest Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep: A greater power than we can contradict Hath thwarted our intents. Come, come away.

src: Then further, all dissembling set aside, Tell me for truth the measure of his love Unto our sister Bona.
trg: Such it seems As may beseem a monarch like himself.

src: And so I say, I'll cut the causes off, Flattering me with impossibilities. My eye's too quick, my heart o'erweens too much, Unless my hand and strength could equal them.
trg: Well, say there is no kingdom then for Richard; What other pleasure can the world afford?

src: Fair sir, and you my merry mistress, That with your strange encounter much amazed me, My name is call'd Vincentio; my dwelling Pisa; And bound I am to Padua;
trg: there to visit A son of mine, which long I have not seen.

src: I thank thee: thou shalt not lose by it.
trg: How fares my noble lord?

src: 'Twas from the canon.
trg: 'Shall'! O good but most unwise patricians! If he have power Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd, Be not as common fools;

src: Ay, the most peerless piece of earth, I think, That e'er the sun shone bright on.
trg: O Hermione, As every present time doth boast itself Above a better gone, so must thy grave Give way to what's seen now!

src: That she, poor wretch, for grief can speak no more; O Margaret, thus 'twill be; and thou, poor soul, Art then forsaken, as thou went'st forlorn!
trg: Say, what art thou that talk'st of kings and queens?

src: Beseech you,--
trg: Verily, I speak it in the freedom of my knowledge: we cannot with such magnificence--in so rare--I know not what to say.

src: Disorder, horror, fear and mutiny Shall here inhabit, and this land be call'd The field of Golgotha and dead men's skulls.
trg: O, if you raise this house against this house, It will the woefullest division prove That ever fell upon this cursed earth.

src: 'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.
trg: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.

src: for I have Pisa left And am to Padua come, as he that leaves A shallow plash to plunge him in the deep And with satiety seeks to quench his thirst.
trg: Mi perdonato, gentle master mine, I am in all affected as yourself; Glad that you thus continue your resolve To suck the sweets of sweet philosophy.

src: Then thus. Baptista is safe, talking with the deceiving father of a deceitful son.
trg: And what of him?

src: My good lords both, with all the heed I may.
trg: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

src: You so remain.
trg: And so are like to do.

src: And, if you will, tell what hath happened, Lucentio's father is arrived in Padua, And how she's like to be Lucentio's wife.
trg: I pray the gods she may with all my heart!

src: But so is not she.
trg: For what reason, I beseech you?

src: What do you think?
trg: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul: So from thy soul's love didst thou love her brothers; And from my heart's love I do thank thee for it.

src: I tell thee, I, that thou hast marr'd her gown.
trg: Your worship is deceived; the gown is made Just as my master had direction: Grumio gave order how it should be done.

src: O royal piece, There's magic in thy majesty, which has My evils conjured to remembrance and From thy admiring daughter took the spirits, Standing like stone with thee.
trg: And give me leave, And do not say 'tis superstition, that I kneel and then implore her blessing. Lady, Dear queen, that ended when I but began, Give me that hand of yours to kiss.

src: Very well; and could be content to give him good report fort, but that he pays himself with being proud.
trg: Nay, but speak not maliciously.

src: Meeting two such wealsmen as you are--I cannot call you Lycurguses--if the drink you give me touch my palate adversely, I make a crooked face at it.
trg: I can't say your worships have delivered the matter well, when I find the ass in compound with the major part of your syllables:

src: For what offence?
trg: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed; Why or for what these nobles were committed Is all unknown to me, my gracious lady.

src: What must the king do now? must he submit? The king shall do it: must he be deposed? The king shall be contented: must he lose The name of king? o' God's name, let it go:
trg: Or I'll be buried in the king's highway, Some way of common trade, where subjects' feet May hourly trample on their sovereign's head; For on my heart they tread now whilst I live;

src: Where were you born, friend?
trg: Here in Vienna, sir.

src: And so it shall be so for Katharina.
trg: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.

src: Where every horse bears his commanding rein, And may direct his course as please himself, As well the fear of harm, as harm apparent, In my opinion, ought to be prevented.
trg: I hope the king made peace with all of us And the compact is firm and true in me.
Fortune speed us! Thus we set on, Camillo, to the sea-side.

src: Sure the gods do this year connive at us, and we may do any thing extempore. The prince himself is about a piece of iniquity, stealing away from his father with his clog at his heels:
trg: if I thought it were a piece of honesty to acquaint the king withal, I would not do't: I hold it the more knavery to conceal it; and therein am I constant to my profession. Aside, aside;

src: Now, therefore, be it known to noble Lewis, That Henry, sole possessor of my love, Is of a king become a banish'd man, And forced to live in Scotland a forlorn;
trg: While proud ambitious Edward Duke of York Usurps the regal title and the seat Of England's true-anointed lawful king.

src: What's he?
trg: His name is Barnardine.

src: I cannot tell; but I had as lief take her dowry with this condition, to be whipped at the high cross every morning.
trg: Faith, as you say, there's small choice in rotten apples. But come; Sweet Bianca! Happy man be his dole! He that runs fastest gets the ring. How say you, Signior Gremio?

src: Aumerle, thou liest; his honour is as true In this appeal as thou art all unjust; And that thou art so, there I throw my gage, To prove it on thee to the extremest point Of mortal breathing:
trg: seize it, if thou darest.

src: a very pretty one: sure, some 'scape: though I am not bookish, yet I can read waiting-gentlewoman in the 'scape. This has been some stair-work, some trunk-work, some behind-door-work:
trg: they were warmer that got this than the poor thing is here. I'll take it up for pity: yet I'll tarry till my son come; he hallooed but even now. Whoa, ho, hoa!

src: I do desire the like.
trg: Do you persuade yourself that I respect you?

src: Ay, with my heart And punish them to your height of pleasure. You, Lord Escalus, Sit with my cousin; lend him your kind pains To find out this abuse, whence 'tis derived.
trg: There is another friar that set them on; Let him be sent for.

src: I will not hence, till, with my talk and tears, Both full of truth, I make King Lewis behold Thy sly conveyance and thy lord's false love; For both of you are birds of selfsame feather.
trg: Warwick, this is some post to us or thee.

src: in sign whereof, Please ye we may contrive this afternoon, And quaff carouses to our mistress' health, And do as adversaries do in law, Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.
trg: O excellent motion! Fellows, let's be gone.

src: lay the fault on us.
trg: Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you. Of the same house Publius and Quintus were, That our beat water brought by conduits hither; And   Twice being   Was his great ancestor.

src: To her, Kate!
trg: To her, widow!

src: Who is it?
trg: Romeo.

src: The better that your lordship please to ask.
trg: I tell thee, man, 'tis better with me now Than when I met thee last where now we meet: Then was I going prisoner to the Tower, By the suggestion of the queen's allies;

src: 'Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.
trg: Out upon you! what a man are you!

src: My Lord of Somerset, what youth is that, Of whom you seem to have so tender care?
trg: My liege, it is young Henry, earl of Richmond.

src: Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate On you or yours, but with all duteous love Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me With hate in those where I expect most love!
trg: When I have most need to employ a friend, And most assured that he is a friend Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile, Be he unto me! this do I beg of God, When I am cold in zeal to yours.

src: Cold fearful drops stand on my trembling flesh. What do I fear?  myself?  there's none else by: Richard loves Richard; that is, I am I. Is there a murderer here?  No. Yes, I am: Then fly.
trg: What, from myself?   Great reason why: Lest I revenge. What, myself upon myself? Alack. I love myself. Wherefore?  for any good That I myself have done unto myself? O, no!

src: I must believe my master; else, I promise you, I should be arguing still upon that doubt: But let it rest. Now, Licio, to you:
trg: Good masters, take it not unkindly, pray, That I have been thus pleasant with you both.

src: Dwelt by a churchyard: I will tell it softly; Yond crickets shall not hear it.
trg: Come on, then, And give't me in mine ear.
The tongue of Isabel. She's come to know If yet her brother's pardon be come hither: But I will keep her ignorant of her good, To make her heavenly comforts of despair, When it is least expected.

src: Whither?
trg: It becomes thy oath full well, Thou to me thy secrets tell.

src: Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at them; which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.
trg: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

src: If you do, sir, I am for you: I serve as good a man as you.
trg: No better.

src: The people's enemy is gone, is gone!
trg: Our enemy is banish'd! he is gone! Hoo! hoo!

src: So, to our tent; Where, ere we do repose us, we will write To Rome of our success. You, Titus Lartius, Must to Corioli back:
trg: send us to Rome The best, with whom we may articulate, For their own good and ours.

src: O, help me, help me! pluck but off these rags; and then, death, death!
trg: Alack, poor soul! thou hast need of more rags to lay on thee, rather than have these off.

src: Gramercy, fellow: there, drink that for me.
trg: God save your lordship!

src: No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.
trg: Northumberland, I hold thee reverently. Break off the parley; for scarce I can refrain The execution of my big-swoln heart Upon that Clifford, that cruel child-killer.

src: And still, as you are weary of the weight, Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry's corse.
trg: Stay, you that bear the corse, and set it down.

src: If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds, Behold this pattern of thy butcheries. O, gentlemen, see, see! dead Henry's wounds Open their congeal'd mouths and bleed afresh!
trg: Blush, Blush, thou lump of foul deformity; For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blood From cold and empty veins, where no blood dwells;

src: Good boatswain, have care. Where's the master? Play the men.
trg: I pray now, keep below.

src: Unless another, As like Hermione as is her picture, Affront his eye.
trg: Good madam,--

src: Sir, I will serve him; for I do find your hangman is a more penitent trade than your bawd; he doth oftener ask forgiveness.
trg: You, sirrah, provide your block and your axe to-morrow four o'clock.

src: I must confess to you, sir, I am no fighter: I am false of heart that way; and that he knew, I warrant him.
trg: How do you now?
Ay, my good lord.

src: To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand: therefore, if thou art moved, thou runn'st away.
trg: A dog of that house shall move me to stand: I will take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.

src: Nay, tarry; I'll go along with thee I can tell thee pretty tales of the duke.
trg: You have told me too many of him already, sir, if they be true; if not true, none were enough.

src: As false, by heaven, as heaven itself is true.
trg: Surrey, thou liest.

src: Although it seems, And so he thinks, and is no less apparent To the vulgar eye, that he bears all things fairly.
trg: And shows good husbandry for the Volscian state, Fights dragon-like, and does achieve as soon As draw his sword;

src: But thine doth fry. Skipper, stand back: 'tis age that nourisheth.
trg: But youth in ladies' eyes that flourisheth.

src: Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine Hath wash'd thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline! How much salt water thrown away in waste, To season love, that of it doth not taste!
trg: The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears, Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears; Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit Of an old tear that is not wash'd off yet:

src: Shall satisfy your father.
trg: Happy be you! All that you speak shows fair.

src: With them, the two brave bears, Warwick and Montague, That in their chains fetter'd the kingly lion And made the forest tremble when they roar'd.
trg: Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat And made our footstool of security. Come hither, Bess, and let me kiss my boy.

src: Look, look! O heavy day!
trg: O me, O me! My child, my only life, Revive, look up, or I will die with thee! Help, help! Call help.

src: I shall, sir.
trg: The augurer tells me we shall have news to-night.

src: Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong, And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long. There's thy reward: be gone.
trg: But, Warwick, Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men, Shall cross the seas, and bid false Edward battle; And, as occasion serves, this noble queen And prince shall follow with a fresh supply.

src: He doth appear.
trg: The senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased To make thee consul.

src: I am sent before to make a fire, and they are coming after to warm them.
trg: Now, were not I a little pot and soon hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me:

src: Even all I have; yea, and myself and all, Will I withal endow a child of thine;
trg: So in the Lethe of thy angry soul Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs Which thou supposest I have done to thee.

src: The gods be good unto us!
trg: No, in such a case the gods will not be good unto us. When we banished him, we respected not them; and, he returning to break our necks, they respect not us.

src: But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom Kate of Kate Hall, my super-dainty Kate, For dainties are all Kates, and therefore, Kate, Take this of me, Kate of my consolation;
trg: Hearing thy mildness praised in every town, Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded, Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs, Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.

src: Is it even so? then I defy you, stars! Thou know'st my lodging: get me ink and paper, And hire post-horses; I will hence to-night.
trg: I do beseech you, sir, have patience: Your looks are pale and wild, and do import Some misadventure.

src: Made glory base and sovereignty a slave, Proud majesty a subject, state a peasant.
trg: My lord,--

src: that is, sir, I will counterfeit the bewitchment of some popular man and give it bountiful to the desirers. Therefore, beseech you, I may be consul.
trg: We hope to find you our friend; and therefore give you our voices heartily.

src: What work's, my countrymen, in hand? where go you With bats and clubs? The matter? speak, I pray you.
trg: Our business is not unknown to the senate; they have had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do, which now we'll show 'em in deeds. They say poor suitors have strong breaths:

src: O God's lady dear! Are you so hot? marry, come up, I trow; Is this the poultice for my aching bones? Henceforward do your messages yourself.
trg: Here's such a coil! come, what says Romeo?

src: 'Faith, my lord. I spoke it but according to the trick. If you will hang me for it, you may; but I had rather it would please you I might be whipt.
trg: Whipt first, sir, and hanged after. Proclaim it, provost, round about the city.

src: Friend, Art thou certain this is true? is it most certain?
trg: As certain as I know the sun is fire: Where have you lurk'd, that you make doubt of it? Ne'er through an arch so hurried the blown tide, As the recomforted through the gates. Why, hark you!

src: I cry thee mercy then, for I had thought That thou hadst call'd me all these bitter names.
trg: Why, so I did; but look'd for no reply. O, let me make the period to my curse!

src: Alack, for pity! I, not remembering how I cried out then, Will cry it o'er again: it is a hint That wrings mine eyes to't.
trg: Hear a little further And then I'll bring thee to the present business Which now's upon's; without the which this story Were most impertinent.

src: What, think you then the king shall be deposed?
trg: Depress'd he is already, and deposed 'Tis doubt he will be: letters came last night To a dear friend of the good Duke of York's, That tell black tidings.

src: And here receive we from our father Stanley Lines of fair comfort and encouragement.
trg: In God's name, cheerly on, courageous friends, To reap the harvest of perpetual peace By this one bloody trial of sharp war.

src: It shall be seven ere I go to horse: Look, what I speak, or do, or think to do, You are still crossing it. Sirs, let't alone: I will not go to-day; and ere I do, It shall be what o'clock I say it is.
For by my scouts I was advertised That she was coming with a full intent To dash our late decree in parliament Touching King Henry's oath and your succession.
trg: Short tale to make, we at Saint Alban's met Our battles join'd, and both sides fiercely fought:

src: Will I live?
trg: Will he woo her? ay, or I'll hang her.

src: Out! A mankind witch! Hence with her, out o' door: A most intelligencing bawd!
trg: Not so: I am as ignorant in that as you In so entitling me, and no less honest Than you are mad; which is enough, I'll warrant, As this world goes, to pass for honest.

src: What are you, sir?
trg: He, sir! a tapster, sir; parcel-bawd; one that serves a bad woman; whose house, sir, was, as they say, plucked down in the suburbs;

src: Aumerle that was; But that is lost for being Richard's friend, And, madam, you must call him Rutland now: I am in parliament pledge for his truth And lasting fealty to the new-made king.
trg: Welcome, my son: who are the violets now That strew the green lap of the new come spring?

src: Peter, didst ever see the like?
trg: He kills her in her own humour.

src: Then he disdains to shine; for by the book He should have braved the east an hour ago A black day will it be to somebody. Ratcliff!
trg: My lord?

src: Be patient, gentlemen; I choose her for myself: If she and I be pleased, what's that to you? 'Tis bargain'd 'twixt us twain, being alone, That she shall still be curst in company.
trg: I tell you, 'tis incredible to believe How much she loves me: O, the kindest Kate! She hung about my neck;

src: No, he must not.
trg: Let him, my son: he shall not need to grieve At knowing of thy choice.

src: Your affairs there, what, with whom, the condition of that fardel, the place of your dwelling, your names, your ages, of what having, breeding, and any thing that is fitting to be known, discover.
trg: We are but plain fellows, sir.

src: I never saw a better-fashion'd gown, More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable: Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.
trg: Why, true; he means to make a puppet of thee.

src: The trick of it?
trg: Still thus, and thus; still worse!

src: The senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased To make thee consul.
trg: I do owe them still My life and services.

src: It is too general a vice, and severity must cure it.
trg: Yes, in good sooth, the vice is of a great kindred; it is well allied: but it is impossible to extirp it quite, friar, till eating and drinking be put down.

src: Stop, Or all will fall in broil.
trg: Are these your herd? Must these have voices, that can yield them now And straight disclaim their tongues? What are your offices? You being their mouths, why rule you not their teeth?

src: And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it: Then, taking him from thence that is not there, You break no privilege nor charter there. Oft have I heard of sanctuary men;
trg: But sanctuary children ne'er till now.

src: You are my father, for methinks in you I see old Gaunt alive; O, then, my father, Will you permit that I shall stand condemn'd A wandering vagabond;
trg: my rights and royalties Pluck'd from my arms perforce and given away To upstart unthrifts? Wherefore was I born? If that my cousin king be King of England, It must be granted I am Duke of Lancaster.

src: But, sirrah, not for my sake, but your master's, I advise You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies: When I am alone, why, then I am Tranio;
trg: But in all places else your master Lucentio.

src: never man Sigh'd truer breath; but that I see thee here, Thou noble thing! more dances my rapt heart Than when I first my wedded mistress saw Bestride my threshold. Why, thou Mars!
trg: I tell thee, We have a power on foot; and I had purpose Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn, Or lose mine arm fort:

src: Golden quoifs and stomachers, For my lads to give their dears: Pins and poking-sticks of steel, What maids lack from head to heel: Come buy of me, come; come buy, come buy;
trg: Buy lads, or else your lasses cry: Come buy.

src: Will't please you walk aside?
trg: O place and greatness! millions of false eyes Are stuck upon thee: volumes of report Run with these false and most contrarious quests Upon thy doings:

src: Consul! what consul?
trg: The consul Coriolanus.

src: I do, my lord; but long I shall not stay I shall return before your lordship thence.
trg: 'Tis like enough, for I stay dinner there.

src: Barkloughly castle call they this at hand?
trg: Yea, my lord. How brooks your grace the air, After your late tossing on the breaking seas?

src: Tribunes, give way; he shall to the market-place.
trg: The people are incensed against him.

src: Rue, even for ruth, here shortly shall be seen, In the remembrance of a weeping queen.
trg: Call forth Bagot. Now, Bagot, freely speak thy mind; What thou dost know of noble Gloucester's death, Who wrought it with the king, and who perform'd The bloody office of his timeless end.

src: Our enemy is banish'd! he is gone! Hoo! hoo!
trg: Go, see him out at gates, and follow him, As he hath followed you, with all despite; Give him deserved vexation. Let a guard Attend us through the city.

src: About that which concerns your grace and us; The crown of England, father, which is yours.
trg: Mine boy? not till King Henry be dead.

src: Oh, if you love my brother, hate not me; I am his brother, and I love him well.
trg: If you be hired for meed, go back again, And I will send you to my brother Gloucester, Who shall reward you better for my life Than Edward will for tidings of my death.

src: Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul Leads discontented steps in foreign soil, This fair alliance quickly shall call home To high promotions and great dignity:
trg: The king, that calls your beauteous daughter wife. Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother;

src: Ay, if you come not in the blood of others, But mantled in your own.
trg: O, let me clip ye In arms as sound as when I woo'd, in heart As merry as when our nuptial day was done, And tapers burn'd to bedward!

src: ' why have they dared to march So many miles upon her peaceful bosom, Frighting her pale-faced villages with war And ostentation of despised arms? Comest thou because the anointed king is hence?
trg: Why, foolish boy, the king is left behind, And in my loyal bosom lies his power. Now prisoner to the palsy, chastise thee And minister correction to thy fault!

src: Now must the world point at poor Katharina, And say, 'Lo, there is mad Petruchio's wife, If it would please him come and marry her!'
trg: Patience, good Katharina, and Baptista too. Upon my life, Petruchio means but well, Whatever fortune stays him from his word: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise;

src: Ha! Marcius coming home!
trg: Ay, worthy Menenius; and with most prosperous approbation.

src: On him I lay what you would lay on me, The right and fortune of his happy stars; Which God defend that I should wring from him!
trg: My lord, this argues conscience in your grace; But the respects thereof are nice and trivial, All circumstances well considered. You say that Edward is your brother's son:

src: Nay, but hear me. Your sense pursues not mine: either you are ignorant, Or seem so craftily; and that's not good.
trg: Let me be ignorant, and in nothing good, But graciously to know I am no better.

src: So shall no foot upon the churchyard tread, Being loose, unfirm, with digging up of graves, But thou shalt hear it: whistle then to me, As signal that thou hear'st something approach.
trg: Give me those flowers. Do as I bid thee, go.

src: Moreover, urge his hateful luxury And bestial appetite in change of lust;
trg: Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives, Even where his lustful eye or savage heart, Without control, listed to make his prey. Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person:

src: Madam, have comfort: all of us have cause To wail the dimming of our shining star; But none can cure their harms by wailing them. Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy; I did not see your grace:
