trg: humbly on my knee I crave your blessing.

src: Sir, believe this, I had rather give my body than my soul.
trg: I talk not of your soul: our compell'd sins Stand more for number than for accompt.

src: For every inch of woman in the world, Ay, every dram of woman's flesh is false, If she be.
trg: Hold your peaces.

src: though the pennyworth on his side be the worst, yet hold thee, there's some boot.
trg: I am a poor fellow, sir. I know ye well enough.

src: But it chances The stealth of our most mutual entertainment With character too gross is writ on Juliet.
trg: With child, perhaps?

src: Which well appeared in his lineaments, Being nothing like the noble duke my father: But touch this sparingly, as 'twere far off, Because you know, my lord, my mother lives.
trg: Fear not, my lord, I'll play the orator As if the golden fee for which I plead Were for myself: and so, my lord, adieu.

src: The Lord protect him from that kingly title! Hath he set bounds betwixt their love and me? I am their mother; who should keep me from them?
trg: I am their fathers mother; I will see them.

src: I could have filed keys off that hung in chains: no hearing, no feeling, but my sir's song, and admiring the nothing of it.
trg: So that in this time of lethargy I picked and cut most of their festival purses;

src: But hear you.
trg: Not a word: if you have any thing to say to me, come to my ward; for thence will not I to-day.

src: 'Tis well that thou hast cause But thou shouldst please me better, wouldst thou weep.
trg: I could weep, madam, would it do you good.

src: Our soldiers', like the night-owl's lazy flight, Or like an idle thresher with a flail, Fell gently down, as if they struck their friends.
trg: I cheer'd them up with justice of our cause, With promise of high pay and great rewards: But all in vain; they had no heart to fight, And we in them no hope to win the day; So that we fled;

src: O, forfend it, God, That in a Christian climate souls refined Should show so heinous, black, obscene a deed! I speak to subjects, and a subject speaks, Stirr'd up by God, thus boldly for his king:
trg: My Lord of Hereford here, whom you call king, Is a foul traitor to proud Hereford's king: And if you crown him, let me prophesy:

src: They fear us not, but issue forth their city. Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight With hearts more proof than shields. Advance, brave Titus:
trg: They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts, Which makes me sweat with wrath. Come on, my fellows: He that retires I'll take him for a Volsce, And he shall feel mine edge.

src: If either of you both love Katharina, Because I know you well and love you well, Leave shall you have to court her at your pleasure.
'Twas you we laughed at.
trg: Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you: so you may continue and laugh at nothing still.

src: O, but impatience waiteth on true sorrow. And see where comes the breeder of my sorrow!
trg: What's he approacheth boldly to our presence?

src: upon thy life, I charge thee, Whate'er thou hear'st or seest, stand all aloof, And do not interrupt me in my course. Why I descend into this bed of death, Is partly to behold my lady's face;
trg: But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger A precious ring, a ring that I must use In dear employment: therefore hence, be gone:

src: A wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns, To make this shameless callet know herself. Helen of Greece was fairer far than thou, Although thy husband may be Menelaus;
trg: And ne'er was Agamemnon's brother wrong'd By that false woman, as this king by thee. His father revell'd in the heart of France, And tamed the king, and made the dauphin stoop;

src: Pardon it; The phrase is to the matter.
trg: Mended again. The matter; proceed.

src: By my white beard, You offer him, if this be so, a wrong Something unfilial:
trg: reason my son Should choose himself a wife, but as good reason The father, all whose joy is nothing else But fair posterity, should hold some counsel In such a business.

src: On what occasion, God he knows, not I, The queen your mother, and your brother York, Have taken sanctuary:
trg: the tender prince Would fain have come with me to meet your grace, But by his mother was perforce withheld.

src: This fellow had a Volscian to his mother; His wife is in Corioli and his child Like him by chance. Yet give us our dispatch: I am hush'd until our city be a-fire, And then I'll speak a little.
trg: O mother, mother! What have you done? Behold, the heavens do ope, The gods look down, and this unnatural scene They laugh at. O my mother, mother! O! You have won a happy victory to Rome;

src: O, then, I see, you will part but with light gifts; In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.
trg: It is too heavy for your grace to wear.

src: Come, come, they are almost here. How many stand for consulships?
trg: Three, they say: but 'tis thought of every one Coriolanus will carry it.

src: To whom I will retail my conquest won, And she shall be sole victress, Caesar's Caesar.
trg: What were I best to say? her father's brother Would be her lord? or shall I say, her uncle? Or, he that slew her brothers and her uncles?

src: O my son, my son! thou art preparing fire for us; look thee, here's water to quench it. I was hardly moved to come to thee;
trg: but being assured none but myself could move thee, I have been blown out of your gates with sighs; and conjure thee to pardon Rome, and thy petitionary countrymen.

src: O, if you raise this house against this house, It will the woefullest division prove That ever fell upon this cursed earth.
trg: Prevent it, resist it, let it not be so, Lest child, child's children, cry against you woe!

src: Answer to us.
trg: Say, then: 'tis true, I ought so.

src: This is it that makes me bridle passion And bear with mildness my misfortune's cross;
trg: Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear And stop the rising of blood-sucking sighs, Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown King Edward's fruit, true heir to the English crown.

src: Down with him! down with him!
trg: Weapons, weapons, weapons! 'Tribunes!' 'Patricians!' 'Citizens!' 'What, ho!' 'Sicinius!' 'Brutus!' 'Coriolanus!' 'Citizens!' 'Peace, peace, peace!' 'Stay, hold, peace!'

src: Your noble Tullus Aufidius will appear well in these wars, his great opposer, Coriolanus, being now in no request of his country.
trg: He cannot choose. I am most fortunate, thus accidentally to encounter you: you have ended my business, and I will merrily accompany you home.

src: And why should we proclaim it in an hour before his entering, that if any crave redress of injustice, they should exhibit their petitions in the street?
trg: He shows his reason for that: to have a dispatch of complaints, and to deliver us from devices hereafter, which shall then have no power to stand against us.

src: with these shreds They vented their complainings;
trg: What is granted them?

src: Immoderately she weeps for Tybalt's death, And therefore have I little talk'd of love; For Venus smiles not in a house of tears.
trg: Now, sir, her father counts it dangerous That she doth give her sorrow so much sway, And in his wisdom hastes our marriage, To stop the inundation of her tears;

src: I would most gladly know the issue of it.
trg: I make a broken delivery of the business; but the changes I perceived in the king and Camillo were very notes of admiration:

src: Sir, make me not your story.
trg: It is true. I would not--though 'tis my familiar sin With maids to seem the lapwing and to jest, Tongue far from heart--play with all virgins so: I hold you as a thing ensky'd and sainted.

src: upon them shall The causes of their death appear, unto Our shame perpetual. Once a day I'll visit The chapel where they lie, and tears shed there Shall be my recreation:
trg: so long as nature Will bear up with this exercise, so long I daily vow to use it. Come and lead me Unto these sorrows.

src: I have advertised him by secret means That if about this hour he make his way Under the colour of his usual game, He shall here find his friends with horse and men To set him free from his captivity.
trg: This way, my lord; for this way lies the game.

src: Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard kill'd him. From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept A hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death:
trg: O upright, just, and true-disposing God, How do I thank thee, that this carnal cur Preys on the issue of his mother's body, And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!

src: Fair Queen of England, worthy Margaret, Sit down with us: it ill befits thy state And birth, that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit.
trg: No, mighty King of France: now Margaret Must strike her sail and learn awhile to serve Where kings command. I was, I must confess, Great Albion's queen in former golden days:

src: Ah. mocker! that's the dog's name; R is for the--No; I know it begins with some other letter:--and she hath the prettiest sententious of it, of you and rosemary, that it would do you good to hear it.
trg: Commend me to thy lady.

src: Thy life hath that dishonour'd.
trg: Then, by myself--

src: I have considered so much, Camillo, and with some care; so far that I have eyes under my service which look upon his removedness;
trg: from whom I have this intelligence, that he is seldom from the house of a most homely shepherd;

src: I think, this coming summer, the King of Sicilia means to pay Bohemia the visitation which he justly owes him.
trg: Wherein our entertainment shall shame us we will be justified in our loves; for indeed--

src: Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot; For then this land was famously enrich'd With politic grave counsel; then the king Had virtuous uncles to protect his grace.
trg: Why, so hath this, both by the father and mother.

src: Hail to you, provost! so I think you are.
trg: I am the provost. What's your will, good friar?

src: Pardon, madam: The one I have almost forgot,--your pardon,-- The other, when she has obtain'd your eye, Will have your tongue too.
trg: This is a creature, Would she begin a sect, might quench the zeal Of all professors else, make proselytes Of who she but bid follow.

src: My language! heavens! I am the best of them that speak this speech, Were I but where 'tis spoken.
trg: How? the best? What wert thou, if the King of Naples heard thee?

src: They call him Doricles; and boasts himself To have a worthy feeding: but I have it Upon his own report and I believe it; He looks like sooth. He says he loves my daughter: I think so too;
trg: for never gazed the moon Upon the water as he'll stand and read As 'twere my daughter's eyes: and, to be plain. I think there is not half a kiss to choose Who loves another best.

src: Come, madam, come; I in all haste was sent.
trg: And I in all unwillingness will go. I would to God that the inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow Were red-hot steel, to sear me to the brain!

src: He's in the right. Constable, what say you to it?
trg: First, an it like you, the house is a respected house; next, this is a respected fellow; and his mistress is a respected woman.

src: He seems to be of great authority: close with him, give him gold; and though authority be a stubborn bear, yet he is oft led by the nose with gold:
trg: show the inside of your purse to the outside of his hand, and no more ado. Remember 'stoned,' and 'flayed alive.'

src: Catesby!
trg: My lord?

src: Petruchio, since we are stepp'd thus far in, I will continue that I broach'd in jest.
trg: I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife With wealth enough and young and beauteous, Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman:

src: Go, Cleomenes; Yourself, assisted with your honour'd friends, Bring them to our embracement. Still, 'tis strange He thus should steal upon us.
trg: Had our prince, Jewel of children, seen this hour, he had pair'd Well with this lord: there was not full a month Between their births.

src: Well hast thou spoken, cousin: be it so.
trg: Ah, know you not the city favours them, And they have troops of soldiers at their beck?

src: yet, wert thou as far As that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea, I would adventure for such merchandise.
trg: Thou know'st the mask of night is on my face, Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain deny What I have spoke:

src: Thanks, gentle Somerset; sweet Oxford, thanks.
trg: And take his thanks that yet hath nothing else.

src: Widow, we will consider of your suit; And come some other time to know our mind.
trg: Right gracious lord, I cannot brook delay: May it please your highness to resolve me now; And what your pleasure is, shall satisfy me.

src: Then give me leave that I may turn the key, That no man enter till my tale be done.
trg: Have thy desire.

src: On's brows: Menenius, he comes the third time home with the oaken garland.
trg: Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?

src: The obsequies that I for thee will keep Nightly shall be to strew thy grave and weep. The boy gives warning something doth approach.
trg: What cursed foot wanders this way to-night, To cross my obsequies and true love's rite? What with a torch! muffle me, night, awhile.

src: I will be satisfied; let me see it, I say. Treason! foul treason! Villain! traitor! slave!
trg: What is the matter, my lord?

src: Have done with words, my lords, and hear me speak.
trg: Defy them then, or else hold close thy lips.

src: By whose direction found'st thou out this place?
trg: By love, who first did prompt me to inquire; He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes. I am no pilot;

src: and his ascent is not by such easy degrees as those who, having been supple and courteous to the people, bonneted, without any further deed to have them at an into their estimation and report:
trg: but he hath so planted his honours in their eyes, and his actions in their hearts, that for their tongues to be silent, and not confess so much, were a kind of ingrateful injury;

src: I will tell you If you'll bestow a small--of what you have little-- Patience awhile, you'll hear the belly's answer.
trg: Ye're long about it.

src: in that sad time My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear; And what these sorrows could not thence exhale, Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping. I never sued to friend nor enemy;
trg: My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word; But now thy beauty is proposed my fee, My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak.

src: But, sure, if you Would be your country's pleader, your good tongue, More than the instant army we can make, Might stop our countryman.
trg: No, I'll not meddle.

src: so if the time thrust forth A cause for thy repeal, we shall not send O'er the vast world to seek a single man, And lose advantage, which doth ever cool I' the absence of the needer.
trg: Fare ye well: Thou hast years upon thee; and thou art too full Of the wars' surfeits, to go rove with one That's yet unbruised: bring me but out at gate.

src: thy horses shall be trapp'd, Their harness studded all with gold and pearl. Dost thou love hawking? thou hast hawks will soar Above the morning lark or wilt thou hunt?
trg: Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them And fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.

src: True, noble prince.
trg: O bitter consequence, That Edward still should live! 'True, noble prince!' Cousin, thou wert not wont to be so dull: Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead; And I would have it suddenly perform'd.

src: Nay, mark how Lewis stamps, as he were nettled: I hope all's for the best.
trg: Warwick, what are thy news? and yours, fair queen?

src: Hear me, people; peace!
trg: Let's hear our tribune: peace Speak, speak, speak.

src: Was ever son so rued a father's death?
trg: Was ever father so bemoan'd his son?

src: And what of all this?
trg: I cannot tell; expect they are busied about a counterfeit assurance: take you assurance of her, 'cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum:' to the church;

src: Why, so I did; but look'd for no reply. O, let me make the period to my curse!
trg: 'Tis done by me, and ends in 'Margaret.'

src: This is that banish'd haughty Montague, That murder'd my love's cousin, with which grief, It is supposed, the fair creature died; And here is come to do some villanous shame To the dead bodies:
trg: I will apprehend him. Stop thy unhallow'd toil, vile Montague! Can vengeance be pursued further than death? Condemned villain, I do apprehend thee: Obey, and go with me; for thou must die.

src: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.
trg: Cousins, indeed; and by their uncle cozen'd Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life. Whose hand soever lanced their tender hearts, Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction:

src: Now let me see if I can construe it: 'Hic ibat Simois,' I know you not, 'hic est Sigeia tellus,' I trust you not;
trg: 'Hic steterat Priami,' take heed he hear us not, 'regia,' presume not, 'celsa senis,' despair not.

src: From all dishonesty he can: in this, Unless he take the course that you have done, Commit me for committing honour, trust it, He shall not rule me.
trg: La you now, you hear: When she will take the rein I let her run; But she'll not stumble.

src: Mark you this, people?
trg: To the rock, to the rock with him!

src: Dorset, embrace him; Hastings, love lord marquess.
trg: This interchange of love, I here protest, Upon my part shall be unviolable.

src: Now, Thomas Mowbray, do I turn to thee, And mark my greeting well; for what I speak My body shall make good upon this earth, Or my divine soul answer it in heaven.
trg: Thou art a traitor and a miscreant, Too good to be so and too bad to live, Since the more fair and crystal is the sky, The uglier seem the clouds that in it fly.

src: Pretty too! What say you, James Soundpost?
trg: Faith, I know not what to say.

src: I prithee now, my son, Go to them, with this bonnet in thy hand;
trg: This but done, Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours; For they have pardons, being ask'd, as free As words to little purpose.

src: Advocate's the court-word for a pheasant: say you have none.
trg: None, sir; I have no pheasant, cock nor hen.

src: Where art thou, keeper? give me a cup of wine.
trg: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.

src: Death is a fearful thing.
trg: And shamed life a hateful.

src: For thine own bowels, which do call thee sire, The mere effusion of thy proper loins, Do curse the gout, serpigo, and the rheum, For ending thee no sooner.
trg: Thou hast nor youth nor age, But, as it were, an after-dinner's sleep, Dreaming on both; for all thy blessed youth Becomes as aged, and doth beg the alms Of palsied eld;

src: Let me twine Mine arms about that body, where against My grained ash an hundred times hath broke And scarr'd the moon with splinters:
trg: here I clip The anvil of my sword, and do contest As hotly and as nobly with thy love As ever in ambitious strength I did Contend against thy valour. Know thou first, I loved the maid I married;

src: or suppose Devouring pestilence hangs in our air And thou art flying to a fresher clime: Look, what thy soul holds dear, imagine it To lie that way thou go'st, not whence thou comest:
trg: Suppose the singing birds musicians, The grass whereon thou tread'st the presence strew'd, The flowers fair ladies, and thy steps no more Than a delightful measure or a dance;

src: O thou mine heir Of Naples and of Milan, what strange fish Hath made his meal on thee?
trg: Sir, he may live: I saw him beat the surges under him, And ride upon their backs; he trod the water, Whose enmity he flung aside, and breasted The surge most swoln that met him;

src: for they are soldiers, Witty, courteous, liberal, full of spirit.
trg: While you are thus employ'd, what resteth more, But that I seek occasion how to rise, And yet the king not privy to my drift, Nor any of the house of Lancaster? But, stay: what news?

src: If he did not care whether he had their love or no, he waved indifferently 'twixt doing them neither good nor harm: but he seeks their hate with greater devotion than can render it him;
trg: and leaves nothing undone that may fully discover him their opposite.

src: I'll pheeze you, in faith.
trg: A pair of stocks, you rogue!

src: In God's name, what art thou?
trg: A man, as you are.

src: 'Tis pity of him.
trg: When I would pray and think, I think and pray To several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words; Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue, Anchors on Isabel:
Tell him he must awake, and that quickly too.

src: My gracious liege, this too much lenity And harmful pity must be laid aside. To whom do lions cast their gentle looks? Not to the beast that would usurp their den.
trg: Whose hand is that the forest bear doth lick? Not his that spoils her young before her face. Who 'scapes the lurking serpent's mortal sting? Not he that sets his foot upon her back.

src: 'Twas a commodity lay fretting by you: 'Twill bring you gain, or perish on the seas.
trg: The gain I seek is, quiet in the match.

src: Fairly offer'd.
trg: This shows a sound affection.

src: What is't? a spirit? Lord, how it looks about! Believe me, sir, It carries a brave form. But 'tis a spirit.
trg: No, wench; it eats and sleeps and hath such senses As we have, such. This gallant which thou seest Was in the wreck;

src: therefore, I prithee, Supply me with the habit and instruct me How I may formally in person bear me Like a true friar. More reasons for this action At our more leisure shall I render you;
trg: Only, this one: Lord Angelo is precise; Stands at a guard with envy; scarce confesses That his blood flows, or that his appetite Is more to bread than stone:

src: With mine own tears I wash away my balm, With mine own hands I give away my crown, With mine own tongue deny my sacred state, With mine own breath release all duty's rites:
trg: All pomp and majesty I do forswear; My manors, rents, revenues I forego; My acts, decrees, and statutes I deny: God pardon all oaths that are broke to me!

src: For on that ground I'll build a holy descant: And be not easily won to our request: Play the maid's part, still answer nay, and take it.
trg: I go; and if you plead as well for them As I can say nay to thee for myself, No doubt well bring it to a happy issue.

src: blood against blood, Self against self: O, preposterous And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen; Or let me die, to look on death no more!
trg: Come, come, my boy; we will to sanctuary. Madam, farewell.

src: 'tis a condition they account gentle: and since the wisdom of their choice is rather to have my hat than my heart, I will practise the insinuating nod and be off to them most counterfeitly;
trg: that is, sir, I will counterfeit the bewitchment of some popular man and give it bountiful to the desirers. Therefore, beseech you, I may be consul.

src: but that death is too soft for him, say I draw our throne into a sheep-cote! all deaths are too few, the sharpest too easy.
trg: Has the old man e'er a son, sir, do you hear. an't like you, sir?

src: Out of her favour, where I am in love.
trg: Alas, that love, so gentle in his view, Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!

src: hasty and tinder-like upon too trivial motion; one that converses more with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the morning: what I think I utter, and spend my malice in my breath.
trg: Meeting two such wealsmen as you are--I cannot call you Lycurguses--if the drink you give me touch my palate adversely, I make a crooked face at it.

src: Some honest Christian trust me with a gage That Norfolk lies: here do I throw down this, If he may be repeal'd, to try his honour.
trg: These differences shall all rest under gage Till Norfolk be repeal'd: repeal'd he shall be, And, though mine enemy, restored again To all his lands and signories:

src: Foul devil, for God's sake, hence, and trouble us not; For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell, Fill'd it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.
trg: If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds, Behold this pattern of thy butcheries. O, gentlemen, see, see! dead Henry's wounds Open their congeal'd mouths and bleed afresh!

src: Why, so! then am I sure of victory. Now therefore let us hence; and lose no hour, Till we meet Warwick with his foreign power. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Trust me, my lord, all hitherto goes well; The common people by numbers swarm to us. But see where Somerset and Clarence come! Speak suddenly, my lords, are we all friends?

src: O fortune, fortune! all men call thee fickle: If thou art fickle, what dost thou with him. That is renown'd for faith? Be fickle, fortune;
trg: For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long, But send him back.

src: False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse, Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.
trg: Foul shame upon you! you have all moved mine.

src: Villain, thou know'st no law of God nor man: No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.
trg: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.

src: An if I live until I be a man, I'll win our ancient right in France again, Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.
What, Warwick, wilt thou leave the town and fight? Or shall we beat the stones about thine ears?
trg: Alas, I am not coop'd here for defence! I will away towards Barnet presently, And bid thee battle, Edward, if thou darest.

src: Coriolanus banished!
trg: Banished, sir.

src: Will you speak well of him that kill'd your cousin?
trg: Shall I speak ill of him that is my husband? Ah, poor my lord, what tongue shall smooth thy name, When I, thy three-hours wife, have mangled it? But, wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?

src: Here's a strange alteration!
trg: By my hand, I had thought to have strucken him with a cudgel; and yet my mind gave me his clothes made a false report of him.

src: You are deceived, your brother Gloucester hates you.
trg: O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear: Go you to him from me.

src: We must find An evident calamity, though we had Our wish, which side should win: For myself, son, I purpose not to wait on fortune till These wars determine:
trg: Ay, and mine, That brought you forth this boy, to keep your name Living to time.

src: Your belly's answer? What! The kingly-crowned head, the vigilant eye, The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier, Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter.
trg: With other muniments and petty helps In this our fabric, if that they--

src: Follow me close, for I will speak to them. Gentlemen, good den: a word with one of you.
trg: And but one word with one of us? couple it with something; make it a word and a blow.

src: But now the Duke of Buckingham and I Are come from visiting his majesty.
trg: What likelihood of his amendment, lords?

src: Here's he that would take from you all your power.
trg: Seize him, AEdiles!

src: Good time of day unto my gracious lord!
trg: As much unto my good lord chamberlain! Well are you welcome to the open air. How hath your lordship brook'd imprisonment?

src: Which he, young wanton and effeminate boy, Takes on the point of honour to support So dissolute a crew.
trg: My lord, some two days since I saw the prince, And told him of those triumphs held at Oxford.

src: She-wolf of France, but worse than wolves of France, Whose tongue more poisons than the adder's tooth!
trg: How ill-beseeming is it in thy sex To triumph, like an Amazonian trull, Upon their woes whom fortune captivates!

src: Soft! I will go along; An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.
trg: Tut, I have lost myself; I am not here; This is not Romeo, he's some other where.

src: Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin.
trg: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list.

src: Urge it no more, my Lord Northumberland.
trg: The commons will not then be satisfied.

src: The prenzie Angelo!
trg: O, 'tis the cunning livery of hell, The damned'st body to invest and cover In prenzie guards! Dost thou think, Claudio? If I would yield him my virginity, Thou mightst be freed.

src: But, that I'll give my voice on Richard's side, To bar my master's heirs in true descent, God knows I will not do it, to the death.
trg: God keep your lordship in that gracious mind!

src: Blister'd be thy tongue For such a wish! he was not born to shame: Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit; For 'tis a throne where honour may be crown'd Sole monarch of the universal earth.
trg: O, what a beast was I to chide at him!

src: I promise you, I scarcely know myself: Hear you the news abroad?
trg: Ay, that the king is dead.

src: My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.
trg: What do you think?

src: O, she is rich in beauty, only poor, That when she dies with beauty dies her store.
trg: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?

src: This, as you say, suggested At some time when his soaring insolence Shall touch the people--which time shall not want, If he be put upon 't;
trg: and that's as easy As to set dogs on sheep--will be his fire To kindle their dry stubble; and their blaze Shall darken him for ever.

src: Women are made to bear, and so are you.
trg: No such jade as you, if me you mean.

src: Friar, not I I have been drinking hard all night, and I will have more time to prepare me, or they shall beat out my brains with billets: I will not consent to die this day, that's certain.
trg: O, sir, you must: and therefore I beseech you Look forward on the journey you shall go.

src: And in this borrow'd likeness of shrunk death Thou shalt continue two and forty hours, And then awake as from a pleasant sleep.
trg: Now, when the bridegroom in the morning comes To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead:

src: What says my brother?
trg: Death is a fearful thing.

src: You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.
trg: We cannot be here and there too. Cheerly, boys; be brisk awhile, and the longer liver take all.

src: But if it were, doubt not her care should be To comb your noddle with a three-legg'd stool And paint your face and use you like a fool.
trg: From all such devils, good Lord deliver us!

src: Because authority, though it err like others, Hath yet a kind of medicine in itself, That skins the vice o' the top. Go to your bosom;
trg: Knock there, and ask your heart what it doth know That's like my brother's fault:

src: Romeo, that she were, O, that she were An open et caetera, thou a poperin pear! Romeo, good night: I'll to my truckle-bed; This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep: Come, shall we go?
trg: Go, then; for 'tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found.

src: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.
trg: True, when avoided grace makes destiny: My babes were destined to a fairer death, If grace had bless'd thee with a fairer life.

src: Aged sir, hands off.
trg: Hence, rotten thing! or I shall shake thy bones Out of thy garments.

src: But if thou, jealous, dost return to pry In what I further shall intend to do, By heaven, I will tear thee joint by joint And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs:
trg: The time and my intents are savage-wild, More fierce and more inexorable far Than empty tigers or the roaring sea.

src: Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind; The thief doth fear each bush an officer.
trg: The bird that hath been limed in a bush, With trembling wings misdoubteth every bush;

src: For, being transported by my jealousies To bloody thoughts and to revenge, I chose Camillo for the minister to poison My friend Polixenes:
trg: which had been done, But that the good mind of Camillo tardied My swift command, though I with death and with Reward did threaten and encourage him, Not doing 't and being done:

src: Then be your eyes the witness of this ill: See how I am bewitch'd; behold mine arm Is, like a blasted sapling, wither'd up:
trg: And this is Edward's wife, that monstrous witch, Consorted with that harlot strumpet Shore, That by their witchcraft thus have marked me.

src: He will shake Your Rome about your ears.
trg: As Hercules Did shake down mellow fruit. You have made fair work!

src: Madam, if't please the queen to send the babe, I know not what I shall incur to pass it, Having no warrant.
trg: You need not fear it, sir:

src: Short tale to make, we at Saint Alban's met Our battles join'd, and both sides fiercely fought:
trg: But whether 'twas the coldness of the king, Who look'd full gently on his warlike queen, That robb'd my soldiers of their heated spleen; Or whether 'twas report of her success;

src: Hear me, my masters, and my common friends,--
trg: He's sentenced; no more hearing.

src: if he could burn us all into one coal, We have deserved it.
trg: Faith, we hear fearful news.

src: Mistress Overdone.
trg: Hath she had any more than one husband?

src: You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin; Had you first died, and he been thus trod down, He should have found his uncle Gaunt a father, To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay.
trg: I am denied to sue my livery here, And yet my letters-patents give me leave: My father's goods are all distrain'd and sold, And these and all are all amiss employ'd. What would you have me do?

src: He smiled and said 'The better for our purpose.'
trg: He was in the right; and so indeed it is. Ten the clock there. Give me a calendar. Who saw the sun to-day?

src: He would not seem to know me.
trg: Do you hear?

src: There.
trg: This is to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.

src: that bed, that womb, That metal, that self-mould, that fashion'd thee Made him a man; and though thou livest and breathest, Yet art thou slain in him:
trg: thou dost consent In some large measure to thy father's death, In that thou seest thy wretched brother die, Who was the model of thy father's life. Call it not patience, Gaunt; it is despair:

src: Petruchio, patience; I am Grumio's pledge: Why, this's a heavy chance 'twixt him and you, Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.
trg: And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy gale Blows you to Padua here from old Verona?

src: Why that's my spirit! But was not this nigh shore?
trg: Close by, my master.

src: Pardon me, noble lord: I thought it was a fault, but knew it not; Yet did repent me, after more advice;
trg: For testimony whereof, one in the prison, That should by private order else have died, I have reserved alive.

src: That cannot be; the noise of thy cross-bow Will scare the herd, and so my shoot is lost. Here stand we both, and aim we at the best:
trg: And, for the time shall not seem tedious, I'll tell thee what befell me on a day In this self-place where now we mean to stand.

src: If guilty dread have left thee so much strength As to take up mine honour's pawn, then stoop:
trg: By that and all the rites of knighthood else, Will I make good against thee, arm to arm, What I have spoke, or thou canst worse devise.

src: were I but twenty-one, Your father's image is so hit in you, His very air, that I should call you brother, As I did him, and speak of something wildly By us perform'd before. Most dearly welcome!
trg: And your fair princess,--goddess!--O, alas! I lost a couple, that 'twixt heaven and earth Might thus have stood begetting wonder as You, gracious couple, do:

src: Then tell me, if I get your daughter's love, What dowry shall I have with her to wife?
trg: After my death the one half of my lands, And in possession twenty thousand crowns.

src: Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it? I mean, in a sort.
trg: That sort was well fished for.

src: If love be rough with you, be rough with love; Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down. Give me a case to put my visage in: A visor for a visor!
trg: what care I What curious eye doth quote deformities? Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.

src: Well said, master; mum! and gaze your fill.
trg: Gentlemen, that I may soon make good What I have said, Bianca, get you in: And let it not displease thee, good Bianca, For I will love thee ne'er the less, my girl.

src: Yea, and perhaps with more successful words Than you, unless you were a scholar, sir.
trg: O this learning, what a thing it is!

src: The benefit thereof is always granted To those whose dealings have deserved the place, And those who have the wit to claim the place: This prince hath neither claim'd it nor deserved it;
trg: And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it: Then, taking him from thence that is not there, You break no privilege nor charter there. Oft have I heard of sanctuary men;

src: What, you mean my face?
trg: Well aim'd of such a young one.

src: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.
trg: To serve me well, you all should do me duty, Teach me to be your queen, and you my subjects: O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!

src: Do so, it is a point of wisdom: fare you well.
trg: What, shall we stab him as he sleeps?

src: Content. What is the wager?
trg: Twenty crowns.

src: These babes for Clarence weep and so do I; I for an Edward weep, so do not they: Alas, you three, on me, threefold distress'd, Pour all your tears!
trg: I am your sorrow's nurse, And I will pamper it with lamentations.

src: Prosper you, sweet sir! Your purse is not hot enough to purchase your spice. I'll be with you at your sheep-shearing too:
trg: if I make not this cheat bring out another and the shearers prove sheep, let me be unrolled and my name put in the book of virtue! Jog on, jog on, the foot-path way, And merrily hent the stile-a:

src: Lay hands on the villain: I believe a' means to cozen somebody in this city under my countenance.
trg: I have seen them in the church together: God send 'em good shipping! But who is here? mine old master Vincentio! now we are undone and brought to nothing.

src: laws for all faults, But faults so countenanced, that the strong statutes Stand like the forfeits in a barber's shop, As much in mock as mark.
trg: Slander to the state! Away with him to prison!

src: I pray thee, pretty York, who told thee this?
trg: Grandam, his nurse.

src: Go we to our tent: The blood upon your visage dries; 'tis time It should be look'd to: come.
trg: The town is ta'en!

src: What cause, do you think, I have to swoon?
trg: I neither care for the world nor your general: for such things as you, I can scarce think there's any, ye're so slight. He that hath a will to die by himself fears it not from another:
Who's there? come in: the wish deserves a welcome.

src: What is that curt'sy worth? or those doves' eyes, Which can make gods forsworn? I melt, and am not Of stronger earth than others. My mother bows;
trg: As if Olympus to a molehill should In supplication nod: and my young boy Hath an aspect of intercession, which Great nature cries 'Deny not.' let the Volsces Plough Rome and harrow Italy:

src: But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame, My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys Till that my nails were anchor'd in thine eyes;
trg: And I, in such a desperate bay of death, Like a poor bark, of sails and tackling reft, Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.

src: We may live, son, to shed many more.
trg: Ay; or else 'twere hard luck, being in so preposterous estate as we are.

src: And mine with hers, and thine, and Margaret's. Therefore at last I firmly am resolved You shall have aid.
trg: Let me give humble thanks for all at once.

src: How! turn thy back and run?
trg: Fear me not.

src: The loss you have is but a son being king, And by that loss your daughter is made queen. I cannot make you what amends I would, Therefore accept such kindness as I can.
trg: Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul Leads discontented steps in foreign soil, This fair alliance quickly shall call home To high promotions and great dignity:

src: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder; His lordship knows me well, and loves me well.
trg: I thank your grace.

src: And you.
trg: Does Bridget paint still, Pompey, ha?

src: All this from my remembrance brutish wrath Sinfully pluck'd, and not a man of you Had so much grace to put it in my mind.
trg: But when your carters or your waiting-vassals Have done a drunken slaughter, and defaced The precious image of our dear Redeemer, You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon;

src: Go you before, and I will follow you. He cannot live, I hope; and must not die Till George be pack'd with post-horse up to heaven.
trg: I'll in, to urge his hatred more to Clarence, With lies well steel'd with weighty arguments; And, if I fall not in my deep intent, Clarence hath not another day to live:

src: Not better than he, by her own report.
trg: Say you?

src: And wherefore gaze this goodly company, As if they saw some wondrous monument, Some comet or unusual prodigy?
trg: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding-day: First were we sad, fearing you would not come; Now sadder, that you come so unprovided.

src: The which shall point you forth at every sitting What you must say; that he shall not perceive But that you have your father's bosom there And speak his very heart.
trg: I am bound to you: There is some sap in this.

src: Think'st thou that I will leave my kingly throne, Wherein my grandsire and my father sat? No: first shall war unpeople this my realm;
trg: Ay, and their colours, often borne in France, And now in England to our heart's great sorrow, Shall be my winding-sheet. Why faint you, lords? My title's good, and better far than his.

src: So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.
trg: If I do so, it will be of more price, Being spoke behind your back, than to your face.

src: Why, what is it, my lord?
trg: Give me my boots, I say; saddle my horse. Now, by mine honour, by my life, by my troth, I will appeach the villain.

src: Marcius, We have at disadvantage fought and did Retire to win our purpose.
trg: How lies their battle? know you on which side They have placed their men of trust?

src: And for our eyes do hate the dire aspect Of civil wounds plough'd up with neighbours' sword;
trg: You, cousin Hereford, upon pain of life, Till twice five summers have enrich'd our fields Shall not regreet our fair dominions, But tread the stranger paths of banishment.

src: Why, she hath a face of her own.
trg: Who knows not that?

src: Therefore we'll have some half a dozen friends, And there an end. But what say you to Thursday?
trg: My lord, I would that Thursday were to-morrow.

src: Well met, my lord; I am glad to see your honour.
trg: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart. I am in your debt for your last exercise; Come the next Sabbath, and I will content you.

src: What, will he come?
trg: He's coming.

src: Nay, if the devil have given thee proofs for sin, Thou wilt prove his. Take him to prison, officer: Correction and instruction must both work Ere this rude beast will profit.
trg: He must before the deputy, sir; he has given him warning: the deputy cannot abide a whoremaster: if he be a whoremonger, and comes before him, he were as good go a mile on his errand.

src: Let me embrace thee, sour adversity, For wise men say it is the wisest course.
trg: Why linger we? let us lay hands upon him.

src: So may you lose your arms: If you strike me, you are no gentleman; And if no gentleman, why then no arms.
trg: A herald, Kate? O, put me in thy books!

src: each your doing, So singular in each particular, Crowns what you are doing in the present deed, That all your acts are queens.
trg: O Doricles, Your praises are too large:

src: Unfit to live or die: O gravel heart! After him, fellows; bring him to the block.
trg: Now, sir, how do you find the prisoner?

src: You will be there, I know.
trg: If God prevent not, I purpose so.

src: In sign of truth, I kiss your highness' hand.
trg: Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate!

src: Good Paulina, Lead us from hence, where we may leisurely Each one demand an answer to his part Perform'd in this wide gap of time since first We were dissever'd: hastily lead away.
trg: Escalus.

src: Ay, but give me worship and quietness; I like it better than a dangerous honour. If Warwick knew in what estate he stands, 'Tis to be doubted he would waken him.
trg: Unless our halberds did shut up his passage.

src: Either I must, or have mine honour soil'd With the attainder of his slanderous lips. There is my gage, the manual seal of death, That marks thee out for hell:
trg: I say, thou liest, And will maintain what thou hast said is false In thy heart-blood, though being all too base To stain the temper of my knightly sword.

src: No, indeed, sir, not of a pin; you are therein in the right: but to the point. As I say, this Mistress Elbow, being, as I say, with child, and being great-bellied, and longing, as I said, for prunes;
trg: and having but two in the dish, as I said, Master Froth here, this very man, having eaten the rest, as I said, and, as I say, paying for them very honestly;

src: The king, that calls your beauteous daughter wife. Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother;
trg: Again shall you be mother to a king, And all the ruins of distressful times Repair'd with double riches of content. What! we have many goodly days to see:

src: Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid, He is frank'd up to fatting for his pains God pardon them that are the cause of it!
trg: A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion, To pray for them that have done scathe to us.

src: The lord protector lost it, and not I: When I was crown'd I was but nine months old.
trg: You are old enough now, and yet, methinks, you lose. Father, tear the crown from the usurper's head.

src: They are near the city?
trg: Almost at point to enter.

src: How, Camillo, May this, almost a miracle, be done? That I may call thee something more than man And after that trust to thee.
trg: Have you thought on A place whereto you'll go?

src: Therefore this order hath Baptista ta'en, That none shall have access unto Bianca Till Katharina the curst have got a husband.
trg: Katharina the curst! A title for a maid of all titles the worst.

src: Say, then: 'tis true, I ought so.
trg: We charge you, that you have contrived to take From Rome all season'd office and to wind Yourself into a power tyrannical; For which you are a traitor to the people.

src: So is the dear'st o' the loss.
trg: My lord Sebastian, The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness And time to speak it in: you rub the sore, When you should bring the plaster.

src: There is a vice that most I do abhor, And most desire should meet the blow of justice; For which I would not plead, but that I must;
trg: For which I must not plead, but that I am At war 'twixt will and will not.

src: Which to the high top-gallant of my joy Must be my convoy in the secret night. Farewell; be trusty, and I'll quit thy pains: Farewell; commend me to thy mistress.
trg: Now God in heaven bless thee! Hark you, sir.

src: Well, let her be admitted. See you the fornicatress be removed: Let have needful, but not lavish, means; There shall be order for't.
trg: God save your honour!

src: The revenue whereof shall furnish us For our affairs in hand: if that come short, Our substitutes at home shall have blank charters;
trg: Whereto, when they shall know what men are rich, They shall subscribe them for large sums of gold And send them after to supply our wants; For we will make for Ireland presently. Bushy, what news?

src: But what likelihood is in that?
trg: Not a resemblance, but a certainty.

src: We did observe. Cousin Aumerle, How far brought you high Hereford on his way?
trg: I brought high Hereford, if you call him so, But to the next highway, and there I left him.

src: I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.
trg: So shalt thou show me friendship. Take thou that: Live, and be prosperous: and farewell, good fellow.

src: I tell thee, Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away; And I expressly am forbid to touch it, For it engenders choler, planteth anger;
trg: And better 'twere that both of us did fast, Since, of ourselves, ourselves are choleric, Than feed it with such over-roasted flesh. Be patient;

src: Bid them wash their faces And keep their teeth clean. So, here comes a brace. You know the cause, air, of my standing here.
trg: We do, sir; tell us what hath brought you to't.

src: And now, instead of mounting barded steeds To fright the souls of fearful adversaries, He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
trg: But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks, Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass; I, that am rudely stamp'd, and want love's majesty To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;

src: Lords, knights, and gentlemen, what I should say My tears gainsay; for every word I speak, Ye see, I drink the water of mine eyes. Therefore, no more but this:
trg: Henry, your sovereign, Is prisoner to the foe; his state usurp'd, His realm a slaughter-house, his subjects slain, His statutes cancell'd and his treasure spent;

src: Clifford, repent in bootless penitence.
trg: Clifford, devise excuses for thy faults.

src: To tell, he longs to see his son, were strong: But let him say so then, and let him go; But let him swear so, and he shall not stay, We'll thwack him hence with distaffs.
trg: Yet of your royal presence I'll adventure The borrow of a week. When at Bohemia You take my lord, I'll give him my commission To let him there a month behind the gest Prefix'd for's parting:

src: Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes, That have been so bedazzled with the sun That everything I look on seemeth green: Now I perceive thou art a reverend father;
trg: Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.

src: Not a more cowardly rogue in all Bohemia: if you had but looked big and spit at him, he'ld have run.
trg: I must confess to you, sir, I am no fighter: I am false of heart that way; and that he knew, I warrant him.

src: Blessed be your royal grace! I have stood by, my lord, and I have heard Your royal ear abused.
trg: First, hath this woman Most wrongfully accused your substitute, Who is as free from touch or soil with her As she from one ungot.

src: But you, my noble lords, may name the time; And in the duke's behalf I'll give my voice, Which, I presume, he'll take in gentle part.
trg: Now in good time, here comes the duke himself.

src: Neither the king, nor he that loves him best, The proudest he that holds up Lancaster, Dares stir a wing, if Warwick shake his bells. I'll plant Plantagenet, root him up who dares:
trg: Resolve thee, Richard; claim the English crown.

src: No, no, forsooth; I dare not for my life.
trg: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears: What, did he marry me to famish me? Beggars, that come unto my father's door, Upon entreaty have a present aims;

src: Bid me farewell.
trg: 'Tis more than you deserve; But since you teach me how to flatter you, Imagine I have said farewell already.

src: Katharina, that cap of yours becomes you not: Off with that bauble, throw it under-foot.
trg: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh, Till I be brought to such a silly pass!

src: We will so: almost all Repent in their election.
trg: Let them go on; This mutiny were better put in hazard, Than stay, past doubt, for greater: If, as his nature is, he fall in rage With their refusal, both observe and answer The vantage of his anger.

src: Come down? Down, court! down, king! For night-owls shriek where mounting larks should sing.
trg: What says his majesty?

src: How! no more!
trg: You speak o' the people, As if you were a god to punish, not A man of their infirmity.

src: You have a daughter call'd Elizabeth, Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.
trg: And must she die for this? O, let her live, And I'll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty; Slander myself as false to Edward's bed; Throw over her the veil of infamy:

src: Little.
trg: My Lord of York will still be cross in talk: Uncle, your grace knows how to bear with him.

src: I hope, sir, your good worship will be my bail.
trg: No, indeed, will I not, Pompey; it is not the wear. I will pray, Pompey, to increase your bondage: If you take it not patiently, why, your mettle is the more. Adieu, trusty Pompey. 'Bless you, friar.

src: After the bloody fray at Wakefield fought, Where your brave father breathed his latest gasp, Tidings, as swiftly as the posts could run, Were brought me of your loss and his depart.
trg: For by my scouts I was advertised That she was coming with a full intent To dash our late decree in parliament Touching King Henry's oath and your succession.

src: It did, it did; alas the day, it did!
trg: O serpent heart, hid with a flowering face! Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave? Beautiful tyrant! fiend angelical! Dove-feather'd raven! wolvish-ravening lamb! Despised substance of divinest show!

src: Such hope have all the line of John of Gaunt!
trg: Thus do I hope to shake King Henry's head.

src: His name! as if I knew not his name: I have brought him up ever since he was three years old, and his name is Tranio.
trg: Away, away, mad ass! his name is Lucentio and he is mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.

src: Not so, not so; his life is parallel'd Even with the stroke and line of his great justice: He doth with holy abstinence subdue That in himself which he spurs on his power To qualify in others:
trg: were he meal'd with that Which he corrects, then were he tyrannous; But this being so, he's just. Now are they come. This is a gentle provost: seldom when The steeled gaoler is the friend of men.

src: So that in this time of lethargy I picked and cut most of their festival purses;
trg: and had not the old man come in with a whoo-bub against his daughter and the king's son and scared my choughs from the chaff, I had not left a purse alive in the whole army.

src: It is but needful: Mercy is not itself, that oft looks so; Pardon is still the nurse of second woe: But yet,--poor Claudio! There is no remedy. Come, sir.
trg: He's hearing of a cause; he will come straight I'll tell him of you.

src: Here in Vienna, sir.
trg: Are you of fourscore pounds a year?
I will converse with iron-witted fools And unrespective boys: none are for me That look into me with considerate eyes: High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect. Boy!

src: thence, A prosperous south-wind friendly, we have cross'd, To execute the charge my father gave me For visiting your highness: my best train I have from your Sicilian shores dismiss'd;
trg: Who for Bohemia bend, to signify Not only my success in Libya, sir, But my arrival and my wife's in safety Here where we are.

src: Here in the prison, father, There died this morning of a cruel fever One Ragozine, a most notorious pirate, A man of Claudio's years; his beard and head Just of his colour.
trg: What if we do omit This reprobate till he were well inclined; And satisfy the deputy with the visage Of Ragozine, more like to Claudio?

src: I should sin To think but nobly of my grandmother: Good wombs have borne bad sons.
trg: Now the condition. The King of Naples, being an enemy To me inveterate, hearkens my brother's suit;

src: then comes she to me, And, with wild looks, bid me devise some mean To rid her from this second marriage, Or in my cell there would she kill herself.
trg: Then gave I her, so tutor'd by my art, A sleeping potion; which so took effect As I intended, for it wrought on her The form of death:

src: The good gods assuage thy wrath, and turn the dregs of it upon this varlet here,--this, who, like a block, hath denied my access to thee.
trg: Away!

src: Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence? And little Ned Plantagenet, his son?
trg: Where is kind Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

src: Come, bring forth the prisoners.
trg: Sir Richard Ratcliff, let me tell thee this: To-day shalt thou behold a subject die For truth, for duty, and for loyalty.

src: Kings are no less unhappy, their issue not being gracious, than they are in losing them when they have approved their virtues.
trg: Sir, it is three days since I saw the prince. What his happier affairs may be, are to me unknown:

src: Are you my wife and will not call me husband? My men should call me 'lord:' I am your goodman.
trg: My husband and my lord, my lord and husband; I am your wife in all obedience.

src: much upon this time have I promised here to meet.
trg: You have not been inquired after: I have sat here all day.

src: Well, say. Peace, ho!
trg: Shall I be charged no further than this present? Must all determine here?

src: Gramercies, lad, go forward; this contents: The rest will comfort, for thy counsel's sound.
trg: Master, you look'd so longly on the maid, Perhaps you mark'd not what's the pith of all.

src: For what, I pray thee?
trg: For your broken shin.

src: Well, no more of it, Master Froth: farewell. Come you hither to me, Master tapster. What's your name, Master tapster?
trg: Pompey.

src: Would all were well! but that will never be I fear our happiness is at the highest.
trg: They do me wrong, and I will not endure it: Who are they that complain unto the king, That I, forsooth, am stern, and love them not?

src: I pray you, sir, let him go while the humour lasts. O' my word, an she knew him as well as I do, she would think scolding would do little good upon him:
trg: she may perhaps call him half a score knaves or so: why, that's nothing; an he begin once, he'll rail in his rope-tricks.

src: But now mischance hath trod my title down, And with dishonour laid me on the ground; Where I must take like seat unto my fortune, And to my humble seat conform myself.
trg: Why, say, fair queen, whence springs this deep despair?

src: Only, this one: Lord Angelo is precise; Stands at a guard with envy; scarce confesses That his blood flows, or that his appetite Is more to bread than stone:
trg: hence shall we see, If power change purpose, what our seemers be.

src: I know your virtue hath a licence in't, Which seems a little fouler than it is, To pluck on others.
trg: Believe me, on mine honour, My words express my purpose.

src: Be patient, gentle queen, and I will stay.
trg: Who can be patient in such extremes? Ah, wretched man!

src: The old cock.
trg: The cockerel.

src: Tut, she's a lamb, a dove, a fool to him! I'll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priest Should ask, if Katharina should be his wife, 'Ay, by gogs-wouns,' quoth he;
trg: and swore so loud, That, all-amazed, the priest let fall the book;

src: Trust to't, bethink you; I'll not be forsworn.
trg: Is there no pity sitting in the clouds, That sees into the bottom of my grief? O, sweet my mother, cast me not away! Delay this marriage for a month, a week;

src: By course of justice!
trg: And she will speak most bitterly and strange.

src: comfort me, counsel me. Alack, alack, that heaven should practise stratagems Upon so soft a subject as myself! What say'st thou? hast thou not a word of joy? Some comfort, nurse.
trg: Faith, here it is. Romeo is banish'd; and all the world to nothing, That he dares ne'er come back to challenge you; Or, if he do, it needs must be by stealth.

src: Here in your city; I now came from him: I speak amazedly; and it becomes My marvel and my message.
trg: Camillo has betray'd me; Whose honour and whose honesty till now Endured all weathers.

src: it is a gentleman of the greatest promise that ever came into my note.
trg: I very well agree with you in the hopes of him: it is a gallant child; one that indeed physics the subject, makes old hearts fresh:

src: I do love My country's good with a respect more tender, More holy and profound, than mine own life, My dear wife's estimate, her womb's increase, And treasure of my loins;
trg: then if I would Speak that,--

src: 'Tis done.
trg: Agreed.

src: I have done. Yet, if my lord will marry,--if you will, sir, No remedy, but you will,--give me the office To choose you a queen: she shall not be so young As was your former;
trg: but she shall be such As, walk'd your first queen's ghost, it should take joy To see her in your arms.

src: I'll wait upon your lordship.
trg: Come, bring forth the prisoners.

src: He is my father, sir; and, sooth to say, In countenance somewhat doth resemble you.
And would you not do much to do them good?
trg: To do them good, I would sustain some harm.

src: O, not by much.
trg: So much the more our carver's excellence; Which lets go by some sixteen years and makes her As she lived now.

src: Ah, sirs, consider, he that set you on To do this deed will hate you for the deed.
trg: What shall we do?

src: What, art thou waking?
trg: Do you not hear me speak?

src: I have some wounds upon me, and they smart To hear themselves remember'd.
trg: Should they not, Well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude, And tent themselves with death.

src: O heavens! O wife, look how our daughter bleeds! This dagger hath mista'en--for, lo, his house Is empty on the back of Montague,-- And it mis-sheathed in my daughter's bosom!
trg: O me! this sight of death is as a bell, That warns my old age to a sepulchre.

src: My lord?
trg: Send out a pursuivant at arms To Stanley's regiment; bid him bring his power Before sunrising, lest his son George fall Into the blind cave of eternal night. Fill me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch.

src: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.
trg: Sin from thy lips? O trespass sweetly urged! Give me my sin again.

src: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach? Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?
trg: Here were the servants of your adversary, And yours, close fighting ere I did approach: I drew to part them:

src: who, in my rage, Kneel'd at my feet, and bade me be advised Who spake of brotherhood? who spake of love? Who told me how the poor soul did forsake The mighty Warwick, and did fight for me?
trg: Who told me, in the field by Tewksbury When Oxford had me down, he rescued me, And said, 'Dear brother, live, and be a king'?

src: Pray you, be gone.
trg: I would to heaven I had your potency, And you were Isabel! should it then be thus? No; I would tell what 'twere to be a judge, And what a prisoner.

src: Next, it imports no reason That with such vehemency he should pursue Faults proper to himself: if he had so offended, He would have weigh'd thy brother by himself And not have cut him off.
trg: Some one hath set you on: Confess the truth, and say by whose advice Thou camest here to complain.

src: there, at the moated grange, resides this dejected Mariana. At that place call upon me; and dispatch with Angelo, that it may be quickly.
trg: I thank you for this comfort. Fare you well, good father.

src: That's but a cavil: he is old, I young.
trg: And may not young men die, as well as old?

src: Let me speak: I have been consul, and can show for Rome Her enemies' marks upon me.
trg: I do love My country's good with a respect more tender, More holy and profound, than mine own life, My dear wife's estimate, her womb's increase, And treasure of my loins;

src: Peace and prosperity! Who is't that calls
trg: Hail, virgin, if you be, as those cheek-roses Proclaim you are no less!

src: He shall not.
trg: Prithee, let him.

src: More bitterly could I expostulate, Save that, for reverence to some alive, I give a sparing limit to my tongue. Then, good my lord, take to your royal self This proffer'd benefit of dignity;
trg: If non to bless us and the land withal, Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry From the corruption of abusing times, Unto a lineal true-derived course.

src: I confess two sleeves.
Then learn to know him now; this is the duke.
trg: My gracious lord, I tender you my service, Such as it is, being tender, raw and young: Which elder days shall ripen and confirm To more approved service and desert.

src: only he hath made an essay of her virtue to practise his judgment with the disposition of natures:
trg: she, having the truth of honour in her, hath made him that gracious denial which he is most glad to receive. I am confessor to Angelo, and I know this to be true; therefore prepare yourself to death:

src: A hundred, if they'll do you any good. Is lechery so look'd after?
trg: Thus stands it with me: upon a true contract I got possession of Julietta's bed: You know the lady; she is fast my wife, Save that we do the denunciation lack Of outward order:

src: I will not bandy with thee word for word, But buckle with thee blows, twice two for one.
trg: Hold, valiant Clifford! for a thousand causes I would prolong awhile the traitor's life. Wrath makes him deaf: speak thou, Northumberland.

src: No, I'll nor sell nor give him: lend you him I will For half a hundred years. Summon the town.
trg: How far off lie these armies?

src: Look, sir, your mother!
trg: O, You have, I know, petition'd all the gods For my prosperity!

src: Ay, but yet Let us be keen, and rather cut a little, Than fall, and bruise to death. Alas, this gentleman Whom I would save, had a most noble father!
trg: 'Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus, Another thing to fall. I not deny, The jury, passing on the prisoner's life, May in the sworn twelve have a thief or two Guiltier than him they try.

src: This done, he took the bride about the neck And kiss'd her lips with such a clamorous smack That at the parting all the church did echo: And I seeing this came thence for very shame;
trg: And after me, I know, the rout is coming. Such a mad marriage never was before: Hark, hark! I hear the minstrels play.

src: O noble prince, I can discover all The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl: There lies the man, slain by young Romeo, That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.
trg: Tybalt, my cousin! O my brother's child! O prince! O cousin! husband! O, the blood is spilt O my dear kinsman! Prince, as thou art true, For blood of ours, shed blood of Montague. O cousin, cousin!

src: I aim'd so near, when I supposed you loved.
trg: A right good mark-man! And she's fair I love.

src: God bless your grace! we see it, and will say it.
trg: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.

src: Master, master! news, old news, and such news as you never heard of!
trg: Is it new and old too? how may that be?

src: Princes have but their tides for their glories, An outward honour for an inward toil; And, for unfelt imagination, They often feel a world of restless cares:
trg: So that, betwixt their tides and low names, There's nothing differs but the outward fame.

src: I thank you, good my lord; and thank you all.
trg: I thought my mother, and my brother York, Would long ere this have met us on the way Fie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes not To tell us whether they will come or no!

src: You say well.
trg: Yea, is the worst well? very well took, i' faith; wisely, wisely.

src: Sir, the duke is marvellous little beholding to your reports; but the best is, he lives not in them.
trg: Friar, thou knowest not the duke so well as I do: he's a better woodman than thou takest him for.

src: Draw near, And list what with our council we have done. For that our kingdom's earth should not be soil'd With that dear blood which it hath fostered;
trg: And for our eyes do hate the dire aspect Of civil wounds plough'd up with neighbours' sword;

src: O king, believe not this hard-hearted man! Love loving not itself none other can.
trg: Thou frantic woman, what dost thou make here? Shall thy old dugs once more a traitor rear?

src: See how the surly Warwick mans the wall!
trg: O unbid spite! is sportful Edward come? Where slept our scouts, or how are they seduced, That we could hear no news of his repair?

src: For 'tis a sore upon us, You cannot tent yourself: be gone, beseech you.
trg: Come, sir, along with us.

src: Carnally, she says.
trg: Sirrah, no more!

src: Thy woes will make them sharp, and pierce like mine.
trg: Why should calamity be full of words?

src: Is it true too, think you?
trg: Five justices' hands at it, and witnesses more than my pack will hold.

src: This is to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.
trg: And therefore 'tis called a sensible tale: and this cuff was but to knock at your ear, and beseech listening. Now I begin: Imprimis, we came down a foul hill, my master riding behind my mistress,--

src: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory Can from his mother win the Duke of York, Anon expect him here;
trg: but if she be obdurate To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid We should infringe the holy privilege Of blessed sanctuary! not for all this land Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.

src: You have misled a prince, a royal king, A happy gentleman in blood and lineaments, By you unhappied and disfigured clean: This and much more, much more than twice all this, Condemns you to the death.
trg: See them deliver'd over To execution and the hand of death.

src: What, art thou ashamed of me?
trg: No, sir, God forbid; but ashamed to kiss.

src: No remedy. Have you done there?
trg: Should I now meet my father, He would not call me son.

src: So she may live unscarr'd of bleeding slaughter, I will confess she was not Edward's daughter.
trg: Wrong not her birth, she is of royal blood.

src: Go, nurse, go with her: we'll to church to-morrow.
trg: We shall be short in our provision: 'Tis now near night.

src: Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt With modest warrant.
trg: Sir, how comes't that you Have holp to make this rescue?

src: Towards him I made, but he was ware of me And stole into the covert of the wood:
trg: I, measuring his affections by my own, That most are busied when they're most alone, Pursued my humour not pursuing his, And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.

src: On the sudden, I warrant him consul.
trg: Then our office may, During his power, go sleep.

src: Here's the midwife's name to't, one Mistress Tale-porter, and five or six honest wives that were present. Why should I carry lies abroad?
trg: Pray you now, buy it.

src: I say, sir, I will detest myself also, as well as she, that this house, if it be not a bawd's house, it is pity of her life, for it is a naughty house.
trg: How dost thou know that, constable?

src: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two, to make merry withal?
trg: Keep your hundred pounds to yourself: he shall need none, so long as I live.

src: There is none worthy, Respecting her that's gone. Besides, the gods Will have fulfill'd their secret purposes;
trg: For has not the divine Apollo said, Is't not the tenor of his oracle, That King Leontes shall not have an heir Till his lost child be found?

src: Fear me not.
trg: No, marry; I fear thee!

src: there they hoist us, To cry to the sea that roar'd to us, to sigh To the winds whose pity, sighing back again, Did us but loving wrong.
trg: Alack, what trouble Was I then to you!

src: Mistress, what cheer?
trg: Faith, as cold as can be.

src: Why, he that wears her like a medal, hanging About his neck, Bohemia:
trg: who, if I Had servants true about me, that bare eyes To see alike mine honour as their profits, Their own particular thrifts, they would do that Which should undo more doing:

src: What is about to be? I am out of breath; Confusion's near; I cannot speak. You, tribunes To the people! Coriolanus, patience! Speak, good Sicinius.
trg: Hear me, people; peace!

src: It grieves me for the death of Claudio; But there's no remedy.
trg: Lord Angelo is severe.

src: I'll not remember you of my own lord, Who is lost too: take your patience to you, And I'll say nothing.
trg: Thou didst speak but well When most the truth; which I receive much better Than to be pitied of thee. Prithee, bring me To the dead bodies of my queen and son: One grave shall be for both:

src: Could great men thunder As Jove himself does, Jove would ne'er be quiet, For every pelting, petty officer Would use his heaven for thunder; Nothing but thunder!
trg: Merciful Heaven, Thou rather with thy sharp and sulphurous bolt Split'st the unwedgeable and gnarled oak Than the soft myrtle: who, with our spleens, Would all themselves laugh mortal.

src: Sir, sir,--
trg: Peace!

src: No doubt, no doubt; and so shall Clarence too; For they that were your enemies are his, And have prevail'd as much on him as you.
trg: More pity that the eagle should be mew'd, While kites and buzzards prey at liberty.

src: Stay thy revengeful hand; thou hast no cause to fear.
O sir, such a life, with such a wife, were strange! But if you have a stomach, to't i' God's name: You shall have me assisting you in all. But will you woo this wild-cat?
trg: Will I live?

src: And many more of noble fame and worth: And towards London they do bend their course, If by the way they be not fought withal.
trg: Return unto thy lord; commend me to him: Tell him the queen hath heartily consented He shall espouse Elizabeth her daughter. These letters will resolve him of my mind. Farewell.

src: Nay, all of you that stand and look upon, Whilst that my wretchedness doth bait myself, Though some of you with Pilate wash your hands Showing an outward pity;
trg: yet you Pilates Have here deliver'd me to my sour cross, And water cannot wash away your sin.

src: One kiss shall stop our mouths, and dumbly part; Thus give I mine, and thus take I thy heart.
trg: Give me mine own again; 'twere no good part To take on me to keep and kill thy heart. So, now I have mine own again, be gone, That I might strive to kill it with a groan.

src: whither should they come?
trg: Up.

src: Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome, And occupations perish!
trg: What, what, what! I shall be loved when I am lack'd. Nay, mother.

src: Where's Captain Margaret, to fence you now?
trg: They mock thee, Clifford: swear as thou wast wont.

src: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?
trg: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.

src: Ay, those attires are best:
trg: but, gentle nurse, I pray thee, leave me to myself to-night, For I have need of many orisons To move the heavens to smile upon my state, Which, well thou know'st, is cross, and full of sin.

src: Mine, full of sorrow and heart's discontent.
trg: What! has your king married the Lady Grey! And now, to soothe your forgery and his, Sends me a paper to persuade me patience? Is this the alliance that he seeks with France?

src: By'r lady, thirty years.
trg: What, man! 'tis not so much, 'tis not so much: 'Tis since the nuptials of Lucentio, Come pentecost as quickly as it will, Some five and twenty years; and then we mask'd.

src: It was, villain, ere thy hand did set it down. I tore it from the traitor's bosom, king; Fear, and not love, begets his penitence:
trg: Forget to pity him, lest thy pity prove A serpent that will sting thee to the heart.

src: You have made good work, You and your apron-men; you that stood so up much on the voice of occupation and The breath of garlic-eaters!
trg: He will shake Your Rome about your ears.

src: Forbear awhile; we'll hear a little more.
trg: My queen and son are gone to France for aid; And, as I hear, the great commanding Warwick Is thither gone, to crave the French king's sister To wife for Edward:

src: You have not been inquired after: I have sat here all day.
trg: I do constantly believe you. The time is come even now. I shall crave your forbearance a little: may be I will call upon you anon, for some advantage to yourself.

src: Ay; and you'll look pale Before you find it other. All the regions Do smilingly revolt; and who resist Are mock'd for valiant ignorance, And perish constant fools. Who is't can blame him?
trg: Your enemies and his find something in him.

src: I have heard, sir, of such a man, who hath a daughter of most rare note: the report of her is extended more than can be thought to begin from such a cottage.
trg: That's likewise part of my intelligence; but, I fear, the angle that plucks our son thither. Thou shalt accompany us to the place;

src: Methought he bore him in the thickest troop As doth a lion in a herd of neat;
trg: Or as a bear, encompass'd round with dogs, Who having pinch'd a few and made them cry, The rest stand all aloof, and bark at him. So fared our father with his enemies;

src: Art thou gone so? love, lord, ay, husband, friend! I must hear from thee every day in the hour, For in a minute there are many days:
trg: O, by this count I shall be much in years Ere I again behold my Romeo!

src: My sword, I say! Old Montague is come, And flourishes his blade in spite of me.
trg: Thou villain Capulet,--Hold me not, let me go.

src: She shall, Lucentio. Come, gentlemen, let's go.
trg: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and all foul ways! Was ever man so beaten? was ever man so rayed? was ever man so weary?

src: I'll fight with none but thee; for I do hate thee Worse than a promise-breaker.
trg: We hate alike: Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.

src: By heaven, I will not do thee so much ease.
trg: Good Clarence, do; sweet Clarence, do thou do it.

src: In earnest, it's true; I heard a senator speak it. Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth; against whom Cominius the general is gone, with one part of our Roman power:
trg: your lord and Titus Lartius are set down before their city Corioli; they nothing doubt prevailing and to make it brief wars. This is true, on mine honour; and so, I pray, go with us.

src: of that kind Our rustic garden's barren; and I care not To get slips of them.
trg: Wherefore, gentle maiden, Do you neglect them?

src: Norfolk, we must have knocks; ha! must we not?
trg: We must both give and take, my gracious lord.

src: King Edward, valiant Richard, Montague, Stay we no longer, dreaming of renown, But sound the trumpets, and about our task.
trg: Then, Clifford, were thy heart as hard as steel, As thou hast shown it flinty by thy deeds, I come to pierce it, or to give thee mine.

src: Well, let that pass. Dorset is fled to Richmond.
trg: I hear that news, my lord.

src: And I will do it without fear or doubt, To live an unstain'd wife to my sweet love.
trg: Hold, then; go home, be merry, give consent To marry Paris: Wednesday is to-morrow: To-morrow night look that thou lie alone; Let not thy nurse lie with thee in thy chamber:

src: Believe me, thou talkest of an admirable conceited fellow. Has he any unbraided wares?
trg: He hath ribbons of an the colours i' the rainbow; points more than all the lawyers in Bohemia can learnedly handle, though they come to him by the gross: inkles, caddisses, cambrics, lawns:

src: if the old fantastical duke of dark corners had been at home, he had lived.
trg: Sir, the duke is marvellous little beholding to your reports; but the best is, he lives not in them.

src: Say that the king, which may command, entreats.
trg: That at her hands which the king's King forbids.

src: Sir, you say well and well you do conceive; And since you do profess to be a suitor, You must, as we do, gratify this gentleman, To whom we all rest generally beholding.
trg: Sir, I shall not be slack:

src: And far surmounts our labour to attain it.
trg: Evermore thanks, the exchequer of the poor; Which, till my infant fortune comes to years, Stands for my bounty. But who comes here?

src: No, my good lord.
trg: No matter: get thee gone, And hire those horses; I'll be with thee straight. Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee to-night. Let's see for means:

src: O lamentable day!
trg: What is the matter?

src: nutmegs, seven; a race or two of ginger, but that I may beg; four pound of prunes, and as many of raisins o' the sun.
trg: O that ever I was born!

src: out o' the substitution And executing the outward face of royalty, With all prerogative: hence his ambition growing-- Dost thou hear?
trg: Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.

src: Worthy voices!
trg: You have stood your limitation; and the tribunes Endue you with the people's voice: remains That, in the official marks invested, you Anon do meet the senate.

src: Else let my brother die, If not a feodary, but only he Owe and succeed thy weakness.
trg: Nay, women are frail too.
