src: Younger than she are happy mothers made.
trg: And too soon marr'd are those so early made. The earth hath swallow'd all my hopes but she, She is the hopeful lady of my earth:

src: Thou desperate pilot, now at once run on The dashing rocks thy sea-sick weary bark! Here's to my love! O true apothecary! Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die.
trg: Saint Francis be my speed! how oft to-night Have my old feet stumbled at graves! Who's there?

src: in a rebellion, When what's not meet, but what must be, was law, Then were they chosen: in a better hour, Let what is meet be said it must be meet, And throw their power i' the dust.
trg: Manifest treason!

src: An hour before I came, the duchess died.
trg: God for his mercy! what a tide of woes Comes rushing on this woeful land at once! I know not what to do:

src: Wouldst thou withdraw it? for what purpose, love?
trg: But to be frank, and give it thee again. And yet I wish but for the thing I have: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep;

src: I have seen the day That I have worn a visor and could tell A whispering tale in a fair lady's ear, Such as would please: 'tis gone, 'tis gone, 'tis gone: You are welcome, gentlemen!
trg: come, musicians, play. A hall, a hall! give room! and foot it, girls. More light, you knaves; and turn the tables up, And quench the fire, the room is grown too hot.

src: More to know Did never meddle with my thoughts.
trg: 'Tis time I should inform thee farther. Lend thy hand, And pluck my magic garment from me. So: Lie there, my art. Wipe thou thine eyes; have comfort. Sit down; For thou must now know farther.

src: Why, this it is, when men are ruled by women: 'Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower: My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, 'tis she That tempers him to this extremity.
trg: Was it not she and that good man of worship, Anthony Woodville, her brother there, That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower, From whence this present day he is deliver'd?

src: I would they were in Tiber! What the vengeance! Could he not speak 'em fair?
trg: Where is this viper That would depopulate the city and Be every man himself?

src: we must be burnt for you.
trg: Nay, pray, be patient: if you refuse your aid In this so never-needed help, yet do not Upbraid's with our distress.

src: This way, my lord; for this way lies the game.
trg: Nay, this way, man: see where the huntsmen stand. Now, brother of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, and the rest, Stand you thus close, to steal the bishop's deer?

src: But now, I tell thee--keep it to thyself-- This day those enemies are put to death, And I in better state than e'er I was.
trg: God hold it, to your honour's good content!

src: So is the equal of this fell war. Here on this molehill will I sit me down. To whom God will, there be the victory! For Margaret my queen, and Clifford too, Have chid me from the battle;
trg: swearing both They prosper best of all when I am thence. Would I were dead! if God's good will were so; For what is in this world but grief and woe? O God!

src: Ah, know you not the city favours them, And they have troops of soldiers at their beck?
trg: But when the duke is slain, they'll quickly fly.

src: O ho, O ho! would't had been done! Thou didst prevent me; I had peopled else This isle with Calibans.
trg: Abhorred slave, Which any print of goodness wilt not take, Being capable of all ill! I pitied thee, Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour One thing or other:

src: The wrinkles in my brows, now filled with blood, Were liken'd oft to kingly sepulchres; For who lived king, but I could dig his grave? And who durst mine when Warwick bent his brow?
trg: Lo, now my glory smear'd in dust and blood! My parks, my walks, my manors that I had. Even now forsake me, and of all my lands Is nothing left me but my body's length.

src: You may, sir.
trg: That I'll straight do; and, knowing myself again, Repair to the senate-house.

src: No, good my lord; let's fight with gentle words Till time lend friends and friends their helpful swords.
trg: O God, O God! that e'er this tongue of mine, That laid the sentence of dread banishment On yon proud man, should take it off again With words of sooth!

src: Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported?
trg: She was, good Curtis, before this frost: but, thou knowest, winter tames man, woman and beast; for it hath tamed my old master and my new mistress and myself, fellow Curtis.

src: Romeo, doff thy name, And for that name which is no part of thee Take all myself.
trg: I take thee at thy word: Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized; Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

src: Bless me from marrying a usurer!
trg: Here's the midwife's name to't, one Mistress Tale-porter, and five or six honest wives that were present. Why should I carry lies abroad?

src: guess, but by my entertainment with him, if thou standest not i' the state of hanging, or of some death more long in spectatorship, and crueller in suffering;
trg: behold now presently, and swoon for what's to come upon thee. The glorious gods sit in hourly synod about thy particular prosperity, and love thee no worse than thy old father Menenius does!

src: For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night Whiter than new snow on a raven's back. Come, gentle night, come, loving, black-brow'd night, Give me my Romeo;
trg: and, when he shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine That all the world will be in love with night And pay no worship to the garish sun.

src: There was it: For which my sinews shall be stretch'd upon him. At a few drops of women's rheum, which are As cheap as lies, he sold the blood and labour Of our great action:
trg: therefore shall he die, And I'll renew me in his fall. But, hark!

src: We are but plain fellows, sir.
trg: A lie; you are rough and hairy. Let me have no lying: it becomes none but tradesmen, and they often give us soldiers the lie: but we pay them for it with stamped coin, not stabbing steel;

src: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place; Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.
trg: Is it upon record, or else reported Successively from age to age, he built it?

src: No noise, my lord; but needful conference About some gossips for your highness.
trg: How! Away with that audacious lady! Antigonus, I charged thee that she should not come about me: I knew she would.

src: Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloucester; For Gloucester's dukedom is too ominous.
trg: Tut, that's a foolish observation: Richard, be Duke of Gloucester. Now to London, To see these honours in possession. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.
trg: We know't, we know't.

src: 'Tis not to save labour, nor that I want love.
trg: You would be another Penelope: yet, they say, all the yarn she spun in Ulysses' absence did but fill Ithaca full of moths. Come;

src: Well guess'd, believe me; for that was my meaning.
trg: Stanley, I will requite thy forwardness.

src: 'Tis true: If he were putting to my house the brand That should consume it, I have not the face To say 'Beseech you, cease.' You have made fair hands, You and your crafts! you have crafted fair!
trg: You have brought A trembling upon Rome, such as was never So incapable of help.

src: -- And yet me thinks I see it in thy face, What thou shouldst be: the occasion speaks thee, and My strong imagination sees a crown Dropping upon thy head.
trg: What, art thou waking?

src: My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word; But now thy beauty is proposed my fee, My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak.
trg: Teach not thy lips such scorn, for they were made For kissing, lady, not for such contempt. If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive, Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword;

src: He took good rest to-night; 'Tis hoped his sickness is discharged.
trg: To see his nobleness! Leave me solely: go, See how he fares. Fie, fie! no thought of him: The thought of my revenges that way Recoil upon me: in himself too mighty, And in his parties, his alliance;

src: so use it That my revengeful services may prove As benefits to thee, for I will fight Against my canker'd country with the spleen Of all the under fiends.
trg: But if so be Thou darest not this and that to prove more fortunes Thou'rt tired, then, in a word, I also am Longer to live most weary, and present My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice;

src: Sir, here's the door, this is Lucentio's house: My father's bears more toward the market-place; Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.
trg: You shall not choose but drink before you go: I think I shall command your welcome here, And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward.

src: She is, When once she is my wife.
trg: That 'once' I see by your good father's speed Will come on very slowly.

src: But since correction lieth in those hands Which made the fault that we cannot correct, Put we our quarrel to the will of heaven;
trg: Who, when they see the hours ripe on earth, Will rain hot vengeance on offenders' heads.

src: I fear no uncles dead.
trg: Nor none that live, I hope.

src: My brother's love, the devil, and my rage.
trg: Thy brother's love, our duty, and thy fault, Provoke us hither now to slaughter thee.

src: O heavens! what stuff is here
trg: 'Twas never merry world since, of two usuries, the merriest was put down, and the worser allowed by order of law a furred gown to keep him warm;

src: Villain, not for thy life: take up my mistress' gown for thy master's use!
trg: Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?

src: Many a time hath banish'd Norfolk fought For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field, Streaming the ensign of the Christian cross Against black pagans, Turks, and Saracens:
trg: And toil'd with works of war, retired himself To Italy;

src: The fruits of love I mean, my loving liege.
trg: Ay, but, I fear me, in another sense. What love, think'st thou, I sue so much to get?

src: Finds brotherhood in thee no sharper spur? Hath love in thy old blood no living fire?
trg: Edward's seven sons, whereof thyself art one, Were as seven vials of his sacred blood, Or seven fair branches springing from one root:

src: A lunatic lean-witted fool, Presuming on an ague's privilege, Darest with thy frozen admonition Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood With fury from his native residence.
trg: Now, by my seat's right royal majesty, Wert thou not brother to great Edward's son, This tongue that runs so roundly in thy head Should run thy head from thy unreverent shoulders.

src: Your presence makes us rich, most noble lord.
trg: And far surmounts our labour to attain it.

src: Nay, an there were two such, we should have none shortly, for one would kill the other. Thou! why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more, or a hair less, in his beard, than thou hast:
trg: thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes: what eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?

src: Hast thou that holy feeling in thy soul, To counsel me to make my peace with God, And art thou yet to thy own soul so blind, That thou wilt war with God by murdering me?
trg: Ah, sirs, consider, he that set you on To do this deed will hate you for the deed.

src: Come, boy; I am past moe children, but thy sons and daughters will be all gentlemen born.
trg: You are well met, sir. You denied to fight with me this other day, because I was no gentleman born. See you these clothes? say you see them not and think me still no gentleman born:

src: she, having the truth of honour in her, hath made him that gracious denial which he is most glad to receive. I am confessor to Angelo, and I know this to be true; therefore prepare yourself to death:
trg: do not satisfy your resolution with hopes that are fallible: tomorrow you must die; go to your knees and make ready.

src: Good brother, as thou lovest and honourest arms, Let's fight it out and not stand cavilling thus.
trg: Sound drums and trumpets, and the king will fly.

src: Thou speak'st truth. No more such wives; therefore, no wife:
trg: one worse, And better used, would make her sainted spirit Again possess her corpse, and on this stage, Where we're offenders now, appear soul-vex'd, And begin, 'Why to me?'

src: My father, being the Earl of Warwick's man, Came on the part of York, press'd by his master; And I, who at his hands received my life, him Have by my hands of life bereaved him.
trg: Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did! And pardon, father, for I knew not thee! My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks; And no more words till they have flow'd their fill.

src: Enforced thee! art thou king, and wilt be forced? I shame to hear thee speak. Ah, timorous wretch! Thou hast undone thyself, thy son and me;
trg: And given unto the house of York such head As thou shalt reign but by their sufferance.

src: I know not where; but wheresoever, I wish him well.
trg: It was a mad fantastical trick of him to steal from the state, and usurp the beggary he was never born to. Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence; he puts transgression to 't.

src: 'Tis the Lord Hastings, the king's chiefest friend.
trg: O, is it so? But why commands the king That his chief followers lodge in towns about him, While he himself keeps in the cold field?

src: God make your majesty joyful as you have been!
trg: The Countess Richmond, good my Lord of Derby. To your good prayers will scarcely say amen.

src: Alack, why am I sent for to a king, Before I have shook off the regal thoughts Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet have learn'd To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs:
trg: Give sorrow leave awhile to tutor me To this submission. Yet I well remember The favours of these men: were they not mine? Did they not sometime cry, 'all hail!' to me? So Judas did to Christ:

src: Go, bind thou up yon dangling apricocks, Which, like unruly children, make their sire Stoop with oppression of their prodigal weight: Give some supportance to the bending twigs.
trg: Go thou, and like an executioner, Cut off the heads of too fast growing sprays, That look too lofty in our commonwealth: All must be even in our government.

src: Come; fear you not: good counsellors lack no clients: though you change your place, you need not change your trade; I'll be your tapster still. Courage! there will be pity taken on you:
trg: you that have worn your eyes almost out in the service, you will be considered.

src: for honour, 'Tis a derivative from me to mine, And only that I stand for. I appeal To your own conscience, sir, before Polixenes Came to your court, how I was in your grace, How merited to be so;
trg: since he came, With what encounter so uncurrent I Have strain'd to appear thus:

src: O me, the gods! You must not speak of that: you must desire them To think upon you.
trg: Think upon me! hang 'em! I would they would forget me, like the virtues Which our divines lose by 'em.

src: Come, Warwick, take the time; kneel down, kneel down: Nay, when? strike now, or else the iron cools.
trg: I had rather chop this hand off at a blow, And with the other fling it at thy face, Than bear so low a sail, to strike to thee.

src: Saint Francis be my speed! how oft to-night Have my old feet stumbled at graves! Who's there?
trg: Here's one, a friend, and one that knows you well.

src: Spoke like an officer; ha' to thee, lad!
trg: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?

src: Hence with it, and together with the dam Commit them to the fire!
trg: It is yours; And, might we lay the old proverb to your charge, So like you, 'tis the worse.

src: A' shall not tread on me; I'll run away till I am bigger, but then I'll fight.
trg: Not of a woman's tenderness to be, Requires nor child nor woman's face to see. I have sat too long.

src: Fear not, my lord: we can contain ourselves, Were he the veriest antic in the world.
trg: Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery, And give them friendly welcome every one: Let them want nothing that my house affords.

src: Out, alas! You'd be so lean, that blasts of January Would blow you through and through. Now, my fair'st friend, I would I had some flowers o' the spring that might Become your time of day;
trg: and yours, and yours, That wear upon your virgin branches yet Your maidenheads growing: O Proserpina, For the flowers now, that frighted thou let'st fall From Dis's waggon!

src: Richard, enough; I will be king, or die. Brother, thou shalt to London presently, And whet on Warwick to this enterprise.
trg: Thou, Richard, shalt to the Duke of Norfolk, And tell him privily of our intent. You Edward, shall unto my Lord Cobham, With whom the Kentishmen will willingly rise: In them I trust;

src: He could not miss't.
trg: It must needs be of subtle, tender and delicate temperance.

src: What! have I twice said well? when was't before? I prithee tell me; cram's with praise, and make's As fat as tame things: one good deed dying tongueless Slaughters a thousand waiting upon that.
trg: Our praises are our wages: you may ride's With one soft kiss a thousand furlongs ere With spur we beat an acre. But to the goal: My last good deed was to entreat his stay: What was my first?

src: But say, I pray, what nobleman is that That with the king here resteth in his tent?
trg: 'Tis the Lord Hastings, the king's chiefest friend.

src: Ay me! sad hours seem long. Was that my father that went hence so fast?
trg: It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?

src: Stay your thanks a while; And pay them when you part.
trg: Sir, that's to-morrow. I am question'd by my fears, of what may chance Or breed upon our absence; that may blow No sneaping winds at home, to make us say 'This is put forth too truly:

src: They have a leader, Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to 't. I sin in envying his nobility, And were I any thing but what I am, I would wish me only he.
trg: You have fought together.

src: The citizens of Corioli have issued, And given to Lartius and to Marcius battle: I saw our party to their trenches driven, And then I came away.
trg: Though thou speak'st truth, Methinks thou speak'st not well. How long is't since?

src: Why, cousin, wert thou regent of the world, It were a shame to let this land by lease; But for thy world enjoying but this land, Is it not more than shame to shame it so?
trg: Landlord of England art thou now, not king: Thy state of law is bondslave to the law; And thou--

src: For why, the senseless brands will sympathize The heavy accent of thy moving tongue And in compassion weep the fire out;
trg: And some will mourn in ashes, some coal-black, For the deposing of a rightful king.

src: Say, she shall be a high and mighty queen.
trg: To wail the tide, as her mother doth.

src: When every grief is entertain'd that's offer'd, Comes to the entertainer--
trg: A dollar.

src: they that went on crutches ere he was born desire yet their life to see him a man.
trg: Would they else be content to die?

src: His better doth not breathe upon the earth.
trg: He lives that loves thee better than he could.

src: I, that please some, try all, both joy and terror Of good and bad, that makes and unfolds error, Now take upon me, in the name of Time, To use my wings.
trg: Let me pass The same I am, ere ancient'st order was Or what is now received: I witness to The times that brought them in;

src: The ship, sir, the slip; can you not conceive?
trg: Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was great; and in such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy.

src: I prithee, give no limits to my tongue: I am a king, and privileged to speak.
trg: My liege, the wound that bred this meeting here Cannot be cured by words; therefore be still.

src: Young York he is but boot, because both they Match not the high perfection of my loss: Thy Clarence he is dead that kill'd my Edward;
trg: And the beholders of this tragic play, The adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey, Untimely smother'd in their dusky graves.

src: Oh for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!
trg: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!

src: To entail him and his heirs unto the crown, What is it, but to make thy sepulchre And creep into it far before thy time? Warwick is chancellor and the lord of Calais;
trg: Stern Falconbridge commands the narrow seas; The duke is made protector of the realm; And yet shalt thou be safe? such safety finds The trembling lamb environed with wolves.

src: Nay, I hear nothing: his mother and his wife Hear nothing from him.
trg: The gods preserve you both!

src: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.
trg: Now, by my holidame, here comes Katharina!

src: He was convey'd by Richard Duke of Gloucester And the Lord Hastings, who attended him In secret ambush on the forest side And from the bishop's huntsmen rescued him;
trg: For hunting was his daily exercise.

src: Brother, I'll go and bring it thee.
trg: Now must I to the monument alone; Within three hours will fair Juliet wake: She will beshrew me much that Romeo Hath had no notice of these accidents;

src: And lessen'd be that small, God, I beseech thee! Thy honour, state and seat is due to me.
trg: What! threat you me with telling of the king? Tell him, and spare not: look, what I have said I will avouch in presence of the king: I dare adventure to be sent to the Tower. 'Tis time to speak;

src: All things that we ordained festival, Turn from their office to black funeral;
trg: Sir, go you in; and, madam, go with him; And go, Sir Paris; every one prepare To follow this fair corse unto her grave: The heavens do lour upon you for some ill;

src: How now, my friend! why dost thou look so pale?
trg: For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.

src: Well done, my lord.
trg: Though I am satisfied and need no more Than what I know, yet shall the oracle Give rest to the minds of others, such as he Whose ignorant credulity will not Come up to the truth.

src: If ever he have child, abortive be it, Prodigious, and untimely brought to light, Whose ugly and unnatural aspect May fright the hopeful mother at the view; And that be heir to his unhappiness!
trg: If ever he have wife, let her he made A miserable by the death of him As I am made by my poor lord and thee! Come, now towards Chertsey with your holy load, Taken from Paul's to be interred there;

src: Ay, there's the villany.
trg: Error i' the bill, sir; error i' the bill. I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again; and that I'll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.

src: And blessing Against this cruelty fight on thy side, Poor thing, condemn'd to loss!
trg: No, I'll not rear Another's issue.

src: Marry, I thank your good worship for it. What is't your worship's pleasure I shall do with this wicked caitiff?
trg: Truly, officer, because he hath some offences in him that thou wouldst discover if thou couldst, let him continue in his courses till thou knowest what they are.

src: Hold out my horse, and I will first be there.
trg: Madam, your majesty is too much sad: You promised, when you parted with the king, To lay aside life-harming heaviness And entertain a cheerful disposition.

src: This jealousy Is for a precious creature: Fear o'ershades me: Good expedition be my friend, and comfort The gracious queen, part of his theme, but nothing Of his ill-ta'en suspicion! Come, Camillo;
trg: I will respect thee as a father if Thou bear'st my life off hence: let us avoid.

src: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?
trg: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

src: Women and children of so high a courage, And warriors faint! why, 'twere perpetual shame. O brave young prince! thy famous grandfather Doth live again in thee:
trg: long mayst thou live To bear his image and renew his glories!

src: I'll prove the contrary, if you'll hear me speak.
trg: Thou canst not, son; it is impossible.

src: Let be, let be. Would I were dead, but that, methinks, already-- What was he that did make it? See, my lord, Would you not deem it breathed? and that those veins Did verily bear blood?
trg: Masterly done: The very life seems warm upon her lip.

src: but were he dead, Yet here Prince Edward stands, King Henry's son. Look, therefore, Lewis, that by this league and marriage Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonour;
trg: For though usurpers sway the rule awhile, Yet heavens are just, and time suppresseth wrongs.

src: How! not women?
trg: Women will love her, that she is a woman More worth than any man; men, that she is The rarest of all women.

src: It stands your grace upon to do him right.
trg: Base men by his endowments are made great.

src: Honest goodfellows, ah, put up, put up; For, well you know, this is a pitiful case.
trg: Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.

src: Why the devil came you between us? I was hurt under your arm.
trg: I thought all for the best.

src: And what you do, do it unfeignedly.
trg: Here, Hastings; I will never more remember Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine!

src: Dispute not with her; she is lunatic.
trg: Peace, master marquess, you are malapert: Your fire-new stamp of honour is scarce current. O, that your young nobility could judge What 'twere to lose it, and be miserable!

src: Where did you dwell when I was King of England?
trg: Here in this country, where we now remain.

src: Fellows in arms, and my most loving friends, Bruised underneath the yoke of tyranny, Thus far into the bowels of the land Have we march'd on without impediment;
trg: And here receive we from our father Stanley Lines of fair comfort and encouragement.

src: In her consists my happiness and thine; Without her, follows to this land and me, To thee, herself, and many a Christian soul, Death, desolation, ruin and decay: It cannot be avoided but by this;
trg: It will not be avoided but by this. Therefore, good mother,--I must can you so-- Be the attorney of my love to her: Plead what I will be, not what I have been;

src: and when thou art old and rich, Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor beauty, To make thy riches pleasant. What's yet in this That bears the name of life?
trg: Yet in this life Lie hid moe thousand deaths: yet death we fear, That makes these odds all even.

src: Madam, he hath not slept tonight; commanded None should come at him.
trg: Not so hot, good sir: I come to bring him sleep. 'Tis such as you, That creep like shadows by him and do sigh At each his needless heavings, such as you Nourish the cause of his awaking:

src: let your general do his worst. For you, be that you are, long; and your misery increase with your age! I say to you, as I was said to, Away!
trg: A noble fellow, I warrant him.

src: Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible,--
trg: Yet,--

src: Stand all apart, And show fair duty to his majesty. My gracious lord,--
trg: Fair cousin, you debase your princely knee To make the base earth proud with kissing it: Me rather had my heart might feel your love Than my unpleased eye see your courtesy. Up, cousin, up;

src: the kings and the princes, our kindred, are going to see the queen's picture. Come, follow us: we'll be thy good masters.
trg: O grave and good Paulina, the great comfort That I have had of thee!

src: Now He that made me knows I see thee ill; Ill in myself to see, and in thee seeing ill. Thy death-bed is no lesser than thy land Wherein thou liest in reputation sick;
trg: And thou, too careless patient as thou art, Commit'st thy anointed body to the cure Of those physicians that first wounded thee:

src: What raiment will your honour wear to-day?
trg: I am Christophero Sly; call not me 'honour' nor 'lordship:' I ne'er drank sack in my life; and if you give me any conserves, give me conserves of beef: ne'er ask me what raiment I'll wear;

src: No, not till Thursday; there is time enough.
trg: Go, nurse, go with her: we'll to church to-morrow.

src: Here are the keys, there sits the duke asleep: I'll to the king; and signify to him That thus I have resign'd my charge to you.
trg: Do so, it is a point of wisdom: fare you well.

src: A woeful pageant have we here beheld.
trg: The woe's to come; the children yet unborn. Shall feel this day as sharp to them as thorn.

src: In proof whereof, there is my honour's pawn; Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.
trg: How fondly dost thou spur a forward horse! If I dare eat, or drink, or breathe, or live, I dare meet Surrey in a wilderness, And spit upon him, whilst I say he lies, And lies, and lies:

src: While I remain above the ground, you shall Hear from me still, and never of me aught But what is like me formerly.
trg: That's worthily As any ear can hear. Come, let's not weep. If I could shake off but one seven years From these old arms and legs, by the good gods, I'ld with thee every foot.

src: The queen with all the northern earls and lords Intend here to besiege you in your castle: She is hard by with twenty thousand men; And therefore fortify your hold, my lord.
trg: Ay, with my sword. What! think'st thou that we fear them? Edward and Richard, you shall stay with me; My brother Montague shall post to London:

src: So it should seem by that I have to say. First, he commends him to your noble lordship.
trg: And then?

src: It is, and wants but nomination.
trg: To-morrow, then, I judge a happy day.

src: Then, on the other side, I cheque'd my friends. Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first, And then, in speaking, not to incur the last, Definitively thus I answer you.
trg: Your love deserves my thanks; but my desert Unmeritable shuns your high request. But, God be thank'd, there's no need of me, And much I need to help you, if need were;

src: I willingly obey your command.
trg: My best Camillo! We must disguise ourselves.

src: in that day's feats, When he might act the woman in the scene, He proved best man i' the field, and for his meed Was brow-bound with the oak.
trg: His pupil age Man-enter'd thus, he waxed like a sea, And in the brunt of seventeen battles since He lurch'd all swords of the garland.

src: buy food, and get thyself in flesh. Come, cordial and not poison, go with me To Juliet's grave; for there must I use thee.
trg: Holy Franciscan friar! brother, ho!

src: I have done so, but he's not to be found. I prithee, Lucio, do me this kind service: This day my sister should the cloister enter And there receive her approbation:
trg: Acquaint her with the danger of my state: Implore her, in my voice, that she make friends To the strict deputy; bid herself assay him: I have great hope in that;

src: Your husband, he is gone to save far off, Whilst others come to make him lose at home: Here am I left to underprop his land, Who, weak with age, cannot support myself:
trg: Now comes the sick hour that his surfeit made; Now shall he try his friends that flatter'd him.

src: That's my brave boy!
trg: Even he, your wife, this lady, and myself, Are suitors to you.

src: To save your life in this extremity, This favour will I do you for his sake; And think it not the worst of an your fortunes That you are like to Sir Vincentio.
trg: His name and credit shall you undertake, And in my house you shall be friendly lodged: Look that you take upon you as you should; You understand me, sir:

src: Now, good my lord, Let there be some more test made of my metal, Before so noble and so great a figure Be stamp'd upon it.
trg: No more evasion: We have with a leaven'd and prepared choice Proceeded to you; therefore take your honours.

src: You take my part from me, sir; I have the most cause to be glad of yours.
trg: Well, let us go together.

src: Ay, and their colours, often borne in France, And now in England to our heart's great sorrow, Shall be my winding-sheet. Why faint you, lords? My title's good, and better far than his.
trg: Prove it, Henry, and thou shalt be king.

src: And I, the hapless male to one sweet bird, Have now the fatal object in my eye Where my poor young was limed, was caught and kill'd.
trg: Why, what a peevish fool was that of Crete, That taught his son the office of a fowl! An yet, for all his wings, the fool was drown'd.

src: Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke After the prompter, for our entrance: But let them measure us by what they will; We'll measure them a measure, and be gone.
trg: Give me a torch: I am not for this ambling; Being but heavy, I will bear the light.

src: Why stay we now? These soldiers shall be levied, And thou, Lord Bourbon, our high admiral, Shalt waft them over with our royal fleet.
trg: I long till Edward fall by war's mischance, For mocking marriage with a dame of France.

src: they seemed almost, with staring on one another, to tear the cases of their eyes; there was speech in their dumbness, language in their very gesture;
trg: they looked as they had heard of a world ransomed, or one destroyed: a notable passion of wonder appeared in them;

src: And lo, where George of Clarence sweeps along, Of force enough to bid his brother battle; With whom an upright zeal to right prevails More than the nature of a brother's love! Come, Clarence, come;
trg: thou wilt, if Warwick call.

src: He does well in 't.
trg: A little more lenity to lechery would do no harm in him: something too crabbed that way, friar.

src: Each day still better other's happiness; Until the heavens, envying earth's good hap, Add an immortal title to your crown!
trg: We thank you both: yet one but flatters us, As well appeareth by the cause you come; Namely to appeal each other of high treason.

src: You are i' the right, sir: 'tis for my mistress.
trg: Go, take it up unto thy master's use.

src: O God, I have an ill-divining soul! Methinks I see thee, now thou art below, As one dead in the bottom of a tomb: Either my eyesight fails, or thou look'st pale.
trg: And trust me, love, in my eye so do you: Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Adieu, adieu!

src: Call't not a plot: The people cry you mock'd them, and of late, When corn was given them gratis, you repined;
trg: Scandal'd the suppliants for the people, call'd them Time-pleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.

src: How now, how now, chop-logic! What is this? 'Proud,' and 'I thank you,' and 'I thank you not; Out, you green-sickness carrion! out, you baggage! You tallow-face!
trg: Fie, fie! what, are you mad?

src: Be gone; Put not your worthy rage into your tongue; One time will owe another.
trg: On fair ground I could beat forty of them.

src: His neck will come to your waist,--a cord, sir.
trg: I spy comfort; I cry bail. Here's a gentleman and a friend of mine.

src: Forgot you! no, sir: I could not forget you, for I never saw you before in all my life.
trg: What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see thy master's father, Vincentio?

src: No, indeed, will I not, Pompey; it is not the wear. I will pray, Pompey, to increase your bondage: If you take it not patiently, why, your mettle is the more. Adieu, trusty Pompey. 'Bless you, friar.
trg: And you.

src: Ay, so I did indeed.
trg: Why, very well; I telling you then, if you be remembered, that such a one and such a one were past cure of the thing you wot of, unless they kept very good diet, as I told you,--

src: No, sir, God forbid; but ashamed to kiss.
trg: Why, then let's home again. Come, sirrah, let's away.

src: Sirrah, go you to Barthol'mew my page, And see him dress'd in all suits like a lady: That done, conduct him to the drunkard's chamber; And call him 'madam,' do him obeisance.
trg: Tell him from me, as he will win my love, He bear himself with honourable action, Such as he hath observed in noble ladies Unto their lords, by them accomplished:

src: And as for Clarence, as my letters tell me, He's very likely now to fall from him, For matching more for wanton lust than honour, Or than for strength and safety of our country.
trg: Dear brother, how shall Bona be revenged But by thy help to this distressed queen?

src: A great suspicion: stay the friar too.
trg: What misadventure is so early up, That calls our person from our morning's rest?

src: For ever may my knees grow to the earth, My tongue cleave to my roof within my mouth Unless a pardon ere I rise or speak.
trg: Intended or committed was this fault? If on the first, how heinous e'er it be, To win thy after-love I pardon thee.

src: O, good sir, tenderly, O!
trg: Alas, poor soul!

src: A boon, my sovereign, for my service done!
trg: I pray thee, peace: my soul is full of sorrow.

src: Saw you no more? mark'd you not how her sister Began to scold and raise up such a storm That mortal ears might hardly endure the din?
trg: Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move And with her breath she did perfume the air: Sacred and sweet was all I saw in her.

src: make the rope of his destiny our cable, for our own doth little advantage. If he be not born to be hanged, our case is miserable.
trg: Down with the topmast! yare! lower, lower! Bring her to try with main-course. A plague upon this howling! they are louder than the weather or our office. Yet again! what do you here?

src: He's not past it yet, and I say to thee, he would mouth with a beggar, though she smelt brown bread and garlic: say that I said so. Farewell.
trg: No might nor greatness in mortality Can censure 'scape; back-wounding calumny The whitest virtue strikes. What king so strong Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue? But who comes here?

src: so it should now, Were there necessity in your request, although 'Twere needful I denied it. My affairs Do even drag me homeward: which to hinder Were in your love a whip to me;
trg: my stay To you a charge and trouble: to save both, Farewell, our brother.

src: if you can bring Tincture or lustre in her lip, her eye, Heat outwardly or breath within, I'll serve you As I would do the gods. But, O thou tyrant!
trg: Do not repent these things, for they are heavier Than all thy woes can stir; therefore betake thee To nothing but despair.

src: Pray now, sit down.
trg: I had rather have one scratch my head i' the sun When the alarum were struck than idly sit To hear my nothings monster'd.

src: but this virtuous maid Subdues me quite. Even till now, When men were fond, I smiled and wonder'd how.
trg: Hail to you, provost! so I think you are.

src: If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him, And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.
trg: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory Can from his mother win the Duke of York, Anon expect him here;

src: Sir, that's to-morrow. I am question'd by my fears, of what may chance Or breed upon our absence; that may blow No sneaping winds at home, to make us say 'This is put forth too truly:
trg: ' besides, I have stay'd To tire your royalty.

src: marry her, And, with my best endeavours in your absence, Your discontenting father strive to qualify And bring him up to liking.
trg: How, Camillo, May this, almost a miracle, be done? That I may call thee something more than man And after that trust to thee.

src: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.
trg: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.

src: Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?
trg: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for: Take up my mistress' gown to his master's use! O, fie, fie, fie!

src: Anointed let me be with deadly venom, And die, ere men can say, God save the queen!
trg: Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory To feed my humour, wish thyself no harm.

src: My lord and husband!
trg: These eyes are not the same I wore in Rome.

src: How now! is he dead already? or is it fear That makes him close his eyes? I'll open them.
trg: So looks the pent-up lion o'er the wretch That trembles under his devouring paws; And so he walks, insulting o'er his prey, And so he comes, to rend his limbs asunder.

src: Now, brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest, Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends, And says that once more I shall interchange My waned state for Henry's regal crown.
trg: Well have we pass'd and now repass'd the seas And brought desired help from Burgundy:

src: O, I cry you mercy; you are the singer: I will say for you. It is 'music with her silver sound,' because musicians have no gold for sounding:
trg: 'Then music with her silver sound With speedy help doth lend redress.'

src: Sir, if you'ld save your life, fly to your house:
trg: The plebeians have got your fellow-tribune And hale him up and down, all swearing, if The Roman ladies bring not comfort home, They'll give him death by inches.

src: Bastards and all. Good man, the wounds that he does bear for Rome!
trg: Come, come, peace.

src: And so will I.
trg: Peace, children, peace! the king doth love you well: Incapable and shallow innocents, You cannot guess who caused your father's death.

src: Virtue is bold, and goodness never fearful. Have you not heard speak of Mariana, the sister of Frederick the great soldier who miscarried at sea?
trg: I have heard of the lady, and good words went with her name.

src: Thou churl, for this time, Though full of our displeasure, yet we free thee From the dead blow of it. And you, enchantment.-- Worthy enough a herdsman:
trg: Even here undone! I was not much afeard;

src: As thus, to drop them still upon one place, Till they have fretted us a pair of graves Within the earth; and, therein laid,--there lies Two kinsmen digg'd their graves with weeping eyes.
trg: Would not this ill do well? Well, well, I see I talk but idly, and you laugh at me. Most mighty prince, my Lord Northumberland, What says King Bolingbroke?

src: Pitchers have ears.
trg: Here comes a messenger. What news?

src: We are advertised by our loving friends That they do hold their course toward Tewksbury: We, having now the best at Barnet field, Will thither straight, for willingness rids way;
trg: And, as we march, our strength will be augmented In every county as we go along. Strike up the drum; cry 'Courage!' and away. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: There, Coriolanus.
trg: May I change these garments?

src: Would not this ill do well? Well, well, I see I talk but idly, and you laugh at me. Most mighty prince, my Lord Northumberland, What says King Bolingbroke?
trg: will his majesty Give Richard leave to live till Richard die? You make a leg, and Bolingbroke says ay.

src: Mowbray, impartial are our eyes and ears: He is our subject, Mowbray; so art thou: Free speech and fearless I to thee allow.
trg: Then, Bolingbroke, as low as to thy heart, Through the false passage of thy throat, thou liest. Three parts of that receipt I had for Calais Disbursed I duly to his highness' soldiers;

src: What devil art thou, that dost torment me thus? This torture should be roar'd in dismal hell. Hath Romeo slain himself?
trg: say thou but 'I,' And that bare vowel 'I' shall poison more Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice: I am not I, if there be such an I; Or those eyes shut, that make thee answer 'I.

src: I'll go along with you.
trg: You have no cause.

src: Edward, what satisfaction canst thou make For bearing arms, for stirring up my subjects, And all the trouble thou hast turn'd me to?
trg: Speak like a subject, proud ambitious York! Suppose that I am now my father's mouth;

src: 'Tis far off And rather like a dream than an assurance That my remembrance warrants. Had I not Four or five women once that tended me?
trg: Thou hadst, and more, Miranda. But how is it That this lives in thy mind? What seest thou else In the dark backward and abysm of time?

src: Lords, you that here are under our arrest, Procure your sureties for your days of answer. Little are we beholding to your love, And little look'd for at your helping hands.
trg: Alack, why am I sent for to a king, Before I have shook off the regal thoughts Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet have learn'd To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs:

src: Comfort, my lord; and so I take my leave.
trg: And thus I seal my truth, and bid adieu.

src: Not so: I am as ignorant in that as you In so entitling me, and no less honest Than you are mad; which is enough, I'll warrant, As this world goes, to pass for honest.
trg: Traitors! Will you not push her out? Give her the bastard. Thou dotard! thou art woman-tired, unroosted By thy dame Partlet here. Take up the bastard; Take't up, I say; give't to thy crone.

src: Romeo, come forth; come forth, thou fearful man: Affliction is enamour'd of thy parts, And thou art wedded to calamity.
trg: Father, what news? what is the prince's doom? What sorrow craves acquaintance at my hand, That I yet know not?

src: multitudes, and fear?
trg: So cowards fight when they can fly no further; So doves do peck the falcon's piercing talons; So desperate thieves, all hopeless of their lives, Breathe out invectives 'gainst the officers.

src: The visitor will not give him o'er so.
trg: Look he's winding up the watch of his wit; by and by it will strike.

src: I mean, sir, in delay We waste our lights in vain, like lamps by day. Take our good meaning, for our judgment sits Five times in that ere once in our five wits.
trg: And we mean well in going to this mask; But 'tis no wit to go.

src: Romeo can, Though heaven cannot: O Romeo, Romeo! Who ever would have thought it? Romeo!
trg: What devil art thou, that dost torment me thus? This torture should be roar'd in dismal hell. Hath Romeo slain himself?

src: I know not where to turn: O, welcome home: And welcome, general: and ye're welcome all.
trg: A hundred thousand welcomes. I could weep And I could laugh, I am light and heavy. Welcome. A curse begin at very root on's heart, That is not glad to see thee! You are three That Rome should dote on:

src: Yet, to have join'd with France in such alliance Would more have strengthen'd this our commonwealth 'Gainst foreign storms than any home-bred marriage.
trg: Why, knows not Montague that of itself England is safe, if true within itself?

src: Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile, Intolerable, not to be endured! Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress; Say, I command her to come to me.
trg: I know her answer.

src: No, no, no, no, no.
trg: If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people, I may be heard, I would crave a word or two; The which shall turn you to no further harm Than so much loss of time.

src: My lords of England, let me tell you this: I have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs And laboured all I could to do him right;
trg: But in this kind to come, in braving arms, Be his own carver and cut out his way, To find out right with wrong, it may not be;

src: Richard!
trg: Ha!

src: Think I am dead and that even here thou takest, As from my death-bed, thy last living leave.
trg: In winter's tedious nights sit by the fire With good old folks and let them tell thee tales Of woeful ages long ago betid;

src: I Am heir to my affection.
trg: Be advised.

src: I request you To give my poor host freedom.
trg: O, well begg'd! Were he the butcher of my son, he should Be free as is the wind. Deliver him, Titus.

src: O that ever I was born!
trg: I' the name of me--

src: Well, jest on, brothers: I can tell you both Her suit is granted for her husband's lands.
trg: My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken, And brought your prisoner to your palace gate.

src: Pardon me, good father; it is against my oath.
trg: Were you sworn to the duke, or to the deputy?

src: This comes off well; here's a wise officer.
trg: Go to: what quality are they of? Elbow is your name? why dost thou not speak, Elbow?

src: Come on, lay it by: and let's first see moe ballads; we'll buy the other things anon.
trg: Here's another ballad of a fish, that appeared upon the coast on Wednesday the four-score of April, forty thousand fathom above water, and sung this ballad against the hard hearts of maids:
The broken rancour of your high-swoln hearts, But lately splinter'd, knit, and join'd together, Must gently be preserved, cherish'd, and kept:

src: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds? Turn thee, Benvolio, look upon thy death.
trg: I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword, Or manage it to part these men with me.

src: Let noble Warwick, Cobham, and the rest, Whom we have left protectors of the king, With powerful policy strengthen themselves, And trust not simple Henry nor his oaths.
trg: Brother, I go; I'll win them, fear it not: And thus most humbly I do take my leave. Sir John and Sir Hugh Mortimer, mine uncles, You are come to Sandal in a happy hour;

src: thou hast beat me out Twelve several times, and I have nightly since Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me;
trg: We have been down together in my sleep, Unbuckling helms, fisting each other's throat, And waked half dead with nothing. O, come, go in, And take our friendly senators by the hands;

src: Our spoils we have brought home Do more than counterpoise a full third part The charges of the action. We have made peace With no less honour to the Antiates Than shame to the Romans:
trg: and we here deliver, Subscribed by the consuls and patricians, Together with the seal o' the senate, what We have compounded on.

src: Too late? why, no; I, that do speak a word. May call it back again. If he had been as you and you as he, You would have slipt like him; but he, like you, Would not have been so stern.
trg: Pray you, be gone.

src: I never heard the absent duke much detected for women; he was not inclined that way.
trg: O, sir, you are deceived.

src: I must confess your offer is the best; And, let your father make her the assurance, She is your own; else, you must pardon me, if you should die before him, where's her dower?
trg: That's but a cavil: he is old, I young.

src: I swear I'll cuff you, if you strike again.
trg: So may you lose your arms: If you strike me, you are no gentleman; And if no gentleman, why then no arms.

src: What will you give us?
trg: No money, on my faith, but the gleek; I will give you the minstrel.

src: Good king of cats, nothing but one of your nine lives; that I mean to make bold withal, and as you shall use me hereafter, drybeat the rest of the eight.
trg: Will you pluck your sword out of his pitcher by the ears? make haste, lest mine be about your ears ere it be out.

src: What, marry, may she! marry with a king, A bachelor, a handsome stripling too: I wis your grandam had a worser match.
trg: My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs: By heaven, I will acquaint his majesty With those gross taunts I often have endured.

src: A very superficial, ignorant, unweighing fellow.
trg: Either this is the envy in you, folly, or mistaking: the very stream of his life and the business he hath helmed must upon a warranted need give him a better proclamation.

src: Base men by his endowments are made great.
trg: My lords of England, let me tell you this: I have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs And laboured all I could to do him right;

src: Nay, let us share thy thoughts, as thou dost ours.
trg: Be confident to speak, Northumberland: We three are but thyself; and, speaking so, Thy words are but as thoughts; therefore, be bold.

src: It cannot be.
trg: Let me entreat you.

src: Hope I may choose, sir.
trg: Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?

src: If thou neglect'st or dost unwillingly What I command, I'll rack thee with old cramps, Fill all thy bones with aches, make thee roar That beasts shall tremble at thy din.
trg: No, pray thee. I must obey: his art is of such power, It would control my dam's god, Setebos, and make a vassal of him.

src: Ay, no; no, ay; for I must nothing be; Therefore no no, for I resign to thee. Now mark me, how I will undo myself;
trg: I give this heavy weight from off my head And this unwieldy sceptre from my hand, The pride of kingly sway from out my heart;

src: Some say he is with the Emperor of Russia; other some, he is in Rome: but where is he, think you?
trg: I know not where; but wheresoever, I wish him well.

src: Was he met there? his train? Camillo with him?
trg: Behind the tuft of pines I met them; never Saw I men scour so on their way: I eyed them Even to their ships.

src: And I, to keep all this.
trg: Norfolk, so far as to mine enemy:-- By this time, had the king permitted us, One of our souls had wander'd in the air.

src: It is a bitter deputy.
trg: Not so, not so; his life is parallel'd Even with the stroke and line of his great justice: He doth with holy abstinence subdue That in himself which he spurs on his power To qualify in others:

src: What proclamation, man?
trg: All houses in the suburbs of Vienna must be plucked down.

src: and furred with fox and lamb-skins too, to signify, that craft, being richer than innocency, stands for the facing.
trg: Come your way, sir. 'Bless you, good father friar.

src: Saddle white Surrey for the field to-morrow. Look that my staves be sound, and not too heavy. Ratcliff!
trg: My lord?

src: Awaked you not with this sore agony?
trg: O, no, my dream was lengthen'd after life;

src: My hair doth stand on end to hear her curses.
trg: And so doth mine: I muse why she's at liberty.

src: Lo, citizens, he says he is content: The warlike service he has done, consider; think Upon the wounds his body bears, which show Like graves i' the holy churchyard.
trg: Scratches with briers, Scars to move laughter only.

src: My lord, most villanously; believe it.
trg: Well, he in time may come to clear himself; But at this instant he is sick my lord, Of a strange fever.

src: Environed he was with many foes, And stood against them, as the hope of Troy Against the Greeks that would have enter'd Troy. But Hercules himself must yield to odds;
trg: And many strokes, though with a little axe, Hew down and fell the hardest-timber'd oak. By many hands your father was subdued;

src: I neither know it nor can learn of him.
trg: Have you importuned him by any means?

src: Ay, ay. thou wouldst be gone to join with Richmond: I will not trust you, sir.
trg: Most mighty sovereign, You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful: I never was nor never will be false.

src: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower, And was embark'd to cross to Burgundy; And, in my company, my brother Gloucester; Who from my cabin tempted me to walk Upon the hatches:
trg: thence we looked toward England, And cited up a thousand fearful times, During the wars of York and Lancaster That had befall'n us.

src: This afternoon, sir? well, she shall be there.
trg: And stay, good nurse, behind the abbey wall: Within this hour my man shall be with thee And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair;

src: I am your sorrow's nurse, And I will pamper it with lamentations.
trg: Comfort, dear mother: God is much displeased That you take with unthankfulness, his doing:

src: I think 'twas Soto that your honour means.
trg: 'Tis very true: thou didst it excellent. Well, you are come to me in a happy time; The rather for I have some sport in hand Wherein your cunning can assist me much.

src: But I'll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery: Marry, go before to field, he'll be your follower; Your worship in that sense may call him 'man.'
trg: Romeo, the hate I bear thee can afford No better term than this,--thou art a villain.

src: Now, go thy ways; thou hast tamed a curst shrew.
trg: 'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.

src: Ay, with my sword. What! think'st thou that we fear them? Edward and Richard, you shall stay with me; My brother Montague shall post to London:
trg: Let noble Warwick, Cobham, and the rest, Whom we have left protectors of the king, With powerful policy strengthen themselves, And trust not simple Henry nor his oaths.

src: I, even I: what think you of it, madam?
trg: How canst thou woo her?

src: I thank his grace, I know he loves me well; But, for his purpose in the coronation. I have not sounded him, nor he deliver'd His gracious pleasure any way therein:
trg: But you, my noble lords, may name the time; And in the duke's behalf I'll give my voice, Which, I presume, he'll take in gentle part.

src: My gracious lord, I tender you my service, Such as it is, being tender, raw and young: Which elder days shall ripen and confirm To more approved service and desert.
trg: I thank thee, gentle Percy; and be sure I count myself in nothing else so happy As in a soul remembering my good friends;

src: Well, then, imprison him: if imprisonment be the due of a bawd, why, 'tis his right: bawd is he doubtless, and of antiquity too; bawd-born. Farewell, good Pompey. Commend me to the prison, Pompey:
trg: you will turn good husband now, Pompey; you will keep the house.

src: Yes, faith, sir.
trg: Why, 'tis not amiss, Pompey. Farewell: go, say I sent thee thither. For debt, Pompey? or how?

src: Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably: come, you must go visit the good lady that lies in.
trg: I will wish her speedy strength, and visit her with my prayers; but I cannot go thither.

src: O sweet Juliet, Thy beauty hath made me effeminate And in my temper soften'd valour's steel!
trg: O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio's dead! That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds, Which too untimely here did scorn the earth.

src: ' Amongst much other talk, that very time, I heard you say that you had rather refuse The offer of an hundred thousand crowns Than Bolingbroke's return to England;
trg: Adding withal how blest this land would be In this your cousin's death.

src: Now, had I not the dash of my former life in me, would preferment drop on my head. I brought the old man and his son aboard the prince: told him I heard them talk of a fardel and I know not what:
trg: But 'tis all one to me; for had I been the finder out of this secret, it would not have relished among my other discredits.

src: even this, So criminal and in such capital kind, Deserves the extremest death.
trg: But since he hath Served well for Rome,--

src: As I remember, Henry the Sixth Did prophesy that Richmond should be king, When Richmond was a little peevish boy. A king, perhaps, perhaps,--
trg: My lord!

src: O, true-bred!
trg: Your company to the Capitol; where, I know, Our greatest friends attend us.

src: O Hermione, As every present time doth boast itself Above a better gone, so must thy grave Give way to what's seen now!
trg: Sir, you yourself Have said and writ so, but your writing now Is colder than that theme, 'She had not been, Nor was not to be equall'd;'--thus your verse Flow'd with her beauty once:

src: Not in this heat, sir, now.
trg: Now, as I live, I will. My nobler friends, I crave their pardons: For the mutable, rank-scented many, let them Regard me as I do not flatter, and Therein behold themselves:

src: Who knows not he is dead! who knows he is?
trg: All seeing heaven, what a world is this!

src: How ill-beseeming is it in thy sex To triumph, like an Amazonian trull, Upon their woes whom fortune captivates!
trg: But that thy face is, vizard-like, unchanging, Made impudent with use of evil deeds, I would assay, proud queen, to make thee blush.

src: Are you a courtier, an't like you, sir?
trg: Whether it like me or no, I am a courtier. Seest thou not the air of the court in these enfoldings? hath not my gait in it the measure of the court? receives not thy nose court-odor from me?

src: Go thou, and like an executioner, Cut off the heads of too fast growing sprays, That look too lofty in our commonwealth: All must be even in our government.
trg: You thus employ'd, I will go root away The noisome weeds, which without profit suck The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers.

src: Are these your herd? Must these have voices, that can yield them now And straight disclaim their tongues? What are your offices? You being their mouths, why rule you not their teeth?
trg: Have you not set them on?

src: You shall not choose but drink before you go: I think I shall command your welcome here, And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward.
trg: They're busy within; you were best knock louder.

src: Yes, that thou hast, whether thou art tainted or free.
trg: Behold, behold. where Madam Mitigation comes! I have purchased as many diseases under her roof as come to--

src: and all this is long of you.
trg: The gods be good unto us!

src: Ay, wherefore else guard we his royal tent, But to defend his person from night-foes?
trg: This is his tent; and see where stand his guard. Courage, my masters! honour now or never! But follow me, and Edward shall be ours.

src: Come, enough.
trg: Enough, with over-measure.

src: Mean time let this defend my loyalty, By all my hopes, most falsely doth he lie.
trg: Pale trembling coward, there I throw my gage, Disclaiming here the kindred of the king, And lay aside my high blood's royalty, Which fear, not reverence, makes thee to except.

src: Revenged may she be on that hateful duke, Whose haughty spirit, winged with desire, Will cost my crown, and like an empty eagle Tire on the flesh of me and of my son!
trg: The loss of those three lords torments my heart: I'll write unto them and entreat them fair. Come, cousin you shall be the messenger.

src: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.
trg: As if it had lungs and rotten ones.

src: Out, devil! I remember them too well: Thou slewest my husband Henry in the Tower, And Edward, my poor son, at Tewksbury.
trg: Ere you were queen, yea, or your husband king, I was a pack-horse in his great affairs; A weeder-out of his proud adversaries, A liberal rewarder of his friends:

src: For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork Of a poor worm. Thy best of rest is sleep, And that thou oft provokest; yet grossly fear'st Thy death, which is no more. Thou art not thyself;
trg: For thou exist'st on many a thousand grains That issue out of dust. Happy thou art not; For what thou hast not, still thou strivest to get, And what thou hast, forget'st. Thou art not certain;

src: The queen this day here holds her parliament, But little thinks we shall be of her council: By words or blows here let us win our right.
trg: Arm'd as we are, let's stay within this house.

src: 'Tis right.
trg: It was his word: O, he would miss it rather Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him, And the desire of the nobles.

src: Look you, sir; here comes your ghostly father: do we jest now, think you?
trg: Sir, induced by my charity, and hearing how hastily you are to depart, I am come to advise you, comfort you and pray with you.

src: This last old man, Whom with a crack'd heart I have sent to Rome, Loved me above the measure of a father; Nay, godded me, indeed. Their latest refuge Was to send him;
trg: for whose old love I have, Though I show'd sourly to him, once more offer'd The first conditions, which they did refuse And cannot now accept;

src: I do perceive These poor informal women are no more But instruments of some more mightier member That sets them on: let me have way, my lord, To find this practise out.
trg: Ay, with my heart And punish them to your height of pleasure. You, Lord Escalus, Sit with my cousin; lend him your kind pains To find out this abuse, whence 'tis derived.

src: I prithee, grieve, to make me merry, York. What, hath thy fiery heart so parch'd thine entrails That not a tear can fall for Rutland's death? Why art thou patient, man? thou shouldst be mad;
trg: And I, to make thee mad, do mock thee thus. Stamp, rave, and fret, that I may sing and dance. Thou wouldst be fee'd, I see, to make me sport: York cannot speak, unless he wear a crown.

src: Ay, and a subtle; as he most learnedly delivered.
trg: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.

src: He hath some meaning in his mad attire: We will persuade him, be it possible, To put on better ere he go to church.
trg: I'll after him, and see the event of this.

src: This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child And here was left by the sailors. Thou, my slave, As thou report'st thyself, wast then her servant;
trg: within which rift Imprison'd thou didst painfully remain A dozen years; within which space she died And left thee there; where thou didst vent thy groans As fast as mill-wheels strike.

src: If you be hired for meed, go back again, And I will send you to my brother Gloucester, Who shall reward you better for my life Than Edward will for tidings of my death.
trg: You are deceived, your brother Gloucester hates you.

src: As any in Vienna, on my word.
trg: Call that same Isabel here once again; I would speak with her. Pray you, my lord, give me leave to question; you shall see how I'll handle her.

src: Ay, and mine, That brought you forth this boy, to keep your name Living to time.
trg: A' shall not tread on me; I'll run away till I am bigger, but then I'll fight.

src: For your physicians have expressly charged, In peril to incur your former malady, That I should yet absent me from your bed: I hope this reason stands for my excuse.
trg: Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long. But I would be loath to fall into my dreams again: I will therefore tarry in despite of the flesh and the blood.

src: And so did I.
trg: And so did I; and, to say the truth, so did very many of us: that we did, we did for the best; and though we willingly consented to his banishment, yet it was against our will.

src: We should by this, to all our lamentation, If he had gone forth consul, found it so.
trg: The gods have well prevented it, and Rome Sits safe and still without him.

src: My dagger, little cousin? with all my heart.
trg: A beggar, brother?

src: The guilt of conscience take thou for thy labour, But neither my good word nor princely favour: With Cain go wander through shades of night, And never show thy head by day nor light.
trg: Lords, I protest, my soul is full of woe, That blood should sprinkle me to make me grow: Come, mourn with me for that I do lament, And put on sullen black incontinent:

src: Though he be merry, yet withal he's honest.
trg: Would Katharina had never seen him though!

src: Is this your speeding? nay, then, good night our part!
trg: Be patient, gentlemen; I choose her for myself: If she and I be pleased, what's that to you? 'Tis bargain'd 'twixt us twain, being alone, That she shall still be curst in company.

src: Had thy brethren here, their lives and thine Were not revenge sufficient for me;
trg: No, if I digg'd up thy forefathers' graves And hung their rotten coffins up in chains, It could not slake mine ire, nor ease my heart.

src: Clifford, devise excuses for thy faults.
trg: While we devise fell tortures for thy faults.

src: Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchant's part, And venture madly on a desperate mart.
trg: 'Twas a commodity lay fretting by you: 'Twill bring you gain, or perish on the seas.

src: And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness, I will with you, if you be so contented, Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.
trg: See, how they kiss and court!

src: Yet ask.
trg: And shall I have?

src: your lord and Titus Lartius are set down before their city Corioli; they nothing doubt prevailing and to make it brief wars. This is true, on mine honour; and so, I pray, go with us.
trg: Give me excuse, good madam; I will obey you in every thing hereafter.

src: Heard ye not what an humble suppliant Lord hastings was to her for his delivery?
trg: Humbly complaining to her deity Got my lord chamberlain his liberty. I'll tell you what; I think it is our way, If we will keep in favour with the king, To be her men and wear her livery:

src: Resolve thee, Richard; claim the English crown.
trg: My lords, look where the sturdy rebel sits, Even in the chair of state: belike he means, Back'd by the power of Warwick, that false peer, To aspire unto the crown and reign as king.

src: He ran this way, and leap'd this orchard wall: Call, good Mercutio.
trg: Nay, I'll conjure too. Romeo! humours! madman! passion! lover! Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh: Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied; Cry but 'Ay me!' pronounce but 'love' and 'dove;

src: Any thing, my lord, That my ability may undergo And nobleness impose: at least thus much: I'll pawn the little blood which I have left To save the innocent: any thing possible.
trg: It shall be possible. Swear by this sword Thou wilt perform my bidding.

src: Romeo!
trg: My dear?

src: Ay, boy.
trg: I cannot think it. Hark! what noise is this?

src: Why, very well, then,--
trg: Come, you are a tedious fool: to the purpose. What was done to Elbow's wife, that he hath cause to complain of? Come me to what was done to her.

src: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair, To merit bliss by making me despair: She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow Do I live dead that live to tell it now.
trg: Be ruled by me, forget to think of her.

src: Either thou wilt die, by God's just ordinance, Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror, Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish And never look upon thy face again.
trg: Therefore take with thee my most heavy curse; Which, in the day of battle, tire thee more Than all the complete armour that thou wear'st! My prayers on the adverse party fight;
A messenger from the Lord Stanley.

src: Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby, His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries To-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle;
trg: And bid my friend, for joy of this good news, Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.

src: Press me not, beseech you, so. There is no tongue that moves, none, none i' the world, So soon as yours could win me:
trg: so it should now, Were there necessity in your request, although 'Twere needful I denied it. My affairs Do even drag me homeward: which to hinder Were in your love a whip to me;

src: Then, grandam, you conclude that he is dead. The king my uncle is to blame for this: God will revenge it; whom I will importune With daily prayers all to that effect.
trg: And so will I.

src: and with sighs they jar Their watches on unto mine eyes, the outward watch, Whereto my finger, like a dial's point, Is pointing still, in cleansing them from tears.
trg: Now sir, the sound that tells what hour it is Are clamorous groans, which strike upon my heart, Which is the bell: so sighs and tears and groans Show minutes, times, and hours:

src: Methinks King Richard and myself should meet With no less terror than the elements Of fire and water, when their thundering shock At meeting tears the cloudy cheeks of heaven.
trg: Be he the fire, I'll be the yielding water: The rage be his, whilst on the earth I rain My waters; on the earth, and not on him. March on, and mark King Richard how he looks.

src: We are not furnish'd like Bohemia's son, Nor shall appear in Sicilia.
trg: My lord, Fear none of this: I think you know my fortunes Do all lie there: it shall be so my care To have you royally appointed as if The scene you play were mine.

src: and let them fight that will, For I have murdered where I should not kill.
trg: Sad-hearted men, much overgone with care, Here sits a king more woful than you are.

src: My lord?
trg: When I was last in Holborn, I saw good strawberries in your garden there I do beseech you send for some of them.

src: There spake my brother; there my father's grave Did utter forth a voice. Yes, thou must die: Thou art too noble to conserve a life In base appliances.
trg: The prenzie Angelo!

src: Fitzwater, thou art damn'd to hell for this.
trg: Aumerle, thou liest; his honour is as true In this appeal as thou art all unjust; And that thou art so, there I throw my gage, To prove it on thee to the extremest point Of mortal breathing:

src: The castle royally is mann'd, my lord, Against thy entrance.
trg: Royally! Why, it contains no king?

src: Two props of virtue for a Christian prince, To stay him from the fall of vanity: And, see, a book of prayer in his hand, True ornaments to know a holy man.
trg: Famous Plantagenet, most gracious prince, Lend favourable ears to our request; And pardon us the interruption Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.

src: Let's be calm.
trg: The people are abused; set on. This paltering Becomes not Rome, nor has Coriolanus Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely I' the plain way of his merit.

src: We cannot be here and there too. Cheerly, boys; be brisk awhile, and the longer liver take all.
trg: Welcome, gentlemen! ladies that have their toes Unplagued with corns will have a bout with you. Ah ha, my mistresses! which of you all Will now deny to dance?

src: Away, away! for he is coming hither.
trg: Thus have I politicly begun my reign, And 'tis my hope to end successfully. My falcon now is sharp and passing empty;

src: My heart is great; but it must break with silence, Ere't be disburden'd with a liberal tongue.
trg: Nay, speak thy mind; and let him ne'er speak more That speaks thy words again to do thee harm!

src: where I find him, were it At home, upon my brother's guard, even there, Against the hospitable canon, would I Wash my fierce hand in's heart. Go you to the city; Learn how 'tis held;
trg: and what they are that must Be hostages for Rome.

src: With old Menenius, and those senators That always favour'd him.
trg: Have you a catalogue Of all the voices that we have procured Set down by the poll?

src: But smother'd it within my panting bulk, Which almost burst to belch it in the sea.
trg: Awaked you not with this sore agony?

src: for where I thought to crush him in an equal force, True sword to sword, I'll potch at him some way Or wrath or craft may get him.
trg: He's the devil.

src: Indeed, brother-in-law was the farthest off you could have been to him and then your blood had been the dearer by I know how much an ounce.
Tutus Aufidius, is he within your walls?
trg: No, nor a man that fears you less than he, That's lesser than a little. Hark! our drums Are bringing forth our youth. We'll break our walls, Rather than they shall pound us up:

src: Vincetino's son brought up in Florence It shall become to serve all hopes conceived, To deck his fortune with his virtuous deeds:
trg: And therefore, Tranio, for the time I study, Virtue and that part of philosophy Will I apply that treats of happiness By virtue specially to be achieved. Tell me thy mind;

src: How now! canst stand?
But, master mayor, if Henry be your king, Yet Edward at the least is Duke of York.
trg: True, my good lord; I know you for no less.

src: The sun that sear'd the wings of my sweet boy Thy brother Edward, and thyself the sea Whose envious gulf did swallow up his life. Ah, kill me with thy weapon, not with words!
trg: My breast can better brook thy dagger's point Than can my ears that tragic history. But wherefore dost thou come? is't for my life?

src: Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee! What should the people do with these bald tribunes? On whom depending, their obedience fails To the greater bench:
trg: in a rebellion, When what's not meet, but what must be, was law, Then were they chosen: in a better hour, Let what is meet be said it must be meet, And throw their power i' the dust.

src: Now this extremity Hath brought me to thy hearth;
trg: so use it That my revengeful services may prove As benefits to thee, for I will fight Against my canker'd country with the spleen Of all the under fiends.

src: Sir, she came in great with child; and longing, saving your honour's reverence, for stewed prunes;
trg: sir, we had but two in the house, which at that very distant time stood, as it were, in a fruit-dish, a dish of some three-pence; your honours have seen such dishes;

src: No, none, but only a repair i' the dark; And that I have possess'd him my most stay Can be but brief;
trg: for I have made him know I have a servant comes with me along, That stays upon me, whose persuasion is I come about my brother.

src: She should this Angelo have married; was affianced to her by oath, and the nuptial appointed:
trg: between which time of the contract and limit of the solemnity, her brother Frederick was wrecked at sea, having in that perished vessel the dowry of his sister.

src: The sorrow that delivers us thus changed Makes you think so.
trg: Like a dull actor now, I have forgot my part, and I am out, Even to a full disgrace. Best of my flesh, Forgive my tyranny; but do not say For that 'Forgive our Romans.

src: Therefore lay hold of him; Bear him to the rock Tarpeian, and from thence Into destruction cast him.
trg: AEdiles, seize him!

src: ghastly looks Are at my service, like enforced smiles; And both are ready in their offices, At any time, to grace my stratagems. But what, is Catesby gone?
trg: He is; and, see, he brings the mayor along.

src: What means this scene of rude impatience?
trg: To make an act of tragic violence: Edward, my lord, your son, our king, is dead. Why grow the branches now the root is wither'd? Why wither not the leaves the sap being gone? If you will live, lament;

src: That is, because the traitor murderer lives.
trg: Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands: Would none but I might venge my cousin's death!

src: What fellow's this?
trg: A strange one as ever I looked on: I cannot get him out of the house: prithee, call my master to him.

src: Let me but stand; I will not hurt your hearth.
trg: What are you?

src: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.
trg: Good sooth, even thus; therefore ha' done with words: To me she's married, not unto my clothes:

src: But what's his offence?
trg: Groping for trouts in a peculiar river.

src: Go to, we pardon thee: therefore, in brief, Tell me their words as near as thou canst guess them. What answer makes King Lewis unto our letters?
trg: At my depart, these were his very words: 'Go tell false Edward, thy supposed king, That Lewis of France is sending over masquers To revel it with him and his new bride.'

src: Be collected: No more amazement: tell your piteous heart There's no harm done.
trg: O, woe the day!

src: This wind, you talk of, blows us from ourselves; Supper is done, and we shall come too late.
trg: I fear, too early: But He, that hath the steerage of my course, Direct my sail! On, lusty gentlemen.

src: No less! nay, bigger; women grow by men.
trg: Speak briefly, can you like of Paris' love?

src: He has our voices, sir.
trg: We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.

src: This, my lord.
trg: There was a friar told me of this man. Sirrah, thou art said to have a stubborn soul. That apprehends no further than this world, And squarest thy life according. Thou'rt condemn'd:

src: Peace, sirrah!
trg: Grumio, mum! God save you, Signior Gremio.

src: Great Lord of Warwick, if we should recount Our baleful news, and at each word's deliverance Stab poniards in our flesh till all were told, The words would add more anguish than the wounds.
trg: O valiant lord, the Duke of York is slain!

src: What say you? can you love the gentleman? This night you shall behold him at our feast; Read o'er the volume of young Paris' face, And find delight writ there with beauty's pen;
trg: Examine every married lineament, And see how one another lends content And what obscured in this fair volume lies Find written in the margent of his eyes.

src: Our fatherless distress was left unmoan'd; Your widow-dolour likewise be unwept!
trg: Give me no help in lamentation;

src: when he's return'd, Against Aumerle we will enforce his trial.
trg: That honourable day shall ne'er be seen.

src: For she's a woman to be pitied much: Her sighs will make a battery in his breast; Her tears will pierce into a marble heart; The tiger will be mild whiles she doth mourn;
trg: And Nero will be tainted with remorse, To hear and see her plaints, her brinish tears. Ay, but she's come to beg, Warwick to give;

src: for this drivelling love is like a great natural, that runs lolling up and down to hide his bauble in a hole.
trg: Stop there, stop there.

src: The trumpets, sackbuts, psalteries and fifes, Tabours and cymbals and the shouting Romans, Make the sun dance. Hark you!
trg: This is good news: I will go meet the ladies. This Volumnia Is worth of consuls, senators, patricians, A city full; of tribunes, such as you, A sea and land full. You have pray'd well to-day:
