src: How far into the morning is it, lords?
trg: Upon the stroke of four.

src: What! lack I credit?
trg: I had rather you did lack than I, my lord, Upon this ground; and more it would content me To have her honour true than your suspicion, Be blamed for't how you might.

src: If it? please your honour, I know not well what they are: but precise villains they are, that I am sure of; and void of all profanation in the world that good Christians ought to have.
trg: This comes off well; here's a wise officer.

src: Lord Warwick, on thy shoulder will I lean; And when thou fail'st--as God forbid the hour!-- Must Edward fall, which peril heaven forfend!
trg: No longer Earl of March, but Duke of York: The next degree is England's royal throne; For King of England shalt thou be proclaim'd In every borough as we pass along;

src: I pray God he be not, I say.
trg: I pray you all, tell me what they deserve That do conspire my death with devilish plots Of damned witchcraft, and that have prevail'd Upon my body with their hellish charms?

src: For thee, fond boy, If I may ever know thou dost but sigh That thou no more shalt see this knack, as never I mean thou shalt, we'll bar thee from succession;
trg: Not hold thee of our blood, no, not our kin, Far than Deucalion off: mark thou my words: Follow us to the court.

src: it is my father's face, Whom in this conflict I unwares have kill'd. O heavy times, begetting such events! From London by the king was I press'd forth;
trg: My father, being the Earl of Warwick's man, Came on the part of York, press'd by his master; And I, who at his hands received my life, him Have by my hands of life bereaved him.

src: I am none of his skains-mates. And thou must stand by too, and suffer every knave to use me at his pleasure?
trg: I saw no man use you a pleasure; if I had, my weapon should quickly have been out, I warrant you: I dare draw as soon as another man, if I see occasion in a good quarrel, and the law on my side.

src: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone; We have a trifling foolish banquet towards. Is it e'en so? why, then, I thank you all I thank you, honest gentlemen; good night. More torches here!
trg: Come on then, let's to bed. Ah, sirrah, by my fay, it waxes late: I'll to my rest.

src: Aufidius, and you Volsces, mark; for we'll Hear nought from Rome in private. Your request?
trg: Should we be silent and not speak, our raiment And state of bodies would bewray what life We have led since thy exile. Think with thyself How more unfortunate than all living women Are we come hither:

src: 'Save your honour!
trg: From thee, even from thy virtue! What's this, what's this? Is this her fault or mine? The tempter or the tempted, who sins most? Ha! Not she: nor doth she tempt:

src: I thought you had been willing to resign.
trg: My crown I am; but still my griefs are mine: You may my glories and my state depose, But not my griefs; still am I king of those.

src: for your voices have Done many things, some less, some more your voices: Indeed I would be consul.
trg: He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest man's voice.

src: A book of prayers on their pillow lay; Which once,' quoth Forrest, 'almost changed my mind; But O! the devil'--there the villain stopp'd Whilst Dighton thus told on:
trg: 'We smothered The most replenished sweet work of nature, That from the prime creation e'er she framed.' Thus both are gone with conscience and remorse; They could not speak;

src: Bring me my boots: I will unto the king.
trg: Strike him, Aumerle. Poor boy, thou art amazed. Hence, villain! never more come in my sight.

src: Do not stand upon't. We recommend to you, tribunes of the people, Our purpose to them: and to our noble consul Wish we all joy and honour.
trg: To Coriolanus come all joy and honour!

src: In very good time: speak not you to him till we call upon you.
trg: Mum.

src: I am as well acquainted here as I was in our house of profession: one would think it were Mistress Overdone's own house, for here be many of her old customers. First, here's young Master Rash;
trg: he's in for a commodity of brown paper and old ginger, ninescore and seventeen pounds; of which he made five marks, ready money:

src: Princes and noble lords, What answer shall I make to this base man? Shall I so much dishonour my fair stars, On equal terms to give him chastisement?
trg: Either I must, or have mine honour soil'd With the attainder of his slanderous lips. There is my gage, the manual seal of death, That marks thee out for hell:

src: By what? by any other house or person? Of any thing the image tell me that Hath kept with thy remembrance.
trg: 'Tis far off And rather like a dream than an assurance That my remembrance warrants. Had I not Four or five women once that tended me?

src: Then, no, my lord. My suit is at an end.

trg: What shrill-voiced suppliant makes this eager cry?

src: Brave followers, yonder stands the thorny wood, Which, by the heavens' assistance and your strength, Must by the roots be hewn up yet ere night.
trg: I need not add more fuel to your fire, For well I wot ye blaze to burn them out Give signal to the fight, and to it, lords!

src: No.
trg: They will, then, ere't be long.

src: And thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humour. He that knows better how to tame a shrew, Now let him speak: 'tis charity to show.
trg: Is't possible, friend Licio, that Mistress Bianca Doth fancy any other but Lucentio? I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.

src: I know them both.
trg: The contents of this is the return of the duke: you shall anon over-read it at your pleasure; where you shall find, within these two days he will be here. This is a thing that Angelo knows not;

src: Great Apollo Turn all to the best! These proclamations, So forcing faults upon Hermione, I little like.
trg: The violent carriage of it Will clear or end the business: when the oracle, Thus by Apollo's great divine seal'd up, Shall the contents discover, something rare Even then will rush to knowledge. Go:

src: And from that torment I will free myself, Or hew my way out with a bloody axe.
trg: Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile, And cry 'Content' to that which grieves my heart, And wet my cheeks with artificial tears, And frame my face to all occasions.

src: O, you have made good work!
trg: What news? what news?

src: Had you a special warrant for the deed?
trg: No, my good lord; it was by private message.

src: He'll be hang'd yet, Though every drop of water swear against it And gape at widest to glut him.
trg: Let's all sink with the king.

src: if my deep prayers cannot appease thee, But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds, Yet execute thy wrath in me alone, O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!
trg: I pray thee, gentle keeper, stay by me; My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.

src: To whom should I complain? Did I tell this, Who would believe me? O perilous mouths, That bear in them one and the self-same tongue, Either of condemnation or approof;
trg: Bidding the law make court'sy to their will: Hooking both right and wrong to the appetite, To follow as it draws! I'll to my brother:

src: But mark how heavily this befell to the poor gentlewoman: there she lost a noble and renowned brother, in his love toward her ever most kind and natural;
trg: with him, the portion and sinew of her fortune, her marriage-dowry; with both, her combinate husband, this well-seeming Angelo.

src: We have very oft awaked him, as if to carry him to execution, and showed him a seeming warrant for it: it hath not moved him at all.
trg: More of him anon. There is written in your brow, provost, honesty and constancy: if I read it not truly, my ancient skill beguiles me; but, in the boldness of my cunning, I will lay myself in hazard.

src: Benedicite! What early tongue so sweet saluteth me? Young son, it argues a distemper'd head So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed:
trg: Care keeps his watch in every old man's eye, And where care lodges, sleep will never lie; But where unbruised youth with unstuff'd brain Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign:

src: Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck, And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats, Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades, Of healths five-fathom deep;
trg: and then anon Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes, And being thus frighted swears a prayer or two And sleeps again.

src: Where, underneath the grove of sycamore That westward rooteth from the city's side, So early walking did I see your son:
trg: Towards him I made, but he was ware of me And stole into the covert of the wood:

src: Why do you wring your hands, and beat your breast, And cry 'O Clarence, my unhappy son!'
trg: Why do you look on us, and shake your head, And call us wretches, orphans, castaways If that our noble father be alive?

src: Titus Lartius writes, they fought together, but Aufidius got off.
trg: And 'twas time for him too, I'll warrant him that: an he had stayed by him, I would not have been so fidiused for all the chests in Corioli, and the gold that's in them.

src: Unsavoury news! but how made he escape?
trg: He was convey'd by Richard Duke of Gloucester And the Lord Hastings, who attended him In secret ambush on the forest side And from the bishop's huntsmen rescued him;

src: Call it a travel that thou takest for pleasure.
trg: My heart will sigh when I miscall it so, Which finds it an inforced pilgrimage.

src: ' dismiss'd me Thus, with his speechless hand: what he would do, He sent in writing after me; what he would not, Bound with an oath to yield to his conditions: So that all hope is vain.
trg: Unless his noble mother, and his wife; Who, as I hear, mean to solicit him For mercy to his country. Therefore, let's hence, And with our fair entreaties haste them on.

src: For has not the divine Apollo said, Is't not the tenor of his oracle, That King Leontes shall not have an heir Till his lost child be found?
trg: which that it shall, Is all as monstrous to our human reason As my Antigonus to break his grave And come again to me; who, on my life, Did perish with the infant.

src: He is coming, sir, he is coming; I hear his straw rustle.
trg: Is the axe upon the block, sirrah?

src: Why, this was moulded on a porringer; A velvet dish: fie, fie! 'tis lewd and filthy: Why, 'tis a cockle or a walnut-shell, A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby's cap: Away with it!
trg: come, let me have a bigger.

src: By that and all the rites of knighthood else, Will I make good against thee, arm to arm, What I have spoke, or thou canst worse devise.
trg: I take it up; and by that sword I swear Which gently laid my knighthood on my shoulder, I'll answer thee in any fair degree, Or chivalrous design of knightly trial:

src: but I cannot Believe this crack to be in my dread mistress, So sovereignly being honourable. I have loved thee,--
trg: Make that thy question, and go rot! Would I do this? Could man so blench?

src: And then will I be general of your woes, And lead you even to death: meantime forbear, And let mischance be slave to patience. Bring forth the parties of suspicion.
trg: I am the greatest, able to do least, Yet most suspected, as the time and place Doth make against me of this direful murder;

src: 'Tis death for any one in Mantua To come to Padua. Know you not the cause?
trg: Your ships are stay'd at Venice, and the duke, For private quarrel 'twixt your duke and him, Hath publish'd and proclaim'd it openly:

src: You have made Good work, you and your cry! Shall's to the Capitol?
trg: O, ay, what else?

src: I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord, You said that idle weeds are fast in growth The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.
trg: He hath, my lord.

src: What is that Barnardine who is to be executed in the afternoon?
trg: A Bohemian born, but here nursed un and bred; one that is a prisoner nine years old.

src: Why, that was he.
trg: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.

src: Nay, I dare not swear it.
trg: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

src: And thou the velvet: thou art good velvet; thou'rt a three-piled piece, I warrant thee: I had as lief be a list of an English kersey as be piled, as thou art piled, for a French velvet.
trg: Do I speak feelingly now?

src: How far is it to Berkeley? and what stir Keeps good old York there with his men of war?
trg: There stands the castle, by yon tuft of trees, Mann'd with three hundred men, as I have heard; And in it are the Lords of York, Berkeley, and Seymour; None else of name and noble estimate.

src: Pray you, put up your dagger, and put out your wit.
trg: Then have at you with my wit! I will dry-beat you with an iron wit, and put up my iron dagger. Answer me like men:

src: The motion's good indeed and be it so, Petruchio, I shall be your ben venuto.
trg: Good sister, wrong me not, nor wrong yourself, To make a bondmaid and a slave of me; That I disdain:

src: I came from Edward as ambassador, But I return his sworn and mortal foe: Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me, But dreadful war shall answer his demand.
trg: Had he none else to make a stale but me? Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow. I was the chief that raised him to the crown, And I'll be chief to bring him down again:

src: And God, not we, hath plagued thy bloody deed.
trg: So just is God, to right the innocent.

src: Here, master: what cheer?
trg: Good, speak to the mariners: fall to't, yarely, or we run ourselves aground: bestir, bestir.

src: O sir, I do; and will repute you ever The patron of my life and liberty.
trg: Then go with me to make the matter good. This, by the way, I let you understand;

src: Why, love forswore me in my mother's womb: And, for I should not deal in her soft laws, She did corrupt frail nature with some bribe, To shrink mine arm up like a wither'd shrub;
trg: To make an envious mountain on my back, Where sits deformity to mock my body; To shape my legs of an unequal size;

src: Why, no.
trg: I'll be supposed upon a book, his face is the worst thing about him. Good, then; if his face be the worst thing about him, how could Master Froth do the constable's wife any harm?

src: O, would he did! and so perhaps he doth: 'Tis but his policy to counterfeit, Because he would avoid such bitter taunts Which in the time of death he gave our father.
trg: If so thou think'st, vex him with eager words.

src: Poor queen! how love to me and to her son Hath made her break out into terms of rage!
trg: Revenged may she be on that hateful duke, Whose haughty spirit, winged with desire, Will cost my crown, and like an empty eagle Tire on the flesh of me and of my son!

src: I do defy thy conjurations, And apprehend thee for a felon here.
trg: Wilt thou provoke me? then have at thee, boy!

src: Why, sir, I pray, are not the streets as free For me as for you?
trg: But so is not she.

src: I beg for justice, which thou, prince, must give; Romeo slew Tybalt, Romeo must not live.
trg: Romeo slew him, he slew Mercutio; Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?

src: That's as York thrives to beat back Bolingbroke.
trg: Alas, poor duke! the task he undertakes Is numbering sands and drinking oceans dry: Where one on his side fights, thousands will fly. Farewell at once, for once, for all, and ever.

src: How now, my lord! what hap? what hope of good?
trg: Our hap is loss, our hope but sad despair; Our ranks are broke, and ruin follows us: What counsel give you? whither shall we fly?

src: 'Tis not the devil's crest. How now! who's there?
trg: One Isabel, a sister, desires access to you.

src: If any in Vienna be of worth To undergo such ample grace and honour, It is Lord Angelo.
trg: Look where he comes.

src: A fellow, sir, that I have known to go about with troll-my-dames; I knew him once a servant of the prince:
trg: I cannot tell, good sir, for which of his virtues it was, but he was certainly whipped out of the court.

src: You have fought together.
trg: Were half to half the world by the ears and he. Upon my party, I'ld revolt to make Only my wars with him: he is a lion That I am proud to hunt.

src: I never did her any, to my knowledge.
trg: But you have all the vantage of her wrong. I was too hot to do somebody good, That is too cold in thinking of it now.

src: And, for more slander to thy dismal seat, We give thee up our guiltless blood to drink.
trg: Now Margaret's curse is fall'n upon our heads, For standing by when Richard stabb'd her son.

src: Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong, To strive for that which resteth in my choice: I am no breeching scholar in the schools;
trg: I'll not be tied to hours nor 'pointed times, But learn my lessons as I please myself. And, to cut off all strife, here sit we down: Take you your instrument, play you the whiles;

src: For gnarling sorrow hath less power to bite The man that mocks at it and sets it light.
trg: O, who can hold a fire in his hand By thinking on the frosty Caucasus? Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite By bare imagination of a feast?

src: Leave your prating: since these good men are pleased, let them come in; but quickly now.
trg: Why, they stay at door, sir.

src: the breasts of Hecuba, When she did suckle Hector, look'd not lovelier Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blood At Grecian sword, contemning. Tell Valeria, We are fit to bid her welcome.
trg: Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!

src: Is not a dukedom, sir, a goodly gift?
trg: Ay, by my faith, for a poor earl to give: I'll do thee service for so good a gift.

src: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.
trg: Foul devil, for God's sake, hence, and trouble us not; For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell, Fill'd it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.

src: Then was your sin of heavier kind than his.
trg: I do confess it, and repent it, father.

src: Romeo, away, be gone! The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain. Stand not amazed: the prince will doom thee death, If thou art taken: hence, be gone, away!
trg: O, I am fortune's fool!

src: Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord: Thou hast a lady far more beautiful Than any woman in this waning age.
trg: And till the tears that she hath shed for thee Like envious floods o'er-run her lovely face, She was the fairest creature in the world; And yet she is inferior to none.

src: Setting aside his high blood's royalty, And let him be no kinsman to my liege, I do defy him, and I spit at him; Call him a slanderous coward and a villain:
trg: Which to maintain I would allow him odds, And meet him, were I tied to run afoot Even to the frozen ridges of the Alps, Or any other ground inhabitable, Where ever Englishman durst set his foot.

src: Mistress, how mean you that?
trg: Thus I conceive by him.

src: God ye good morrow, gentlemen.
trg: God ye good den, fair gentlewoman.

src: What then, sir?
trg: Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as any in Rome.

src: Masters o' the people, We do request your kindest ears, and after, Your loving motion toward the common body, To yield what passes here.
trg: We are convented Upon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts Inclinable to honour and advance The theme of our assembly.

src: The king's son have I landed by himself; Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs In an odd angle of the isle and sitting, His arms in this sad knot.
trg: Of the king's ship The mariners say how thou hast disposed And all the rest o' the fleet.

src: What is the matter?
trg: Look, look! O heavy day!

src: This letter doth make good the friar's words, Their course of love, the tidings of her death:
trg: And here he writes that he did buy a poison Of a poor 'pothecary, and therewithal Came to this vault to die, and lie with Juliet. Where be these enemies? Capulet! Montague!

src: I think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple.
trg: And, sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bring forth more islands.

src: Ay, to such mercy as his ruthless arm, With downright payment, show'd unto my father. Now Phaethon hath tumbled from his car, And made an evening at the noontide prick.
trg: My ashes, as the phoenix, may bring forth A bird that will revenge upon you all: And in that hope I throw mine eyes to heaven, Scorning whate'er you can afflict me with. Why come you not? what!

src: O that deceit should dwell In such a gorgeous palace!
trg: There's no trust, No faith, no honesty in men; all perjured, All forsworn, all naught, all dissemblers. Ah, where's my man? give me some aqua vitae:

src: Boatswain!
trg: Here, master: what cheer?

src: I believe thee; for I think thou never wast where grace was said.
trg: No? a dozen times at least.

src: This nor hurts him nor profits you a jot; Forbear it therefore; give your cause to heaven. Mark what I say, which you shall find By every syllable a faithful verity: The duke comes home to-morrow;
trg: nay, dry your eyes; One of our convent, and his confessor, Gives me this instance:

src: Sir, let me be so bold as ask you, Did you yet ever see Baptista's daughter?
trg: No, sir; but hear I do that he hath two, The one as famous for a scolding tongue As is the other for beauteous modesty.

src: A little gale will soon disperse that cloud And blow it to the source from whence it came: The very beams will dry those vapours up, For every cloud engenders not a storm.
trg: The queen is valued thirty thousand strong, And Somerset, with Oxford fled to her: If she have time to breathe be well assured Her faction will be full as strong as ours.

src: MARIANA: Break off thy song, and haste thee quick away: Here comes a man of comfort, whose advice Hath often still'd my brawling discontent. I cry you mercy, sir;
trg: and well could wish You had not found me here so musical: Let me excuse me, and believe me so, My mirth it much displeased, but pleased my woe.

src: Lord, Lord! methought, what pain it was to drown! What dreadful noise of waters in mine ears! What ugly sights of death within mine eyes! Methought I saw a thousand fearful wrecks;
trg: Ten thousand men that fishes gnaw'd upon; Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl, Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels, All scatter'd in the bottom of the sea: Some lay in dead men's skulls;

src: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.
trg: And so it is: I wonder what it bodes.

src: I prithee now, sweet son, as thou hast said My praises made thee first a soldier, so, To have my praise for this, perform a part Thou hast not done before.
trg: Well, I must do't: Away, my disposition, and possess me Some harlot's spirit!

src: Is Lewis so brave? belike he thinks me Henry. But what said Lady Bona to my marriage?
trg: These were her words, utter'd with mad disdain: 'Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly, I'll wear the willow garland for his sake.'

src: He's coming.
trg: How accompanied?

src: Take Hereford's rights away, and take from Time His charters and his customary rights; Let not to-morrow then ensue to-day; Be not thyself;
trg: for how art thou a king But by fair sequence and succession? Now, afore God--God forbid I say true!

src: Here is the sister of the man condemn'd Desires access to you.
trg: Hath he a sister?

src: Why, York, what wilt thou do? Wilt thou not hide the trespass of thine own? Have we more sons? or are we like to have? Is not my teeming date drunk up with time?
trg: And wilt thou pluck my fair son from mine age, And rob me of a happy mother's name? Is he not like thee? is he not thine own?

src: when and where and how We met, we woo'd and made exchange of vow, I'll tell thee as we pass; but this I pray, That thou consent to marry us to-day.
trg: Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here! Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear, So soon forsaken? young men's love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.

src: So, slave; hence! Come unto these yellow sands, And then take hands: Courtsied when you have and kiss'd The wild waves whist, Foot it featly here and there; And, sweet sprites, the burthen bear.
trg: Hark, hark!

src: There's some in hope.
trg: It is a bitter deputy.

src: but when we have stuff'd These and these conveyances of our blood With wine and feeding, we have suppler souls Than in our priest-like fasts:
trg: therefore I'll watch him Till he be dieted to my request, And then I'll set upon him.

src: I see, as in a map, the end of all.
trg: Accursed and unquiet wrangling days, How many of you have mine eyes beheld! My husband lost his life to get the crown;

src: A gentleman, nurse, that loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to in a month.
trg: An a' speak any thing against me, I'll take him down, an a' were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks; and if I cannot, I'll find those that shall. Scurvy knave! I am none of his flirt-gills;

src: Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death, Gorged with the dearest morsel of the earth, Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open, And, in despite, I'll cram thee with more food!
trg: This is that banish'd haughty Montague, That murder'd my love's cousin, with which grief, It is supposed, the fair creature died; And here is come to do some villanous shame To the dead bodies:

src: This is true that I say: an I had thee in place where, thou shouldst know it.
trg: I am for thee straight: take thou the bill, give me thy mete-yard, and spare not me.

src: do not take His rougher accents for malicious sounds, But, as I say, such as become a soldier, Rather than envy you.
trg: Well, well, no more.

src: Business, my lord! I think most understand Bohemia stays here longer.
trg: Ha!

src: my child is dead; And with my child my joys are buried.
trg: Peace, ho, for shame! confusion's cure lives not In these confusions. Heaven and yourself Had part in this fair maid; now heaven hath all, And all the better is it for the maid:

src: I need not add more fuel to your fire, For well I wot ye blaze to burn them out Give signal to the fight, and to it, lords!
trg: Lords, knights, and gentlemen, what I should say My tears gainsay; for every word I speak, Ye see, I drink the water of mine eyes. Therefore, no more but this:

src: My lord, Before I freely speak my mind herein, You shall not only take the sacrament To bury mine intents, but also to effect Whatever I shall happen to devise.
trg: I see your brows are full of discontent, Your hearts of sorrow and your eyes of tears: Come home with me to supper; and I'll lay A plot shall show us all a merry day.

src: Again shall you be mother to a king, And all the ruins of distressful times Repair'd with double riches of content. What! we have many goodly days to see:
trg: The liquid drops of tears that you have shed Shall come again, transform'd to orient pearl, Advantaging their loan with interest Of ten times double gain of happiness.

src: Tell Bolingbroke--for yond methinks he stands-- That every stride he makes upon my land Is dangerous treason: he is come to open The purple testament of bleeding war;
trg: The king of heaven forbid our lord the king Should so with civil and uncivil arms Be rush'd upon! Thy thrice noble cousin Harry Bolingbroke doth humbly kiss thy hand;

src: Therefore, at your vantage, Ere he express himself, or move the people With what he would say, let him feel your sword, Which we will second.
trg: When he lies along, After your way his tale pronounced shall bury His reasons with his body.

src: Sir, we have all Great cause to give great thanks.
trg: They are near the city?

src: There was casting up of eyes, holding up of hands, with countenances of such distraction that they were to be known by garment, not by favour.
trg: Our king, being ready to leap out of himself for joy of his found daughter, as if that joy were now become a loss, cries 'O, thy mother, thy mother!' then asks Bohemia forgiveness;

src: Come, sir, along with us.
trg: I would they were barbarians--as they are, Though in Rome litter'd--not Romans--as they are not, Though calved i' the porch o' the Capitol--

src: No marvel, my lord, though it affrighted you; I promise, I am afraid to hear you tell it.
trg: O Brakenbury, I have done those things, Which now bear evidence against my soul, For Edward's sake; and see how he requites me! O God!

src: Ay, and he'll tame her.
trg: He says so, Tranio.

src: Ay, what's o'clock?
trg: I am thus bold to put your grace in mind Of what you promised me.

src: Talk not of France, sith thou hast lost it all.
trg: The lord protector lost it, and not I: When I was crown'd I was but nine months old.

src: All lost! to prayers, to prayers! all lost!
trg: What, must our mouths be cold?
By and by, I come:-- To cease thy suit, and leave me to my grief: To-morrow will I send.

src: The people are abused; set on. This paltering Becomes not Rome, nor has Coriolanus Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely I' the plain way of his merit.
trg: Tell me of corn! This was my speech, and I will speak't again--

src: With signs of war about his aged neck: O, full of careful business are his looks! Uncle, for God's sake, speak comfortable words.
trg: Should I do so, I should belie my thoughts: Comfort's in heaven; and we are on the earth, Where nothing lives but crosses, cares and grief.

src: Draw, Benvolio; beat down their weapons. Gentlemen, for shame, forbear this outrage! Tybalt, Mercutio, the prince expressly hath Forbidden bandying in Verona streets: Hold, Tybalt! good Mercutio!
trg: I am hurt. A plague o' both your houses! I am sped. Is he gone, and hath nothing?

src: thy food shall be The fresh-brook muscles, wither'd roots and husks Wherein the acorn cradled. Follow.
trg: No; I will resist such entertainment till Mine enemy has more power.

src: His nurse! why, she was dead ere thou wert born.
trg: If 'twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.

src: That you might well have signified the same Unto the citizens, who haply may Misconstrue us in him and wail his death.
trg: And to that end we wish'd your lord-ship here, To avoid the carping censures of the world.

src: I prithee, spare.
trg: Well, I have done: but yet,--

src: Then our office may, During his power, go sleep.
trg: He cannot temperately transport his honours From where he should begin and end, but will Lose those he hath won.

src: Alas, that love, whose view is muffled still, Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will! Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here? Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.
trg: Here's much to do with hate, but more with love. Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate! O any thing, of nothing first create! O heavy lightness! serious vanity!

src: Marry, farewell! I pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this, that was so full of his ropery?
trg: A gentleman, nurse, that loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to in a month.

src: These were his very words.
trg: 'Have I no friend?' quoth he: he spake it twice, And urged it twice together, did he not?

src: Always obedient to your grace's will, I come to know your pleasure.
trg: Angelo, There is a kind of character in thy life, That to the observer doth thy history Fully unfold.

src: By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am: My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself, Because it is an enemy to thee; Had I it written, I would tear the word.
trg: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words Of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound: Art thou not Romeo and a Montague?

src: and we here deliver, Subscribed by the consuls and patricians, Together with the seal o' the senate, what We have compounded on.
trg: Read it not, noble lords; But tell the traitor, in the high'st degree He hath abused your powers.

src: I would you did but see how it chafes, how it rages, how it takes up the shore! but that's not the point. O, the most piteous cry of the poor souls! sometimes to see 'em, and not to see 'em;
trg: now the ship boring the moon with her main-mast, and anon swallowed with yest and froth, as you'ld thrust a cork into a hogshead.

src: Come, sir; come, sir; come, sir; foh, sir! Why, you bald-pated, lying rascal, you must be hooded, must you? Show your knave's visage, with a pox to you!
trg: show your sheep-biting face, and be hanged an hour! Will't not off?

src: You, cousin Hereford, upon pain of life, Till twice five summers have enrich'd our fields Shall not regreet our fair dominions, But tread the stranger paths of banishment.
trg: Your will be done: this must my comfort be, Sun that warms you here shall shine on me; And those his golden beams to you here lent Shall point on me and gild my banishment.

src: Hear me a word; For I shall never speak to thee again.
trg: So.

src: Welcome home, Grumio!
trg: How now, Grumio!

src: There is differency between a grub and a butterfly; yet your butterfly was a grub. This Marcius is grown from man to dragon: he has wings; he's more than a creeping thing.
trg: He loved his mother dearly.

src: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied; And vice sometimes by action dignified. Within the infant rind of this small flower Poison hath residence and medicine power:
trg: For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part; Being tasted, slays all senses with the heart. Two such opposed kings encamp them still In man as well as herbs, grace and rude will;

src: Long live Edward the Fourth!
trg: Thanks, brave Montgomery; and thanks unto you all: If fortune serve me, I'll requite this kindness. Now, for this night, let's harbour here in York;

src: This shall assure my constant loyalty, That if our queen and this young prince agree, I'll join mine eldest daughter and my joy To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands.
trg: Yes, I agree, and thank you for your motion. Son Edward, she is fair and virtuous, Therefore delay not, give thy hand to Warwick;

src: But let thy spiders, that suck up thy venom, And heavy-gaited toads lie in their way, Doing annoyance to the treacherous feet Which with usurping steps do trample thee:
trg: Yield stinging nettles to mine enemies;

src: Marshal, ask yonder knight in arms, Both who he is and why he cometh hither Thus plated in habiliments of war, And formally, according to our law, Depose him in the justice of his cause.
trg: What is thy name? and wherefore comest thou hither, Before King Richard in his royal lists? Against whom comest thou? and what's thy quarrel? Speak like a true knight, so defend thee heaven!

src: Besides, if things go well, Opinion that so sticks on Marcius shall Of his demerits rob Cominius.
trg: Come: Half all Cominius' honours are to Marcius. Though Marcius earned them not, and all his faults To Marcius shall be honours, though indeed In aught he merit not.

src: But when your carters or your waiting-vassals Have done a drunken slaughter, and defaced The precious image of our dear Redeemer, You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon;
trg: And I unjustly too, must grant it you But for my brother not a man would speak, Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself For him, poor soul.

src: Of the king's ship The mariners say how thou hast disposed And all the rest o' the fleet.
trg: Safely in harbour Is the king's ship; in the deep nook, where once Thou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dew From the still-vex'd Bermoothes, there she's hid: The mariners all under hatches stow'd;

src: O sweet Paulina, Make me to think so twenty years together! No settled senses of the world can match The pleasure of that madness. Let 't alone.
trg: I am sorry, sir, I have thus far stirr'd you: but I could afflict you farther.

src: Hail sir!
trg: Hail to you both!

src: Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for your pains: I know you think to dine with me to-day, And have prepared great store of wedding cheer;
trg: But so it is, my haste doth call me hence, And therefore here I mean to take my leave.

src: Get you gone.
trg: Stand fast; We have as many friends as enemies.

src: Evermore weeping for your cousin's death? What, wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears? An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live; Therefore, have done: some grief shows much of love;
trg: But much of grief shows still some want of wit.

src: And then?
trg: The old priest of Saint Luke's church is at your command at all hours.

src: only this methought I heard the shepherd say, he found the child.
trg: I would most gladly know the issue of it.

src: Then his good report should have been my son; I therein would have found issue. Hear me profess sincerely:
trg: had I a dozen sons, each in my love alike and none less dear than thine and my good Marcius, I had rather had eleven die nobly for their country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.

src: Thou hast sworn it more to me: Then whither goest? say, whither?
trg: We'll have this song out anon by ourselves: my father and the gentlemen are in sad talk, and we'll not trouble them. Come, bring away thy pack after me. Wenches, I'll buy for you both.

src: He should have lived, Save that riotous youth, with dangerous sense, Might in the times to come have ta'en revenge, By so receiving a dishonour'd life With ransom of such shame.
trg: Would yet he had lived! A lack, when once our grace we have forgot, Nothing goes right: we would, and we would not.

src: They are.
trg: Call them forth.
Come forth, I say! there's other business for thee: Come, thou tortoise! when? Fine apparition! My quaint Ariel, Hark in thine ear.

src: By the king.
trg: For what?

src: As if Olympus to a molehill should In supplication nod: and my young boy Hath an aspect of intercession, which Great nature cries 'Deny not.' let the Volsces Plough Rome and harrow Italy:
trg: I'll never Be such a gosling to obey instinct, but stand, As if a man were author of himself And knew no other kin.

src: Hood my unmann'd blood, bating in my cheeks, With thy black mantle; till strange love, grown bold, Think true love acted simple modesty. Come, night; come, Romeo; come, thou day in night;
trg: For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night Whiter than new snow on a raven's back. Come, gentle night, come, loving, black-brow'd night, Give me my Romeo;

src: If my heart's dear love--
trg: Well, do not swear: although I joy in thee, I have no joy of this contract to-night: It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden;

src: Go ask his name: if he be married. My grave is like to be my wedding bed.
trg: His name is Romeo, and a Montague; The only son of your great enemy.

src: Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet. Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.
trg: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs, And throw them in the entrails of the wolf? When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?

src: If thou refuse And wilt encounter with my wrath, say so; The bastard brains with these my proper hands Shall I dash out. Go, take it to the fire; For thou set'st on thy wife.
trg: I did not, sir: These lords, my noble fellows, if they please, Can clear me in't.

src: Right true it is, your son Lucentio here Doth love my daughter and she loveth him, Or both dissemble deeply their affections:
trg: And therefore, if you say no more than this, That like a father you will deal with him And pass my daughter a sufficient dower, The match is made, and all is done:

src: A little joy enjoys the queen thereof; For I am she, and altogether joyless. I can no longer hold me patient.
trg: Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out In sharing that which you have pill'd from me! Which of you trembles not that looks on me?

src: A murrain on't! I took this for silver.
trg: See here these movers that do prize their hours At a crack'd drachm!

src: but they themselves are o' the mind, if it be not too rough for some that know little but bowling, it will please plentifully.
trg: Away! we'll none on 't: here has been too much homely foolery already. I know, sir, we weary you.

src: Yes, worthy sir, The slave's report is seconded; and more, More fearful, is deliver'd.
trg: What more fearful?

src: What if he had said 'widower AEneas' too? Good Lord, how you take it!
trg: 'Widow Dido' said you? you make me study of that: she was of Carthage, not of Tunis.

src: Put in their hands thy bruising irons of wrath, That they may crush down with a heavy fall The usurping helmets of our adversaries!
trg: Make us thy ministers of chastisement, That we may praise thee in the victory! To thee I do commend my watchful soul, Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes: Sleeping and waking, O, defend me still!

src: As she lived peerless, So her dead likeness, I do well believe, Excels whatever yet you look'd upon Or hand of man hath done; therefore I keep it Lonely, apart. But here it is:
trg: prepare To see the life as lively mock'd as ever Still sleep mock'd death: behold, and say 'tis well. I like your silence, it the more shows off Your wonder: but yet speak;

src: Let's to the Capitol. Would half my wealth Would buy this for a lie!
trg: Pray, let us go.

src: Ah, Richard, with the eyes of heavy mind I see thy glory like a shooting star Fall to the base earth from the firmament.
trg: Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west, Witnessing storms to come, woe and unrest: Thy friends are fled to wait upon thy foes, And crossly to thy good all fortune goes.

src: Would they make peace? terrible hell make war Upon their spotted souls for this offence!
trg: Sweet love, I see, changing his property, Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate: Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made With heads, and not with hands;

src: Daughter, well met.
trg: God give your graces both A happy and a joyful time of day!

src: I know my remedy; I must go fetch the third--borough.
trg: Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I'll answer him by law: I'll not budge an inch, boy: let him come, and kindly.

src: Come, what talk you Of Marcius?
trg: Go see this rumourer whipp'd. It cannot be The Volsces dare break with us.

src: Famous Plantagenet, most gracious prince, Lend favourable ears to our request; And pardon us the interruption Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.
trg: My lord, there needs no such apology: I rather do beseech you pardon me, Who, earnest in the service of my God, Neglect the visitation of my friends. But, leaving this, what is your grace's pleasure?

src: Why, and I challenge nothing but my dukedom, As being well content with that alone.
What must I say? 'I Pray, sir'--Plague upon't! I cannot bring My tongue to such a pace:--'Look, sir, my wounds!
trg: I got them in my country's service, when Some certain of your brethren roar'd and ran From the noise of our own drums.'

src: O, I have bought the mansion of a love, But not possess'd it, and, though I am sold, Not yet enjoy'd:
trg: so tedious is this day As is the night before some festival To an impatient child that hath new robes And may not wear them. O, here comes my nurse, And she brings news;

src: Let me ask my sister pardon. I am so out of love with life that I will sue to be rid of it.
trg: Hold you there: farewell. Provost, a word with you!

src: Pink for flower.
trg: Right.

src: Thanks, gentle Norfolk: stay by me, my lords; And, soldiers, stay and lodge by me this night.
trg: And when the king comes, offer no violence, Unless he seek to thrust you out perforce.

src: Why, is it not news, to hear of Petruchio's coming?
trg: Is he come?

src: Peace, foolish woman.
trg: I will not peace. What is the matter, Aumerle.

src: 'twas no need, I trow, To bid me trudge: And since that time it is eleven years; For then she could stand alone; nay, by the rood, She could have run and waddled all about;
trg: For even the day before, she broke her brow: And then my husband--God be with his soul! A' was a merry man--took up the child: 'Yea,' quoth he, 'dost thou fall upon thy face?

src: which had been done, But that the good mind of Camillo tardied My swift command, though I with death and with Reward did threaten and encourage him, Not doing 't and being done:
trg: how he glisters Thorough my rust! and how his pity Does my deeds make the blacker!

src: and by and by Think that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke, And straight am nothing:
trg: but whate'er I be, Nor I nor any man that but man is With nothing shall be pleased, till he be eased With being nothing. Music do I hear? Ha, ha! keep time:

src: Why, that's all one.
trg: Nay, by Saint Jamy, I hold you a penny, A horse and a man Is more than one, And yet not many.

src: So.
trg: And his offence is so, as it appears, Accountant to the law upon that pain.

src: Ho! who is within there? Saddle my horse. God for his mercy, what treachery is here!
trg: Why, what is it, my lord?

src: How know you that?
trg: My wife, sir, whom I detest before heaven and your honour,--

src: Hence, old goat!
trg: We'll surety him.

src: Good Captain Blunt, bear my good night to him And by the second hour in the morning Desire the earl to see me in my tent:
trg: Yet one thing more, good Blunt, before thou go'st, Where is Lord Stanley quarter'd, dost thou know?

src: The fires i' the lowest hell fold-in the people! Call me their traitor! Thou injurious tribune!
trg: Within thine eyes sat twenty thousand deaths, In thy hand clutch'd as many millions, in Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say 'Thou liest' unto thee with a voice as free As I do pray the gods.

src: but with true prayers That shall be up at heaven and enter there Ere sun-rise, prayers from preserved souls, From fasting maids whose minds are dedicate To nothing temporal.
trg: Well; come to me to-morrow.

src: Balk logic with acquaintance that you have And practise rhetoric in your common talk; Music and poesy use to quicken you;
trg: The mathematics and the metaphysics, Fall to them as you find your stomach serves you; No profit grows where is no pleasure ta'en: In brief, sir, study what you most affect.

src: Ariel, thy charge Exactly is perform'd: but there's more work. What is the time o' the day?
trg: Past the mid season.

src: How often he had met you, sword to sword; That of all things upon the earth he hated Your person most, that he would pawn his fortunes To hopeless restitution, so he might Be call'd your vanquisher.
trg: At Antium lives he?

src: And I unto the sea from whence I came.
trg: And I, with grief and sorrow, to the court.

src: Oxford, how haps it, in this smooth discourse, You told not how Henry the Sixth hath lost All that which Henry Fifth had gotten? Methinks these peers of France should smile at that.
trg: But for the rest, you tell a pedigree Of threescore and two years; a silly time To make prescription for a kingdom's worth.

src: Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel:
trg: Arise; one knocks; good Romeo, hide thyself.

src: foolish wench! To the most of men this is a Caliban And they to him are angels.
trg: My affections Are then most humble; I have no ambition To see a goodlier man.

src: For God's sake, a pot of small ale.
trg: Will't please your lordship drink a cup of sack?

src: If he took you a box o' the ear, you might have your action of slander too.
trg: Marry, I thank your good worship for it. What is't your worship's pleasure I shall do with this wicked caitiff?

src: Thank you, sir: farewell. O world, thy slippery turns!
trg: so, fellest foes, Whose passions and whose plots have broke their sleep, To take the one the other, by some chance, Some trick not worth an egg, shall grow dear friends And interjoin their issues.

src: Marry, sir, I think, if you handled her privately, she would sooner confess: perchance, publicly, she'll be ashamed.
trg: I will go darkly to work with her.

src: Erroneous vassal! the great King of kings Hath in the tables of his law commanded That thou shalt do no murder: and wilt thou, then, Spurn at his edict and fulfil a man's? Take heed;
trg: for he holds vengeance in his hands, To hurl upon their heads that break his law.

src: Hark, how the villain would close now, after his treasonable abuses!
trg: Such a fellow is not to be talked withal. Away with him to prison! Where is the provost? Away with him to prison! lay bolts enough upon him: let him speak no more.

src: standing, speaking, moving, And yet so fast asleep.
trg: Noble Sebastian, Thou let'st thy fortune sleep--die, rather; wink'st Whiles thou art waking.

src: my prime request, Which I do last pronounce, is, O you wonder! If you be maid or no?
trg: No wonder, sir; But certainly a maid.
Ay, by and by; But we will drink together; and you shall bear A better witness back than words, which we, On like conditions, will have counter-seal'd. Come, enter with us.

src: 'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself: 'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.
trg: O ho, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.

src: Dolour comes to him, indeed: you have spoken truer than you purposed.
trg: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.

src: And when they from thy bosom pluck a flower, Guard it, I pray thee, with a lurking adder Whose double tongue may with a mortal touch Throw death upon thy sovereign's enemies.
trg: Mock not my senseless conjuration, lords: This earth shall have a feeling and these stones Prove armed soldiers, ere her native king Shall falter under foul rebellion's arms.

src: Marshal, demand of yonder champion The cause of his arrival here in arms: Ask him his name and orderly proceed To swear him in the justice of his cause.
trg: In God's name and the king's, say who thou art And why thou comest thus knightly clad in arms, Against what man thou comest, and what thy quarrel: Speak truly, on thy knighthood and thy oath;

src: if you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with you.
trg: She will indite him to some supper.

src: One on 's father's moods.
trg: Indeed, la, 'tis a noble child.

src: A certain number, Though thanks to all, must I select from all: the rest Shall bear the business in some other fight, As cause will be obey'd. Please you to march;
trg: And four shall quickly draw out my command, Which men are best inclined.

src: There's no more to be said, but he is banish'd, As enemy to the people and his country: It shall be so.
trg: It shall be so, it shall be so.

src: Cousin, throw up your gage; do you begin.
trg: O, God defend my soul from such deep sin! Shall I seem crest-fall'n in my father's sight? Or with pale beggar-fear impeach my height Before this out-dared dastard?

src: Not out of doors!
trg: She shall, she shall.

src: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.
trg: Now, by my mother's son, and that's myself, It shall be moon, or star, or what I list, Or ere I journey to your father's house. Go on, and fetch our horses back again. Evermore cross'd and cross'd;

src: Then we are rid of Licio.
trg: I' faith, he'll have a lusty widow now, That shall be wood and wedded in a day.

src: Then with directions to repair to Ravenspurgh.
trg: Have you forgot the Duke of Hereford, boy?

src: While we pursued the horsemen of the north, He slily stole away and left his men: Whereat the great Lord of Northumberland, Whose warlike ears could never brook retreat, Cheer'd up the drooping army;
trg: and himself, Lord Clifford and Lord Stafford, all abreast, Charged our main battle's front, and breaking in Were by the swords of common soldiers slain.

src: And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig's tail Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep, Then dreams, he of another benefice:
trg: Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck, And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats, Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades, Of healths five-fathom deep;

src: And many strokes, though with a little axe, Hew down and fell the hardest-timber'd oak. By many hands your father was subdued;
trg: But only slaughter'd by the ireful arm Of unrelenting Clifford and the queen, Who crown'd the gracious duke in high despite, Laugh'd in his face;

src: What, ho, Barnardine!
How! Was it we? we loved him but, like beasts And cowardly nobles, gave way unto your clusters, Who did hoot him out o' the city.
trg: But I fear They'll roar him in again. Tullus Aufidius, The second name of men, obeys his points As if he were his officer:

src: He's a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb. You two are old men: tell me one thing that I shall ask you.
trg: Well, sir.

src: so every true man's apparel fits your thief.
trg: Are you agreed?
Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick! Yet am I arm'd against the worst can happen; And haste is needful in this desperate case.

src: First, hath this woman Most wrongfully accused your substitute, Who is as free from touch or soil with her As she from one ungot.
trg: We did believe no less. Know you that Friar Lodowick that she speaks of?

src: Are you a maid?
trg: No, my lord.

src: if it be, The man I speak of cannot in the world Be singly counterpoised. At sixteen years, When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought Beyond the mark of others:
trg: our then dictator, Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight, When with his Amazonian chin he drove The bristled lips before him:

src: For who is living, if those two are gone?
trg: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banished; Romeo that kill'd him, he is banished.

src: These high wild hills and rough uneven ways Draws out our miles, and makes them wearisome, And yet your fair discourse hath been as sugar, Making the hard way sweet and delectable.
trg: But theirs is sweetened with the hope to have The present benefit which I possess; And hope to joy is little less in joy Than hope enjoy'd:

src: Consort! what, dost thou make us minstrels? an thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but discords: here's my fiddlestick; here's that shall make you dance. 'Zounds, consort!
trg: We talk here in the public haunt of men: Either withdraw unto some private place, And reason coldly of your grievances, Or else depart; here all eyes gaze on us.

src: To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return for conscience sake, to help to get thee a wife.
trg: You are never without your tricks: you may, you may.

src: Prepare thy brow to frown: know'st thou me yet?
trg: I know thee not: thy name?

src: Why, there thou hast it: two deep enemies, Foes to my rest and my sweet sleep's disturbers Are they that I would have thee deal upon: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.
trg: Let me have open means to come to them, And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them.

src: A hundred thousand welcomes. I could weep And I could laugh, I am light and heavy. Welcome. A curse begin at very root on's heart, That is not glad to see thee! You are three That Rome should dote on:
trg: yet, by the faith of men, We have some old crab-trees here at home that will not Be grafted to your relish. Yet welcome, warriors: We call a nettle but a nettle and The faults of fools but folly.

src: Wise! why, no question but he was.
trg: A very superficial, ignorant, unweighing fellow.

src: My gracious lord, I may be negligent, foolish and fearful; In every one of these no man is free, But that his negligence, his folly, fear, Among the infinite doings of the world, Sometime puts forth.
trg: In your affairs, my lord, If ever I were wilful-negligent, It was my folly; if industriously I play'd the fool, it was my negligence, Not weighing well the end;

src: I pray you, sir, of what disposition was the duke?
trg: One that, above all other strifes, contended especially to know himself.

src: From too much liberty, my Lucio, liberty: As surfeit is the father of much fast, So every scope by the immoderate use Turns to restraint.
trg: Our natures do pursue, Like rats that ravin down their proper bane, A thirsty evil; and when we drink we die.

src: Should dying men flatter with those that live?
trg: No, no, men living flatter those that die.

src: For myself, I'll put My fortunes to your service, which are here By this discovery lost. Be not uncertain; For, by the honour of my parents, I Have utter'd truth:
trg: which if you seek to prove, I dare not stand by; nor shall you be safer Than one condemn'd by the king's own mouth, thereon His execution sworn.

src: I will respect thee as a father if Thou bear'st my life off hence: let us avoid.
trg: It is in mine authority to command The keys of all the posterns: please your highness To take the urgent hour. Come, sir, away.

src: God save your honour!
trg: Stay a little while. You're welcome: what's your will?

src: methinks I see my cousin's ghost Seeking out Romeo, that did spit his body Upon a rapier's point: stay, Tybalt, stay! Romeo, I come! this do I drink to thee.
trg: Hold, take these keys, and fetch more spices, nurse.

src: How now! what noise? That spirit's possessed with haste That wounds the unsisting postern with these strokes.
trg: There he must stay until the officer Arise to let him in: he is call'd up.

src: Of Mantua.
trg: Of Mantua, sir? marry, God forbid! And come to Padua, careless of your life?

src: Why, Warwick, canst thou speak against thy liege, Whom thou obeyed'st thirty and six years, And not bewray thy treason with a blush?
trg: Can Oxford, that did ever fence the right, Now buckler falsehood with a pedigree? For shame! leave Henry, and call Edward king.

src: I think 'twill serve, if he Can thereto frame his spirit.
trg: He must, and will Prithee now, say you will, and go about it.

src: An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should buy the fee-simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.
trg: The fee-simple! O simple!

src: 'Madam,' and nothing else: so lords call ladies.
trg: Madam wife, they say that I have dream'd And slept above some fifteen year or more.

src: What a pestilent knave is this same!
trg: Hang him, Jack! Come, we'll in here; tarry for the mourners, and stay dinner.

src: It is extempore, from my mother-wit.
trg: A witty mother! witless else her son.

src: Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave, That goes not out to prey.
trg: Now, as fond fathers, Having bound up the threatening twigs of birch, Only to stick it in their children's sight For terror, not to use, in time the rod Becomes more mock'd than fear'd;

src: It is an honour that I dream not of.
trg: An honour! were not I thine only nurse, I would say thou hadst suck'd wisdom from thy teat.

src: It may be right; but you are i' the wrong To speak before your time. Proceed.
trg: I went To this pernicious caitiff deputy,--

src: O sir, I shall be hated to report it! The prince your son, with mere conceit and fear Of the queen's speed, is gone.
trg: How! gone!

src: O, make them joyful, grant their lawful suit!
trg: Alas, why would you heap these cares on me? I am unfit for state and majesty; I do beseech you, take it not amiss; I cannot nor I will not yield to you.

src: A dearer merit, not so deep a maim As to be cast forth in the common air, Have I deserved at your highness' hands. The language I have learn'd these forty years, My native English, now I must forego:
trg: And now my tongue's use is to me no more Than an unstringed viol or a harp, Or like a cunning instrument cased up, Or, being open, put into his hands That knows no touch to tune the harmony:

src: The senators of Rome are this good belly, And you the mutinous members; What do you think, You, the great toe of this assembly?
trg: I the great toe! why the great toe?

src: He breathes, my lord. Were he not warm'd with ale, This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.
trg: O monstrous beast! how like a swine he lies! Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image! Sirs, I will practise on this drunken man.

src: And mine, fair lady Bona, joins with yours.
trg: And mine with hers, and thine, and Margaret's. Therefore at last I firmly am resolved You shall have aid.

src: I remember you, sir, by the sound of your voice: I met you at the prison, in the absence of the duke.
trg: O, did you so? And do you remember what you said of the duke?

src: Yes, I accept her, for she well deserves it; And here, to pledge my vow, I give my hand.
trg: Why stay we now? These soldiers shall be levied, And thou, Lord Bourbon, our high admiral, Shalt waft them over with our royal fleet.

src: then wisely, good sir, weigh Our sorrow with our comfort.
trg: Prithee, peace.

src: But 'tis all one to me; for had I been the finder out of this secret, it would not have relished among my other discredits.
trg: Here come those I have done good to against my will, and already appearing in the blossoms of their fortune.

src: The broken rancour of your high-swoln hearts, But lately splinter'd, knit, and join'd together, Must gently be preserved, cherish'd, and kept:
trg: Me seemeth good, that, with some little train, Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fetch'd Hither to London, to be crown'd our king.

src: Sir, give him head: I know he'll prove a jade.
trg: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?

src: Hadst thou been kill'd when first thou didst presume, Thou hadst not lived to kill a son of mine. The owl shriek'd at thy birth,--an evil sign; The night-crow cried, aboding luckless time;
trg: Dogs howl'd, and hideous tempest shook down trees; The raven rook'd her on the chimney's top, And chattering pies in dismal discords sung.
'Twere pity they should lose their father's lands.

src: Yet show some pity.
trg: I show it most of all when I show justice; For then I pity those I do not know, Which a dismiss'd offence would after gall; And do him right that, answering one foul wrong, Lives not to act another.

src: Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir: Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.
trg: How well my comfort is revived by this!

src: What must be shall be.
trg: That's a certain text.

src: One word more, one word. This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find The harm of unscann'd swiftness, will too late Tie leaden pounds to's heels. Proceed by process;
trg: Lest parties, as he is beloved, break out, And sack great Rome with Romans.

src: Here, sir: I'ld have beaten him like a dog, but for disturbing the lords within.
trg: Whence comest thou? what wouldst thou? thy name? Why speak'st not? speak, man: what's thy name?

src: Well, say there is no kingdom then for Richard; What other pleasure can the world afford?
trg: I'll make my heaven in a lady's lap, And deck my body in gay ornaments, And witch sweet ladies with my words and looks. O miserable thought! and more unlikely Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns!

src: Respect to your great place! and let the devil Be sometime honour'd for his burning throne! Where is the duke? 'tis he should hear me speak.
trg: The duke's in us; and we will hear you speak: Look you speak justly.

src: Hush, master! here's some good pastime toward: That wench is stark mad or wonderful froward.
trg: But in the other's silence do I see Maid's mild behavior and sobriety. Peace, Tranio!

src: For which the heavens, taking angry note, Have left me issueless; and your father's blest, As he from heaven merits it, with you Worthy his goodness.
trg: What might I have been, Might I a son and daughter now have look'd on, Such goodly things as you!

src: One that, above all other strifes, contended especially to know himself.
trg: What pleasure was he given to?

src: Landlord of England art thou now, not king: Thy state of law is bondslave to the law; And thou--
trg: A lunatic lean-witted fool, Presuming on an ague's privilege, Darest with thy frozen admonition Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood With fury from his native residence.

src: You see, sweet maid, we marry A gentler scion to the wildest stock, And make conceive a bark of baser kind By bud of nobler race:
trg: this is an art Which does mend nature, change it rather, but The art itself is nature.

src: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them; But how or in what place I do not know.
trg: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after supper, And thou shalt tell the process of their death. Meantime, but think how I may do thee good, And be inheritor of thy desire. Farewell till soon.

src: Who would be thence that has the benefit of access? every wink of an eye some new grace will be born: our absence makes us unthrifty to our knowledge. Let's along.
trg: Now, had I not the dash of my former life in me, would preferment drop on my head. I brought the old man and his son aboard the prince: told him I heard them talk of a fardel and I know not what:

src: And now in peace my soul shall part to heaven, Since I have set my friends at peace on earth. Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand; Dissemble not your hatred, swear your love.
trg: By heaven, my heart is purged from grudging hate: And with my hand I seal my true heart's love.

src: And to that end we wish'd your lord-ship here, To avoid the carping censures of the world.
trg: But since you come too late of our intents, Yet witness what you hear we did intend: And so, my good lord mayor, we bid farewell.

src: If thou love me, 'tis time thou wert away.
trg: What my tongue dares not, that my heart shall say.

src: He neither does nor shall.
trg: Methinks a father Is at the nuptial of his son a guest That best becomes the table. Pray you once more, Is not your father grown incapable Of reasonable affairs?

src: And so did I.
trg: Well, what was yours?

src: Who but to-day hammer'd of this design, But durst not tempt a minister of honour, Lest she should be denied.
trg: Tell her, Emilia. I'll use that tongue I have: if wit flow from't As boldness from my bosom, let 't not be doubted I shall do good.

src: Methinks a woman of this valiant spirit Should, if a coward heard her speak these words, Infuse his breast with magnanimity And make him, naked, foil a man at arms.
trg: I speak not this as doubting any here For did I but suspect a fearful man He should have leave to go away betimes, Lest in our need he might infect another And make him of like spirit to himself.

src: Well, here he comes.
trg: Calmly, I do beseech you.

src: No; God forbid your grace should be forsworn.
trg: I shall be, if I claim by open war.

src: Show me how, good father.
trg: This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuance of her first affection:

src: The fringed curtains of thine eye advance And say what thou seest yond.
trg: What is't? a spirit? Lord, how it looks about! Believe me, sir, It carries a brave form. But 'tis a spirit.

src: Unless I have mista'en his colours much, Which well I am assured I have not done, His regiment lies half a mile at least South from the mighty power of the king.
trg: If without peril it be possible, Good Captain Blunt, bear my good-night to him, And give him from me this most needful scroll.

src: No, my good lord; therefore be patient.
trg: This is All-Souls' day, fellows, is it not?

src: our gates, Which yet seem shut, we, have but pinn'd with rushes; They'll open of themselves. Hark you. far off! There is Aufidius; list, what work he makes Amongst your cloven army.
trg: O, they are at it!

src: O blessed, blessed night! I am afeard. Being in night, all this is but a dream, Too flattering-sweet to be substantial.
trg: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.

src: My crown I am; but still my griefs are mine: You may my glories and my state depose, But not my griefs; still am I king of those.
trg: Part of your cares you give me with your crown.

src: Should by the cormorant belly be restrain'd, Who is the sink o' the body,--
trg: Well, what then?

src: His vices, you would say; there's no virtue whipped out of the court: they cherish it to make it stay there; and yet it will no more but abide.
trg: Vices, I would say, sir. I know this man well: he hath been since an ape-bearer; then a process-server, a bailiff;

src: I would he knew that I had saved his brother! Take thou the fee, and tell him what I say; For I repent me that the duke is slain.
trg: So do not I: go, coward as thou art. Now must I hide his body in some hole, Until the duke take order for his burial: And when I have my meed, I must away; For this will out, and here I must not stay.

src: Methinks I am a prophet new inspired And thus expiring do foretell of him: His rash fierce blaze of riot cannot last, For violent fires soon burn out themselves;
trg: Small showers last long, but sudden storms are short; He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes; With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder:

src: Romeo will answer it.
trg: Any man that can write may answer a letter.

src: if we lose the field, We cannot keep the town.
trg: Fear not our care, sir.

src: What is thy name? and wherefore comest thou hither, Before King Richard in his royal lists? Against whom comest thou? and what's thy quarrel? Speak like a true knight, so defend thee heaven!
trg: Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby Am I; And as I truly fight, defend me heaven!

src: Speak, good Cominius: Leave nothing out for length, and make us think Rather our state's defective for requital Than we to stretch it out.
trg: Masters o' the people, We do request your kindest ears, and after, Your loving motion toward the common body, To yield what passes here.

src: These differences shall all rest under gage Till Norfolk be repeal'd: repeal'd he shall be, And, though mine enemy, restored again To all his lands and signories:
trg: when he's return'd, Against Aumerle we will enforce his trial.

src: but, I'll warrant you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal world. Doth not rosemary and Romeo begin both with a letter?
trg: Ay, nurse; what of that? both with an R.

src: Nor I.
trg: Let's to the Capitol. Would half my wealth Would buy this for a lie!

src: Besides, I heard the banish'd Norfolk say That thou, Aumerle, didst send two of thy men To execute the noble duke at Calais.
trg: Some honest Christian trust me with a gage That Norfolk lies: here do I throw down this, If he may be repeal'd, to try his honour.

src: Your brother is a forfeit of the law, And you but waste your words.
trg: Alas, alas! Why, all the souls that were were forfeit once; And He that might the vantage best have took Found out the remedy.

src: The blood of English shall manure the ground, And future ages groan for this foul act;
trg: Peace shall go sleep with Turks and infidels, And in this seat of peace tumultuous wars Shall kin with kin and kind with kind confound;

src: Be you content, fair maid; It is the law, not I condemn your brother: Were he my kinsman, brother, or my son, It should be thus with him: he must die tomorrow.
trg: To-morrow! O, that's sudden! Spare him, spare him! He's not prepared for death. Even for our kitchens We kill the fowl of season:

src: Join with the present sickness that I have; And thy unkindness be like crooked age, To crop at once a too long wither'd flower. Live in thy shame, but die not shame with thee!
trg: These words hereafter thy tormentors be! Convey me to my bed, then to my grave: Love they to live that love and honour have.

src: I am Christophero Sly; call not me 'honour' nor 'lordship:' I ne'er drank sack in my life; and if you give me any conserves, give me conserves of beef: ne'er ask me what raiment I'll wear;
trg: for I have no more doublets than backs, no more stockings than legs, nor no more shoes than feet; nay, sometimes more feet than shoes, or such shoes as my toes look through the over-leather.

src: Royally! Why, it contains no king?
trg: Yes, my good lord, It doth contain a king; King Richard lies Within the limits of yon lime and stone:

src: 'Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus, Another thing to fall. I not deny, The jury, passing on the prisoner's life, May in the sworn twelve have a thief or two Guiltier than him they try.
trg: What's open made to justice, That justice seizes: what know the laws That thieves do pass on thieves? 'Tis very pregnant, The jewel that we find, we stoop and take't Because we see it;

src: And in the very pangs of death he cried, Like to a dismal clangour heard from far, 'Warwick, revenge! brother, revenge my death!
trg: ' So, underneath the belly of their steeds, That stain'd their fetlocks in his smoking blood, The noble gentleman gave up the ghost.

src: A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion, To pray for them that have done scathe to us.
trg: So do I ever: being well-advised. For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.

src: Live each of you the subjects to his hate, And he to yours, and all of you to God's!
trg: My hair doth stand on end to hear her curses.

src: I'll tell you how these lands are to be got.
trg: So shall you bind me to your highness' service.

src: That dreamers often lie.
trg: In bed asleep, while they do dream things true.

src: Well demanded, wench: My tale provokes that question.
trg: Dear, they durst not, So dear the love my people bore me, nor set A mark so bloody on the business, but With colours fairer painted their foul ends.

src: Ay, but he's dead: off with the traitor's head, And rear it in the place your father's stands. And now to London with triumphant march, There to be crowned England's royal king:
trg: From whence shall Warwick cut the sea to France, And ask the Lady Bona for thy queen: So shalt thou sinew both these lands together;

src: Then, for his mind, be Edward England's king: But Henry now shall wear the English crown, And be true king indeed, thou but the shadow.
trg: My Lord of Somerset, at my request, See that forthwith Duke Edward be convey'd Unto my brother, Archbishop of York.

src: I know you are now, sir, a gentleman born.
trg: Ay, and have been so any time these four hours.

src: For shame, thou helding of a devilish spirit, Why dost thou wrong her that did ne'er wrong thee? When did she cross thee with a bitter word?
trg: Her silence flouts me, and I'll be revenged.

src: Yea, my good lord.
trg: Then I must not say no.

src: Scratches with briers, Scars to move laughter only.
trg: Consider further, That when he speaks not like a citizen, You find him like a soldier:

src: Come you to make confession to this father?
trg: To answer that, I should confess to you.

src: The news I have to tell your majesty Is, that by sudden floods and fall of waters, Buckingham's army is dispersed and scatter'd; And he himself wander'd away alone, No man knows whither.
trg: I cry thee mercy: There is my purse to cure that blow of thine. Hath any well-advised friend proclaim'd Reward to him that brings the traitor in?

src: Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.
trg: Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir: Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.

src: Up, sir, go with me; I charge thee in the princes name, obey.
trg: Where are the vile beginners of this fray?

src: Nor showing, as the manner is, his wounds To the people, beg their stinking breaths.
trg: 'Tis right.

src: Marry, sir, he hath offended the law: and, sir, we take him to be a thief too, sir; for we have found upon him, sir, a strange picklock, which we have sent to the deputy.
trg: Fie, sirrah! a bawd, a wicked bawd! The evil that thou causest to be done, That is thy means to live. Do thou but think What 'tis to cram a maw or clothe a back From such a filthy vice:

src: I told you. Lord Angelo, belike thinking me remiss in mine office, awakens me with this unwonted putting-on; methinks strangely, for he hath not used it before.
trg: Pray you, let's hear.

src: Of neither, girl: For of joy, being altogether wanting, It doth remember me the more of sorrow; Or if of grief, being altogether had, It adds more sorrow to my want of joy:
trg: For what I have I need not to repeat; And what I want it boots not to complain.

src: The Duke of Norfolk, sprightfully and bold, Stays but the summons of the appellant's trumpet.
trg: Why, then, the champions are prepared, and stay For nothing but his majesty's approach.

src: Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford? How far hence is thy lord, mine honest fellow?
trg: By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward.

src: And there the little souls of Edward's children Whisper the spirits of thine enemies And promise them success and victory. Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end;
trg: Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.

src: Look not pale, Bianca; thy father will not frown.
trg: My cake is dough; but I'll in among the rest, Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.

src: This a consul? no.
trg: The aediles, ho! Let him be apprehended.

src: but, sure, that part Was aptly fitted and naturally perform'd.
trg: I think 'twas Soto that your honour means.

src: A jealous hood, a jealous hood! Now, fellow, What's there?
trg: Things for the cook, sir; but I know not what.

src: or if it did not, Your first is dead; or 'twere as good he were, As living here and you no use of him.
trg: Speakest thou from thy heart?

src: Yet, ere thou go, but answer me one doubt, What pledge have we of thy firm loyalty?
trg: This shall assure my constant loyalty, That if our queen and this young prince agree, I'll join mine eldest daughter and my joy To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands.

src: I do beseech you, sir, have patience: Your looks are pale and wild, and do import Some misadventure.
trg: Tush, thou art deceived: Leave me, and do the thing I bid thee do. Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?

src: To the syllable.
trg: Come, follow. Speak not for him.

src: When clouds appear, wise men put on their cloaks; When great leaves fall, the winter is at hand; When the sun sets, who doth not look for night? Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.
trg: All may be well; but, if God sort it so, 'Tis more than we deserve, or I expect.

src: 'Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signor mio Petruchio.' Rise, Grumio, rise: we will compound this quarrel.
trg: Nay, 'tis no matter, sir, what he 'leges in Latin. if this be not a lawful case for me to leave his service, look you, sir, he bid me knock him and rap him soundly, sir:

src: Because your lordship was proclaimed traitor.
trg: But he, my lord, is gone to Ravenspurgh, To offer service to the Duke of Hereford, And sent me over by Berkeley, to discover What power the Duke of York had levied there;

src: Keep your hundred pounds to yourself: he shall need none, so long as I live.
trg: Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua. Do you hear, sir?

src: And you, sir! you are welcome. Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?
trg: Sir, at the farthest for a week or two: But then up farther, and as for as Rome; And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.

src: It rested in your grace To unloose this tied-up justice when you pleased: And it in you more dreadful would have seem'd Than in Lord Angelo.
trg: I do fear, too dreadful: Sith 'twas my fault to give the people scope, 'Twould be my tyranny to strike and gall them For what I bid them do:

src: Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste, And every day I cannot come to woo.
trg: You knew my father well, and in him me, Left solely heir to all his lands and goods, Which I have better'd rather than decreased:

src: Peace, you mumbling fool! Utter your gravity o'er a gossip's bowl; For here we need it not.
trg: You are too hot.

src: Yea, noise? then I'll be brief. O happy dagger! This is thy sheath; there rust, and let me die.
trg: This is the place; there, where the torch doth burn.

src: Well, sir; my mistress is the sweetest lady--Lord, Lord! when 'twas a little prating thing:--O, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard;
trg: but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him. I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man;

src: Brave warriors, Clifford and Northumberland, Come, make him stand upon this molehill here, That raught at mountains with outstretched arms, Yet parted but the shadow with his hand. What!
trg: was it you that would be England's king? Was't you that revell'd in our parliament, And made a preachment of your high descent? Where are your mess of sons to back you now?
Why do you put these sayings upon me?
