src: every day some sailor's wife, The masters of some merchant and the merchant Have just our theme of woe; but for the miracle, I mean our preservation, few in millions Can speak like us:
trg: then wisely, good sir, weigh Our sorrow with our comfort.

src: We will before the walls of Rome tomorrow Set down our host. My partner in this action, You must report to the Volscian lords, how plainly I have borne this business.
trg: Only their ends You have respected; stopp'd your ears against The general suit of Rome; never admitted A private whisper, no, not with such friends That thought them sure of you.

src: She being none of your flesh and blood, your flesh and blood has not offended the king; and so your flesh and blood is not to be punished by him.
trg: Show those things you found about her, those secret things, all but what she has with her: this being done, let the law go whistle: I warrant you.

src: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense: I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.
trg: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.

src: Upon record, my gracious lord.
trg: But say, my lord, it were not register'd, Methinks the truth should live from age to age, As 'twere retail'd to all posterity, Even to the general all-ending day.

src: O gracious duke, Harp not on that, nor do not banish reason For inequality; but let your reason serve To make the truth appear where it seems hid, And hide the false seems true.
trg: Many that are not mad Have, sure, more lack of reason. What would you say?

src: Come on, bawd; I will instruct thee in my trade; follow.
trg: I do desire to learn, sir: and I hope, if you have occasion to use me for your own turn, you shall find me yare; for truly, sir, for your kindness I owe you a good turn.

src: Every man's conscience is a thousand swords, To fight against that bloody homicide.
trg: I doubt not but his friends will fly to us.

src: So 'tis said, sir; about his son, that should have married a shepherd's daughter.
trg: If that shepherd be not in hand-fast, let him fly: the curses he shall have, the tortures he shall feel, will break the back of man, the heart of monster.

src: Not your gaoler, then, But your kind hostess. Come, I'll question you Of my lord's tricks and yours when you were boys: You were pretty lordings then?
trg: We were, fair queen, Two lads that thought there was no more behind But such a day to-morrow as to-day, And to be boy eternal.

src: All men, I hope, live so.
trg: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.

src: You cavil, widow: I did mean, my queen.
trg: 'Twill grieve your grace my sons should call you father.

src: Let me embrace with old Vincentio, And wander we to see thy honest son, Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.
trg: But is it true? or else is it your pleasure, Like pleasant travellers, to break a jest Upon the company you overtake?

src: To-morrow! O, that's sudden! Spare him, spare him! He's not prepared for death. Even for our kitchens We kill the fowl of season:
trg: shall we serve heaven With less respect than we do minister To our gross selves? Good, good my lord, bethink you; Who is it that hath died for this offence? There's many have committed it.

src: Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior,-- For yet his honour never heard a play-- You break into some merry passion And so offend him; for I tell you, sirs, If you should smile he grows impatient.
trg: Fear not, my lord: we can contain ourselves, Were he the veriest antic in the world.

src: Tell him his fears are shallow, wanting instance: Go, bid thy master rise and come to me And we will both together to the Tower, Where, he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.
trg: My gracious lord, I'll tell him what you say.

src: He was in the right; and so indeed it is. Ten the clock there. Give me a calendar. Who saw the sun to-day?
trg: Not I, my lord.
King Lewis and Lady Bona, hear me speak, Before you answer Warwick. His demand Springs not from Edward's well-meant honest love, But from deceit bred by necessity;

src: Well, madam, and in health.
trg: What is thy news then?

src: You have undone a man of fourscore three, That thought to fill his grave in quiet, yea, To die upon the bed my father died, To lie close by his honest bones:
trg: but now Some hangman must put on my shroud and lay me Where no priest shovels in dust. O cursed wretch, That knew'st this was the prince, and wouldst adventure To mingle faith with him! Undone!

src: And so do I. Victorious Prince of York, Before I see thee seated in that throne Which now the house of Lancaster usurps, I vow by heaven these eyes shall never close.
trg: This is the palace of the fearful king, And this the regal seat: possess it, York; For this is thine and not King Henry's heirs'

src: Good my lord, be cured Of this diseased opinion, and betimes; For 'tis most dangerous.
trg: Say it be, 'tis true.

src: This news is mortal to the queen: look down And see what death is doing.
trg: Take her hence: Her heart is but o'ercharged; she will recover: I have too much believed mine own suspicion: Beseech you, tenderly apply to her Some remedies for life.

src: Now be you blest for it! I'll to the queen: please you, come something nearer.
trg: Madam, if't please the queen to send the babe, I know not what I shall incur to pass it, Having no warrant.

src: No, I'll not meddle.
trg: Pray you, go to him.

src: I am glad to see your ladyship.
trg: How do you both? you are manifest house-keepers. What are you sewing here? A fine spot, in good faith. How does your little son?

src: Their power, I think, is thirty thousand strong:
trg: Now, if the help of Norfolk and myself, With all the friends that thou, brave Earl of March, Amongst the loving Welshmen canst procure, Will but amount to five and twenty thousand, Why, Via!

src: You will not bail me, then, sir?
trg: Then, Pompey, nor now. What news abroad, friar? what news?

src: Prove me, my gracious sovereign.
trg: Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?

src: I swounded at the sight.
trg: O, break, my heart! poor bankrupt, break at once! To prison, eyes, ne'er look on liberty! Vile earth, to earth resign; end motion here; And thou and Romeo press one heavy bier!

src: They say she's mad.
trg: They have ta'en note of us: keep on your way.

src: Nay, it's no matter for that.
trg: Worth six on him.

src: that you may-- For I do fear eyes over--to shipboard Get undescried.
trg: I see the play so lies That I must bear a part.

src: The gates are open, let us enter too.
trg: So other foes may set upon our backs. Stand we in good array; for they no doubt Will issue out again and bid us battle:

src: To me comes a creature, Sometimes her head on one side, some another; I never saw a vessel of like sorrow, So fill'd and so becoming:
trg: in pure white robes, Like very sanctity, she did approach My cabin where I lay; thrice bow'd before me, And gasping to begin some speech, her eyes Became two spouts:

src: if I make not this cheat bring out another and the shearers prove sheep, let me be unrolled and my name put in the book of virtue! Jog on, jog on, the foot-path way, And merrily hent the stile-a:
trg: A merry heart goes all the day, Your sad tires in a mile-a.

src: Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wife's allies, And make me happy in your unity.
trg: Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate On you or yours, but with all duteous love Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me With hate in those where I expect most love!

src: Here's such a coil! come, what says Romeo?
trg: Have you got leave to go to shrift to-day?

src: I have not been desirous of their wealth, Nor much oppress'd them with great subsidies. Nor forward of revenge, though they much err'd: Then why should they love Edward more than me?
trg: No, Exeter, these graces challenge grace: And when the lion fawns upon the lamb, The lamb will never cease to follow him.

src: Right, As snow in harvest. Thou deceivest thyself: 'Tis he that sent us hither now to slaughter thee.
trg: It cannot be; for when I parted with him, He hugg'd me in his arms, and swore, with sobs, That he would labour my delivery.

src: This is good news: I will go meet the ladies. This Volumnia Is worth of consuls, senators, patricians, A city full; of tribunes, such as you, A sea and land full. You have pray'd well to-day:
trg: This morning for ten thousand of your throats I'd not have given a doit. Hark, how they joy!

src: Saw you the king to-day, my Lord of Derby?
trg: But now the Duke of Buckingham and I Are come from visiting his majesty.

src: Richard of York! how fares our loving brother?
trg: Well, my dread lord; so must I call you now.

src: for, coming thence, My son is lost and, in my rate, she too, Who is so far from Italy removed I ne'er again shall see her.
trg: O thou mine heir Of Naples and of Milan, what strange fish Hath made his meal on thee?

src: See, where he comes: so please you, step aside; I'll know his grievance, or be much denied.
trg: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay, To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away.

src: He will hear none: he hath evermore had the liberty of the prison; give him leave to escape hence, he would not: drunk many times a day, if not many days entirely drunk.
trg: We have very oft awaked him, as if to carry him to execution, and showed him a seeming warrant for it: it hath not moved him at all.

src: To take is not to give.
trg: Look, how this ring encompasseth finger. Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart; Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.

src: By heaven, brat, I'll plague ye for that word.
trg: Ay, thou wast born to be a plague to men.

src: My sovereign liege, no letters; and few words, But such as I, without your special pardon, Dare not relate.
trg: Go to, we pardon thee: therefore, in brief, Tell me their words as near as thou canst guess them. What answer makes King Lewis unto our letters?

src: If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's work, Thou'ldst not believe thy deeds:
trg: but I'll report it Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles, Where great patricians shall attend and shrug, I' the end admire, where ladies shall be frighted, And, gladly quaked, hear more;

src: for what miscarries Shall be the general's fault, though he perform To the utmost of a man, and giddy censure Will then cry out of Marcius 'O if he Had borne the business!'
trg: Besides, if things go well, Opinion that so sticks on Marcius shall Of his demerits rob Cominius.

src: Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge; Use careful watch, choose trusty sentinels.
trg: I go, my lord.

src: See, how she leans her cheek upon her hand! O, that I were a glove upon that hand, That I might touch that cheek!
trg: Ay me!

src: Well, well, he was the covert'st shelter'd traitor That ever lived.
trg: What, had he so?

src: We follow thee. Juliet, the county stays.
trg: Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.

src: He'll go, he says, and sowl the porter of Rome gates by the ears: he will mow all down before him, and leave his passage polled.
trg: And he's as like to do't as any man I can imagine.

src: For, I am sure, you have your hands full all, In this so sudden business.
trg: Good night: Get thee to bed, and rest; for thou hast need.

src: Out upon you! what a man are you!
trg: One, gentlewoman, that God hath made for himself to mar.

src: Cold friends to Richard: what do they in the north, When they should serve their sovereign in the west?
trg: They have not been commanded, mighty sovereign: Please it your majesty to give me leave, I'll muster up my friends, and meet your grace Where and what time your majesty shall please.

src: I will confess to you that I love him.
trg: So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.

src: What is six winters? they are quickly gone.
trg: To men in joy; but grief makes one hour ten.

src: Strike, drum.
trg: Where's Potpan, that he helps not to take away? He shift a trencher? he scrape a trencher!

src: Be he the fire, I'll be the yielding water: The rage be his, whilst on the earth I rain My waters; on the earth, and not on him. March on, and mark King Richard how he looks.
trg: Yet looks he like a king: behold, his eye, As bright as is the eagle's, lightens forth Controlling majesty: alack, alack, for woe, That any harm should stain so fair a show!

src: Twice for one step I'll groan, the way being short, And piece the way out with a heavy heart. Come, come, in wooing sorrow let's be brief, Since, wedding it, there is such length in grief;
trg: One kiss shall stop our mouths, and dumbly part; Thus give I mine, and thus take I thy heart.

src: On Thursday, sir? the time is very short.
trg: My father Capulet will have it so; And I am nothing slow to slack his haste.

src: Thus I conceive by him.
trg: Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?

src: You have told them home; And, by my troth, you have cause. You'll sup with me?
trg: Anger's my meat; I sup upon myself, And so shall starve with feeding. Come, let's go: Leave this faint puling and lament as I do, In anger, Juno-like. Come, come, come.

src: He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest man's voice.
trg: Therefore let him be consul: the gods give him joy, and make him good friend to the people!

src: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!
trg: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.

src: Nay, this way, man: see where the huntsmen stand. Now, brother of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, and the rest, Stand you thus close, to steal the bishop's deer?
trg: Brother, the time and case requireth haste: Your horse stands ready at the park-corner.

src: It is; you lie, you lie:
trg: I say thou liest, Camillo, and I hate thee, Pronounce thee a gross lout, a mindless slave, Or else a hovering temporizer, that Canst with thine eyes at once see good and evil, Inclining to them both:

src: Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife To come to me forthwith.
trg: O, ho! entreat her! Nay, then she must needs come.

src: But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench, Thou pout'st upon thy fortune and thy love: Take heed, take heed, for such die miserable.
trg: Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed, Ascend her chamber, hence and comfort her: But look thou stay not till the watch be set, For then thou canst not pass to Mantua; Go before, nurse:

src: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord, The citizens are mum and speak not a word.
trg: Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's children?

src: You look as if you held a brow of much distraction Are you moved, my lord?
trg: No, in good earnest. How sometimes nature will betray its folly, Its tenderness, and make itself a pastime To harder bosoms!

src: Go, take it up unto thy master's use.
trg: Villain, not for thy life: take up my mistress' gown for thy master's use!

src: But whither shall we then?
trg: To Lynn, my lord, And ship from thence to Flanders.

src: my rights and royalties Pluck'd from my arms perforce and given away To upstart unthrifts? Wherefore was I born? If that my cousin king be King of England, It must be granted I am Duke of Lancaster.
trg: You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin; Had you first died, and he been thus trod down, He should have found his uncle Gaunt a father, To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay.

src: No, gracious lord, except I cannot do it.
trg: Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask.

src: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?
trg: Biondello, what of that?

src: Your own is yours, and I am yours, and all.
trg: So far be mine, my most redoubted lord, As my true service shall deserve your love.

src: If it be so, We need no grave to bury honesty: There's not a grain of it the face to sweeten Of the whole dungy earth.
trg: What! lack I credit?

src: Nay, good my lord, be not angry.
trg: No, I warrant you; I will not adventure my discretion so weakly. Will you laugh me asleep, for I am very heavy?

src: And a half, sir.
trg: Alas, it hath been great pains to you. They do you wrong to put you so oft upon 't: are there not men in your ward sufficient to serve it?

src: ' And so he vanish'd: then came wandering by A shadow like an angel, with bright hair Dabbled in blood; and he squeak'd out aloud, 'Clarence is come;
trg: false, fleeting, perjured Clarence, That stabb'd me in the field by Tewksbury; Seize on him, Furies, take him to your torments!

src: Yet looks he like a king: behold, his eye, As bright as is the eagle's, lightens forth Controlling majesty: alack, alack, for woe, That any harm should stain so fair a show!
trg: We are amazed; and thus long have we stood To watch the fearful bending of thy knee, Because we thought ourself thy lawful king:

src: would thy best friends did know How it doth grieve me that thy head is here!
trg: My lord, cheer up your spirits: our foes are nigh, And this soft courage makes your followers faint. You promised knighthood to our forward son: Unsheathe your sword, and dub him presently.

src: Had he been slaughter-man to all my kin, I should not for my life but weep with him. To see how inly sorrow gripes his soul.
trg: What, weeping-ripe, my Lord Northumberland? Think but upon the wrong he did us all, And that will quickly dry thy melting tears.

src: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.
trg: It is a quarrel most unnatural, To be revenged on him that loveth you.

src: as at that time Through all the signories it was the first And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed In dignity, and for the liberal arts Without a parallel;
trg: those being all my study, The government I cast upon my brother And to my state grew stranger, being transported And rapt in secret studies. Thy false uncle-- Dost thou attend me?

src: Ay, thou wast born to be a plague to men.
trg: For God's sake, take away this captive scold.

src: but whate'er I be, Nor I nor any man that but man is With nothing shall be pleased, till he be eased With being nothing. Music do I hear? Ha, ha! keep time:
trg: how sour sweet music is, When time is broke and no proportion kept! So is it in the music of men's lives. And here have I the daintiness of ear To cheque time broke in a disorder'd string;

src: To both their deaths thou shalt be accessary.
trg: I would I knew thy heart.

src: Say that I slew them not?
trg: Why, then they are not dead: But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.

src: Welcome, Sir John! But why come you in arms?
trg: To help King Edward in his time of storm, As every loyal subject ought to do.

src: Yet of your royal presence I'll adventure The borrow of a week. When at Bohemia You take my lord, I'll give him my commission To let him there a month behind the gest Prefix'd for's parting:
trg: yet, good deed, Leontes, I love thee not a jar o' the clock behind What lady-she her lord. You'll stay?

src: You see how he intends to use the people.
trg: May they perceive's intent! He will require them, As if he did contemn what he requested Should be in them to give.

src: I not doubt He came alive to land.
trg: No, no, he's gone.

src: God's is the quarrel; for God's substitute, His deputy anointed in His sight, Hath caused his death: the which if wrongfully, Let heaven revenge;
trg: for I may never lift An angry arm against His minister.

src: which was so much, That heirless it hath made my kingdom and Destroy'd the sweet'st companion that e'er man Bred his hopes out of.
trg: True, too true, my lord: If, one by one, you wedded all the world, Or from the all that are took something good, To make a perfect woman, she you kill'd Would be unparallel'd.

src: At that sad stop, my lord, Where rude misgovern'd hands from windows' tops Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.
trg: welcome, Bolingbroke!' Whilst he, from the one side to the other turning, Bareheaded, lower than his proud steed's neck, Bespake them thus: 'I thank you, countrymen:

src: Why, that is spoken like a toward prince.
trg: Royal commanders, be in readiness: For with a band of thirty thousand men Comes Warwick, backing of the Duke of York; And in the towns, as they do march along, Proclaims him king, and many fly to him:

src: Not to kill him, having a warrant for it; but to be damned for killing him, from which no warrant can defend us.
trg: I thought thou hadst been resolute.

src: O, swear not by the moon, the inconstant moon, That monthly changes in her circled orb, Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.
trg: What shall I swear by?

src: if this news be true, Poor queen and son, your labour is but lost; For Warwick is a subtle orator, And Lewis a prince soon won with moving words. By this account then Margaret may win him;
trg: For she's a woman to be pitied much: Her sighs will make a battery in his breast; Her tears will pierce into a marble heart; The tiger will be mild whiles she doth mourn;

src: Black and portentous must this humour prove, Unless good counsel may the cause remove.
trg: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?

src: Have you no countermand for Claudio yet, But he must die to-morrow?
trg: None, sir, none.

src: And I am one that love Bianca more Than words can witness, or your thoughts can guess.
trg: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.

src: I'll be supposed upon a book, his face is the worst thing about him. Good, then; if his face be the worst thing about him, how could Master Froth do the constable's wife any harm?
trg: I would know that of your honour.

src: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?
trg: If to have done the thing you gave in charge Beget your happiness, be happy then, For it is done, my lord.

src: God save you, sir!
trg: And you, sir! you are welcome. Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?

src: But the bottom of the news is that our general is cut i' the middle and but one half of what he was yesterday; for the other has half, by the entreaty and grant of the whole table.
trg: He'll go, he says, and sowl the porter of Rome gates by the ears: he will mow all down before him, and leave his passage polled.

src: And all this day an unaccustom'd spirit Lifts me above the ground with cheerful thoughts. I dreamt my lady came and found me dead-- Strange dream, that gives a dead man leave to think!
trg: -- And breathed such life with kisses in my lips, That I revived, and was an emperor. Ah me! how sweet is love itself possess'd, When but love's shadows are so rich in joy! News from Verona!

src: Then go with me to make the matter good. This, by the way, I let you understand;
trg: my father is here look'd for every day, To pass assurance of a dower in marriage 'Twixt me and one Baptista's daughter here: In all these circumstances I'll instruct you:

src: O just but severe law! I had a brother, then. Heaven keep your honour!
they join, embrace, and seem to kiss, As if they vow'd some league inviolable: Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun. In this the heaven figures some event.
trg: 'Tis wondrous strange, the like yet never heard of. Whate'er it bodes, henceforward will I bear Upon my target three fair-shining suns.

src: No, 'tis impossible he should escape, For, though before his face I speak the words Your brother Richard mark'd him for the grave: And wheresoe'er he is, he's surely dead.
trg: Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave?

src: Your horror's pardon: I had rather have my wounds to heal again Than hear say how I got them.
trg: Sir, I hope My words disbench'd you not.

src: Six frozen winter spent, Return with welcome home from banishment.
trg: How long a time lies in one little word! Four lagging winters and four wanton springs End in a word: such is the breath of kings.

src: Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long. But I would be loath to fall into my dreams again: I will therefore tarry in despite of the flesh and the blood.
trg: Your honour's players, heating your amendment, Are come to play a pleasant comedy;

src: Doth your honour see any harm in his face?
trg: Why, no.

src: Only, good master, while we do admire This virtue and this moral discipline, Let's be no stoics nor no stocks, I pray; Or so devote to Aristotle's cheques As Ovid be an outcast quite abjured:
trg: Balk logic with acquaintance that you have And practise rhetoric in your common talk; Music and poesy use to quicken you;

src: and himself, Lord Clifford and Lord Stafford, all abreast, Charged our main battle's front, and breaking in Were by the swords of common soldiers slain.
trg: Lord Stafford's father, Duke of Buckingham, Is either slain or wounded dangerously; I cleft his beaver with a downright blow: That this is true, father, behold his blood.

src: O, 'tis an accident that heaven provides! Dispatch it presently; the hour draws on Prefix'd by Angelo: see this be done, And sent according to command;
trg: whiles I Persuade this rude wretch willingly to die.

src: Antonio, my father, is deceased; And I have thrust myself into this maze, Haply to wive and thrive as best I may: Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home, And so am come abroad to see the world.
trg: Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to thee And wish thee to a shrewd ill-favour'd wife? Thou'ldst thank me but a little for my counsel: And yet I'll promise thee she shall be rich And very rich:

src: Merciful Heaven, Thou rather with thy sharp and sulphurous bolt Split'st the unwedgeable and gnarled oak Than the soft myrtle: who, with our spleens, Would all themselves laugh mortal.
And he that throws not up his cap for joy Shall for the fault make forfeit of his head.
trg: King Edward, valiant Richard, Montague, Stay we no longer, dreaming of renown, But sound the trumpets, and about our task.

src: The miserable have no other medicine But only hope: I've hope to live, and am prepared to die.
trg: Be absolute for death; either death or life Shall thereby be the sweeter. Reason thus with life: If I do lose thee, I do lose a thing That none but fools would keep:

src: What's that to thee?
trg: Why, a horse.

src: We are true subjects to the king, King Edward.
trg: So would you be again to Henry, If he were seated as King Edward is.

src: for I may never lift An angry arm against His minister.
trg: Where then, alas, may I complain myself?

src: Sir, you have done enough, and have perform'd A saint-like sorrow: no fault could you make, Which you have not redeem'd; indeed, paid down More penitence than done trespass:
trg: at the last, Do as the heavens have done, forget your evil; With them forgive yourself.

src: We are the queen's abjects, and must obey. Brother, farewell: I will unto the king;
trg: And whatsoever you will employ me in, Were it to call King Edward's widow sister, I will perform it to enfranchise you.

src: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark. Now will he sit under a medlar tree, And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit As maids call medlars, when they laugh alone.
trg: Romeo, that she were, O, that she were An open et caetera, thou a poperin pear! Romeo, good night: I'll to my truckle-bed; This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep: Come, shall we go?

src: Your lady mother is coming to your chamber: The day is broke; be wary, look about.
trg: Then, window, let day in, and let life out.

src: Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily, That we have had no time to move our daughter: Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly, And so did I:--Well, we were born to die.
trg: 'Tis very late, she'll not come down to-night: I promise you, but for your company, I would have been a-bed an hour ago.

src: The better, given me by so holy a man. Hath yet the deputy sent my brother's pardon?
trg: He hath released him, Isabel, from the world: His head is off and sent to Angelo.

src: What of his heart perceive you in his face By any likelihood he show'd to-day?
trg: Marry, that with no man here he is offended; For, were he, he had shown it in his looks.

src: When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows, I'll follow you, and tell what answer Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him. Now, for a while farewell, good Duke of York.
trg: What fates impose, that men must needs abide; It boots not to resist both wind and tide.

src: Repent you, fair one, of the sin you carry?
trg: I do; and bear the shame most patiently.

src: Whoever got thee, there thy mother stands; For, well I wot, thou hast thy mother's tongue.
trg: But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam; But like a foul mis-shapen stigmatic, Mark'd by the destinies to be avoided, As venom toads, or lizards' dreadful stings.

src: thou barr'st us Our prayers to the gods, which is a comfort That all but we enjoy; for how can we, Alas, how can we for our country pray.
trg: Whereto we are bound, together with thy victory, Whereto we are bound? alack, or we must lose The country, our dear nurse, or else thy person, Our comfort in the country.

src: Mistrust it not: for, sure, AEacides Was Ajax, call'd so from his grandfather.
trg: I must believe my master; else, I promise you, I should be arguing still upon that doubt: But let it rest. Now, Licio, to you:

src: How now, old lad?
trg: Welcome, you;--how now, you;-- what, you;--fellow, you;--and thus much for greeting. Now, my spruce companions, is all ready, and all things neat?

src: His word is more than the miraculous harp; he hath raised the wall and houses too.
trg: What impossible matter will he make easy next?

src: Bagot, forbear; thou shalt not take it up.
trg: Excepting one, I would he were the best In all this presence that hath moved me so.

src: I'faith, sir, you shall never need to fear: I wis it is not half way to her heart;
trg: But if it were, doubt not her care should be To comb your noddle with a three-legg'd stool And paint your face and use you like a fool.

src: see, see what showers arise, Blown with the windy tempest of my heart, Upon thy words, that kill mine eye and heart! O, pity, God, this miserable age!
trg: What stratagems, how fell, how butcherly, Erroneous, mutinous and unnatural, This deadly quarrel daily doth beget!

src: I pray she may; I'll to her.
trg: I thank you, good friend Lucio.

src: Say, I, her sovereign, am her subject love.
trg: But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.

src: Rather than fool it so, Let the high office and the honour go To one that would do thus. I am half through; The one part suffer'd, the other will I do. Here come more voices. Your voices:
trg: for your voices I have fought; Watch'd for your voices; for Your voices bear Of wounds two dozen odd; battles thrice six I have seen and heard of;

src: I cry you mercy: I mean the lord protector.
trg: The Lord protect him from that kingly title! Hath he set bounds betwixt their love and me? I am their mother; who should keep me from them?

src: ' Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word, One nick-name for her purblind son and heir, Young Adam Cupid, he that shot so trim, When King Cophetua loved the beggar-maid!
trg: He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not; The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.

src: Even here undone! I was not much afeard;
trg: for once or twice I was about to speak and tell him plainly, The selfsame sun that shines upon his court Hides not his visage from our cottage but Looks on alike. Will't please you, sir, be gone?

src: or, to redeem him, Give up your body to such sweet uncleanness As she that he hath stain'd?
trg: Sir, believe this, I had rather give my body than my soul.

src: I hope he is; but yet let mothers doubt.
trg: Now, by my troth, if I had been remember'd, I could have given my uncle's grace a flout, To touch his growth nearer than he touch'd mine.

src: Nay, rather, good my lords, be second to me: Fear you his tyrannous passion more, alas, Than the queen's life? a gracious innocent soul, More free than he is jealous.
trg: That's enough.

src: Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner, Either betray'd by falsehood of his guard Or by his foe surprised at unawares:
trg: And, as I further have to understand, Is new committed to the Bishop of York, Fell Warwick's brother and by that our foe.

src: O ho, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.
trg: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.

src: Ha, ha, ha! So, you're paid.
trg: Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible,--

src: What, Grumio!
trg: Fellow Grumio!

src: I can add colours to the chameleon, Change shapes with Proteus for advantages, And set the murderous Machiavel to school. Can I do this, and cannot get a crown?
trg: Tut, were it farther off, I'll pluck it down. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: I can bear my part; you must know 'tis my occupation; have at it with you.
trg: Get you hence, for I must go Where it fits not you to know.

src: Not I: No, God forbid that I should wish them sever'd Whom God hath join'd together; ay, and 'twere pity To sunder them that yoke so well together.
trg: Setting your scorns and your mislike aside, Tell me some reason why the Lady Grey Should not become my wife and England's queen. And you too, Somerset and Montague, Speak freely what you think.

src: Long live King Henry! Plantagenet embrace him.
trg: And long live thou and these thy forward sons!

src: swearing both They prosper best of all when I am thence. Would I were dead! if God's good will were so; For what is in this world but grief and woe? O God!
trg: methinks it were a happy life, To be no better than a homely swain;

src: Go, be gone. We shall be much unfurnished for this time. What, is my daughter gone to Friar Laurence?
trg: Ay, forsooth.

src: Down with him, down with him!
trg: Go, get you to your house; be gone, away! All will be naught else.

src: An if he may, then am I lawful king; For Richard, in the view of many lords, Resign'd the crown to Henry the Fourth, Whose heir my father was, and I am his.
trg: He rose against him, being his sovereign, And made him to resign his crown perforce.

src: and that's as easy As to set dogs on sheep--will be his fire To kindle their dry stubble; and their blaze Shall darken him for ever.
trg: What's the matter?

src: She is not hot, but temperate as the morn; For patience she will prove a second Grissel, And Roman Lucrece for her chastity:
trg: And to conclude, we have 'greed so well together, That upon Sunday is the wedding-day.

src: Father, you cannot disinherit me: If you be king, why should not I succeed?
trg: Pardon me, Margaret; pardon me, sweet son: The Earl of Warwick and the duke enforced me.

src: For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford.
trg: Ay, what of that? it was my will and grant; And for this once my will shall stand for law.

src: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?
trg: Your highness told me I should post before.

src: No, I'll die here. There's some among you have beheld me fighting: Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me.
trg: Down with that sword! Tribunes, withdraw awhile.

src: Villain, I say, knock me here soundly.
trg: Knock you here, sir! why, sir, what am I, sir, that I should knock you here, sir?

src: Who calls so loud?
trg: Come hither, man. I see that thou art poor: Hold, there is forty ducats:

src: Ah, Juliet, I already know thy grief; It strains me past the compass of my wits: I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it, On Thursday next be married to this county.
trg: Tell me not, friar, that thou hear'st of this, Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it:

src: Stirr'd up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Ely, He makes for England, there to claim the crown.
trg: Is the chair empty? is the sword unsway'd? Is the king dead? the empire unpossess'd? What heir of York is there alive but we? And who is England's king but great York's heir?

src: Should all despair That have revolted wives, the tenth of mankind Would hang themselves. Physic for't there is none; It is a bawdy planet, that will strike Where 'tis predominant;
trg: and 'tis powerful, think it, From east, west, north and south: be it concluded, No barricado for a belly; know't; It will let in and out the enemy With bag and baggage:

src: Pray, Master Barnardine, awake till you are executed, and sleep afterwards.
trg: Go in to him, and fetch him out.

src: Farewell, thou woful welcomer of glory!
trg: Adieu, poor soul, that takest thy leave of it!

src: Poor Clifford! how I scorn his worthless threats!
trg: Will you we show our title to the crown? If not, our swords shall plead it in the field.

src: My love and fear glued many friends to thee; And, now I fall, thy tough commixture melts. Impairing Henry, strengthening misproud York, The common people swarm like summer flies;
trg: And whither fly the gnats but to the sun? And who shines now but Henry's enemies?

src: Tut, I am strong-framed, he cannot prevail with me, I warrant thee.
trg: Spoke like a tail fellow that respects his reputation. Come, shall we to this gear?

src: All places yield to him ere he sits down; And the nobility of Rome are his: The senators and patricians love him too: The tribunes are no soldiers;
trg: and their people Will be as rash in the repeal, as hasty To expel him thence. I think he'll be to Rome As is the osprey to the fish, who takes it By sovereignty of nature.

src: Glad am I that your highness is so arm'd To bear the tidings of calamity. White-beards have arm'd their thin and hairless scalps Against thy majesty;
trg: boys, with women's voices, Strive to speak big and clap their female joints In stiff unwieldy arms against thy crown: The very beadsmen learn to bend their bows Of double-fatal yew against thy state;

src: To save her life, I'll say she is not so.
trg: Her life is only safest in her birth.

src: Slander to the state! Away with him to prison!
trg: What can you vouch against him, Signior Lucio? Is this the man that you did tell us of?

src: I know not.
trg: Go ask his name: if he be married. My grave is like to be my wedding bed.

src: Plantagenet shall speak first: hear him, lords; And be you silent and attentive too, For he that interrupts him shall not live.
trg: Think'st thou that I will leave my kingly throne, Wherein my grandsire and my father sat? No: first shall war unpeople this my realm;

src: We shall entreat you to abide here till he come and enforce them against him: we shall find this friar a notable fellow.
trg: As any in Vienna, on my word.

src: Husband, let's follow, to see the end of this ado.
trg: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

src: Do then: but I'll not hear.
trg: I will be mild and gentle in my speech.

src: Why, he is so made on here within, as if he were son and heir to Mars; set at upper end o' the table; no question asked him by any of the senators, but they stand bald before him:
trg: our general himself makes a mistress of him: sanctifies himself with's hand and turns up the white o' the eye to his discourse.

src: Thou pitied'st Rutland; I will pity thee.
trg: Where's Captain Margaret, to fence you now?

src: But if I could, by Him that gave me life, I would attach you all and make you stoop Unto the sovereign mercy of the king; But since I cannot, be it known to you I do remain as neuter.
trg: So, fare you well; Unless you please to enter in the castle And there repose you for this night.

src: here is more matter for a hot brain: every lane's end, every shop, church, session, hanging, yields a careful man work.
trg: See, see; what a man you are now! There is no other way but to tell the king she's a changeling and none of your flesh and blood.

src: Fiend, thou torment'st me ere I come to hell!
trg: Urge it no more, my Lord Northumberland.

src: Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.
trg: Do, good old grandsire; and withal make known Which way thou travellest: if along with us, We shall be joyful of thy company.

src: So had you need. In brief, sir, sith it your pleasure is, And I am tied to be obedient;
trg: For so your father charged me at our parting, 'Be serviceable to my son,' quoth he, Although I think 'twas in another sense; I am content to be Lucentio, Because so well I love Lucentio.

src: A good swift simile, but something currish.
trg: 'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself: 'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.

src: I would thou hadst done so by Claudio. Go fetch him hither; let me look upon him.
trg: I am sorry, one so learned and so wise As you, Lord Angelo, have still appear'd, Should slip so grossly, both in the heat of blood. And lack of temper'd judgment afterward.

src: Perpetual durance?
trg: Ay, just; perpetual durance, a restraint, Though all the world's vastidity you had, To a determined scope.

src: Thou art like one of those fellows that when he enters the confines of a tavern claps me his sword upon the table and says 'God send me no need of thee!
trg: ' and by the operation of the second cup draws it on the drawer, when indeed there is no need.

src: O Phoebus, hadst thou never given consent That Phaethon should cheque thy fiery steeds, Thy burning car never had scorch'd the earth!
trg: And, Henry, hadst thou sway'd as kings should do, Or as thy father and his father did, Giving no ground unto the house of York, They never then had sprung like summer flies;

src: Direct me, if it be your will, Where great Aufidius lies: is he in Antium?
trg: He is, and feasts the nobles of the state At his house this night.

src: As surely as I live, my lord.
trg: Sweet peace conduct his sweet soul to the bosom Of good old Abraham! Lords appellants, Your differences shall all rest under gage Till we assign you to your days of trial.

src: Prithee bring him in; and let him approach singing.
trg: Forewarn him that he use no scurrilous words in 's tunes.

src: Speak, speak.
trg: You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

src: Thy father was a traitor to the crown.
trg: Exeter, thou art a traitor to the crown In following this usurping Henry.

src: I thank your worship. For mine own part, I never come into any room in a tap-house, but I am drawn in.
trg: Well, no more of it, Master Froth: farewell. Come you hither to me, Master tapster. What's your name, Master tapster?

src: Ay, my good lord.
trg: I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders Ere I will see the crown so foul misplaced. But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?

src: Mine innocency and Saint George to thrive!
trg: However God or fortune cast my lot, There lives or dies, true to King Richard's throne, A loyal, just and upright gentleman:

src: I know not: but I am sure 'tis safer to Avoid what's grown than question how 'tis born.
trg: If therefore you dare trust my honesty, That lies enclosed in this trunk which you Shall bear along impawn'd, away to-night!

src: By the woman's means?
trg: Ay, sir, by Mistress Overdone's means: but as she spit in his face, so she defied him.

src: What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel? And soothe the devil that I warn thee from?
trg: O, but remember this another day, When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow, And say poor Margaret was a prophetess!

src: Do, good old grandsire; and withal make known Which way thou travellest: if along with us, We shall be joyful of thy company.
trg: Fair sir, and you my merry mistress, That with your strange encounter much amazed me, My name is call'd Vincentio; my dwelling Pisa; And bound I am to Padua;

src: Camillo was his help in this, his pander: There is a plot against my life, my crown; All's true that is mistrusted: that false villain Whom I employ'd was pre-employ'd by him:
trg: He has discover'd my design, and I Remain a pinch'd thing; yea, a very trick For them to play at will. How came the posterns So easily open?

src: Now, by Saint Paul, this news is bad indeed. O, he hath kept an evil diet long, And overmuch consumed his royal person: 'Tis very grievous to be thought upon. What, is he in his bed?
trg: He is.

src: the tender prince Would fain have come with me to meet your grace, But by his mother was perforce withheld.
trg: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course Is this of hers! Lord cardinal, will your grace Persuade the queen to send the Duke of York Unto his princely brother presently?

src: I take thee at thy word: Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized; Henceforth I never will be Romeo.
trg: What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night So stumblest on my counsel?

src: who being so heighten'd, He water'd his new plants with dews of flattery, Seducing so my friends; and, to this end, He bow'd his nature, never known before But to be rough, unswayable and free.
trg: Sir, his stoutness When he did stand for consul, which he lost By lack of stooping,--

src: Do you hear, ho? you must meet my master to countenance my mistress.
trg: Why, she hath a face of her own.

src: Pray you now, buy it.
trg: Come on, lay it by: and let's first see moe ballads; we'll buy the other things anon.

src: I have no more sons of the royal blood For thee to murder: for my daughters, Richard, They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens; And therefore level not to hit their lives.
trg: You have a daughter call'd Elizabeth, Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

src: alack the heavy day, That I have worn so many winters out, And know not now what name to call myself!
trg: O that I were a mockery king of snow, Standing before the sun of Bolingbroke, To melt myself away in water-drops!

src: So proud that Bolingbroke was on his back! That jade hath eat bread from my royal hand; This hand hath made him proud with clapping him. Would he not stumble?
trg: would he not fall down, Since pride must have a fall, and break the neck Of that proud man that did usurp his back? Forgiveness, horse!

src: This precious book of love, this unbound lover, To beautify him, only lacks a cover: The fish lives in the sea, and 'tis much pride For fair without the fair within to hide:
trg: That book in many's eyes doth share the glory, That in gold clasps locks in the golden story; So shall you share all that he doth possess, By having him, making yourself no less.

src: You are too hot.
trg: God's bread! it makes me mad: Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play, Alone, in company, still my care hath been To have her match'd:

src: When the devout religion of mine eye Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires; And these, who often drown'd could never die, Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!
trg: One fairer than my love! the all-seeing sun Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.

src: He has discover'd my design, and I Remain a pinch'd thing; yea, a very trick For them to play at will. How came the posterns So easily open?
trg: By his great authority; Which often hath no less prevail'd than so On your command.

src: Under the canopy.
trg: Under the canopy!

src: To what, I pray?
trg: Judge.

src: Think'st thou it honourable for a noble man Still to remember wrongs? Daughter, speak you: He cares not for your weeping. Speak thou, boy:
trg: Perhaps thy childishness will move him more Than can our reasons. There's no man in the world More bound to 's mother; yet here he lets me prate Like one i' the stocks.

src: So, the good horse is mine.
trg: I'll buy him of you.

src: To have no screen between this part he play'd And him he play'd it for, he needs will be Absolute Milan. Me, poor man, my library Was dukedom large enough:
trg: of temporal royalties He thinks me now incapable;

src: She had; and would incense me To murder her I married.
trg: I should so. Were I the ghost that walk'd, I'ld bid you mark Her eye, and tell me for what dull part in't You chose her; then I'ld shriek, that even your ears Should rift to hear me;

src: Not so hot, good sir: I come to bring him sleep. 'Tis such as you, That creep like shadows by him and do sigh At each his needless heavings, such as you Nourish the cause of his awaking:
trg: I Do come with words as medicinal as true, Honest as either, to purge him of that humour That presses him from sleep.

src: Thou hast sworn my love to be.
trg: Thou hast sworn it more to me: Then whither goest? say, whither?

src: Will you we show our title to the crown? If not, our swords shall plead it in the field.
trg: What title hast thou, traitor, to the crown? Thy father was, as thou art, Duke of York; Thy grandfather, Roger Mortimer, Earl of March:

src: so shall you stay Till you have done your business in the city: If this be courtesy, sir, accept of it.
trg: O sir, I do; and will repute you ever The patron of my life and liberty.

src: What black magician conjures up this fiend, To stop devoted charitable deeds?
trg: Villains, set down the corse; or, by Saint Paul, I'll make a corse of him that disobeys.

src: He's one honest enough: would all the rest were so!
trg: What work's, my countrymen, in hand? where go you With bats and clubs? The matter? speak, I pray you.

src: 'Tis in reversion that I do possess; But what it is, that is not yet known; what I cannot name; 'tis nameless woe, I wot.
trg: God save your majesty! and well met, gentlemen: I hope the king is not yet shipp'd for Ireland.

src: Courageous Richmond, well hast thou acquit thee. Lo, here, this long-usurped royalty From the dead temples of this bloody wretch Have I pluck'd off, to grace thy brows withal:
trg: Wear it, enjoy it, and make much of it.

src: Get you gone, and let me hear no more of you.
trg: I thank your worship. For mine own part, I never come into any room in a tap-house, but I am drawn in.

src: There's time enough for that; Lest they desire upon this push to trouble Your joys with like relation. Go together, You precious winners all; your exultation Partake to every one.
trg: I, an old turtle, Will wing me to some wither'd bough and there My mate, that's never to be found again, Lament till I am lost.

src: Ay, my lord: and fear We have landed in ill time: the skies look grimly And threaten present blusters. In my conscience, The heavens with that we have in hand are angry And frown upon 's.
trg: Their sacred wills be done! Go, get aboard; Look to thy bark: I'll not be long before I call upon thee.

src: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste, For beauty starved with her severity Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
trg: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair, To merit bliss by making me despair: She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow Do I live dead that live to tell it now.

src: which though it be great pity, yet it is necessary. An old sheep-whistling rogue a ram-tender, to offer to have his daughter come into grace! Some say he shall be stoned;
trg: but that death is too soft for him, say I draw our throne into a sheep-cote! all deaths are too few, the sharpest too easy.

src: Be patient, gentle Earl of Westmoreland.
trg: Patience is for poltroons, such as he: He durst not sit there, had your father lived. My gracious lord, here in the parliament Let us assail the family of York.

src: I can hardly believe that, since you know not what you speak. But, if ever the duke return, as our prayers are he may, let me desire you to make your answer before him.
trg: If it be honest you have spoke, you have courage to maintain it: I am bound to call upon you; and, I pray you, your name?
Be of comfort; My father's of a better nature, sir, Than he appears by speech: this is unwonted Which now came from him.

src: Fellow, give place; here is no longer stay.
trg: If thou love me, 'tis time thou wert away.

src: For curious I cannot be with you, Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.
trg: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say: Your plainness and your shortness please me well.

src: Nay,'tis true.
trg: Look, here's a letter from him: the state hath another, his wife another; and, I think, there's one at home for you.

src: Thou hast nor youth nor age, But, as it were, an after-dinner's sleep, Dreaming on both; for all thy blessed youth Becomes as aged, and doth beg the alms Of palsied eld;
trg: and when thou art old and rich, Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor beauty, To make thy riches pleasant. What's yet in this That bears the name of life?

src: Call Coriolanus.
trg: He doth appear.

src: Or more than common fear of Clifford's rigour, Who thunders to his captives blood and death, I cannot judge: but to conclude with truth, Their weapons like to lightning came and went;
trg: Our soldiers', like the night-owl's lazy flight, Or like an idle thresher with a flail, Fell gently down, as if they struck their friends.

src: And, lords, towards Coventry bend we our course Where peremptory Warwick now remains: The sun shines hot; and, if we use delay, Cold biting winter mars our hoped-for hay.
trg: Away betimes, before his forces join, And take the great-grown traitor unawares: Brave warriors, march amain towards Coventry. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: Well, do not swear: although I joy in thee, I have no joy of this contract to-night: It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden;
trg: Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be Ere one can say 'It lightens.' Sweet, good night! This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath, May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.

src: Go, you cot-quean, go, Get you to bed; faith, You'll be sick to-morrow For this night's watching.
trg: No, not a whit: what! I have watch'd ere now All night for lesser cause, and ne'er been sick.

src: We shall be shorten'd in our aim, which was To take in many towns ere almost Rome Should know we were afoot.
trg: Noble Aufidius, Take your commission; hie you to your bands: Let us alone to guard Corioli: If they set down before 's, for the remove Bring your army;

src: Why, that was when Three crabbed months had sour'd themselves to death, Ere I could make thee open thy white hand And clap thyself my love: then didst thou utter 'I am yours for ever.'
trg: 'Tis grace indeed. Why, lo you now, I have spoke to the purpose twice: The one for ever earn'd a royal husband; The other for some while a friend.

src: And yet not so, for what can we bequeath Save our deposed bodies to the ground?
trg: Our lands, our lives and all are Bolingbroke's, And nothing can we call our own but death And that small model of the barren earth Which serves as paste and cover to our bones.

src: My lord, this argues conscience in your grace; But the respects thereof are nice and trivial, All circumstances well considered. You say that Edward is your brother's son:
trg: So say we too, but not by Edward's wife;

src: All this divided York and Lancaster, Divided in their dire division, O, now, let Richmond and Elizabeth, The true succeeders of each royal house, By God's fair ordinance conjoin together!
trg: And let their heirs, God, if thy will be so. Enrich the time to come with smooth-faced peace, With smiling plenty and fair prosperous days!

src: I mean, thy general.
trg: My general cares not for you. Back, I say, go; lest I let forth your half-pint of blood; back,--that's the utmost of your having: back.

src: underneath whose arm An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled;
trg: But by and by comes back to Romeo, Who had but newly entertain'd revenge, And to 't they go like lightning, for, ere I Could draw to part them, was stout Tybalt slain.

src: I will not fail: 'tis twenty years till then. I have forgot why I did call thee back.
trg: Let me stand here till thou remember it.

src: and he is a motion generative; that's infallible.
trg: You are pleasant, sir, and speak apace.

src: Upon mine honour, thou shalt marry her. Thy slanders I forgive; and therewithal Remit thy other forfeits. Take him to prison; And see our pleasure herein executed.
trg: Marrying a punk, my lord, is pressing to death, whipping, and hanging.

src: This other doth command a little door Which from the vineyard to the garden leads; There have I made my promise Upon the heavy middle of the night To call upon him.
trg: But shall you on your knowledge find this way?

src: Might there not be a charity in sin To save this brother's life?
trg: Please you to do't, I'll take it as a peril to my soul, It is no sin at all, but charity.

src: Hie thee to hell for shame, and leave the world, Thou cacodemon! there thy kingdom is.
trg: My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days Which here you urge to prove us enemies, We follow'd then our lord, our lawful king: So should we you, if you should be our king.

src: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.
trg: You are i' the right, sir: 'tis for my mistress.

src: Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian; Speak and look back, and pry on every side, Tremble and start at wagging of a straw, Intending deep suspicion:
trg: ghastly looks Are at my service, like enforced smiles; And both are ready in their offices, At any time, to grace my stratagems. But what, is Catesby gone?

src: your heart is up, I know, Thus high at least, although your knee be low.
trg: My gracious lord, I come but for mine own.

src: Aiming, belike, at your interior hatred, Which in your outward actions shows itself Against my kindred, brothers, and myself, Makes him to send;
trg: that thereby he may gather The ground of your ill-will, and so remove it.

src: To teach you gamut in a briefer sort, More pleasant, pithy and effectual, Than hath been taught by any of my trade: And there it is in writing, fairly drawn.
trg: Why, I am past my gamut long ago.

src: Who's yonder, That does appear as he were flay'd? O gods He has the stamp of Marcius; and I have Before-time seen him thus.
He hath ribbons of an the colours i' the rainbow; points more than all the lawyers in Bohemia can learnedly handle, though they come to him by the gross: inkles, caddisses, cambrics, lawns:
trg: why, he sings 'em over as they were gods or goddesses; you would think a smock were a she-angel, he so chants to the sleeve-hand and the work about the square on't.

src: Me too, let me go thither.
trg: Or thou goest to the orange or mill.

src: Come, come, my boy; we will to sanctuary. Madam, farewell.
trg: I'll go along with you.

src: Right.
trg: It may be right; but you are i' the wrong To speak before your time. Proceed.

src: Faith, none, but Humphrey Hour, that call'd your grace To breakfast once forth of my company. If I be so disgracious in your sight, Let me march on, and not offend your grace. Strike the drum.
trg: I prithee, hear me speak.

src: Which, too much minded by herself alone, May be put from her by society: Now do you know the reason of this haste.
O, were it but my life, I'ld throw it down for your deliverance As frankly as a pin.
trg: Thanks, dear Isabel.

src: your dishonour Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state Of that integrity which should become't, Not having the power to do the good it would, For the in which doth control't.
trg: Has said enough.

src: Well, my lord.
trg: This is no witness for Lord Angelo.

src: then true noblesse would Learn him forbearance from so foul a wrong. What subject can give sentence on his king? And who sits here that is not Richard's subject?
trg: Thieves are not judged but they are by to hear, Although apparent guilt be seen in them;

src: Well, come, my Kate; we will unto your father's Even in these honest mean habiliments: Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor; For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich;
trg: And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds, So honour peereth in the meanest habit. What is the jay more precious than the lark, Because his fathers are more beautiful?

src: No, like a bank for love to lie and play on; Not like a corse; or if, not to be buried, But quick and in mine arms. Come, take your flowers:
trg: Methinks I play as I have seen them do In Whitsun pastorals: sure this robe of mine Does change my disposition.

src: By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward.
trg: How far off is our brother Montague? Where is the post that came from Montague?

src: A match! 'tis done.
trg: Who shall begin?

src: but, with thy grim looks and The thunder-like percussion of thy sounds, Thou madst thine enemies shake, as if the world Were feverous and did tremble.
trg: Look, sir.

src: Well, well, I see the issue of these arms: I cannot mend it, I must needs confess, Because my power is weak and all ill left:
trg: But if I could, by Him that gave me life, I would attach you all and make you stoop Unto the sovereign mercy of the king; But since I cannot, be it known to you I do remain as neuter.

src: Ay, so we will.
trg: Tell him, when that our princely father York Bless'd his three sons with his victorious arm, And charged us from his soul to love each other, He little thought of this divided friendship:

src: Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford, Vouchsafe, at our request, to stand aside, While I use further conference with Warwick.
trg: Heavens grant that Warwick's words bewitch him not!

src: A messenger from the Lord Stanley.
trg: What is't o'clock?

src: There's some ill planet reigns: I must be patient till the heavens look With an aspect more favourable. Good my lords, I am not prone to weeping, as our sex Commonly are;
trg: the want of which vain dew Perchance shall dry your pities: but I have That honourable grief lodged here which burns Worse than tears drown:

src: Within these three hours, Tullus, Alone I fought in your Corioli walls, And made what work I pleased: 'tis not my blood Wherein thou seest me mask'd;
trg: for thy revenge Wrench up thy power to the highest.

src: Go tell the lords o' the city I am here: Deliver them this paper: having read it, Bid them repair to the market place; where I, Even in theirs and in the commons' ears, Will vouch the truth of it.
trg: Him I accuse The city ports by this hath enter'd and Intends to appear before the people, hoping To purge herself with words: dispatch. Most welcome!

src: Marry, sir, that's Claudio, Signior Claudio.
trg: Claudio to prison? 'tis not so.

src: God save your lordship!
trg: Well met, my lord; I am glad to see your honour.

src: But I fear They'll roar him in again. Tullus Aufidius, The second name of men, obeys his points As if he were his officer:
trg: desperation Is all the policy, strength and defence, That Rome can make against them.

src: No matter where; of comfort no man speak: Let's talk of graves, of worms, and epitaphs;
trg: Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes Write sorrow on the bosom of the earth, Let's choose executors and talk of wills:

src: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.
trg: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long; Meantime, have patience.

src: Banish'd this frail sepulchre of our flesh, As now our flesh is banish'd from this land: Confess thy treasons ere thou fly the realm;
trg: Since thou hast far to go, bear not along The clogging burthen of a guilty soul.
How many children hast thou, widow? tell me.

src: For, till I see them here, by doubtful fear My joy of liberty is half eclipsed.
trg: It shall be done, my sovereign, with all speed.

src: By his command Have I here touch'd Sicilia and from him Give you all greetings that a king, at friend, Can send his brother:
trg: and, but infirmity Which waits upon worn times hath something seized His wish'd ability, he had himself The lands and waters 'twixt your throne and his Measured to look upon you;

src: Buy lads, or else your lasses cry: Come buy.
trg: If I were not in love with Mopsa, thou shouldst take no money of me; but being enthralled as I am, it will also be the bondage of certain ribbons and gloves.

src: Why will you mew her up, Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell, And make her bear the penance of her tongue?
trg: Gentlemen, content ye; I am resolved: Go in, Bianca: And for I know she taketh most delight In music, instruments and poetry, Schoolmasters will I keep within my house, Fit to instruct her youth.

src: Adding withal how blest this land would be In this your cousin's death.
trg: Princes and noble lords, What answer shall I make to this base man? Shall I so much dishonour my fair stars, On equal terms to give him chastisement?

src: So with me: My birth-place hate I, and my love's upon This enemy town. I'll enter: if he slay me, He does fair justice; if he give me way, I'll do his country service.
trg: Wine, wine, wine! What service is here! I think our fellows are asleep.

src: Please you, sir, Do not omit the heavy offer of it: It seldom visits sorrow; when it doth, It is a comforter.
trg: We two, my lord, Will guard your person while you take your rest, And watch your safety.

src: Last night, I hear, they lay at Northampton; At Stony-Stratford will they be to-night: To-morrow, or next day, they will be here.
trg: I long with all my heart to see the prince: I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.

src: O, peace, Paulina! Thou shouldst a husband take by my consent, As I by thine a wife: this is a match, And made between's by vows. Thou hast found mine; But how, is to be question'd;
trg: for I saw her, As I thought, dead, and have in vain said many A prayer upon her grave. I'll not seek far-- For him, I partly know his mind--to find thee An honourable husband.

src: Now in good time, here comes the duke himself.
trg: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow. I have been long a sleeper; but, I hope, My absence doth neglect no great designs, Which by my presence might have been concluded.

src: this we came not to, Only for propagation of a dower Remaining in the coffer of her friends, From whom we thought it meet to hide our love Till time had made them for us.
trg: But it chances The stealth of our most mutual entertainment With character too gross is writ on Juliet.

src: See you yond coign o' the Capitol, yond corner-stone?
trg: Why, what of that?

src: I long till Edward fall by war's mischance, For mocking marriage with a dame of France.
trg: I came from Edward as ambassador, But I return his sworn and mortal foe: Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me, But dreadful war shall answer his demand.

src: Apprehend Nothing but jollity. The gods themselves, Humbling their deities to love, have taken The shapes of beasts upon them: Jupiter Became a bull, and bellow'd;
trg: the green Neptune A ram, and bleated; and the fire-robed god, Golden Apollo, a poor humble swain, As I seem now.

src: sometimes am I king; Then treasons make me wish myself a beggar, And so I am: then crushing penury Persuades me I was better when a king; Then am I king'd again:
trg: and by and by Think that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke, And straight am nothing:

src: What hast thou found?
trg: No hare, sir; unless a hare, sir, in a lenten pie, that is something stale and hoar ere it be spent.

src: Go, girl; I cannot blame thee now to weep; For such an injury would vex a very saint, Much more a shrew of thy impatient humour.
trg: Master, master! news, old news, and such news as you never heard of!

src: Now welcome more, and ten times more beloved, Than if thou never hadst deserved our hate.
trg: Welcome, good Clarence; this is brotherlike.

src: Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out In sharing that which you have pill'd from me! Which of you trembles not that looks on me?
trg: If not, that, I being queen, you bow like subjects, Yet that, by you deposed, you quake like rebels? O gentle villain, do not turn away!

src: on the topmast, The yards and bowsprit, would I flame distinctly, Then meet and join. Jove's lightnings, the precursors O' the dreadful thunder-claps, more momentary And sight-outrunning were not;
trg: the fire and cracks Of sulphurous roaring the most mighty Neptune Seem to besiege and make his bold waves tremble, Yea, his dread trident shake.
That is, because the traitor murderer lives.

src: Give me your hand, And let the subject see, to make them know That outward courtesies would fain proclaim Favours that keep within. Come, Escalus, You must walk by us on our other hand;
trg: And good supporters are you.

src: This boy, that cannot tell what he would have But kneels and holds up bands for fellowship, Does reason our petition with more strength Than thou hast to deny 't. Come, let us go:
trg: This fellow had a Volscian to his mother; His wife is in Corioli and his child Like him by chance. Yet give us our dispatch: I am hush'd until our city be a-fire, And then I'll speak a little.

src: The ground indeed is tawny.
trg: With an eye of green in't.

src: He is both king and Duke of Lancaster; And that the Lord of Westmoreland shall maintain.
trg: And Warwick shall disprove it. You forget That we are those which chased you from the field And slew your fathers, and with colours spread March'd through the city to the palace gates.

src: It is yours; And, might we lay the old proverb to your charge, So like you, 'tis the worse.
trg: A gross hag And, lozel, thou art worthy to be hang'd, That wilt not stay her tongue.

src: in the instant came The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared, Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears, He swung about his head and cut the winds, Who nothing hurt withal hiss'd him in scorn:
trg: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows, Came more and more and fought on part and part, Till the prince came, who parted either part.

src: And what said the gallant?
trg: His answer was, he would unto the stews, And from the common'st creature pluck a glove, And wear it as a favour; and with that He would unhorse the lustiest challenger.

src: If you would seek us, We are yours i' the garden: shall's attend you there?
trg: To your own bents dispose you: you'll be found, Be you beneath the sky. I am angling now, Though you perceive me not how I give line. Go to, go to! How she holds up the neb, the bill to him!
What say you, uncle?

src: What, master, read you? first resolve me that.
trg: I read that I profess, the Art to Love.

src: O, no! thou diest, though I the sicker be.
trg: I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.

src: Yes, in good sooth, the vice is of a great kindred; it is well allied: but it is impossible to extirp it quite, friar, till eating and drinking be put down.
trg: They say this Angelo was not made by man and woman after this downright way of creation: is it true, think you?

src: Apollo be my judge!
trg: This your request Is altogether just: therefore bring forth, And in Apollos name, his oracle.

src: Go to; let that be mine: Do you your office, or give up your place, And you shall well be spared.
trg: I crave your honour's pardon. What shall be done, sir, with the groaning Juliet? She's very near her hour.

src: A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears, And harsh in sound to thine.
trg: Say, what's thy name? Thou hast a grim appearance, and thy face Bears a command in't; though thy tackle's torn. Thou show'st a noble vessel: what's thy name?

src: Did you such a thing?
trg: Yes, marry, did I but I was fain to forswear it; they would else have married me to the rotten medlar.

src: Resume that spirit, when you were wont to say, If you had been the wife of Hercules, Six of his labours you'ld have done, and saved Your husband so much sweat. Cominius, Droop not; adieu.
trg: Farewell, my wife, my mother: I'll do well yet. Thou old and true Menenius, Thy tears are salter than a younger man's, And venomous to thine eyes.

src: You souls of geese, That bear the shapes of men, how have you run From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell! All hurt behind; backs red, and faces pale With flight and agued fear!
trg: Mend and charge home, Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave the foe And make my wars on you: look to't: come on;

src: No; it is stopp'd with other flattering sounds, As praises, of whose taste the wise are fond, Lascivious metres, to whose venom sound The open ear of youth doth always listen;
trg: Report of fashions in proud Italy, Whose manners still our tardy apish nation Limps after in base imitation.

src: A blessed labour, my most sovereign liege: Amongst this princely heap, if any here, By false intelligence, or wrong surmise, Hold me a foe;
trg: If I unwittingly, or in my rage, Have aught committed that is hardly borne By any in this presence, I desire To reconcile me to his friendly peace: 'Tis death to me to be at enmity;

src: Now old desire doth in his death-bed lie, And young affection gapes to be his heir; That fair for which love groan'd for and would die, With tender Juliet match'd, is now not fair.
trg: Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike betwitched by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love's sweet bait from fearful hooks:

src: Well, I say no: and therefore for assurance Let's each one send unto his wife; And he whose wife is most obedient To come at first when he doth send for her, Shall win the wager which we will propose.
trg: Content. What is the wager?

src: Vouchsafe, defused infection of a man, For these known evils, but to give me leave, By circumstance, to curse thy cursed self.
trg: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have Some patient leisure to excuse myself.

src: Then Clarence is at hand, I hear his drum.
trg: It is not his, my lord; here Southam lies: The drum your honour hears marcheth from Warwick.

src: My lords, forbear this talk; here comes the king.
trg: And his well-chosen bride.

src: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?
trg: You shall, my lord.

src: poor wretch, That for thy mother's fault art thus exposed To loss and what may follow! Weep I cannot, But my heart bleeds; and most accursed am I To be by oath enjoin'd to this. Farewell!
trg: The day frowns more and more: thou'rt like to have A lullaby too rough: I never saw The heavens so dim by day. A savage clamour! Well may I get aboard! This is the chase: I am gone for ever.

src: That would I learn of you, As one that are best acquainted with her humour.
trg: And wilt thou learn of me?

src: and they follow him, Against us brats, with no less confidence Than boys pursuing summer butterflies, Or butchers killing flies.
trg: You have made good work, You and your apron-men; you that stood so up much on the voice of occupation and The breath of garlic-eaters!

src: Rich men look sad and ruffians dance and leap, The one in fear to lose what they enjoy, The other to enjoy by rage and war: These signs forerun the death or fall of kings. Farewell:
trg: our countrymen are gone and fled, As well assured Richard their king is dead.

src: No, wrangling woman, we'll no longer stay: These words will cost ten thousand lives this day. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Forspent with toil, as runners with a race, I lay me down a little while to breathe;

src: Did my heart love till now? forswear it, sight! For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.
trg: This, by his voice, should be a Montague. Fetch me my rapier, boy. What dares the slave Come hither, cover'd with an antic face, To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?

src: At Antium lives he?
trg: At Antium.

src: The son of Clarence have I pent up close; His daughter meanly have I match'd in marriage; The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom, And Anne my wife hath bid the world good night.
trg: Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter, And, by that knot, looks proudly o'er the crown, To her I go, a jolly thriving wooer.

src: Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue!
trg: I prithee, spare.

src: Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?
trg: He had, my lord; and that it was which caused Our swifter composition.

src: Why, 'tis good; it is the right of it; it must be so: ever your fresh whore and your powdered bawd: an unshunned consequence; it must be so. Art going to prison, Pompey?
trg: Yes, faith, sir.

src: Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead; And Paris too. Come, I'll dispose of thee Among a sisterhood of holy nuns: Stay not to question, for the watch is coming;
trg: Come, go, good Juliet, I dare no longer stay.

src: Prithee, be my present partner in this business, and lay aside the thoughts of Sicilia.
trg: I willingly obey your command.

src: Whate'er I read to her, I'll plead for you As for my patron, stand you so assured, As firmly as yourself were still in place:
trg: Yea, and perhaps with more successful words Than you, unless you were a scholar, sir.

src: Was ever gentleman thus grieved as I? But who comes here?
trg: Good morrow, neighbour Baptista.

src: Belike, some noble gentleman that means, Travelling some journey, to repose him here. How now! who is it?
trg: An't please your honour, players That offer service to your lordship.

src: No, madam; we have cull'd such necessaries As are behoveful for our state to-morrow: So please you, let me now be left alone, And let the nurse this night sit up with you;
trg: For, I am sure, you have your hands full all, In this so sudden business.
To save your life in this extremity, This favour will I do you for his sake; And think it not the worst of an your fortunes That you are like to Sir Vincentio.

src: Not I, my lord.
trg: Then he disdains to shine; for by the book He should have braved the east an hour ago A black day will it be to somebody. Ratcliff!

src: But how prevail'd you?
trg: Will the time serve to tell? I do not think. Where is the enemy? are you lords o' the field? If not, why cease you till you are so?

src: Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile, And cry 'Content' to that which grieves my heart, And wet my cheeks with artificial tears, And frame my face to all occasions.
trg: I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall; I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk;

src: fortune's blows, When most struck home, being gentle wounded, craves A noble cunning: you were used to load me With precepts that would make invincible The heart that conn'd them.
trg: O heavens! O heavens!

src: Here comes a man; let's stay till he be past.
trg: From Scotland am I stol'n, even of pure love, To greet mine own land with my wishful sight. No, Harry, Harry, 'tis no land of thine;

src: Who else? what, Paris too? And steep'd in blood? Ah, what an unkind hour Is guilty of this lamentable chance! The lady stirs.
trg: O comfortable friar! where is my lord? I do remember well where I should be, And there I am. Where is my Romeo?

src: Bishop, farewell: shield thee from Warwick's frown; And pray that I may repossess the crown. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Subjects may challenge nothing of their sovereigns; But if an humble prayer may prevail, I then crave pardon of your majesty.

src: Shall we hear from thee, Tyrrel, ere we sleep?
trg: Ye shall, my Lord.

src: Knock there, and ask your heart what it doth know That's like my brother's fault:
trg: if it confess A natural guiltiness such as is his, Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue Against my brother's life.

src: Madam, 'tis now in tune.
trg: All but the base.

src: Enough, my lord.
trg: My lord, I must confess I know this woman: And five years since there was some speech of marriage Betwixt myself and her;

src: This is All-Souls' day, fellows, is it not?
trg: It is, my lord.

src: What, sovereign sir, I did not well I meant well. All my services You have paid home:
trg: O Paulina, We honour you with trouble: but we came To see the statue of our queen: your gallery Have we pass'd through, not without much content In many singularities;

src: Say, where, when, and how, Camest thou by this ill tidings? speak, thou wretch.
trg: Pardon me, madam: little joy have I To breathe this news; yet what I say is true. King Richard, he is in the mighty hold Of Bolingbroke: their fortunes both are weigh'd:

src: And if thou tell'st the heavy story right, Upon my soul, the hearers will shed tears; Yea even my foes will shed fast-falling tears, And say 'Alas, it was a piteous deed!
trg: ' There, take the crown, and, with the crown, my curse; And in thy need such comfort come to thee As now I reap at thy too cruel hand! Hard-hearted Clifford, take me from the world:

src: Thoughts tending to content flatter themselves That they are not the first of fortune's slaves, Nor shall not be the last;
trg: like silly beggars Who sitting in the stocks refuge their shame, That many have and others must sit there;
