src: With love's light wings did I o'er-perch these walls; For stony limits cannot hold love out, And what love can do that dares love attempt; Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me.
trg: If they do see thee, they will murder thee.

src: What is the city but the people?
trg: True, The people are the city.

src: I call them forth to credit her.
trg: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.

src: Three times to-day my foot-cloth horse did stumble, And startled, when he look'd upon the Tower, As loath to bear me to the slaughter-house. O, now I want the priest that spake to me:
trg: I now repent I told the pursuivant As 'twere triumphing at mine enemies, How they at Pomfret bloodily were butcher'd, And I myself secure in grace and favour.

src: Only make trial what your love can do For Rome, towards Marcius.
trg: Well, and say that Marcius Return me, as Cominius is return'd, Unheard; what then? But as a discontented friend, grief-shot With his unkindness? say't be so?

src: That we were all, as some would seem to be, From our faults, as faults from seeming, free!
trg: His neck will come to your waist,--a cord, sir.

src: Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley; Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt, And Rice ap Thomas with a valiant crew;
trg: And many more of noble fame and worth: And towards London they do bend their course, If by the way they be not fought withal.

src: Peter, stay at the gate.
trg: Now, good sweet nurse,--O Lord, why look'st thou sad? Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily; If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news By playing it to me with so sour a face.

src: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?
trg: I think she'll sooner prove a soldier Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.

src: Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster, There to be crowned Richard's royal queen.
trg: O, cut my lace in sunder, that my pent heart May have some scope to beat, or else I swoon With this dead-killing news!

src: And reason too: Who should succeed the father but the son?
trg: Are you there, butcher? O, I cannot speak!

src: Peace, master marquess, you are malapert: Your fire-new stamp of honour is scarce current. O, that your young nobility could judge What 'twere to lose it, and be miserable!
trg: They that stand high have many blasts to shake them; And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.

src: I dare be sworn you were: And, sir, it is no little thing to make Mine eyes to sweat compassion. But, good sir, What peace you'll make, advise me: for my part, I'll not to Rome, I'll back with you;
trg: and pray you, Stand to me in this cause. O mother! wife!

src: Is dead.
trg: Apollo's angry; and the heavens themselves Do strike at my injustice. How now there!

src: With all the gracious utterance thou hast Speak to his gentle hearing kind commends. We do debase ourselves, cousin, do we not, To look so poorly and to speak so fair?
trg: Shall we call back Northumberland, and send Defiance to the traitor, and so die?

src: My lord.
trg: Of government the properties to unfold, Would seem in me to affect speech and discourse;

src: The widow likes it not, for she looks very sad.
trg: You'll think it strange if I should marry her.

src: I'll be hanged first: thou art deceived in me, friar. But no more of this. Canst thou tell if Claudio die to-morrow or no?
trg: Why should he die, sir?

src: But come, let us in, To comfort Edward with our company.
trg: We wait upon your grace.

src: That common chances common men could bear; That when the sea was calm all boats alike Show'd mastership in floating;
trg: fortune's blows, When most struck home, being gentle wounded, craves A noble cunning: you were used to load me With precepts that would make invincible The heart that conn'd them.

src: Because, my lord, we would have had you heard The traitor speak, and timorously confess The manner and the purpose of his treason;
trg: That you might well have signified the same Unto the citizens, who haply may Misconstrue us in him and wail his death.

src: Now, messenger, what letters or what news From France?
trg: My sovereign liege, no letters; and few words, But such as I, without your special pardon, Dare not relate.

src: To tear with thunder the wide cheeks o' the air, And yet to charge thy sulphur with a bolt That should but rive an oak. Why dost not speak?
trg: Think'st thou it honourable for a noble man Still to remember wrongs? Daughter, speak you: He cares not for your weeping. Speak thou, boy:

src: I spy comfort; I cry bail. Here's a gentleman and a friend of mine.
trg: How now, noble Pompey! What, at the wheels of Caesar? art thou led in triumph?

src: O my poor father! The heaven sets spies upon us, will not have Our contract celebrated.
trg: You are married?

src: I would not be a stander-by to hear My sovereign mistress clouded so, without My present vengeance taken: 'shrew my heart, You never spoke what did become you less Than this;
trg: which to reiterate were sin As deep as that, though true.

src: Where is that slave Which told me they had beat you to your trenches? Where is he? call him hither.
trg: Let him alone; He did inform the truth: but for our gentlemen, The common file--a plague! tribunes for them!-- The mouse ne'er shunn'd the cat as they did budge From rascals worse than they.

src: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.
trg: It would seem strange unto him when he waked.

src: Nor night nor day no rest: it is but weakness To bear the matter thus; mere weakness. If The cause were not in being,--part o' the cause, She the adulteress;
trg: for the harlot king Is quite beyond mine arm, out of the blank And level of my brain, plot-proof; but she I can hook to me:

src: Having no other reason But that his beard grew thin and hungerly And seem'd to ask him sops as he was drinking.
trg: This done, he took the bride about the neck And kiss'd her lips with such a clamorous smack That at the parting all the church did echo: And I seeing this came thence for very shame;

src: The duty that I owe unto your majesty I seal upon the lips of this sweet babe.
trg: Thanks, noble Clarence; worthy brother, thanks.

src: So many miseries have crazed my voice, That my woe-wearied tongue is mute and dumb, Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?
trg: Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet. Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.

src: We know your drift: speak what?
trg: There's no more to be said, but he is banish'd, As enemy to the people and his country: It shall be so.

src: But do you hear, sir? have you married my daughter without asking my good will?
trg: Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: but I will in, to be revenged for this villany.

src: Well, well, no more of that.
trg: Though there the people had more absolute power, I say, they nourish'd disobedience, fed The ruin of the state.

src: So smooth he daub'd his vice with show of virtue, That, his apparent open guilt omitted, I mean, his conversation with Shore's wife, He lived from all attainder of suspect.
trg: Well, well, he was the covert'st shelter'd traitor That ever lived.

src: There will we mount, and thither walk on foot Let's see; I think 'tis now some seven o'clock, And well we may come there by dinner-time.
trg: I dare assure you, sir, 'tis almost two; And 'twill be supper-time ere you come there.

src: thou need'st not to be gone.
trg: Let me be ta'en, let me be put to death; I am content, so thou wilt have it so. I'll say yon grey is not the morning's eye, 'Tis but the pale reflex of Cynthia's brow;

src: Very nobly Have you deserved: it is my father's music To speak your deeds, not little of his care To have them recompensed as thought on.
trg: Well, my lord, If you may please to think I love the king And through him what is nearest to him, which is Your gracious self, embrace but my direction:

src: You'll see your Rome embraced with fire before You'll speak with Coriolanus.
trg: Good my friends, If you have heard your general talk of Rome, And of his friends there, it is lots to blanks, My name hath touch'd your ears it is Menenius.

src: Thou attend'st not.
trg: O, good sir, I do.

src: Bring forth that fatal screech-owl to our house, That nothing sung but death to us and ours: Now death shall stop his dismal threatening sound, And his ill-boding tongue no more shall speak.
trg: I think his understanding is bereft. Speak, Clifford, dost thou know who speaks to thee? Dark cloudy death o'ershades his beams of life, And he nor sees nor hears us what we say.

src: Happily You something know; yet I believe there comes No countermand; no such example have we: Besides, upon the very siege of justice Lord Angelo hath to the public ear Profess'd the contrary.
trg: This is his lordship's man.

src: Tush, man, abodements must not now affright us: By fair or foul means we must enter in, For hither will our friends repair to us.
trg: My liege, I'll knock once more to summon them.

src: Ay, worthy Menenius; and with most prosperous approbation.
trg: Take my cap, Jupiter, and I thank thee. Hoo! Marcius coming home!

src: I ne'er heard yet That any of these bolder vices wanted Less impudence to gainsay what they did Than to perform it first.
trg: That's true enough; Through 'tis a saying, sir, not due to me.

src: What an arm he has! he turned me about with his finger and his thumb, as one would set up a top.
trg: Nay, I knew by his face that there was something in him: he had, sir, a kind of face, methought,--I cannot tell how to term it.

src: 'Tis nothing less: conceit is still derived From some forefather grief; mine is not so, For nothing had begot my something grief; Or something hath the nothing that I grieve:
trg: 'Tis in reversion that I do possess; But what it is, that is not yet known; what I cannot name; 'tis nameless woe, I wot.

src: Fellow Grumio!
trg: How now, old lad?

src: Why, such is love's transgression. Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast, Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest With more of thine:
trg: this love that thou hast shown Doth add more grief to too much of mine own. Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs; Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes;

src: Go with me to the vault.
trg: I dare not, sir My master knows not but I am gone hence; And fearfully did menace me with death, If I did stay to look on his intents.

src: No cock of mine; you crow too like a craven.
trg: Nay, come, Kate, come; you must not look so sour.

src: Who will believe thee, Isabel?
trg: My unsoil'd name, the austereness of my life, My vouch against you, and my place i' the state, Will so your accusation overweigh, That you shall stifle in your own report And smell of calumny.

src: What, will the aspiring blood of Lancaster Sink in the ground? I thought it would have mounted. See how my sword weeps for the poor king's death!
trg: O, may such purple tears be alway shed From those that wish the downfall of our house! If any spark of life be yet remaining, Down, down to hell; and say I sent thee thither:

src: I swear--
trg: By nothing; for this is no oath: The George, profaned, hath lost his holy honour; The garter, blemish'd, pawn'd his knightly virtue; The crown, usurp'd, disgraced his kingly glory.

src: Here's Lucentio, Right son to the right Vincentio; That have by marriage made thy daughter mine, While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.
trg: Here's packing, with a witness to deceive us all!

src: And what to?
trg: Nay, an there were two such, we should have none shortly, for one would kill the other. Thou! why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more, or a hair less, in his beard, than thou hast:

src: Come, you are so full of cony-catching!
trg: Why, therefore fire; for I have caught extreme cold. Where's the cook? is supper ready, the house trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept;

src: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries That thou hast done me; therefore turn and draw.
trg: I do protest, I never injured thee, But love thee better than thou canst devise, Till thou shalt know the reason of my love:

src: Madam, we did: he desires to make atonement Betwixt the Duke of Gloucester and your brothers, And betwixt them and my lord chamberlain; And sent to warn them to his royal presence.
trg: Would all were well! but that will never be I fear our happiness is at the highest.

src: and more than so, my father, Even in the downfall of his mellow'd years, When nature brought him to the door of death? No, Warwick, no;
trg: while life upholds this arm, This arm upholds the house of Lancaster.

src: I am a feather for each wind that blows: Shall I live on to see this bastard kneel And call me father? better burn it now Than curse it then. But be it; let it live. It shall not neither.
trg: You, sir, come you hither;

src: If not, the city being but of small defence, We'll quickly rouse the traitors in the same.
trg: O, welcome, Oxford! for we want thy help.

src: I pray thee, moralize them.
trg: Then thus. Baptista is safe, talking with the deceiving father of a deceitful son.

src: I'll ha' thee burnt.
trg: I care not: It is an heretic that makes the fire, Not she which burns in't. I'll not call you tyrant;

src: For thou exist'st on many a thousand grains That issue out of dust. Happy thou art not; For what thou hast not, still thou strivest to get, And what thou hast, forget'st. Thou art not certain;
trg: For thy complexion shifts to strange effects, After the moon. If thou art rich, thou'rt poor;

src: The lion dying thrusteth forth his paw, And wounds the earth, if nothing else, with rage To be o'erpower'd;
trg: and wilt thou, pupil-like, Take thy correction mildly, kiss the rod, And fawn on rage with base humility, Which art a lion and a king of beasts?

src: This cannot anger him: 'twould anger him To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle Of some strange nature, letting it there stand Till she had laid it and conjured it down; That were some spite:
trg: my invocation Is fair and honest, and in his mistress' name I conjure only but to raise up him.

src: But, sure, I fear, we shall ne'er win him to it.
trg: Marry, God forbid his grace should say us nay!

src: And be thy wife--if any be so mad-- As miserable by the life of thee As thou hast made me by my dear lord's death!
trg: For never yet one hour in his bed Have I enjoy'd the golden dew of sleep, But have been waked by his timorous dreams. Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick;

src: A good direction, warlike sovereign. This found I on my tent this morning.
My ladies both, good day to you.
trg: Sweet madam.

src: I pray you, tell my lord and father, madam, I will not marry yet; and, when I do, I swear, It shall be Romeo, whom you know I hate, Rather than Paris. These are news indeed!
trg: Here comes your father; tell him so yourself, And see how he will take it at your hands.

src: It will not be avoided but by this. Therefore, good mother,--I must can you so-- Be the attorney of my love to her: Plead what I will be, not what I have been;
trg: Not my deserts, but what I will deserve: Urge the necessity and state of times, And be not peevish-fond in great designs.

src: It was his word: O, he would miss it rather Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him, And the desire of the nobles.
trg: I wish no better Than have him hold that purpose and to put it In execution.

src: And is it not well served in to a sweet goose?
trg: O here's a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!

src: And therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt: Gaunt am I for the grave, gaunt as a grave, Whose hollow womb inherits nought but bones.
trg: Can sick men play so nicely with their names?

src: Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this sun of York; And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
trg: Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths; Our bruised arms hung up for monuments; Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings, Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.

src: And thou, too careless patient as thou art, Commit'st thy anointed body to the cure Of those physicians that first wounded thee:
trg: A thousand flatterers sit within thy crown, Whose compass is no bigger than thy head; And yet, incaged in so small a verge, The waste is no whit lesser than thy land.

src: Her natural posture! Chide me, dear stone, that I may say indeed Thou art Hermione; or rather, thou art she In thy not chiding, for she was as tender As infancy and grace.
trg: But yet, Paulina, Hermione was not so much wrinkled, nothing So aged as this seems.

src: And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy gale Blows you to Padua here from old Verona?
trg: Such wind as scatters young men through the world, To seek their fortunes farther than at home Where small experience grows. But in a few, Signior Hortensio, thus it stands with me:

src: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.
trg: Alive, in triumph! and Mercutio slain! Away to heaven, respective lenity, And fire-eyed fury be my conduct now! Now, Tybalt, take the villain back again, That late thou gavest me;

src: And whither fly the gnats but to the sun? And who shines now but Henry's enemies?
trg: O Phoebus, hadst thou never given consent That Phaethon should cheque thy fiery steeds, Thy burning car never had scorch'd the earth!

src: Make your best haste, and go not Too far i' the land: 'tis like to be loud weather; Besides, this place is famous for the creatures Of prey that keep upon't.
trg: Go thou away: I'll follow instantly.

src: He seems to be the more noble in being fantastical: a great man, I'll warrant; I know by the picking on's teeth.
trg: The fardel there? what's i' the fardel? Wherefore that box?

src: Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.
trg: No, no, forsooth; I dare not for my life.

src: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.
trg: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words, Brags of his substance, not of ornament: They are but beggars that can count their worth;

src: O worthy duke, You bid me seek redemption of the devil: Hear me yourself; for that which I must speak Must either punish me, not being believed, Or wring redress from you. Hear me, O hear me, here!
trg: My lord, her wits, I fear me, are not firm: She hath been a suitor to me for her brother Cut off by course of justice,--

src: Go, go, up to the leads; the lord mayor knocks. Welcome my lord; I dance attendance here; I think the duke will not be spoke withal. Here comes his servant: how now, Catesby, What says he?
trg: My lord: he doth entreat your grace; To visit him to-morrow or next day: He is within, with two right reverend fathers, Divinely bent to meditation;

src: Have you not set them on?
trg: Be calm, be calm.

src: You are like to do such business.
trg: Not unlike, Each way, to better yours.

src: We are, my lord; and come to have the warrant That we may be admitted where he is.
trg: Well thought upon; I have it here about me. When you have done, repair to Crosby Place. But, sirs, be sudden in the execution, Withal obdurate, do not hear him plead;

src: He is.
trg: Go you before, and I will follow you. He cannot live, I hope; and must not die Till George be pack'd with post-horse up to heaven.

src: Thou wilt amend thy life?
trg: Ay, an it like your good worship.

src: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours; And never in my life, I do protest, Was it more precious to me than 'tis now:
trg: Think you, but that I know our state secure, I would be so triumphant as I am?

src: Note me this, good friend; Your most grave belly was deliberate, Not rash like his accusers, and thus answer'd:
trg: 'True is it, my incorporate friends,' quoth he, 'That I receive the general food at first, Which you do live upon; and fit it is, Because I am the store-house and the shop Of the whole body:

src: ' Some one be ready with a costly suit And ask him what apparel he will wear; Another tell him of his hounds and horse, And that his lady mourns at his disease: Persuade him that he hath been lunatic;
trg: And when he says he is, say that he dreams, For he is nothing but a mighty lord. This do and do it kindly, gentle sirs: It will be pastime passing excellent, If it be husbanded with modesty.

src: Why should calamity be full of words?
trg: Windy attorneys to their client woes, Airy succeeders of intestate joys, Poor breathing orators of miseries! Let them have scope: though what they do impart Help not all, yet do they ease the heart.

src: A rhyme I learn'd even now Of one I danced withal.
trg: Anon, anon! Come, let's away; the strangers all are gone.
We cannot weigh our brother with ourself: Great men may jest with saints; 'tis wit in them, But in the less foul profanation.

src: No more.
trg: Measureless liar, thou hast made my heart Too great for what contains it. Boy! O slave! Pardon me, lords, 'tis the first time that ever I was forced to scold.

src: If he be leaden, icy-cold, unwilling, Be thou so too; and so break off your talk, And give us notice of his inclination:
trg: For we to-morrow hold divided councils, Wherein thyself shalt highly be employ'd.

src: But I hear, no; they say my son of York Hath almost overta'en him in his growth.
trg: Ay, mother; but I would not have it so.

src: I may not answer.
trg: A sickness caught of me, and yet I well! I must be answer'd. how far off, how near; Which way to be prevented, if to be; If not, how best to bear it.

src: Sir, how comes't that you Have holp to make this rescue?
trg: Hear me speak: As I do know the consul's worthiness, So can I name his faults,--

src: Such pity as my rapier's point affords.
trg: I never did thee harm: why wilt thou slay me?

src: Ay, marry, am I, sir; and now 'tis plotted.
trg: I have it, Tranio.

src: She'll take the enterprise upon her, father, If you advise it.
trg: It is not my consent, But my entreaty too.

src: What then?
trg: An if he may, then am I lawful king; For Richard, in the view of many lords, Resign'd the crown to Henry the Fourth, Whose heir my father was, and I am his.

src: Her silence flouts me, and I'll be revenged.
trg: What, in my sight? Bianca, get thee in.

src: Ay, if yourself's remembrance wrong yourself.
trg: But thou didst kill my children.

src: Faith, here it is. Romeo is banish'd; and all the world to nothing, That he dares ne'er come back to challenge you; Or, if he do, it needs must be by stealth.
trg: Then, since the case so stands as now it doth, I think it best you married with the county. O, he's a lovely gentleman! Romeo's a dishclout to him:

src: Had she affections and warm youthful blood, She would be as swift in motion as a ball; My words would bandy her to my sweet love, And his to me: But old folks, many feign as they were dead;
trg: Unwieldy, slow, heavy and pale as lead. O God, she comes! O honey nurse, what news? Hast thou met with him? Send thy man away.

src: Well, and say that Marcius Return me, as Cominius is return'd, Unheard; what then? But as a discontented friend, grief-shot With his unkindness? say't be so?
trg: Yet your good will must have that thanks from Rome, after the measure As you intended well.

src: Are you mankind?
trg: Ay, fool; is that a shame? Note but this fool. Was not a man my father? Hadst thou foxship To banish him that struck more blows for Rome Than thou hast spoken words?

src: A mighty man of Pisa; by report I know him well: you are very welcome, sir, Take you the lute, and you the set of books; You shall go see your pupils presently. Holla, within!
trg: Sirrah, lead these gentlemen To my daughters; and tell them both, These are their tutors: bid them use them well. We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner.

src: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.
trg: Of all mad matches never was the like.

src: Sweet flower, with flowers thy bridal bed I strew,-- O woe! thy canopy is dust and stones;-- Which with sweet water nightly I will dew, Or, wanting that, with tears distill'd by moans:
trg: The obsequies that I for thee will keep Nightly shall be to strew thy grave and weep. The boy gives warning something doth approach.

src: Go, Bushy, to the Earl of Wiltshire straight: Bid him repair to us to Ely House To see this business. To-morrow next We will for Ireland; and 'tis time, I trow:
trg: And we create, in absence of ourself, Our uncle York lord governor of England; For he is just and always loved us well. Come on, our queen: to-morrow must we part;

src: This morning for ten thousand of your throats I'd not have given a doit. Hark, how they joy!
trg: First, the gods bless you for your tidings; next, Accept my thankfulness.

src: therefore, back to Rome, and prepare for your execution: you are condemned, our general has sworn you out of reprieve and pardon.
trg: Sirrah, if thy captain knew I were here, he would use me with estimation.

src: Well, I must do't: Away, my disposition, and possess me Some harlot's spirit!
trg: my throat of war be turn'd, Which quired with my drum, into a pipe Small as an eunuch, or the virgin voice That babies lulls asleep!

src: Ho! who's here?
trg: In God's name what are you, and how came you hither?

src: I am your free dependant.
trg: Quick, dispatch, and send the head to Angelo.

src: First, to thy sacred state wish I all happiness. The next news is, I have to London sent The heads of Oxford, Salisbury, Blunt, and Kent:
trg: The manner of their taking may appear At large discoursed in this paper here.

src: No, I'll not go: you hear what he hath said Which was sometime his general; who loved him In a most dear particular. He call'd me father: But what o' that? Go, you that banish'd him;
trg: A mile before his tent fall down, and knee The way into his mercy: nay, if he coy'd To hear Cominius speak, I'll keep at home.

src: With all my heart; and much it joys me too, To see you are become so penitent. Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.
trg: Bid me farewell.

src: Come on, my masters, each man take his stand: The king by this is set him down to sleep.
trg: What, will he not to bed?

src: Very well.
trg: Make them be strong and ready for this hint, When we shall hap to give 't them.

src: And I shall.
trg: Where dwellest thou?

src: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.
trg: Roundly replied.

src: but your loves, Thinking upon his services, took from you The apprehension of his present portance, Which most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion After the inveterate hate he bears you.
trg: Lay A fault on us, your tribunes; that we laboured, No impediment between, but that you must Cast your election on him.

src: Great king, within this coffin I present Thy buried fear: herein all breathless lies The mightiest of thy greatest enemies, Richard of Bordeaux, by me hither brought.
trg: Exton, I thank thee not; for thou hast wrought A deed of slander with thy fatal hand Upon my head and all this famous land.

src: Why 'Heart's ease?'
trg: O, musicians, because my heart itself plays 'My heart is full of woe:' O, play me some merry dump, to comfort me.

src: The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears, Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears; Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit Of an old tear that is not wash'd off yet:
trg: If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine, Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline: And art thou changed? pronounce this sentence then, Women may fall, when there's no strength in men.

src: Let no man mock me, For I will kiss her.
trg: Good my lord, forbear: The ruddiness upon her lip is wet; You'll mar it if you kiss it, stain your own With oily painting. Shall I draw the curtain?

src: No, good madam, pardon me; indeed, I will not forth.
trg: In truth, la, go with me; and I'll tell you excellent news of your husband.

src: I brought my master news of Juliet's death; And then in post he came from Mantua To this same place, to this same monument.
trg: This letter he early bid me give his father, And threatened me with death, going in the vault, I departed not and left him there.

src: But that thy face is, vizard-like, unchanging, Made impudent with use of evil deeds, I would assay, proud queen, to make thee blush.
trg: To tell thee whence thou camest, of whom derived, Were shame enough to shame thee, wert thou not shameless.

src: How like, methought, I then was to this kernel, This squash, this gentleman. Mine honest friend, Will you take eggs for money?
trg: No, my lord, I'll fight.

src: Bid them all home; he's gone, and we'll no further. The nobility are vex'd, whom we see have sided In his behalf.
trg: Now we have shown our power, Let us seem humbler after it is done Than when it was a-doing.

src: Once, sir? there was nothing done to her once.
trg: I beseech you, sir, ask him what this man did to my wife.

src: An offer, uncle, that we will accept:
trg: It may be I will go with you: but yet I'll pause; For I am loath to break our country's laws. Nor friends nor foes, to me welcome you are: Things past redress are now with me past care.

src: And, honest company, I thank you all, That have beheld me give away myself To this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife: Dine with my father, drink a health to me; For I must hence;
trg: and farewell to you all.

src: It is, my lord.
trg: Why, then All-Souls' day is my body's doomsday. This, this All-Souls' day to my fearful soul Is the determined respite of my wrongs:

src: No, Pompey.
trg: Truly, sir, in my poor opinion, they will to't then. If your worship will take order for the drabs and the knaves, you need not to fear the bawds.

src: for the gentlewoman is young; and, therefore, if you should deal double with her, truly it were an ill thing to be offered to any gentlewoman, and very weak dealing.
trg: Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress. I protest unto thee--

src: Our army's in the field We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready To answer us.
trg: Nor did you think it folly To keep your great pretences veil'd till when They needs must show themselves; which in the hatching, It seem'd, appear'd to Rome. By the discovery.

src: As I do think, to-morrow. I have provided for you: stay awhile, And you shall be conducted.
trg: Repent you, fair one, of the sin you carry?

src: Indeed, my lord, If I had thought the sight of my poor image Would thus have wrought you,--for the stone is mine-- I'ld not have show'd it.
trg: Do not draw the curtain.

src: Yes, truly; I speak not as desiring more; But rather wishing a more strict restraint Upon the sisterhood, the votarists of Saint Clare.
I do bite my thumb, sir.
trg: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

src: It is a purposed thing, and grows by plot, To curb the will of the nobility: Suffer't, and live with such as cannot rule Nor ever will be ruled.
trg: Call't not a plot: The people cry you mock'd them, and of late, When corn was given them gratis, you repined;

src: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.
trg: Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither; For he was fitter for that place than earth.

src: Soft! who comes here?
trg: Worthy Menenius Agrippa; one that hath always loved the people.

src: My lord, 'tis but begun.
trg: 'Tis a very excellent piece of work, madam lady: would 'twere done!

src: Ay, and a kind one too: Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.
trg: I hope better.

src: Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's children?
trg: I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy, And his contract by deputy in France; The insatiate greediness of his desires, And his enforcement of the city wives; His tyranny for trifles;

src: My lord, I warrant you we will play our part, As he shall think by our true diligence He is no less than what we say he is.
trg: Take him up gently and to bed with him; And each one to his office when he wakes. Sirrah, go see what trumpet 'tis that sounds:

src: Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths; Our bruised arms hung up for monuments; Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings, Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.
trg: Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front;

src: Then, since the case so stands as now it doth, I think it best you married with the county. O, he's a lovely gentleman! Romeo's a dishclout to him:
trg: an eagle, madam, Hath not so green, so quick, so fair an eye As Paris hath. Beshrew my very heart, I think you are happy in this second match, For it excels your first:

src: Brothers, you muse what chat we two have had.
trg: The widow likes it not, for she looks very sad.

src: Why, uncle, what's the matter?
trg: O my liege, Pardon me, if you please; if not, I, pleased Not to be pardon'd, am content withal. Seek you to seize and gripe into your hands The royalties and rights of banish'd Hereford?

src: What wilt thou tell her, nurse? thou dost not mark me.
trg: I will tell her, sir, that you do protest; which, as I take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.

src: One thus descended, That hath beside well in his person wrought To be set high in place, we did commend To your remembrances:
trg: but you have found, Scaling his present bearing with his past, That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke Your sudden approbation.

src: And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds, So honour peereth in the meanest habit. What is the jay more precious than the lark, Because his fathers are more beautiful?
trg: Or is the adder better than the eel, Because his painted skin contents the eye? O, no, good Kate; neither art thou the worse For this poor furniture and mean array. if thou account'st it shame.

src: and pray you, Stand to me in this cause. O mother! wife!
These were her words, utter'd with mad disdain: 'Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly, I'll wear the willow garland for his sake.'
trg: I blame not her, she could say little less; She had the wrong. But what said Henry's queen? For I have heard that she was there in place.

src: But, most of all, agreeing with the proclamation.
trg: Away! let's go learn the truth of it.

src: Henry, your sovereign, Is prisoner to the foe; his state usurp'd, His realm a slaughter-house, his subjects slain, His statutes cancell'd and his treasure spent;
trg: And yonder is the wolf that makes this spoil. You fight in justice: then, in God's name, lords, Be valiant and give signal to the fight. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: Away! we'll none on 't: here has been too much homely foolery already. I know, sir, we weary you.
trg: You weary those that refresh us: pray, let's see these four threes of herdsmen.

src: Why, thou unreverend and unhallow'd friar, Is't not enough thou hast suborn'd these women To accuse this worthy man, but, in foul mouth And in the witness of his proper ear, To call him villain?
trg: and then to glance from him To the duke himself, to tax him with injustice? Take him hence; to the rack with him! We'll touse you Joint by joint, but we will know his purpose. What 'unjust'!

src: And that's the wavering commons: for their love Lies in their purses, and whoso empties them By so much fills their hearts with deadly hate.
trg: Wherein the king stands generally condemn'd.

src: How now, my headstrong! where have you been gadding?
trg: Where I have learn'd me to repent the sin Of disobedient opposition To you and your behests, and am enjoin'd By holy Laurence to fall prostrate here, And beg your pardon: pardon, I beseech you!

src: Is there no remedy?
trg: None, but such remedy as, to save a head, To cleave a heart in twain.

src: You have deserved nobly of your country, and you have not deserved nobly.
trg: Your enigma?

src: In God's name, I'll ascend the regal throne.
trg: Marry. God forbid! Worst in this royal presence may I speak, Yet best beseeming me to speak the truth. Would God that any in this noble presence Were enough noble to be upright judge Of noble Richard!

src: I know her father, though I know not her; And he knew my deceased father well. I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her;
trg: And therefore let me be thus bold with you To give you over at this first encounter, Unless you will accompany me thither.

src: God keep all vows unbroke that swear to thee! Make me, that nothing have, with nothing grieved, And thou with all pleased, that hast all achieved!
trg: Long mayst thou live in Richard's seat to sit, And soon lie Richard in an earthly pit! God save King Harry, unking'd Richard says, And send him many years of sunshine days! What more remains?

src: Ah, that thy father had been so resolved!
trg: That you might still have worn the petticoat, And ne'er have stol'n the breech from Lancaster.

src: For raging wind blows up incessant showers, And when the rage allays, the rain begins. These tears are my sweet Rutland's obsequies:
trg: And every drop cries vengeance for his death, 'Gainst thee, fell Clifford, and thee, false Frenchwoman.

src: True! I'll be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded? God save your good worships! Marcius is coming home: he has more cause to be proud. Where is he wounded?
trg: I' the shoulder and i' the left arm there will be large cicatrices to show the people, when he shall stand for his place. He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts i' the body.

src: As certain as I know the sun is fire: Where have you lurk'd, that you make doubt of it? Ne'er through an arch so hurried the blown tide, As the recomforted through the gates. Why, hark you!
trg: The trumpets, sackbuts, psalteries and fifes, Tabours and cymbals and the shouting Romans, Make the sun dance. Hark you!

src: Either this is the envy in you, folly, or mistaking: the very stream of his life and the business he hath helmed must upon a warranted need give him a better proclamation.
trg: Let him be but testimonied in his own bringings-forth, and he shall appear to the envious a scholar, a statesman and a soldier. Therefore you speak unskilfully:

src: I charge you, as you hope to have redemption By Christ's dear blood shed for our grievous sins, That you depart and lay no hands on me The deed you undertake is damnable.
trg: What we will do, we do upon command.

src: But by and by comes back to Romeo, Who had but newly entertain'd revenge, And to 't they go like lightning, for, ere I Could draw to part them, was stout Tybalt slain.
trg: And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly. This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.

src: for I do feel it gone, But know not how it went. My second joy And first-fruits of my body, from his presence I am barr'd, like one infectious.
trg: My third comfort Starr'd most unluckily, is from my breast, The innocent milk in its most innocent mouth, Haled out to murder: myself on every post Proclaimed a strumpet:

src: Come, come, you are well understood to be a perfecter giber for the table than a necessary bencher in the Capitol.
trg: Our very priests must become mockers, if they shall encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are. When you speak best unto the purpose, it is not worth the wagging of your beards;

src: From Rome.
trg: You may not pass, you must return: our general Will no more hear from thence.

src: I will go wash; And when my face is fair, you shall perceive Whether I blush or no: howbeit, I thank you.
trg: I mean to stride your steed, and at all times To undercrest your good addition To the fairness of my power.

src: I can tell you; but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you sought him: I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.
trg: You say well.

src: Very foul.
trg: Had I plantation of this isle, my lord,--

src: My lord, will't please you pass along? Myself and my good cousin Buckingham Will to your mother, to entreat of her To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.
trg: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?

src: Tears then for babes; blows and revenge for me Richard, I bear thy name; I'll venge thy death, Or die renowned by attempting it.
trg: His name that valiant duke hath left with thee; His dukedom and his chair with me is left.

src: Yes, an't please you, sir.
trg: So. What trade are you of, sir?

src: And now my tongue's use is to me no more Than an unstringed viol or a harp, Or like a cunning instrument cased up, Or, being open, put into his hands That knows no touch to tune the harmony:
trg: Within my mouth you have engaol'd my tongue, Doubly portcullis'd with my teeth and lips; And dull unfeeling barren ignorance Is made my gaoler to attend on me.

src: Art thou, indeed?
trg: Prove me, my gracious sovereign.

src: Richmond, in Yorkshire, sent out a boat Unto the shore, to ask those on the banks If they were his assistants, yea or no; Who answer'd him, they came from Buckingham. Upon his party:
trg: he, mistrusting them, Hoisted sail and made away for Brittany.

src: Love me or love me not, I like the cap; And it I will have, or I will have none.
trg: Thy gown? why, ay: come, tailor, let us see't. O mercy, God! what masquing stuff is here? What's this? a sleeve? 'tis like a demi-cannon: What, up and down, carved like an apple-tart?

src: This letter, then, to Friar Peter give; 'Tis that he sent me of the duke's return: Say, by this token, I desire his company At Mariana's house to-night.
trg: Her cause and yours I'll perfect him withal, and he shall bring you Before the duke, and to the head of Angelo Accuse him home and home.

src: Help, ye citizens!
trg: On both sides more respect.

src: Did ever Dian so become a grove As Kate this chamber with her princely gait? O, be thou Dian, and let her be Kate; And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sportful!
trg: Where did you study all this goodly speech?

src: Yea, and much more: but I was born so high, Our aery buildeth in the cedar's top, And dallies with the wind and scorns the sun.
trg: And turns the sun to shade; alas! alas! Witness my son, now in the shade of death; Whose bright out-shining beams thy cloudy wrath Hath in eternal darkness folded up.

src: Now, by my troth, if I had been remember'd, I could have given my uncle's grace a flout, To touch his growth nearer than he touch'd mine.
trg: How, my pretty York? I pray thee, let me hear it.

src: That life is better life, past fearing death, Than that which lives to fear: make it your comfort, So happy is your brother.
trg: I do, my lord.

src: Withdraw, my lord; I'll help you to a horse.
trg: Slave, I have set my life upon a cast, And I will stand the hazard of the die: I think there be six Richmonds in the field; Five have I slain to-day instead of him. A horse! a horse!

src: Blush, Blush, thou lump of foul deformity; For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blood From cold and empty veins, where no blood dwells;
trg: Thy deed, inhuman and unnatural, Provokes this deluge most unnatural. O God, which this blood madest, revenge his death! O earth, which this blood drink'st revenge his death!

src: Henry of Lancaster, resign thy crown. What mutter you, or what conspire you, lords?
trg: Do right unto this princely Duke of York, Or I will fill the house with armed men, And over the chair of state, where now he sits, Write up his title with usurping blood.

src: For being a bawd, for being a bawd.
trg: Well, then, imprison him: if imprisonment be the due of a bawd, why, 'tis his right: bawd is he doubtless, and of antiquity too; bawd-born. Farewell, good Pompey. Commend me to the prison, Pompey:

src: Marry, and shall.
trg: Hold, Richard, hold; for we have done too much.

src: Indeed, I have had earnest: but I cannot with conscience take it.
trg: Unbuckle, unbuckle. Fortunate mistress,--let my prophecy Come home to ye!--you must retire yourself Into some covert:

src: long mayst thou live To bear his image and renew his glories!
trg: And he that will not fight for such a hope. Go home to bed, and like the owl by day, If he arise, be mock'd and wonder'd at.

src: which if to-day thou shed, Lament we may, but not revenge thee dead.
trg: O let no noble eye profane a tear For me, if I be gored with Mowbray's spear: As confident as is the falcon's flight Against a bird, do I with Mowbray fight. My loving lord, I take my leave of you;

src: I will not sup to-night. Give me some ink and paper. What, is my beaver easier than it was? And all my armour laid into my tent?
trg: If is, my liege; and all things are in readiness.

src: there is my bond of faith, To tie thee to my strong correction. As I intend to thrive in this new world, Aumerle is guilty of my true appeal:
trg: Besides, I heard the banish'd Norfolk say That thou, Aumerle, didst send two of thy men To execute the noble duke at Calais.

src: Worthy man!
trg: He cannot but with measure fit the honours Which we devise him.

src: No, by my life. Privy to none of this. How will this grieve you, When you shall come to clearer knowledge, that You thus have publish'd me!
trg: Gentle my lord, You scarce can right me throughly then to say You did mistake.

src: didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter? with another, for tying his new shoes with old riband? and yet thou wilt tutor me from quarrelling!
trg: An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should buy the fee-simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.

src: There may be in the cup A spider steep'd, and one may drink, depart, And yet partake no venom, for his knowledge Is not infected:
trg: but if one present The abhorr'd ingredient to his eye, make known How he hath drunk, he cracks his gorge, his sides, With violent hefts. I have drunk, and seen the spider.

src: Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?
trg: My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.

src: Wars have not wasted it, for warr'd he hath not, But basely yielded upon compromise That which his noble ancestors achieved with blows: More hath he spent in peace than they in wars.
trg: The Earl of Wiltshire hath the realm in farm.

src: They will, then, ere't be long.
trg: What comfort is for Claudio?

src: Would Katharina had never seen him though!
trg: Go, girl; I cannot blame thee now to weep; For such an injury would vex a very saint, Much more a shrew of thy impatient humour.

src: Sir, I will tell you; Since I am charged in honour and by him That I think honourable:
trg: therefore mark my counsel, Which must be even as swiftly follow'd as I mean to utter it, or both yourself and me Cry lost, and so good night!

src: A senseless villain! Good Hortensio, I bade the rascal knock upon your gate And could not get him for my heart to do it.
trg: Knock at the gate! O heavens! Spake you not these words plain, 'Sirrah, knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly'? And come you now with, 'knocking at the gate'?

src: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?
trg: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

src: Withdraw you hence, my lord, I'll follow you.
trg: We have not yet set down this day of triumph. To-morrow, in mine opinion, is too sudden; For I myself am not so well provided As else I would be, were the day prolong'd.

src: At Antium.
trg: I wish I had a cause to seek him there, To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home. Behold, these are the tribunes of the people, The tongues o' the common mouth: I do despise them;

src: Away! the tribunes do attend you: arm yourself To answer mildly; for they are prepared With accusations, as I hear, more strong Than are upon you yet.
trg: The word is 'mildly.' Pray you, let us go: Let them accuse me by invention, I Will answer in mine honour.
Gentle my lord, turn back.

src: I am sorry for't: All faults I make, when I shall come to know them, I do repent. Alas! I have show'd too much The rashness of a woman: he is touch'd To the noble heart.
trg: What's gone and what's past help Should be past grief: do not receive affliction At my petition; I beseech you, rather Let me be punish'd, that have minded you Of what you should forget.

src: Father, 'tis thus: yourself and all the world, That talk'd of her, have talk'd amiss of her: If she be curst, it is for policy, For she's not froward, but modest as the dove;
trg: She is not hot, but temperate as the morn; For patience she will prove a second Grissel, And Roman Lucrece for her chastity:

src: How lies their battle? know you on which side They have placed their men of trust?
trg: As I guess, Marcius, Their bands i' the vaward are the Antiates, Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius, Their very heart of hope.

src: And trust me, love, in my eye so do you: Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Adieu, adieu!
trg: O fortune, fortune! all men call thee fickle: If thou art fickle, what dost thou with him. That is renown'd for faith? Be fickle, fortune;

src: Tailor, I'll pay thee for thy gown tomorrow: Take no unkindness of his hasty words: Away! I say; commend me to thy master.
trg: Well, come, my Kate; we will unto your father's Even in these honest mean habiliments: Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor; For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich;

src: Yet may he live awhile; and, it may be, As long as you or I yet he must die.
trg: Under your sentence?

src: but it is I That, lying by the violet in the sun, Do as the carrion does, not as the flower, Corrupt with virtuous season. Can it be That modesty may more betray our sense Than woman's lightness?
trg: Having waste ground enough, Shall we desire to raze the sanctuary And pitch our evils there? O, fie, fie, fie! What dost thou, or what art thou, Angelo?

src: But, as 'tis, We cannot miss him: he does make our fire, Fetch in our wood and serves in offices That profit us. What, ho! slave! Caliban! Thou earth, thou! speak.
Methinks I play as I have seen them do In Whitsun pastorals: sure this robe of mine Does change my disposition.
trg: What you do Still betters what is done. When you speak, sweet. I'ld have you do it ever: when you sing, I'ld have you buy and sell so, so give alms, Pray so;

src: and, my good lord, But Tuesday night last gone in's garden-house He knew me as a wife. As this is true, Let me in safety raise me from my knees Or else for ever be confixed here, A marble monument!
trg: I did but smile till now: Now, good my lord, give me the scope of justice My patience here is touch'd.

src: Edward, kneel down.
trg: Edward Plantagenet, arise a knight; And learn this lesson, draw thy sword in right.

src: there's a French salutation to your French slop. You gave us the counterfeit fairly last night.
trg: Good morrow to you both. What counterfeit did I give you?

src: Profaned, dishonour'd, and the third usurp'd.
trg: I swear--

src: Unbuckle, unbuckle. Fortunate mistress,--let my prophecy Come home to ye!--you must retire yourself Into some covert:
trg: take your sweetheart's hat And pluck it o'er your brows, muffle your face, Dismantle you, and, as you can, disliken The truth of your own seeming;

src: I long to die, If what thou speak'st speak not of remedy.
trg: Hold, daughter: I do spy a kind of hope, Which craves as desperate an execution. As that is desperate which we would prevent. And, if thou darest, I'll give thee remedy.

src: Then give me leave to go.
trg: Whither?

src: For this new-married man approaching here, Whose salt imagination yet hath wrong'd Your well defended honour, you must pardon For Mariana's sake:' Haste still pays haste, and leisure answers leisure;
trg: Like doth quit like, and MEASURE still FOR MEASURE. Then, Angelo, thy fault's thus manifested; Which, though thou wouldst deny, denies thee vantage.

src: O, but remember this another day, When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow, And say poor Margaret was a prophetess!
trg: Live each of you the subjects to his hate, And he to yours, and all of you to God's!

src: Why, knows not Montague that of itself England is safe, if true within itself?
trg: But the safer when 'tis back'd with France.

src: Those are they That most are willing. If any such be here-- As it were sin to doubt--that love this painting Wherein you see me smear'd; if any fear Lesser his person than an ill report;
trg: If any think brave death outweighs bad life And that his country's dearer than himself; Let him alone, or so many so minded, Wave thus, to express his disposition, And follow Marcius. O, me alone!

src: I crave your honour's pardon. What shall be done, sir, with the groaning Juliet? She's very near her hour.
trg: Dispose of her To some more fitter place, and that with speed.

src: Had you such leisure in the time of death To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?
trg: Methought I had; and often did I strive To yield the ghost: but still the envious flood Kept in my soul, and would not let it forth To seek the empty, vast and wandering air;

src: And let his manly face, which promiseth Successful fortune, steel thy melting heart To hold thine own and leave thine own with him.
trg: Full well hath Clifford play'd the orator, Inferring arguments of mighty force. But, Clifford, tell me, didst thou never hear That things ill-got had ever bad success?

src: O, no more, no more! You have said you will not grant us any thing; For we have nothing else to ask, but that Which you deny already: yet we will ask;
trg: That, if you fail in our request, the blame May hang upon your hardness: therefore hear us.

src: Never crave him; we are definitive.
trg: Gentle my liege,--

src: What, dress'd! and in your clothes! and down again! I must needs wake you; Lady! lady! lady! Alas, alas! Help, help! my lady's dead! O, well-a-day, that ever I was born! Some aqua vitae, ho! My lord!
trg: my lady!

src: Fellow, why dost thou show me thus to the world? Bear me to prison, where I am committed.
trg: I do it not in evil disposition, But from Lord Angelo by special charge.

src: ' But, as you will not wed, I'll pardon you: Graze where you will you shall not house with me: Look to't, think on't, I do not use to jest. Thursday is near; lay hand on heart, advise:
trg: An you be mine, I'll give you to my friend; And you be not, hang, beg, starve, die in the streets, For, by my soul, I'll ne'er acknowledge thee, Nor what is mine shall never do thee good:

src: Farewell, my lord: securely I espy Virtue with valour couched in thine eye. Order the trial, marshal, and begin.
trg: Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby, Receive thy lance; and God defend the right!

src: Old sir, I know She prizes not such trifles as these are: The gifts she looks from me are pack'd and lock'd Up in my heart; which I have given already, But not deliver'd.
trg: O, hear me breathe my life Before this ancient sir, who, it should seem, Hath sometime loved!

src: and from this time, For what he did before Corioli, call him, With all the applause and clamour of the host, CAIUS MARCIUS CORIOLANUS! Bear The addition nobly ever!
trg: Caius Marcius Coriolanus!

src: shall I believe That unsubstantial death is amorous, And that the lean abhorred monster keeps Thee here in dark to be his paramour? For fear of that, I still will stay with thee;
trg: And never from this palace of dim night Depart again: here, here will I remain With worms that are thy chamber-maids;

src: I cannot help it now, Unless, by using means, I lame the foot Of our design. He bears himself more proudlier, Even to my person, than I thought he would When first I did embrace him:
trg: yet his nature In that's no changeling; and I must excuse What cannot be amended.

src: First, mighty sovereign, let me know your mind, What from your grace I shall deliver to him.
trg: O, true, good Catesby: bid him levy straight The greatest strength and power he can make, And meet me presently at Salisbury.

src: My business in this state Made me a looker on here in Vienna, Where I have seen corruption boil and bubble Till it o'er-run the stew;
trg: laws for all faults, But faults so countenanced, that the strong statutes Stand like the forfeits in a barber's shop, As much in mock as mark.

src: So shall you quietly enjoy your hope, And marry sweet Bianca with consent.
trg: Were it not that my fellow-school-master Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly, 'Twere good, methinks, to steal our marriage;

src: Monday! ha, ha! Well, Wednesday is too soon, O' Thursday let it be: o' Thursday, tell her, She shall be married to this noble earl. Will you be ready? do you like this haste?
trg: We'll keep no great ado,--a friend or two; For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late, It may be thought we held him carelessly, Being our kinsman, if we revel much:

src: Will you hence, Before the tag return? whose rage doth rend Like interrupted waters and o'erbear What they are used to bear.
trg: Pray you, be gone: I'll try whether my old wit be in request With those that have but little: this must be patch'd With cloth of any colour.

src: and now she professes a hot-house, which, I think, is a very ill house too.
trg: How know you that?

src: When thou camest first, Thou strokedst me and madest much of me, wouldst give me Water with berries in't, and teach me how To name the bigger light, and how the less, That burn by day and night:
trg: and then I loved thee And show'd thee all the qualities o' the isle, The fresh springs, brine-pits, barren place and fertile: Cursed be I that did so!

src: Which, like a usurer, abound'st in all, And usest none in that true use indeed Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit:
trg: Thy noble shape is but a form of wax, Digressing from the valour of a man; Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury, Killing that love which thou hast vow'd to cherish; What, rouse thee, man!

src: and what he with his oath And all probation will make up full clear, Whensoever he's convented. First, for this woman.
trg: To justify this worthy nobleman, So vulgarly and personally accused, Her shall you hear disproved to her eyes, Till she herself confess it.

src: Nay, if thy wits run the wild-goose chase, I have done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five: was I with you there for the goose?
trg: Thou wast never with me for any thing when thou wast not there for the goose.

src: Where is that damned villain Tranio, That faced and braved me in this matter so?
trg: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?

src: A lie; you are rough and hairy. Let me have no lying: it becomes none but tradesmen, and they often give us soldiers the lie: but we pay them for it with stamped coin, not stabbing steel;
trg: therefore they do not give us the lie.

src: A man that apprehends death no more dreadfully but as a drunken sleep; careless, reckless, and fearless of what's past, present, or to come; insensible of mortality, and desperately mortal.
trg: He wants advice.

src: My lord and you were then at Mantua:-- Nay, I do bear a brain:
trg: --but, as I said, When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool, To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug! Shake quoth the dove-house:

src: The news is very fair and good, my lord: Richard not far from hence hath hid his head.
trg: It would beseem the Lord Northumberland To say 'King Richard:' alack the heavy day When such a sacred king should hide his head.

src: This follows, if you will not change your purpose But undergo this flight, make for Sicilia, And there present yourself and your fair princess, For so I see she must be, 'fore Leontes:
trg: She shall be habited as it becomes The partner of your bed. Methinks I see Leontes opening his free arms and weeping His welcomes forth;

src: Why, she's a devil, a devil, the devil's dam.
trg: Tut, she's a lamb, a dove, a fool to him! I'll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priest Should ask, if Katharina should be his wife, 'Ay, by gogs-wouns,' quoth he;

src: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul: So from thy soul's love didst thou love her brothers; And from my heart's love I do thank thee for it.
trg: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning: I mean, that with my soul I love thy daughter, And mean to make her queen of England.

src: Where it seems best unto your royal self. If I may counsel you, some day or two Your highness shall repose you at the Tower:
trg: Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit For your best health and recreation.

src: Peace, I have done. God mark thee to his grace! Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed: An I might live to see thee married once, I have my wish.
trg: Marry, that 'marry' is the very theme I came to talk of. Tell me, daughter Juliet, How stands your disposition to be married?

src: One of these is true: I think affliction may subdue the cheek, But not take in the mind.
trg: Yea, say you so? There shall not at your father's house these seven years Be born another such.

src: Who, not the duke? yes, your beggar of fifty; and his use was to put a ducat in her clack-dish: the duke had crotchets in him. He would be drunk too; that let me inform you.
trg: You do him wrong, surely.

src: Can you so stead me As bring me to the sight of Isabella, A novice of this place and the fair sister To her unhappy brother Claudio?
trg: Why 'her unhappy brother'? let me ask, The rather for I now must make you know I am that Isabella and his sister.

src: But in the other's silence do I see Maid's mild behavior and sobriety. Peace, Tranio!
trg: Well said, master; mum! and gaze your fill.

src: A glooming peace this morning with it brings; The sun, for sorrow, will not show his head: Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things; Some shall be pardon'd, and some punished:
trg: For never was a story of more woe Than this of Juliet and her Romeo.

src: And after many scorns, many foul taunts, They took his head, and on the gates of York They set the same; and there it doth remain, The saddest spectacle that e'er I view'd.
trg: Sweet Duke of York, our prop to lean upon, Now thou art gone, we have no staff, no stay. O Clifford, boisterous Clifford! thou hast slain The flower of Europe for his chivalry;

src: but I'll report it Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles, Where great patricians shall attend and shrug, I' the end admire, where ladies shall be frighted, And, gladly quaked, hear more;
trg: where the dull tribunes, That, with the fusty plebeians, hate thine honours, Shall say against their hearts 'We thank the gods Our Rome hath such a soldier.

src: then embraces his son-in-law; then again worries he his daughter with clipping her; now he thanks the old shepherd, which stands by like a weather-bitten conduit of many kings' reigns.
trg: I never heard of such another encounter, which lames report to follow it and undoes description to do it.

src: For what?
trg: He thinks, nay, with all confidence he swears, As he had seen't or been an instrument To vice you to't, that you have touch'd his queen Forbiddenly.

src: Then be it so; and go we to determine Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow. Madam, and you, my mother, will you go To give your censures in this weighty business?
trg: With all our harts.

src: We would so, and then go a bat-fowling.
trg: Nay, good my lord, be not angry.

src: It fits, when such a villain is a guest: I'll not endure him.
trg: He shall be endured: What, goodman boy! I say, he shall: go to; Am I the master here, or you? go to. You'll not endure him! God shall mend my soul! You'll make a mutiny among my guests!

src: Hoyday, a riddle! neither good nor bad! Why dost thou run so many mile about, When thou mayst tell thy tale a nearer way? Once more, what news?
trg: Richmond is on the seas.

src: Escalus.
trg: My lord.

src: and that, since then, You have not dared to break the holy seal Nor read the secrets in't.
trg: All this we swear.

src: Not Isabel?
trg: No.

src: What we will do, we do upon command.
trg: And he that hath commanded is the king.

src: Ah, Clifford, murder not this innocent child, Lest thou be hated both of God and man!
trg: How now! is he dead already? or is it fear That makes him close his eyes? I'll open them.

src: Come, come, we know your meaning, brother Gloucester; You envy my advancement and my friends': God grant we never may have need of you!
trg: Meantime, God grants that we have need of you: Your brother is imprison'd by your means, Myself disgraced, and the nobility Held in contempt;

src: I do not know what witchcraft's in him, but Your soldiers use him as the grace 'fore meat, Their talk at table, and their thanks at end; And you are darken'd in this action, sir, Even by your own.
trg: I cannot help it now, Unless, by using means, I lame the foot Of our design. He bears himself more proudlier, Even to my person, than I thought he would When first I did embrace him:

src: And look upon, as if the tragedy Were play'd in jest by counterfeiting actors?
trg: Here on my knee I vow to God above, I'll never pause again, never stand still, Till either death hath closed these eyes of mine Or fortune given me measure of revenge.

src: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee Doth much excuse the appertaining rage To such a greeting: villain am I none; Therefore farewell; I see thou know'st me not.
trg: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries That thou hast done me; therefore turn and draw.

src: You show too much of that For which the people stir:
trg: if you will pass To where you are bound, you must inquire your way, Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit, Or never be so noble as a consul, Nor yoke with him for tribune.

src: I had rather have one scratch my head i' the sun When the alarum were struck than idly sit To hear my nothings monster'd.
trg: Masters of the people, Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter-- That's thousand to one good one--when you now see He had rather venture all his limbs for honour Than one on's ears to hear it?

src: I shall inform them.
trg: And when such time they have begun to cry, Let them not cease, but with a din confused Enforce the present execution Of what we chance to sentence.

src: My lords, when you shall know--as in this rage, Provoked by him, you cannot--the great danger Which this man's life did owe you, you'll rejoice That he is thus cut off.
trg: Please it your honours To call me to your senate, I'll deliver Myself your loyal servant, or endure Your heaviest censure.

src: Still thus, and thus; still worse!
trg: How doth my dear morsel, thy mistress? Procures she still, ha?

src: Come your ways, sir; come.
trg: Go to kennel, Pompey; go. What news, friar, of the duke?

src: Herein your highness wrongs both them and me. But, mighty lord, this merry inclination Accords not with the sadness of my suit: Please you dismiss me either with 'ay' or 'no.'
trg: Ay, if thou wilt say 'ay' to my request; No if thou dost say 'no' to my demand.

src: Which for some reasons, sir, I mean to see. I fear, I fear,--
trg: What should you fear? 'Tis nothing but some bond, that he is enter'd into For gay apparel 'gainst the triumph day.

src: Where the warlike Smalus, That noble honour'd lord, is fear'd and loved?
trg: Most royal sir, from thence; from him, whose daughter His tears proclaim'd his, parting with her:

src: Thou hast most kindly hit it.
trg: A most courteous exposition.

src: Now, what's the matter. Provost?
trg: Is it your will Claudio shall die tomorrow?

src: Your eyes drop millstones, when fools' eyes drop tears: I like you, lads; about your business straight; Go, go, dispatch.
trg: We will, my noble lord.

src: How? thy wife?
trg: Ay, sir; whom, I thank heaven, is an honest woman,--

src: Should they not, Well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude, And tent themselves with death.
trg: I thank you, general; But cannot make my heart consent to take A bribe to pay my sword: I do refuse it; And stand upon my common part with those That have beheld the doing.

src: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding-day: First were we sad, fearing you would not come; Now sadder, that you come so unprovided.
trg: Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate, An eye-sore to our solemn festival!

src: O this learning, what a thing it is!
trg: O this woodcock, what an ass it is!

src: I know it well. What must I call her?
trg: Madam.

src: Else might I think that Clarence, Edward's brother, Were but a feigned friend to our proceedings: But welcome, sweet Clarence; my daughter shall be thine.
trg: Our scouts have found the adventure very easy: I say not, slaughter him, For I intend but only to surprise him. You that will follow me to this attempt, Applaud the name of Henry with your leader.

src: I will, my lord.
trg: Mark and perform it, see'st thou! for the fail Of any point in't shall not only be Death to thyself but to thy lewd-tongued wife, Whom for this time we pardon.

src: The ripest fruit first falls, and so doth he; His time is spent, our pilgrimage must be. So much for that. Now for our Irish wars:
trg: We must supplant those rough rug-headed kerns, Which live like venom where no venom else But only they have privilege to live.

src: Away, sir! you must go.
trg: One word, good friend. Lucio, a word with you.

src: My lord, we'll do it throughly. Signior Lucio, did not you say you knew that Friar Lodowick to be a dishonest person?
trg: 'Cucullus non facit monachum:' honest in nothing but in his clothes; and one that hath spoke most villanous speeches of the duke.

src: They have ta'en note of us: keep on your way.
trg: O, ye're well met: the hoarded plague o' the gods Requite your love!

src: Well, bear you well in this new spring of time, Lest you be cropp'd before you come to prime. What news from Oxford? hold those justs and triumphs?
trg: For aught I know, my lord, they do.

src: 'Tis wondrous strange, the like yet never heard of. Whate'er it bodes, henceforward will I bear Upon my target three fair-shining suns.
trg: Nay, bear three daughters: by your leave I speak it, You love the breeder better than the male. But what art thou, whose heavy looks foretell Some dreadful story hanging on thy tongue?

src: Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate, An eye-sore to our solemn festival!
trg: And tells us, what occasion of import Hath all so long detain'd you from your wife, And sent you hither so unlike yourself?

src: Art thou against us, Duke of Exeter?
trg: His is the right, and therefore pardon me.

src: Are you call'd forth from out a world of men To slay the innocent? What is my offence? Where are the evidence that do accuse me? What lawful quest have given their verdict up Unto the frowning judge?
trg: or who pronounced The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death? Before I be convict by course of law, To threaten me with death is most unlawful.

src: Next to thyself and my young rover, he's Apparent to my heart.
trg: If you would seek us, We are yours i' the garden: shall's attend you there?

src: O Tranio, till I found it to be true, I never thought it possible or likely; But see, while idly I stood looking on, I found the effect of love in idleness:
trg: And now in plainness do confess to thee, That art to me as secret and as dear As Anna to the queen of Carthage was, Tranio, I burn, I pine, I perish, Tranio, If I achieve not this young modest girl.

src: And though the edge hath something hit ourselves, Yet, know thou, since we have begun to strike, We'll never leave till we have hewn thee down, Or bathed thy growing with our heated bloods.
trg: And, in this resolution, I defy thee; Not willing any longer conference, Since thou deniest the gentle king to speak. Sound trumpets! let our bloody colours wave! And either victory, or else a grave.

src: Where's Potpan, that he helps not to take away? He shift a trencher? he scrape a trencher!
trg: When good manners shall lie all in one or two men's hands and they unwashed too, 'tis a foul thing.

src: Ay, sir.
trg: This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child And here was left by the sailors. Thou, my slave, As thou report'st thyself, wast then her servant;

src: Against him first: he's a very dog to the commonalty.
trg: Consider you what services he has done for his country?

src: We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.
trg: Amen, sir: to my poor unworthy notice, He mock'd us when he begg'd our voices.

src: Who? that Petruchio came?
trg: Ay, that Petruchio came.

src: Was ever king so grieved for subjects' woe? Much is your sorrow; mine ten times so much.
trg: I'll bear thee hence, where I may weep my fill.

src: Edward the Fourth, by the grace of God, king of England and France, and lord of Ireland, &c.
trg: And whosoe'er gainsays King Edward's right, By this I challenge him to single fight.

src: He cannot choose. I am most fortunate, thus accidentally to encounter you: you have ended my business, and I will merrily accompany you home.
trg: I shall, between this and supper, tell you most strange things from Rome; all tending to the good of their adversaries. Have you an army ready, say you?

src: Surrey, thou liest.
trg: Dishonourable boy! That lie shall lie so heavy on my sword, That it shall render vengeance and revenge Till thou the lie-giver and that lie do lie In earth as quiet as thy father's skull:

src: Marry, will I; and you shall help to put him i' the ground.
trg: 'Tis a lucky day, boy, and we'll do good deeds on't.

src: The king! why, who's that?
trg: I cry you mercy: I mean the lord protector.

src: And if I be, sir, is it any offence?
trg: No; if without more words you will get you hence.

src: That may be must be, love, on Thursday next.
trg: What must be shall be.

src: But thy vile race, Though thou didst learn, had that in't which good natures Could not abide to be with; therefore wast thou Deservedly confined into this rock, Who hadst deserved more than a prison.
trg: You taught me language; and my profit on't Is, I know how to curse. The red plague rid you For learning me your language!

src: ' As were our England in reversion his, And he our subjects' next degree in hope.
trg: Well, he is gone; and with him go these thoughts.

src: What sayest thou? speak suddenly; be brief.
trg: Your grace may do your pleasure.

src: If you shall chance, Camillo, to visit Bohemia, on the like occasion whereon my services are now on foot, you shall see, as I have said, great difference betwixt our Bohemia and your Sicilia.
trg: I think, this coming summer, the King of Sicilia means to pay Bohemia the visitation which he justly owes him.

src: Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear And stop the rising of blood-sucking sighs, Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown King Edward's fruit, true heir to the English crown.
trg: But, madam, where is Warwick then become?

src: They, for their truth, might better wear their heads Than some that have accused them wear their hats. But come, my lord, let us away.
trg: Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow. How now, sirrah! how goes the world with thee?

src: What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!
trg: A crutch, a crutch! why call you for a sword?

src: Beseech you, sir, be merry; you have cause, So have we all, of joy; for our escape Is much beyond our loss. Our hint of woe Is common;
trg: every day some sailor's wife, The masters of some merchant and the merchant Have just our theme of woe; but for the miracle, I mean our preservation, few in millions Can speak like us:

src: Nay, if I turn mine eyes upon myself, I find myself a traitor with the rest; For I have given here my soul's consent To undeck the pompous body of a king;
trg: Made glory base and sovereignty a slave, Proud majesty a subject, state a peasant.

src: The town is ta'en!
trg: 'Twill be deliver'd back on good condition.

src: And he, and more Than he, and men, the earth, the heavens, and all: for her employ them all; Commend them and condemn them to her service Or to their own perdition.
trg: Fairly offer'd.

src: And ne'er was Agamemnon's brother wrong'd By that false woman, as this king by thee. His father revell'd in the heart of France, And tamed the king, and made the dauphin stoop;
trg: And had he match'd according to his state, He might have kept that glory to this day; For what hath broach'd this tumult but thy pride? Hadst thou been meek, our title still had slept;

src: give the like notice To Valentinus, Rowland, and to Crassus, And bid them bring the trumpets to the gate; But send me Flavius first.
trg: It shall be speeded well.

src: many thousand on's Have the disease, and feel't not. How now, boy!
trg: I am like you, they say.

src: Not a word: if you have any thing to say to me, come to my ward; for thence will not I to-day.
trg: Unfit to live or die: O gravel heart! After him, fellows; bring him to the block.

src: but, I think, you'll find They've not prepared for us.
trg: O, doubt not that; I speak from certainties. Nay, more, Some parcels of their power are forth already, And only hitherward. I leave your honours.

src: 'Tis the more honour, because more dangerous.
trg: Ay, but give me worship and quietness; I like it better than a dangerous honour. If Warwick knew in what estate he stands, 'Tis to be doubted he would waken him.

src: My Lord Aumerle, I know your daring tongue Scorns to unsay what once it hath deliver'd.
trg: In that dead time when Gloucester's death was plotted, I heard you say, 'Is not my arm of length, That reacheth from the restful English court As far as Calais, to mine uncle's head?

src: How, my lord! What cheer? how is't with you, best brother?
trg: You look as if you held a brow of much distraction Are you moved, my lord?

src: And, sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bring forth more islands.
trg: Ay.

src: Go to, go to; You are a saucy boy: is't so, indeed? This trick may chance to scathe you, I know what: You must contrary me! marry, 'tis time. Well said, my hearts! You are a princox; go:
trg: Be quiet, or--More light, more light! For shame! I'll make you quiet. What, cheerly, my hearts!

src: I humbly thank you. To sue to live, I find I seek to die; And, seeking death, find life: let it come on.
Well, girl, thou weep'st not so much for his death, As that the villain lives which slaughter'd him.
trg: What villain madam?

src: I' the name of me--
trg: O, help me, help me! pluck but off these rags; and then, death, death!

src: It will be dangerous to go on: no further.
trg: What makes this change?

src: Why, then they are not dead: But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.
trg: I did not kill your husband.

src: Ere he would have hanged a man for the getting a hundred bastards, he would have paid for the nursing a thousand: he had some feeling of the sport:
trg: he knew the service, and that instructed him to mercy.

src: Tush! Fear not, my lord, we will not stand to prate; Talkers are no good doers: be assured We come to use our hands and not our tongues.
trg: Your eyes drop millstones, when fools' eyes drop tears: I like you, lads; about your business straight; Go, go, dispatch.

src: Let them lay by their helmets and their spears, And both return back to their chairs again: Withdraw with us: and let the trumpets sound While we return these dukes what we decree.
trg: Draw near, And list what with our council we have done. For that our kingdom's earth should not be soil'd With that dear blood which it hath fostered;

src: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.
trg: Head, and butt! an hasty-witted body Would say your head and butt were head and horn.

src: Take him up gently and to bed with him; And each one to his office when he wakes. Sirrah, go see what trumpet 'tis that sounds:
trg: Belike, some noble gentleman that means, Travelling some journey, to repose him here. How now! who is it?

src: The red rose and the white are on his face, The fatal colours of our striving houses: The one his purple blood right well resembles; The other his pale cheeks, methinks, presenteth:
trg: Wither one rose, and let the other flourish; If you contend, a thousand lives must wither.

src: Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace As 'longeth to a lover's blessed case! Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love, And have forsworn you with Hortensio.
trg: Tranio, you jest: but have you both forsworn me?
