src: But not a minute, king, that thou canst give: Shorten my days thou canst with sullen sorrow, And pluck nights from me, but not lend a morrow;
trg: Thou canst help time to furrow me with age, But stop no wrinkle in his pilgrimage; Thy word is current with him for my death, But dead, thy kingdom cannot buy my breath.

src: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.
trg: Come, come, you wasp; i' faith, you are too angry.

src: Why, how now, Juliet!
trg: Madam, I am not well.

src: Be-mock the modest moon.
trg: The present wars devour him: he is grown Too proud to be so valiant.

src: -- Alack, alack, is it not like that I, So early waking, what with loathsome smells, And shrieks like mandrakes' torn out of the earth, That living mortals, hearing them, run mad:
trg: -- O, if I wake, shall I not be distraught, Environed with all these hideous fears? And madly play with my forefather's joints? And pluck the mangled Tybalt from his shroud?

src: Better it were they all came by the father, Or by the father there were none at all; For emulation now, who shall be nearest, Will touch us all too near, if God prevent not.
trg: O, full of danger is the Duke of Gloucester! And the queen's sons and brothers haught and proud: And were they to be ruled, and not to rule, This sickly land might solace as before.

src: Are not these large enough?
trg: Yes, truly; I speak not as desiring more; But rather wishing a more strict restraint Upon the sisterhood, the votarists of Saint Clare.

src: I know thee not: thy name?
trg: My name is Caius Marcius, who hath done To thee particularly and to all the Volsces Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness may My surname, Coriolanus:

src: O, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.
trg: She is the fairies' midwife, and she comes In shape no bigger than an agate-stone On the fore-finger of an alderman, Drawn with a team of little atomies Athwart men's noses as they lie asleep;

src: And here comes Claudio's pardon.
Off with the crown, and with the crown his head; And, whilst we breathe, take time to do him dead.
trg: That is my office, for my father's sake.

src: Hold him in safety, till the prince come hither.
trg: Here is a friar, that trembles, sighs and weeps: We took this mattock and this spade from him, As he was coming from this churchyard side.

src: Nay, prithee, dispatch: the gentleman is half flayed already.
trg: Are you in earnest, sir? I smell the trick on't.

src: Who is't that calls? is it my lady mother? Is she not down so late, or up so early? What unaccustom'd cause procures her hither?
trg: Why, how now, Juliet!

src: And topping all others in boasting.
trg: This is strange now: do you two know how you are censured here in the city, I mean of us o' the right-hand file? do you?

src: It is: may it be done?
trg: Not possible; for who shall bear your part, And be in Padua here Vincentio's son, Keep house and ply his book, welcome his friends, Visit his countrymen and banquet them?

src: thy seat is up on high; Whilst my gross flesh sinks downward, here to die.
trg: As full of valour as of royal blood: Both have I spill'd; O would the deed were good! For now the devil, that told me I did well, Says that this deed is chronicled in hell.

src: The sullen passage of thy weary steps Esteem as foil wherein thou art to set The precious jewel of thy home return.
trg: Nay, rather, every tedious stride I make Will but remember me what a deal of world I wander from the jewels that I love.

src: Make way, unruly woman!
trg: After, Aumerle! mount thee upon his horse; Spur post, and get before him to the king, And beg thy pardon ere he do accuse thee. I'll not be long behind;

src: Alas! for whose sake did I that ill deed? For Edward, for my brother, for his sake: Why, sirs, He sends ye not to murder me for this For in this sin he is as deep as I.
trg: If God will be revenged for this deed. O, know you yet, he doth it publicly, Take not the quarrel from his powerful arm;

src: our cakes dough on both sides. Farewell: yet for the love I bear my sweet Bianca, if I can by any means light on a fit man to teach her that wherein she delights, I will wish him to her father.
trg: So will I, Signior Gremio: but a word, I pray.

src: He shall well know The noble tribunes are the people's mouths, And we their hands.
trg: He shall, sure on't.

src: and every man that means to live well endeavours to trust to himself and to live without it.
trg: 'Zounds, it is even now at my elbow, persuading me not to kill the duke.

src: O, stand up blest! Whilst, with no softer cushion than the flint, I kneel before thee; and unproperly Show duty, as mistaken all this while Between the child and parent.
trg: What is this? Your knees to me? to your corrected son? Then let the pebbles on the hungry beach Fillip the stars; then let the mutinous winds Strike the proud cedars 'gainst the fiery sun;

src: and the delighted spirit To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice;
trg: To be imprison'd in the viewless winds, And blown with restless violence round about The pendent world; or to be worse than worst Of those that lawless and incertain thought Imagine howling:

src: Twenty crowns! I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound, But twenty times so much upon my wife.
trg: A hundred then.

src: Then, seeing 'twas he that made you to depose, Your oath, my lord, is vain and frivolous. Therefore, to arms! And, father, do but think How sweet a thing it is to wear a crown;
trg: Within whose circuit is Elysium And all that poets feign of bliss and joy. Why do we finger thus? I cannot rest Until the white rose that I wear be dyed Even in the lukewarm blood of Henry's heart.

src: To your own bents dispose you: you'll be found, Be you beneath the sky. I am angling now, Though you perceive me not how I give line. Go to, go to! How she holds up the neb, the bill to him!
trg: And arms her with the boldness of a wife To her allowing husband! Gone already! Inch-thick, knee-deep, o'er head and ears a fork'd one! Go, play, boy, play:

src: A French crown more.
trg: Thou art always figuring diseases in me; but thou art full of error; I am sound.

src: Because that now it lies you on to speak To the people;
trg: Now, this no more dishonours you at all Than to take in a town with gentle words, Which else would put you to your fortune and The hazard of much blood.

src: you will turn good husband now, Pompey; you will keep the house.
trg: I hope, sir, your good worship will be my bail.

src: I cannot speak, nor think Nor dare to know that which I know. O sir!
trg: You have undone a man of fourscore three, That thought to fill his grave in quiet, yea, To die upon the bed my father died, To lie close by his honest bones:

src: She hangs about his neck: If she pertain to life let her speak too.
trg: Ay, and make't manifest where she has lived, Or how stolen from the dead.

src: Your highness shall do well to grant her suit; It were dishonour to deny it her.
trg: It were no less; but yet I'll make a pause.

src: But so it is, my haste doth call me hence, And therefore here I mean to take my leave.
trg: Is't possible you will away to-night?

src: I make you both protectors of this land, While I myself will lead a private life And in devotion spend my latter days, To sin's rebuke and my Creator's praise.
trg: What answers Clarence to his sovereign's will?

src: But you will take exceptions to my boon.
trg: No, gracious lord, except I cannot do it.

src: and if you please to like No worse than I, upon some agreement Me shall you find ready and willing With one consent to have her so bestow'd;
trg: For curious I cannot be with you, Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.

src: Angelo, There is a kind of character in thy life, That to the observer doth thy history Fully unfold.
trg: Thyself and thy belongings Are not thine own so proper as to waste Thyself upon thy virtues, they on thee. Heaven doth with us as we with torches do, Not light them for themselves;

src: O, no, no, no.
trg: O, he is wounded; I thank the gods for't.

src: Prithee, no more: thou dost talk nothing to me.
trg: I do well believe your highness; and did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use to laugh at nothing.

src: And shall I stand, and thou sit in my throne?
trg: It must and shall be so: content thyself.

src: I'll after him, and see the event of this.
trg: But to her love concerneth us to add Her father's liking: which to bring to pass, As I before unparted to your worship, I am to get a man,--whate'er he be, It skills not much.

src: Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands: Would none but I might venge my cousin's death!
trg: We will have vengeance for it, fear thou not: Then weep no more.

src: And ere thou bid good night, to quit their griefs, Tell thou the lamentable tale of me And send the hearers weeping to their beds:
trg: For why, the senseless brands will sympathize The heavy accent of thy moving tongue And in compassion weep the fire out;

src: Among them know you one Vincentio?
trg: I know him not, but I have heard of him; A merchant of incomparable wealth.

src: O sir, the loathsomeness of them offends me more than the stripes I have received, which are mighty ones and millions.
trg: Alas, poor man! a million of beating may come to a great matter.

src: but now Some hangman must put on my shroud and lay me Where no priest shovels in dust. O cursed wretch, That knew'st this was the prince, and wouldst adventure To mingle faith with him! Undone!
trg: undone! If I might die within this hour, I have lived To die when I desire.

src: Hang him, Jack! Come, we'll in here; tarry for the mourners, and stay dinner.
trg: If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep, My dreams presage some joyful news at hand: My bosom's lord sits lightly in his throne;

src: Why speaks my father so ungently? This Is the third man that e'er I saw, the first That e'er I sigh'd for: pity move my father To be inclined my way!
trg: O, if a virgin, And your affection not gone forth, I'll make you The queen of Naples.

src: Where is kind Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?
trg: A flourish, trumpets! strike alarum, drums! Let not the heavens hear these tell-tale women Rail on the Lord's enointed: strike, I say!

src: None, man; all idle: whores and knaves.
trg: I would with such perfection govern, sir, To excel the golden age.

src: So they are; My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.
trg: My father's loss, the weakness which I feel, The wreck of all my friends, nor this man's threats, To whom I am subdued, are but light to me, Might I but through my prison once a day Behold this maid:

src: You will not, then?
trg: No.

src: By Jupiter! forgot. I am weary; yea, my memory is tired. Have we no wine here?
trg: Go we to our tent: The blood upon your visage dries; 'tis time It should be look'd to: come.

src: Would he were here, my lord! for he indeed Hath set the women on to this complaint: Your provost knows the place where he abides And he may fetch him.
trg: Go do it instantly. And you, my noble and well-warranted cousin, Whom it concerns to hear this matter forth, Do with your injuries as seems you best, In any chastisement: I for a while will leave you;

src: do not shun her Until you see her die again; for then You kill her double. Nay, present your hand: When she was young you woo'd her; now in age Is she become the suitor?
trg: O, she's warm! If this be magic, let it be an art Lawful as eating.

src: O, father, you'll know more of that hereafter. Is it not too far gone? 'Tis time to part them. He's simple and tells much. How now, fair shepherd!
trg: Your heart is full of something that does take Your mind from feasting. Sooth, when I was young And handed love as you do, I was wont To load my she with knacks:

src: Go some of you and fetch a looking-glass.
trg: Read o'er this paper while the glass doth come.

src: The son and heir of old Tiberio.
trg: What's he that now is going out of door?

src: By Providence divine. so, of his gentleness, Knowing I loved my books, he furnish'd me From mine own library with volumes that I prize above my dukedom.
trg: Would I might But ever see that man!

src: Sir, I have been an unlawful bawd time out of mind; but yet I will be content to be a lawful hangman. I would be glad to receive some instruction from my fellow partner.
trg: What, ho! Abhorson! Where's Abhorson, there?

src: I must indeed; and therefore came I hither. Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man; Fly hence, and leave me: think upon these gone; Let them affright thee.
trg: I beseech thee, youth, Put not another sin upon my head, By urging me to fury: O, be gone! By heaven, I love thee better than myself; For I come hither arm'd against myself: Stay not, be gone;

src: Here on my knee I vow to God above, I'll never pause again, never stand still, Till either death hath closed these eyes of mine Or fortune given me measure of revenge.
trg: O Warwick, I do bend my knee with thine; And in this vow do chain my soul to thine! Now, lords, take leave until we meet again, Where'er it be, in heaven or in earth.

src: Let's levy men, and beat him back again.
trg: A little fire is quickly trodden out; Which, being suffer'd, rivers cannot quench.

src: I was a poor groom of thy stable, king, When thou wert king; who, travelling towards York, With much ado at length have gotten leave To look upon my sometimes royal master's face.
trg: Rode he on Barbary? Tell me, gentle friend, How went he under him?

src: Set on towards London, cousin, is it so?
trg: Yea, my good lord.

src: I am ashamed that women are so simple To offer war where they should kneel for peace; Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway, When they are bound to serve, love and obey.
trg: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, Unapt to toil and trouble in the world, But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts?

src: I guess not.
trg: And why should we proclaim it in an hour before his entering, that if any crave redress of injustice, they should exhibit their petitions in the street?

src: Marry, would the word 'farewell' have lengthen'd hours And added years to his short banishment, He should have had a volume of farewells; But since it would not, he had none of me.
trg: He is our cousin, cousin; but 'tis doubt, When time shall call him home from banishment, Whether our kinsman come to see his friends.

src: You may go walk, and give me leave a while: My lessons make no music in three parts.
trg: Are you so formal, sir? well, I must wait, And watch withal; for, but I be deceived, Our fine musician groweth amorous.

src: Ay, when the special thing is well obtain'd, That is, her love; for that is all in all.
trg: Why, that is nothing: for I tell you, father, I am as peremptory as she proud-minded; And where two raging fires meet together They do consume the thing that feeds their fury:

src: Take, then, this your companion by the hand, Who hath a story ready for your ear. I shall attend your leisure: but make haste; The vaporous night approaches.
trg: Will't please you walk aside?

src: a getter of more bastard children than war's a destroyer of men.
trg: 'Tis so: and as war, in some sort, may be said to be a ravisher, so it cannot be denied but peace is a great maker of cuckolds.

src: Why, I pray you?
trg: 'Tis not to save labour, nor that I want love.

src: Well, let it strike.
trg: Why let it strike?

src: O bloody Richard! miserable England! I prophesy the fearful'st time to thee That ever wretched age hath look'd upon. Come, lead me to the block; bear him my head.
trg: They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.

src: But that her tender shame Will not proclaim against her maiden loss, How might she tongue me! Yet reason dares her no;
trg: For my authority bears of a credent bulk, That no particular scandal once can touch But it confounds the breather.

src: Nay, that's a mock: I have seen a lady's nose That has been blue, but not her eyebrows.
trg: Hark ye; The queen your mother rounds apace: we shall Present our services to a fine new prince One of these days; and then you'ld wanton with us, If we would have you.

src: Your honour's players, heating your amendment, Are come to play a pleasant comedy;
trg: For so your doctors hold it very meet, Seeing too much sadness hath congeal'd your blood, And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy:

src: Thou hast done a deed whereat valour will weep.
trg: Tread not upon him. Masters all, be quiet; Put up your swords.

src: Ha! what is that?
trg: It will be dangerous to go on: no further.

src: Anon!
trg: My fan, Peter.

src: When he lies along, After your way his tale pronounced shall bury His reasons with his body.
trg: Say no more: Here come the lords.

src: one who never feels The wanton stings and motions of the sense, But doth rebate and blunt his natural edge With profits of the mind, study and fast.
trg: He--to give fear to use and liberty, Which have for long run by the hideous law, As mice by lions--hath pick'd out an act, Under whose heavy sense your brother's life Falls into forfeit:

src: Marry, and will, my lord, with all my heart.
trg: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.

src: So then the Volsces stand but as at first, Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road. Upon's again.
trg: They are worn, lord consul, so, That we shall hardly in our ages see Their banners wave again.

src: My remedy is then, to pluck it out.
trg: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies,

src: Good my lord, forbear: The ruddiness upon her lip is wet; You'll mar it if you kiss it, stain your own With oily painting. Shall I draw the curtain?
trg: No, not these twenty years.

src: Good my liege, I come;
trg: And, I beseech you, hear me, who profess Myself your loyal servant, your physician, Your most obedient counsellor, yet that dare Less appear so in comforting your evils, Than such as most seem yours:

src: Let him that makes but trifles of his eyes First hand me: on mine own accord I'll off; But first I'll do my errand. The good queen, For she is good, hath brought you forth a daughter; Here 'tis;
trg: commends it to your blessing.

src: Could I repair what she will wear in me, As I can change these poor accoutrements, 'Twere well for Kate and better for myself.
trg: But what a fool am I to chat with you, When I should bid good morrow to my bride, And seal the title with a lovely kiss!

src: So she does any thing; though I report it, That should be silent: if young Doricles Do light upon her, she shall bring him that Which he not dreams of.
trg: O master, if you did but hear the pedlar at the door, you would never dance again after a tabour and pipe; no, the bagpipe could not move you: he sings several tunes faster than you'll tell money;

src: Left her in her tears, and dried not one of them with his comfort; swallowed his vows whole, pretending in her discoveries of dishonour:
trg: in few, bestowed her on her own lamentation, which she yet wears for his sake; and he, a marble to her tears, is washed with them, but relents not.

src: Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate: Better once than never, for never too late.
trg: At last, though long, our jarring notes agree: And time it is, when raging war is done, To smile at scapes and perils overblown.

src: But stay a while: what company is this?
trg: Master, some show to welcome us to town.

src: I'll slit the villain's nose, that would have sent me to the gaol.
trg: But do you hear, sir? have you married my daughter without asking my good will?

src: I make a broken delivery of the business; but the changes I perceived in the king and Camillo were very notes of admiration:
trg: they seemed almost, with staring on one another, to tear the cases of their eyes; there was speech in their dumbness, language in their very gesture;

src: O, by this count I shall be much in years Ere I again behold my Romeo!
trg: Farewell! I will omit no opportunity That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.

src: Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men To turn their own points on their masters' bosoms: Now Margaret's curse is fallen upon my head;
trg: 'When he,' quoth she, 'shall split thy heart with sorrow, Remember Margaret was a prophetess.' Come, sirs, convey me to the block of shame; Wrong hath but wrong, and blame the due of blame.

src: This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.
trg: Carthage?

src: Tell me, sweet Kate, and tell me truly too, Hast thou beheld a fresher gentlewoman? Such war of white and red within her cheeks!
trg: What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty, As those two eyes become that heavenly face? Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee. Sweet Kate, embrace her for her beauty's sake.

src: The cockerel.
trg: Done. The wager?

src: Marry, and did; but if you be remember'd, I did not bid you mar it to the time. Go, hop me over every kennel home, For you shall hop without my custom, sir: I'll none of it: hence!
trg: make your best of it.

src: 'Tis he,'tis he: O, he is grown most kind of late.
trg: Hail sir!

src: Send out a pursuivant at arms To Stanley's regiment; bid him bring his power Before sunrising, lest his son George fall Into the blind cave of eternal night. Fill me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch.
trg: Saddle white Surrey for the field to-morrow. Look that my staves be sound, and not too heavy. Ratcliff!

src: Tongue-tied, our queen? speak you.
trg: I had thought, sir, to have held my peace until You have drawn oaths from him not to stay. You, sir, Charge him too coldly. Tell him, you are sure All in Bohemia's well;

src: make you a sword of me? If these shows be not outward, which of you But is four Volsces? none of you but is Able to bear against the great Aufidius A shield as hard as his.
trg: A certain number, Though thanks to all, must I select from all: the rest Shall bear the business in some other fight, As cause will be obey'd. Please you to march;

src: my invocation Is fair and honest, and in his mistress' name I conjure only but to raise up him.
trg: Come, he hath hid himself among these trees, To be consorted with the humorous night: Blind is his love and best befits the dark.

src: This sudden stag of rancour I misdoubt: Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward! What, shall we toward the Tower? the day is spent.
trg: Come, come, have with you. Wot you what, my lord? To-day the lords you talk of are beheaded.

src: For corn at their own rates; whereof, they say, The city is well stored.
trg: Hang 'em! They say! They'll sit by the fire, and presume to know What's done i' the Capitol; who's like to rise, Who thrives and who declines; side factions and give out Conjectural marriages;

src: Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to visit you.
trg: Beseech you, give me leave to retire myself.

src: God give him joy!
trg: Ay, and he'll tame her.

src: Marry, I will, let them play it. Is not a comondy a Christmas gambold or a tumbling-trick?
trg: No, my good lord; it is more pleasing stuff.

src: So stood the state when Henry the Sixth Was crown'd in Paris but at nine months old.
trg: Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot; For then this land was famously enrich'd With politic grave counsel; then the king Had virtuous uncles to protect his grace.

src: what shout is this? Shall I be tempted to infringe my vow In the same time 'tis made? I will not. My wife comes foremost;
trg: then the honour'd mould Wherein this trunk was framed, and in her hand The grandchild to her blood. But, out, affection! All bond and privilege of nature, break! Let it be virtuous to be obstinate.

src: That you might know it, would much better please me Than to demand what 'tis. Your brother cannot live.
trg: Even so. Heaven keep your honour!

src: May these same instruments, which you profane, Never sound more! when drums and trumpets shall I' the field prove flatterers, let courts and cities be Made all of false-faced soothing!
trg: When steel grows soft as the parasite's silk, Let him be made a coverture for the wars! No more, I say! For that I have not wash'd My nose that bled, or foil'd some debile wretch.

src: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.
trg: No man but prophesied revenge for it.

src: O my good lord! Sweet Isabel, take my part; Lend me your knees, and all my life to come I'll lend you all my life to do you service.
trg: Against all sense you do importune her: Should she kneel down in mercy of this fact, Her brother's ghost his paved bed would break, And take her hence in horror.

src: Nurse!
trg: Ah sir! ah sir! Well, death's the end of all.

src: I know no further: Let them pronounce the steep Tarpeian death, Vagabond exile, raying, pent to linger But with a grain a day, I would not buy Their mercy at the price of one fair word;
trg: Nor cheque my courage for what they can give, To have't with saying 'Good morrow.'

src: That I'll try.
trg: I swear I'll cuff you, if you strike again.

src: I'll make a voyage to the Holy Land, To wash this blood off from my guilty hand: March sadly after; grace my mournings here; In weeping after this untimely bier.
trg: SAMPSON: Gregory, o' my word, we'll not carry coals.

src: Therefore, be it known, As to us, to all the world, that Caius Marcius Wears this war's garland: in token of the which, My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him, With all his trim belonging;
trg: and from this time, For what he did before Corioli, call him, With all the applause and clamour of the host, CAIUS MARCIUS CORIOLANUS! Bear The addition nobly ever!

src: As if that name, Shot from the deadly level of a gun, Did murder her; as that name's cursed hand Murder'd her kinsman. O, tell me, friar, tell me, In what vile part of this anatomy Doth my name lodge?
trg: tell me, that I may sack The hateful mansion.

src: Her husband, knave: wouldst thou betray me?
trg: I beseech your grace to pardon me, and withal Forbear your conference with the noble duke.

src: A callat Of boundless tongue, who late hath beat her husband And now baits me! This brat is none of mine; It is the issue of Polixenes:
trg: Hence with it, and together with the dam Commit them to the fire!

src: I do; and surely It is a sleepy language and thou speak'st Out of thy sleep. What is it thou didst say? This is a strange repose, to be asleep With eyes wide open;
trg: standing, speaking, moving, And yet so fast asleep.

src: We will not from the helm to sit and weep, But keep our course, though the rough wind say no, From shelves and rocks that threaten us with wreck. As good to chide the waves as speak them fair.
trg: And what is Edward but ruthless sea? What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit? And Richard but a ragged fatal rock? All these the enemies to our poor bark. Say you can swim; alas, 'tis but a while!

src: So longest way shall have the longest moans.
trg: Twice for one step I'll groan, the way being short, And piece the way out with a heavy heart. Come, come, in wooing sorrow let's be brief, Since, wedding it, there is such length in grief;

src: A nest of traitors!
trg: I am none, by this good light.

src: For me, I'll not be gone till I please myself: 'Tis like you'll prove a jolly surly groom, That take it on you at the first so roundly.
trg: O Kate, content thee; prithee, be not angry.

src: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.
trg: That's my office.

src: While we devise fell tortures for thy faults.
trg: Thou didst love York, and I am son to York.

src: I would he had continued to his country As he began, and not unknit himself The noble knot he made.
trg: I would he had.

src: O, patience! The statue is but newly fix'd, the colour's Not dry.
trg: My lord, your sorrow was too sore laid on, Which sixteen winters cannot blow away, So many summers dry; scarce any joy Did ever so long live; no sorrow But kill'd itself much sooner.

src: Tell him he must awake, and that quickly too.
trg: Pray, Master Barnardine, awake till you are executed, and sleep afterwards.

src: Ah, no, no, no, it is mine only son! Ah, boy, if any life be left in thee, Throw up thine eye!
trg: see, see what showers arise, Blown with the windy tempest of my heart, Upon thy words, that kill mine eye and heart! O, pity, God, this miserable age!

src: And were his daughter fairer than she is, She may more suitors have and me for one. Fair Leda's daughter had a thousand wooers; Then well one more may fair Bianca have: And so she shall;
trg: Lucentio shall make one, Though Paris came in hope to speed alone.

src: Let me entreat you.
trg: I am content.

src: Besides two thousand ducats by the year Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure. What, have I pinch'd you, Signior Gremio?
trg: Two thousand ducats by the year of land! My land amounts not to so much in all: That she shall have; besides an argosy That now is lying in Marseilles' road. What, have I choked you with an argosy?

src: Bring forth these men. Bushy and Green, I will not vex your souls-- Since presently your souls must part your bodies-- With too much urging your pernicious lives, For 'twere no charity;
trg: yet, to wash your blood From off my hands, here in the view of men I will unfold some causes of your deaths.

src: Come, come, you froward and unable worms! My mind hath been as big as one of yours, My heart as great, my reason haply more, To bandy word for word and frown for frown;
trg: But now I see our lances are but straws, Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.

src: You are to know That prosperously I have attempted and With bloody passage led your wars even to The gates of Rome.
trg: Our spoils we have brought home Do more than counterpoise a full third part The charges of the action. We have made peace With no less honour to the Antiates Than shame to the Romans:

src: And why not queen?
trg: Because thy father Henry did usurp; And thou no more are prince than she is queen.

src: Speak it in French, king; say, 'pardonne moi.'
trg: Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy? Ah, my sour husband, my hard-hearted lord, That set'st the word itself against the word! Speak 'pardon' as 'tis current in our land;

src: O my lord! I would your spirit were easier for advice, Or stronger for your need.
trg: Hark, Perdita I'll hear you by and by.

src: That book in many's eyes doth share the glory, That in gold clasps locks in the golden story; So shall you share all that he doth possess, By having him, making yourself no less.
trg: No less! nay, bigger; women grow by men.

src: Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel Go, by this token: rise, and lend thine ear: There is no more but so: say it is done, And I will love thee, and prefer thee too.
trg: 'Tis done, my gracious lord.

src: Your beauty was the cause of that effect; Your beauty: which did haunt me in my sleep To undertake the death of all the world, So I might live one hour in your sweet bosom.
trg: If I thought that, I tell thee, homicide, These nails should rend that beauty from my cheeks.

src: Because you talk of pride now,--will you not be angry?
trg: Well, well, sir, well.

src: Never, but once.
trg: What! have I twice said well? when was't before? I prithee tell me; cram's with praise, and make's As fat as tame things: one good deed dying tongueless Slaughters a thousand waiting upon that.

src: But did you never swear, and break an oath?
trg: No, never such an oath; nor will not now.

src: In few, they hurried us aboard a bark, Bore us some leagues to sea; where they prepared A rotten carcass of a boat, not rigg'd, Nor tackle, sail, nor mast; the very rats Instinctively had quit it:
trg: there they hoist us, To cry to the sea that roar'd to us, to sigh To the winds whose pity, sighing back again, Did us but loving wrong.

src: Meantime, this deep disgrace in brotherhood Touches me deeper than you can imagine.
trg: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.

src: I know it; And my pretext to strike at him admits A good construction. I raised him, and I pawn'd Mine honour for his truth:
trg: who being so heighten'd, He water'd his new plants with dews of flattery, Seducing so my friends; and, to this end, He bow'd his nature, never known before But to be rough, unswayable and free.

src: Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you. Of the same house Publius and Quintus were, That our beat water brought by conduits hither; And   Twice being   Was his great ancestor.
trg: One thus descended, That hath beside well in his person wrought To be set high in place, we did commend To your remembrances:

src: I see your brows are full of discontent, Your hearts of sorrow and your eyes of tears: Come home with me to supper; and I'll lay A plot shall show us all a merry day.
trg: This way the king will come; this is the way To Julius Caesar's ill-erected tower, To whose flint bosom my condemned lord Is doom'd a prisoner by proud Bolingbroke:

src: What, you will not? Prithee, tell my master what a strange guest he has here.
trg: And I shall.

src: No, holy father; throw away that thought; Believe not that the dribbling dart of love Can pierce a complete bosom.
trg: Why I desire thee To give me secret harbour, hath a purpose More grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends Of burning youth.

src: Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.
trg: How canst thou urge God's dreadful law to us, When thou hast broke it in so dear degree?

src: Two of thy name, both Dukes of Somerset, Have sold their lives unto the house of York; And thou shalt be the third if this sword hold.
trg: And lo, where George of Clarence sweeps along, Of force enough to bid his brother battle; With whom an upright zeal to right prevails More than the nature of a brother's love! Come, Clarence, come;

src: And he that got it, sentenced; a young man More fit to do another such offence Than die for this.
trg: When must he die?

src: so that, if they love they know not why, they hate upon no better a ground:
trg: therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate him manifests the true knowledge he has in their disposition; and out of his noble carelessness lets them plainly see't.

src: Prithee, peace.
trg: He receives comfort like cold porridge.

src: Dogs howl'd, and hideous tempest shook down trees; The raven rook'd her on the chimney's top, And chattering pies in dismal discords sung.
trg: Thy mother felt more than a mother's pain, And, yet brought forth less than a mother's hope, To wit, an indigested and deformed lump, Not like the fruit of such a goodly tree.

src: This is the point. The duke is very strangely gone from hence; Bore many gentlemen, myself being one, In hand and hope of action:
trg: but we do learn By those that know the very nerves of state, His givings-out were of an infinite distance From his true-meant design.

src: They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command. Obey the bride, you that attend on her;
trg: Go to the feast, revel and domineer, Carouse full measure to her maidenhead, Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves: But for my bonny Kate, she must with me.

src: First, the fair reverence of your highness curbs me From giving reins and spurs to my free speech; Which else would post until it had return'd These terms of treason doubled down his throat.
trg: Setting aside his high blood's royalty, And let him be no kinsman to my liege, I do defy him, and I spit at him; Call him a slanderous coward and a villain:

src: When they are gone, then must I count my gains.
trg: Set down, set down your honourable load, If honour may be shrouded in a hearse, Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament The untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster. Poor key-cold figure of a holy king!

src: My gracious sovereign, on the western coast Rideth a puissant navy; to the shore Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends, Unarm'd, and unresolved to beat them back:
trg: 'Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral; And there they hull, expecting but the aid Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.

src: Patience perforce with wilful choler meeting Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting. I will withdraw: but this intrusion shall Now seeming sweet convert to bitter gall.
I was provoked by her slanderous tongue, which laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.
trg: Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind. Which never dreamt on aught but butcheries: Didst thou not kill this king?

src: O, that thou wouldst as well afford a grave As thou canst yield a melancholy seat! Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here. O, who hath any cause to mourn but I?
trg: If ancient sorrow be most reverend, Give mine the benefit of seniory, And let my woes frown on the upper hand. If sorrow can admit society, Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine:

src: Nor cheque my courage for what they can give, To have't with saying 'Good morrow.'
trg: i' the people's name, I say it shall be so.

src: As thus, 'Come, little ones,' and then again, 'It is as hard to come as for a camel To thread the postern of a small needle's eye.' Thoughts tending to ambition, they do plot Unlikely wonders;
trg: how these vain weak nails May tear a passage through the flinty ribs Of this hard world, my ragged prison walls, And, for they cannot, die in their own pride.

src: an old hat and 'the humour of forty fancies' pricked in't for a feather: a monster, a very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman's lackey.
trg: 'Tis some odd humour pricks him to this fashion; Yet oftentimes he goes but mean-apparell'd.

src: I say 'silver sound,' because musicians sound for silver.
trg: Pretty too! What say you, James Soundpost?

src: I thought my mother, and my brother York, Would long ere this have met us on the way Fie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes not To tell us whether they will come or no!
trg: And, in good time, here comes the sweating lord.

src: Would they else be content to die?
trg: Yes; if there were no other excuse why they should desire to live.

src: 'tis shrewdly ebb'd, To say you have seen a better.
trg: Pardon, madam: The one I have almost forgot,--your pardon,-- The other, when she has obtain'd your eye, Will have your tongue too.

src: Must I do so? and must I ravel out My weaved-up folly? Gentle Northumberland, If thy offences were upon record, Would it not shame thee in so fair a troop To read a lecture of them?
trg: If thou wouldst, There shouldst thou find one heinous article, Containing the deposing of a king And cracking the strong warrant of an oath, Mark'd with a blot, damn'd in the book of heaven:

src: What then? 'Fore me, this fellow speaks! What then? what then?
trg: Should by the cormorant belly be restrain'd, Who is the sink o' the body,--

src: Our spoils he kick'd at, And look'd upon things precious as they were The common muck of the world: he covets less Than misery itself would give;
trg: rewards His deeds with doing them, and is content To spend the time to end it.

src: But on thy side I may not be too forward Lest, being seen, thy brother, tender George, Be executed in his father's sight. Farewell:
trg: the leisure and the fearful time Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love And ample interchange of sweet discourse, Which so long sunder'd friends should dwell upon:

src: Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?
trg: Titus Lartius writes, they fought together, but Aufidius got off.

src: There he must stay until the officer Arise to let him in: he is call'd up.
trg: Have you no countermand for Claudio yet, But he must die to-morrow?

src: And still is friend to him and Margaret: But if your title to the crown be weak, As may appear by Edward's good success, Then 'tis but reason that I be released From giving aid which late I promised.
trg: Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand That your estate requires and mine can yield.

src: Welcome, gentlemen! ladies that have their toes Unplagued with corns will have a bout with you. Ah ha, my mistresses! which of you all Will now deny to dance?
trg: she that makes dainty, She, I'll swear, hath corns; am I come near ye now? Welcome, gentlemen!

src: O, peace! the friar is come.
trg: Come, I have found you out a stand most fit, Where you may have such vantage on the duke, He shall not pass you. Twice have the trumpets sounded;

src: Go, masters, get you home; be not dismay'd: These are a side that would be glad to have This true which they so seem to fear. Go home, And show no sign of fear.
trg: The gods be good to us! Come, masters, let's home. I ever said we were i' the wrong when we banished him.

src: My affections Are then most humble; I have no ambition To see a goodlier man.
trg: Come on; obey: Thy nerves are in their infancy again And have no vigour in them.

src: A gross hag And, lozel, thou art worthy to be hang'd, That wilt not stay her tongue.
trg: Hang all the husbands That cannot do that feat, you'll leave yourself Hardly one subject.

src: Lord Stafford's father, Duke of Buckingham, Is either slain or wounded dangerously; I cleft his beaver with a downright blow: That this is true, father, behold his blood.
trg: And, brother, here's the Earl of Wiltshire's blood, Whom I encounter'd as the battles join'd.

src: The readiest way to make the wench amends Is to become her husband and her father: The which will I;
trg: not all so much for love As for another secret close intent, By marrying her which I must reach unto. But yet I run before my horse to market: Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns:

src: And will deny him: I'll have five hundred voices of that sound.
trg: I twice five hundred and their friends to piece 'em.

src: O Dorset, speak not to me, get thee hence! Death and destruction dog thee at the heels; Thy mother's name is ominous to children.
trg: If thou wilt outstrip death, go cross the seas, And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughter-house, Lest thou increase the number of the dead;

src: Richard, I will create thee Duke of Gloucester, And George, of Clarence: Warwick, as ourself, Shall do and undo as him pleaseth best.
trg: Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloucester; For Gloucester's dukedom is too ominous.

src: Why, courage then! what cannot be avoided 'Twere childish weakness to lament or fear.
trg: Methinks a woman of this valiant spirit Should, if a coward heard her speak these words, Infuse his breast with magnanimity And make him, naked, foil a man at arms.

src: These, as I learn, and such like toys as these Have moved his highness to commit me now.
trg: Why, this it is, when men are ruled by women: 'Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower: My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, 'tis she That tempers him to this extremity.

src: Why, then, give way, dull clouds, to my quick curses! If not by war, by surfeit die your king, As ours by murder, to make him a king!
trg: Edward thy son, which now is Prince of Wales, For Edward my son, which was Prince of Wales, Die in his youth by like untimely violence!

src: And fearless minds climb soonest unto crowns. Brother, we will proclaim you out of hand: The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.
trg: Then be it as you will; for 'tis my right, And Henry but usurps the diadem.

src: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.
trg: To her, Kate!

src: but thou'rt too much my friend, And I'll not wish thee to her.
trg: Signior Hortensio, 'twixt such friends as we Few words suffice; I come to wive it wealthily in Padua; If wealthily, then happily in Padua.

src: If no inconstant toy, nor womanish fear, Abate thy valour in the acting it.
trg: Give me, give me! O, tell not me of fear!

src: And you, good brother father. What offence hath this man made you, sir?
trg: Marry, sir, he hath offended the law: and, sir, we take him to be a thief too, sir; for we have found upon him, sir, a strange picklock, which we have sent to the deputy.

src: Soft son! Sir, by your leave: having come to Padua To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio Made me acquainted with a weighty cause Of love between your daughter and himself:
trg: And, for the good report I hear of you And for the love he beareth to your daughter And she to him, to stay him not too long, I am content, in a good father's care, To have him match'd;

src: Or wallow naked in December snow By thinking on fantastic summer's heat? O, no! the apprehension of the good Gives but the greater feeling to the worse:
trg: Fell sorrow's tooth doth never rankle more Than when he bites, but lanceth not the sore.

src: Why, Clarence, to myself.
trg: That would be ten days' wonder at the least.

src: Our natures do pursue, Like rats that ravin down their proper bane, A thirsty evil; and when we drink we die.
trg: If could speak so wisely under an arrest, I would send for certain of my creditors: and yet, to say the truth, I had as lief have the foppery of freedom as the morality of imprisonment.

src: No.
trg: No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir, but I bite my thumb, sir.

src: A fortnight and odd days.
trg: Even or odd, of all days in the year, Come Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen. Susan and she--God rest all Christian souls!-- Were of an age: well, Susan is with God; She was too good for me:

src: The word is 'mildly.' Pray you, let us go: Let them accuse me by invention, I Will answer in mine honour.
trg: Ay, but mildly.

src: Stay, then; I'll go alone. Fear comes upon me: O, much I fear some ill unlucky thing.
trg: As I did sleep under this yew-tree here, I dreamt my master and another fought, And that my master slew him.

src: The noble duke hath been too much abused.
trg: It stands your grace upon to do him right.

src: O miserable lady! But, for me, What case stand I in? I must be the poisoner Of good Polixenes;
trg: and my ground to do't Is the obedience to a master, one Who in rebellion with himself will have All that are his so too. To do this deed, Promotion follows.

src: his bold head 'Bove the contentious waves he kept, and oar'd Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke To the shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bow'd, As stooping to relieve him:
trg: I not doubt He came alive to land.

src: Therefore they thought it good you hear a play And frame your mind to mirth and merriment, Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.
trg: Marry, I will, let them play it. Is not a comondy a Christmas gambold or a tumbling-trick?

src: Cursed the blood that let this blood from hence!
trg: More direful hap betide that hated wretch, That makes us wretched by the death of thee, Than I can wish to adders, spiders, toads, Or any creeping venom'd thing that lives!

src: Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here! Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear, So soon forsaken? young men's love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.
trg: Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine Hath wash'd thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline! How much salt water thrown away in waste, To season love, that of it doth not taste!

src: It is a mind That shall remain a poison where it is, Not poison any further.
trg: Shall remain! Hear you this Triton of the minnows? mark you His absolute 'shall'?

src: And long live thou and these thy forward sons!
trg: Now York and Lancaster are reconciled.

src: It shall be done, my sovereign, with all speed.
trg: My Lord of Somerset, what youth is that, Of whom you seem to have so tender care?

src: Sir, I know him, and I love him.
trg: Love talks with better knowledge, and knowledge with dearer love.

src: Your native town you enter'd like a post, And had no welcomes home: but he returns, Splitting the air with noise.
trg: And patient fools, Whose children he hath slain, their base throats tear With giving him glory.

src: This speak I, lords, to let you understand, If case some one of you would fly from us, That there's no hoped-for mercy with the brothers More than with ruthless waves, with sands and rocks.
trg: Why, courage then! what cannot be avoided 'Twere childish weakness to lament or fear.

src: Your love deserves my thanks; but my desert Unmeritable shuns your high request. But, God be thank'd, there's no need of me, And much I need to help you, if need were;
trg: The royal tree hath left us royal fruit, Which, mellow'd by the stealing hours of time, Will well become the seat of majesty, And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.

src: Why, then All-Souls' day is my body's doomsday. This, this All-Souls' day to my fearful soul Is the determined respite of my wrongs:
trg: That high All-Seer that I dallied with Hath turn'd my feigned prayer on my head And given in earnest what I begg'd in jest.

src: Things for the cook, sir; but I know not what.
trg: Make haste, make haste. Sirrah, fetch drier logs: Call Peter, he will show thee where they are.

src: That England, that was wont to conquer others, Hath made a shameful conquest of itself. Ah, would the scandal vanish with my life, How happy then were my ensuing death!
trg: The king is come: deal mildly with his youth; For young hot colts being raged do rage the more.

src: whereof I reckon The casting forth to crows thy baby-daughter To be or none or little; though a devil Would have shed water out of fire ere done't: this is not, no, Laid to thy answer:
trg: but the last,--O lords, When I have said, cry 'woe!' the queen, the queen, The sweet'st, dear'st creature's dead, and vengeance for't Not dropp'd down yet.

src: All but the base.
trg: The base is right; 'tis the base knave that jars. How fiery and forward our pedant is! Now, for my life, the knave doth court my love: Pedascule, I'll watch you better yet.

src: And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?
trg: A bridegroom say you? 'tis a groom indeed, A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.

src: Methinks a father Is at the nuptial of his son a guest That best becomes the table. Pray you once more, Is not your father grown incapable Of reasonable affairs?
trg: is he not stupid With age and altering rheums? can he speak? hear? Know man from man? dispute his own estate? Lies he not bed-rid? and again does nothing But what he did being childish?

src: Tell him, my mourning weeds are laid aside, And I am ready to put armour on.
trg: Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong, And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long. There's thy reward: be gone.

src: Give me the crown. Here, cousin, seize the crown; Here cousin: On this side my hand, and on that side yours.
trg: Now is this golden crown like a deep well That owes two buckets, filling one another, The emptier ever dancing in the air, The other down, unseen and full of water:

src: clamour your tongues, and not a word more.
trg: I have done. Come, you promised me a tawdry-lace and a pair of sweet gloves.

src: And good supporters are you.
trg: Now is your time: speak loud and kneel before him.

src: Too familiar Is my dear son with such sour company: I bring thee tidings of the prince's doom.
trg: What less than dooms-day is the prince's doom?

src: Northumberland, say thus the king returns: His noble cousin is right welcome hither; And all the number of his fair demands Shall be accomplish'd without contradiction:
trg: With all the gracious utterance thou hast Speak to his gentle hearing kind commends. We do debase ourselves, cousin, do we not, To look so poorly and to speak so fair?

src: if I thought it were a piece of honesty to acquaint the king withal, I would not do't: I hold it the more knavery to conceal it; and therein am I constant to my profession. Aside, aside;
trg: here is more matter for a hot brain: every lane's end, every shop, church, session, hanging, yields a careful man work.

src: My unsoil'd name, the austereness of my life, My vouch against you, and my place i' the state, Will so your accusation overweigh, That you shall stifle in your own report And smell of calumny.
trg: I have begun, And now I give my sensual race the rein: Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite; Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes, That banish what they sue for;

src: O Lord, I could have stay'd here all the night To hear good counsel: O, what learning is! My lord, I'll tell my lady you will come.
trg: Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.

src: Blossom, speed thee well! There lie, and there thy character: there these; Which may, if fortune please, both breed thee, pretty, And still rest thine. The storm begins;
trg: poor wretch, That for thy mother's fault art thus exposed To loss and what may follow! Weep I cannot, But my heart bleeds; and most accursed am I To be by oath enjoin'd to this. Farewell!

src: Say, Signior Gremio, What can you assure her?
trg: First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnished with plate and gold; Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry;

src: From worthy Edward, King of Albion, My lord and sovereign, and thy vowed friend, I come, in kindness and unfeigned love, First, to do greetings to thy royal person;
trg: And then to crave a league of amity; And lastly, to confirm that amity With a nuptial knot, if thou vouchsafe to grant That virtuous Lady Bona, thy fair sister, To England's king in lawful marriage.

src: Nay, it is ten times strange.
trg: It is not truer he is Angelo Than this is all as true as it is strange: Nay, it is ten times true; for truth is truth To the end of reckoning.

src: I do beseech your grace to pardon me: It is a matter of small consequence, Which for some reasons I would not have seen.
trg: Which for some reasons, sir, I mean to see. I fear, I fear,--

src: Measureless liar, thou hast made my heart Too great for what contains it. Boy! O slave! Pardon me, lords, 'tis the first time that ever I was forced to scold.
trg: Your judgments, my grave lords, Must give this cur the lie: and his own notion-- Who wears my stripes impress'd upon him;

src: What, thou?
trg: I, even I: what think you of it, madam?

src: The gods grant them true!
trg: True! pow, wow.

src: Why, so he doth, now he delivers thee From this world's thraldom to the joys of heaven.
trg: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

src: He hath not money for these Irish wars, His burthenous taxations notwithstanding, But by the robbing of the banish'd duke.
trg: His noble kinsman: most degenerate king! But, lords, we hear this fearful tempest sing, Yet see no shelter to avoid the storm;

src: I partly know the man: go, call him hither. The deep-revolving witty Buckingham No more shall be the neighbour to my counsel: Hath he so long held out with me untired, And stops he now for breath?
trg: How now! what news with you?

src: What counsel, lords? Edward from Belgia, With hasty Germans and blunt Hollanders, Hath pass'd in safety through the narrow seas, And with his troops doth march amain to London;
trg: And many giddy people flock to him.

src: Let the first budger die the other's slave, And the gods doom him after!
trg: If I fly, Marcius, Holloa me like a hare.

src: There were none fine but Adam, Ralph, and Gregory; The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly; Yet, as they are, here are they come to meet you.
trg: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in. Where is the life that late I led-- Where are those--Sit down, Kate, and welcome.-- Sound, sound, sound, sound! Why, when, I say?

src: So did I, I'll be sworn: he is simply the rarest man i' the world.
trg: I think he is: but a greater soldier than he you wot on.

src: Patience, good Katharina, and Baptista too. Upon my life, Petruchio means but well, Whatever fortune stays him from his word: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise;
trg: Though he be merry, yet withal he's honest.

src: from whom I have this intelligence, that he is seldom from the house of a most homely shepherd;
trg: a man, they say, that from very nothing, and beyond the imagination of his neighbours, is grown into an unspeakable estate.

src: But speedily.
trg: I will about it straight; No longer staying but to give the mother Notice of my affair. I humbly thank you: Commend me to my brother: soon at night I'll send him certain word of my success.

src: By the elements, If e'er again I meet him beard to beard, He's mine, or I am his: mine emulation Hath not that honour in't it had;
trg: for where I thought to crush him in an equal force, True sword to sword, I'll potch at him some way Or wrath or craft may get him.

src: Then must your brother die.
trg: And 'twere the cheaper way: Better it were a brother died at once, Than that a sister, by redeeming him, Should die for ever.

src: I'll make all speed.
My Lord of Hereford here, whom you call king, Is a foul traitor to proud Hereford's king: And if you crown him, let me prophesy:
trg: The blood of English shall manure the ground, And future ages groan for this foul act;

src: Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery, Our trusty friend, unless I be deceived.
trg: Welcome, Sir John! But why come you in arms?

src: What now remains, my lords, for us to do But march to London with our soldiers?
trg: Ay, that's the first thing that we have to do; To free King Henry from imprisonment And see him seated in the regal throne. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: And therefore 'tis called a sensible tale: and this cuff was but to knock at your ear, and beseech listening. Now I begin: Imprimis, we came down a foul hill, my master riding behind my mistress,--
trg: Both of one horse?

src: Lets along.
trg: So, your opinion is, Aufidius, That they of Rome are entered in our counsels And know how we proceed.

src: I hope so.
trg: I know so.

src: Who? Camillo?
trg: Camillo, sir; I spake with him; who now Has these poor men in question. Never saw I Wretches so quake: they kneel, they kiss the earth; Forswear themselves as often as they speak:

src: Beseech you, sir, were you present at this relation?
trg: I was by at the opening of the fardel, heard the old shepherd deliver the manner how he found it: whereupon, after a little amazedness, we were all commanded out of the chamber;

src: What, had he so?
trg: What, think You we are Turks or infidels?

src: How oft when men are at the point of death Have they been merry! which their keepers call A lightning before death: O, how may I Call this a lightning? O my love! my wife!
trg: Death, that hath suck'd the honey of thy breath, Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty: Thou art not conquer'd;

src: I am, in this, commanded to deliver The noble Duke of Clarence to your hands: I will not reason what is meant hereby, Because I will be guiltless of the meaning.
trg: Here are the keys, there sits the duke asleep: I'll to the king; and signify to him That thus I have resign'd my charge to you.

src: Good Catesby, go, effect this business soundly.
trg: My good lords both, with all the heed I may.

src: Even so As with a man by his own alms empoison'd, And with his charity slain.
trg: Most noble sir, If you do hold the same intent wherein You wish'd us parties, we'll deliver you Of your great danger.

src: Sound trumpet; Edward shall be here proclaim'd: Come, fellow-soldier, make thou proclamation.
trg: Edward the Fourth, by the grace of God, king of England and France, and lord of Ireland, &c.

src: My lord, stand back, and let the coffin pass.
trg: Unmanner'd dog! stand thou, when I command: Advance thy halbert higher than my breast, Or, by Saint Paul, I'll strike thee to my foot, And spurn upon thee, beggar, for thy boldness.

src: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not? What, shall I be appointed hours; as though, belike, I knew not what to take and what to leave, ha?
trg: You may go to the devil's dam: your gifts are so good, here's none will hold you. Their love is not so great, Hortensio, but we may blow our nails together, and fast it fairly out:

src: For hunting was his daily exercise.
trg: My brother was too careless of his charge. But let us hence, my sovereign, to provide A salve for any sore that may betide.

src: I thought thou hadst been resolute.
trg: So I am, to let him live.

src: Gentlemen, God save you. If I may be bold, Tell me, I beseech you, which is the readiest way To the house of Signior Baptista Minola?
trg: He that has the two fair daughters: is't he you mean?

src: Pray you then, Conduct me to the queen.
trg: I may not, madam: To the contrary I have express commandment.

src: I do not say 'thwack our general;' but he was always good enough for him.
trg: Come, we are fellows and friends: he was ever too hard for him; I have heard him say so himself.

src: Well, you'll answer this one day. Fare ye well.
trg: Nay, tarry; I'll go along with thee I can tell thee pretty tales of the duke.

src: What, by a horseman, or a footman?
trg: A footman, sweet sir, a footman.

src: Do your will.
trg: Away! the tribunes do attend you: arm yourself To answer mildly; for they are prepared With accusations, as I hear, more strong Than are upon you yet.

src: Montague, Montague, for Lancaster!
trg: Thou and thy brother both shall buy this treason Even with the dearest blood your bodies bear.

src: Go, signify as much, while here we march Upon the grassy carpet of this plain.
trg: Let's march without the noise of threatening drum, That from this castle's tatter'd battlements Our fair appointments may be well perused.

src: You had much ado to make his anchor hold: When you cast out, it still came home.
trg: Didst note it?

src: was it you that would be England's king? Was't you that revell'd in our parliament, And made a preachment of your high descent? Where are your mess of sons to back you now?
trg: The wanton Edward, and the lusty George? And where's that valiant crook-back prodigy, Dicky your boy, that with his grumbling voice Was wont to cheer his dad in mutinies?

src: Thou wrong'st it, more than tears, with that report.
trg: That is no slander, sir, which is a truth; And what I spake, I spake it to my face.

src: O despiteful love! unconstant womankind! I tell thee, Licio, this is wonderful.
trg: Mistake no more: I am not Licio, Nor a musician, as I seem to be; But one that scorn to live in this disguise, For such a one as leaves a gentleman, And makes a god of such a cullion:

src: O woful time!
trg: Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail, Ties up my tongue, and will not let me speak.

src: I will then give it you soundly.
trg: What will you give us?

src: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.
trg: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.

src: Light vanity, insatiate cormorant, Consuming means, soon preys upon itself.
trg: England, bound in with the triumphant sea Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege Of watery Neptune, is now bound in with shame, With inky blots and rotten parchment bonds:

src: If you, Hortensio, Or Signior Gremio, you, know any such, Prefer them hither; for to cunning men I will be very kind, and liberal To mine own children in good bringing up: And so farewell.
trg: Katharina, you may stay; For I have more to commune with Bianca.

src: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.
trg: Gentlemen, God save you. If I may be bold, Tell me, I beseech you, which is the readiest way To the house of Signior Baptista Minola?

src: Consider further, That when he speaks not like a citizen, You find him like a soldier:
trg: do not take His rougher accents for malicious sounds, But, as I say, such as become a soldier, Rather than envy you.

src: True, when avoided grace makes destiny: My babes were destined to a fairer death, If grace had bless'd thee with a fairer life.
trg: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.

src: If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations; he hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition. What shouts are these? The other side o' the city is risen: why stay we prating here?
trg: to the Capitol!
Since what I am to say must be but that Which contradicts my accusation and The testimony on my part no other But what comes from myself, it shall scarce boot me To say 'not guilty:

src: The tender love I bear your grace, my lord, Makes me most forward in this noble presence To doom the offenders, whatsoever they be I say, my lord, they have deserved death.
trg: Then be your eyes the witness of this ill: See how I am bewitch'd; behold mine arm Is, like a blasted sapling, wither'd up:

src: If so thou think'st, vex him with eager words.
trg: Clifford, ask mercy and obtain no grace.

src: If not, Signior Gremio: And so, I take my leave, and thank you both.
trg: Adieu, good neighbour. Now I fear thee not: Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool To give thee all, and in his waning age Set foot under thy table: tut, a toy!

src: Well; what has he done?
trg: A woman.

src: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.
trg: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.

src: 'Twas my inheritance, as the earldom was.
trg: Thy father was a traitor to the crown.

src: Your aery buildeth in our aery's nest. O God, that seest it, do not suffer it! As it was won with blood, lost be it so!
trg: Have done! for shame, if not for charity.

src: But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks, Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass; I, that am rudely stamp'd, and want love's majesty To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;
trg: Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace, Have no delight to pass away the time, Unless to spy my shadow in the sun And descant on mine own deformity:

src: Ay, now methinks I hear great Warwick speak: Ne'er may he live to see a sunshine day, That cries 'Retire,' if Warwick bid him stay.
trg: Lord Warwick, on thy shoulder will I lean; And when thou fail'st--as God forbid the hour!-- Must Edward fall, which peril heaven forfend!

src: I'll warrant him for drowning; though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as an unstanched wench.
trg: Lay her a-hold, a-hold! set her two courses off to sea again; lay her off.

src: And stay thy lady too that lives in thee, By doing damned hate upon thyself? Why rail'st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?
trg: Since birth, and heaven, and earth, all three do meet In thee at once; which thou at once wouldst lose. Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit;

src: My father's death--
trg: Thy life hath that dishonour'd.

src: For Gloucester's death, I slew him not; but to my own disgrace Neglected my sworn duty in that case. This is my fault:
trg: as for the rest appeall'd, It issues from the rancour of a villain, A recreant and most degenerate traitor Which in myself I boldly will defend;

src: Madam, I have a touch of your condition, Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.
trg: O, let me speak!

src: O, 'tis the cunning livery of hell, The damned'st body to invest and cover In prenzie guards! Dost thou think, Claudio? If I would yield him my virginity, Thou mightst be freed.
trg: O heavens! it cannot be.

src: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold In him that did object the same to thee;
trg: He was the wretched'st thing when he was young, So long a-growing and so leisurely, That, if this rule were true, he should be gracious.

src: So. What trade are you of, sir?
trg: Tapster; a poor widow's tapster.

src: O, break, my heart! poor bankrupt, break at once! To prison, eyes, ne'er look on liberty! Vile earth, to earth resign; end motion here; And thou and Romeo press one heavy bier!
trg: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had! O courteous Tybalt! honest gentleman! That ever I should live to see thee dead!

src: Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower. Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes Whom envy hath immured within your walls! Rough cradle for such little pretty ones!
trg: Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow For tender princes, use my babies well! So foolish sorrow bids your stones farewell.

src: Come hither, sirrah. Can you cut off a man's head?
trg: If the man be a bachelor, sir, I can; but if he be a married man, he's his wife's head, and I can never cut off a woman's head.

src: Twenty-three days They have been absent: 'tis good speed; foretells The great Apollo suddenly will have The truth of this appear. Prepare you, lords;
trg: Summon a session, that we may arraign Our most disloyal lady, for, as she hath Been publicly accused, so shall she have A just and open trial. While she lives My heart will be a burthen to me.

src: Beshrew me, but his passion moves me so That hardly can I cheque my eyes from tears.
trg: That face of his the hungry cannibals Would not have touch'd, would not have stain'd with blood: But you are more inhuman, more inexorable, O, ten times more, than tigers of Hyrcania.

src: A little more lenity to lechery would do no harm in him: something too crabbed that way, friar.
trg: It is too general a vice, and severity must cure it.
Shepherdess, A fair one are you--well you fit our ages With flowers of winter.

src: This is the place; there, where the torch doth burn.
trg: The ground is bloody; search about the churchyard: Go, some of you, whoe'er you find attach. Pitiful sight!

src: Strong as a tower in hope, I cry amen.
trg: Go bear this lance to Thomas, Duke of Norfolk.

src: and give no foot of ground!' And cried 'A crown, or else a glorious tomb! A sceptre, or an earthly sepulchre!' With this, we charged again: but, out, alas! We bodged again;
trg: as I have seen a swan With bootless labour swim against the tide And spend her strength with over-matching waves. Ah, hark! the fatal followers do pursue; And I am faint and cannot fly their fury:

src: Speakest thou from thy heart?
trg: And from my soul too; Or else beshrew them both.

src: I was moved withal.
trg: I dare be sworn you were: And, sir, it is no little thing to make Mine eyes to sweat compassion. But, good sir, What peace you'll make, advise me: for my part, I'll not to Rome, I'll back with you;

src: Katharina, you may stay; For I have more to commune with Bianca.
trg: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not? What, shall I be appointed hours; as though, belike, I knew not what to take and what to leave, ha?

src: Not yet, I thee beseech: For ever will I walk upon my knees, And never see day that the happy sees, Till thou give joy; until thou bid me joy, By pardoning Rutland, my transgressing boy.
trg: Unto my mother's prayers I bend my knee.

src: My lord of Ely!
trg: My lord?

src: His nature is too noble for the world: He would not flatter Neptune for his trident, Or Jove for's power to thunder. His heart's his mouth: What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent;
trg: And, being angry, does forget that ever He heard the name of death. Here's goodly work!

src: Now Jove afford you cause! To me the difference forges dread; your greatness Hath not been used to fear. Even now I tremble To think your father, by some accident, Should pass this way as you did:
trg: O, the Fates! How would he look, to see his work so noble Vilely bound up? What would he say? Or how Should I, in these my borrow'd flaunts, behold The sternness of his presence?

src: And brief, good mother; for I am in haste.
trg: Art thou so hasty? I have stay'd for thee, God knows, in anguish, pain and agony.

src: What was your dream? I long to hear you tell it.
trg: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower, And was embark'd to cross to Burgundy; And, in my company, my brother Gloucester; Who from my cabin tempted me to walk Upon the hatches:

src: O noble lord, bethink thee of thy birth, Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment And banish hence these abject lowly dreams.
trg: Look how thy servants do attend on thee, Each in his office ready at thy beck. Wilt thou have music? hark! Apollo plays, And twenty caged nightingales do sing: Or wilt thou sleep?

src: who, if I Had servants true about me, that bare eyes To see alike mine honour as their profits, Their own particular thrifts, they would do that Which should undo more doing:
trg: Which draught to me were cordial.

src: O, what cause have I, Thine being but a moiety of my grief, To overgo thy plaints and drown thy cries!
trg: Good aunt, you wept not for our father's death; How can we aid you with our kindred tears?

src: What means Sicilia?
trg: He something seems unsettled.

src: What's in a name? that which we call a rose By any other name would smell as sweet; So Romeo would, were he not Romeo call'd, Retain that dear perfection which he owes Without that title.
trg: Romeo, doff thy name, And for that name which is no part of thee Take all myself.

src: Now sways it this way, like a mighty sea Forced by the tide to combat with the wind; Now sways it that way, like the selfsame sea Forced to retire by fury of the wind:
trg: Sometime the flood prevails, and then the wind; Now one the better, then another best; Both tugging to be victors, breast to breast, Yet neither conqueror nor conquered:

src: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.
trg: We are the queen's abjects, and must obey. Brother, farewell: I will unto the king;

src: Behold, behold. where Madam Mitigation comes! I have purchased as many diseases under her roof as come to--
trg: To what, I pray?

src: He was too hard for him directly, to say the troth on't: before Corioli he scotched him and notched him like a carbon ado.
trg: An he had been cannibally given, he might have broiled and eaten him too.

src: I could not send it,--here it is again,-- Nor get a messenger to bring it thee, So fearful were they of infection.
trg: Unhappy fortune! by my brotherhood, The letter was not nice but full of charge Of dear import, and the neglecting it May do much danger. Friar John, go hence;

src: Must die to-morrow! O injurious love, That respites me a life, whose very comfort Is still a dying horror!
trg: 'Tis pity of him.

src: I do; and bear the shame most patiently.
trg: I'll teach you how you shall arraign your conscience, And try your penitence, if it be sound, Or hollowly put on.

src: A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.
trg: No cock of mine; you crow too like a craven.

src: Why, so I am, in mind; and that's enough.
trg: But, if thou be a king, where is thy crown?

src: How! away!
trg: Wife, mother, child, I know not. My affairs Are servanted to others: though I owe My revenge properly, my remission lies In Volscian breasts.

src: Yet in this one thing let me blame your grace, For choosing me when Clarence is in place.
trg: No, Warwick, thou art worthy of the sway, To whom the heavens in thy nativity Adjudged an olive branch and laurel crown, As likely to be blest in peace and war;

src: Now, good Camillo; I am so fraught with curious business that I leave out ceremony.
trg: Sir, I think You have heard of my poor services, i' the love That I have borne your father?

src: So cowards fight when they can fly no further; So doves do peck the falcon's piercing talons; So desperate thieves, all hopeless of their lives, Breathe out invectives 'gainst the officers.
trg: O Clifford, but bethink thee once again, And in thy thought o'er-run my former time;

src: A boy?
trg: A daughter, and a goodly babe, Lusty and like to live: the queen receives Much comfort in't; says 'My poor prisoner, I am innocent as you.'

src: Would the nobility lay aside their ruth, And let me use my sword, I'll make a quarry With thousands of these quarter'd slaves, as high As I could pick my lance.
trg: Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded; For though abundantly they lack discretion, Yet are they passing cowardly. But, I beseech you, What says the other troop?

src: You knew my father well, and in him me, Left solely heir to all his lands and goods, Which I have better'd rather than decreased:
trg: Then tell me, if I get your daughter's love, What dowry shall I have with her to wife?

src: Never?
trg: Never, but once.

src: Thanks. What's the matter, you dissentious rogues, That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion, Make yourselves scabs?
trg: We have ever your good word.

src: Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye Than twenty of their swords: look thou but sweet, And I am proof against their enmity.
trg: I would not for the world they saw thee here.

src: Here pitch our battle; hence we will not budge.
trg: Brave followers, yonder stands the thorny wood, Which, by the heavens' assistance and your strength, Must by the roots be hewn up yet ere night.

src: She dances featly.
trg: So she does any thing; though I report it, That should be silent: if young Doricles Do light upon her, she shall bring him that Which he not dreams of.

src: rests me his minim rest, one, two, and the third in your bosom: the very butcher of a silk button, a duellist, a duellist; a gentleman of the very first house, of the first and second cause:
trg: ah, the immortal passado! the punto reverso! the hai!

src: this reverend holy friar, Our whole city is much bound to him.
trg: Nurse, will you go with me into my closet, To help me sort such needful ornaments As you think fit to furnish me to-morrow?

src: Where is thy power, then, to beat him back? Where are thy tenants and thy followers? Are they not now upon the western shore. Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships!
trg: No, my good lord, my friends are in the north.

src: How now? moody? What is't thou canst demand?
trg: My liberty.

src: 'Tis for the followers fortune widens them, Not for the fliers: mark me, and do the like.
trg: Fool-hardiness; not I.

src: I did but smile till now: Now, good my lord, give me the scope of justice My patience here is touch'd.
trg: I do perceive These poor informal women are no more But instruments of some more mightier member That sets them on: let me have way, my lord, To find this practise out.

src: I call'd thee then vain flourish of my fortune; I call'd thee then poor shadow, painted queen; The presentation of but what I was; The flattering index of a direful pageant;
trg: One heaved a-high, to be hurl'd down below; A mother only mock'd with two sweet babes;

src: Cousin, farewell; and, uncle, bid him so: Six years we banish him, and he shall go.
trg: Cousin, farewell: what presence must not know, From where you do remain let paper show.

src: Do right unto this princely Duke of York, Or I will fill the house with armed men, And over the chair of state, where now he sits, Write up his title with usurping blood.
trg: My Lord of Warwick, hear me but one word: Let me for this my life-time reign as king.

src: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long; Meantime, have patience.
trg: I must perforce. Farewell.

src: Nay, nothing; all is said His tongue is now a stringless instrument; Words, life and all, old Lancaster hath spent.
trg: Be York the next that must be bankrupt so! Though death be poor, it ends a mortal woe.

src: You'll kiss me hard and speak to me as if I were a baby still. I love you better.
trg: And why so, my lord?

src: The main blaze of it is past, but a small thing would make it flame again:
trg: for the nobles receive so to heart the banishment of that worthy Coriolanus, that they are in a ripe aptness to take all power from the people and to pluck from them their tribunes for ever.

src: I mind to tell him plainly what I think.
trg: Now, brother of Clarence, how like you our choice, That you stand pensive, as half malcontent?

src: Help, masters, help! my master is mad.
trg: Now, knock when I bid you, sirrah villain!

src: But my true love is grown to such excess I cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.
trg: Come, come with me, and we will make short work; For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone Till holy church incorporate two in one.

src: Master, some show to welcome us to town.
trg: Gentlemen, importune me no farther, For how I firmly am resolved you know; That is, not bestow my youngest daughter Before I have a husband for the elder:

src: I pay thy poverty, and not thy will.
trg: Put this in any liquid thing you will, And drink it off; and, if you had the strength Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight.

src: Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste To help Cominius.
