trg: Worthy sir, thou bleed'st; Thy exercise hath been too violent for A second course of fight.

src: If his own life answer the straitness of his proceeding, it shall become him well; wherein if he chance to fail, he hath sentenced himself.
trg: I am going to visit the prisoner. Fare you well.

src: Ay me!
trg: She speaks: O, speak again, bright angel!

src: Age, thou hast lost thy labour.
trg: Why, sir?

src: Take thou this vial, being then in bed, And this distilled liquor drink thou off;
trg: When presently through all thy veins shall run A cold and drowsy humour, for no pulse Shall keep his native progress, but surcease: No warmth, no breath, shall testify thou livest;

src: Have I had children's voices?
trg: Tribunes, give way; he shall to the market-place.

src: Then, Warwick, thus: our sister shall be Edward's; And now forthwith shall articles be drawn Touching the jointure that your king must make, Which with her dowry shall be counterpoised.
trg: Draw near, Queen Margaret, and be a witness That Bona shall be wife to the English king.

src: Sweet love, I see, changing his property, Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate: Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made With heads, and not with hands;
trg: those whom you curse Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound And lie full low, graved in the hollow ground.

src: how he glisters Thorough my rust! and how his pity Does my deeds make the blacker!
trg: Woe the while! O, cut my lace, lest my heart, cracking it, Break too.

src: Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.
trg: Speak, speak.

src: Nay, not so neither: but I take him to be the greater soldier.
trg: Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that: for the defence of a town, our general is excellent.

src: You're a made old man: if the sins of your youth are forgiven you, you're well to live. Gold! all gold!
trg: This is fairy gold, boy, and 'twill prove so: up with't, keep it close: home, home, the next way. We are lucky, boy; and to be so still requires nothing but secrecy. Let my sheep go:

src: What should it be, that they so shriek abroad?
trg: The people in the street cry Romeo, Some Juliet, and some Paris; and all run, With open outcry toward our monument.

src: so our decrees, Dead to infliction, to themselves are dead; And liberty plucks justice by the nose; The baby beats the nurse, and quite athwart Goes all decorum.
trg: It rested in your grace To unloose this tied-up justice when you pleased: And it in you more dreadful would have seem'd Than in Lord Angelo.

src: Ah, my young princes! ah, my tender babes! My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets!
trg: If yet your gentle souls fly in the air And be not fix'd in doom perpetual, Hover about me with your airy wings And hear your mother's lamentation!

src: and therefore hence amain.
trg: Away! for vengeance comes along with them: Nay, stay not to expostulate, make speed; Or else come after: I'll away before.

src: Why, that is nothing: for I tell you, father, I am as peremptory as she proud-minded; And where two raging fires meet together They do consume the thing that feeds their fury:
trg: Though little fire grows great with little wind, Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all: So I to her and so she yields to me; For I am rough and woo not like a babe.

src: Return again, and take an oath with thee. Lay on our royal sword your banish'd hands;
trg: Swear by the duty that you owe to God-- Our part therein we banish with yourselves-- To keep the oath that we administer: You never shall, so help you truth and God!

src: Since thou hast far to go, bear not along The clogging burthen of a guilty soul.
trg: No, Bolingbroke: if ever I were traitor, My name be blotted from the book of life, And I from heaven banish'd as from hence! But what thou art, God, thou, and I do know;

src: If thou wilt outstrip death, go cross the seas, And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughter-house, Lest thou increase the number of the dead;
trg: And make me die the thrall of Margaret's curse, Nor mother, wife, nor England's counted queen.

src: This but done, Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours; For they have pardons, being ask'd, as free As words to little purpose.
trg: Prithee now, Go, and be ruled: although I know thou hadst rather Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf Than flatter him in a bower. Here is Cominius.

src: You rogue, I have been drinking all night; I am not fitted for 't.
trg: O, the better, sir; for he that drinks all night, and is hanged betimes in the morning, may sleep the sounder all the next day.

src: 'Tis a very excellent piece of work, madam lady: would 'twere done!
trg: Verona, for a while I take my leave, To see my friends in Padua, but of all My best beloved and approved friend, Hortensio; and I trow this is his house. Here, sirrah Grumio; knock, I say.

src: Flower of warriors, How is it with Titus Lartius?
trg: As with a man busied about decrees: Condemning some to death, and some to exile; Ransoming him, or pitying, threatening the other;

src: That's a good deed. If thou mayest discern by that which is left of him what he is, fetch me to the sight of him.
trg: Marry, will I; and you shall help to put him i' the ground.

src: Am I like such a fellow?
trg: Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as soon moody to be moved.

src: My lord?
trg: Saw'st thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?

src: In ivory coffers I have stuff'd my crowns; then, at my farm I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail, Sixscore fat oxen standing in my stalls, And all things answerable to this portion.
trg: Myself am struck in years, I must confess; And if I die to-morrow, this is hers, If whilst I live she will be only mine.

src: La you now, you hear: When she will take the rein I let her run; But she'll not stumble.
trg: Good my liege, I come;

src: and, for the ordering your affairs, To sing them too: when you do dance, I wish you A wave o' the sea, that you might ever do Nothing but that; move still, still so, And own no other function:
trg: each your doing, So singular in each particular, Crowns what you are doing in the present deed, That all your acts are queens.

src: But stir not you till you have well determined Upon these slanderers.
trg: My lord, we'll do it throughly. Signior Lucio, did not you say you knew that Friar Lodowick to be a dishonest person?

src: And here's the heart that triumphs in their death And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother To execute the like upon thyself; And so, have at thee!
trg: Nay Warwick, single out some other chase; For I myself will hunt this wolf to death. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: And she will speak most bitterly and strange.
trg: Most strange, but yet most truly, will I speak: That Angelo's forsworn; is it not strange? That Angelo's a murderer; is 't not strange?

src: Good heart, at what?
trg: At thy good heart's oppression.

src: Pray, let us go.
trg: Do they still fly to the Roman?

src: Why, no; for he hath made a solemn vow Never to lie and take his natural rest Till Warwick or himself be quite suppress'd.
trg: To-morrow then belike shall be the day, If Warwick be so near as men report.

src: A dog of that house shall move me to stand: I will take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.
trg: That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes to the wall.
I cannot do't without counters. Let me see; what am I to buy for our sheep-shearing feast? Three pound of sugar, five pound of currants, rice,--what will this sister of mine do with rice?

src: Her eldest sister is so curst and shrewd That till the father rid his hands of her, Master, your love must live a maid at home;
trg: And therefore has he closely mew'd her up, Because she will not be annoy'd with suitors.

src: and having but two in the dish, as I said, Master Froth here, this very man, having eaten the rest, as I said, and, as I say, paying for them very honestly;
trg: for, as you know, Master Froth, I could not give you three-pence again.

src: Here, most gracious liege.
trg: Norfolk, we must have knocks; ha! must we not?

src: Truly, sir, I would desire you to clap into your prayers; for, look you, the warrant's come.
trg: You rogue, I have been drinking all night; I am not fitted for 't.

src: By mine honesty, If she be mad,--as I believe no other,-- Her madness hath the oddest frame of sense, Such a dependency of thing on thing, As e'er I heard in madness.
trg: O gracious duke, Harp not on that, nor do not banish reason For inequality; but let your reason serve To make the truth appear where it seems hid, And hide the false seems true.

src: but my brother justice have I found so severe, that he hath forced me to tell him he is indeed Justice.
trg: If his own life answer the straitness of his proceeding, it shall become him well; wherein if he chance to fail, he hath sentenced himself.

src: My daughter he hath wedded: I will die, And leave him all; life, living, all is Death's.
trg: Have I thought long to see this morning's face, And doth it give me such a sight as this?

src: Hang 'em! They say! They'll sit by the fire, and presume to know What's done i' the Capitol; who's like to rise, Who thrives and who declines; side factions and give out Conjectural marriages;
trg: making parties strong And feebling such as stand not in their liking Below their cobbled shoes. They say there's grain enough!

src: Which if thou please to hide in this true bosom. And let the soul forth that adoreth thee, I lay it naked to the deadly stroke, And humbly beg the death upon my knee. Nay, do not pause;
trg: for I did kill King Henry, But 'twas thy beauty that provoked me. Nay, now dispatch; 'twas I that stabb'd young Edward, But 'twas thy heavenly face that set me on.

src: Let him be but testimonied in his own bringings-forth, and he shall appear to the envious a scholar, a statesman and a soldier. Therefore you speak unskilfully:
trg: or if your knowledge be more it is much darkened in your malice.

src: Defy them then, or else hold close thy lips.
trg: I prithee, give no limits to my tongue: I am a king, and privileged to speak.

src: Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while, Till we can clear these ambiguities, And know their spring, their head, their true descent;
trg: And then will I be general of your woes, And lead you even to death: meantime forbear, And let mischance be slave to patience. Bring forth the parties of suspicion.

src: My Lord Northumberland, see them dispatch'd. Uncle, you say the queen is at your house; For God's sake, fairly let her be entreated: Tell her I send to her my kind commends;
trg: Take special care my greetings be deliver'd.

src: What, what, what? let's partake.
trg: I would not be a Roman, of all nations; I had as lieve be a condemned man.

src: Let's have that, good sir. Come on, sit down: come on, and do your best To fright me with your sprites; you're powerful at it.
trg: There was a man--

src: Many years of happy days befal My gracious sovereign, my most loving liege!
trg: Each day still better other's happiness; Until the heavens, envying earth's good hap, Add an immortal title to your crown!

src: There is a lord will hear you play to-night: But I am doubtful of your modesties;
trg: Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior,-- For yet his honour never heard a play-- You break into some merry passion And so offend him; for I tell you, sirs, If you should smile he grows impatient.

src: Romeo! my cousin Romeo!
trg: He is wise; And, on my lie, hath stol'n him home to bed.

src: So I am, to let him live.
trg: Back to the Duke of Gloucester, tell him so.

src: See where she comes from shrift with merry look.
trg: How now, my headstrong! where have you been gadding?

src: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu; I will to Venice; Sunday comes apace: We will have rings and things and fine array; And kiss me, Kate, we will be married o'Sunday.
trg: Was ever match clapp'd up so suddenly?

src: Content.
trg: A match! 'tis done.

src: Why, say, fair queen, whence springs this deep despair?
trg: From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears And stops my tongue, while heart is drown'd in cares.

src: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.
trg: My remedy is then, to pluck it out.

src: Do you hear how we are shent for keeping your greatness back?
trg: What cause, do you think, I have to swoon?

src: You have told me too many of him already, sir, if they be true; if not true, none were enough.
trg: I was once before him for getting a wench with child.

src: therefore shall he die, And I'll renew me in his fall. But, hark!
trg: Your native town you enter'd like a post, And had no welcomes home: but he returns, Splitting the air with noise.

src: To sit upon a hill, as I do now, To carve out dials quaintly, point by point, Thereby to see the minutes how they run, How many make the hour full complete; How many hours bring about the day;
trg: How many days will finish up the year; How many years a mortal man may live. When this is known, then to divide the times: So many hours must I tend my flock; So many hours must I take my rest;

src: Show me thy humble heart, and not thy knee, Whose duty is deceiveable and false.
trg: My gracious uncle--

src: Stanley, he is your wife's son well, look to it.
trg: My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise, For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd; The earldom of Hereford and the moveables The which you promised I should possess.

src: Prevent it, resist it, let it not be so, Lest child, child's children, cry against you woe!
trg: Well have you argued, sir; and, for your pains, Of capital treason we arrest you here. My Lord of Westminster, be it your charge To keep him safely till his day of trial.

src: She shall not.
trg: I say she shall: and first begin with her.

src: You are gentlemen of brave metal; you would lift the moon out of her sphere, if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.
trg: We would so, and then go a bat-fowling.

src: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.
trg: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.

src: Amen.
trg: Will the king come, that I may breathe my last In wholesome counsel to his unstaid youth?

src: Faith, he is gone unto the taming-school.
trg: The taming-school! what, is there such a place?

src: Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam. Take all the swift advantage of the hours; You shall have letters from me to my son To meet you on the way, and welcome you.
trg: Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.

src: Seven year and a half, sir.
trg: I thought, by your readiness in the office, you had continued in it some time. You say, seven years together?

src: For though usurpers sway the rule awhile, Yet heavens are just, and time suppresseth wrongs.
trg: Injurious Margaret!

src: Why, then, let's on our way in silent sort: For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George! 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Come on, my masters, each man take his stand: The king by this is set him down to sleep.

src: Marcius!
trg: Ay, Marcius, Caius Marcius: dost thou think I'll grace thee with that robbery, thy stol'n name Coriolanus in Corioli?

src: I mean, an we be in choler, we'll draw.
trg: Ay, while you live, draw your neck out o' the collar.

src: She says your worship means to make a puppet of her.
trg: O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest, thou thread, thou thimble, Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail! Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou!

src: Now sir, the sound that tells what hour it is Are clamorous groans, which strike upon my heart, Which is the bell: so sighs and tears and groans Show minutes, times, and hours:
trg: but my time Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's proud joy, While I stand fooling here, his Jack o' the clock. This music mads me; let it sound no more;

src: I fear me both are false.
trg: Then never man was true.

src: That, being mad herself, she's madly mated.
trg: I warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.

src: Now God in heaven bless thee! Hark you, sir.
trg: What say'st thou, my dear nurse?

src: Speak thou for me and tell them what I did.
trg: Richard hath best deserved of all my sons. But is your grace dead, my Lord of Somerset?

src: No, coz, I rather weep.
trg: Good heart, at what?

src: You'll mar all: I'll leave you: pray you, speak to 'em, I pray you, In wholesome manner.
trg: Bid them wash their faces And keep their teeth clean. So, here comes a brace. You know the cause, air, of my standing here.

src: And interchangeably hurl down my gage Upon this overweening traitor's foot, To prove myself a loyal gentleman Even in the best blood chamber'd in his bosom.
trg: In haste whereof, most heartily I pray Your highness to assign our trial day.

src: And let our hearts and eyes, like civil war, Be blind with tears, and break o'ercharged with grief.
trg: Thou that so stoutly hast resisted me, Give me thy gold, if thou hast any gold: For I have bought it with an hundred blows. But let me see: is this our foeman's face?

src: O Kate, content thee; prithee, be not angry.
trg: I will be angry: what hast thou to do? Father, be quiet; he shall stay my leisure.

src: Where doth the world thrust forth a vanity-- So it be new, there's no respect how vile-- That is not quickly buzzed into his ears?
trg: Then all too late comes counsel to be heard, Where will doth mutiny with wit's regard. Direct not him whose way himself will choose: 'Tis breath thou lack'st, and that breath wilt thou lose.

src: Since arm from arm that voice doth us affray, Hunting thee hence with hunt's-up to the day, O, now be gone; more light and light it grows.
trg: More light and light; more dark and dark our woes!

src: Raised only, that the weaker sort may wish Good Marcius home again.
trg: The very trick on't.

src: O, she that might have intercepted thee, By strangling thee in her accursed womb From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done!
trg: Hidest thou that forehead with a golden crown, Where should be graven, if that right were right, The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown, And the dire death of my two sons and brothers?

src: In God's name, cheerly on, courageous friends, To reap the harvest of perpetual peace By this one bloody trial of sharp war.
trg: Every man's conscience is a thousand swords, To fight against that bloody homicide.

src: Revoke that doom of mercy, for 'tis Clifford;
trg: From off the gates of York fetch down the head, Your father's head, which Clifford placed there; Instead whereof let this supply the room: Measure for measure must be answered.

src: How will my wife for slaughter of my son Shed seas of tears and ne'er be satisfied!
trg: How will the country for these woful chances Misthink the king and not be satisfied!

src: I do not, sir.
trg: Thou liest, malignant thing! Hast thou forgot The foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy Was grown into a hoop? hast thou forgot her?

src: Mine were the very cipher of a function, To fine the faults whose fine stands in record, And let go by the actor.
trg: O just but severe law! I had a brother, then. Heaven keep your honour!

src: What is the matter?
trg: Peace, foolish woman.

src: My name is Caius Marcius, who hath done To thee particularly and to all the Volsces Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness may My surname, Coriolanus:
trg: the painful service, The extreme dangers and the drops of blood Shed for my thankless country are requited But with that surname;

src: Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.
trg: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.

src: For shame, come down: he made thee Duke of York.
trg: 'Twas my inheritance, as the earldom was.

src: Shall I be heard?
trg: Who is't that goes with me? Beseech your highness, My women may be with me; for you see My plight requires it. Do not weep, good fools; There is no cause:

src: If that thy valour stand on sympathy, There is my gage, Aumerle, in gage to thine:
trg: By that fair sun which shows me where thou stand'st, I heard thee say, and vauntingly thou spakest it That thou wert cause of noble Gloucester's death. If thou deny'st it twenty times, thou liest;

src: I have no tongue but one: gentle my lord, Let me entreat you speak the former language.
trg: Plainly conceive, I love you.

src: Upon the stroke of ten.
trg: Well, let it strike.

src: My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks:
trg: O, if thine eye be not a flatterer, Come thou on my side, and entreat for me, As you would beg, were you in my distress A begging prince what beggar pities not?

src: Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.
trg: Not since widow Dido's time.

src: Our Earl of Warwick, Edward's greatest friend.
trg: Welcome, brave Warwick! What brings thee to France?

src: What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty, As those two eyes become that heavenly face? Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee. Sweet Kate, embrace her for her beauty's sake.
trg: A' will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.

src: And, Montague, come you this afternoon, To know our further pleasure in this case, To old Free-town, our common judgment-place. Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.
trg: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach? Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?

src: He was drunk then, my lord: it can be no better.
trg: For the benefit of silence, would thou wert so too!

src: And yet within these five hours lived Lord Hastings, Untainted, unexamined, free, at liberty Here's a good world the while! Why who's so gross, That seeth not this palpable device?
trg: Yet who's so blind, but says he sees it not? Bad is the world; and all will come to nought, When such bad dealings must be seen in thought.

src: Not possible.
trg: The nobles in great earnestness are going All to the senate-house: some news is come That turns their countenances.

src: Mercutio and his brother Valentine; mine uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; my fair niece Rosaline; Livia; Signior Valentio and his cousin Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.' A fair assembly:
trg: whither should they come?

src: Three glorious suns, each one a perfect sun; Not separated with the racking clouds, But sever'd in a pale clear-shining sky. See, see!
trg: they join, embrace, and seem to kiss, As if they vow'd some league inviolable: Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun. In this the heaven figures some event.

src: I am, as thy general is.
trg: Then you should hate Rome, as he does. Can you think to blow out the intended fire your city is ready to flame in, with such weak breath as this? No, you are deceived;

src: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.
trg: Pink for flower.

src: This shall be done, good father, presently. But Barnardine must die this afternoon: And how shall we continue Claudio, To save me from the danger that might come If he were known alive?
trg: Let this be done. Put them in secret holds, both Barnardine and Claudio: Ere twice the sun hath made his journal greeting To the under generation, you shall find Your safety manifested.

src: That is no slander, sir, which is a truth; And what I spake, I spake it to my face.
trg: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slander'd it.

src: Has he dined, canst thou tell? for I would not speak with him till after dinner.
trg: You are a Roman, are you?

src: What's gone and what's past help Should be past grief: do not receive affliction At my petition; I beseech you, rather Let me be punish'd, that have minded you Of what you should forget.
trg: Now, good my liege Sir, royal sir, forgive a foolish woman: The love I bore your queen--lo, fool again!-- I'll speak of her no more, nor of your children;

src: My lord, I like not of this flight of Edward's; For doubtless Burgundy will yield him help, And we shall have more wars before 't be long.
trg: As Henry's late presaging prophecy Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond, So doth my heart misgive me, in these conflicts What may befall him, to his harm and ours:

src: Here comes the Lady Paulina's steward: he can deliver you more. How goes it now, sir? this news which is called true is so like an old tale, that the verity of it is in strong suspicion:
trg: has the king found his heir?

src: Twenty crowns.
trg: Twenty crowns! I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound, But twenty times so much upon my wife.

src: And I in all unwillingness will go. I would to God that the inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow Were red-hot steel, to sear me to the brain!
trg: Anointed let me be with deadly venom, And die, ere men can say, God save the queen!

src: why, he sings 'em over as they were gods or goddesses; you would think a smock were a she-angel, he so chants to the sleeve-hand and the work about the square on't.
trg: Prithee bring him in; and let him approach singing.

src: Welcome, you;--how now, you;-- what, you;--fellow, you;--and thus much for greeting. Now, my spruce companions, is all ready, and all things neat?
trg: All things is ready. How near is our master?

src: These words hereafter thy tormentors be! Convey me to my bed, then to my grave: Love they to live that love and honour have.
trg: And let them die that age and sullens have; For both hast thou, and both become the grave.

src: For there it is, crack'd in a hundred shivers. Mark, silent king, the moral of this sport, How soon my sorrow hath destroy'd my face.
trg: The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'd The shadow or your face.

src: He did, my lord.
trg: How? what?

src: My lords, before it pleased his majesty To raise my state to title of a queen, Do me but right, and you must all confess That I was not ignoble of descent;
trg: And meaner than myself have had like fortune. But as this title honours me and mine, So your dislike, to whom I would be pleasing, Doth cloud my joys with danger and with sorrow.

src: Bid a sick man in sadness make his will: Ah, word ill urged to one that is so ill! In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.
trg: I aim'd so near, when I supposed you loved.

src: See, your guests approach: Address yourself to entertain them sprightly, And let's be red with mirth.
trg: Fie, daughter! when my old wife lived, upon This day she was both pantler, butler, cook, Both dame and servant; welcomed all, served all; Would sing her song and dance her turn;

src: I would I knew thy heart.
trg: 'Tis figured in my tongue.

src: Now, now: I have not winked since I saw these sights: the men are not yet cold under water, nor the bear half dined on the gentleman: he's at it now.
trg: Would I had been by, to have helped the old man!

src: Butchers and villains! bloody cannibals! How sweet a plant have you untimely cropp'd! You have no children, butchers! if you had, The thought of them would have stirr'd up remorse:
trg: But if you ever chance to have a child, Look in his youth to have him so cut off As, deathmen, you have rid this sweet young prince!

src: Call forth an officer. Carry this mad knave to the gaol. Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forthcoming.
trg: Carry me to the gaol!

src: So then it seems your most offenceful act Was mutually committed?
trg: Mutually.

src: Ay, that he razed.
trg: Why, 'twas a commandment to command the captain and all the rest from their functions: they put forth to steal.

src: Get me an iron crow, and bring it straight Unto my cell.
trg: Brother, I'll go and bring it thee.

src: I am a Roman; and my services are, as you are, against 'em: know you me yet?
trg: Nicanor? no.

src: Which is his house, beseech you?
trg: This, here before you.

src: To whom, my lord?
trg: Why, Clarence, to myself.

src: A good demand.
trg: Why force you this?

src: Commend me to my wife. I'll return consul; Or never trust to what my tongue can do I' the way of flattery further.
trg: Do your will.

src: that it was no better than picture-like to hang by the wall, if renown made it not stir, was pleased to let him seek danger where he was like to find fame. To a cruel war I sent him;
trg: from whence he returned, his brows bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I sprang not more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child than now in first seeing he had proved himself a man.

src: Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded; For though abundantly they lack discretion, Yet are they passing cowardly. But, I beseech you, What says the other troop?
trg: They are dissolved: hang 'em! They said they were an-hungry;

src: Sir, you yourself Have said and writ so, but your writing now Is colder than that theme, 'She had not been, Nor was not to be equall'd;'--thus your verse Flow'd with her beauty once:
trg: 'tis shrewdly ebb'd, To say you have seen a better.

src: Come, therefore, let us fly while we may fly: If Warwick take us we are sure to die. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Now, my Lord Hastings and Sir William Stanley, Leave off to wonder why I drew you hither, Into this chiefest thicket of the park. Thus stands the case:

src: for once or twice I was about to speak and tell him plainly, The selfsame sun that shines upon his court Hides not his visage from our cottage but Looks on alike. Will't please you, sir, be gone?
trg: I told you what would come of this: beseech you, Of your own state take care: this dream of mine,-- Being now awake, I'll queen it no inch farther, But milk my ewes and weep.

src: Tybalt, my cousin! O my brother's child! O prince! O cousin! husband! O, the blood is spilt O my dear kinsman! Prince, as thou art true, For blood of ours, shed blood of Montague. O cousin, cousin!
trg: Benvolio, who began this bloody fray?

src: How now, Abhorson? what's the news with you?
trg: Truly, sir, I would desire you to clap into your prayers; for, look you, the warrant's come.

src: Love you the man that wrong'd you?
trg: Yes, as I love the woman that wrong'd him.

src: I'll see thee hang'd on Sunday first.
trg: Hark, Petruchio; she says she'll see thee hang'd first.

src: They that stand high have many blasts to shake them; And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.
trg: Good counsel, marry: learn it, learn it, marquess.

src: yet, good deed, Leontes, I love thee not a jar o' the clock behind What lady-she her lord. You'll stay?
trg: No, madam.
The law hath not been dead, though it hath slept: Those many had not dared to do that evil, If the first that did the edict infringe Had answer'd for his deed:

src: Fell sorrow's tooth doth never rankle more Than when he bites, but lanceth not the sore.
trg: Come, come, my son, I'll bring thee on thy way: Had I thy youth and cause, I would not stay.

src: Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise. If, Biondello, thou wert come ashore, We could at once put us in readiness, And take a lodging fit to entertain Such friends as time in Padua shall beget.
trg: But stay a while: what company is this?

src: To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace. When have I injured thee? when done thee wrong? Or thee? or thee? or any of your faction? A plague upon you all!
trg: His royal person,-- Whom God preserve better than you would wish!-- Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing-while, But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.

src: and there's all the love they bear us.
trg: Either you must Confess yourselves wondrous malicious, Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you A pretty tale: it may be you have heard it;

src: This cannot be but a great courtier.
trg: His garments are rich, but he wears them not handsomely.

src: 'Tis very true: you were in presence then; And you can witness with me this is true.
trg: As false, by heaven, as heaven itself is true.

src: I think there's never a man in Christendom That can less hide his love or hate than he; For by his face straight shall you know his heart.
trg: What of his heart perceive you in his face By any likelihood he show'd to-day?

src: As Henry's late presaging prophecy Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond, So doth my heart misgive me, in these conflicts What may befall him, to his harm and ours:
trg: Therefore, Lord Oxford, to prevent the worst, Forthwith we'll send him hence to Brittany, Till storms be past of civil enmity.

src: Ay, by any means prove a tall fellow: if I do not wonder how thou darest venture to be drunk, not being a tall fellow, trust me not. Hark!
trg: the kings and the princes, our kindred, are going to see the queen's picture. Come, follow us: we'll be thy good masters.

src: Come hither to me, Master Elbow; come hither, Master constable. How long have you been in this place of constable?
trg: Seven year and a half, sir.

src: No! why? O, when, I say, I look'd on Richard's face, This was my wish: 'Be thou,' quoth I, ' accursed, For making me, so young, so old a widow! And, when thou wed'st, let sorrow haunt thy bed;
trg: And be thy wife--if any be so mad-- As miserable by the life of thee As thou hast made me by my dear lord's death!

src: Ay, full as dearly as I love myself.
trg: And would you not do much to do them good?

src: and even so The general, subject to a well-wish'd king, Quit their own part, and in obsequious fondness Crowd to his presence, where their untaught love Must needs appear offence. How now, fair maid?
trg: I am come to know your pleasure.

src: Withdraw yourselves, and leave us here alone. What is the matter with our cousin now?
trg: For ever may my knees grow to the earth, My tongue cleave to my roof within my mouth Unless a pardon ere I rise or speak.

src: thousand escapes of wit Make thee the father of their idle dreams And rack thee in their fancies. Welcome, how agreed?
trg: She'll take the enterprise upon her, father, If you advise it.

src: I will tell the king all, every word, yea, and his son's pranks too; who, I may say, is no honest man, neither to his father nor to me, to go about to make me the king's brother-in-law.
trg: Indeed, brother-in-law was the farthest off you could have been to him and then your blood had been the dearer by I know how much an ounce.

src: O general, Here is the steed, we the caparison: Hadst thou beheld--
trg: Pray now, no more: my mother, Who has a charter to extol her blood, When she does praise me grieves me. I have done As you have done; that's what I can; induced As you have been;

src: for he holds vengeance in his hands, To hurl upon their heads that break his law.
trg: And that same vengeance doth he hurl on thee, For false forswearing and for murder too: Thou didst receive the holy sacrament, To fight in quarrel of the house of Lancaster.

src: if any where I have them, 'tis by the seaside, browsing of ivy. Good luck, an't be thy will what have we here! Mercy on 's, a barne a very pretty barne! A boy or a child, I wonder? A pretty one;
trg: a very pretty one: sure, some 'scape: though I am not bookish, yet I can read waiting-gentlewoman in the 'scape. This has been some stair-work, some trunk-work, some behind-door-work:

src: O, good sir, I do.
trg: I pray thee, mark me. and my trust, Like a good parent, did beget of him A falsehood in its contrary as great As my trust was; which had indeed no limit, A confidence sans bound.

src: Be it with resolution then to fight.
trg: My royal father, cheer these noble lords And hearten those that fight in your defence: Unsheathe your sword, good father; cry 'Saint George!'

src: He would not stay at your petitions: made His business more material.
trg: Didst perceive it? They're here with me already, whispering, rounding 'Sicilia is a so-forth:' 'tis far gone, When I shall gust it last. How came't, Camillo, That he did stay?

src: O' my word, the father's son: I'll swear,'tis a very pretty boy. O' my troth, I looked upon him o' Wednesday half an hour together: has such a confirmed countenance.
trg: I saw him run after a gilded butterfly: and when he caught it, he let it go again; and after it again; and over and over he comes, and again; catched it again;

src: I would not for the world they saw thee here.
trg: I have night's cloak to hide me from their sight; And but thou love me, let them find me here: My life were better ended by their hate, Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.

src: Is't so, indeed.
trg: Help, help, help! here's a madman will murder me.

src: desperation Is all the policy, strength and defence, That Rome can make against them.
trg: Here come the clusters. And is Aufidius with him? You are they That made the air unwholesome, when you cast Your stinking greasy caps in hooting at Coriolanus' exile. Now he's coming;

src: What men of name resort to him?
trg: Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley; Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt, And Rice ap Thomas with a valiant crew;

src: Now, Warwick, wilt thou ope the city gates, Speak gentle words and humbly bend thy knee, Call Edward king and at his hands beg mercy? And he shall pardon thee these outrages.
trg: Nay, rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence, Confess who set thee up and pluck'd thee own, Call Warwick patron and be penitent? And thou shalt still remain the Duke of York.

src: Pale trembling coward, there I throw my gage, Disclaiming here the kindred of the king, And lay aside my high blood's royalty, Which fear, not reverence, makes thee to except.
trg: If guilty dread have left thee so much strength As to take up mine honour's pawn, then stoop:

src: See them deliver'd over To execution and the hand of death.
trg: More welcome is the stroke of death to me Than Bolingbroke to England. Lords, farewell.

src: And, by despairing, shouldst thou stand excused; For doing worthy vengeance on thyself, Which didst unworthy slaughter upon others.
trg: Say that I slew them not?

src: Not within, sir.
trg: O pretty Isabella, I am pale at mine heart to see thine eyes so red: thou must be patient. I am fain to dine and sup with water and bran; I dare not for my head fill my belly;

src: O, what a beast was I to chide at him!
trg: Will you speak well of him that kill'd your cousin?

src: O, do not slander him, for he is kind.
trg: Right, As snow in harvest. Thou deceivest thyself: 'Tis he that sent us hither now to slaughter thee.

src: No.
trg: Thou dost, and think'st it much to tread the ooze Of the salt deep, To run upon the sharp wind of the north, To do me business in the veins o' the earth When it is baked with frost.

src: Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge, And now I cloy me with beholding it. Thy Edward he is dead, that stabb'd my Edward: Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;
trg: Young York he is but boot, because both they Match not the high perfection of my loss: Thy Clarence he is dead that kill'd my Edward;

src: Nay, do not say, 'stand up;' Say, 'pardon' first, and afterwards 'stand up.' And if I were thy nurse, thy tongue to teach, 'Pardon' should be the first word of thy speech.
trg: I never long'd to hear a word till now; Say 'pardon,' king; let pity teach thee how: The word is short, but not so short as sweet; No word like 'pardon' for kings' mouths so meet.

src: Tell me thine first.
trg: You will be schoolmaster And undertake the teaching of the maid: That's your device.

src: Make haste; the hour of death is expiate.
trg: Come, Grey, come, Vaughan, let us all embrace: And take our leave, until we meet in heaven.

src: I thank your ladyship; well, good madam.
trg: He had rather see the swords, and hear a drum, than look upon his school-master.

src: Come, stir, stir, stir! the second cock hath crow'd, The curfew-bell hath rung, 'tis three o'clock: Look to the baked meats, good Angelica: Spare not for the cost.
trg: Go, you cot-quean, go, Get you to bed; faith, You'll be sick to-morrow For this night's watching.

src: If not, elsewhere they meet with charity:
trg: But I, who never knew how to entreat, Nor never needed that I should entreat, Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep, With oath kept waking and with brawling fed:

src: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.
trg: No, to their lives bad friends were contrary.

src: Urge it no more; lest that, instead of words, I send thee, Warwick, such a messenger As shall revenge his death before I stir.
trg: Poor Clifford! how I scorn his worthless threats!

src: Tut, man, one fire burns out another's burning, One pain is lessen'd by another's anguish; Turn giddy, and be holp by backward turning; One desperate grief cures with another's languish:
trg: Take thou some new infection to thy eye, And the rank poison of the old will die.

src: O, I do fear thee, Claudio; and I quake, Lest thou a feverous life shouldst entertain, And six or seven winters more respect Than a perpetual honour. Darest thou die?
trg: The sense of death is most in apprehension; And the poor beetle, that we tread upon, In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great As when a giant dies.

src: he arrests him on it; And follows close the rigour of the statute, To make him an example. All hope is gone, Unless you have the grace by your fair prayer To soften Angelo:
trg: and that's my pith of business 'Twixt you and your poor brother.

src: The violent carriage of it Will clear or end the business: when the oracle, Thus by Apollo's great divine seal'd up, Shall the contents discover, something rare Even then will rush to knowledge. Go:
trg: fresh horses! And gracious be the issue!

src: I thank your worship for your good counsel: but I shall follow it as the flesh and fortune shall better determine. Whip me? No, no; let carman whip his jade:
trg: The valiant heart is not whipt out of his trade.

src: The army of the queen mean to besiege us.
trg: She shall not need; we'll meet her in the field.

src: Are you agreed?
trg: Sir, I will serve him; for I do find your hangman is a more penitent trade than your bawd; he doth oftener ask forgiveness.

src: What shall I swear by?
trg: Do not swear at all; Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And I'll believe thee.

src: at the least if you take it as a pleasure to you in being so. You blame Marcius for being proud?
trg: We do it not alone, sir.

src: To my house. Fare you well. What's o'clock, think you?
trg: Eleven, sir.

src: Well thought upon; I have it here about me. When you have done, repair to Crosby Place. But, sirs, be sudden in the execution, Withal obdurate, do not hear him plead;
trg: For Clarence is well-spoken, and perhaps May move your hearts to pity if you mark him.

src: Farewell! I will omit no opportunity That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.
trg: O think'st thou we shall ever meet again?

src: I cannot tarry: I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit; and so may you, sir: and so, adieu, sir.
trg: My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Luke's, to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.

src: We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a power that we have no power to do; for if he show us his wounds and tell us his deeds, we are to put our tongues into those wounds and speak for them;
trg: so, if he tell us his noble deeds, we must also tell him our noble acceptance of them. Ingratitude is monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful, were to make a monster of the multitude:

src: All may be well; but, if God sort it so, 'Tis more than we deserve, or I expect.
trg: Truly, the souls of men are full of dread: Ye cannot reason almost with a man That looks not heavily and full of fear.

src: Where should this music be? i' the air or the earth? It sounds no more: and sure, it waits upon Some god o' the island.
trg: Sitting on a bank, Weeping again the king my father's wreck, This music crept by me upon the waters, Allaying both their fury and my passion With its sweet air:

src: O God, O God! that e'er this tongue of mine, That laid the sentence of dread banishment On yon proud man, should take it off again With words of sooth!
trg: O that I were as great As is my grief, or lesser than my name! Or that I could forget what I have been, Or not remember what I must be now! Swell'st thou, proud heart?

src: For first he was contract to Lady Lucy-- Your mother lives a witness to that vow-- And afterward by substitute betroth'd To Bona, sister to the King of France.
trg: More bitterly could I expostulate, Save that, for reverence to some alive, I give a sparing limit to my tongue. Then, good my lord, take to your royal self This proffer'd benefit of dignity;

src: Good friar, let's hear it. Do you not smile at this, Lord Angelo? O heaven, the vanity of wretched fools! Give us some seats. Come, cousin Angelo; In this I'll be impartial;
trg: be you judge Of your own cause. Is this the witness, friar? First, let her show her face, and after speak.

src: Rivers and Dorset, you were standers by, And so wast thou, Lord Hastings, when my son Was stabb'd with bloody daggers:
trg: God, I pray him, That none of you may live your natural age, But by some unlook'd accident cut off!

src: Not a word, a word; we stand upon our manners. Come, strike up!
trg: Pray, good shepherd, what fair swain is this Which dances with your daughter?

src: Send to her, by the man that slew her brothers, A pair of bleeding-hearts; thereon engrave Edward and York; then haply she will weep:
trg: Therefore present to her--as sometime Margaret Did to thy father, steep'd in Rutland's blood,-- A handkerchief;

src: What is it?
trg: That it would please thee leave these sad designs To him that hath more cause to be a mourner, And presently repair to Crosby Place;

src: Mercutio, thou consort'st with Romeo,--
trg: Consort! what, dost thou make us minstrels? an thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but discords: here's my fiddlestick; here's that shall make you dance. 'Zounds, consort!

src: Now, perjured Henry! wilt thou kneel for grace, And set thy diadem upon my head; Or bide the mortal fortune of the field?
trg: Go, rate thy minions, proud insulting boy! Becomes it thee to be thus bold in terms Before thy sovereign and thy lawful king?

src: Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow. How now, sirrah! how goes the world with thee?
trg: The better that your lordship please to ask.

src: I shall obey him.
And what of him?
trg: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.

src: But, after all this fooling, I would not have it so. Art thou sure of this?
trg: I am too sure of it: and it is for getting Madam Julietta with child.

src: I cannot tell; I fear 'tis choleric. What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?
trg: A dish that I do love to feed upon.

src: Your knee, sirrah.
trg: That's my brave boy!

src: Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own, That, being a stranger in this city here, Do make myself a suitor to your daughter, Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous.
trg: Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me, In the preferment of the eldest sister.

src: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.
trg: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do; They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.

src: Thou, being a king, blest with a goodly son, Didst yield consent to disinherit him, Which argued thee a most unloving father. Unreasonable creatures feed their young;
trg: For shame, my liege, make them your precedent! Ah, what a shame were this! Look on the boy;

src: Content you, gentlemen: I will compound this strife: 'Tis deeds must win the prize; and he of both That can assure my daughter greatest dower Shall have my Bianca's love.
trg: Say, Signior Gremio, What can you assure her?

src: Sir, we were talking that our garments seem now as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage of your daughter, who is now queen.
trg: And the rarest that e'er came there.

src: Give sorrow leave awhile to tutor me To this submission. Yet I well remember The favours of these men: were they not mine? Did they not sometime cry, 'all hail!' to me? So Judas did to Christ:
trg: but he, in twelve, Found truth in all but one: I, in twelve thousand, none. God save the king! Will no man say amen? Am I both priest and clerk? well then, amen. God save the king!

src: They shall be satisfied: I'll read enough, When I do see the very book indeed Where all my sins are writ, and that's myself. Give me the glass, and therein will I read. No deeper wrinkles yet?
trg: hath sorrow struck So many blows upon this face of mine, And made no deeper wounds? O flattering glass, Like to my followers in prosperity, Thou dost beguile me!

src: You have, my lord: would it might please your grace, At our entreaties, to amend that fault!
trg: Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?

src: Yea, brother Richard, are you offended too?
trg: Not I: No, God forbid that I should wish them sever'd Whom God hath join'd together; ay, and 'twere pity To sunder them that yoke so well together.

src: thou hast quarrelled with a man for coughing in the street, because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun:
trg: didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter? with another, for tying his new shoes with old riband? and yet thou wilt tutor me from quarrelling!

src: My lord, I had forgot to tell your lordship, To-day, as I came by, I called there; But I shall grieve you to report the rest.
trg: What is't, knave?

src: Faith, we hear fearful news.
trg: For mine own part, When I said, banish him, I said 'twas pity.

src: And yet you halt not.
trg: Not so well apparell'd As I wish you were.

src: When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.
trg: O, that thou wouldst as well afford a grave As thou canst yield a melancholy seat! Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here. O, who hath any cause to mourn but I?

src: What, is't murder?
trg: No.

src: The same, sir.
trg: You had more beard when I last saw you; but your favour is well approved by your tongue. What's the news in Rome? I have a note from the Volscian state, to find you out there:

src: Then I salute you with this kingly title: Long live Richard, England's royal king!
trg: Amen.

src: Sir, I was an inward of his. A shy fellow was the duke: and I believe I know the cause of his withdrawing.
trg: What, I prithee, might be the cause?

src: Dull thing, I say so; he, that Caliban Whom now I keep in service. Thou best know'st What torment I did find thee in; thy groans Did make wolves howl and penetrate the breasts Of ever angry bears:
trg: it was a torment To lay upon the damn'd, which Sycorax Could not again undo: it was mine art, When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape The pine and let thee out.

src: Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed, Ascend her chamber, hence and comfort her: But look thou stay not till the watch be set, For then thou canst not pass to Mantua; Go before, nurse:
trg: commend me to thy lady; And bid her hasten all the house to bed, Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto: Romeo is coming.

src: matrons flung gloves, Ladies and maids their scarfs and handkerchers, Upon him as he pass'd:
trg: the nobles bended, As to Jove's statue, and the commons made A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts: I never saw the like.

src: This being granted in course,--and now follows all,--we shall advise this wronged maid to stead up your appointment, go in your place;
trg: if the encounter acknowledge itself hereafter, it may compel him to her recompense:
Plantagenet, for all the claim thou lay'st, Think not that Henry shall be so deposed.

src: 'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.
trg: Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.

src: We wait upon your grace.
trg: Tell me, good grandam, is our father dead?

src: Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me, In the preferment of the eldest sister.
trg: This liberty is all that I request, That, upon knowledge of my parentage, I may have welcome 'mongst the rest that woo And free access and favour as the rest:

src: No money, on my faith, but the gleek; I will give you the minstrel.
trg: Then I will give you the serving-creature.

src: Is not Gaunt dead, and doth not Hereford live? Was not Gaunt just, and is not Harry true? Did not the one deserve to have an heir? Is not his heir a well-deserving son?
trg: Take Hereford's rights away, and take from Time His charters and his customary rights; Let not to-morrow then ensue to-day; Be not thyself;

src: And, through the cranks and offices of man, The strongest nerves and small inferior veins From me receive that natural competency Whereby they live:
trg: and though that all at once, You, my good friends,'--this says the belly, mark me,--

src: Signior Hortensio, I have often heard Of your entire affection to Bianca;
trg: And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness, I will with you, if you be so contented, Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.

src: A bawd, sir? fie upon him! he will discredit our mystery.
trg: Go to, sir; you weigh equally; a feather will turn the scale.

src: I'll have no bigger: this doth fit the time, And gentlewomen wear such caps as these
trg: When you are gentle, you shall have one too, And not till then.

src: The date is out of such prolixity: We'll have no Cupid hoodwink'd with a scarf, Bearing a Tartar's painted bow of lath, Scaring the ladies like a crow-keeper;
trg: Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke After the prompter, for our entrance: But let them measure us by what they will; We'll measure them a measure, and be gone.

src: And joy comes well in such a needy time: What are they, I beseech your ladyship?
trg: Well, well, thou hast a careful father, child; One who, to put thee from thy heaviness, Hath sorted out a sudden day of joy, That thou expect'st not nor I look'd not for.

src: But when goes this forward?
trg: To-morrow; to-day; presently; you shall have the drum struck up this afternoon: 'tis, as it were, a parcel of their feast, and to be executed ere they wipe their lips.

src: Bid my guard watch; leave me. Ratcliff, about the mid of night come to my tent And help to arm me. Leave me, I say.
trg: Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!

src: On, to the Capitol!
trg: All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights Are spectacled to see him: your prattling nurse Into a rapture lets her baby cry While she chats him:

src: If thou deny, their blood upon thy head; For York in justice puts his armour on.
trg: If that be right which Warwick says is right, There is no wrong, but every thing is right.

src: Master, for my hand, Both our inventions meet and jump in one.
trg: Tell me thine first.

src: Being vex'd a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears: What is it else? a madness most discreet, A choking gall and a preserving sweet. Farewell, my coz.
trg: Soft! I will go along; An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.

src: At thy choice, then: To beg of thee, it is my more dishonour Than thou of them. Come all to ruin;
trg: let Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at death With as big heart as thou.

src: Thy brother's love, our duty, and thy fault, Provoke us hither now to slaughter thee.
trg: Oh, if you love my brother, hate not me; I am his brother, and I love him well.

src: What would your grace have done unto him now?
trg: Brave warriors, Clifford and Northumberland, Come, make him stand upon this molehill here, That raught at mountains with outstretched arms, Yet parted but the shadow with his hand. What!

src: What, in metre?
trg: In any proportion or in any language.

src: What is her mother?
trg: Marry, bachelor, Her mother is the lady of the house, And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous I nursed her daughter, that you talk'd withal;

src: Courage, man; the hurt cannot be much.
trg: No, 'tis not so deep as a well, nor so wide as a church-door; but 'tis enough,'twill serve: ask for me to-morrow, and you shall find me a grave man. I am peppered, I warrant, for this world.

src: The best and wholesomest spirts of the night Envelope you, good Provost! Who call'd here of late?
trg: None, since the curfew rung.

src: I never did thee harm: why wilt thou slay me?
trg: Thy father hath.

src: but we saw not That which my daughter came to look upon, The statue of her mother.
trg: As she lived peerless, So her dead likeness, I do well believe, Excels whatever yet you look'd upon Or hand of man hath done; therefore I keep it Lonely, apart. But here it is:

src: Let me have war, say I; it exceeds peace as far as day does night; it's spritely, waking, audible, and full of vent. Peace is a very apoplexy, lethargy; mulled, deaf, sleepy, insensible;
trg: a getter of more bastard children than war's a destroyer of men.

src: Nay, I'll conjure too. Romeo! humours! madman! passion! lover! Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh: Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied; Cry but 'Ay me!' pronounce but 'love' and 'dove;
trg: ' Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word, One nick-name for her purblind son and heir, Young Adam Cupid, he that shot so trim, When King Cophetua loved the beggar-maid!

src: Anon!
trg: Peter, take my fan, and go before and apace.

src: What said our cousin when you parted with him?
trg: 'Farewell:' And, for my heart disdained that my tongue Should so profane the word, that taught me craft To counterfeit oppression of such grief That words seem'd buried in my sorrow's grave.

src: To the ground, mistress.
trg: Why, here's a change indeed in the commonwealth! What shall become of me?

src: Good my lord, She came from Libya.
trg: Where the warlike Smalus, That noble honour'd lord, is fear'd and loved?

src: I wonder how our princely father 'scaped, Or whether he be 'scaped away or no From Clifford's and Northumberland's pursuit: Had he been ta'en, we should have heard the news;
trg: Had he been slain, we should have heard the news; Or had he 'scaped, methinks we should have heard The happy tidings of his good escape. How fares my brother? why is he so sad?

src: Seize him, AEdiles!
trg: Down with him! down with him!

src: I beseech you, sir, ask him what this man did to my wife.
trg: I beseech your honour, ask me.

src: I say it is the moon.
trg: I know it is the moon.

src: Ourself and Bushy, Bagot here and Green Observed his courtship to the common people; Off goes his bonnet to an oyster-wench;
trg: A brace of draymen bid God speed him well And had the tribute of his supple knee, With 'Thanks, my countrymen, my loving friends;

src: Such it seems As may beseem a monarch like himself.
trg: Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve.

src: Who is that calls so coldly?
trg: A piece of ice: if thou doubt it, thou mayst slide from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run but my head and my neck. A fire good Curtis.

src: I wonder how the king escaped our hands.
trg: While we pursued the horsemen of the north, He slily stole away and left his men: Whereat the great Lord of Northumberland, Whose warlike ears could never brook retreat, Cheer'd up the drooping army;

src: I'll gladly learn.
trg: Love you the man that wrong'd you?

src: Talk not to me, for I'll not speak a word: Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.
trg: O God!--O nurse, how shall this be prevented? My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven; How shall that faith return again to earth, Unless that husband send it me from heaven By leaving earth?

src: And, after many lengthen'd hours of grief, Die neither mother, wife, nor England's queen!
trg: Rivers and Dorset, you were standers by, And so wast thou, Lord Hastings, when my son Was stabb'd with bloody daggers:

src: You are sent for to the Capitol. 'Tis thought That Marcius shall be consul: I have seen the dumb men throng to see him and The blind to bear him speak:
trg: matrons flung gloves, Ladies and maids their scarfs and handkerchers, Upon him as he pass'd:

src: By my troth, it is well said; 'for himself to mar,' quoth a'? Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I may find the young Romeo?
trg: I can tell you; but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you sought him: I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.

src: So do not I: go, coward as thou art. Now must I hide his body in some hole, Until the duke take order for his burial: And when I have my meed, I must away; For this will out, and here I must not stay.
trg: Why, so: now have I done a good day's work: You peers, continue this united league: I every day expect an embassage From my Redeemer to redeem me hence;

src: Lucentio is your name; of whence, I pray?
trg: Of Pisa, sir; son to Vincentio.

src: Mock not my senseless conjuration, lords: This earth shall have a feeling and these stones Prove armed soldiers, ere her native king Shall falter under foul rebellion's arms.
trg: Fear not, my lord: that Power that made you king Hath power to keep you king in spite of all. The means that heaven yields must be embraced, And not neglected;

src: Sir, it is a mystery.
trg: Proof?

src: My lord, you do me shameful injury, Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.
trg: You may deny that you were not the cause Of my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment.

src: Out of their saddles into the dirt; and thereby hangs a tale.
trg: Let's ha't, good Grumio.

src: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, Unapt to toil and trouble in the world, But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts?
trg: Come, come, you froward and unable worms! My mind hath been as big as one of yours, My heart as great, my reason haply more, To bandy word for word and frown for frown;

src: Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here, Shalt with him hence.
trg: This shall determine that.

src: I dare be sworn These dangerous unsafe lunes i' the king, beshrew them! He must be told on't, and he shall: the office Becomes a woman best; I'll take't upon me:
trg: If I prove honey-mouth'd let my tongue blister And never to my red-look'd anger be The trumpet any more. Pray you, Emilia, Commend my best obedience to the queen:

src: From off the gates of York fetch down the head, Your father's head, which Clifford placed there; Instead whereof let this supply the room: Measure for measure must be answered.
trg: Bring forth that fatal screech-owl to our house, That nothing sung but death to us and ours: Now death shall stop his dismal threatening sound, And his ill-boding tongue no more shall speak.

src: Our business is not unknown to the senate; they have had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do, which now we'll show 'em in deeds. They say poor suitors have strong breaths:
trg: they shall know we have strong arms too.

src: Nay, hear me, Isabel.
trg: O, fie, fie, fie! Thy sin's not accidental, but a trade. Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd: 'Tis best thou diest quickly.

src: How? what?
trg: How often he had met you, sword to sword; That of all things upon the earth he hated Your person most, that he would pawn his fortunes To hopeless restitution, so he might Be call'd your vanquisher.

src: What is the news i' the court?
trg: None rare, my lord.

src: Edward thy son, which now is Prince of Wales, For Edward my son, which was Prince of Wales, Die in his youth by like untimely violence!
trg: Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen, Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self! Long mayst thou live to wail thy children's loss;

src: Therefore let him be consul: the gods give him joy, and make him good friend to the people!
trg: Amen, amen. God save thee, noble consul!

src: Then give me leave to read philosophy, And while I pause, serve in your harmony.
trg: Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.

src: else, if heaven would, And we will not, heaven's offer we refuse, The proffer'd means of succor and redress.
trg: He means, my lord, that we are too remiss; Whilst Bolingbroke, through our security, Grows strong and great in substance and in power.

src: I have a daughter, sir, called Katharina.
trg: You are too blunt: go to it orderly.

src: My lord protector needs will have it so.
trg: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

src: What should she do here? My dismal scene I needs must act alone. Come, vial. What if this mixture do not work at all? Shall I be married then to-morrow morning? No, no: this shall forbid it:
trg: lie thou there. What if it be a poison, which the friar Subtly hath minister'd to have me dead, Lest in this marriage he should be dishonour'd, Because he married me before to Romeo? I fear it is:

src: Quick, dispatch, and send the head to Angelo.
trg: Now will I write letters to Angelo,-- The provost, he shall bear them, whose contents Shall witness to him I am near at home, And that, by great injunctions, I am bound To enter publicly:

src: Verona's summer hath not such a flower.
trg: Nay, he's a flower; in faith, a very flower.

src: Hence! hang not on my garments.
trg: Sir, have pity; I'll be his surety.

src: Your voices therefore.' When we granted that, Here was 'I thank you for your voices: thank you: Your most sweet voices: now you have left your voices, I have no further with you.
trg: ' Was not this mockery?

src: About what?
trg: About that which concerns your grace and us; The crown of England, father, which is yours.

src: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother: Then bring me to their sights; I'll bear thy blame And take thy office from thee, on my peril.
trg: No, madam, no; I may not leave it so: I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.

src: Norfolk, throw down, we bid; there is no boot.
trg: Myself I throw, dread sovereign, at thy foot. My life thou shalt command, but not my shame: The one my duty owes;

src: Here, if it like your honour.
trg: See that Claudio Be executed by nine to-morrow morning: Bring him his confessor, let him be prepared; For that's the utmost of his pilgrimage.

src: What less than dooms-day is the prince's doom?
trg: A gentler judgment vanish'd from his lips, Not body's death, but body's banishment.

src: No.
trg: I will then give it you soundly.

src: 'Tis but thy name that is my enemy; Thou art thyself, though not a Montague. What's Montague? it is nor hand, nor foot, Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part Belonging to a man. O, be some other name!
trg: What's in a name? that which we call a rose By any other name would smell as sweet; So Romeo would, were he not Romeo call'd, Retain that dear perfection which he owes Without that title.

src: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course Is this of hers! Lord cardinal, will your grace Persuade the queen to send the Duke of York Unto his princely brother presently?
trg: If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him, And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.

src: and have already O'erborne their way, consumed with fire, and took What lay before them.
trg: O, you have made good work!

src: Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray? 'Con tutto il cuore, ben trovato,' may I say.
trg: 'Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signor mio Petruchio.' Rise, Grumio, rise: we will compound this quarrel.

src: but that your youth, And the true blood which peepeth fairly through't, Do plainly give you out an unstain'd shepherd, With wisdom I might fear, my Doricles, You woo'd me the false way.
trg: I think you have As little skill to fear as I have purpose To put you to't. But come; our dance, I pray: Your hand, my Perdita: so turtles pair, That never mean to part.

src: What if both Lewis and Warwick be appeased By such invention as I can devise?
trg: Yet, to have join'd with France in such alliance Would more have strengthen'd this our commonwealth 'Gainst foreign storms than any home-bred marriage.

src: That so I may, by this device, at least Have leave and leisure to make love to her And unsuspected court her by herself.
trg: Here's no knavery! See, to beguile the old folks, how the young folks lay their heads together! Master, master, look about you: who goes there, ha?

src: I know not what to say: but give me your hands; God send you joy, Petruchio! 'tis a match.
trg: Amen, say we: we will be witnesses.

src: And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself? O, in this love, you love your child so ill, That you run mad, seeing that she is well:
trg: She's not well married that lives married long; But she's best married that dies married young. Dry up your tears, and stick your rosemary On this fair corse;

src: Had I been there, which am a silly woman, The soldiers should have toss'd me on their pikes Before I would have granted to that act. But thou preferr'st thy life before thine honour:
trg: And seeing thou dost, I here divorce myself Both from thy table, Henry, and thy bed, Until that act of parliament be repeal'd Whereby my son is disinherited.

src: You were kneel'd to and importuned otherwise By all of us, and the fair soul herself Weigh'd between loathness and obedience, at Which end o' the beam should bow.
trg: We have lost your son, I fear, for ever: Milan and Naples have More widows in them of this business' making Than we bring men to comfort them: The fault's your own.

src: For we to-morrow hold divided councils, Wherein thyself shalt highly be employ'd.
trg: Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby, His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries To-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle;

src: What more fearful?
trg: This is most likely!

src: Henceforward I am ever ruled by you.
trg: Send for the county; go tell him of this: I'll have this knot knit up to-morrow morning.

src: Fly, father, fly! for all your friends are fled, And Warwick rages like a chafed bull: Away! for death doth hold us in pursuit.
trg: Mount you, my lord; towards Berwick post amain:

src: Spoke he of me?
trg: He did, my lord.

src: No, to White-Friars; there attend my coining. Was ever woman in this humour woo'd? Was ever woman in this humour won? I'll have her; but I will not keep her long. What!
trg: I, that kill'd her husband and his father, To take her in her heart's extremest hate, With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes, The bleeding witness of her hatred by;

src: O, he is even in my mistress' case, Just in her case! O woful sympathy! Piteous predicament! Even so lies she, Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering. Stand up, stand up;
trg: stand, and you be a man: For Juliet's sake, for her sake, rise and stand; Why should you fall into so deep an O?

src: Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind. Which never dreamt on aught but butcheries: Didst thou not kill this king?
trg: I grant ye.

src: If from me he have wholesome beverage, Account me not your servant.
trg: This is all: Do't and thou hast the one half of my heart; Do't not, thou split'st thine own.

src: Feed not thy sovereign's foe, my gentle earth, Nor with thy sweets comfort his ravenous sense;
trg: But let thy spiders, that suck up thy venom, And heavy-gaited toads lie in their way, Doing annoyance to the treacherous feet Which with usurping steps do trample thee:

src: Find thou the means, and I'll find such a man. But now I'll tell thee joyful tidings, girl.
trg: And joy comes well in such a needy time: What are they, I beseech your ladyship?

src: Be patient, they are friends, Ratcliff and Lovel.
trg: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor, The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

src: Ay, but, I fear me, in another sense. What love, think'st thou, I sue so much to get?
trg: My love till death, my humble thanks, my prayers; That love which virtue begs and virtue grants.

src: I do beseech you, pardon me; I may not show it.
trg: I will be satisfied; let me see it, I say. Treason! foul treason! Villain! traitor! slave!

src: Ay; and that thou and the proudest of you all shall find when he comes home. But what talk I of this? Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop and the rest:
trg: let their heads be sleekly combed their blue coats brushed and their garters of an indifferent knit:

src: My Lord of Somerset, at my request, See that forthwith Duke Edward be convey'd Unto my brother, Archbishop of York.
trg: When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows, I'll follow you, and tell what answer Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him. Now, for a while farewell, good Duke of York.

src: trust not my holy order, If I pervert your course. Who's here?
trg: Good even. Friar, where's the provost?

src: Who shall begin?
trg: That will I. Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.

src: 'Tis your counsel My lord should to the heavens be contrary, Oppose against their wills. Care not for issue; The crown will find an heir: great Alexander Left his to the worthiest;
trg: so his successor Was like to be the best.

src: Go, get thee hence, for I will not away. What's here? a cup, closed in my true love's hand? Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end: O churl! drunk all, and left no friendly drop To help me after?
trg: I will kiss thy lips; Haply some poison yet doth hang on them, To make die with a restorative. Thy lips are warm.

src: Alas! good Kate, I will not burden thee; For, knowing thee to be but young and light--
trg: Too light for such a swain as you to catch; And yet as heavy as my weight should be.

src: I'll send to one in Mantua, Where that same banish'd runagate doth live, Shall give him such an unaccustom'd dram, That he shall soon keep Tybalt company: And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.
trg: Indeed, I never shall be satisfied With Romeo, till I behold him--dead-- Is my poor heart for a kinsman vex'd. Madam, if you could find out but a man To bear a poison, I would temper it;

src: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.
trg: Why, our battalion trebles that account: Besides, the king's name is a tower of strength, Which they upon the adverse party want. Up with my tent there!

src: I do suspect I have done some offence That seems disgracious in the city's eyes, And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.
trg: You have, my lord: would it might please your grace, At our entreaties, to amend that fault!

src: Many a morning hath he there been seen, With tears augmenting the fresh morning dew. Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs;
trg: Black and portentous must this humour prove, Unless good counsel may the cause remove.

src: or whether his fall enraged him, or how 'twas, he did so set his teeth and tear it; O, I warrant it, how he mammocked it!
trg: One on 's father's moods.

src: take your sweetheart's hat And pluck it o'er your brows, muffle your face, Dismantle you, and, as you can, disliken The truth of your own seeming;
trg: that you may-- For I do fear eyes over--to shipboard Get undescried.

src: O, ay, what else?
trg: Go, masters, get you home; be not dismay'd: These are a side that would be glad to have This true which they so seem to fear. Go home, And show no sign of fear.

src: O then, belike, you fancy riches more: You will have Gremio to keep you fair.
trg: Is it for him you do envy me so? Nay then you jest, and now I well perceive You have but jested with me all this while: I prithee, sister Kate, untie my hands.

src: I thank your grace.
trg: My lord of Ely!

src: Come hither, England's hope. If secret powers Suggest but truth to my divining thoughts, This pretty lad will prove our country's bliss.
trg: His looks are full of peaceful majesty, His head by nature framed to wear a crown, His hand to wield a sceptre, and himself Likely in time to bless a regal throne.

src: More health and happiness betide my liege Than can my care-tuned tongue deliver him!
trg: Mine ear is open and my heart prepared; The worst is worldly loss thou canst unfold. Say, is my kingdom lost? why, 'twas my care And what loss is it to be rid of care?

src: Charges she more than me?
trg: Not that I know.

src: and, as the custom is, In all her best array bear her to church: For though fond nature bids us an lament, Yet nature's tears are reason's merriment.
trg: All things that we ordained festival, Turn from their office to black funeral;

src: Then, England's ground, farewell; sweet soil, adieu; My mother, and my nurse, that bears me yet! Where'er I wander, boast of this I can, Though banish'd, yet a trueborn Englishman.
trg: We did observe. Cousin Aumerle, How far brought you high Hereford on his way?

src: We stood to't in good time. Is this Menenius?
trg: 'Tis he,'tis he: O, he is grown most kind of late.

src: You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?
trg: No, not a denier. Go by, Jeronimy: go to thy cold bed, and warm thee.

src: Move them no more by crossing their high will.
trg: Faith, we may put up our pipes, and be gone.

src: and when he bites, His venom tooth will rankle to the death: Have not to do with him, beware of him; Sin, death, and hell have set their marks on him, And all their ministers attend on him.
trg: What doth she say, my Lord of Buckingham?

src: Is this the promise that you made your mother?
trg: Know, I pray you,--

src: Wherefore did they not That hour destroy us?
trg: Well demanded, wench: My tale provokes that question.

src: I would to God, So my untruth had not provoked him to it, The king had cut off my head with my brother's. What, are there no posts dispatch'd for Ireland? How shall we do for money for these wars?
trg: Come, sister,--cousin, I would say--pray, pardon me. Go, fellow, get thee home, provide some carts And bring away the armour that is there. Gentlemen, will you go muster men?

src: It was a mad fantastical trick of him to steal from the state, and usurp the beggary he was never born to. Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence; he puts transgression to 't.
trg: He does well in 't.

src: Here's another ballad of a fish, that appeared upon the coast on Wednesday the four-score of April, forty thousand fathom above water, and sung this ballad against the hard hearts of maids:
trg: it was thought she was a woman and was turned into a cold fish for she would not exchange flesh with one that loved her: the ballad is very pitiful and as true.

src: I warrant it is: and thy head stands so tickle on thy shoulders that a milkmaid, if she be in love, may sigh it off. Send after the duke and appeal to him.
trg: I have done so, but he's not to be found. I prithee, Lucio, do me this kind service: This day my sister should the cloister enter And there receive her approbation:

src: What, will you not suffer me? Nay, now I see She is your treasure, she must have a husband; I must dance bare-foot on her wedding day And for your love to her lead apes in hell. Talk not to me:
trg: I will go sit and weep Till I can find occasion of revenge.

src: Bid them home: Say their great enemy is gone, and they Stand in their ancient strength.
trg: Dismiss them home. Here comes his mother.

src: For this reason, if you'll know, That she's the choice love of Signior Gremio.
trg: That she's the chosen of Signior Hortensio.

src: When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?
trg: You cram these words into mine ears against The stomach of my sense. Would I had never Married my daughter there!

src: Who can do good on him? Well, go, prepare yourself. But, hark, what noise? Heaven give your spirits comfort! By and by. I hope it is some pardon or reprieve For the most gentle Claudio.
trg: Welcome father.

src: Clifford, ask mercy and obtain no grace.
trg: Clifford, repent in bootless penitence.

src: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curse That bottled spider, that foul bunch-back'd toad!
trg: I call'd thee then vain flourish of my fortune; I call'd thee then poor shadow, painted queen; The presentation of but what I was; The flattering index of a direful pageant;

src: You, to remove that siege of grief from her, Betroth'd and would have married her perforce To County Paris:
trg: then comes she to me, And, with wild looks, bid me devise some mean To rid her from this second marriage, Or in my cell there would she kill herself.

src: My lord?
