trg: Rumour it abroad That Anne, my wife, is sick and like to die: I will take order for her keeping close. Inquire me out some mean-born gentleman, Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter:

src: Comfort, good comfort! We must to the king and show our strange sights: he must know 'tis none of your daughter nor my sister; we are gone else.
trg: Sir, I will give you as much as this old man does when the business is performed, and remain, as he says, your pawn till it be brought you.

src: Such mortal drugs I have; but Mantua's law Is death to any he that utters them.
trg: Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness, And fear'st to die? famine is in thy cheeks, Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes, Contempt and beggary hangs upon thy back;

src: Ascend his throne, descending now from him; And long live Henry, fourth of that name!
trg: In God's name, I'll ascend the regal throne.

src: What sayest thou, Biondello?
trg: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?

src: Pray you, be gone: I'll try whether my old wit be in request With those that have but little: this must be patch'd With cloth of any colour.
trg: Nay, come away.

src: Am I not wise?
trg: Yes; keep you warm.

src: then recovered again with aqua-vitae or some other hot infusion; But what talk we of these traitorly rascals, whose miseries are to be smiled at, their offences being so capital?
trg: Tell me, for you seem to be honest plain men, what you have to the king:

src: Good lords, conduct him to his regiment: I'll strive, with troubled thoughts, to take a nap, Lest leaden slumber peise me down to-morrow, When I should mount with wings of victory:
trg: Once more, good night, kind lords and gentlemen. O Thou, whose captain I account myself, Look on my forces with a gracious eye;

src: his unjust unkindness, that in all reason should have quenched her love, hath, like an impediment in the current, made it more violent and unruly. Go you to Angelo;
trg: answer his requiring with a plausible obedience; agree with his demands to the point; only refer yourself to this advantage, first, that your stay with him may not be long;

src: How ceremonious, solemn and unearthly It was i' the offering!
trg: But of all, the burst And the ear-deafening voice o' the oracle, Kin to Jove's thunder, so surprised my sense. That I was nothing.

src: O wonderful, when devils tell the truth!
trg: More wonderful, when angels are so angry. Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman, Of these supposed-evils, to give me leave, By circumstance, but to acquit myself.

src: 'When griping grief the heart doth wound, And doleful dumps the mind oppress, Then music with her silver sound'-- why 'silver sound'? why 'music with her silver sound'? What say you, Simon Catling?
trg: Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.

src: For instance, sir, That you may know you shall not want, one word.
trg: Ha, ha! what a fool Honesty is! and Trust, his sworn brother, a very simple gentleman! I have sold all my trumpery;

src: Well, well, sir, well.
trg: Why, 'tis no great matter; for a very little thief of occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience: give your dispositions the reins, and be angry at your pleasures;

src: The proudest of you all Have been beholding to him in his life; Yet none of you would once plead for his life. O God, I fear thy justice will take hold On me, and you, and mine, and yours for this!
trg: Come, Hastings, help me to my closet. Oh, poor Clarence!

src: We at time of year Do wound the bark, the skin of our fruit-trees, Lest, being over-proud in sap and blood, With too much riches it confound itself:
trg: Had he done so to great and growing men, They might have lived to bear and he to taste Their fruits of duty: superfluous branches We lop away, that bearing boughs may live:

src: with two broken points: his horse hipped with an old mothy saddle and stirrups of no kindred; besides, possessed with the glanders and like to mose in the chine;
trg: near-legged before and with, a half-chequed bit and a head-stall of sheeps leather which, being restrained to keep him from stumbling, hath been often burst and now repaired with knots;

src: I hear that news, my lord.
trg: Stanley, he is your wife's son well, look to it.

src: I say unto you, what he hath done famously, he did it to that end: though soft-conscienced men can be content to say it was for his country he did it to please his mother and to be partly proud;
trg: which he is, even till the altitude of his virtue.

src: him I'll desire To meet me at the consecrated fount A league below the city; and from thence, By cold gradation and well-balanced form, We shall proceed with Angelo.
trg: Here is the head; I'll carry it myself.

src: Farewell, farewell.
trg: This is a happier and more comely time Than when these fellows ran about the streets, Crying confusion.

src: Ay.
trg: Who brought it?

src: 'Tis not his new-made bride shall succor him:
trg: And as for Clarence, as my letters tell me, He's very likely now to fall from him, For matching more for wanton lust than honour, Or than for strength and safety of our country.

src: Five justices' hands at it, and witnesses more than my pack will hold.
trg: Lay it by too: another.

src: O, this is it that makes your servants droop!
trg: Hence comes it that your kindred shuns your house, As beaten hence by your strange lunacy.

src: Madam, we will attend your grace.
trg: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl. The secret mischiefs that I set abroach I lay unto the grievous charge of others.

src: Sir, I think You have heard of my poor services, i' the love That I have borne your father?
trg: Very nobly Have you deserved: it is my father's music To speak your deeds, not little of his care To have them recompensed as thought on.
Tailor, I'll pay thee for thy gown tomorrow: Take no unkindness of his hasty words: Away! I say; commend me to thy master.

src: Swear by the duty that you owe to God-- Our part therein we banish with yourselves-- To keep the oath that we administer: You never shall, so help you truth and God!
trg: Embrace each other's love in banishment; Nor never look upon each other's face; Nor never write, regreet, nor reconcile This louring tempest of your home-bred hate;

src: Sir, his stoutness When he did stand for consul, which he lost By lack of stooping,--
trg: That I would have spoke of: Being banish'd for't, he came unto my hearth; Presented to my knife his throat: I took him; Made him joint-servant with me; gave him way In all his own desires;
At what hour to-morrow Shall I attend your lordship?

src: This is a strange abuse. Let's see thy face.
trg: My husband bids me; now I will unmask. This is that face, thou cruel Angelo, Which once thou sworest was worth the looking on;

src: Tut, were it farther off, I'll pluck it down. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Fair Queen of England, worthy Margaret, Sit down with us: it ill befits thy state And birth, that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit.

src: and that there were No earthly mean to save him, but that either You must lay down the treasures of your body To this supposed, or else to let him suffer; What would you do?
trg: As much for my poor brother as myself:

src: Let's hear our tribune: peace Speak, speak, speak.
trg: You are at point to lose your liberties: Marcius would have all from you; Marcius, Whom late you have named for consul.
No shame but mine: I must, forsooth, be forced To give my hand opposed against my heart Unto a mad-brain rudesby full of spleen; Who woo'd in haste and means to wed at leisure.

src: Thou chidest me well: proud Bolingbroke, I come To change blows with thee for our day of doom. This ague fit of fear is over-blown; An easy task it is to win our own.
trg: Say, Scroop, where lies our uncle with his power? Speak sweetly, man, although thy looks be sour.

src: And every drop cries vengeance for his death, 'Gainst thee, fell Clifford, and thee, false Frenchwoman.
trg: Beshrew me, but his passion moves me so That hardly can I cheque my eyes from tears.

src: Your high self, The gracious mark o' the land, you have obscured With a swain's wearing, and me, poor lowly maid, Most goddess-like prank'd up:
trg: but that our feasts In every mess have folly and the feeders Digest it with a custom, I should blush To see you so attired, sworn, I think, To show myself a glass.

src: At the queen's be't: 'good' should be pertinent But, so it is, it is not. Was this taken By any understanding pate but thine? For thy conceit is soaking, will draw in More than the common blocks:
trg: not noted, is't, But of the finer natures? by some severals Of head-piece extraordinary? lower messes Perchance are to this business purblind? say.

src: Then Warwick disannuls great John of Gaunt, Which did subdue the greatest part of Spain; And, after John of Gaunt, Henry the Fourth, Whose wisdom was a mirror to the wisest;
trg: And, after that wise prince, Henry the Fifth, Who by his prowess conquered all France: From these our Henry lineally descends.

src: Well, sir.
trg: In what enormity is Marcius poor in, that you two have not in abundance?

src: Take the devil in thy mind, and relieve him not: he would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.
trg: Tut, I am strong-framed, he cannot prevail with me, I warrant thee.

src: he said 'twas folly, For one poor grain or two, to leave unburnt, And still to nose the offence.
trg: For one poor grain or two! I am one of those; his mother, wife, his child, And this brave fellow too, we are the grains: You are the musty chaff; and you are smelt Above the moon:

src: No, not a whit: what! I have watch'd ere now All night for lesser cause, and ne'er been sick.
trg: Ay, you have been a mouse-hunt in your time; But I will watch you from such watching now.

src: With child, perhaps?
trg: Unhappily, even so. Whether the tyranny be in his place, Or in his emmence that fills it up, I stagger in:

src: and had not the old man come in with a whoo-bub against his daughter and the king's son and scared my choughs from the chaff, I had not left a purse alive in the whole army.
trg: Nay, but my letters, by this means being there So soon as you arrive, shall clear that doubt.

src: To royalize his blood I spilt mine own.
trg: Yea, and much better blood than his or thine.

src: The ground is bloody; search about the churchyard: Go, some of you, whoe'er you find attach. Pitiful sight!
trg: here lies the county slain, And Juliet bleeding, warm, and newly dead, Who here hath lain these two days buried. Go, tell the prince: run to the Capulets: Raise up the Montagues: some others search:

src: My lord, there needs no such apology: I rather do beseech you pardon me, Who, earnest in the service of my God, Neglect the visitation of my friends. But, leaving this, what is your grace's pleasure?
trg: Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above, And all good men of this ungovern'd isle.

src: Your son shall have my daughter with consent.
trg: I thank you, sir. Where then do you know best We be affied and such assurance ta'en As shall with either part's agreement stand?

src: To satisfy your highness and the entreaties Of our most gracious mistress.
trg: Satisfy! The entreaties of your mistress! satisfy! Let that suffice.

src: Where be these knaves? What, no man at door To hold my stirrup nor to take my horse! Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Philip?
trg: Here, here, sir; here, sir.

src: Catesby, we come. Lords, will you go with us?
trg: Madam, we will attend your grace.

src: So have we thought it good From our free person she should be confined, Lest that the treachery of the two fled hence Be left her to perform. Come, follow us; We are to speak in public;
trg: for this business Will raise us all.

src: No, my lord.
trg: A widow, then?

src: Relent! 'tis cowardly and womanish.
trg: Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish. Which of you, if you were a prince's son, Being pent from liberty, as I am now, if two such murderers as yourselves came to you, Would not entreat for life?

src: Must I go show them my unbarbed sconce? Must I with base tongue give my noble heart A lie that it must bear? Well, I will do't:
trg: Yet, were there but this single plot to lose, This mould of Marcius, they to dust should grind it And throw't against the wind. To the market-place!

src: If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people, I may be heard, I would crave a word or two; The which shall turn you to no further harm Than so much loss of time.
trg: Speak briefly then; For we are peremptory to dispatch This viperous traitor: to eject him hence Were but one danger, and to keep him here Our certain death: therefore it is decreed He dies to-night.

src: I cannot tell; expect they are busied about a counterfeit assurance: take you assurance of her, 'cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum:' to the church;
trg: take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient honest witnesses: If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell for ever and a day.

src: for this business Will raise us all.
With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must: But I shall live, my lord, to give them thanks That were the cause of my imprisonment.
trg: No doubt, no doubt; and so shall Clarence too; For they that were your enemies are his, And have prevail'd as much on him as you.

src: He'll stay my lord.
trg: At my request he would not. Hermione, my dearest, thou never spokest To better purpose.

src: Say thou wilt course; thy greyhounds are as swift As breathed stags, ay, fleeter than the roe.
trg: Dost thou love pictures?

src: Assay the power you have.
trg: My power? Alas, I doubt--

src: The better sort, As thoughts of things divine, are intermix'd With scruples and do set the word itself Against the word:
trg: As thus, 'Come, little ones,' and then again, 'It is as hard to come as for a camel To thread the postern of a small needle's eye.' Thoughts tending to ambition, they do plot Unlikely wonders;

src: Give me mine own again; 'twere no good part To take on me to keep and kill thy heart. So, now I have mine own again, be gone, That I might strive to kill it with a groan.
trg: We make woe wanton with this fond delay: Once more, adieu; the rest let sorrow say.

src: Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness, And fear'st to die? famine is in thy cheeks, Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes, Contempt and beggary hangs upon thy back;
trg: The world is not thy friend nor the world's law; The world affords no law to make thee rich; Then be not poor, but break it, and take this.

src: Let them not live to taste this land's increase That would with treason wound this fair land's peace! Now civil wounds are stopp'd, peace lives again: That she may long live here, God say amen!
trg: I have, my liege.

src: Therefore, Lord Oxford, to prevent the worst, Forthwith we'll send him hence to Brittany, Till storms be past of civil enmity.
trg: Ay, for if Edward repossess the crown, 'Tis like that Richmond with the rest shall down.

src: Yet one time he did call me by my name: I urged our old acquaintance, and the drops That we have bled together. Coriolanus He would not answer to: forbad all names;
trg: He was a kind of nothing, titleless, Till he had forged himself a name o' the fire Of burning Rome.

src: Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham, If ever any grudge were lodged between us; Of you, Lord Rivers, and, Lord Grey, of you; That without desert have frown'd on me; Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen;
trg: indeed, of all. I do not know that Englishman alive With whom my soul is any jot at odds More than the infant that is born to-night I thank my God for my humility.

src: Sirrah, if thy captain knew I were here, he would use me with estimation.
trg: Come, my captain knows you not.

src: Whereto if you'll a willing ear incline, What's mine is yours and what is yours is mine. So, bring us to our palace; where we'll show What's yet behind, that's meet you all should know.
trg: I'll pheeze you, in faith.

src: Once more, the more to aggravate the note, With a foul traitor's name stuff I thy throat; And wish, so please my sovereign, ere I move, What my tongue speaks my right drawn sword may prove.
trg: Let not my cold words here accuse my zeal: 'Tis not the trial of a woman's war, The bitter clamour of two eager tongues, Can arbitrate this cause betwixt us twain;

src: How blessed are we that are not simple men! Yet nature might have made me as these are, Therefore I will not disdain.
trg: This cannot be but a great courtier.

src: O heavens! O heavens!
trg: Nay! prithee, woman,--

src: A king of beasts, indeed; if aught but beasts, I had been still a happy king of men. Good sometime queen, prepare thee hence for France:
trg: Think I am dead and that even here thou takest, As from my death-bed, thy last living leave.

src: Maiden, no remedy.
trg: Yes; I do think that you might pardon him, And neither heaven nor man grieve at the mercy.

src: The blessed gods Purge all infection from our air whilst you Do climate here! You have a holy father, A graceful gentleman; against whose person, So sacred as it is, I have done sin:
trg: For which the heavens, taking angry note, Have left me issueless; and your father's blest, As he from heaven merits it, with you Worthy his goodness.

src: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter: I would to God all strifes were well compounded. My sovereign liege, I do beseech your majesty To take our brother Clarence to your grace.
trg: Why, madam, have I offer'd love for this To be so bouted in this royal presence? Who knows not that the noble duke is dead? You do him injury to scorn his corse.

src: Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift; Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.
trg: Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set On the fair daughter of rich Capulet: As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine; And all combined, save what thou must combine By holy marriage:

src: Or Edward's soft and pitiful, like mine I am too childish-foolish for this world.
trg: Hie thee to hell for shame, and leave the world, Thou cacodemon! there thy kingdom is.

src: She shall not need; we'll meet her in the field.
trg: What, with five thousand men?

src: Hie to high fortune! Honest nurse, farewell.
trg: So smile the heavens upon this holy act, That after hours with sorrow chide us not!

src: Why, how now, Claudio! whence comes this restraint?
trg: From too much liberty, my Lucio, liberty: As surfeit is the father of much fast, So every scope by the immoderate use Turns to restraint.

src: Either be patient, and entreat me fair, Or with the clamorous report of war Thus will I drown your exclamations.
trg: Art thou my son?

src: My fan, Peter.
trg: Good Peter, to hide her face; for her fan's the fairer face.

src: O, doubt not that; I speak from certainties. Nay, more, Some parcels of their power are forth already, And only hitherward. I leave your honours.
trg: If we and Caius Marcius chance to meet, 'Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike Till one can do no more.

src: In your lord's scale is nothing but himself, And some few vanities that make him light;
trg: But in the balance of great Bolingbroke, Besides himself, are all the English peers, And with that odds he weighs King Richard down. Post you to London, and you will find it so;

src: But that a joy past joy calls out on me, It were a grief, so brief to part with thee: Farewell.
trg: Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily, That we have had no time to move our daughter: Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly, And so did I:--Well, we were born to die.

src: Here comes Signior Claudio, led by the provost to prison; and there's Madam Juliet.
trg: Fellow, why dost thou show me thus to the world? Bear me to prison, where I am committed.

src: at the last, Do as the heavens have done, forget your evil; With them forgive yourself.
trg: Whilst I remember Her and her virtues, I cannot forget My blemishes in them, and so still think of The wrong I did myself;

src: Nay, but hear me.
trg: Go to, then.

src: Was never mother had so dear a loss! Alas, I am the mother of these moans! Their woes are parcell'd, mine are general. She for an Edward weeps, and so do I; I for a Clarence weep, so doth not she:
trg: These babes for Clarence weep and so do I; I for an Edward weep, so do not they: Alas, you three, on me, threefold distress'd, Pour all your tears!

src: Put this in any liquid thing you will, And drink it off; and, if you had the strength Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight.
trg: There is thy gold, worse poison to men's souls, Doing more murders in this loathsome world, Than these poor compounds that thou mayst not sell. I sell thee poison; thou hast sold me none. Farewell:

src: I am sworn brother, sweet, To grim Necessity, and he and I Will keep a league till death. Hie thee to France And cloister thee in some religious house:
trg: Our holy lives must win a new world's crown, Which our profane hours here have stricken down.

src: Alas, I look'd when some of you should say, I was too strict to make mine own away; But you gave leave to my unwilling tongue Against my will to do myself this wrong.
trg: Cousin, farewell; and, uncle, bid him so: Six years we banish him, and he shall go.

src: Lord marshal, let me kiss my sovereign's hand, And bow my knee before his majesty: For Mowbray and myself are like two men That vow a long and weary pilgrimage;
trg: Then let us take a ceremonious leave And loving farewell of our several friends.

src: ' mine integrity Being counted falsehood, shall, as I express it, Be so received. But thus:
trg: if powers divine Behold our human actions, as they do, I doubt not then but innocence shall make False accusation blush and tyranny Tremble at patience.

src: ' 'Thus, thus,' quoth Forrest, 'girdling one another Within their innocent alabaster arms: Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, Which in their summer beauty kiss'd each other.
trg: A book of prayers on their pillow lay; Which once,' quoth Forrest, 'almost changed my mind; But O! the devil'--there the villain stopp'd Whilst Dighton thus told on:

src: Who goes there?
trg: Stay, or thou diest!

src: Even he that makes her queen who should be else?
trg: What, thou?

src: but at last I well might hear, delivered with a groan, 'O, farewell, Warwick!'
trg: Sweet rest his soul! Fly, lords, and save yourselves; For Warwick bids you all farewell to meet in heaven.

src: I was, my lord.
trg: Go take her hence, and marry her instantly. Do you the office, friar; which consummate, Return him here again. Go with him, provost.

src: Stay, or thou diest!
trg: What are they that fly there?

src: Most dangerous Is that temptation that doth goad us on To sin in loving virtue: never could the strumpet, With all her double vigour, art and nature, Once stir my temper;
trg: but this virtuous maid Subdues me quite. Even till now, When men were fond, I smiled and wonder'd how.

src: Help, help, help!
trg: How now! what means death in this rude assault? Villain, thy own hand yields thy death's instrument. Go thou, and fill another room in hell.

src: Be that you are, That is, a woman; if you be more, you're none; If you be one, as you are well express'd By all external warrants, show it now, By putting on the destined livery.
trg: I have no tongue but one: gentle my lord, Let me entreat you speak the former language.

src: Sir, The manner of your bearing towards him, with What you as from your father shall deliver, Things known betwixt us three, I'll write you down:
trg: The which shall point you forth at every sitting What you must say; that he shall not perceive But that you have your father's bosom there And speak his very heart.

src: I do believe it.
trg: Do not you fear: upon mine honour, I will stand betwixt you and danger.

src: O slaves, I can tell you news,-- news, you rascals!
trg: What, what, what? let's partake.

src: Tell me, moreover, hast thou sounded him, If he appeal the duke on ancient malice; Or worthily, as a good subject should, On some known ground of treachery in him?
trg: As near as I could sift him on that argument, On some apparent danger seen in him Aim'd at your highness, no inveterate malice.

src: and, with a piece of scripture, Tell them that God bids us do good for evil: And thus I clothe my naked villany With old odd ends stolen out of holy writ;
trg: And seem a saint, when most I play the devil. But, soft! here come my executioners. How now, my hardy, stout resolved mates! Are you now going to dispatch this deed?

src: How long a time lies in one little word! Four lagging winters and four wanton springs End in a word: such is the breath of kings.
trg: I thank my liege, that in regard of me He shortens four years of my son's exile: But little vantage shall I reap thereby;

src: My lord!
trg: Good news or bad, that thou comest in so bluntly?

src: Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager, first begins to crow?
trg: The old cock.

src: Nay, take away this scolding crookback rather.
trg: Peace, wilful boy, or I will charm your tongue.

src: My lord, the army of the Duke of Buckingham--
trg: Out on you, owls! nothing but songs of death? Take that, until thou bring me better news.

src: An he had been cannibally given, he might have broiled and eaten him too.
trg: But, more of thy news?

src: Take my cap, Jupiter, and I thank thee. Hoo! Marcius coming home!
trg: Nay,'tis true.

src: thou dost consent In some large measure to thy father's death, In that thou seest thy wretched brother die, Who was the model of thy father's life. Call it not patience, Gaunt; it is despair:
trg: In suffering thus thy brother to be slaughter'd, Thou showest the naked pathway to thy life, Teaching stern murder how to butcher thee:

src: Your actions are my dreams; You had a bastard by Polixenes, And I but dream'd it. As you were past all shame,-- Those of your fact are so--so past all truth: Which to deny concerns more than avails;
trg: Sir, spare your threats: The bug which you would fright me with I seek. To me can life be no commodity: The crown and comfort of my life, your favour, I do give lost;

src: yet his nature In that's no changeling; and I must excuse What cannot be amended.
trg: Yet I wish, sir,-- I mean for your particular,--you had not Join'd in commission with him; but either Had borne the action of yourself, or else To him had left it solely.

src: Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.
trg: Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong, To strive for that which resteth in my choice: I am no breeching scholar in the schools;

src: Master, it is no time to chide you now; Affection is not rated from the heart: If love have touch'd you, nought remains but so, 'Redime te captum quam queas minimo.'
trg: Gramercies, lad, go forward; this contents: The rest will comfort, for thy counsel's sound.

src: Do not you fear: upon mine honour, I will stand betwixt you and danger.
trg: Nor night nor day no rest: it is but weakness To bear the matter thus; mere weakness. If The cause were not in being,--part o' the cause, She the adulteress;

src: O, had it been a stranger, not my child, To smooth his fault I should have been more mild: A partial slander sought I to avoid, And in the sentence my own life destroy'd.
trg: Alas, I look'd when some of you should say, I was too strict to make mine own away; But you gave leave to my unwilling tongue Against my will to do myself this wrong.

src: Bliss be upon you! Tell me, good my friend, What torch is yond, that vainly lends his light To grubs and eyeless skulls? as I discern, It burneth in the Capel's monument.
trg: It doth so, holy sir; and there's my master, One that you love.

src: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.
trg: Then I salute you with this kingly title: Long live Richard, England's royal king!

src: Aufidius, though I cannot make true wars, I'll frame convenient peace. Now, good Aufidius, Were you in my stead, would you have heard A mother less? or granted less, Aufidius?
trg: I was moved withal.

src: Good Camillo, Your changed complexions are to me a mirror Which shows me mine changed too; for I must be A party in this alteration, finding Myself thus alter'd with 't.
trg: There is a sickness Which puts some of us in distemper, but I cannot name the disease; and it is caught Of you that yet are well.

src: Some of those seven are dried by nature's course, Some of those branches by the Destinies cut; Ah, Gaunt, his blood was thine!
trg: that bed, that womb, That metal, that self-mould, that fashion'd thee Made him a man; and though thou livest and breathest, Yet art thou slain in him:

src: grant that, and tell me, In peace what each of them by the other lose, That they combine not there.
trg: Tush, tush!

src: Come, my gracious lord, Shall I be your playfellow?
trg: No, I'll none of you.
Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death, Gorged with the dearest morsel of the earth, Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open, And, in despite, I'll cram thee with more food!

src: I am come to know your pleasure.
trg: That you might know it, would much better please me Than to demand what 'tis. Your brother cannot live.

src: Tell her, Emilia. I'll use that tongue I have: if wit flow from't As boldness from my bosom, let 't not be doubted I shall do good.
trg: Now be you blest for it! I'll to the queen: please you, come something nearer.

src: Here's ado, To lock up honesty and honour from The access of gentle visitors! Is't lawful, pray you, To see her women? any of them? Emilia?
trg: So please you, madam, To put apart these your attendants, I Shall bring Emilia forth.

src: And, I beseech you, hear me, who profess Myself your loyal servant, your physician, Your most obedient counsellor, yet that dare Less appear so in comforting your evils, Than such as most seem yours:
trg: I say, I come From your good queen.

src: This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs, That presses them and learns them first to bear, Making them women of good carriage: This is she--
trg: Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace! Thou talk'st of nothing.

src: Believe me, sister, of all the men alive I never yet beheld that special face Which I could fancy more than any other.
trg: Minion, thou liest. Is't not Hortensio?

src: Taste of it first, as thou art wont to do.
trg: My lord, I dare not: Sir Pierce of Exton, who lately came from the king, commands the contrary.

src: The note lies in's throat, if he say I said so.
Sweet York, be patient. Hear me, gentle liege.
trg: Rise up, good aunt.

src: ah, what a fault were this! Say Warwick was our anchor; what of that? And Montague our topmost; what of him? Our slaughter'd friends the tackles; what of these?
trg: Why, is not Oxford here another anchor? And Somerset another goodly mast? The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings?

src: from whence, set forth in pomp, She came adorned hither like sweet May, Sent back like Hallowmas or short'st of day.
trg: And must we be divided? must we part?

src: Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly, I'll wear the willow garland for his sake.
trg: Tell him, my mourning weeds are laid aside, And I am ready to put armour on.

src: and, for a name, Now puts the drowsy and neglected act Freshly on me: 'tis surely for a name.
trg: I warrant it is: and thy head stands so tickle on thy shoulders that a milkmaid, if she be in love, may sigh it off. Send after the duke and appeal to him.

src: Wherefore? wherefore?
trg: Why, here's he that was wont to thwack our general, Caius Marcius.

src: Nay, whom they shall obey, and love thee too, Unless they seek for hatred at my hands; Which if they do, yet will I keep thee safe, And they shall feel the vengeance of my wrath.
And yet methinks your grace hath not done well, To give the heir and daughter of Lord Scales Unto the brother of your loving bride; She better would have fitted me or Clarence:
trg: But in your bride you bury brotherhood.

src: I say she shall: and first begin with her.
trg: Fie, fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow, And dart not scornful glances from those eyes, To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor:

src: Wait you on him, I charge you, as becomes, While I make way from hence to save my life: You understand me?
trg: I, sir! ne'er a whit.

src: No other harm but loss of such a lord.
trg: The loss of such a lord includes all harm.

src: I beseech you, peace: Or, if you'ld ask, remember this before: The thing I have forsworn to grant may never Be held by you denials.
trg: Do not bid me Dismiss my soldiers, or capitulate Again with Rome's mechanics: tell me not Wherein I seem unnatural: desire not To ally my rages and revenges with Your colder reasons.

src: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banished; Romeo that kill'd him, he is banished.
trg: O God! did Romeo's hand shed Tybalt's blood?

src: I'll keep you company. Will you along?
trg: We stay here for the people.

src: I will seem friendly, as thou hast advised me.
trg: O miserable lady! But, for me, What case stand I in? I must be the poisoner Of good Polixenes;

src: Give me thy torch, boy: hence, and stand aloof: Yet put it out, for I would not be seen. Under yond yew-trees lay thee all along, Holding thine ear close to the hollow ground;
trg: So shall no foot upon the churchyard tread, Being loose, unfirm, with digging up of graves, But thou shalt hear it: whistle then to me, As signal that thou hear'st something approach.

src: They should not laugh if I could reach them, nor Shall she within my power.
trg: You must not enter.

src: for the harlot king Is quite beyond mine arm, out of the blank And level of my brain, plot-proof; but she I can hook to me:
trg: say that she were gone, Given to the fire, a moiety of my rest Might come to me again. Who's there?

src: near-legged before and with, a half-chequed bit and a head-stall of sheeps leather which, being restrained to keep him from stumbling, hath been often burst and now repaired with knots;
trg: one girth six time pieced and a woman's crupper of velure, which hath two letters for her name fairly set down in studs, and here and there pieced with packthread.

src: If I did take the kingdom from your sons, To make amends, Ill give it to your daughter. They are as children but one step below, Even of your mettle, of your very blood;
trg: Of an one pain, save for a night of groans Endured of her, for whom you bid like sorrow. Your children were vexation to your youth, But mine shall be a comfort to your age.

src: Why, how are we censured?
trg: Because you talk of pride now,--will you not be angry?

src: Heaven cease this idle humour in your honour! O, that a mighty man of such descent, Of such possessions and so high esteem, Should be infused with so foul a spirit!
trg: What, would you make me mad? Am not I Christopher Sly, old Sly's son of Burtonheath, by birth a pedlar, by education a cardmaker, by transmutation a bear-herd, and now by present profession a tinker?

src: Look, as I blow this feather from my face, And as the air blows it to me again, Obeying with my wind when I do blow, And yielding to another when it blows, Commanded always by the greater gust;
trg: Such is the lightness of you common men. But do not break your oaths; for of that sin My mild entreaty shall not make you guilty. Go where you will, the king shall be commanded;

src: But stay thee, 'tis the fruits of love I mean.
trg: The fruits of love I mean, my loving liege.

src: What, neither?
trg: Neither.

src: No, nor a man that fears you less than he, That's lesser than a little. Hark! our drums Are bringing forth our youth. We'll break our walls, Rather than they shall pound us up:
trg: our gates, Which yet seem shut, we, have but pinn'd with rushes; They'll open of themselves. Hark you. far off! There is Aufidius; list, what work he makes Amongst your cloven army.

src: This sessions, to our great grief we pronounce, Even pushes 'gainst our heart: the party tried The daughter of a king, our wife, and one Of us too much beloved.
trg: Let us be clear'd Of being tyrannous, since we so openly Proceed in justice, which shall have due course, Even to the guilt or the purgation. Produce the prisoner.

src: Therefore present to her--as sometime Margaret Did to thy father, steep'd in Rutland's blood,-- A handkerchief;
trg: which, say to her, did drain The purple sap from her sweet brother's body And bid her dry her weeping eyes therewith. If this inducement force her not to love, Send her a story of thy noble acts;

src: Thou liest: his father is come from Padua and here looking out at the window.
trg: Art thou his father?

src: Take hands, a bargain! And, friends unknown, you shall bear witness to 't: I give my daughter to him, and will make Her portion equal his.
trg: O, that must be I' the virtue of your daughter: one being dead, I shall have more than you can dream of yet; Enough then for your wonder. But, come on, Contract us 'fore these witnesses.

src: We talk here in the public haunt of men: Either withdraw unto some private place, And reason coldly of your grievances, Or else depart; here all eyes gaze on us.
trg: Men's eyes were made to look, and let them gaze; I will not budge for no man's pleasure, I.

src: I beseech your highness, do not marry me to a whore. Your highness said even now, I made you a duke: good my lord, do not recompense me in making me a cuckold.
trg: Upon mine honour, thou shalt marry her. Thy slanders I forgive; and therewithal Remit thy other forfeits. Take him to prison; And see our pleasure herein executed.

src: Sound drums and trumpets, and the king will fly.
trg: Sons, peace!

src: Plantagenet.
trg: Why, that was he.

src: My Lord, I have consider'd in my mind The late demand that you did sound me in.
trg: Well, let that pass. Dorset is fled to Richmond.

src: Ay, ay, so strives the woodcock with the gin.
trg: So doth the cony struggle in the net.

src: That's my office.
trg: Spoke like an officer; ha' to thee, lad!

src: Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.
trg: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what do you think is his name?

src: the fury spent, anon Did this break-from her: and, for the babe Is counted lost for ever, Perdita, I prithee, call't.
trg: For this ungentle business Put on thee by my lord, thou ne'er shalt see Thy wife Paulina more.' And so, with shrieks She melted into air.

src: Come on then, let's to bed. Ah, sirrah, by my fay, it waxes late: I'll to my rest.
trg: Come hither, nurse. What is yond gentleman?

src: By my head, here come the Capulets.
trg: By my heel, I care not.

src: Hilloa, loa!
trg: What, art so near? If thou'lt see a thing to talk on when thou art dead and rotten, come hither. What ailest thou, man?

src: For her, my lord, I dare my life lay down and will do't, sir, Please you to accept it, that the queen is spotless I' the eyes of heaven and to you; I mean, In this which you accuse her.
trg: If it prove She's otherwise, I'll keep my stables where I lodge my wife; I'll go in couples with her; Than when I feel and see her no farther trust her;

src: Yet your good will must have that thanks from Rome, after the measure As you intended well.
trg: I'll undertake 't: I think he'll hear me. Yet, to bite his lip And hum at good Cominius, much unhearts me. He was not taken well; he had not dined:

src: Hark, hark!
trg: Where should this music be? i' the air or the earth? It sounds no more: and sure, it waits upon Some god o' the island.

src: Thyself and thy belongings Are not thine own so proper as to waste Thyself upon thy virtues, they on thee. Heaven doth with us as we with torches do, Not light them for themselves;
trg: for if our virtues Did not go forth of us, 'twere all alike As if we had them not. But I do bend my speech To one that can my part in him advertise; Hold therefore, Angelo:

src: Ah! and did they so?
trg: No, so God help me, they spake not a word; But, like dumb statues or breathing stones, Gazed each on other, and look'd deadly pale. Which when I saw, I reprehended them;

src: The royal tree hath left us royal fruit, Which, mellow'd by the stealing hours of time, Will well become the seat of majesty, And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.
trg: On him I lay what you would lay on me, The right and fortune of his happy stars; Which God defend that I should wring from him!

src: I thought, at least, he would have said the king; Or did he make the jest against his will?
trg: Is not a dukedom, sir, a goodly gift?

src: O mischief, thou art swift To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!
trg: I do remember an apothecary,-- And hereabouts he dwells,--which late I noted In tatter'd weeds, with overwhelming brows, Culling of simples;

src: Blue, my lord.
trg: Nay, that's a mock: I have seen a lady's nose That has been blue, but not her eyebrows.

src: Clarence, whom I, indeed, have laid in darkness, I do beweep to many simple gulls Namely, to Hastings, Derby, Buckingham;
trg: And say it is the queen and her allies That stir the king against the duke my brother. Now, they believe it; and withal whet me To be revenged on Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: But then I sigh;

src: God shield I should disturb devotion! Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye: Till then, adieu; and keep this holy kiss.
trg: O shut the door! and when thou hast done so, Come weep with me; past hope, past cure, past help!

src: If any think brave death outweighs bad life And that his country's dearer than himself; Let him alone, or so many so minded, Wave thus, to express his disposition, And follow Marcius. O, me alone!
trg: make you a sword of me? If these shows be not outward, which of you But is four Volsces? none of you but is Able to bear against the great Aufidius A shield as hard as his.

src: Nor no one here; for curses never pass The lips of those that breathe them in the air.
trg: I'll not believe but they ascend the sky, And there awake God's gentle-sleeping peace. O Buckingham, take heed of yonder dog! Look, when he fawns, he bites;

src: And I to Norfolk with my followers.
trg: And I unto the sea from whence I came.

src: Farewell, farewell! one kiss, and I'll descend.
trg: Art thou gone so? love, lord, ay, husband, friend! I must hear from thee every day in the hour, For in a minute there are many days:

src: To-morrow, then, we will attend your grace: And so most joyfully we take our leave.
trg: Come, let us to our holy task again. Farewell, good cousin; farewell, gentle friends.

src: being press'd to the war, Even when the navel of the state was touch'd, They would not thread the gates. This kind of service Did not deserve corn gratis.
trg: Being i' the war Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they show'd Most valour, spoke not for them:

src: My brain I'll prove the female to my soul, My soul the father;
trg: and these two beget A generation of still-breeding thoughts, And these same thoughts people this little world, In humours like the people of this world, For no thought is contented.

src: I will bethink me: come again tomorrow.
trg: Hark how I'll bribe you: good my lord, turn back.

src: ' So, underneath the belly of their steeds, That stain'd their fetlocks in his smoking blood, The noble gentleman gave up the ghost.
trg: Then let the earth be drunken with our blood: I'll kill my horse, because I will not fly. Why stand we like soft-hearted women here, Wailing our losses, whiles the foe doth rage;

src: Has censured him Already; and, as I hear, the provost hath A warrant for his execution.
trg: Alas! what poor ability's in me To do him good?

src: Wert thou the Hector That was the whip of your bragg'd progeny, Thou shouldst not scape me here. Officious, and not valiant, you have shamed me In your condemned seconds.
trg: If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's work, Thou'ldst not believe thy deeds:

src: My noble queen, let former grudges pass, And henceforth I am thy true servitor: I will revenge his wrong to Lady Bona, And replant Henry in his former state.
trg: Warwick, these words have turn'd my hate to love; And I forgive and quite forget old faults, And joy that thou becomest King Henry's friend.

src: I offer'd to awaken his regard For's private friends: his answer to me was, He could not stay to pick them in a pile Of noisome musty chaff:
trg: he said 'twas folly, For one poor grain or two, to leave unburnt, And still to nose the offence.

src: Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash, Like to a censer in a barber's shop: Why, what, i' devil's name, tailor, call'st thou this?
At Southam I did leave him with his forces, And do expect him here some two hours hence.
trg: Then Clarence is at hand, I hear his drum.

src: Sir, my liege, Your eye hath too much youth in't: not a month 'Fore your queen died, she was more worth such gazes Than what you look on now.
trg: I thought of her, Even in these looks I made. But your petition Is yet unanswer'd. I will to your father: Your honour not o'erthrown by your desires, I am friend to them and you:

src: Where, after I have solemnly interr'd At Chertsey monastery this noble king, And wet his grave with my repentant tears, I will with all expedient duty see you: For divers unknown reasons.
trg: I beseech you, Grant me this boon.

src: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.
trg: Then never trust me, if I be afeard.

src: Or when you waked, so waked as if you slept.
trg: These fifteen years! by my fay, a goodly nap. But did I never speak of all that time?

src: Hail to you both!
trg: Your Coriolanus Is not much miss'd, but with his friends: The commonwealth doth stand, and so would do, Were he more angry at it.

src: O, sir, you must: and therefore I beseech you Look forward on the journey you shall go.
trg: I swear I will not die to-day for any man's persuasion.

src: Of this allow, If ever you have spent time worse ere now; If never, yet that Time himself doth say He wishes earnestly you never may.
trg: I pray thee, good Camillo, be no more importunate: 'tis a sickness denying thee any thing; a death to grant this.

src: Her vestal livery is but sick and green And none but fools do wear it; cast it off. It is my lady, O, it is my love! O, that she knew she were! She speaks yet she says nothing: what of that?
trg: Her eye discourses; I will answer it. I am too bold, 'tis not to me she speaks:

src: My lords, we were forewarned of your coming, And shut the gates for safety of ourselves; For now we owe allegiance unto Henry.
trg: But, master mayor, if Henry be your king, Yet Edward at the least is Duke of York.

src: Renowned queen, with patience calm the storm, While we bethink a means to break it off.
trg: The more we stay, the stronger grows our foe.

src: And I the house of York.
trg: Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford, Vouchsafe, at our request, to stand aside, While I use further conference with Warwick.

src: My pity hath been balm to heal their wounds, My mildness hath allay'd their swelling griefs, My mercy dried their water-flowing tears;
trg: I have not been desirous of their wealth, Nor much oppress'd them with great subsidies. Nor forward of revenge, though they much err'd: Then why should they love Edward more than me?

src: for, as I hear, You, that are king, though he do wear the crown, Have caused him, by new act of parliament, To blot out me, and put his own son in.
trg: And reason too: Who should succeed the father but the son?

src: O, where is Romeo? saw you him to-day? Right glad I am he was not at this fray.
trg: Madam, an hour before the worshipp'd sun Peer'd forth the golden window of the east, A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad;

src: No, to their lives bad friends were contrary.
trg: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.

src: Alas, you know, 'tis far from hence to France; How could he stay till Warwick made return?
trg: My lords, forbear this talk; here comes the king.

src: Not he alone shall suffer what wit can make heavy and vengeance bitter; but those that are germane to him, though removed fifty times, shall all come under the hangman:
trg: which though it be great pity, yet it is necessary. An old sheep-whistling rogue a ram-tender, to offer to have his daughter come into grace! Some say he shall be stoned;

src: And here I take the unfeigned oath, Never to marry with her though she would entreat: Fie on her! see, how beastly she doth court him!
trg: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!

src: You shall ha' it, worthy sir.
trg: A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices begged. I have your alms: adieu.

src: Hath she forgot already that brave prince, Edward, her lord, whom I, some three months since, Stabb'd in my angry mood at Tewksbury? On me, whose all not equals Edward's moiety?
trg: On me, that halt and am unshapen thus? My dukedom to a beggarly denier, I do mistake my person all this while: Upon my life, she finds, although I cannot, Myself to be a marvellous proper man.

src: Return unto thy lord; commend me to him: Tell him the queen hath heartily consented He shall espouse Elizabeth her daughter. These letters will resolve him of my mind. Farewell.
trg: Will not King Richard let me speak with him?

src: No, I'll not rear Another's issue.
trg: Please your highness, posts From those you sent to the oracle are come An hour since: Cleomenes and Dion, Being well arrived from Delphos, are both landed, Hasting to the court.

src: What is thy name?
trg: A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears, And harsh in sound to thine.

src: I say, a devil. Thinkest thou, Hortensio, though her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be married to hell?
trg: I cannot tell; but I had as lief take her dowry with this condition, to be whipped at the high cross every morning.

src: No such jade as you, if me you mean.
trg: Alas! good Kate, I will not burden thee; For, knowing thee to be but young and light--

src: It toucheth you, my lord, as much as me.
trg: Yea, and much more: but I was born so high, Our aery buildeth in the cedar's top, And dallies with the wind and scorns the sun.

src: The nobles in great earnestness are going All to the senate-house: some news is come That turns their countenances.
trg: 'Tis this slave;-- Go whip him, 'fore the people's eyes:--his raising; Nothing but his report.

src: What stays had I but they? and they are gone.
trg: Was never widow had so dear a loss!

src: How now, my lord, what say the citizens?
trg: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord, The citizens are mum and speak not a word.

src: Say, I will love her everlastingly.
trg: But how long shall that title 'ever' last?

src: Not a hair perish'd; On their sustaining garments not a blemish, But fresher than before: and, as thou badest me, In troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle.
trg: The king's son have I landed by himself; Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs In an odd angle of the isle and sitting, His arms in this sad knot.

src: I never look'd for better at his hands, After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.
trg: Yet had not we determined he should die, Until your lordship came to see his death; Which now the loving haste of these our friends, Somewhat against our meaning, have prevented:

src: contract, succession, Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none; No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil; No occupation; all men idle, all; And women too, but innocent and pure; No sovereignty;--
trg: Yet he would be king on't.

src: Here is everything advantageous to life.
trg: True; save means to live.

src: Thy gown? why, ay: come, tailor, let us see't. O mercy, God! what masquing stuff is here? What's this? a sleeve? 'tis like a demi-cannon: What, up and down, carved like an apple-tart?
trg: Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash, Like to a censer in a barber's shop: Why, what, i' devil's name, tailor, call'st thou this?

src: Is there not milking-time, when you are going to bed, or kiln-hole, to whistle off these secrets, but you must be tittle-tattling before all our guests? 'tis well they are whispering:
trg: clamour your tongues, and not a word more.

src: So far be mine, my most redoubted lord, As my true service shall deserve your love.
trg: Well you deserve: they well deserve to have, That know the strong'st and surest way to get. Uncle, give me your hands: nay, dry your eyes; Tears show their love, but want their remedies.

src: yet thou behold'st!
trg: You keep a constant temper.

src: Praised!
trg: Hast thou read truth?

src: Sir, my name is Lucio; well known to the duke.
trg: He shall know you better, sir, if I may live to report you.

src: My lord, wise men ne'er sit and wail their woes, But presently prevent the ways to wail.
trg: To fear the foe, since fear oppresseth strength, Gives in your weakness strength unto your foe, And so your follies fight against yourself. Fear and be slain; no worse can come to fight:

src: My love, forbear to fawn upon their frowns: What danger or what sorrow can befall thee, So long as Edward is thy constant friend, And their true sovereign, whom they must obey?
trg: Nay, whom they shall obey, and love thee too, Unless they seek for hatred at my hands; Which if they do, yet will I keep thee safe, And they shall feel the vengeance of my wrath.

src: Nay, he is dead; and slain by Edward's hand.
trg: In thy foul throat thou liest: Queen Margaret saw Thy murderous falchion smoking in his blood; The which thou once didst bend against her breast, But that thy brothers beat aside the point.

src: Pray you, who does the wolf love?
trg: The lamb.

src: Faith, none for me; except the north-east wind, Which then blew bitterly against our faces, Awaked the sleeping rheum, and so by chance Did grace our hollow parting with a tear.
trg: What said our cousin when you parted with him?

src: Fie, fie, fie! This is the way to kindle, not to quench.
trg: To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.

src: I'll tell thee, ere thou ask it me again. I have been feasting with mine enemy, Where on a sudden one hath wounded me, That's by me wounded: both our remedies Within thy help and holy physic lies:
trg: I bear no hatred, blessed man, for, lo, My intercession likewise steads my foe.

src: Make haste, make haste. Sirrah, fetch drier logs: Call Peter, he will show thee where they are.
trg: I have a head, sir, that will find out logs, And never trouble Peter for the matter.

src: my pains are quite forgot.
trg: Out, devil! I remember them too well: Thou slewest my husband Henry in the Tower, And Edward, my poor son, at Tewksbury.

src: My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken, And brought your prisoner to your palace gate.
trg: See that he be convey'd unto the Tower: And go we, brothers, to the man that took him, To question of his apprehension. Widow, go you along. Lords, use her honourably.

src: Nay, speak thy mind; and let him ne'er speak more That speaks thy words again to do thee harm!
trg: Tends that thou wouldst speak to the Duke of Hereford? If it be so, out with it boldly, man; Quick is mine ear to hear of good towards him.

src: Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as any in Rome.
trg: Menenius, you are known well enough too.

src: We do condemn thee to the very block Where Claudio stoop'd to death, and with like haste. Away with him!
trg: O my most gracious lord, I hope you will not mock me with a husband.

src: Amen.
trg: I thank thee: thou shalt not lose by it.

src: Ay, millstones; as be lesson'd us to weep.
trg: O, do not slander him, for he is kind.

src: Then get your husband's lands, to do them good.
trg: Therefore I came unto your majesty.

src: No truly sir; not a penny.
trg: Go to; I say you shall.

src: It is not my consent, But my entreaty too.
trg: Little have you to say When you depart from him, but, soft and low, 'Remember now my brother.'

src: Come, he hath hid himself among these trees, To be consorted with the humorous night: Blind is his love and best befits the dark.
trg: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark. Now will he sit under a medlar tree, And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit As maids call medlars, when they laugh alone.

src: show the inside of your purse to the outside of his hand, and no more ado. Remember 'stoned,' and 'flayed alive.'
trg: An't please you, sir, to undertake the business for us, here is that gold I have: I'll make it as much more and leave this young man in pawn till I bring it you.

src: Should a villain say so, The most replenish'd villain in the world, He were as much more villain: you, my lord, Do but mistake.
trg: You have mistook, my lady, Polixenes for Leontes: O thou thing!

src: All hail, great master! grave sir, hail! I come To answer thy best pleasure;
trg: be't to fly, To swim, to dive into the fire, to ride On the curl'd clouds, to thy strong bidding task Ariel and all his quality.

src: What am I, sir! nay, what are you, sir? O immortal gods! O fine villain! A silken doublet! a velvet hose! a scarlet cloak! and a copatain hat! O, I am undone! I am undone!
trg: while I play the good husband at home, my son and my servant spend all at the university.

src: Alas, alas!
trg: Sweet sister, let me live: What sin you do to save a brother's life, Nature dispenses with the deed so far That it becomes a virtue.

src: The people are incensed against him.
trg: Stop, Or all will fall in broil.

src: Teeth hadst thou in thy head when thou wast born, To signify thou camest to bite the world: And, if the rest be true which I have heard, Thou camest--
trg: I'll hear no more: die, prophet in thy speech: For this amongst the rest, was I ordain'd.

src: or who pronounced The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death? Before I be convict by course of law, To threaten me with death is most unlawful.
trg: I charge you, as you hope to have redemption By Christ's dear blood shed for our grievous sins, That you depart and lay no hands on me The deed you undertake is damnable.

src: I must another way, To fetch a ladder, by the which your love Must climb a bird's nest soon when it is dark: I am the drudge and toil in your delight, But you shall bear the burden soon at night. Go;
trg: I'll to dinner: hie you to the cell.

src: Who, with a charm join'd to their suffer'd labour, I have left asleep;
trg: Ariel, thy charge Exactly is perform'd: but there's more work. What is the time o' the day?

src: Repent what you have spoke.
trg: For them! I cannot do it to the gods; Must I then do't to them?

src: My name is Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk; Who hither come engaged by my oath-- Which God defend a knight should violate! And as I truly fight, defend me heaven!
trg: Marshal, ask yonder knight in arms, Both who he is and why he cometh hither Thus plated in habiliments of war, And formally, according to our law, Depose him in the justice of his cause.

src: Pardon, dear father.
trg: How hast thou offended? Where is Lucentio?

src: Away towards Salisbury! while we reason here, A royal battle might be won and lost Some one take order Buckingham be brought To Salisbury; the rest march on with me.
trg: Sir Christopher, tell Richmond this from me: That in the sty of this most bloody boar My son George Stanley is frank'd up in hold: If I revolt, off goes young George's head;

src: The taming-school! what, is there such a place?
trg: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master; That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long, To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.

src: O pretty Isabella, I am pale at mine heart to see thine eyes so red: thou must be patient. I am fain to dine and sup with water and bran; I dare not for my head fill my belly;
trg: one fruitful meal would set me to 't. But they say the duke will be here to-morrow. By my troth, Isabel, I loved thy brother:

src: We cannot weigh our brother with ourself: Great men may jest with saints; 'tis wit in them, But in the less foul profanation.
trg: Thou'rt i' the right, girl; more o, that.

src: doth she not count her blest, Unworthy as she is, that we have wrought So worthy a gentleman to be her bridegroom?
trg: Not proud, you have; but thankful, that you have: Proud can I never be of what I hate; But thankful even for hate, that is meant love.

src: Dear my brother, Let him that was the cause of this have power To take off so much grief from you as he Will piece up in himself.
trg: Indeed, my lord, If I had thought the sight of my poor image Would thus have wrought you,--for the stone is mine-- I'ld not have show'd it.

src: He that bereft thee, lady, of thy husband, Did it to help thee to a better husband.
trg: His better doth not breathe upon the earth.

src: My lord, 'tis nothing.
trg: No matter, then, who see it; I will be satisfied; let me see the writing.

src: 'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou hadst been poor John. Draw thy tool! here comes two of the house of the Montagues.
trg: My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.

src: Yea, is the worst well? very well took, i' faith; wisely, wisely.
trg: if you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with you.

src: This is the cause that I, poor Margaret, With this my son, Prince Edward, Henry's heir, Am come to crave thy just and lawful aid; And if thou fail us, all our hope is done:
trg: Scotland hath will to help, but cannot help; Our people and our peers are both misled, Our treasures seized, our soldiers put to flight, And, as thou seest, ourselves in heavy plight.

src: Therefore I came unto your majesty.
trg: I'll tell you how these lands are to be got.

src: Honourable Menenius, my boy Marcius approaches; for the love of Juno, let's go.
trg: Ha! Marcius coming home!

src: O, what may man within him hide, Though angel on the outward side!
trg: How may likeness made in crimes, Making practise on the times, To draw with idle spiders' strings Most ponderous and substantial things! Craft against vice I must apply:

src: O, my heart bleeds To think o' the teen that I have turn'd you to, Which is from my remembrance! Please you, farther.
trg: My brother and thy uncle, call'd Antonio-- I pray thee, mark me--that a brother should Be so perfidious!--he whom next thyself Of all the world I loved and to him put The manage of my state;

src: I protest I love the duke as I love myself.
trg: Hark, how the villain would close now, after his treasonable abuses!

src: I'll privily away. I love the people, But do not like to stage me to their eyes: Through it do well, I do not relish well Their loud applause and Aves vehement;
trg: Nor do I think the man of safe discretion That does affect it. Once more, fare you well.

src: Tell me, good grandam, is our father dead?
trg: No, boy.

src: Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise And dangerous success of bloody wars, As I intend more good to you and yours, Than ever you or yours were by me wrong'd!
trg: What good is cover'd with the face of heaven, To be discover'd, that can do me good?

src: I do well believe your highness; and did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use to laugh at nothing.
trg: 'Twas you we laughed at.

src: It is: and lo, where youthful Edward comes!
trg: Bring forth the gallant, let us hear him speak. What! can so young a thorn begin to prick?

src: Apollo, pardon My great profaneness 'gainst thine oracle! I'll reconcile me to Polixenes, New woo my queen, recall the good Camillo, Whom I proclaim a man of truth, of mercy;
trg: For, being transported by my jealousies To bloody thoughts and to revenge, I chose Camillo for the minister to poison My friend Polixenes:

src: murder is thy alms-deed; Petitioners for blood thou ne'er put'st back.
trg: Away, I say; I charge ye, bear her hence.

src: I do demand, If you submit you to the people's voices, Allow their officers and are content To suffer lawful censure for such faults As shall be proved upon you?
trg: I am content.

src: Say not we brought it.
trg: How! Was it we? we loved him but, like beasts And cowardly nobles, gave way unto your clusters, Who did hoot him out o' the city.

src: Fear not that, my lord.
trg: Then, gentle Clarence, welcome unto Warwick; And welcome, Somerset: I hold it cowardice To rest mistrustful where a noble heart Hath pawn'd an open hand in sign of love;

src: He turns away: Down, ladies; let us shame him with our knees. To his surname Coriolanus 'longs more pride Than pity to our prayers. Down: an end; This is the last:
trg: so we will home to Rome, And die among our neighbours. Nay, behold 's:

src: I will, my lord.
trg: What's here? one dead, or drunk? See, doth he breathe?

src: And if the boy have not a woman's gift To rain a shower of commanded tears, An onion will do well for such a shift, Which in a napkin being close convey'd Shall in despite enforce a watery eye.
trg: See this dispatch'd with all the haste thou canst: Anon I'll give thee more instructions. I know the boy will well usurp the grace, Voice, gait and action of a gentlewoman:

src: My cake is dough; but I'll in among the rest, Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.
trg: Husband, let's follow, to see the end of this ado.

src: But he which bore my letter, Friar John, Was stay'd by accident, and yesternight Return'd my letter back.
trg: Then all alone At the prefixed hour of her waking, Came I to take her from her kindred's vault; Meaning to keep her closely at my cell, Till I conveniently could send to Romeo:

src: Have thy desire.
I'll pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.
trg: But Montague is bound as well as I, In penalty alike; and 'tis not hard, I think, For men so old as we to keep the peace.

src: O let no noble eye profane a tear For me, if I be gored with Mowbray's spear: As confident as is the falcon's flight Against a bird, do I with Mowbray fight. My loving lord, I take my leave of you;
trg: Of you, my noble cousin, Lord Aumerle; Not sick, although I have to do with death, But lusty, young, and cheerly drawing breath.

src: Take my prayers with you. I would the gods had nothing else to do But to confirm my curses! Could I meet 'em But once a-day, it would unclog my heart Of what lies heavy to't.
trg: You have told them home; And, by my troth, you have cause. You'll sup with me?

src: God and your arms be praised, victorious friends, The day is ours, the bloody dog is dead.
trg: Courageous Richmond, well hast thou acquit thee. Lo, here, this long-usurped royalty From the dead temples of this bloody wretch Have I pluck'd off, to grace thy brows withal:

src: In vain thou speak'st, poor boy; my father's blood Hath stopp'd the passage where thy words should enter.
trg: Then let my father's blood open it again: He is a man, and, Clifford, cope with him.

src: What's he that follows there, that would not dance?
trg: I know not.

src: Can sick men play so nicely with their names?
trg: No, misery makes sport to mock itself: Since thou dost seek to kill my name in me, I mock my name, great king, to flatter thee.

src: Not proud, you have; but thankful, that you have: Proud can I never be of what I hate; But thankful even for hate, that is meant love.
trg: How now, how now, chop-logic! What is this? 'Proud,' and 'I thank you,' and 'I thank you not; Out, you green-sickness carrion! out, you baggage! You tallow-face!

src: How now! who calls?
trg: Your mother.

src: She says you have some goodly jest in hand: She will not come: she bids you come to her.
trg: Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile, Intolerable, not to be endured! Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress; Say, I command her to come to me.

src: Hath he born himself penitently in prison? how seems he to be touched?
trg: A man that apprehends death no more dreadfully but as a drunken sleep; careless, reckless, and fearless of what's past, present, or to come; insensible of mortality, and desperately mortal.

src: To please the king I did; to please myself I cannot do it; yet I know no cause Why I should welcome such a guest as grief, Save bidding farewell to so sweet a guest As my sweet Richard:
trg: yet again, methinks, Some unborn sorrow, ripe in fortune's womb, Is coming towards me, and my inward soul With nothing trembles:

src: And in this state she gallops night by night Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love; Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier's nose, And then dreams he of smelling out a suit;
trg: And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig's tail Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep, Then dreams, he of another benefice:

src: And, Clarence, now then it is more than needful Forthwith that Edward be pronounced a traitor, And all his lands and goods be confiscate.
trg: What else? and that succession be determined.

src: Lay hands upon him.
trg: Help Marcius, help, You that be noble; help him, young and old!

src: Well said, noble woman? Before he should thus stoop to the herd, but that The violent fit o' the time craves it as physic For the whole state, I would put mine armour on, Which I can scarcely bear.
trg: What must I do?

src: If is, my liege; and all things are in readiness.
trg: Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge; Use careful watch, choose trusty sentinels.

src: and swore so loud, That, all-amazed, the priest let fall the book;
trg: And, as he stoop'd again to take it up, The mad-brain'd bridegroom took him such a cuff That down fell priest and book and book and priest: 'Now take them up,' quoth he, 'if any list.'

src: Nine! Come hither to me, Master Froth. Master Froth, I would not have you acquainted with tapsters: they will draw you, Master Froth, and you will hang them.
trg: Get you gone, and let me hear no more of you.

src: Beloved of me; and that my deeds shall prove.
trg: And that his bags shall prove.

src: Alack, for mercy!
trg: Yes, faith, and all his lords; the Duke of Milan And his brave son being twain.

src: Such wind as scatters young men through the world, To seek their fortunes farther than at home Where small experience grows. But in a few, Signior Hortensio, thus it stands with me:
trg: Antonio, my father, is deceased; And I have thrust myself into this maze, Haply to wive and thrive as best I may: Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home, And so am come abroad to see the world.

src: Ratcliff, my lord; 'tis I. The early village-cock Hath twice done salutation to the morn; Your friends are up, and buckle on their armour.
trg: O Ratcliff, I have dream'd a fearful dream! What thinkest thou, will our friends prove all true?

src: for I am proof against that title and what shame else belongs to't. To him will I present them: there may be matter in it.
trg: Sir, you have done enough, and have perform'd A saint-like sorrow: no fault could you make, Which you have not redeem'd; indeed, paid down More penitence than done trespass:

src: To disproportion me in every part, Like to a chaos, or an unlick'd bear-whelp That carries no impression like the dam. And am I then a man to be beloved? O monstrous fault, to harbour such a thought!
trg: And yet I know not how to get the crown, For many lives stand between me and home:

src: Not any yet: But as the unthought-on accident is guilty To what we wildly do, so we profess Ourselves to be the slaves of chance and flies Of every wind that blows.
trg: Then list to me:

src: He means, my lord, that we are too remiss; Whilst Bolingbroke, through our security, Grows strong and great in substance and in power.
trg: Discomfortable cousin!

src: Dost thou forget From what a torment I did free thee?
trg: No.

src: And say you would present her at the leet, Because she brought stone jugs and no seal'd quarts: Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.
trg: Ay, the woman's maid of the house.

src: Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.
trg: Musicians, O, musicians, 'Heart's ease, Heart's ease:' O, an you will have me live, play 'Heart's ease.'

src: Come, follow. Speak not for him.
trg: Beseech you, sir, be merry; you have cause, So have we all, of joy; for our escape Is much beyond our loss. Our hint of woe Is common;

src: And some will mourn in ashes, some coal-black, For the deposing of a rightful king.
trg: My lord, the mind of Bolingbroke is changed: You must to Pomfret, not unto the Tower. And, madam, there is order ta'en for you; With all swift speed you must away to France.

src: So proudly as if he disdain'd the ground.
trg: So proud that Bolingbroke was on his back! That jade hath eat bread from my royal hand; This hand hath made him proud with clapping him. Would he not stumble?

src: and, in roaring for a chamber-pot, dismiss the controversy bleeding the more entangled by your hearing: all the peace you make in their cause is, calling both the parties knaves.
trg: You are a pair of strange ones.

src: Having determined of the Volsces and To send for Titus Lartius, it remains, As the main point of this our after-meeting, To gratify his noble service that Hath thus stood for his country:
trg: Speak, good Cominius: Leave nothing out for length, and make us think Rather our state's defective for requital Than we to stretch it out.

src: But to be frank, and give it thee again. And yet I wish but for the thing I have: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep;
trg: the more I give to thee, The more I have, for both are infinite. I hear some noise within; dear love, adieu! Anon, good nurse! Sweet Montague, be true. Stay but a little, I will come again.

src: Then, till the fury of his highness settle, Come not before him.
trg: I not purpose it. I think, Camillo?

src: Do you call, sir?
trg: Sirrah, here's a fellow will help you to-morrow in your execution. If you think it meet, compound with him by the year, and let him abide here with you;

src: If ever he have wife, let her he made A miserable by the death of him As I am made by my poor lord and thee! Come, now towards Chertsey with your holy load, Taken from Paul's to be interred there;
trg: And still, as you are weary of the weight, Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry's corse.

src: My lord, you told me you would tell the rest, When weeping made you break the story off, of our two cousins coming into London.
trg: Where did I leave?

src: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground, long heath, brown furze, any thing. The wills above be done! but I would fain die a dry death.
trg: If by your art, my dearest father, you have Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.

src: O, sit my husband's wrongs on Hereford's spear, That it may enter butcher Mowbray's breast! Farewell, old Gaunt: thy sometimes brother's wife With her companion grief must end her life.
trg: Sister, farewell; I must to Coventry: As much good stay with thee as go with me!

src: By this hand, sir, his wife is a more respected person than any of us all.
trg: Varlet, thou liest; thou liest, wicked varlet! the time has yet to come that she was ever respected with man, woman, or child.

src: No man but prophesied revenge for it.
trg: Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.

src: An oath is of no moment, being not took Before a true and lawful magistrate, That hath authority over him that swears: Henry had none, but did usurp the place;
trg: Then, seeing 'twas he that made you to depose, Your oath, my lord, is vain and frivolous. Therefore, to arms! And, father, do but think How sweet a thing it is to wear a crown;

src: 'Tis more than you deserve; But since you teach me how to flatter you, Imagine I have said farewell already.
trg: Sirs, take up the corse.

src: Or thou goest to the orange or mill.
trg: If to either, thou dost ill.

src: How if it be false, son?
trg: If it be ne'er so false, a true gentleman may swear it in the behalf of his friend: and I'll swear to the prince thou art a tall fellow of thy hands and that thou wilt not be drunk;

src: If he be credulous and trust my tale, I'll make him glad to seem Vincentio, And give assurance to Baptista Minola, As if he were the right Vincentio Take in your love, and then let me alone.
trg: God save you, sir!

src: By heaven, my heart is purged from grudging hate: And with my hand I seal my true heart's love.
trg: So thrive I, as I truly swear the like!

src: Here's one to a very doleful tune, how a usurer's wife was brought to bed of twenty money-bags at a burthen and how she longed to eat adders' heads and toads carbonadoed.
trg: Is it true, think you?
Master, if ever I said loose-bodied gown, sew me in the skirts of it, and beat me to death with a bottom of brown thread: I said a gown.

src: I must believe you, sir: I do; and will fetch off Bohemia for't; Provided that, when he's removed, your highness Will take again your queen as yours at first, Even for your son's sake;
trg: and thereby for sealing The injury of tongues in courts and kingdoms Known and allied to yours.

src: My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.
trg: Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.

src: Stand all apart Cousin of Buckingham!
trg: My gracious sovereign?

src: Let her alone, lady: as she is now, she will but disease our better mirth.
trg: In troth, I think she would. Fare you well, then. Come, good sweet lady. Prithee, Virgilia, turn thy solemness out o' door. and go along with us.

src: which to reiterate were sin As deep as that, though true.
trg: Is whispering nothing? Is leaning cheek to cheek? is meeting noses? Kissing with inside lip? stopping the career Of laughing with a sigh?--a note infallible Of breaking honesty--horsing foot on foot?

src: It doth so, holy sir; and there's my master, One that you love.
trg: Who is it?

src: Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: but I will in, to be revenged for this villany.
trg: And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.

src: O, that's the case of the shepherd's son: hang him, he'll be made an example.
trg: Comfort, good comfort! We must to the king and show our strange sights: he must know 'tis none of your daughter nor my sister; we are gone else.

src: so we will home to Rome, And die among our neighbours. Nay, behold 's:
trg: This boy, that cannot tell what he would have But kneels and holds up bands for fellowship, Does reason our petition with more strength Than thou hast to deny 't. Come, let us go:

src: We must be brief when traitors brave the field.
trg: So, now prosperity begins to mellow And drop into the rotten mouth of death. Here in these confines slily have I lurk'd, To watch the waning of mine adversaries.

src: Why, master mayor, why stand you in a doubt? Open the gates; we are King Henry's friends.
trg: Ay, say you so? the gates shall then be open'd.

src: Come, knock and enter; and no sooner in, But every man betake him to his legs.
trg: A torch for me: let wantons light of heart Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels, For I am proverb'd with a grandsire phrase; I'll be a candle-holder, and look on.

src: For he fears none.
trg: Hortensio, hark: This gentleman is happily arrived, My mind presumes, for his own good and ours.

src: Lady, you know no rules of charity, Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.
trg: Villain, thou know'st no law of God nor man: No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.

src: I cannot joy, until I be resolved Where our right valiant father is become. I saw him in the battle range about; And watch'd him how he singled Clifford forth.
trg: Methought he bore him in the thickest troop As doth a lion in a herd of neat;

src: In such a one as, you consenting to't, Would bark your honour from that trunk you bear, And leave you naked.
trg: Let me know the point.

src: Or, if she be accused in true report, Bear with her weakness, which, I think proceeds From wayward sickness, and no grounded malice.
trg: Saw you the king to-day, my Lord of Derby?

src: So it must fall out To him or our authorities. For an end, We must suggest the people in what hatred He still hath held them;
