trg: This, as you say, suggested At some time when his soaring insolence Shall touch the people--which time shall not want, If he be put upon 't;

src: Their transformations Were never for a piece of beauty rarer, Nor in a way so chaste, since my desires Run not before mine honour, nor my lusts Burn hotter than my faith.
trg: O, but, sir, Your resolution cannot hold, when 'tis Opposed, as it must be, by the power of the king:

src: Prithee, peace.
trg: You were kneel'd to and importuned otherwise By all of us, and the fair soul herself Weigh'd between loathness and obedience, at Which end o' the beam should bow.

src: O villains, vipers, damn'd without redemption! Dogs, easily won to fawn on any man! Snakes, in my heart-blood warm'd, that sting my heart! Three Judases, each one thrice worse than Judas!
trg: Would they make peace? terrible hell make war Upon their spotted souls for this offence!

src: You, sirrah, provide your block and your axe to-morrow four o'clock.
trg: Come on, bawd; I will instruct thee in my trade; follow.

src: And will you pale your head in Henry's glory, And rob his temples of the diadem, Now in his life, against your holy oath? O, 'tis a fault too too unpardonable!
trg: Off with the crown, and with the crown his head; And, whilst we breathe, take time to do him dead.

src: Not of a woman's tenderness to be, Requires nor child nor woman's face to see. I have sat too long.
trg: Nay, go not from us thus. If it were so that our request did tend To save the Romans, thereby to destroy The Volsces whom you serve, you might condemn us, As poisonous of your honour: no;

src: Farewell.
trg: Farewell.

src: The king of heaven forbid our lord the king Should so with civil and uncivil arms Be rush'd upon! Thy thrice noble cousin Harry Bolingbroke doth humbly kiss thy hand;
trg: Which on thy royal party granted once, His glittering arms he will commend to rust, His barbed steeds to stables, and his heart To faithful service of your majesty.

src: whiles I Persuade this rude wretch willingly to die.
trg: This shall be done, good father, presently. But Barnardine must die this afternoon: And how shall we continue Claudio, To save me from the danger that might come If he were known alive?

src: We thank thee, gentle Percy, for thy pains; And to thy worth will add right worthy gains.
trg: My lord, I have from Oxford sent to London The heads of Brocas and Sir Bennet Seely, Two of the dangerous consorted traitors That sought at Oxford thy dire overthrow.

src: Within this mile and half.
trg: Then shall we hear their 'larum, and they ours. Now, Mars, I prithee, make us quick in work, That we with smoking swords may march from hence, To help our fielded friends! Come, blow thy blast.

src: As much unto my good lord chamberlain! Well are you welcome to the open air. How hath your lordship brook'd imprisonment?
trg: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must: But I shall live, my lord, to give them thanks That were the cause of my imprisonment.

src: And here I'll fling the pillow, there the bolster, This way the coverlet, another way the sheets: Ay, and amid this hurly I intend That all is done in reverend care of her;
trg: And in conclusion she shall watch all night: And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawl And with the clamour keep her still awake. This is a way to kill a wife with kindness;

src: I pray thee, chide not; she whom I love now Doth grace for grace and love for love allow; The other did not so.
trg: O, she knew well Thy love did read by rote and could not spell. But come, young waverer, come, go with me, In one respect I'll thy assistant be;

src: How chance the prophet could not at that time Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?
trg: My lord, your promise for the earldom,--

src: So said, so done, is well. Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?
trg: I know she is an irksome brawling scold: If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.

src: Cominius, no.
trg: Have I had children's voices?

src: The hope thereof makes Clifford mourn in steel.
trg: What, shall we suffer this? let's pluck him down: My heart for anger burns; I cannot brook it.

src: Biondello, what of that?
trg: Faith, nothing; but has left me here behind, to expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.

src: He that has the two fair daughters: is't he you mean?
trg: Even he, Biondello.

src: I will be angry: what hast thou to do? Father, be quiet; he shall stay my leisure.
trg: Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.

src: Happy be you! All that you speak shows fair.
trg: Who have we here? We'll make an instrument of this, omit Nothing may give us aid.
You bid me make it orderly and well, According to the fashion and the time.

src: Come, come, you have been too rough, something too rough; You must return and mend it.
trg: There's no remedy; Unless, by not so doing, our good city Cleave in the midst, and perish.

src: Break up the seals and read.
and what I saw, to my good use I remembered.
trg: My clown, who wants but something to be a reasonable man, grew so in love with the wenches' song, that he would not stir his pettitoes till he had both tune and words;

src: It was the lark, the herald of the morn, No nightingale: look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east:
trg: Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops. I must be gone and live, or stay and die.

src: Welcome, then.
trg: O holy friar, O, tell me, holy friar, Where is my lady's lord, where's Romeo?

src: Old John of Gaunt is grievous sick, my lord, Suddenly taken; and hath sent post haste To entreat your majesty to visit him.
trg: Where lies he?

src: Mistress, we have.
trg: Then we are rid of Licio.

src: Upon my life, my lord, I'll under-take it; And so, God give you quiet rest to-night!
trg: Good night, good Captain Blunt. Come gentlemen, Let us consult upon to-morrow's business In to our tent; the air is raw and cold.

src: Then, window, let day in, and let life out.
trg: Farewell, farewell! one kiss, and I'll descend.

src: My liege, it is young Henry, earl of Richmond.
trg: Come hither, England's hope. If secret powers Suggest but truth to my divining thoughts, This pretty lad will prove our country's bliss.

src: There's no trust, No faith, no honesty in men; all perjured, All forsworn, all naught, all dissemblers. Ah, where's my man? give me some aqua vitae:
trg: These griefs, these woes, these sorrows make me old. Shame come to Romeo!

src: O, pardon me, my lord; it oft falls out, To have what we would have, we speak not what we mean: I something do excuse the thing I hate, For his advantage that I dearly love.
trg: We are all frail.

src: I am the sister of one Claudio, Condemn'd upon the act of fornication To lose his head; condemn'd by Angelo: I, in probation of a sisterhood, Was sent to by my brother;
trg: one Lucio As then the messenger,--

src: Many good morrows to my noble lord!
trg: Good morrow, Catesby; you are early stirring What news, what news, in this our tottering state?

src: You are at point to lose your liberties: Marcius would have all from you; Marcius, Whom late you have named for consul.
trg: Fie, fie, fie! This is the way to kindle, not to quench.

src: My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince, For God's sake, let not us two be behind;
trg: For, by the way, I'll sort occasion, As index to the story we late talk'd of, To part the queen's proud kindred from the king.

src: Come, my old son: I pray God make thee new.
trg: Didst thou not mark the king, what words he spake, 'Have I no friend will rid me of this living fear?' Was it not so?

src: Here comes the Duke of York.
trg: With signs of war about his aged neck: O, full of careful business are his looks! Uncle, for God's sake, speak comfortable words.

src: O the heavens! What foul play had we, that we came from thence? Or blessed was't we did?
trg: Both, both, my girl: By foul play, as thou say'st, were we heaved thence, But blessedly holp hither.

src: My gracious lady, go; And thither bear your treasure and your goods. For my part, I'll resign unto your grace The seal I keep: and so betide to me As well I tender you and all of yours!
trg: Come, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.

src: Yet know, my master, God omnipotent, Is mustering in his clouds on our behalf Armies of pestilence;
trg: and they shall strike Your children yet unborn and unbegot, That lift your vassal hands against my head And threat the glory of my precious crown.
Nay, let them follow: The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thither To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutiners, Your valour puts well forth: pray, follow.

src: Some light-foot friend post to the Duke of Norfolk: Ratcliff, thyself, or Catesby; where is he?
trg: Here, my lord.

src: Benefactors? Well; what benefactors are they? are they not malefactors?
trg: If it? please your honour, I know not well what they are: but precise villains they are, that I am sure of; and void of all profanation in the world that good Christians ought to have.

src: Who shall ask it? The tribunes cannot do't for shame; the people Deserve such pity of him as the wolf Does of the shepherds:
trg: for his best friends, if they Should say 'Be good to Rome,' they charged him even As those should do that had deserved his hate, And therein show'd like enemies.

src: The weary sun hath made a golden set, And by the bright track of his fiery car, Gives signal, of a goodly day to-morrow. Sir William Brandon, you shall bear my standard.
trg: Give me some ink and paper in my tent I'll draw the form and model of our battle, Limit each leader to his several charge, And part in just proportion our small strength.

src: Thus to have said, As you were fore-advised, had touch'd his spirit And tried his inclination; so putting him to rage, You should have ta'en the advantage of his choler And pass'd him unelected.
trg: Did you perceive He did solicit you in free contempt When he did need your loves, and do you think That his contempt shall not be bruising to you, When he hath power to crush?

src: and thereby for sealing The injury of tongues in courts and kingdoms Known and allied to yours.
trg: Thou dost advise me Even so as I mine own course have set down: I'll give no blemish to her honour, none.

src: O, pardon me, Signior Gremio; I would fain be doing.
trg: I doubt it not, sir; but you will curse your wooing. Neighbour, this is a gift very grateful, I am sure of it.

src: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.
trg: Farewell, thou woful welcomer of glory!

src: Call hither Barnardine and Claudio: The one has my pity; not a jot the other, Being a murderer, though he were my brother. Look, here's the warrant, Claudio, for thy death:
trg: 'Tis now dead midnight, and by eight to-morrow Thou must be made immortal. Where's Barnardine?

src: Pray now, your news? You have made fair work, I fear me.--Pray, your news?-- If Marcius should be join'd with Volscians,--
trg: If! He is their god: he leads them like a thing Made by some other deity than nature, That shapes man better;

src: and I thank thee, king, For thy great bounty, that not only givest Me cause to wail but teachest me the way How to lament the cause. I'll beg one boon, And then be gone and trouble you no more.
trg: Shall I obtain it?

src: Sweet sister, let me live: What sin you do to save a brother's life, Nature dispenses with the deed so far That it becomes a virtue.
trg: O you beast! O faithless coward! O dishonest wretch! Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice? Is't not a kind of incest, to take life From thine own sister's shame? What should I think?

src: What stay had I but Edward? and he's gone.
trg: What stay had we but Clarence? and he's gone.

src: I may not, verily.
trg: Verily! You put me off with limber vows; but I, Though you would seek to unsphere the stars with oaths, Should yet say 'Sir, no going.' Verily, You shall not go:

src: Woe, woe for England! not a whit for me; For I, too fond, might have prevented this. Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm; But I disdain'd it, and did scorn to fly:
trg: Three times to-day my foot-cloth horse did stumble, And startled, when he look'd upon the Tower, As loath to bear me to the slaughter-house. O, now I want the priest that spake to me:

src: Thou fond mad woman, Wilt thou conceal this dark conspiracy? A dozen of them here have ta'en the sacrament, And interchangeably set down their hands, To kill the king at Oxford.
trg: He shall be none; We'll keep him here: then what is that to him?

src: Lend thine ear.
trg: Here.

src: Sir, praise me not; My work hath yet not warm'd me: fare you well: The blood I drop is rather physical Than dangerous to me: to Aufidius thus I will appear, and fight.
trg: Now the fair goddess, Fortune, Fall deep in love with thee; and her great charms Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman, Prosperity be thy page!

src: No, in good earnest. How sometimes nature will betray its folly, Its tenderness, and make itself a pastime To harder bosoms!
trg: How like, methought, I then was to this kernel, This squash, this gentleman. Mine honest friend, Will you take eggs for money?

src: We have lost your son, I fear, for ever: Milan and Naples have More widows in them of this business' making Than we bring men to comfort them: The fault's your own.
trg: So is the dear'st o' the loss.

src: Naught to do with mistress Shore! I tell thee, fellow, He that doth naught with her, excepting one, Were best he do it secretly, alone.
trg: What one, my lord?

src: I'll give thee scope to beat, Since foes have scope to beat both thee and me.
trg: Northumberland comes back from Bolingbroke.

src: Give me the letter; I will look on it. Where is the county's page, that raised the watch? Sirrah, what made your master in this place?
trg: He came with flowers to strew his lady's grave; And bid me stand aloof, and so I did: Anon comes one with light to ope the tomb; And by and by my master drew on him;

src: I must Forsake the court: to do't, or no, is certain To me a break-neck. Happy star, reign now! Here comes Bohemia.
trg: This is strange: methinks My favour here begins to warp. Not speak? Good day, Camillo.

src: Northumberland comes back from Bolingbroke.
trg: What must the king do now? must he submit? The king shall do it: must he be deposed? The king shall be contented: must he lose The name of king? o' God's name, let it go:

src: Your bed-chamber.
trg: I'll rest betide the chamber where thou liest!

src: And when they bear me say 'It shall be so I' the right and strength o' the commons,' be it either For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them If I say fine, cry 'Fine;' if death, cry 'Death.
trg: ' Insisting on the old prerogative And power i' the truth o' the cause.

src: I would your highness would depart the field: The queen hath best success when you are absent.
trg: Ay, good my lord, and leave us to our fortune.

src: No cause! Thy father slew my father; therefore, die.
trg: Di faciant laudis summa sit ista tuae!

src: Then both, or one, or any thing thou wilt.
trg: Why then, the mustard without the beef.

src: By the vow of mine order I warrant you, if my instructions may be your guide. Let this Barnardine be this morning executed, and his head born to Angelo.
trg: Angelo hath seen them both, and will discover the favour.

src: Was not my lord The verier wag o' the two?
trg: We were as twinn'd lambs that did frisk i' the sun, And bleat the one at the other: what we changed Was innocence for innocence; we knew not The doctrine of ill-doing, nor dream'd That any did.

src: Sir, sir, the first's for me; let her go by.
trg: Yea, leave that labour to great Hercules; And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.

src: Even when you please, since you will have it so.
trg: To-morrow, then, we will attend your grace: And so most joyfully we take our leave.

src: I do beseech you, Let me o'erleap that custom, for I cannot Put on the gown, stand naked and entreat them, For my wounds' sake, to give their suffrage: please you That I may pass this doing.
trg: Sir, the people Must have their voices; neither will they bate One jot of ceremony.

src: Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?
trg: They sit conferring by the parlor fire.

src: It is my son, young Harry Percy, Sent from my brother Worcester, whencesoever. Harry, how fares your uncle?
trg: I had thought, my lord, to have learn'd his health of you.

src: O this woodcock, what an ass it is!
trg: Peace, sirrah!

src: O, was she so? I must Once in a month recount what thou hast been, Which thou forget'st.
trg: This damn'd witch Sycorax, For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible To enter human hearing, from Argier, Thou know'st, was banish'd: for one thing she did They would not take her life.

src: It is your former promise.
trg: Sir, it is; And I am constant. Titus Lartius, thou Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus' face. What, art thou stiff? stand'st out?

src: Not in my house, Lucentio; for, you know, Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants: Besides, old Gremio is hearkening still; And happily we might be interrupted.
trg: Then at my lodging, an it like you: There doth my father lie; and there, this night, We'll pass the business privately and well. Send for your daughter by your servant here:

src: Henry the Fourth by conquest got the crown.
trg: 'Twas by rebellion against his king.

src: Yes, Warwick, Edward dares, and leads the way. Lords, to the field; Saint George and victory! 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: So, lie thou there: die thou, and die our fear; For Warwick was a bug that fear'd us all. Now, Montague, sit fast; I seek for thee, That Warwick's bones may keep thine company.

src: She's not fourteen.
trg: I'll lay fourteen of my teeth,-- And yet, to my teeth be it spoken, I have but four-- She is not fourteen. How long is it now To Lammas-tide?

src: till at length Your ignorance, which finds not till it feels, Making not reservation of yourselves, Still your own foes, deliver you as most Abated captives to some nation That won you without blows!
trg: Despising, For you, the city, thus I turn my back: There is a world elsewhere.

src: Lovel and Ratcliff, look that it be done: The rest, that love me, rise and follow me.
trg: Woe, woe for England! not a whit for me; For I, too fond, might have prevented this. Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm; But I disdain'd it, and did scorn to fly:

src: Most manifest, and not denied by himself.
trg: Hath he born himself penitently in prison? how seems he to be touched?

src: Yet, for I loved thee, Take this along; I writ it for thy sake And would have rent it. Another word, Menenius, I will not hear thee speak. This man, Aufidius, Was my beloved in Rome:
trg: yet thou behold'st!

src: My noble masters, hear me speak.
trg: O Tullus,--

src: To murder me?
trg: Ay, ay.

src: What else?
trg: Bum, sir.

src: It shall be so, it shall be so.
trg: You common cry of curs! whose breath I hate As reek o' the rotten fens, whose loves I prize As the dead carcasses of unburied men That do corrupt my air, I banish you;

src: I'll claim that promise at your grace's hands.
trg: And look to have it yielded with all willingness. Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards We may digest our complots in some form.

src: Give me my boots, I say; saddle my horse. Now, by mine honour, by my life, by my troth, I will appeach the villain.
trg: What is the matter?

src: Come, is the bride ready to go to church?
trg: Ready to go, but never to return. O son! the night before thy wedding-day Hath Death lain with thy wife. There she lies, Flower as she was, deflowered by him. Death is my son-in-law, Death is my heir;

src: That's my good son: but where hast thou been, then?
trg: I'll tell thee, ere thou ask it me again. I have been feasting with mine enemy, Where on a sudden one hath wounded me, That's by me wounded: both our remedies Within thy help and holy physic lies:

src: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs; or I'll cry a match.
trg: Nay, if thy wits run the wild-goose chase, I have done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five: was I with you there for the goose?

src: say't and justify't.
trg: I would not be a stander-by to hear My sovereign mistress clouded so, without My present vengeance taken: 'shrew my heart, You never spoke what did become you less Than this;

src: And were I strong, I would not shun their fury: The sands are number'd that make up my life; Here must I stay, and here my life must end.
trg: Come, bloody Clifford, rough Northumberland, I dare your quenchless fury to more rage: I am your butt, and I abide your shot.

src: No, misery makes sport to mock itself: Since thou dost seek to kill my name in me, I mock my name, great king, to flatter thee.
trg: Should dying men flatter with those that live?

src: The generous and gravest citizens Have hent the gates, and very near upon The duke is entering: therefore, hence, away!
trg: My very worthy cousin, fairly met! Our old and faithful friend, we are glad to see you.

src: And now in plainness do confess to thee, That art to me as secret and as dear As Anna to the queen of Carthage was, Tranio, I burn, I pine, I perish, Tranio, If I achieve not this young modest girl.
trg: Counsel me, Tranio, for I know thou canst; Assist me, Tranio, for I know thou wilt.

src: I doubt not but his friends will fly to us.
trg: He hath no friends but who are friends for fear. Which in his greatest need will shrink from him.

src: They have not been commanded, mighty sovereign: Please it your majesty to give me leave, I'll muster up my friends, and meet your grace Where and what time your majesty shall please.
trg: Ay, ay. thou wouldst be gone to join with Richmond: I will not trust you, sir.

src: Where have I been! Nay, how now! where are you? Master, has my fellow Tranio stolen your clothes? Or you stolen his? or both? pray, what's the news?
trg: Sirrah, come hither: 'tis no time to jest, And therefore frame your manners to the time.

src: That shall you know hereafter.
trg: But shall I live in hope?

src: Every true man's apparel fits your thief: if it be too little for your thief, your true man thinks it big enough; if it be too big for your thief, your thief thinks it little enough:
trg: so every true man's apparel fits your thief.

src: This gentleman, the prince's near ally, My very friend, hath got his mortal hurt In my behalf; my reputation stain'd With Tybalt's slander,--Tybalt, that an hour Hath been my kinsman!
trg: O sweet Juliet, Thy beauty hath made me effeminate And in my temper soften'd valour's steel!

src: Such comfort as do lusty young men feel When well-apparell'd April on the heel Of limping winter treads, even such delight Among fresh female buds shall you this night Inherit at my house;
trg: hear all, all see, And like her most whose merit most shall be: Which on more view, of many mine being one May stand in number, though in reckoning none, Come, go with me.

src: I am content: Richard Plantagenet, Enjoy the kingdom after my decease.
trg: What wrong is this unto the prince your son!

src: Urge neither charity nor shame to me: Uncharitably with me have you dealt, And shamefully by you my hopes are butcher'd.
trg: My charity is outrage, life my shame And in that shame still live my sorrow's rage.

src: Look to the drawbridge there!
trg: Hark! a drum.

src: Ah, well-a-day! he's dead, he's dead, he's dead! We are undone, lady, we are undone! Alack the day! he's gone, he's kill'd, he's dead!
trg: Can heaven be so envious?

src: What fates impose, that men must needs abide; It boots not to resist both wind and tide.
trg: What now remains, my lords, for us to do But march to London with our soldiers?

src: We shall write to you, As time and our concernings shall importune, How it goes with us, and do look to know What doth befall you here. So, fare you well;
trg: To the hopeful execution do I leave you Of your commissions.

src: 'Tis well; and I have met a gentleman Hath promised me to help me to another, A fine musician to instruct our mistress; So shall I no whit be behind in duty To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.
trg: Beloved of me; and that my deeds shall prove.

src: Nay, 'tis no matter, sir, what he 'leges in Latin. if this be not a lawful case for me to leave his service, look you, sir, he bid me knock him and rap him soundly, sir:
trg: well, was it fit for a servant to use his master so, being perhaps, for aught I see, two and thirty, a pip out? Whom would to God I had well knock'd at first, Then had not Grumio come by the worst.

src: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.
trg: Where is he?

src: a brave vessel, Who had, no doubt, some noble creature in her, Dash'd all to pieces. O, the cry did knock Against my very heart. Poor souls, they perish'd.
trg: Had I been any god of power, I would Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere It should the good ship so have swallow'd and The fraughting souls within her.

src: the king's son, Ferdinand, With hair up-staring,--then like reeds, not hair,-- Was the first man that leap'd; cried, 'Hell is empty And all the devils are here.'
trg: Why that's my spirit! But was not this nigh shore?

src: The Emperor of Russia was my father: O that he were alive, and here beholding His daughter's trial! that he did but see The flatness of my misery, yet with eyes Of pity, not revenge!
trg: and that, since then, You have not dared to break the holy seal Nor read the secrets in't.

src: Your uncle York is join'd with Bolingbroke, And all your northern castles yielded up, And all your southern gentlemen in arms Upon his party.
trg: Thou hast said enough. Beshrew thee, cousin, which didst lead me forth Of that sweet way I was in to despair! What say you now? what comfort have we now?

src: And so, good Capulet,--which name I tender As dearly as my own,--be satisfied.
trg: O calm, dishonourable, vile submission! Alla stoccata carries it away. Tybalt, you rat-catcher, will you walk?

src: Then thus: Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay The first departing of the king for Ireland. But if you faint, as fearing to do so, Stay and be secret, and myself will go.
trg: To horse, to horse! urge doubts to them that fear.

src: when he walks, he moves like an engine, and the ground shrinks before his treading: he is able to pierce a corslet with his eye; talks like a knell, and his hum is a battery.
trg: He sits in his state, as a thing made for Alexander. What he bids be done is finished with his bidding. He wants nothing of a god but eternity and a heaven to throne in.

src: With die and drab I purchased this caparison, and my revenue is the silly cheat. Gallows and knock are too powerful on the highway: beating and hanging are terrors to me:
trg: for the life to come, I sleep out the thought of it. A prize! a prize!

src: now I trust I shall. My women, come; you have leave.
trg: Go, do our bidding; hence!

src: For my part, I'll not trouble thee with words.
trg: Nor I, but stoop with patience to my fortune.

src: Thomas the Earl of Surrey, and himself, Much about cock-shut time, from troop to troop Went through the army, cheering up the soldiers.
trg: So, I am satisfied. Give me a bowl of wine: I have not that alacrity of spirit, Nor cheer of mind, that I was wont to have. Set it down. Is ink and paper ready?

src: 'Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I have fought with the men, I will be cruel with the maids, and cut off their heads.
trg: The heads of the maids?

src: These eyes could never endure sweet beauty's wreck; You should not blemish it, if I stood by: As all the world is cheered by the sun, So I by that; it is my day, my life.
trg: Black night o'ershade thy day, and death thy life!

src: Nay, I have offer'd all, I have no more; And she can have no more than all I have: If you like me, she shall have me and mine.
trg: Why, then the maid is mine from all the world, By your firm promise: Gremio is out-vied.

src: Ay, an it like your good worship.
trg: Give me thy hand: I will swear to the prince thou art as honest a true fellow as any is in Bohemia.

src: Upon what cause?
trg: Because my name is George.

src: I would I were thy bird.
trg: Sweet, so would I: Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing. Good night, good night! parting is such sweet sorrow, That I shall say good night till it be morrow.

src: If it be ne'er so false, a true gentleman may swear it in the behalf of his friend: and I'll swear to the prince thou art a tall fellow of thy hands and that thou wilt not be drunk;
trg: but I know thou art no tall fellow of thy hands and that thou wilt be drunk: but I'll swear it, and I would thou wouldst be a tall fellow of thy hands.

src: O upright, just, and true-disposing God, How do I thank thee, that this carnal cur Preys on the issue of his mother's body, And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!
trg: O Harry's wife, triumph not in my woes! God witness with me, I have wept for thine.

src: Menenius, you are known well enough too.
trg: I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying Tiber in't; said to be something imperfect in favouring the first complaint;

src: There rest. Your partner, as I hear, must die to-morrow, And I am going with instruction to him. Grace go with you, Benedicite!
trg: Must die to-morrow! O injurious love, That respites me a life, whose very comfort Is still a dying horror!

src: marry, then ginger was not much in request, for the old women were all dead.
trg: Then is there here one Master Caper, at the suit of Master Three-pile the mercer, for some four suits of peach-coloured satin, which now peaches him a beggar.

src: Well, sir.
trg: Say 'better:' here comes one of my master's kinsmen.

src: What is he, Biondello?
trg: Master, a mercatante, or a pedant, I know not what; but format in apparel, In gait and countenance surely like a father.

src: Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.
trg: O ill-dispersing wind of misery! O my accursed womb, the bed of death! A cockatrice hast thou hatch'd to the world, Whose unavoided eye is murderous.

src: In love?
trg: Out--

src: No more of him; he is a worthy man: make way, they are coming.
trg: Having determined of the Volsces and To send for Titus Lartius, it remains, As the main point of this our after-meeting, To gratify his noble service that Hath thus stood for his country:

src: Not hold thee of our blood, no, not our kin, Far than Deucalion off: mark thou my words: Follow us to the court.
trg: Thou churl, for this time, Though full of our displeasure, yet we free thee From the dead blow of it. And you, enchantment.-- Worthy enough a herdsman:

src: Alas, that Warwick had no more forecast, But, whiles he thought to steal the single ten, The king was slily finger'd from the deck!
trg: You left poor Henry at the Bishop's palace, And, ten to one, you'll meet him in the Tower.
'Tis better said than done, my gracious lord: I am a subject fit to jest withal, But far unfit to be a sovereign.

src: The first that there did greet my stranger soul, Was my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick; Who cried aloud, 'What scourge for perjury Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?
trg: ' And so he vanish'd: then came wandering by A shadow like an angel, with bright hair Dabbled in blood; and he squeak'd out aloud, 'Clarence is come;

src: Bad news, my lord: Ely is fled to Richmond; And Buckingham, back'd with the hardy Welshmen, Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.
trg: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near Than Buckingham and his rash-levied army. Come, I have heard that fearful commenting Is leaden servitor to dull delay;

src: Hold, take these keys, and fetch more spices, nurse.
trg: They call for dates and quinces in the pastry.

src: Will he woo her? ay, or I'll hang her.
trg: Why came I hither but to that intent? Think you a little din can daunt mine ears? Have I not in my time heard lions roar?

src: Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met, Upon agreement from us to his liking, Will undertake to woo curst Katharina, Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.
trg: So said, so done, is well. Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?
Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak; And speak I will; I am no child, no babe: Your betters have endured me say my mind, And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.

src: No, my lord, I'll fight.
trg: You will! why, happy man be's dole! My brother, Are you so fond of your young prince as we Do seem to be of ours?

src: Shall I bring thee on the way?
trg: No, good-faced sir; no, sweet sir.

src: Certainly, sir, I can.
trg: By what? by any other house or person? Of any thing the image tell me that Hath kept with thy remembrance.

src: Quarrel sir! no, sir.
trg: If you do, sir, I am for you: I serve as good a man as you.

src: Ay, my good lord; a very virtuous maid, And to be shortly of a sisterhood, If not already.
trg: Well, let her be admitted. See you the fornicatress be removed: Let have needful, but not lavish, means; There shall be order for't.

src: They seek revenge and therefore will not yield.
trg: Ah, Exeter!

src: Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.
trg: No, no; by God's good grace his son shall reign.

src: Come: Half all Cominius' honours are to Marcius. Though Marcius earned them not, and all his faults To Marcius shall be honours, though indeed In aught he merit not.
trg: Let's hence, and hear How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion, More than his singularity, he goes Upon this present action.

src: We cannot, sir, we are undone already.
trg: I tell you, friends, most charitable care Have the patricians of you. For the dearth, The gods, not the patricians, make it, and Your knees to them, not arms, must help.

src: Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub, Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers.
trg: And in this state she gallops night by night Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love; Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier's nose, And then dreams he of smelling out a suit;

src: Good faith, I'll prove him, Speed how it will. I shall ere long have knowledge Of my success.
trg: He'll never hear him.

src: 'Widow Dido' said you? you make me study of that: she was of Carthage, not of Tunis.
trg: This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.

src: An you be mine, I'll give you to my friend; And you be not, hang, beg, starve, die in the streets, For, by my soul, I'll ne'er acknowledge thee, Nor what is mine shall never do thee good:
trg: Trust to't, bethink you; I'll not be forsworn.

src: And take his thanks that yet hath nothing else.
trg: Prepare you, lords, for Edward is at hand. Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.

src: I have a brother is condemn'd to die: I do beseech you, let it be his fault, And not my brother.
Give way there, and go on!

Go do it instantly. And you, my noble and well-warranted cousin, Whom it concerns to hear this matter forth, Do with your injuries as seems you best, In any chastisement: I for a while will leave you;
trg: But stir not you till you have well determined Upon these slanderers.

src: You common cry of curs! whose breath I hate As reek o' the rotten fens, whose loves I prize As the dead carcasses of unburied men That do corrupt my air, I banish you;
trg: And here remain with your uncertainty! Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts! Your enemies, with nodding of their plumes, Fan you into despair! Have the power still To banish your defenders;

src: But wilt thou make a fire, or shall I complain on thee to our mistress, whose hand, she being now at hand, thou shalt soon feel, to thy cold comfort, for being slow in thy hot office?
trg: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?

src: He said the truth: and what said Surrey then?
trg: He smiled and said 'The better for our purpose.'

src: The more we stay, the stronger grows our foe.
trg: The more I stay, the more I'll succor thee.

src: Ay, like a dastard and a treacherous coward, As thou didst kill our tender brother Rutland; But ere sunset I'll make thee curse the deed.
trg: Have done with words, my lords, and hear me speak.

src: and their stol'n marriage-day Was Tybalt's dooms-day, whose untimely death Banish'd the new-made bridegroom from the city, For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pined.
trg: You, to remove that siege of grief from her, Betroth'd and would have married her perforce To County Paris:

src: This gentleman told somewhat of my tale,--
trg: Right.

src: Is't possible, friend Licio, that Mistress Bianca Doth fancy any other but Lucentio? I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.
trg: Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said, Stand by and mark the manner of his teaching.

src: That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes to the wall.
trg: True; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels, are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push Montague's men from the wall, and thrust his maids to the wall.

src: O, but they say the tongues of dying men Enforce attention like deep harmony: Where words are scarce, they are seldom spent in vain, For they breathe truth that breathe their words in pain.
trg: He that no more must say is listen'd more Than they whom youth and ease have taught to glose; More are men's ends mark'd than their lives before:

src: He's to make his requests by particulars; wherein every one of us has a single honour, in giving him our own voices with our own tongues:
trg: therefore follow me, and I direct you how you shall go by him.

src: You know the very road into his kindness, And cannot lose your way.
trg: Good faith, I'll prove him, Speed how it will. I shall ere long have knowledge Of my success.

src: Why, As all comforts are; most good, most good indeed. Lord Angelo, having affairs to heaven, Intends you for his swift ambassador, Where you shall be an everlasting leiger:
trg: Therefore your best appointment make with speed; To-morrow you set on.

src: O, whither?
trg: Whither?

src: Who's that, I pray thee?
trg: Marry, sir, that's Claudio, Signior Claudio.

src: Of all thy suitors, here I charge thee, tell Whom thou lovest best: see thou dissemble not.
trg: Believe me, sister, of all the men alive I never yet beheld that special face Which I could fancy more than any other.

src: seize it, if thou darest.
trg: An if I do not, may my hands rot off And never brandish more revengeful steel Over the glittering helmet of my foe!

src: Be ready, Claudio, for your death tomorrow.
trg: Yes. Has he affections in him, That thus can make him bite the law by the nose, When he would force it? Sure, it is no sin, Or of the deadly seven, it is the least.

src: Say on, my loving lord.
trg: Why, Buckingham, I say, I would be king,

src: He's hearing of a cause; he will come straight I'll tell him of you.
trg: Pray you, do. I'll know His pleasure; may be he will relent. Alas, He hath but as offended in a dream! All sects, all ages smack of this vice; and he To die for't!

src: Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you: so you may continue and laugh at nothing still.
trg: What a blow was there given!

src: Ay, but thou talk'st as if thou wert a king.
trg: Why, so I am, in mind; and that's enough.

src: The present wars devour him: he is grown Too proud to be so valiant.
trg: Such a nature, Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow Which he treads on at noon: but I do wonder His insolence can brook to be commanded Under Cominius.

src: What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?
trg: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?

src: How well resembles it the prime of youth, Trimm'd like a younker prancing to his love!
trg: Dazzle mine eyes, or do I see three suns?

src: Thou didst love York, and I am son to York.
trg: Thou pitied'st Rutland; I will pity thee.

src: Hold, daughter: I do spy a kind of hope, Which craves as desperate an execution. As that is desperate which we would prevent. And, if thou darest, I'll give thee remedy.
trg: O, bid me leap, rather than marry Paris, From off the battlements of yonder tower; Or walk in thievish ways; or bid me lurk Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears;

src: I talk of you: Why did you wish me milder? would you have me False to my nature? Rather say I play The man I am.
trg: O, sir, sir, sir, I would have had you put your power well on, Before you had worn it out.

src: A man, young lady! lady, such a man As all the world--why, he's a man of wax.
trg: Verona's summer hath not such a flower.

src: Why should she live, to fill the world with words?
trg: What, doth she swoon? use means for her recovery.

src: Thus do I hope to shake King Henry's head.
trg: And so do I. Victorious Prince of York, Before I see thee seated in that throne Which now the house of Lancaster usurps, I vow by heaven these eyes shall never close.

src: Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.
trg: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner: I see a woman may be made a fool, If she had not a spirit to resist.
Sir, this is the house: please it you that I call?

src: How fares our noble uncle, Lancaster?
trg: What comfort, man? how is't with aged Gaunt?

src: But I have cause to pry into this pedant: Methinks he looks as though he were in love: Yet if thy thoughts, Bianca, be so humble To cast thy wandering eyes on every stale, Seize thee that list:
trg: if once I find thee ranging, Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing.

src: We are not safe, Clarence; we are not safe.
trg: By heaven, I think there's no man is secure But the queen's kindred and night-walking heralds That trudge betwixt the king and Mistress Shore.

src: The bird that hath been limed in a bush, With trembling wings misdoubteth every bush;
trg: And I, the hapless male to one sweet bird, Have now the fatal object in my eye Where my poor young was limed, was caught and kill'd.

src: What is the business?
trg: O sir, I shall be hated to report it! The prince your son, with mere conceit and fear Of the queen's speed, is gone.

src: That 'once' I see by your good father's speed Will come on very slowly.
trg: I am sorry, Most sorry, you have broken from his liking Where you were tied in duty, and as sorry Your choice is not so rich in worth as beauty, That you might well enjoy her.

src: My father hath a power; inquire of him And learn to make a body of a limb.
trg: Thou chidest me well: proud Bolingbroke, I come To change blows with thee for our day of doom. This ague fit of fear is over-blown; An easy task it is to win our own.

src: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?
trg: O, ay, Curtis, ay: and therefore fire, fire; cast on no water.

src: they are not China dishes, but very good dishes,--
trg: Go to, go to: no matter for the dish, sir.

src: Now, my Lord Hastings and Sir William Stanley, Leave off to wonder why I drew you hither, Into this chiefest thicket of the park. Thus stands the case:
trg: you know our king, my brother, Is prisoner to the bishop here, at whose hands He hath good usage and great liberty, And, often but attended with weak guard, Comes hunting this way to disport himself.

src: So shall you bind me to your highness' service.
trg: What service wilt thou do me, if I give them?

src: Be of good cheer: mother, how fares your grace?
trg: O Dorset, speak not to me, get thee hence! Death and destruction dog thee at the heels; Thy mother's name is ominous to children.

src: When daffodils begin to peer, With heigh! the doxy over the dale, Why, then comes in the sweet o' the year; For the red blood reigns in the winter's pale.
trg: The white sheet bleaching on the hedge, With heigh! the sweet birds, O, how they sing! Doth set my pugging tooth on edge; For a quart of ale is a dish for a king.

src: O my dear lord, I crave no other, nor no better man.
trg: Never crave him; we are definitive.

src: Nor that is not the lark, whose notes do beat The vaulty heaven so high above our heads: I have more care to stay than will to go: Come, death, and welcome! Juliet wills it so. How is't, my soul?
trg: let's talk; it is not day.

src: Bootless is flight, they follow us with wings; And weak we are and cannot shun pursuit.
trg: Ah, Warwick, why hast thou withdrawn thyself? Thy brother's blood the thirsty earth hath drunk, Broach'd with the steely point of Clifford's lance;

src: Gentle and fair, your brother kindly greets you: Not to be weary with you, he's in prison.
trg: Woe me! for what?

src: whither away?
trg: Marry, we were sent for to the justices.

src: redeem thy brother By yielding up thy body to my will; Or else he must not only die the death, But thy unkindness shall his death draw out To lingering sufferance.
trg: Answer me to-morrow, Or, by the affection that now guides me most, I'll prove a tyrant to him. As for you, Say what you can, my false o'erweighs your true.

src: Cannot a plain man live and think no harm, But thus his simple truth must be abused By silken, sly, insinuating Jacks?
trg: To whom in all this presence speaks your grace?

src: Go to the feast, revel and domineer, Carouse full measure to her maidenhead, Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves: But for my bonny Kate, she must with me.
trg: Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret; I will be master of what is mine own: She is my goods, my chattels;

src: To supper; to our house.
trg: Whose house?

src: So shalt thou show me friendship. Take thou that: Live, and be prosperous: and farewell, good fellow.
Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!
trg: All comfort that the dark night can afford Be to thy person, noble father-in-law! Tell me, how fares our loving mother?

src: Small showers last long, but sudden storms are short; He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes; With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder:
trg: Light vanity, insatiate cormorant, Consuming means, soon preys upon itself.

src: But Montague is bound as well as I, In penalty alike; and 'tis not hard, I think, For men so old as we to keep the peace.
trg: Of honourable reckoning are you both; And pity 'tis you lived at odds so long. But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?

src: What fit is this, good lady?
trg: What studied torments, tyrant, hast for me? What wheels? racks? fires? what flaying? boiling? In leads or oils?

src: I will be brief, for my short date of breath Is not so long as is a tedious tale. Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet; And she, there dead, that Romeo's faithful wife: I married them;
trg: and their stol'n marriage-day Was Tybalt's dooms-day, whose untimely death Banish'd the new-made bridegroom from the city, For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pined.

src: That 'only' came well in. Sir, list to me: I am my father's heir and only son:
trg: If I may have your daughter to my wife, I'll leave her houses three or four as good, Within rich Pisa walls, as any one Old Signior Gremio has in Padua;

src: Ay, and for much more slaughter after this. God forgive my sins, and pardon thee!
trg: What, will the aspiring blood of Lancaster Sink in the ground? I thought it would have mounted. See how my sword weeps for the poor king's death!

src: Sirrah, be gone, or talk not, I advise you.
trg: Petruchio, patience; I am Grumio's pledge: Why, this's a heavy chance 'twixt him and you, Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.

src: Yet had not we determined he should die, Until your lordship came to see his death; Which now the loving haste of these our friends, Somewhat against our meaning, have prevented:
trg: Because, my lord, we would have had you heard The traitor speak, and timorously confess The manner and the purpose of his treason;

src: Why either were you ignorant to see't, Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness To yield your voices?
trg: and now, arriving A place of potency and sway o' the state, If he should still malignantly remain Fast foe to the plebeii, your voices might Be curses to yourselves?

src: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast! Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest! Hence will I to my ghostly father's cell, His help to crave, and my dear hap to tell.
trg: The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night, Chequering the eastern clouds with streaks of light, And flecked darkness like a drunkard reels From forth day's path and Titan's fiery wheels:

src: Nine, sir; Overdone by the last.
trg: Nine! Come hither to me, Master Froth. Master Froth, I would not have you acquainted with tapsters: they will draw you, Master Froth, and you will hang them.

src: God keep me from false friends! but they were none.
trg: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.

src: I learnt it out of women's faces. Pray now What colour are your eyebrows?
trg: Blue, my lord.

src: You, that are thus so tender o'er his follies, Will never do him good, not one of you. So, so: farewell; we are gone.
trg: Thou, traitor, hast set on thy wife to this. My child? away with't! Even thou, that hast A heart so tender o'er it, take it hence And see it instantly consumed with fire; Even thou and none but thou.

src: That is my office, for my father's sake.
trg: Nay, stay; lets hear the orisons he makes.

src: With all my heart. This fellow I remember, Since once he play'd a farmer's eldest son: 'Twas where you woo'd the gentlewoman so well: I have forgot your name;
trg: but, sure, that part Was aptly fitted and naturally perform'd.

src: I would to heaven I had your potency, And you were Isabel! should it then be thus? No; I would tell what 'twere to be a judge, And what a prisoner.
This is dear mercy, and thou seest it not.
trg: 'Tis torture, and not mercy: heaven is here, Where Juliet lives; and every cat and dog And little mouse, every unworthy thing, Live here in heaven and may look on her; But Romeo may not:

src: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.
trg: Then move not, while my prayer's effect I take. Thus from my lips, by yours, my sin is purged.

src: Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that I may be consul, I have here the customary gown.
trg: You have deserved nobly of your country, and you have not deserved nobly.

src: What traitor hears me, and says not amen? England hath long been mad, and scarr'd herself;
trg: The brother blindly shed the brother's blood, The father rashly slaughter'd his own son, The son, compell'd, been butcher to the sire:

src: In the Duke of Gloucester's purse.
trg: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.

src: I know him well: you are welcome for his sake.
trg: Saving your tale, Petruchio, I pray, Let us, that are poor petitioners, speak too: Baccare! you are marvellous forward.

src: We had the tune on't a month ago.
trg: I can bear my part; you must know 'tis my occupation; have at it with you.

src: Were you sworn to the duke, or to the deputy?
trg: To him, and to his substitutes.

src: I will converse with iron-witted fools And unrespective boys: none are for me That look into me with considerate eyes: High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect. Boy!
trg: My lord?

src: When I would pray and think, I think and pray To several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words; Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue, Anchors on Isabel:
trg: Heaven in my mouth, As if I did but only chew his name; And in my heart the strong and swelling evil Of my conception.

src: Then, worthy Marcius, Attend upon Cominius to these wars.
trg: It is your former promise.

src: O Clifford, how thy words revive my heart!
trg: Henry of Lancaster, resign thy crown. What mutter you, or what conspire you, lords?

src: Come, cousin, let us tell the queen these news.
trg: Farewell, faint-hearted and degenerate king, In whose cold blood no spark of honour bides.

src: You bless me, gods!
trg: Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou wilt have The leading of thine own revenges, take The one half of my commission;

src: There hath been in Rome strange insurrections; the people against the senators, patricians, and nobles.
trg: Hath been! is it ended, then? Our state thinks not so: they are in a most warlike preparation, and hope to come upon them in the heat of their division.

src: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor, The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.
trg: So dear I loved the man, that I must weep. I took him for the plainest harmless creature That breathed upon this earth a Christian;

src: Then I'll commend her volubility, And say she uttereth piercing eloquence: If she do bid me pack, I'll give her thanks, As though she bid me stay by her a week:
trg: If she deny to wed, I'll crave the day When I shall ask the banns and when be married. But here she comes; and now, Petruchio, speak. Good morrow, Kate; for that's your name, I hear.

src: Welcome, ladies, Welcome!
trg: Go tell the lords o' the city I am here: Deliver them this paper: having read it, Bid them repair to the market place; where I, Even in theirs and in the commons' ears, Will vouch the truth of it.

src: Peace have they made with him indeed, my lord.
trg: O villains, vipers, damn'd without redemption! Dogs, easily won to fawn on any man! Snakes, in my heart-blood warm'd, that sting my heart! Three Judases, each one thrice worse than Judas!

src: Well, then, farewell.
trg: Yonder comes news. A wager they have met.

src: For they do prank them in authority, Against all noble sufferance.
trg: Pass no further.

src: some swooned, all sorrowed: if all the world could have seen 't, the woe had been universal.
trg: Are they returned to the court?

src: Foul wrinkled witch, what makest thou in my sight?
trg: But repetition of what thou hast marr'd; That will I make before I let thee go.

src: I pray you, sir, is it your will To make a stale of me amongst these mates?
trg: Mates, maid! how mean you that? no mates for you, Unless you were of gentler, milder mould.

src: I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders Ere I will see the crown so foul misplaced. But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?
trg: Ay, on my life; and hopes to find forward Upon his party for the gain thereof:

src: God give us leisure for these rites of love! Once more, adieu: be valiant, and speed well!
trg: Good lords, conduct him to his regiment: I'll strive, with troubled thoughts, to take a nap, Lest leaden slumber peise me down to-morrow, When I should mount with wings of victory:

src: You're liars all.
trg: Beseech your highness, give us better credit: we all kneel.

src: Why, no, sir.
trg: What then?

src: He is a kinsman to the Montague; Affection makes him false; he speaks not true: Some twenty of them fought in this black strife, And all those twenty could but kill one life.
trg: I beg for justice, which thou, prince, must give; Romeo slew Tybalt, Romeo must not live.

src: Who, when they see the hours ripe on earth, Will rain hot vengeance on offenders' heads.
trg: Finds brotherhood in thee no sharper spur? Hath love in thy old blood no living fire?

src: but farewell compliment! Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say 'Ay,' And I will take thy word: yet if thou swear'st, Thou mayst prove false; at lovers' perjuries Then say, Jove laughs.
trg: O gentle Romeo, If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully: Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won, I'll frown and be perverse an say thee nay, So thou wilt woo; but else, not for the world.

src: You will set cock-a-hoop! you'll be the man!
trg: Why, uncle, 'tis a shame.

src: No, wench; it eats and sleeps and hath such senses As we have, such. This gallant which thou seest Was in the wreck;
trg: and, but he's something stain'd With grief that's beauty's canker, thou mightst call him A goodly person: he hath lost his fellows And strays about to find 'em.

src: All this we swear.
trg: Break up the seals and read.

src: Yield to our mercy, proud Plantagenet.
trg: Ay, to such mercy as his ruthless arm, With downright payment, show'd unto my father. Now Phaethon hath tumbled from his car, And made an evening at the noontide prick.

src: Arm, arm, my lord; the foe vaunts in the field.
trg: Come, bustle, bustle; caparison my horse. Call up Lord Stanley, bid him bring his power: I will lead forth my soldiers to the plain, And thus my battle shall be ordered:

src: Warwick, what are thy news? and yours, fair queen?
trg: Mine, such as fill my heart with unhoped joys.

src: These fifteen years! by my fay, a goodly nap. But did I never speak of all that time?
trg: O, yes, my lord, but very idle words: For though you lay here in this goodly chamber, Yet would you say ye were beaten out of door; And rail upon the hostess of the house;

src: I have been studying how I may compare This prison where I live unto the world: And for because the world is populous And here is not a creature but myself, I cannot do it; yet I'll hammer it out.
trg: My brain I'll prove the female to my soul, My soul the father;

src: O my dread lord, I should be guiltier than my guiltiness, To think I can be undiscernible, When I perceive your grace, like power divine, Hath look'd upon my passes.
trg: Then, good prince, No longer session hold upon my shame, But let my trial be mine own confession: Immediate sentence then and sequent death Is all the grace I beg.

src: If it were damnable, he being so wise, Why would he for the momentary trick Be perdurably fined? O Isabel!
trg: What says my brother?

src: Do you quarrel, sir?
trg: Quarrel sir! no, sir.

src: Alive, in triumph! and Mercutio slain! Away to heaven, respective lenity, And fire-eyed fury be my conduct now! Now, Tybalt, take the villain back again, That late thou gavest me;
trg: for Mercutio's soul Is but a little way above our heads, Staying for thine to keep him company: Either thou, or I, or both, must go with him.

src: Be satisfied; Your brother dies to-morrow; be content.
trg: So you must be the first that gives this sentence, And he, that suffer's. O, it is excellent To have a giant's strength; but it is tyrannous To use it like a giant.

src: Ay, so I fear; the more is my unrest.
trg: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone; We have a trifling foolish banquet towards. Is it e'en so? why, then, I thank you all I thank you, honest gentlemen; good night. More torches here!

src: It is now apparent?
trg: Most manifest, and not denied by himself.

src: Sir, induced by my charity, and hearing how hastily you are to depart, I am come to advise you, comfort you and pray with you.
trg: Friar, not I I have been drinking hard all night, and I will have more time to prepare me, or they shall beat out my brains with billets: I will not consent to die this day, that's certain.

src: I brought high Hereford, if you call him so, But to the next highway, and there I left him.
trg: And say, what store of parting tears were shed?

src: Pray you, poor gentleman, take up some other station; here's no place for you; pray you, avoid: come.
trg: Follow your function, go, and batten on cold bits.

src: Not?
trg: I tell you, he does sit in gold, his eye Red as 'twould burn Rome; and his injury The gaoler to his pity. I kneel'd before him; 'Twas very faintly he said 'Rise;

src: What! this gentleman will out-talk us all.
trg: Sir, give him head: I know he'll prove a jade.

src: I'll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.
trg: Nurse, where's my daughter? call her forth to me.

src: Quick proceeders, marry! Now, tell me, I pray, You that durst swear at your mistress Bianca Loved none in the world so well as Lucentio.
trg: O despiteful love! unconstant womankind! I tell thee, Licio, this is wonderful.

src: The jealous o'erworn widow and herself, Since that our brother dubb'd them gentlewomen. Are mighty gossips in this monarchy.
trg: I beseech your graces both to pardon me; His majesty hath straitly given in charge That no man shall have private conference, Of what degree soever, with his brother.

src: 'Though all at once cannot See what I do deliver out to each, Yet I can make my audit up, that all From me do back receive the flour of all, And leave me but the bran.' What say you to't?
trg: It was an answer: how apply you this?

src: One i' the neck, and two i' the thigh,--there's nine that I know.
trg: He had, before this last expedition, twenty-five wounds upon him.

src: You wrong me, Signior Gremio: give me leave.
trg: And, for an entrance to my entertainment, I do present you with a man of mine, Cunning in music and the mathematics, To instruct her fully in those sciences, Whereof I know she is not ignorant:

src: Without his roe, like a dried herring: flesh, flesh, how art thou fishified! Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in: Laura to his lady was but a kitchen-wench;
trg: marry, she had a better love to be-rhyme her; Dido a dowdy; Cleopatra a gipsy; Helen and Hero hildings and harlots; Thisbe a grey eye or so, but not to the purpose. Signior Romeo, bon jour!

src: a good memory, And witness of the malice and displeasure Which thou shouldst bear me: only that name remains;
trg: The cruelty and envy of the people, Permitted by our dastard nobles, who Have all forsook me, hath devour'd the rest; And suffer'd me by the voice of slaves to be Whoop'd out of Rome.

src: Unmanner'd dog! stand thou, when I command: Advance thy halbert higher than my breast, Or, by Saint Paul, I'll strike thee to my foot, And spurn upon thee, beggar, for thy boldness.
trg: What, do you tremble? are you all afraid? Alas, I blame you not; for you are mortal, And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil. Avaunt, thou dreadful minister of hell!

src: Nothing but bonfires: the oracle is fulfilled; the king's daughter is found: such a deal of wonder is broken out within this hour that ballad-makers cannot be able to express it.
trg: Here comes the Lady Paulina's steward: he can deliver you more. How goes it now, sir? this news which is called true is so like an old tale, that the verity of it is in strong suspicion:

src: Why should I not now have the like success? 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Ah, whither shall I fly to 'scape their hands? Ah, tutor, look where bloody Clifford comes!

src: -- As far as doth the Capitol exceed The meanest house in Rome, so far my son-- This lady's husband here, this, do you see-- Whom you have banish'd, does exceed you all.
trg: Well, well, we'll leave you.

src: Good my lord,--
trg: It is for you we speak, not for ourselves: You are abused and by some putter-on That will be damn'd for't; would I knew the villain, I would land-damn him.

src: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words Of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound: Art thou not Romeo and a Montague?
trg: Neither, fair saint, if either thee dislike.

src: Ye shall, my Lord.
trg: My Lord, I have consider'd in my mind The late demand that you did sound me in.

src: A dream of what thou wert, a breath, a bubble, A sign of dignity, a garish flag, To be the aim of every dangerous shot, A queen in jest, only to fill the scene. Where is thy husband now?
trg: where be thy brothers? Where are thy children? wherein dost thou, joy? Who sues to thee and cries 'God save the queen'? Where be the bending peers that flatter'd thee?

src: Either heaven with lightning strike the murderer dead, Or earth, gape open wide and eat him quick, As thou dost swallow up this good king's blood Which his hell-govern'd arm hath butchered!
trg: Lady, you know no rules of charity, Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.

src: Ay, sir.
trg: Well, give me the moiety. Are you a party in this business?

src: Your grace may do your pleasure.
trg: Tut, tut, thou art all ice, thy kindness freezeth: Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?

src: And there's for twitting me with perjury.
trg: O, kill me too!

src: How say you?
trg: Nay, I'll not warrant that; for I can speak Against the thing I say. Answer to this: I, now the voice of the recorded law, Pronounce a sentence on your brother's life:

src: Say that she frown, I'll say she looks as clear As morning roses newly wash'd with dew: Say she be mute and will not speak a word;
trg: Then I'll commend her volubility, And say she uttereth piercing eloquence: If she do bid me pack, I'll give her thanks, As though she bid me stay by her a week:

src: most likely 'tis for you: Consider of it.'
trg: Our army's in the field We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready To answer us.

src: do not satisfy your resolution with hopes that are fallible: tomorrow you must die; go to your knees and make ready.
trg: Let me ask my sister pardon. I am so out of love with life that I will sue to be rid of it.

src: Being held a foe, he may not have access To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear; And she as much in love, her means much less To meet her new-beloved any where:
trg: But passion lends them power, time means, to meet Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.

src: My lord?
trg: How does the boy?

src: Sir, I will give you as much as this old man does when the business is performed, and remain, as he says, your pawn till it be brought you.
trg: I will trust you. Walk before toward the sea-side; go on the right hand: I will but look upon the hedge and follow you.

src: Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.
trg: O, widow Dido! ay, widow Dido.

src: But, Warwick, Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men, Shall cross the seas, and bid false Edward battle; And, as occasion serves, this noble queen And prince shall follow with a fresh supply.
trg: Yet, ere thou go, but answer me one doubt, What pledge have we of thy firm loyalty?

src: Where is the master, boatswain?
trg: Do you not hear him? You mar our labour: keep your cabins: you do assist the storm.

src: The devil take Henry of Lancaster and thee! Patience is stale, and I am weary of it.
trg: Help, help, help!

src: We were as twinn'd lambs that did frisk i' the sun, And bleat the one at the other: what we changed Was innocence for innocence; we knew not The doctrine of ill-doing, nor dream'd That any did.
trg: Had we pursued that life, And our weak spirits ne'er been higher rear'd With stronger blood, we should have answer'd heaven Boldly 'not guilty;' the imposition clear'd Hereditary ours.

src: Swear, if thou darest.
trg: Nay, I dare not swear it.

src: he, mistrusting them, Hoisted sail and made away for Brittany.
trg: March on, march on, since we are up in arms; If not to fight with foreign enemies, Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.

src: What, household stuff?
trg: It is a kind of history.

src: Let's hence, and hear How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion, More than his singularity, he goes Upon this present action.
trg: Lets along.

src: And though you think that all, as you have done, Have torn their souls by turning them from us, And we are barren and bereft of friends;
trg: Yet know, my master, God omnipotent, Is mustering in his clouds on our behalf Armies of pestilence;

src: Tell me not, friar, that thou hear'st of this, Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it:
trg: If, in thy wisdom, thou canst give no help, Do thou but call my resolution wise, And with this knife I'll help it presently. God join'd my heart and Romeo's, thou our hands;

src: The sight of any of the house of York Is as a fury to torment my soul; And till I root out their accursed line And leave not one alive, I live in hell. Therefore--
trg: O, let me pray before I take my death! To thee I pray; sweet Clifford, pity me!

src: Villain, I say, knock me at this gate And rap me well, or I'll knock your knave's pate.
trg: My master is grown quarrelsome. I should knock you first, And then I know after who comes by the worst.

src: Most sweet voices! Better it is to die, better to starve, Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.
trg: Why in this woolvish toge should I stand here, To beg of Hob and Dick, that do appear, Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to't:

src: And he shall think that thou, which know'st the way To plant unrightful kings, wilt know again, Being ne'er so little urged, another way To pluck him headlong from the usurped throne.
trg: The love of wicked men converts to fear; That fear to hate, and hate turns one or both To worthy danger and deserved death.

src: Art thou his father?
trg: Ay, sir; so his mother says, if I may believe her.
Too late? why, no; I, that do speak a word. May call it back again. If he had been as you and you as he, You would have slipt like him; but he, like you, Would not have been so stern.

src: Proceed, Cominius.
trg: I shall lack voice: the deeds of Coriolanus Should not be utter'd feebly. It is held That valour is the chiefest virtue, and Most dignifies the haver:

src: Antony, and Potpan!
trg: Ay, boy, ready.

src: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.
trg: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

src: Tranio, be so, because Lucentio loves: And let me be a slave, to achieve that maid Whose sudden sight hath thrall'd my wounded eye. Here comes the rogue. Sirrah, where have you been?
trg: Where have I been! Nay, how now! where are you? Master, has my fellow Tranio stolen your clothes? Or you stolen his? or both? pray, what's the news?

src: I understand the business, I hear it: to have an open ear, a quick eye, and a nimble hand, is necessary for a cut-purse; a good nose is requisite also, to smell out work for the other senses.
trg: I see this is the time that the unjust man doth thrive. What an exchange had this been without boot! What a boot is here with this exchange!

src: Ay, on my life; and hopes to find forward Upon his party for the gain thereof:
trg: And thereupon he sends you this good news, That this same very day your enemies, The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.

src: Away with scrupulous wit! now arms must rule.
trg: And fearless minds climb soonest unto crowns. Brother, we will proclaim you out of hand: The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.

src: O, I am fortune's fool!
trg: Why dost thou stay?

src: You make my bonds still greater.
trg: O, your desert speaks loud;

src: He for his father's sake so loves the prince, That he will not be won to aught against him.
trg: What think'st thou, then, of Stanley? what will he?

src: Shepherdess, A fair one are you--well you fit our ages With flowers of winter.
trg: of that kind Our rustic garden's barren; and I care not To get slips of them.

src: Come on, i' God's name; once more toward our father's. Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!
trg: The moon! the sun: it is not moonlight now.

src: That will be never: tune your instrument.
trg: Where left we last?

src: Call that same Isabel here once again; I would speak with her. Pray you, my lord, give me leave to question; you shall see how I'll handle her.
trg: Not better than he, by her own report.

src: If you'll stand fast, we'll beat them to their wives, As they us to our trenches followed. So, now the gates are ope: now prove good seconds:
trg: 'Tis for the followers fortune widens them, Not for the fliers: mark me, and do the like.

src: Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul, Were equal poise of sin and charity.
trg: That I do beg his life, if it be sin, Heaven let me bear it! you granting of my suit, If that be sin, I'll make it my morn prayer To have it added to the faults of mine, And nothing of your answer.

src: Not that I know.
trg: No? you say your husband.

src: Pretty! What say you, Hugh Rebeck?
trg: I say 'silver sound,' because musicians sound for silver.

src: I fear you not.
trg: O, you hope the duke will return no more; or you imagine me too unhurtful an opposite. But indeed I can do you little harm; you'll forswear this again.

src: Is he come?
trg: Why, no, sir.

src: What title hast thou, traitor, to the crown? Thy father was, as thou art, Duke of York; Thy grandfather, Roger Mortimer, Earl of March:
trg: I am the son of Henry the Fifth, Who made the Dauphin and the French to stoop And seized upon their towns and provinces.

src: I do believe Hermione hath suffer'd death, and that Apollo would, this being indeed the issue Of King Polixenes, it should here be laid, Either for life or death, upon the earth Of its right father.
trg: Blossom, speed thee well! There lie, and there thy character: there these; Which may, if fortune please, both breed thee, pretty, And still rest thine. The storm begins;
What then?

src: besides, forget not With what contempt he wore the humble weed, How in his suit he scorn'd you;
trg: but your loves, Thinking upon his services, took from you The apprehension of his present portance, Which most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion After the inveterate hate he bears you.

src: What's within, boy?
trg: You're a made old man: if the sins of your youth are forgiven you, you're well to live. Gold! all gold!

src: And must she die for this? O, let her live, And I'll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty; Slander myself as false to Edward's bed; Throw over her the veil of infamy:
trg: So she may live unscarr'd of bleeding slaughter, I will confess she was not Edward's daughter.

src: Good counsel, marry: learn it, learn it, marquess.
trg: It toucheth you, my lord, as much as me.

src: Thy head is as fun of quarrels as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarrelling:
trg: thou hast quarrelled with a man for coughing in the street, because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun:

src: I'll play the orator as well as Nestor, Deceive more slily than Ulysses could, And, like a Sinon, take another Troy.
trg: I can add colours to the chameleon, Change shapes with Proteus for advantages, And set the murderous Machiavel to school. Can I do this, and cannot get a crown?

src: It boots thee not to be compassionate: After our sentence plaining comes too late.
trg: Then thus I turn me from my country's light, To dwell in solemn shades of endless night.

src: He's sudden, if a thing comes in his head. Now march we hence: discharge the common sort With pay and thanks, and let's away to London And see our gentle queen how well she fares:
trg: By this, I hope, she hath a son for me. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: O mother, mother! What have you done? Behold, the heavens do ope, The gods look down, and this unnatural scene They laugh at. O my mother, mother! O! You have won a happy victory to Rome;
trg: But, for your son,--believe it, O, believe it, Most dangerously you have with him prevail'd, If not most mortal to him. But, let it come.

src: Then this is mine opinion: that King Lewis Becomes your enemy, for mocking him About the marriage of the Lady Bona.
trg: And Warwick, doing what you gave in charge, Is now dishonoured by this new marriage.

src: Amen, sir: to my poor unworthy notice, He mock'd us when he begg'd our voices.
trg: Certainly He flouted us downright.

src: And so obsequious will thy father be, Even for the loss of thee, having no more, As Priam was for all his valiant sons. I'll bear thee hence;
trg: and let them fight that will, For I have murdered where I should not kill.

src: Then show it me.
trg: Had I a glass, I would.

src: What must I do?
trg: Return to the tribunes.

src: I was anointed king at nine months old; My father and my grandfather were kings, And you were sworn true subjects unto me: And tell me, then, have you not broke your oaths?
trg: No; For we were subjects but while you were king.

src: I'll give my reasons, More worthier than their voices. They know the corn Was not our recompense, resting well assured That ne'er did service for't:
trg: being press'd to the war, Even when the navel of the state was touch'd, They would not thread the gates. This kind of service Did not deserve corn gratis.

src: And I, with grief and sorrow, to the court.
trg: Here comes the queen, whose looks bewray her anger: I'll steal away.

src: O, she says nothing, sir, but weeps and weeps; And now falls on her bed; and then starts up, And Tybalt calls; and then on Romeo cries, And then down falls again.
trg: As if that name, Shot from the deadly level of a gun, Did murder her; as that name's cursed hand Murder'd her kinsman. O, tell me, friar, tell me, In what vile part of this anatomy Doth my name lodge?

src: You are never without your tricks: you may, you may.
trg: Are you all resolved to give your voices? But that's no matter, the greater part carries it. I say, if he would incline to the people, there was never a worthier man.

src: Be advised.
trg: I am, and by my fancy: if my reason Will thereto be obedient, I have reason; If not, my senses, better pleased with madness, Do bid it welcome.

src: But for the concord of my state and time Had not an ear to hear my true time broke. I wasted time, and now doth time waste me; For now hath time made me his numbering clock: My thoughts are minutes;
trg: and with sighs they jar Their watches on unto mine eyes, the outward watch, Whereto my finger, like a dial's point, Is pointing still, in cleansing them from tears.

src: Your company to the Capitol; where, I know, Our greatest friends attend us.
Well have you argued, sir; and, for your pains, Of capital treason we arrest you here. My Lord of Westminster, be it your charge To keep him safely till his day of trial.
trg: May it please you, lords, to grant the commons' suit.

src: Now must I to the monument alone; Within three hours will fair Juliet wake: She will beshrew me much that Romeo Hath had no notice of these accidents;
trg: But I will write again to Mantua, And keep her at my cell till Romeo come; Poor living corse, closed in a dead man's tomb!

src: Happy return be to your royal grace!
trg: Many and hearty thankings to you both. We have made inquiry of you; and we hear Such goodness of your justice, that our soul Cannot but yield you forth to public thanks, Forerunning more requital.

src: Or bid me go into a new-made grave And hide me with a dead man in his shroud; Things that, to hear them told, have made me tremble;
trg: And I will do it without fear or doubt, To live an unstain'd wife to my sweet love.

src: You left poor Henry at the Bishop's palace, And, ten to one, you'll meet him in the Tower.
trg: 'Tis even so; yet you are Warwick still.

src: Untutor'd lad, thou art too malapert.
trg: I know my duty; you are all undutiful: Lascivious Edward, and thou perjured George, And thou mis-shapen Dick, I tell ye all I am your better, traitors as ye are:
Your brother is a forfeit of the law, And you but waste your words.

src: And ere this hand, by thee to Romeo seal'd, Shall be the label to another deed, Or my true heart with treacherous revolt Turn to another, this shall slay them both: Be not so long to speak;
trg: I long to die, If what thou speak'st speak not of remedy.

src: Bear from hence his body; And mourn you for him: let him be regarded As the most noble corse that ever herald Did follow to his urn.
trg: His own impatience Takes from Aufidius a great part of blame. Let's make the best of it.

src: Go; away with her to prison!
trg: Good my lord, be good to me; your honour is accounted a merciful man; good my lord.

src: By such despair, I should accuse myself.
trg: And, by despairing, shouldst thou stand excused; For doing worthy vengeance on thyself, Which didst unworthy slaughter upon others.

src: Let me be ta'en, let me be put to death; I am content, so thou wilt have it so. I'll say yon grey is not the morning's eye, 'Tis but the pale reflex of Cynthia's brow;
trg: Nor that is not the lark, whose notes do beat The vaulty heaven so high above our heads: I have more care to stay than will to go: Come, death, and welcome! Juliet wills it so. How is't, my soul?

src: I.
trg: 'Tis burnt; and so is all the meat. What dogs are these! Where is the rascal cook? How durst you, villains, bring it from the dresser, And serve it thus to me that love it not?
