src: We say that Shore's wife hath a pretty foot, A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue; And that the queen's kindred are made gentle-folks: How say you sir? Can you deny all this?
trg: With this, my lord, myself have nought to do.

src: And whatsoever you will employ me in, Were it to call King Edward's widow sister, I will perform it to enfranchise you.
trg: Meantime, this deep disgrace in brotherhood Touches me deeper than you can imagine.
'Faith, my lord. I spoke it but according to the trick. If you will hang me for it, you may; but I had rather it would please you I might be whipt.

src: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing: They call me Katharina that do talk of me.
trg: You lie, in faith; for you are call'd plain Kate, And bonny Kate and sometimes Kate the curst;

src: Marcius, 'tis true that you have lately told us; The Volsces are in arms.
trg: They have a leader, Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to 't. I sin in envying his nobility, And were I any thing but what I am, I would wish me only he.

src: Come, cousin, canst thou quake, and change thy colour, Murder thy breath in the middle of a word, And then begin again, and stop again, As if thou wert distraught and mad with terror?
trg: Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian; Speak and look back, and pry on every side, Tremble and start at wagging of a straw, Intending deep suspicion:

src: Your plaintain-leaf is excellent for that.
trg: For what, I pray thee?

src: I will tell her, sir, that you do protest; which, as I take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.
trg: Bid her devise Some means to come to shrift this afternoon; And there she shall at Friar Laurence' cell Be shrived and married. Here is for thy pains.

src: Nay, come, sit down; then on.
trg: Dwelt by a churchyard: I will tell it softly; Yond crickets shall not hear it.

src: 'Twas I that gave the kingdom to thy brother.
trg: Why then 'tis mine, if but by Warwick's gift.

src: How came we ashore?
trg: By Providence divine. so, of his gentleness, Knowing I loved my books, he furnish'd me From mine own library with volumes that I prize above my dukedom.

src: My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.
trg: How! turn thy back and run?

src: It would beseem the Lord Northumberland To say 'King Richard:' alack the heavy day When such a sacred king should hide his head.
trg: Your grace mistakes; only to be brief Left I his title out.

src: More nor less to others paying Than by self-offences weighing. Shame to him whose cruel striking Kills for faults of his own liking! Twice treble shame on Angelo, To weed my vice and let his grow!
trg: O, what may man within him hide, Though angel on the outward side!

src: Say my request's unjust, And spurn me back: but if it be not so, Thou art not honest; and the gods will plague thee, That thou restrain'st from me the duty which To a mother's part belongs.
trg: He turns away: Down, ladies; let us shame him with our knees. To his surname Coriolanus 'longs more pride Than pity to our prayers. Down: an end; This is the last:

src: but what we do not see We tread upon, and never think of it. You may not so extenuate his offence For I have had such faults;
trg: but rather tell me, When I, that censure him, do so offend, Let mine own judgment pattern out my death, And nothing come in partial. Sir, he must die.

src: Hold, Clifford! do not honour him so much To prick thy finger, though to wound his heart:
trg: What valour were it, when a cur doth grin, For one to thrust his hand between his teeth, When he might spurn him with his foot away? It is war's prize to take all vantages;

src: No, uncle; but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy I want more uncles here to welcome me.
trg: Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years Hath not yet dived into the world's deceit Nor more can you distinguish of a man Than of his outward show;

src: No, no: but all this did I know before. What says he of our marriage? what of that?
trg: Lord, how my head aches! what a head have I! It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces. My back o' t' other side,--O, my back, my back!

src: Satisfy! The entreaties of your mistress! satisfy! Let that suffice.
trg: I have trusted thee, Camillo, With all the nearest things to my heart, as well My chamber-councils, wherein, priest-like, thou Hast cleansed my bosom, I from thee departed Thy penitent reform'd:

src: That's I, an't like your grace: I came to her from Claudio, and desired her To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo For her poor brother's pardon.
trg: That's he indeed.

src: Have you got leave to go to shrift to-day?
trg: I have.

src: Once more, good night, kind lords and gentlemen. O Thou, whose captain I account myself, Look on my forces with a gracious eye;
trg: Put in their hands thy bruising irons of wrath, That they may crush down with a heavy fall The usurping helmets of our adversaries!

src: Beguiled, divorced, wronged, spited, slain! Most detestable death, by thee beguil'd, By cruel cruel thee quite overthrown! O love! O life! not life, but love in death!
trg: Despised, distressed, hated, martyr'd, kill'd! Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now To murder, murder our solemnity? O child! O child! my soul, and not my child! Dead art thou! Alack!

src: Stay yet another day, thou trusty Welshman: The king reposeth all his confidence in thee.
trg: 'Tis thought the king is dead; we will not stay. The bay-trees in our country are all wither'd And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven;

src: Your suit's unprofitable; stand up, I say. I have bethought me of another fault. Provost, how came it Claudio was beheaded At an unusual hour?
trg: It was commanded so.

src: The appellant in all duty greets your highness, And craves to kiss your hand and take his leave.
trg: We will descend and fold him in our arms. Cousin of Hereford, as thy cause is right, So be thy fortune in this royal fight! Farewell, my blood;

src: Be confident to speak, Northumberland: We three are but thyself; and, speaking so, Thy words are but as thoughts; therefore, be bold.
trg: Then thus: Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay The first departing of the king for Ireland. But if you faint, as fearing to do so, Stay and be secret, and myself will go.

src: Why, there's a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.
trg: Well, go thy ways, old lad; for thou shalt ha't.

src: I shall, sir. Fare you well.
trg: Good night. This deed unshapes me quite, makes me unpregnant And dull to all proceedings. A deflower'd maid! And by an eminent body that enforced The law against it!

src: Thou hast said enough. Beshrew thee, cousin, which didst lead me forth Of that sweet way I was in to despair! What say you now? what comfort have we now?
trg: By heaven, I'll hate him everlastingly That bids me be of comfort any more. Go to Flint castle: there I'll pine away; A king, woe's slave, shall kingly woe obey. That power I have, discharge;

src: Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's love Made me exchange my state with Tranio, While he did bear my countenance in the town;
trg: And happily I have arrived at the last Unto the wished haven of my bliss. What Tranio did, myself enforced him to; Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

src: therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate him manifests the true knowledge he has in their disposition; and out of his noble carelessness lets them plainly see't.
trg: If he did not care whether he had their love or no, he waved indifferently 'twixt doing them neither good nor harm: but he seeks their hate with greater devotion than can render it him;

src: Which draught to me were cordial.
trg: Sir, my lord, I could do this, and that with no rash potion, But with a lingering dram that should not work Maliciously like poison:

src: Ay, but to die, and go we know not where; To lie in cold obstruction and to rot; This sensible warm motion to become A kneaded clod;
trg: and the delighted spirit To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice;

src: A merry heart goes all the day, Your sad tires in a mile-a.
trg: These your unusual weeds to each part of you Do give a life: no shepherdess, but Flora Peering in April's front. This your sheep-shearing Is as a meeting of the petty gods, And you the queen on't.

src: Bear her my true love's kiss; and so, farewell. Relenting fool, and shallow, changing woman! How now! what news?
trg: My gracious sovereign, on the western coast Rideth a puissant navy; to the shore Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends, Unarm'd, and unresolved to beat them back:

src: No doubt, no doubt; O, 'tis a parlous boy; Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable He is all the mother's, from the top to toe.
trg: Well, let them rest. Come hither, Catesby. Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend As closely to conceal what we impart: Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way; What think'st thou?

src: for how art thou a king But by fair sequence and succession? Now, afore God--God forbid I say true!
trg: Think what you will, we seize into our hands His plate, his goods, his money and his lands.

src: and here, by this, is your brother saved, your honour untainted, the poor Mariana advantaged, and the corrupt deputy scaled. The maid will I frame and make fit for his attempt.
trg: If you think well to carry this as you may, the doubleness of the benefit defends the deceit from reproof. What think you of it?

src: What service wilt thou do me, if I give them?
trg: What you command, that rests in me to do.

src: My mind is changed, sir, my mind is changed. How now, what news with you?
trg: None good, my lord, to please you with the hearing; Nor none so bad, but it may well be told.
Happily met, my lady and my wife!

src: Scotland hath will to help, but cannot help; Our people and our peers are both misled, Our treasures seized, our soldiers put to flight, And, as thou seest, ourselves in heavy plight.
trg: Renowned queen, with patience calm the storm, While we bethink a means to break it off.

src: In good time.
trg: The hand that hath made you fair hath made you good: the goodness that is cheap in beauty makes beauty brief in goodness;

src: My lord, this is one Lucio's information against me. Mistress Kate Keepdown was with child by him in the duke's time; he promised her marriage:
trg: his child is a year and a quarter old, come Philip and Jacob: I have kept it myself; and see how he goes about to abuse me!

src: Be of comfort; My father's of a better nature, sir, Than he appears by speech: this is unwonted Which now came from him.
trg: Thou shalt be free As mountain winds: but then exactly do All points of my command.

src: and my ground to do't Is the obedience to a master, one Who in rebellion with himself will have All that are his so too. To do this deed, Promotion follows.
trg: If I could find example Of thousands that had struck anointed kings And flourish'd after, I'ld not do't; but since Nor brass nor stone nor parchment bears not one, Let villany itself forswear't.

src: My lord, you nod; you do not mind the play.
trg: Yes, by Saint Anne, do I. A good matter, surely: comes there any more of it?

src: Faith, we may put up our pipes, and be gone.
trg: Honest goodfellows, ah, put up, put up; For, well you know, this is a pitiful case.

src: To answer that, I should confess to you.
trg: Do not deny to him that you love me.

src: O, woe the day!
trg: No harm.

src: Smile, gentle heaven! or strike, ungentle death! For this world frowns, and Edward's sun is clouded.
trg: How now, my lord! what hap? what hope of good?

src: God-a-mercy, Grumio! then he shall have no odds.
trg: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.

src: and, lips, O you The doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss A dateless bargain to engrossing death! Come, bitter conduct, come, unsavoury guide!
trg: Thou desperate pilot, now at once run on The dashing rocks thy sea-sick weary bark! Here's to my love! O true apothecary! Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die.

src: Lord, how my head aches! what a head have I! It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces. My back o' t' other side,--O, my back, my back!
trg: Beshrew your heart for sending me about, To catch my death with jaunting up and down!

src: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.
trg: Nay, good goose, bite not.

src: Never hung poison on a fouler toad. Out of my sight! thou dost infect my eyes.
trg: Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.

src: I do assure thee, father, so it is.
trg: Come, go along, and see the truth hereof; For our first merriment hath made thee jealous.

src: Of government the properties to unfold, Would seem in me to affect speech and discourse;
trg: Since I am put to know that your own science Exceeds, in that, the lists of all advice My strength can give you:

src: I tell thee, fellow, The general is my lover: I have been The book of his good acts, whence men have read His name unparallel'd, haply amplified;
trg: For I have ever verified my friends, Of whom he's chief, with all the size that verity Would without lapsing suffer:

src: 'Tell him,' quoth she, 'my mourning weeds are done, And I am ready to put armour on.'
trg: Belike she minds to play the Amazon. But what said Warwick to these injuries?

src: At least two glasses. The time 'twixt six and now Must by us both be spent most preciously.
trg: Is there more toil? Since thou dost give me pains, Let me remember thee what thou hast promised, Which is not yet perform'd me.

src: from whence he returned, his brows bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I sprang not more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child than now in first seeing he had proved himself a man.
trg: But had he died in the business, madam; how then?

src: The mighty dukes Gloucester and Buckingham.
trg: For what offence?

src: My master's.
trg: Indeed, I should have ask'd you that before.

src: But, God he knows, thy share thereof is small: 'Tis virtue that doth make them most admired; The contrary doth make thee wonder'd at: 'Tis government that makes them seem divine;
trg: The want thereof makes thee abominable: Thou art as opposite to every good As the Antipodes are unto us, Or as the south to the septentrion. O tiger's heart wrapt in a woman's hide!

src: He shall be none; We'll keep him here: then what is that to him?
trg: Away, fond woman! were he twenty times my son, I would appeach him.

src: O calm, dishonourable, vile submission! Alla stoccata carries it away. Tybalt, you rat-catcher, will you walk?
trg: What wouldst thou have with me?

src: Now, good sweet nurse,--O Lord, why look'st thou sad? Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily; If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news By playing it to me with so sour a face.
trg: I am a-weary, give me leave awhile: Fie, how my bones ache! what a jaunt have I had!

src: Take her hence: Her heart is but o'ercharged; she will recover: I have too much believed mine own suspicion: Beseech you, tenderly apply to her Some remedies for life.
trg: Apollo, pardon My great profaneness 'gainst thine oracle! I'll reconcile me to Polixenes, New woo my queen, recall the good Camillo, Whom I proclaim a man of truth, of mercy;

src: What's the matter?
trg: Now, you companion, I'll say an errand for you: You shall know now that I am in estimation; you shall perceive that a Jack guardant cannot office me from my son Coriolanus:

src: We are tougher, brother, Than you can put us to't.
trg: No longer stay.

src: God keep the prince from all the pack of you! A knot you are of damned blood-suckers!
trg: You live that shall cry woe for this after.

src: Fear me not.
trg: Nor, gentle daughter, fear you not at all. He is your husband on a pre-contract: To bring you thus together, 'tis no sin, Sith that the justice of your title to him Doth flourish the deceit.

src: So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows, As yonder lady o'er her fellows shows. The measure done, I'll watch her place of stand, And, touching hers, make blessed my rude hand.
trg: Did my heart love till now? forswear it, sight! For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.

src: Perjury, perjury, in the high'st degree Murder, stem murder, in the direst degree; All several sins, all used in each degree, Throng to the bar, crying all, Guilty! guilty! I shall despair.
trg: There is no creature loves me; And if I die, no soul shall pity me: Nay, wherefore should they, since that I myself Find in myself no pity to myself?

src: What wisdom stirs amongst you? Come, sir, now I am for you again: pray you, sit by us, And tell 's a tale.
trg: Merry or sad shall't be?

src: But not, as I am, royal.
trg: Nor you, as we are, loyal.

src: Did I forget that by the house of York My father came untimely to his death? Did I let pass the abuse done to my niece? Did I impale him with the regal crown? Did I put Henry from his native right?
trg: And am I guerdon'd at the last with shame? Shame on himself! for my desert is honour: And to repair my honour lost for him, I here renounce him and return to Henry.

src: When he had done, some followers of mine own, At the lower end of the hall, hurl'd up their caps, And some ten voices cried 'God save King Richard!
trg: ' And thus I took the vantage of those few, 'Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,' quoth I; 'This general applause and loving shout Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard:

src: Cousin of Hereford, what dost thou object Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?
trg: First, heaven be the record to my speech!

src: What, is there none of Pygmalion's images, newly made woman, to be had now, for putting the hand in the pocket and extracting it clutch'd? What reply, ha?
trg: What sayest thou to this tune, matter and method? Is't not drowned i' the last rain, ha? What sayest thou, Trot? Is the world as it was, man? Which is the way? Is it sad, and few words? or how?

src: Against them both my true joints bended be. Ill mayst thou thrive, if thou grant any grace!
trg: Pleads he in earnest? look upon his face; His eyes do drop no tears, his prayers are in jest; His words come from his mouth, ours from our breast: He prays but faintly and would be denied;

src: He dreads his wife.
trg: So I would you did; then 'twere past all doubt You'ld call your children yours.

src: No, at a word, madam; indeed, I must not. I wish you much mirth.
trg: Well, then, farewell.

src: Away, begone; the sport is at the best.
trg: Ay, so I fear; the more is my unrest.

src: Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price. Is't a verdict?
trg: No more talking on't; let it be done: away, away!

src: if you are not, Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians, If they be senators: and they are no less, When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste Most palates theirs.
trg: They choose their magistrate, And such a one as he, who puts his 'shall,' His popular 'shall' against a graver bench Than ever frown in Greece. By Jove himself! It makes the consuls base:

src: and will not-- For, as the case now stands, it is a curse He cannot be compell'd to't--once remove The root of his opinion, which is rotten As ever oak or stone was sound.
trg: A callat Of boundless tongue, who late hath beat her husband And now baits me! This brat is none of mine; It is the issue of Polixenes:

src: then the honour'd mould Wherein this trunk was framed, and in her hand The grandchild to her blood. But, out, affection! All bond and privilege of nature, break! Let it be virtuous to be obstinate.
trg: What is that curt'sy worth? or those doves' eyes, Which can make gods forsworn? I melt, and am not Of stronger earth than others. My mother bows;

src: 'Tis better using France than trusting France: Let us be back'd with God and with the seas Which He hath given for fence impregnable, And with their helps only defend ourselves;
trg: In them and in ourselves our safety lies.

src: Alas, I am not coop'd here for defence! I will away towards Barnet presently, And bid thee battle, Edward, if thou darest.
trg: Yes, Warwick, Edward dares, and leads the way. Lords, to the field; Saint George and victory! 3 KING HENRY VI

src: Good day, my lord. What, at your book so hard?
trg: Ay, my good lord:--my lord, I should say rather; 'Tis sin to flatter; 'good' was little better: 'Good Gloucester' and 'good devil' were alike, And both preposterous; therefore, not 'good lord.'

src: Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender Of my child's love: I think she will be ruled In all respects by me; nay, more, I doubt it not. Wife, go you to her ere you go to bed;
trg: Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love; And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next-- But, soft! what day is this?

src: O worthy prince, dishonour not your eye By throwing it on any other object Till you have heard me in my true complaint And given me justice, justice, justice, justice!
trg: Relate your wrongs; in what? by whom? be brief. Here is Lord Angelo shall give you justice: Reveal yourself to him.

src: O, no, my dream was lengthen'd after life;
trg: O, then began the tempest to my soul, Who pass'd, methought, the melancholy flood, With that grim ferryman which poets write of, Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.

src: I'm out of patience.
trg: We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards: This wide-chapp'd rascal--would thou mightst lie drowning The washing of ten tides!

src: O, ay, Curtis, ay: and therefore fire, fire; cast on no water.
trg: Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported?

src: Now, you companion, I'll say an errand for you: You shall know now that I am in estimation; you shall perceive that a Jack guardant cannot office me from my son Coriolanus:
trg: guess, but by my entertainment with him, if thou standest not i' the state of hanging, or of some death more long in spectatorship, and crueller in suffering;

src: My lord, no leave take I; for I will ride, As far as land will let me, by your side.
trg: O, to what purpose dost thou hoard thy words, That thou return'st no greeting to thy friends?

src: The state, whereon I studied Is like a good thing, being often read, Grown fear'd and tedious;
trg: yea, my gravity, Wherein--let no man hear me--I take pride, Could I with boot change for an idle plume, Which the air beats for vain.

src: Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory To feed my humour, wish thyself no harm.
trg: No! why? O, when, I say, I look'd on Richard's face, This was my wish: 'Be thou,' quoth I, ' accursed, For making me, so young, so old a widow! And, when thou wed'st, let sorrow haunt thy bed;

src: Shall we call back Northumberland, and send Defiance to the traitor, and so die?
trg: No, good my lord; let's fight with gentle words Till time lend friends and friends their helpful swords.

src: Then let my father's blood open it again: He is a man, and, Clifford, cope with him.
trg: Had thy brethren here, their lives and thine Were not revenge sufficient for me;

src: Then, good prince, No longer session hold upon my shame, But let my trial be mine own confession: Immediate sentence then and sequent death Is all the grace I beg.
trg: Come hither, Mariana. Say, wast thou e'er contracted to this woman?

src: beauty's ensign yet Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks, And death's pale flag is not advanced there. Tybalt, liest thou there in thy bloody sheet?
trg: O, what more favour can I do to thee, Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain To sunder his that was thine enemy? Forgive me, cousin! Ah, dear Juliet, Why art thou yet so fair?

src: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.
trg: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.

src: Marry, I fare well for here is cheer enough. Where is my wife?
trg: Here, noble lord: what is thy will with her?

src: Knock you here, sir! why, sir, what am I, sir, that I should knock you here, sir?
trg: Villain, I say, knock me at this gate And rap me well, or I'll knock your knave's pate.

src: then no more remains, But that to your sufficiency, as your Worth is able, And let them work.
trg: The nature of our people, Our city's institutions, and the terms For common justice, you're as pregnant in As art and practise hath enriched any That we remember.

src: Say no more: Howe'er the business goes, you have made fault I' the boldness of your speech.
trg: I am sorry for't: All faults I make, when I shall come to know them, I do repent. Alas! I have show'd too much The rashness of a woman: he is touch'd To the noble heart.

src: My heart will sigh when I miscall it so, Which finds it an inforced pilgrimage.
trg: The sullen passage of thy weary steps Esteem as foil wherein thou art to set The precious jewel of thy home return.

src: Hence comes it that your kindred shuns your house, As beaten hence by your strange lunacy.
trg: O noble lord, bethink thee of thy birth, Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment And banish hence these abject lowly dreams.

src: Cushions, leaden spoons, Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves, Ere yet the fight be done, pack up: down with them!
trg: And hark, what noise the general makes! To him! There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius, Piercing our Romans: then, valiant Titus, take Convenient numbers to make good the city;

src: My lord, I know him; 'tis a meddling friar; I do not like the man: had he been lay, my lord For certain words he spake against your grace In your retirement, I had swinged him soundly.
trg: Words against me? this is a good friar, belike! And to set on this wretched woman here Against our substitute! Let this friar be found.

src: I say, I come From your good queen.
trg: Good queen!

src: None, since the curfew rung.
trg: Not Isabel?

src: Shall I speak ill of him that is my husband? Ah, poor my lord, what tongue shall smooth thy name, When I, thy three-hours wife, have mangled it? But, wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?
trg: That villain cousin would have kill'd my husband: Back, foolish tears, back to your native spring; Your tributary drops belong to woe, Which you, mistaking, offer up to joy.

src: Spread thy close curtain, love-performing night, That runaway's eyes may wink and Romeo Leap to these arms, untalk'd of and unseen. Lovers can see to do their amorous rites By their own beauties;
trg: or, if love be blind, It best agrees with night. Come, civil night, Thou sober-suited matron, all in black, And learn me how to lose a winning match, Play'd for a pair of stainless maidenhoods:

src: and thou, son Clarence, Shalt stir up in Suffolk, Norfolk, and in Kent, The knights and gentlemen to come with thee:
trg: Thou, brother Montague, in Buckingham, Northampton and in Leicestershire, shalt find Men well inclined to hear what thou command'st:

src: Sir, in Argier.
trg: O, was she so? I must Once in a month recount what thou hast been, Which thou forget'st.

src: Thou, brother Montague, in Buckingham, Northampton and in Leicestershire, shalt find Men well inclined to hear what thou command'st:
trg: And thou, brave Oxford, wondrous well beloved, In Oxfordshire shalt muster up thy friends.

src: Who hath committed them?
trg: The mighty dukes Gloucester and Buckingham.

src: No.
trg: Lechery?

src: One, Kate, that you must kiss, and be acquainted with. Where are my slippers? Shall I have some water? Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily. You whoreson villain! will you let it fall?
trg: Patience, I pray you; 'twas a fault unwilling.

src: Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign The weary way hath made you melancholy.
trg: No, uncle; but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy I want more uncles here to welcome me.

src: And had he match'd according to his state, He might have kept that glory to this day; For what hath broach'd this tumult but thy pride? Hadst thou been meek, our title still had slept;
trg: And we, in pity of the gentle king, Had slipp'd our claim until another age.

src: What advocate hast thou to him?
trg: I know not, an't like you.

src: Come hither, nurse. What is yond gentleman?
trg: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

src: Would I might But ever see that man!
trg: Now I arise: Sit still, and hear the last of our sea-sorrow. Here in this island we arrived;

src: O, she's warm! If this be magic, let it be an art Lawful as eating.
trg: She embraces him.

src: O bitter consequence, That Edward still should live! 'True, noble prince!' Cousin, thou wert not wont to be so dull: Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead; And I would have it suddenly perform'd.
trg: What sayest thou? speak suddenly; be brief.

src: I pray you all, tell me what they deserve That do conspire my death with devilish plots Of damned witchcraft, and that have prevail'd Upon my body with their hellish charms?
trg: The tender love I bear your grace, my lord, Makes me most forward in this noble presence To doom the offenders, whatsoever they be I say, my lord, they have deserved death.

src: Away with her! Poor soul, She speaks this in the infirmity of sense.
trg: O prince, I conjure thee, as thou believest There is another comfort than this world, That thou neglect me not, with that opinion That I am touch'd with madness!

src: You cram these words into mine ears against The stomach of my sense. Would I had never Married my daughter there!
trg: for, coming thence, My son is lost and, in my rate, she too, Who is so far from Italy removed I ne'er again shall see her.

src: Thou art the first knave that e'er madest a duke. First, provost, let me bail these gentle three. Sneak not away, sir; for the friar and you Must have a word anon. Lay hold on him.
trg: This may prove worse than hanging.

src: No, boy.
trg: Why do you wring your hands, and beat your breast, And cry 'O Clarence, my unhappy son!'

src: What's the news? what's the news?
trg: Your temples burned in their cement, and Your franchises, whereon you stood, confined Into an auger's bore.

src: Shall I not, then, be stifled in the vault, To whose foul mouth no healthsome air breathes in, And there die strangled ere my Romeo comes?
trg: Where bloody Tybalt, yet but green in earth, Lies festering in his shroud; where, as they say, At some hours in the night spirits resort;

src: That Henry's death, my lovely Edward's death, Their kingdom's loss, my woful banishment, Could all but answer for that peevish brat? Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven?
trg: Why, then, give way, dull clouds, to my quick curses! If not by war, by surfeit die your king, As ours by murder, to make him a king!

src: Say, Somerville, what says my loving son? And, by thy guess, how nigh is Clarence now?
trg: At Southam I did leave him with his forces, And do expect him here some two hours hence.

src: Saving your tale, Petruchio, I pray, Let us, that are poor petitioners, speak too: Baccare! you are marvellous forward.
trg: O, pardon me, Signior Gremio; I would fain be doing.

src: My lord, Fear none of this: I think you know my fortunes Do all lie there: it shall be so my care To have you royally appointed as if The scene you play were mine.
trg: For instance, sir, That you may know you shall not want, one word.

src: Say that I did all this for love of her.
trg: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee, Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.

src: Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread? Away, thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant; Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou livest!
trg: I tell thee, I, that thou hast marr'd her gown.

src: For queen, a very caitiff crown'd with care; For one being sued to, one that humbly sues; For one that scorn'd at me, now scorn'd of me; For one being fear'd of all, now fearing one;
trg: For one commanding all, obey'd of none. Thus hath the course of justice wheel'd about, And left thee but a very prey to time;

src: After, Aumerle! mount thee upon his horse; Spur post, and get before him to the king, And beg thy pardon ere he do accuse thee. I'll not be long behind;
trg: though I be old, I doubt not but to ride as fast as York: And never will I rise up from the ground Till Bolingbroke have pardon'd thee. Away, be gone!

src: My sometime general, I have seen thee stem, and thou hast oft beheld Heart-hardening spectacles; tell these sad women 'Tis fond to wail inevitable strokes, As 'tis to laugh at 'em.
trg: My mother, you wot well My hazards still have been your solace:

src: God forgive me, Marry, and amen, how sound is she asleep! I must needs wake her. Madam, madam, madam! Ay, let the county take you in your bed; He'll fright you up, i' faith. Will it not be?
trg: What, dress'd! and in your clothes! and down again! I must needs wake you; Lady! lady! lady! Alas, alas! Help, help! my lady's dead! O, well-a-day, that ever I was born! Some aqua vitae, ho! My lord!

src: He kills her in her own humour.
trg: Where is he?

src: A husband! a devil.
trg: I say, a husband.

src: They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts, Which makes me sweat with wrath. Come on, my fellows: He that retires I'll take him for a Volsce, And he shall feel mine edge.
trg: All the contagion of the south light on you, You shames of Rome!

src: I'll draw the curtain: My lord's almost so far transported that He'll think anon it lives.
trg: O sweet Paulina, Make me to think so twenty years together! No settled senses of the world can match The pleasure of that madness. Let 't alone.

src: What's thy offence, Claudio?
trg: What but to speak of would offend again.

src: My words are dull; O, quicken them with thine!
trg: Thy woes will make them sharp, and pierce like mine.

src: No, I can better play the orator.
trg: But I have reasons strong and forcible.

src: How, my pretty York? I pray thee, let me hear it.
trg: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old 'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth. Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.

src: I am sorry, Most sorry, you have broken from his liking Where you were tied in duty, and as sorry Your choice is not so rich in worth as beauty, That you might well enjoy her.
trg: Dear, look up: Though Fortune, visible an enemy, Should chase us with my father, power no jot Hath she to change our loves. Beseech you, sir, Remember since you owed no more to time Than I do now:

src: He made you for a highway to my bed; But I, a maid, die maiden-widowed. Come, cords, come, nurse; I'll to my wedding-bed; And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!
trg: Hie to your chamber: I'll find Romeo To comfort you: I wot well where he is. Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night: I'll to him; he is hid at Laurence' cell.

src: Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen, That you have ta'en a tardy sluggard here.
trg: How have you slept, my lord?

src: I'll give thee armour to keep off that word: Adversity's sweet milk, philosophy, To comfort thee, though thou art banished.
trg: Yet 'banished'? Hang up philosophy! Unless philosophy can make a Juliet, Displant a town, reverse a prince's doom, It helps not, it prevails not: talk no more.

src: Sweet madam.
trg: I am glad to see your ladyship.

src: Enough, with over-measure.
trg: No, take more: What may be sworn by, both divine and human, Seal what I end withal! purpose so barr'd, it follows, Nothing is done to purpose. let them not lick The sweet which is their poison:

src: Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua. Do you hear, sir?
trg: To leave frivolous circumstances, I pray you, tell Signior Lucentio that his father is come from Pisa, and is here at the door to speak with him.

src: Well, I'll hear it, sir: yet you must not think to fob off our disgrace with a tale: but, an 't please you, deliver.
trg: There was a time when all the body's members Rebell'd against the belly, thus accused it: The belly answer'd--

src: Come, come, peace.
trg: I would he had continued to his country As he began, and not unknit himself The noble knot he made.

src: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster!
trg: The gates are open, let us enter too.

src: Come hither, Mariana. Say, wast thou e'er contracted to this woman?
trg: I was, my lord.

src: Sir, it is; And I am constant. Titus Lartius, thou Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus' face. What, art thou stiff? stand'st out?
trg: No, Caius Marcius; I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with t'other, Ere stay behind this business.

src: I had an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him; I had a Harry, till a Richard kill'd him: Thou hadst an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him; Thou hadst a Richard, till a Richard killed him;
trg: I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him; I had a Rutland too, thou holp'st to kill him.

src: She embraces him.
trg: She hangs about his neck: If she pertain to life let her speak too.

src: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?
trg: What satisfaction canst thou have to-night?

src: Sir, the people Must have their voices; neither will they bate One jot of ceremony.
trg: Put them not to't: Pray you, go fit you to the custom and Take to you, as your predecessors have, Your honour with your form.

src: If I know how or which way to order these affairs Thus thrust disorderly into my hands, Never believe me. Both are my kinsmen: The one is my sovereign, whom both my oath And duty bids defend;
trg: the other again Is my kinsman, whom the king hath wrong'd, Whom conscience and my kindred bids to right. Well, somewhat we must do. Come, cousin, I'll Dispose of you.

src: Where dwellest thou?
trg: Under the canopy.

src: First, know, my horse is tired; my master and mistress fallen out.
trg: How?

src: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.
trg: Come, Kate, we'll to bed. We three are married, but you two are sped. 'Twas I won the wager, though you hit the white; And, being a winner, God give you good night!

src: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham.
trg: Call them again, my lord, and accept their suit.

src: I am not bestraught: here's--
trg: O, this it is that makes your lady mourn!

src: Windy attorneys to their client woes, Airy succeeders of intestate joys, Poor breathing orators of miseries! Let them have scope: though what they do impart Help not all, yet do they ease the heart.
trg: If so, then be not tongue-tied: go with me. And in the breath of bitter words let's smother My damned son, which thy two sweet sons smother'd. I hear his drum: be copious in exclaims.

src: these shrugs, these hums and ha's, When you have said 'she's goodly,' come between Ere you can say 'she's honest:
trg: ' but be 't known, From him that has most cause to grieve it should be, She's an adulteress.

src: Cousin, stand forth, and look upon that man.
trg: My Lord Aumerle, I know your daring tongue Scorns to unsay what once it hath deliver'd.

src: so shall I do To the freshest things now reigning and make stale The glistering of this present, as my tale Now seems to it.
trg: Your patience this allowing, I turn my glass and give my scene such growing As you had slept between: and with speed so pace To speak of Perdita, now grown in grace Equal with wondering:

src: None rare, my lord.
trg: The king hath on him such a countenance As he had lost some province and a region Loved as he loves himself: even now I met him With customary compliment;

src: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.
trg: My voice is now the king's, my looks mine own.

src: That shall not be much amiss: Yet, as the matter now stands, he will avoid your accusation; he made trial of you only. Therefore fasten your ear on my advisings:
trg: to the love I have in doing good a remedy presents itself. I do make myself believe that you may most uprighteously do a poor wronged lady a merited benefit; redeem your brother from the angry law;

src: Well, I beseech you, let it be proclaimed betimes i' the morn; I'll call you at your house: give notice to such men of sort and suit as are to meet him.
trg: I shall, sir. Fare you well.

src: Let me stand here till thou remember it.
trg: I shall forget, to have thee still stand there, Remembering how I love thy company.

src: Good morrow, Richmond!
trg: Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen, That you have ta'en a tardy sluggard here.

src: Who told me, when we both lay in the field Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me Even in his own garments, and gave himself, All thin and naked, to the numb cold night?
trg: All this from my remembrance brutish wrath Sinfully pluck'd, and not a man of you Had so much grace to put it in my mind.

src: Do not believe it. Fewness and truth, 'tis thus: Your brother and his lover have embraced:
trg: As those that feed grow full, as blossoming time That from the seedness the bare fallow brings To teeming foison, even so her plenteous womb Expresseth his full tilth and husbandry.

src: What, marry, may she?
trg: What, marry, may she! marry with a king, A bachelor, a handsome stripling too: I wis your grandam had a worser match.

src: A proper stripling and an amorous!
trg: O, very well; I have perused the note. Hark you, sir: I'll have them very fairly bound: All books of love, see that at any hand; And see you read no other lectures to her: You understand me:

src: more validity, More honourable state, more courtship lives In carrion-flies than Romeo:
trg: they my seize On the white wonder of dear Juliet's hand And steal immortal blessing from her lips, Who even in pure and vestal modesty, Still blush, as thinking their own kisses sin;

src: I have used thee, Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged thee In mine own cell, till thou didst seek to violate The honour of my child.
trg: O ho, O ho! would't had been done! Thou didst prevent me; I had peopled else This isle with Calibans.

src: Well, my dread lord; so must I call you now.
trg: Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours: Too late he died that might have kept that title, Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

src: No,'tis his kind of speech: he did not mock us.
trg: Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says He used us scornfully: he should have show'd us His marks of merit, wounds received for's country.

src: God's bread! it makes me mad: Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play, Alone, in company, still my care hath been To have her match'd:
trg: and having now provided A gentleman of noble parentage, Of fair demesnes, youthful, and nobly train'd, Stuff'd, as they say, with honourable parts, Proportion'd as one's thought would wish a man;

src: It becomes thy oath full well, Thou to me thy secrets tell.
trg: Me too, let me go thither.

src: As wicked dew as e'er my mother brush'd With raven's feather from unwholesome fen Drop on you both! a south-west blow on ye And blister you all o'er!
trg: For this, be sure, to-night thou shalt have cramps, Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up; urchins Shall, for that vast of night that they may work, All exercise on thee;

src: Boldly, at least. But, O, poor souls, Come you to seek the lamb here of the fox? Good night to your redress! Is the duke gone? Then is your cause gone too.
trg: The duke's unjust, Thus to retort your manifest appeal, And put your trial in the villain's mouth Which here you come to accuse.

src: Before the times of change, still is it so: By a divine instinct men's minds mistrust Ensuing dangers; as by proof, we see The waters swell before a boisterous storm. But leave it all to God.
trg: whither away?

src: But what a fool am I to chat with you, When I should bid good morrow to my bride, And seal the title with a lovely kiss!
trg: He hath some meaning in his mad attire: We will persuade him, be it possible, To put on better ere he go to church.

src: some call him Autolycus.
trg: Out upon him! prig, for my life, prig: he haunts wakes, fairs and bear-baitings.

src: Be quiet, or--More light, more light! For shame! I'll make you quiet. What, cheerly, my hearts!
trg: Patience perforce with wilful choler meeting Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting. I will withdraw: but this intrusion shall Now seeming sweet convert to bitter gall.

src: How should this grow?
trg: I know not: but I am sure 'tis safer to Avoid what's grown than question how 'tis born.

src: What a merit were it in death to take this poor maid from the world! What corruption in this life, that it will let this man live! But how out of this can she avail?
trg: It is a rupture that you may easily heal: and the cure of it not only saves your brother, but keeps you from dishonour in doing it.

src: Widow! a pox o' that! How came that widow in? widow Dido!
trg: What if he had said 'widower AEneas' too? Good Lord, how you take it!

src: ' quoth he, as if He had been aboard, carousing to his mates After a storm; quaff'd off the muscadel And threw the sops all in the sexton's face;
trg: Having no other reason But that his beard grew thin and hungerly And seem'd to ask him sops as he was drinking.

src: He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester town; Whither, if it please you, we may now withdraw us.
trg: What men of name are slain on either side?

src: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse Abides in me; I say amen to all.
trg: Stay, madam; I must speak a word with you.

src: God's wrong is most of all. If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him, The unity the king thy brother made Had not been broken, nor my brother slain: What canst thou swear by now?
trg: The time to come.

src: Vices, I would say, sir. I know this man well: he hath been since an ape-bearer; then a process-server, a bailiff;
trg: then he compassed a motion of the Prodigal Son, and married a tinker's wife within a mile where my land and living lies; and, having flown over many knavish professions, he settled only in rogue:

src: Why, Belman is as good as he, my lord; He cried upon it at the merest loss And twice to-day pick'd out the dullest scent: Trust me, I take him for the better dog.
trg: Thou art a fool: if Echo were as fleet, I would esteem him worth a dozen such. But sup them well and look unto them all: To-morrow I intend to hunt again.

src: Am I a lord? and have I such a lady? Or do I dream? or have I dream'd till now? I do not sleep: I see, I hear, I speak; I smell sweet savours and I feel soft things:
trg: Upon my life, I am a lord indeed And not a tinker nor Christophero Sly. Well, bring our lady hither to our sight; And once again, a pot o' the smallest ale.

src: What, not a word? Nay, then thou lovest it not; And all my pains is sorted to no proof. Here, take away this dish.
trg: I pray you, let it stand.

src: I know not whether to depart in silence, Or bitterly to speak in your reproof. If to reprove you for this suit of yours, So season'd with your faithful love to me.
trg: Then, on the other side, I cheque'd my friends. Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first, And then, in speaking, not to incur the last, Definitively thus I answer you.

src: Nay, then, Do what thou canst, I will not go to-day; No, nor to-morrow, not till I please myself. The door is open, sir; there lies your way; You may be jogging whiles your boots are green;
trg: For me, I'll not be gone till I please myself: 'Tis like you'll prove a jolly surly groom, That take it on you at the first so roundly.

src: The smallest worm will turn being trodden on, And doves will peck in safeguard of their brood. Ambitious York doth level at thy crown, Thou smiling while he knit his angry brows:
trg: He, but a duke, would have his son a king, And raise his issue, like a loving sire;

src: What became of his bark and his followers?
trg: Wrecked the same instant of their master's death and in the view of the shepherd: so that all the instruments which aided to expose the child were even then lost when it was found.

src: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.
trg: Art thou, indeed?

src: From your own mouth, my lord, did I this deed.
trg: They love not poison that do poison need, Nor do I thee: though I did wish him dead, I hate the murderer, love him murdered.

src: if it confess A natural guiltiness such as is his, Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue Against my brother's life.
Prove it before these varlets here, thou honourable man; prove it.
trg: Do you hear how he misplaces?

src: and let them go To ear the land that hath some hope to grow, For I have none: let no man speak again To alter this, for counsel is but vain.
trg: My liege, one word.

src: Fie, sirrah! a bawd, a wicked bawd! The evil that thou causest to be done, That is thy means to live. Do thou but think What 'tis to cram a maw or clothe a back From such a filthy vice:
trg: say to thyself, From their abominable and beastly touches I drink, I eat, array myself, and live. Canst thou believe thy living is a life, So stinkingly depending? Go mend, go mend.

src: I say, a husband.
trg: I say, a devil. Thinkest thou, Hortensio, though her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be married to hell?

src: Yet 'banished'? Hang up philosophy! Unless philosophy can make a Juliet, Displant a town, reverse a prince's doom, It helps not, it prevails not: talk no more.
trg: O, then I see that madmen have no ears.

src: I am too old to fawn upon a nurse, Too far in years to be a pupil now: What is thy sentence then but speechless death, Which robs my tongue from breathing native breath?
trg: It boots thee not to be compassionate: After our sentence plaining comes too late.

src: I had rather chop this hand off at a blow, And with the other fling it at thy face, Than bear so low a sail, to strike to thee.
Hold you there: farewell. Provost, a word with you!
trg: What's your will, father

src: Now blessed be the great Apollo!
trg: Praised!

src: Nay, but hear me.
trg: Nay, but hear me.

src: This will last out a night in Russia, When nights are longest there: I'll take my leave. And leave you to the hearing of the cause; Hoping you'll find good cause to whip them all.
trg: I think no less. Good morrow to your lordship. Now, sir, come on: what was done to Elbow's wife, once more?

src: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio. Welcome, good Cambio. But, gentle sir, methinks you walk like a stranger: may I be so bold to know the cause of your coming?
trg: Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own, That, being a stranger in this city here, Do make myself a suitor to your daughter, Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous.

src: Dishonourable boy! That lie shall lie so heavy on my sword, That it shall render vengeance and revenge Till thou the lie-giver and that lie do lie In earth as quiet as thy father's skull:
trg: In proof whereof, there is my honour's pawn; Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.

src: There is another friar that set them on; Let him be sent for.
trg: Would he were here, my lord! for he indeed Hath set the women on to this complaint: Your provost knows the place where he abides And he may fetch him.

src: But new struck nine.
trg: Ay me! sad hours seem long. Was that my father that went hence so fast?

src: One three of them, by their own report, sir, hath danced before the king; and not the worst of the three but jumps twelve foot and a half by the squier.
trg: Leave your prating: since these good men are pleased, let them come in; but quickly now.

src: Give you good morrow, sir.
trg: Doth this news hold of good King Edward's death?

src: In thy foul throat thou liest: Queen Margaret saw Thy murderous falchion smoking in his blood; The which thou once didst bend against her breast, But that thy brothers beat aside the point.
trg: I was provoked by her slanderous tongue, which laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.

src: But are they, Ariel, safe?
trg: Not a hair perish'd; On their sustaining garments not a blemish, But fresher than before: and, as thou badest me, In troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle.

src: but security enough to make fellowships accurst: much upon this riddle runs the wisdom of the world. This news is old enough, yet it is every day's news.
trg: I pray you, sir, of what disposition was the duke?

src: O, teach me how I should forget to think.
trg: By giving liberty unto thine eyes; Examine other beauties.

src: Here is a friar, that trembles, sighs and weeps: We took this mattock and this spade from him, As he was coming from this churchyard side.
trg: A great suspicion: stay the friar too.

src: Why do you look on us, and shake your head, And call us wretches, orphans, castaways If that our noble father be alive?
trg: My pretty cousins, you mistake me much; I do lament the sickness of the king. As loath to lose him, not your father's death; It were lost sorrow to wail one that's lost.

src: O, she doth teach the torches to burn bright! It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope's ear; Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear!
trg: So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows, As yonder lady o'er her fellows shows. The measure done, I'll watch her place of stand, And, touching hers, make blessed my rude hand.

src: stand, and you be a man: For Juliet's sake, for her sake, rise and stand; Why should you fall into so deep an O?
trg: Nurse!

src: Monday, my lord,
trg: Monday! ha, ha! Well, Wednesday is too soon, O' Thursday let it be: o' Thursday, tell her, She shall be married to this noble earl. Will you be ready? do you like this haste?

src: Howlings attend it: how hast thou the heart, Being a divine, a ghostly confessor, A sin-absolver, and my friend profess'd, To mangle me with that word 'banished'?
trg: Thou fond mad man, hear me but speak a word.

src: Well, if you be a king crown'd with content, Your crown content and you must be contented To go along with us; for as we think, You are the king King Edward hath deposed;
trg: And we his subjects sworn in all allegiance Will apprehend you as his enemy.

src: nay, sometimes, Like to a bowl upon a subtle ground, I have tumbled past the throw; and in his praise Have almost stamp'd the leasing: therefore, fellow, I must have leave to pass.
trg: Faith, sir, if you had told as many lies in his behalf as you have uttered words in your own, you should not pass here; no, though it were as virtuous to lie as to live chastely. Therefore, go back.

src: Almost at point to enter.
trg: We will meet them, And help the joy.

src: Holy Franciscan friar! brother, ho!
trg: This same should be the voice of Friar John. Welcome from Mantua: what says Romeo? Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.

src: His noble kinsman: most degenerate king! But, lords, we hear this fearful tempest sing, Yet see no shelter to avoid the storm;
trg: We see the wind sit sore upon our sails, And yet we strike not, but securely perish.

src: Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask.
trg: Why, then I will do what your grace commands.

src: Well, there went but a pair of shears between us.
trg: I grant; as there may between the lists and the velvet. Thou art the list.

src: My business is a word or two with Claudio.
trg: And very welcome. Look, signior, here's your sister.

src: On fair ground I could beat forty of them.
trg: I could myself Take up a brace o' the best of them; yea, the two tribunes: But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic; And manhood is call'd foolery, when it stands Against a falling fabric.

src: Resolved. resolved.
trg: First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.

src: My horse to yours, no.
trg: 'Tis done.

src: At my depart, these were his very words: 'Go tell false Edward, thy supposed king, That Lewis of France is sending over masquers To revel it with him and his new bride.'
trg: Is Lewis so brave? belike he thinks me Henry. But what said Lady Bona to my marriage?

src: This battle fares like to the morning's war, When dying clouds contend with growing light, What time the shepherd, blowing of his nails, Can neither call it perfect day nor night.
trg: Now sways it this way, like a mighty sea Forced by the tide to combat with the wind; Now sways it that way, like the selfsame sea Forced to retire by fury of the wind:

src: Away with those giglots too, and with the other confederate companion!
Look, and thou shalt see.
trg: O thou untaught! what manners is in this? To press before thy father to a grave?

src: That's he indeed.
trg: You were not bid to speak.

src: For this, consorted with the citizens, Your very worshipful and loving friends, And by their vehement instigation, In this just suit come I to move your grace.
trg: I know not whether to depart in silence, Or bitterly to speak in your reproof. If to reprove you for this suit of yours, So season'd with your faithful love to me.

src: No, no; no man saw 'em.
trg: He said he had wounds, which he could show in private; And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn, 'I would be consul,' says he: 'aged custom, But by your voices, will not so permit me;

src: And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.
trg: Look not pale, Bianca; thy father will not frown.

src: The former agents, if they did complain, What could the belly answer?
trg: I will tell you If you'll bestow a small--of what you have little-- Patience awhile, you'll hear the belly's answer.

src: We were not born to sue, but to command; Which since we cannot do to make you friends, Be ready, as your lives shall answer it, At Coventry, upon Saint Lambert's day:
trg: There shall your swords and lances arbitrate The swelling difference of your settled hate: Since we can not atone you, we shall see Justice design the victor's chivalry.

src: When I return with victory from the field I'll see your grace: till then I'll follow her.
trg: Come, son, away; we may not linger thus.

src: the accusation Which they have often made against the senate, All cause unborn, could never be the motive Of our so frank donation. Well, what then?
trg: How shall this bisson multitude digest The senate's courtesy? Let deeds express What's like to be their words: 'we did request it; We are the greater poll, and in true fear They gave us our demands.

src: Know you this woman?
trg: Carnally, she says.

src: I should have been more strange, I must confess, But that thou overheard'st, ere I was ware, My true love's passion:
trg: therefore pardon me, And not impute this yielding to light love, Which the dark night hath so discovered.

src: You have received many wounds for your country.
trg: I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no further.

src: O, let me pray before I take my death! To thee I pray; sweet Clifford, pity me!
trg: Such pity as my rapier's point affords.

src: It was commanded so.
trg: Had you a special warrant for the deed?

src: You do the nobler.
trg: I talk of you: Why did you wish me milder? would you have me False to my nature? Rather say I play The man I am.

src: I think he is: but a greater soldier than he you wot on.
trg: Who, my master?

src: And so farewell, Signior Lucentio. Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks, Shall win my love: and so I take my leave, In resolution as I swore before.
trg: Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace As 'longeth to a lover's blessed case! Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love, And have forsworn you with Hortensio.

src: But, in the midst of this bright-shining day, I spy a black, suspicious, threatening cloud, That will encounter with our glorious sun, Ere he attain his easeful western bed:
trg: I mean, my lords, those powers that the queen Hath raised in Gallia have arrived our coast And, as we hear, march on to fight with us.

src: Thus, what with the war, what with the sweat, what with the gallows and what with poverty, I am custom-shrunk. How now! what's the news with you?
trg: Yonder man is carried to prison.

src: Away!
trg: Away! get you away.

src: One heaved a-high, to be hurl'd down below; A mother only mock'd with two sweet babes;
trg: A dream of what thou wert, a breath, a bubble, A sign of dignity, a garish flag, To be the aim of every dangerous shot, A queen in jest, only to fill the scene. Where is thy husband now?

src: Even so; an't please your worship, Brakenbury, You may partake of any thing we say: We speak no treason, man:
trg: we say the king Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous;

src: My queen and son are gone to France for aid; And, as I hear, the great commanding Warwick Is thither gone, to crave the French king's sister To wife for Edward:
trg: if this news be true, Poor queen and son, your labour is but lost; For Warwick is a subtle orator, And Lewis a prince soon won with moving words. By this account then Margaret may win him;

src: Sent by the king your father To greet him and to give him comforts.
trg: Sir, The manner of your bearing towards him, with What you as from your father shall deliver, Things known betwixt us three, I'll write you down:

src: Ah, gentle Clifford, kill me with thy sword, And not with such a cruel threatening look. Sweet Clifford, hear me speak before I die. I am too mean a subject for thy wrath:
trg: Be thou revenged on men, and let me live.

src: At the good queen's entreaty.
trg: At the queen's be't: 'good' should be pertinent But, so it is, it is not. Was this taken By any understanding pate but thine? For thy conceit is soaking, will draw in More than the common blocks:

src: The harder match'd, the greater victory: My mind presageth happy gain and conquest.
trg: Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster!

src: Jesu, what haste? can you not stay awhile? Do you not see that I am out of breath?
trg: How art thou out of breath, when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath? The excuse that thou dost make in this delay Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.

src: Prove it, Henry, and thou shalt be king.
trg: Henry the Fourth by conquest got the crown.

src: they were warmer that got this than the poor thing is here. I'll take it up for pity: yet I'll tarry till my son come; he hallooed but even now. Whoa, ho, hoa!
trg: Hilloa, loa!

src: I sometime lay here in Corioli At a poor man's house; he used me kindly: He cried to me; I saw him prisoner; But then Aufidius was within my view, And wrath o'erwhelm'd my pity:
trg: I request you To give my poor host freedom.

src: From whence shall Warwick cut the sea to France, And ask the Lady Bona for thy queen: So shalt thou sinew both these lands together;
trg: And, having France thy friend, thou shalt not dread The scatter'd foe that hopes to rise again; For though they cannot greatly sting to hurt, Yet look to have them buzz to offend thine ears.

src: And with him are the Lord Aumerle, Lord Salisbury, Sir Stephen Scroop, besides a clergyman Of holy reverence; who, I cannot learn.
trg: O, belike it is the Bishop of Carlisle.

src: For God he knows, and you may partly see, How far I am from the desire thereof.
trg: God bless your grace! we see it, and will say it.

src: Methought the souls of all that I had murder'd Came to my tent; and every one did threat To-morrow's vengeance on the head of Richard.
trg: My lord!

src: I told you what would come of this: beseech you, Of your own state take care: this dream of mine,-- Being now awake, I'll queen it no inch farther, But milk my ewes and weep.
trg: Why, how now, father! Speak ere thou diest.

src: How long hath he been there?
trg: Full half an hour.

src: Pray, good shepherd, what fair swain is this Which dances with your daughter?
trg: They call him Doricles; and boasts himself To have a worthy feeding: but I have it Upon his own report and I believe it; He looks like sooth. He says he loves my daughter: I think so too;

src: and the words that follow'd Should be 'Remember mine.'
trg: Stars, stars, And all eyes else dead coals! Fear thou no wife; I'll have no wife, Paulina.

src: How now, fair lords! What fare? what news abroad?
trg: Great Lord of Warwick, if we should recount Our baleful news, and at each word's deliverance Stab poniards in our flesh till all were told, The words would add more anguish than the wounds.

src: That hearing how our plaints and prayers do pierce, Pity may move thee 'pardon' to rehearse.
trg: Good aunt, stand up.

src: Why, a horse.
trg: Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crossed me, thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell and she under her horse;

src: Beshrew your heart for sending me about, To catch my death with jaunting up and down!
trg: I' faith, I am sorry that thou art not well. Sweet, sweet, sweet nurse, tell me, what says my love?

src: Come on; obey: Thy nerves are in their infancy again And have no vigour in them.
trg: So they are; My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.

src: Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord, That would reduce these bloody days again, And make poor England weep in streams of blood!
trg: Let them not live to taste this land's increase That would with treason wound this fair land's peace! Now civil wounds are stopp'd, peace lives again: That she may long live here, God say amen!

src: For my poor self, I am combined by a sacred vow And shall be absent. Wend you with this letter: Command these fretting waters from your eyes With a light heart;
trg: trust not my holy order, If I pervert your course. Who's here?

src: And there I stood amazed for a while, As on a pillory, looking through the lute; While she did call me rascal fiddler And twangling Jack;
trg: with twenty such vile terms, As had she studied to misuse me so.

src: And men ne'er spend their fury on a child. What's worse than murderer, that I may name it? No, no, my heart will burst, and if I speak: And I will speak, that so my heart may burst.
trg: Butchers and villains! bloody cannibals! How sweet a plant have you untimely cropp'd! You have no children, butchers! if you had, The thought of them would have stirr'd up remorse:

src: To tell thee whence thou camest, of whom derived, Were shame enough to shame thee, wert thou not shameless.
trg: Thy father bears the type of King of Naples, Of both the Sicils and Jerusalem, Yet not so wealthy as an English yeoman. Hath that poor monarch taught thee to insult?

src: Dear, look up: Though Fortune, visible an enemy, Should chase us with my father, power no jot Hath she to change our loves. Beseech you, sir, Remember since you owed no more to time Than I do now:
trg: with thought of such affections, Step forth mine advocate; at your request My father will grant precious things as trifles.

src: What a strange drowsiness possesses them!
trg: It is the quality o' the climate.

src: Trembled and shook; for why, he stamp'd and swore, As if the vicar meant to cozen him. But after many ceremonies done, He calls for wine: 'A health!
trg: ' quoth he, as if He had been aboard, carousing to his mates After a storm; quaff'd off the muscadel And threw the sops all in the sexton's face;

src: Your highness told me I should post before.
trg: My mind is changed, sir, my mind is changed. How now, what news with you?

src: Adoptedly; as school-maids change their names By vain though apt affection.
trg: She it is.

src: which if you seek to prove, I dare not stand by; nor shall you be safer Than one condemn'd by the king's own mouth, thereon His execution sworn.
trg: I do believe thee: I saw his heart in 's face. Give me thy hand: Be pilot to me and thy places shall Still neighbour mine. My ships are ready and My people did expect my hence departure Two days ago.

src: How doth my dear morsel, thy mistress? Procures she still, ha?
trg: Troth, sir, she hath eaten up all her beef, and she is herself in the tub.

src: which he is, even till the altitude of his virtue.
trg: What he cannot help in his nature, you account a vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.

src: And were the king on't, what would I do?
trg: 'Scape being drunk for want of wine.

src: Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy? Ah, my sour husband, my hard-hearted lord, That set'st the word itself against the word! Speak 'pardon' as 'tis current in our land;
trg: The chopping French we do not understand. Thine eye begins to speak; set thy tongue there; Or in thy piteous heart plant thou thine ear;

src: then straight his doubled spirit Re-quicken'd what in flesh was fatigate, And to the battle came he; where he did Run reeking o'er the lives of men, as if 'Twere a perpetual spoil:
trg: and till we call'd Both field and city ours, he never stood To ease his breast with panting.

src: So did he me: and he no more remembers his mother now than an eight-year-old horse. The tartness of his face sours ripe grapes:
trg: when he walks, he moves like an engine, and the ground shrinks before his treading: he is able to pierce a corslet with his eye; talks like a knell, and his hum is a battery.

src: Oh, he is young and his minority Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester, A man that loves not me, nor none of you.
trg: Is it concluded that he shall be protector?

src: But first I'll turn yon fellow in his grave; And then return lamenting to my love. Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass, That I may see my shadow as I pass.
trg: Have patience, madam: there's no doubt his majesty Will soon recover his accustom'd health.

src: Well, well, no more.
trg: What is the matter That being pass'd for consul with full voice, I am so dishonour'd that the very hour You take it off again?

src: A strange one as ever I looked on: I cannot get him out of the house: prithee, call my master to him.
trg: What have you to do here, fellow? Pray you, avoid the house.

src: Content, content.
trg: O sir, you are not right: have you not known The worthiest men have done't?

src: Good-morrow, cousin.
trg: Is the day so young?

src: What holier than, for royalty's repair, For present comfort and for future good, To bless the bed of majesty again With a sweet fellow to't?
trg: There is none worthy, Respecting her that's gone. Besides, the gods Will have fulfill'd their secret purposes;

src: Who can be patient in such extremes? Ah, wretched man!
trg: would I had died a maid And never seen thee, never borne thee son, Seeing thou hast proved so unnatural a father Hath he deserved to lose his birthright thus?

src: Nay, hear you, Kate: in sooth you scape not so.
trg: I chafe you, if I tarry: let me go.

src: and 'tis powerful, think it, From east, west, north and south: be it concluded, No barricado for a belly; know't; It will let in and out the enemy With bag and baggage:
trg: many thousand on's Have the disease, and feel't not. How now, boy!

src: 'Tis, marvel, but that you are but newly come, You might have heard it else proclaim'd about.
trg: Alas! sir, it is worse for me than so; For I have bills for money by exchange From Florence and must here deliver them.

src: My liege, I'll knock once more to summon them.
trg: My lords, we were forewarned of your coming, And shut the gates for safety of ourselves; For now we owe allegiance unto Henry.

src: Minion, thou liest. Is't not Hortensio?
trg: If you affect him, sister, here I swear I'll plead for you myself, but you shall have him.

src: Go bear this lance to Thomas, Duke of Norfolk.
trg: And dares him to set forward to the fight.

src: I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible That love should of a sudden take such hold?
trg: O Tranio, till I found it to be true, I never thought it possible or likely; But see, while idly I stood looking on, I found the effect of love in idleness:

src: The better for him: would I were so too!
trg: So could I, faith, boy, to have the next wish after, That Lucentio indeed had Baptista's youngest daughter.

src: Richard yet lives, hell's black intelligencer, Only reserved their factor, to buy souls And send them thither: but at hand, at hand, Ensues his piteous and unpitied end:
trg: Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray. To have him suddenly convey'd away. Cancel his bond of life, dear God, I prey, That I may live to say, The dog is dead!

src: lilies of all kinds, The flower-de-luce being one! O, these I lack, To make you garlands of, and my sweet friend, To strew him o'er and o'er!
trg: What, like a corse?

src: The noble duke hath sworn his coming is But for his own; and for the right of that We all have strongly sworn to give him aid; And let him ne'er see joy that breaks that oath!
trg: Well, well, I see the issue of these arms: I cannot mend it, I must needs confess, Because my power is weak and all ill left:

src: But 'twas ere I was born. Thou hast one son; for his sake pity me, Lest in revenge thereof, sith God is just, He be as miserably slain as I. Ah, let me live in prison all my days;
trg: And when I give occasion of offence, Then let me die, for now thou hast no cause.

src: Is it true, think you?
trg: Very true, and but a month old.

src: Pardon me, Margaret; pardon me, sweet son: The Earl of Warwick and the duke enforced me.
trg: Enforced thee! art thou king, and wilt be forced? I shame to hear thee speak. Ah, timorous wretch! Thou hast undone thyself, thy son and me;

src: What then! He'ld make an end of thy posterity.
trg: Bastards and all. Good man, the wounds that he does bear for Rome!

src: Nay, never bear me hence, dispatch me here, Here sheathe thy sword, I'll pardon thee my death: What, wilt thou not? then, Clarence, do it thou.
trg: By heaven, I will not do thee so much ease.

src: the more I give to thee, The more I have, for both are infinite. I hear some noise within; dear love, adieu! Anon, good nurse! Sweet Montague, be true. Stay but a little, I will come again.
trg: O blessed, blessed night! I am afeard. Being in night, all this is but a dream, Too flattering-sweet to be substantial.

src: On, good Camillo.
trg: I am appointed him to murder you.

src: Hearest thou, Biondello?
trg: I cannot tarry: I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit; and so may you, sir: and so, adieu, sir.

src: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to unfold.
trg: How fares the prince?

src: In brief,--for so the season bids us be,-- Prepare thy battle early in the morning, And put thy fortune to the arbitrement Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.
trg: I, as I may--that which I would I cannot,-- With best advantage will deceive the time, And aid thee in this doubtful shock of arms:

src: Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops. I must be gone and live, or stay and die.
trg: Yon light is not day-light, I know it, I: It is some meteor that the sun exhales, To be to thee this night a torch-bearer, And light thee on thy way to Mantua: Therefore stay yet;

src: Death lies on her like an untimely frost Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.
trg: O lamentable day!

src: A woman, and thy aunt, great king; 'tis I. Speak with me, pity me, open the door. A beggar begs that never begg'd before.
trg: Our scene is alter'd from a serious thing, And now changed to 'The Beggar and the King.' My dangerous cousin, let your mother in: I know she is come to pray for your foul sin.

src: A thousand welcomes! And more a friend than e'er an enemy; Yet, Marcius, that was much. Your hand: most welcome!
trg: Here's a strange alteration!

src: That Angelo is an adulterous thief, An hypocrite, a virgin-violator; Is it not strange and strange?
trg: Nay, it is ten times strange.

src: Ah, Exeter!
trg: Why should you sigh, my lord?

src: Now by my soul, I would it were this hour.
trg: Fitzwater, thou art damn'd to hell for this.

src: ' and each in either side Give the all-hail to thee and cry 'Be blest For making up this peace! Whose chronicle thus writ: 'The man was noble, But with his last attempt he wiped it out;
trg: Destroy'd his country, and his name remains To the ensuing age abhorr'd.' Speak to me, son: Thou hast affected the fine strains of honour, To imitate the graces of the gods;

src: If non to bless us and the land withal, Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry From the corruption of abusing times, Unto a lineal true-derived course.
trg: Do, good my lord, your citizens entreat you.

src: whence come you? what's your will?
I, Daedalus; my poor boy, Icarus; Thy father, Minos, that denied our course;
trg: The sun that sear'd the wings of my sweet boy Thy brother Edward, and thyself the sea Whose envious gulf did swallow up his life. Ah, kill me with thy weapon, not with words!

src: And stay, good nurse, behind the abbey wall: Within this hour my man shall be with thee And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair;
trg: Which to the high top-gallant of my joy Must be my convoy in the secret night. Farewell; be trusty, and I'll quit thy pains: Farewell; commend me to thy mistress.

src: Beseech you, father.
trg: Hence! hang not on my garments.

src: over and beside Signior Baptista's liberality, I'll mend it with a largess. Take your paper too, And let me have them very well perfumed For she is sweeter than perfume itself To whom they go to.
trg: What will you read to her?

src: How now, my masters! have you chose this man?
trg: He has our voices, sir.

src: and how doth she? and what says My conceal'd lady to our cancell'd love?
trg: O, she says nothing, sir, but weeps and weeps; And now falls on her bed; and then starts up, And Tybalt calls; and then on Romeo cries, And then down falls again.

src: It then remains That you do speak to the people.
trg: I do beseech you, Let me o'erleap that custom, for I cannot Put on the gown, stand naked and entreat them, For my wounds' sake, to give their suffrage: please you That I may pass this doing.

src: Sons, peace!
trg: Peace, thou! and give King Henry leave to speak.

src: It may be I will go with you: but yet I'll pause; For I am loath to break our country's laws. Nor friends nor foes, to me welcome you are: Things past redress are now with me past care.
trg: My lord of Salisbury, we have stay'd ten days, And hardly kept our countrymen together, And yet we hear no tidings from the king; Therefore we will disperse ourselves: farewell.

src: Belike she minds to play the Amazon. But what said Warwick to these injuries?
trg: He, more incensed against your majesty Than all the rest, discharged me with these words: 'Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong, And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long.'

src: So deal with him as I prove true to you.
trg: My liege, in Kent the Guildfords are in arms; And every hour more competitors Flock to their aid, and still their power increaseth.

src: the kitchen malkin pins Her richest lockram 'bout her reechy neck, Clambering the walls to eye him:
trg: stalls, bulks, windows, Are smother'd up, leads fill'd, and ridges horsed With variable complexions, all agreeing In earnestness to see him:

src: We can both sing it: if thou'lt bear a part, thou shalt hear; 'tis in three parts.
trg: We had the tune on't a month ago.

src: The pox of such antic, lisping, affecting fantasticoes; these new tuners of accents! 'By Jesu, a very good blade! a very tall man! a very good whore! O, their bones, their bones!
trg: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.

src: Arise, dissembler: though I wish thy death, I will not be the executioner.
trg: Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.

src: I play the torturer, by small and small To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken:
trg: Your uncle York is join'd with Bolingbroke, And all your northern castles yielded up, And all your southern gentlemen in arms Upon his party.

src: so, fellest foes, Whose passions and whose plots have broke their sleep, To take the one the other, by some chance, Some trick not worth an egg, shall grow dear friends And interjoin their issues.
trg: So with me: My birth-place hate I, and my love's upon This enemy town. I'll enter: if he slay me, He does fair justice; if he give me way, I'll do his country service.

src: We charge you, in God's name, and the king's, To go with us unto the officers.
trg: In God's name, lead; your king's name be obey'd: And what God will, that let your king perform; And what he will, I humbly yield unto. 3 KING HENRY VI
