src: No, as I am a man.
trg: There's nothing ill can dwell in such a temple: If the ill spirit have so fair a house, Good things will strive to dwell with't.

src: Why, you are nothing then: neither maid, widow, nor wife?
trg: My lord, she may be a punk; for many of them are neither maid, widow, nor wife.

src: As dissolute as desperate; yet through both I see some sparks of better hope, which elder years May happily bring forth. But who comes here?
trg: Where is the king?

src: That is, were I under the terms of death, The impression of keen whips I'ld wear as rubies, And strip myself to death, as to a bed That longing have been sick for, ere I'ld yield My body up to shame.
trg: Then must your brother die.

src: Thanks, noble peer; The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear. What art thou? and how comest thou hither, Where no man never comes but that sad dog That brings me food to make misfortune live?
trg: I was a poor groom of thy stable, king, When thou wert king; who, travelling towards York, With much ado at length have gotten leave To look upon my sometimes royal master's face.

src: Son, I have overheard what hath passed between you and your sister. Angelo had never the purpose to corrupt her;
trg: only he hath made an essay of her virtue to practise his judgment with the disposition of natures:

src: I do not like the Tower, of any place. Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?
trg: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place; Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.

src: But I can give thee more: For I will raise her statue in pure gold; That while Verona by that name is known, There shall no figure at such rate be set As that of true and faithful Juliet.
trg: As rich shall Romeo's by his lady's lie; Poor sacrifices of our enmity!

src: No, good-faced sir; no, sweet sir.
trg: Then fare thee well: I must go buy spices for our sheep-shearing.

src: Up with my tent there! here will I lie tonight; But where to-morrow?  Well, all's one for that. Who hath descried the number of the foe?
trg: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.

src: The sense of death is most in apprehension; And the poor beetle, that we tread upon, In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great As when a giant dies.
trg: Why give you me this shame? Think you I can a resolution fetch From flowery tenderness? If I must die, I will encounter darkness as a bride, And hug it in mine arms.

src: What, are they dead?
trg: They are; and Bolingbroke Hath seized the wasteful king. O, what pity is it That he had not so trimm'd and dress'd his land As we this garden!

src: Of that there's none, or little.
trg: How lush and lusty the grass looks! how green!

src: If I fly, Marcius, Holloa me like a hare.
trg: Within these three hours, Tullus, Alone I fought in your Corioli walls, And made what work I pleased: 'tis not my blood Wherein thou seest me mask'd;

src: Son, I'll be your half, Bianca comes.
trg: I'll have no halves; I'll bear it all myself. How now! what news?

src: Good my lord, be good to me; your honour is accounted a merciful man; good my lord.
trg: Double and treble admonition, and still forfeit in the same kind! This would make mercy swear and play the tyrant.

src: Sirrah, no more!
trg: Enough, my lord.

src: When must he die?
trg: As I do think, to-morrow. I have provided for you: stay awhile, And you shall be conducted.

src: He misses not much.
trg: No; he doth but mistake the truth totally.

src: Whither?
trg: To supper; to our house.

src: Now, by my maidenhead, at twelve year old, I bade her come. What, lamb! what, ladybird! God forbid! Where's this girl? What, Juliet!
trg: How now! who calls?

src: reflect I not on thy baseness court-contempt? Thinkest thou, for that I insinuate, or toaze from thee thy business, I am therefore no courtier? I am courtier cap-a-pe;
trg: and one that will either push on or pluck back thy business there: whereupon I command thee to open thy affair.

src: Ay, as the rocks cheer them that fear their wreck: To see this sight, it irks my very soul. Withhold revenge, dear God! 'tis not my fault, Nor wittingly have I infringed my vow.
trg: My gracious liege, this too much lenity And harmful pity must be laid aside. To whom do lions cast their gentle looks? Not to the beast that would usurp their den.

src: The sun will not be seen to-day; The sky doth frown and lour upon our army. I would these dewy tears were from the ground. Not shine to-day! Why, what is that to me More than to Richmond?
trg: for the selfsame heaven That frowns on me looks sadly upon him.

src: Fare you well. He has it now, and by his looks methink 'Tis warm at 's heart.
trg: With a proud heart he wore his humble weeds. will you dismiss the people?

src: but they are most of them means and bases; but one puritan amongst them, and he sings psalms to horn-pipes. I must have saffron to colour the warden pies; mace; dates?--none, that's out of my note;
trg: nutmegs, seven; a race or two of ginger, but that I may beg; four pound of prunes, and as many of raisins o' the sun.

src: who in a cheap estimation, is worth predecessors since Deucalion, though peradventure some of the best of 'em were hereditary hangmen. God-den to your worships:
trg: more of your conversation would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians: I will be bold to take my leave of you.

src: God keep you from them, and from such false friends!
trg: God keep me from false friends! but they were none.

src: Go, trumpet, to the walls, and sound a parle.
trg: See how the surly Warwick mans the wall!

src: Do you not hear him? You mar our labour: keep your cabins: you do assist the storm.
trg: Nay, good, be patient.

src: Be it forbid, my lord!
trg: To bide upon't, thou art not honest, or, If thou inclinest that way, thou art a coward, Which hoxes honesty behind, restraining From course required;

src: And be a happy mother by the deed.
trg: I go. Write to me very shortly. And you shall understand from me her mind.

src: Yet, Warwick, in despite of all mischance, Of thee thyself and all thy complices, Edward will always bear himself as king:
trg: Though fortune's malice overthrow my state, My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.

src: A dollar.
trg: Dolour comes to him, indeed: you have spoken truer than you purposed.

src: Her father is Baptista Minola, An affable and courteous gentleman: Her name is Katharina Minola, Renown'd in Padua for her scolding tongue.
trg: I know her father, though I know not her; And he knew my deceased father well. I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her;

src: So minutes, hours, days, months, and years, Pass'd over to the end they were created, Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave. Ah, what a life were this! how sweet! how lovely!
trg: Gives not the hawthorn-bush a sweeter shade To shepherds looking on their silly sheep, Than doth a rich embroider'd canopy To kings that fear their subjects' treachery? O, yes, it doth;

src: And you will rather show our general louts How you can frown than spend a fawn upon 'em, For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard Of what that want might ruin.
trg: Noble lady! Come, go with us; speak fair: you may salve so, Not what is dangerous present, but the loss Of what is past.

src: Sad-hearted men, much overgone with care, Here sits a king more woful than you are.
trg: Fly, father, fly! for all your friends are fled, And Warwick rages like a chafed bull: Away! for death doth hold us in pursuit.

src: 'Tis done, my gracious lord.
trg: Shall we hear from thee, Tyrrel, ere we sleep?

src: So he did, my lord: The army marvell'd at it, and, in the last, When he had carried Rome and that we look'd For no less spoil than glory,--
trg: There was it: For which my sinews shall be stretch'd upon him. At a few drops of women's rheum, which are As cheap as lies, he sold the blood and labour Of our great action:

src: Pass no further.
trg: Ha! what is that?

src: Heaven keep your honour safe!
Well, then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby, And, as it were far off sound thou Lord Hastings, How doth he stand affected to our purpose;
trg: And summon him to-morrow to the Tower, To sit about the coronation. If thou dost find him tractable to us, Encourage him, and show him all our reasons:

src: Nay, then, 'tis time to stir him from his trance. I pray, awake, sir: if you love the maid, Bend thoughts and wits to achieve her. Thus it stands:
trg: Her eldest sister is so curst and shrewd That till the father rid his hands of her, Master, your love must live a maid at home;

src: The more I stay, the more I'll succor thee.
trg: O, but impatience waiteth on true sorrow. And see where comes the breeder of my sorrow!

src: Farewell, faint-hearted and degenerate king, In whose cold blood no spark of honour bides.
trg: Be thou a prey unto the house of York, And die in bands for this unmanly deed!

src: Gracious my lord, You know your father's temper: at this time He will allow no speech, which I do guess You do not purpose to him; and as hardly Will he endure your sight as yet, I fear:
trg: Then, till the fury of his highness settle, Come not before him.

src: The rabble should have first unroof'd the city, Ere so prevail'd with me: it will in time Win upon power and throw forth greater themes For insurrection's arguing.
trg: This is strange.

src: The higher powers forbid!
trg: I say she's dead; I'll swear't. If word nor oath Prevail not, go and see:

src: A hundred then.
trg: Content.

src: -- With all good speed at Plashy visit me. Alack, and what shall good old York there see But empty lodgings and unfurnish'd walls, Unpeopled offices, untrodden stones?
trg: And what hear there for welcome but my groans? Therefore commend me; let him not come there, To seek out sorrow that dwells every where. Desolate, desolate, will I hence and die:

src: Look not to the ground, Ye favourites of a king: are we not high? High be our thoughts: I know my uncle York Hath power enough to serve our turn. But who comes here?
trg: More health and happiness betide my liege Than can my care-tuned tongue deliver him!

src: Fair cousin, you debase your princely knee To make the base earth proud with kissing it: Me rather had my heart might feel your love Than my unpleased eye see your courtesy. Up, cousin, up;
trg: your heart is up, I know, Thus high at least, although your knee be low.

src: so your sweet majesty, Looking awry upon your lord's departure, Find shapes of grief, more than himself, to wail; Which, look'd on as it is, is nought but shadows Of what it is not.
trg: Then, thrice-gracious queen, More than your lord's departure weep not: more's not seen; Or if it be, 'tis with false sorrow's eye, Which for things true weeps things imaginary.

src: and here you sty me In this hard rock, whiles you do keep from me The rest o' the island.
trg: Thou most lying slave, Whom stripes may move, not kindness!

src: Base, fearful and despairing Henry!
trg: How hast thou injured both thyself and us!

src: And thereupon he sends you this good news, That this same very day your enemies, The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.
trg: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news, Because they have been still mine enemies:

src: from face to foot He was a thing of blood, whose every motion Was timed with dying cries: alone he enter'd The mortal gate of the city, which he painted With shunless destiny;
trg: aidless came off, And with a sudden reinforcement struck Corioli like a planet: now all's his: When, by and by, the din of war gan pierce His ready sense;

src: Caius Marcius was A worthy officer i' the war; but insolent, O'ercome with pride, ambitious past all thinking, Self-loving,--
trg: And affecting one sole throne, Without assistance.

src: I have heard of the lady, and good words went with her name.
trg: She should this Angelo have married; was affianced to her by oath, and the nuptial appointed:

src: I think I have the letter here; yes, here it is. 'They have press'd a power, but it is not known Whether for east or west: the dearth is great; The people mutinous;
trg: and it is rumour'd, Cominius, Marcius your old enemy, Who is of Rome worse hated than of you, And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman, These three lead on this preparation Whither 'tis bent:

src: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.
trg: Not I, believe me: you have dancing shoes With nimble soles: I have a soul of lead So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.

src: Faith, there had been many great men that have flattered the people, who ne'er loved them; and there be many that they have loved, they know not wherefore:
trg: so that, if they love they know not why, they hate upon no better a ground:

src: I warrant thee, my man's as true as steel.
trg: Well, sir; my mistress is the sweetest lady--Lord, Lord! when 'twas a little prating thing:--O, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard;
Your friends, sir; the hangman. You must be so good, sir, to rise and be put to death.

src: He hath, my lord.
trg: And therefore is he idle?

src: Then say at once what thou dost know in this.
trg: I will be brief, for my short date of breath Is not so long as is a tedious tale. Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet; And she, there dead, that Romeo's faithful wife: I married them;

src: Why, Buckingham, I say, I would be king,
trg: Why, so you are, my thrice renowned liege.

src: Is it even so? rewards he my true service With such deep contempt made I him king for this? O, let me think on Hastings, and be gone To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!
trg: The tyrannous and bloody deed is done. The most arch of piteous massacre That ever yet this land was guilty of. 'Lo, thus' quoth Dighton, 'lay those tender babes:

src: The tyrannous and bloody deed is done. The most arch of piteous massacre That ever yet this land was guilty of. 'Lo, thus' quoth Dighton, 'lay those tender babes:
trg: ' 'Thus, thus,' quoth Forrest, 'girdling one another Within their innocent alabaster arms: Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, Which in their summer beauty kiss'd each other.

src: There on the ground, with his own tears made drunk.
trg: O, he is even in my mistress' case, Just in her case! O woful sympathy! Piteous predicament! Even so lies she, Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering. Stand up, stand up;

src: These eyes that never shed remorseful tear, No, when my father York and Edward wept, To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him;
trg: in that sad time My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear; And what these sorrows could not thence exhale, Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping. I never sued to friend nor enemy;

src: hear all, all see, And like her most whose merit most shall be: Which on more view, of many mine being one May stand in number, though in reckoning none, Come, go with me.
trg: Go, sirrah, trudge about Through fair Verona; find those persons out Whose names are written there, and to them say, My house and welcome on their pleasure stay.

src: I twice five hundred and their friends to piece 'em.
trg: Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends, They have chose a consul that will from them take Their liberties;

src: O thou untaught! what manners is in this? To press before thy father to a grave?
trg: Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while, Till we can clear these ambiguities, And know their spring, their head, their true descent;

src: Right, you say true: as Hereford's love, so his; As theirs, so mine; and all be as it is.
trg: My liege, old Gaunt commends him to your majesty.

src: In that there's comfort.
trg: I heard him swear, Were he to stand for consul, never would he Appear i' the market-place nor on him put The napless vesture of humility;

src: Mistake not, uncle, further than you should.
trg: Take not, good cousin, further than you should. Lest you mistake the heavens are o'er our heads.

src: Here.
trg: There.

src: Away! for vengeance comes along with them: Nay, stay not to expostulate, make speed; Or else come after: I'll away before.
trg: Nay, take me with thee, good sweet Exeter: Not that I fear to stay, but love to go Whither the queen intends. Forward; away! 3 KING HENRY VI

src: I see the play so lies That I must bear a part.
trg: No remedy. Have you done there?

src: Thy overflow of good converts to bad, And thy abundant goodness shall excuse This deadly blot in thy digressing son.
trg: So shall my virtue be his vice's bawd; And he shall spend mine honour with his shame, As thriftless sons their scraping fathers' gold.

src: and what they are that must Be hostages for Rome.
trg: Will not you go?

src: Very well: you being then, if you be remembered, cracking the stones of the foresaid prunes,--
trg: Ay, so I did indeed.

src: Who knows the lord protector's mind herein? Who is most inward with the royal duke?
trg: Your grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.

src: My lord, the enemy is past the marsh After the battle let George Stanley die.
trg: A thousand hearts are great within my bosom: Advance our standards, set upon our foes Our ancient word of courage, fair Saint George, Inspire us with the spleen of fiery dragons! Upon them!

src: Give me some ink and paper in my tent I'll draw the form and model of our battle, Limit each leader to his several charge, And part in just proportion our small strength.
trg: My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon, And you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me. The Earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment:

src: Come, Kate, we'll to bed. We three are married, but you two are sped. 'Twas I won the wager, though you hit the white; And, being a winner, God give you good night!
trg: Now, go thy ways; thou hast tamed a curst shrew.

src: King Henry, be thy title right or wrong, Lord Clifford vows to fight in thy defence: May that ground gape and swallow me alive, Where I shall kneel to him that slew my father!
trg: O Clifford, how thy words revive my heart!

src: Nay, he's a flower; in faith, a very flower.
trg: What say you? can you love the gentleman? This night you shall behold him at our feast; Read o'er the volume of young Paris' face, And find delight writ there with beauty's pen;

src: Hold your peaces.
trg: Good my lord,--

src: God keep your lordship in that gracious mind!
trg: But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence, That they who brought me in my master's hate I live to look upon their tragedy. I tell thee, Catesby--

src: O sir, it is better to be brief than tedious. Show him our commission; talk no more.
trg: I am, in this, commanded to deliver The noble Duke of Clarence to your hands: I will not reason what is meant hereby, Because I will be guiltless of the meaning.

src: Ay, boy, ready.
trg: You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.

src: thy Juliet is alive, For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead; There art thou happy: Tybalt would kill thee, But thou slew'st Tybalt; there are thou happy too:
trg: The law that threaten'd death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile; there art thou happy: A pack of blessings lights up upon thy back; Happiness courts thee in her best array;

src: Nay, go not from us thus. If it were so that our request did tend To save the Romans, thereby to destroy The Volsces whom you serve, you might condemn us, As poisonous of your honour: no;
trg: our suit Is that you reconcile them: while the Volsces May say 'This mercy we have show'd;' the Romans, 'This we received;

src: Nay, rather, every tedious stride I make Will but remember me what a deal of world I wander from the jewels that I love.
trg: Must I not serve a long apprenticehood To foreign passages, and in the end, Having my freedom, boast of nothing else But that I was a journeyman to grief?

src: 'Tis figured in my tongue.
trg: I fear me both are false.

src: so heavy sad As, though on thinking on no thought I think, Makes me with heavy nothing faint and shrink.
trg: 'Tis nothing but conceit, my gracious lady.

src: Born in Verona, old Antonio's son: My father dead, my fortune lives for me; And I do hope good days and long to see.
trg: O sir, such a life, with such a wife, were strange! But if you have a stomach, to't i' God's name: You shall have me assisting you in all. But will you woo this wild-cat?

src: They lie in view; but have not spoke as yet.
trg: So, the good horse is mine.

src: where the dull tribunes, That, with the fusty plebeians, hate thine honours, Shall say against their hearts 'We thank the gods Our Rome hath such a soldier.
trg: ' Yet camest thou to a morsel of this feast, Having fully dined before.

src: And, by the glorious worth of my descent, This arm shall do it, or this life be spent.
trg: How high a pitch his resolution soars! Thomas of Norfolk, what say'st thou to this?

src: With this, my lord, myself have nought to do.
trg: Naught to do with mistress Shore! I tell thee, fellow, He that doth naught with her, excepting one, Were best he do it secretly, alone.

src: The gods forbid! I prithee, noble friend, home to thy house; Leave us to cure this cause.
trg: For 'tis a sore upon us, You cannot tent yourself: be gone, beseech you.

src: Stir with the lark to-morrow, gentle Norfolk.
trg: I warrant you, my lord.

src: Know'st thou not any whom corrupting gold Would tempt unto a close exploit of death?
trg: My lord, I know a discontented gentleman, Whose humble means match not his haughty mind: Gold were as good as twenty orators, And will, no doubt, tempt him to any thing.

src: O sir, you are not right: have you not known The worthiest men have done't?
trg: What must I say? 'I Pray, sir'--Plague upon't! I cannot bring My tongue to such a pace:--'Look, sir, my wounds!

src: Not Romeo, prince, he was Mercutio's friend; His fault concludes but what the law should end, The life of Tybalt.
trg: And for that offence Immediately we do exile him hence: I have an interest in your hate's proceeding, My blood for your rude brawls doth lie a-bleeding;

src: A flourish, trumpets! strike alarum, drums! Let not the heavens hear these tell-tale women Rail on the Lord's enointed: strike, I say!
trg: Either be patient, and entreat me fair, Or with the clamorous report of war Thus will I drown your exclamations.

src: I do beseech you, By all the battles wherein we have fought, By the blood we have shed together, by the vows We have made to endure friends, that you directly Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates;
trg: And that you not delay the present, but, Filling the air with swords advanced and darts, We prove this very hour.

src: Safely in harbour Is the king's ship; in the deep nook, where once Thou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dew From the still-vex'd Bermoothes, there she's hid: The mariners all under hatches stow'd;
trg: Who, with a charm join'd to their suffer'd labour, I have left asleep;

src: He shows his reason for that: to have a dispatch of complaints, and to deliver us from devices hereafter, which shall then have no power to stand against us.
trg: Well, I beseech you, let it be proclaimed betimes i' the morn; I'll call you at your house: give notice to such men of sort and suit as are to meet him.

src: The youngest daughter whom you hearken for Her father keeps from all access of suitors, And will not promise her to any man Until the elder sister first be wed:
trg: The younger then is free and not before.

src: Now for the rebels which stand out in Ireland, Expedient manage must be made, my liege, Ere further leisure yield them further means For their advantage and your highness' loss.
trg: We will ourself in person to this war: And, for our coffers, with too great a court And liberal largess, are grown somewhat light, We are inforced to farm our royal realm;

src: Is thy news good, or bad? answer to that; Say either, and I'll stay the circumstance: Let me be satisfied, is't good or bad?
trg: Well, you have made a simple choice; you know not how to choose a man: Romeo! no, not he; though his face be better than any man's, yet his leg excels all men's;

src: Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.
trg: Ay, millstones; as be lesson'd us to weep.

src: Wherefore, gentle maiden, Do you neglect them?
trg: For I have heard it said There is an art which in their piedness shares With great creating nature.

src: Saw you Aufidius?
trg: On safe-guard he came to me; and did curse Against the Volsces, for they had so vilely Yielded the town: he is retired to Antium.

src: What is't o'clock?
trg: Upon the stroke of four.

src: O Doricles, Your praises are too large:
trg: but that your youth, And the true blood which peepeth fairly through't, Do plainly give you out an unstain'd shepherd, With wisdom I might fear, my Doricles, You woo'd me the false way.

src: Be it as your wisdom will.
trg: Where is the provost?

src: as weeds before A vessel under sail, so men obey'd And fell below his stem: his sword, death's stamp, Where it did mark, it took;
trg: from face to foot He was a thing of blood, whose every motion Was timed with dying cries: alone he enter'd The mortal gate of the city, which he painted With shunless destiny;

src: In suffering thus thy brother to be slaughter'd, Thou showest the naked pathway to thy life, Teaching stern murder how to butcher thee:
trg: That which in mean men we intitle patience Is pale cold cowardice in noble breasts. What shall I say? to safeguard thine own life, The best way is to venge my Gloucester's death.

src: Your judgments, my grave lords, Must give this cur the lie: and his own notion-- Who wears my stripes impress'd upon him;
trg: that Must bear my beating to his grave--shall join To thrust the lie unto him.

src: What was his reason? He was not so resolved when last we spake together.
trg: Because your lordship was proclaimed traitor.

src: Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace! Thou talk'st of nothing.
trg: This wind, you talk of, blows us from ourselves; Supper is done, and we shall come too late.

src: But now you partly may perceive my mind.
trg: My mind will never grant what I perceive Your highness aims at, if I aim aright.

src: Your pardon, sir; for this I'll blush you thanks.
trg: My prettiest Perdita! But O, the thorns we stand upon! Camillo, Preserver of my father, now of me, The medicine of our house, how shall we do?

src: So shall my virtue be his vice's bawd; And he shall spend mine honour with his shame, As thriftless sons their scraping fathers' gold.
trg: Mine honour lives when his dishonour dies, Or my shamed life in his dishonour lies: Thou kill'st me in his life; giving him breath, The traitor lives, the true man's put to death.

src: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.
trg: O wonderful, when devils tell the truth!

src: Is there no manners left among maids? will they wear their plackets where they should bear their faces?
trg: Is there not milking-time, when you are going to bed, or kiln-hole, to whistle off these secrets, but you must be tittle-tattling before all our guests? 'tis well they are whispering:

src: I am hurt. A plague o' both your houses! I am sped. Is he gone, and hath nothing?
trg: What, art thou hurt?

src: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
and these two beget A generation of still-breeding thoughts, And these same thoughts people this little world, In humours like the people of this world, For no thought is contented.
trg: The better sort, As thoughts of things divine, are intermix'd With scruples and do set the word itself Against the word:

src: Far be the thought of this from Henry's heart, To make a shambles of the parliament-house! Cousin of Exeter, frowns, words and threats Shall be the war that Henry means to use.
trg: Thou factious Duke of York, descend my throne, and kneel for grace and mercy at my feet; I am thy sovereign.

src: commend me to thy lady; And bid her hasten all the house to bed, Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto: Romeo is coming.
trg: O Lord, I could have stay'd here all the night To hear good counsel: O, what learning is! My lord, I'll tell my lady you will come.

src: How should they, when that wise men have no eyes?
trg: Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.

src: Hark, Petruchio; she says she'll see thee hang'd first.
trg: Is this your speeding? nay, then, good night our part!

src: Now is your time: speak loud and kneel before him.
trg: Justice, O royal duke! Vail your regard Upon a wrong'd, I would fain have said, a maid!

src: Take that, thou likeness of this railer here.
trg: Sprawl'st thou? take that, to end thy agony.

src: Sound, trumpets; and set forward, combatants. Stay, the king hath thrown his warder down.
trg: Let them lay by their helmets and their spears, And both return back to their chairs again: Withdraw with us: and let the trumpets sound While we return these dukes what we decree.

src: What says your highness to my just demand?
trg: As I remember, Henry the Sixth Did prophesy that Richmond should be king, When Richmond was a little peevish boy. A king, perhaps, perhaps,--

src: O monstrous beast! how like a swine he lies! Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image! Sirs, I will practise on this drunken man.
trg: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.

src: Yes, mercy, if you report him truly.
trg: I paint him in the character. Mark what mercy his mother shall bring from him: there is no more mercy in him than there is milk in a male tiger; that shall our poor city find:

src: I will not do't, Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth And by my body's action teach my mind A most inherent baseness.
trg: At thy choice, then: To beg of thee, it is my more dishonour Than thou of them. Come all to ruin;

src: Hot lavender, mints, savoury, marjoram; The marigold, that goes to bed wi' the sun And with him rises weeping: these are flowers Of middle summer, and I think they are given To men of middle age.
trg: You're very welcome.

src: Stay, gentle Margaret, and hear me speak.
trg: Thou hast spoke too much already: get thee gone.

src: Tread on the sand; why, there you quickly sink: Bestride the rock; the tide will wash you off, Or else you famish; that's a threefold death.
trg: This speak I, lords, to let you understand, If case some one of you would fly from us, That there's no hoped-for mercy with the brothers More than with ruthless waves, with sands and rocks.

src: I call thee not.
trg: I cry thee mercy then, for I had thought That thou hadst call'd me all these bitter names.

src: We'll show thee Io as she was a maid, And how she was beguiled and surprised, As lively painted as the deed was done.
trg: Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood, Scratching her legs that one shall swear she bleeds, And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep, So workmanly the blood and tears are drawn.

src: It is apart That I shall blush in acting, and might well Be taken from the people.
trg: Mark you that?

src: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.
trg: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.

src: Is she a Capulet? O dear account! my life is my foe's debt.
trg: Away, begone; the sport is at the best.

src: I thank thee, gentle Percy; and be sure I count myself in nothing else so happy As in a soul remembering my good friends;
trg: And, as my fortune ripens with thy love, It shall be still thy true love's recompense: My heart this covenant makes, my hand thus seals it.

src: But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger A precious ring, a ring that I must use In dear employment: therefore hence, be gone:
trg: But if thou, jealous, dost return to pry In what I further shall intend to do, By heaven, I will tear thee joint by joint And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs:

src: What should you fear? 'Tis nothing but some bond, that he is enter'd into For gay apparel 'gainst the triumph day.
trg: Bound to himself! what doth he with a bond That he is bound to? Wife, thou art a fool. Boy, let me see the writing.

src: That now you are come, you will be gone. Leave me awhile with the maid: my mind promises with my habit no loss shall touch her by my company.
trg: In good time.

src: Our haste from hence is of so quick condition That it prefers itself and leaves unquestion'd Matters of needful value.
trg: We shall write to you, As time and our concernings shall importune, How it goes with us, and do look to know What doth befall you here. So, fare you well;

src: Counsel me, Tranio, for I know thou canst; Assist me, Tranio, for I know thou wilt.
trg: Master, it is no time to chide you now; Affection is not rated from the heart: If love have touch'd you, nought remains but so, 'Redime te captum quam queas minimo.'

src: Her life is only safest in her birth.
trg: And only in that safety died her brothers.

src: Gentlemen, content ye; I am resolved: Go in, Bianca: And for I know she taketh most delight In music, instruments and poetry, Schoolmasters will I keep within my house, Fit to instruct her youth.
trg: If you, Hortensio, Or Signior Gremio, you, know any such, Prefer them hither; for to cunning men I will be very kind, and liberal To mine own children in good bringing up: And so farewell.

src: Why, then I would not fly. Ah, Montague, If thou be there, sweet brother, take my hand. And with thy lips keep in my soul awhile! Thou lovest me not;
trg: for, brother, if thou didst, Thy tears would wash this cold congealed blood That glues my lips and will not let me speak. Come quickly, Montague, or I am dead.

src: if something thou wilt swear to be believed, Swear then by something that thou hast not wrong'd.
trg: Now, by the world--

src: Has spoken like a traitor, and shall answer As traitors do.
trg: Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee! What should the people do with these bald tribunes? On whom depending, their obedience fails To the greater bench:

src: my throat of war be turn'd, Which quired with my drum, into a pipe Small as an eunuch, or the virgin voice That babies lulls asleep!
trg: the smiles of knaves Tent in my cheeks, and schoolboys' tears take up The glasses of my sight!

src: No, 'tis not so deep as a well, nor so wide as a church-door; but 'tis enough,'twill serve: ask for me to-morrow, and you shall find me a grave man. I am peppered, I warrant, for this world.
trg: A plague o' both your houses! 'Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat, to scratch a man to death! a braggart, a rogue, a villain, that fights by the book of arithmetic!

src: Discomfortable cousin!
trg: know'st thou not That when the searching eye of heaven is hid, Behind the globe, that lights the lower world, Then thieves and robbers range abroad unseen In murders and in outrage, boldly here;

src: therefore, I beseech you In sign of what you are, not to reward What you have done--before our army hear me.
trg: I have some wounds upon me, and they smart To hear themselves remember'd.

src: love's heralds should be thoughts, Which ten times faster glide than the sun's beams, Driving back shadows over louring hills:
trg: Therefore do nimble-pinion'd doves draw love, And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.

src: stir, nay, come away, Bequeath to death your numbness, for from him Dear life redeems you. You perceive she stirs: Start not; her actions shall be holy as You hear my spell is lawful:
trg: do not shun her Until you see her die again; for then You kill her double. Nay, present your hand: When she was young you woo'd her; now in age Is she become the suitor?

src: What is your crest? a coxcomb?
trg: A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.

src: Now comes the sick hour that his surfeit made; Now shall he try his friends that flatter'd him.
trg: My lord, your son was gone before I came.

src: I'll wait upon your honour.
trg: If the duke with the other dukes come not to composition with the King of Hungary, why then all the dukes fall upon the king.

src: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it: And yet I would it were to give again.
trg: Wouldst thou withdraw it? for what purpose, love?

src: Go to, then.
trg: She being none of your flesh and blood, your flesh and blood has not offended the king; and so your flesh and blood is not to be punished by him.

src: I think thou dost; and, indeed, with most painful feeling of thy speech: I will, out of thine own confession, learn to begin thy health; but, whilst I live, forget to drink after thee.
trg: I think I have done myself wrong, have I not?

src: Richard except, those whom we fight against Had rather have us win than him they follow: For what is he they follow?  truly, gentlemen, A bloody tyrant and a homicide;
trg: One raised in blood, and one in blood establish'd; One that made means to come by what he hath, And slaughter'd those that were the means to help him;

src: I am content you shall entreat me stay; But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.
trg: Now, if you love me, stay.

src: If it Please your honour, I am the poor duke's constable, and my name is Elbow: I do lean upon justice, sir, and do bring in here before your good honour two notorious benefactors.
trg: Benefactors? Well; what benefactors are they? are they not malefactors?

src: Marry, God forbid his grace should say us nay!
trg: I fear he will. How now, Catesby, what says your lord?

src: The climate's delicate, the air most sweet, Fertile the isle, the temple much surpassing The common praise it bears.
trg: I shall report, For most it caught me, the celestial habits, Methinks I so should term them, and the reverence Of the grave wearers. O, the sacrifice!

src: Woe above woe! grief more than common grief! O that my death would stay these ruthful deeds! O pity, pity, gentle heaven, pity!
trg: The red rose and the white are on his face, The fatal colours of our striving houses: The one his purple blood right well resembles; The other his pale cheeks, methinks, presenteth:

src: I do not sue to stand; Pardon is all the suit I have in hand.
trg: I pardon him, as God shall pardon me.

src: I'll not put The dibble in earth to set one slip of them; No more than were I painted I would wish This youth should say 'twere well and only therefore Desire to breed by me. Here's flowers for you;
trg: Hot lavender, mints, savoury, marjoram; The marigold, that goes to bed wi' the sun And with him rises weeping: these are flowers Of middle summer, and I think they are given To men of middle age.

src: this love that thou hast shown Doth add more grief to too much of mine own. Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs; Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes;
trg: Being vex'd a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears: What is it else? a madness most discreet, A choking gall and a preserving sweet. Farewell, my coz.

src: Then fare you well, for I will hence again: I came to serve a king and not a duke. Drummer, strike up, and let us march away.
trg: Nay, stay, Sir John, awhile, and we'll debate By what safe means the crown may be recover'd.

src: Mine eyes are full of tears, I cannot see: And yet salt water blinds them not so much But they can see a sort of traitors here.
trg: Nay, if I turn mine eyes upon myself, I find myself a traitor with the rest; For I have given here my soul's consent To undeck the pompous body of a king;

src: Whom should he follow but his natural king?
trg: True, Clifford; and that's Richard Duke of York.

src: She hath not seen the change of fourteen years, Let two more summers wither in their pride, Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.
trg: Younger than she are happy mothers made.

src: March on, march on, since we are up in arms; If not to fight with foreign enemies, Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.
trg: My liege, the Duke of Buckingham is taken; That is the best news: that the Earl of Richmond Is with a mighty power landed at Milford, Is colder tidings, yet they must be told.

src: My lord, I must confess I know this woman: And five years since there was some speech of marriage Betwixt myself and her;
trg: which was broke off, Partly for that her promised proportions Came short of composition, but in chief For that her reputation was disvalued In levity:

src: and then to glance from him To the duke himself, to tax him with injustice? Take him hence; to the rack with him! We'll touse you Joint by joint, but we will know his purpose. What 'unjust'!
trg: Be not so hot; the duke Dare no more stretch this finger of mine than he Dare rack his own: his subject am I not, Nor here provincial.

src: As I guess, Marcius, Their bands i' the vaward are the Antiates, Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius, Their very heart of hope.
trg: I do beseech you, By all the battles wherein we have fought, By the blood we have shed together, by the vows We have made to endure friends, that you directly Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates;

src: And meaner than myself have had like fortune. But as this title honours me and mine, So your dislike, to whom I would be pleasing, Doth cloud my joys with danger and with sorrow.
trg: My love, forbear to fawn upon their frowns: What danger or what sorrow can befall thee, So long as Edward is thy constant friend, And their true sovereign, whom they must obey?

src: That they have let the dangerous enemy Measure our confines with such peaceful steps? If we prevail, their heads shall pay for it: I warrant they have made peace with Bolingbroke.
trg: Peace have they made with him indeed, my lord.

src: and then anon Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes, And being thus frighted swears a prayer or two And sleeps again.
trg: This is that very Mab That plats the manes of horses in the night, And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs, Which once untangled, much misfortune bodes:

src: I would know that of your honour.
trg: He's in the right. Constable, what say you to it?

src: The time to come.
trg: That thou hast wronged in the time o'erpast; For I myself have many tears to wash Hereafter time, for time past wrong'd by thee.

src: They break their faith to God as well as us: Cry woe, destruction, ruin and decay: The worst is death, and death will have his day.
trg: Glad am I that your highness is so arm'd To bear the tidings of calamity. White-beards have arm'd their thin and hairless scalps Against thy majesty;

src: I have.
trg: Then hie you hence to Friar Laurence' cell; There stays a husband to make you a wife: Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks, They'll be in scarlet straight at any news. Hie you to church;

src: Myself am struck in years, I must confess; And if I die to-morrow, this is hers, If whilst I live she will be only mine.
trg: That 'only' came well in. Sir, list to me: I am my father's heir and only son:

src: You are a Roman, are you?
trg: I am, as thy general is.

src: Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above, And all good men of this ungovern'd isle.
trg: I do suspect I have done some offence That seems disgracious in the city's eyes, And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.

src: and took some pride To do myself this wrong: till, at the last, I seem'd his follower, not partner, and He waged me with his countenance, as if I had been mercenary.
trg: So he did, my lord: The army marvell'd at it, and, in the last, When he had carried Rome and that we look'd For no less spoil than glory,--

src: A thousand times good night!
trg: A thousand times the worse, to want thy light. Love goes toward love, as schoolboys from their books, But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.

src: Thou hast faced many things.
trg: I have.

src: Sister, farewell; I must to Coventry: As much good stay with thee as go with me!
trg: Yet one word more: grief boundeth where it falls, Not with the empty hollowness, but weight: I take my leave before I have begun, For sorrow ends not when it seemeth done.

src: Why do you say 'thwack our general '?
trg: I do not say 'thwack our general;' but he was always good enough for him.

src: For what I have I need not to repeat; And what I want it boots not to complain.
trg: Madam, I'll sing.

src: O that I had him, With six Aufidiuses, or more, his tribe, To use my lawful sword!
trg: Insolent villain!

src: What hast here? ballads?
trg: Pray now, buy some: I love a ballad in print o' life, for then we are sure they are true.

src: Dispatch, my lord; the duke would be at dinner: Make a short shrift; he longs to see your head.
trg: O momentary grace of mortal men, Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!

src: True, too true, my lord: If, one by one, you wedded all the world, Or from the all that are took something good, To make a perfect woman, she you kill'd Would be unparallel'd.
trg: I think so. Kill'd! She I kill'd! I did so: but thou strikest me Sorely, to say I did; it is as bitter Upon thy tongue as in my thought: now, good now, Say so but seldom.

src: for we bid this be done, When evil deeds have their permissive pass And not the punishment. Therefore indeed, my father, I have on Angelo imposed the office;
trg: Who may, in the ambush of my name, strike home, And yet my nature never in the fight To do in slander. And to behold his sway, I will, as 'twere a brother of your order, Visit both prince and people:

src: This is no witness for Lord Angelo.
trg: Charges she more than me?

src: I am a poor fellow, sir. I know ye well enough.
trg: Nay, prithee, dispatch: the gentleman is half flayed already.

src: What talk you of debating? in few words, If you'll not here proclaim yourself our king, I'll leave you to your fortune and be gone To keep them back that come to succor you:
trg: Why shall we fight, if you pretend no title?

src: And wilt thou learn of me?
trg: Madam, with all my heart.

src: What news, my friend?
trg: That Edward is escaped from your brother, And fled, as he hears since, to Burgundy.

src: Now tell me, brother Clarence, what think you Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey? Hath not our brother made a worthy choice?
trg: Alas, you know, 'tis far from hence to France; How could he stay till Warwick made return?

src: Well, gentlemen, I am thus resolved: on Sunday next you know My daughter Katharina is to be married: Now, on the Sunday following, shall Bianca Be bride to you, if you this assurance;
trg: If not, Signior Gremio: And so, I take my leave, and thank you both.

src: His majesty Tendering my person's safety, hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower.
trg: Upon what cause?

src: Joy absent, grief is present for that time.
trg: What is six winters? they are quickly gone.

src: AEdiles, seize him!
trg: Yield, Marcius, yield!

src: I know it, uncle, and oppose not myself Against their will. But who comes here? Welcome, Harry: what, will not this castle yield?
trg: The castle royally is mann'd, my lord, Against thy entrance.

src: Why in this woolvish toge should I stand here, To beg of Hob and Dick, that do appear, Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to't:
trg: What custom wills, in all things should we do't, The dust on antique time would lie unswept, And mountainous error be too highly heapt For truth to o'er-peer.

src: Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.
trg: Perhaps you have learned it without book: but, I pray, can you read any thing you see?

src: And, for the time shall not seem tedious, I'll tell thee what befell me on a day In this self-place where now we mean to stand.
trg: Here comes a man; let's stay till he be past.

src: So thrive my soul--
trg: A thousand times good night!

src: Peace! We need not put new matter to his charge:
trg: What you have seen him do and heard him speak, Beating your officers, cursing yourselves, Opposing laws with strokes and here defying Those whose great power must try him;

src: Down with that sword! Tribunes, withdraw awhile.
trg: Lay hands upon him.

src: Why, noble lords, Will you be put in mind of his blind fortune, Which was your shame, by this unholy braggart, 'Fore your own eyes and ears?
trg: Let him die for't.

src: To make an act of tragic violence: Edward, my lord, your son, our king, is dead. Why grow the branches now the root is wither'd? Why wither not the leaves the sap being gone? If you will live, lament;
trg: if die, be brief, That our swift-winged souls may catch the king's; Or, like obedient subjects, follow him To his new kingdom of perpetual rest.

src: Ay me, I see the downfall of our house! The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind; Insulting tyranny begins to jet Upon the innocent and aweless throne: Welcome, destruction, death, and massacre!
trg: I see, as in a map, the end of all.

src: it is almost clear dawn.
trg: I am as well acquainted here as I was in our house of profession: one would think it were Mistress Overdone's own house, for here be many of her old customers. First, here's young Master Rash;

src: How do you both? you are manifest house-keepers. What are you sewing here? A fine spot, in good faith. How does your little son?
trg: I thank your ladyship; well, good madam.

src: I swear.
trg: And I, to keep all this.

src: Yea, my lord. How brooks your grace the air, After your late tossing on the breaking seas?
trg: Needs must I like it well: I weep for joy To stand upon my kingdom once again. Dear earth, I do salute thee with my hand, Though rebels wound thee with their horses' hoofs:

src: I assure you, Carthage.
trg: His word is more than the miraculous harp; he hath raised the wall and houses too.

src: Say no more: Here come the lords.
trg: You are most welcome home.

src: The last leave of thee takes my weeping eye.
trg: My Lord Aumerle, is Harry Hereford arm'd?

src: The image of it gives me content already; and I trust it will grow to a most prosperous perfection.
trg: It lies much in your holding up. Haste you speedily to Angelo: if for this night he entreat you to his bed, give him promise of satisfaction. I will presently to Saint Luke's:

src: Lords, I protest, my soul is full of woe, That blood should sprinkle me to make me grow: Come, mourn with me for that I do lament, And put on sullen black incontinent:
trg: I'll make a voyage to the Holy Land, To wash this blood off from my guilty hand: March sadly after; grace my mournings here; In weeping after this untimely bier.
O my dread lord, I should be guiltier than my guiltiness, To think I can be undiscernible, When I perceive your grace, like power divine, Hath look'd upon my passes.

src: But I will write again to Mantua, And keep her at my cell till Romeo come; Poor living corse, closed in a dead man's tomb!
trg: Give me thy torch, boy: hence, and stand aloof: Yet put it out, for I would not be seen. Under yond yew-trees lay thee all along, Holding thine ear close to the hollow ground;

src: Feeling so the loss, Cannot choose but ever weep the friend.
trg: Well, girl, thou weep'st not so much for his death, As that the villain lives which slaughter'd him.

src: Thus do I leave thee. Come, son, let's away; Our army is ready; come, we'll after them.
trg: Stay, gentle Margaret, and hear me speak.

src: I talk of that, that know it.
trg: You?

src: Ay.
trg: Where's that?

src: That villain cousin would have kill'd my husband: Back, foolish tears, back to your native spring; Your tributary drops belong to woe, Which you, mistaking, offer up to joy.
trg: My husband lives, that Tybalt would have slain; And Tybalt's dead, that would have slain my husband: All this is comfort; wherefore weep I then?

src: Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.
trg: Here is a friar, and slaughter'd Romeo's man; With instruments upon them, fit to open These dead men's tombs.

src: Why, how now, dame! whence grows this insolence? Bianca, stand aside. Poor girl! she weeps. Go ply thy needle; meddle not with her.
trg: For shame, thou helding of a devilish spirit, Why dost thou wrong her that did ne'er wrong thee? When did she cross thee with a bitter word?

src: What, would you make me mad? Am not I Christopher Sly, old Sly's son of Burtonheath, by birth a pedlar, by education a cardmaker, by transmutation a bear-herd, and now by present profession a tinker?
trg: Ask Marian Hacket, the fat ale-wife of Wincot, if she know me not: if she say I am not fourteen pence on the score for sheer ale, score me up for the lyingest knave in Christendom. What!

src: The hand that hath made you fair hath made you good: the goodness that is cheap in beauty makes beauty brief in goodness;
trg: but grace, being the soul of your complexion, shall keep the body of it ever fair. The assault that Angelo hath made to you, fortune hath conveyed to my understanding;

src: And I'll keep London with my soldiers.
trg: And I to Norfolk with my followers.

src: What, ho! They are all forth. Well, I will walk myself To County Paris, to prepare him up Against to-morrow: my heart is wondrous light, Since this same wayward girl is so reclaim'd.
trg: Ay, those attires are best:

src: Nay, he will answer the letter's master, how he dares, being dared.
trg: Alas poor Romeo! he is already dead; stabbed with a white wench's black eye; shot through the ear with a love-song; the very pin of his heart cleft with the blind bow-boy's butt-shaft:

src: The fardel there? what's i' the fardel? Wherefore that box?
trg: Sir, there lies such secrets in this fardel and box, which none must know but the king; and which he shall know within this hour, if I may come to the speech of him.

src: Peace, impudent and shameless Warwick, peace, Proud setter up and puller down of kings!
trg: I will not hence, till, with my talk and tears, Both full of truth, I make King Lewis behold Thy sly conveyance and thy lord's false love; For both of you are birds of selfsame feather.

src: Him I accuse The city ports by this hath enter'd and Intends to appear before the people, hoping To purge herself with words: dispatch. Most welcome!
trg: How is it with our general?

src: Weapons, weapons, weapons! 'Tribunes!' 'Patricians!' 'Citizens!' 'What, ho!' 'Sicinius!' 'Brutus!' 'Coriolanus!' 'Citizens!' 'Peace, peace, peace!' 'Stay, hold, peace!'
trg: What is about to be? I am out of breath; Confusion's near; I cannot speak. You, tribunes To the people! Coriolanus, patience! Speak, good Sicinius.

src: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio. Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola. I promised to inquire carefully About a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca:
trg: And by good fortune I have lighted well On this young man, for learning and behavior Fit for her turn, well read in poetry And other books, good ones, I warrant ye.

src: Think you so, sir?
trg: Not he alone shall suffer what wit can make heavy and vengeance bitter; but those that are germane to him, though removed fifty times, shall all come under the hangman:

src: Didst note it?
trg: He would not stay at your petitions: made His business more material.

src: Long mayst thou live in Richard's seat to sit, And soon lie Richard in an earthly pit! God save King Harry, unking'd Richard says, And send him many years of sunshine days! What more remains?
trg: No more, but that you read These accusations and these grievous crimes Committed by your person and your followers Against the state and profit of this land;

src: Go make thyself like a nymph o' the sea: be subject To no sight but thine and mine, invisible To every eyeball else. Go take this shape And hither come in't: go, hence with diligence!
trg: Awake, dear heart, awake! thou hast slept well; Awake!

src: O,'tis Marcius! Let's fetch him off, or make remain alike.
trg: This will I carry to Rome.

src: 'He that is giddy thinks the world turns round:' I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.
trg: Your husband, being troubled with a shrew, Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe: And now you know my meaning,

src: Why, brother, wherefore stand you on nice points?
trg: When we grow stronger, then we'll make our claim: Till then, 'tis wisdom to conceal our meaning.
Mistress, your father prays you leave your books And help to dress your sister's chamber up: You know to-morrow is the wedding-day.

src: And better 'twere you troubled him than France.
trg: Peace, impudent and shameless Warwick, peace, Proud setter up and puller down of kings!

src: No, pardon; 'tis a secret must be locked within the teeth and the lips: but this I can let you understand, the greater file of the subject held the duke to be wise.
trg: Wise! why, no question but he was.

src: Be pitiful, dread lord, and grant it then.
trg: Lords, give us leave: I'll try this widow's wit.

src: Cousin of Buckingham, and you sage, grave men, Since you will buckle fortune on my back, To bear her burthen, whether I will or no, I must have patience to endure the load:
trg: But if black scandal or foul-faced reproach Attend the sequel of your imposition, Your mere enforcement shall acquittance me From all the impure blots and stains thereof;

src: A dire induction am I witness to, And will to France, hoping the consequence Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical. Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret: who comes here?
trg: Ah, my young princes! ah, my tender babes! My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets!

src: Thou frantic woman, what dost thou make here? Shall thy old dugs once more a traitor rear?
trg: Sweet York, be patient. Hear me, gentle liege.

src: For all the rest is held at such a rate As brings a thousand-fold more care to keep Than in possession and jot of pleasure. Ah, cousin York!
trg: would thy best friends did know How it doth grieve me that thy head is here!

src: I tell you, he that can lay hold of her Shall have the chinks.
trg: Is she a Capulet? O dear account! my life is my foe's debt.

src: O, here Will I set up my everlasting rest, And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars From this world-wearied flesh. Eyes, look your last! Arms, take your last embrace!
trg: and, lips, O you The doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss A dateless bargain to engrossing death! Come, bitter conduct, come, unsavoury guide!

src: Noble tribunes, It is the humane way: the other course Will prove too bloody, and the end of it Unknown to the beginning.
trg: Noble Menenius, Be you then as the people's officer. Masters, lay down your weapons.

src: By his great authority; Which often hath no less prevail'd than so On your command.
trg: I know't too well. Give me the boy: I am glad you did not nurse him: Though he does bear some signs of me, yet you Have too much blood in him.

src: Doth this news hold of good King Edward's death?
trg: Ay, sir, it is too true; God help the while!

src: Marry, this Claudio is condemned for untrussing. Farewell, good friar: I prithee, pray for me. The duke, I say to thee again, would eat mutton on Fridays.
trg: He's not past it yet, and I say to thee, he would mouth with a beggar, though she smelt brown bread and garlic: say that I said so. Farewell.

src: Then never trust me, if I be afeard.
trg: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense: I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.

src: this is an art Which does mend nature, change it rather, but The art itself is nature.
trg: So it is.

src: To the pot, I warrant him.
trg: What is become of Marcius?

src: Who lets it hop a little from her hand, Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, And with a silk thread plucks it back again, So loving-jealous of his liberty.
trg: I would I were thy bird.

src: you know our king, my brother, Is prisoner to the bishop here, at whose hands He hath good usage and great liberty, And, often but attended with weak guard, Comes hunting this way to disport himself.
trg: I have advertised him by secret means That if about this hour he make his way Under the colour of his usual game, He shall here find his friends with horse and men To set him free from his captivity.
Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower. Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes Whom envy hath immured within your walls! Rough cradle for such little pretty ones!

src: But leave we him to his events, with a prayer they may prove prosperous; and let me desire to know how you find Claudio prepared. I am made to understand that you have lent him visitation.
trg: He professes to have received no sinister measure from his judge, but most willingly humbles himself to the determination of justice:

src: Come, come with me, and we will make short work; For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone Till holy church incorporate two in one.
trg: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let's retire: The day is hot, the Capulets abroad, And, if we meet, we shall not scape a brawl; For now, these hot days, is the mad blood stirring.

src: he knew the service, and that instructed him to mercy.
trg: I never heard the absent duke much detected for women; he was not inclined that way.

src: My ashes, as the phoenix, may bring forth A bird that will revenge upon you all: And in that hope I throw mine eyes to heaven, Scorning whate'er you can afflict me with. Why come you not? what!
trg: multitudes, and fear?

src: O, thou art deceived; I would have made it short: for I was come to the whole depth of my tale; and meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.
trg: Here's goodly gear!

src: But in the balance of great Bolingbroke, Besides himself, are all the English peers, And with that odds he weighs King Richard down. Post you to London, and you will find it so;
trg: I speak no more than every one doth know.

src: But much of grief shows still some want of wit.
trg: Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.

src: friends, part!' and, swifter than his tongue, His agile arm beats down their fatal points, And 'twixt them rushes;
trg: underneath whose arm An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled;

src: I am now going to resolve him: I had rather my brother die by the law than my son should be unlawfully born. But, O, how much is the good duke deceived in Angelo!
trg: If ever he return and I can speak to him, I will open my lips in vain, or discover his government.

src: All seeing heaven, what a world is this!
trg: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?

src: To justify this worthy nobleman, So vulgarly and personally accused, Her shall you hear disproved to her eyes, Till she herself confess it.
trg: Good friar, let's hear it. Do you not smile at this, Lord Angelo? O heaven, the vanity of wretched fools! Give us some seats. Come, cousin Angelo; In this I'll be impartial;

src: If at home, sir, He's all my exercise, my mirth, my matter, Now my sworn friend and then mine enemy, My parasite, my soldier, statesman, all:
trg: He makes a July's day short as December, And with his varying childness cures in me Thoughts that would thick my blood.

src: He sits in his state, as a thing made for Alexander. What he bids be done is finished with his bidding. He wants nothing of a god but eternity and a heaven to throne in.
trg: Yes, mercy, if you report him truly.

src: O think'st thou we shall ever meet again?
trg: I doubt it not; and all these woes shall serve For sweet discourses in our time to come.

src: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, Whither away, or where is thy abode? Happy the parents of so fair a child; Happier the man, whom favourable stars Allot thee for his lovely bed-fellow!
trg: Why, how now, Kate! I hope thou art not mad: This is a man, old, wrinkled, faded, wither'd, And not a maiden, as thou say'st he is.

src: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.
trg: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.

src: like silly beggars Who sitting in the stocks refuge their shame, That many have and others must sit there;
trg: And in this thought they find a kind of ease, Bearing their own misfortunes on the back Of such as have before endured the like. Thus play I in one person many people, And none contented:

src: Why, am I dead? do I not breathe a man? Ah, simple men, you know not what you swear!
trg: Look, as I blow this feather from my face, And as the air blows it to me again, Obeying with my wind when I do blow, And yielding to another when it blows, Commanded always by the greater gust;

src: By the consent of all, we were establish'd The people's magistrates.
trg: You so remain.

src: and when with grief he wept, The ruthless queen gave him to dry his cheeks A napkin steeped in the harmless blood Of sweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford slain:
trg: And after many scorns, many foul taunts, They took his head, and on the gates of York They set the same; and there it doth remain, The saddest spectacle that e'er I view'd.

src: He rose against him, being his sovereign, And made him to resign his crown perforce.
trg: Suppose, my lords, he did it unconstrain'd, Think you 'twere prejudicial to his crown?

src: So that by this intelligence we learn The Welshmen are dispersed, and Salisbury Is gone to meet the king, who lately landed With some few private friends upon this coast.
trg: The news is very fair and good, my lord: Richard not far from hence hath hid his head.

src: Thou art a traitor and a miscreant, Too good to be so and too bad to live, Since the more fair and crystal is the sky, The uglier seem the clouds that in it fly.
trg: Once more, the more to aggravate the note, With a foul traitor's name stuff I thy throat; And wish, so please my sovereign, ere I move, What my tongue speaks my right drawn sword may prove.

src: Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was great; and in such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy.
trg: That's as much as to say, such a case as yours constrains a man to bow in the hams.

src: In her chamber, making a sermon of continency to her; And rails, and swears, and rates, that she, poor soul, Knows not which way to stand, to look, to speak, And sits as one new-risen from a dream.
trg: Away, away! for he is coming hither.

src: I go, my lord.
trg: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may. Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come, Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

src: Marry, my lord, lest, by a multitude, The new-heal'd wound of malice should break out, Which would be so much the more dangerous By how much the estate is green and yet ungovern'd:
trg: Where every horse bears his commanding rein, And may direct his course as please himself, As well the fear of harm, as harm apparent, In my opinion, ought to be prevented.

src: Faith, I know not what to say.
trg: O, I cry you mercy; you are the singer: I will say for you. It is 'music with her silver sound,' because musicians have no gold for sounding:

src: And then he sends you word He dreamt to-night the boar had razed his helm: Besides, he says there are two councils held;
trg: And that may be determined at the one which may make you and him to rue at the other.

src: That it would please thee leave these sad designs To him that hath more cause to be a mourner, And presently repair to Crosby Place;
trg: Where, after I have solemnly interr'd At Chertsey monastery this noble king, And wet his grave with my repentant tears, I will with all expedient duty see you: For divers unknown reasons.

src: Now I arise: Sit still, and hear the last of our sea-sorrow. Here in this island we arrived;
trg: and here Have I, thy schoolmaster, made thee more profit Than other princesses can that have more time For vainer hours and tutors not so careful.

src: the nobles bended, As to Jove's statue, and the commons made A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts: I never saw the like.
trg: Let's to the Capitol; And carry with us ears and eyes for the time, But hearts for the event.

src: Come, leave your tears: a brief farewell: the beast With many heads butts me away. Nay, mother, Where is your ancient courage? you were used To say extremity was the trier of spirits;
trg: That common chances common men could bear; That when the sea was calm all boats alike Show'd mastership in floating;

src: Why, madam, have I offer'd love for this To be so bouted in this royal presence? Who knows not that the noble duke is dead? You do him injury to scorn his corse.
trg: Who knows not he is dead! who knows he is?

src: So do I ever: being well-advised. For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.
trg: Madam, his majesty doth call for you, And for your grace; and you, my noble lords.

src: Methought I had; and often did I strive To yield the ghost: but still the envious flood Kept in my soul, and would not let it forth To seek the empty, vast and wandering air;
trg: But smother'd it within my panting bulk, Which almost burst to belch it in the sea.

src: We shall be short in our provision: 'Tis now near night.
trg: Tush, I will stir about, And all things shall be well, I warrant thee, wife: Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her; I'll not to bed to-night; let me alone; I'll play the housewife for this once.

src: We hate alike: Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.
trg: Let the first budger die the other's slave, And the gods doom him after!

src: Here's no knavery! See, to beguile the old folks, how the young folks lay their heads together! Master, master, look about you: who goes there, ha?
trg: Peace, Grumio! it is the rival of my love. Petruchio, stand by a while.

src: Here come those I have done good to against my will, and already appearing in the blossoms of their fortune.
trg: Come, boy; I am past moe children, but thy sons and daughters will be all gentlemen born.

src: Was ever father so bemoan'd his son?
trg: Was ever king so grieved for subjects' woe? Much is your sorrow; mine ten times so much.

src: Come, where be these gallants? who's at home?
trg: You are welcome, sir.

src: Why, 'tis no great matter; for a very little thief of occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience: give your dispositions the reins, and be angry at your pleasures;
trg: at the least if you take it as a pleasure to you in being so. You blame Marcius for being proud?

src: Good or bad?
trg: Not according to the prayer of the people, for they love not Marcius.

src: And, as he stoop'd again to take it up, The mad-brain'd bridegroom took him such a cuff That down fell priest and book and book and priest: 'Now take them up,' quoth he, 'if any list.'
trg: What said the wench when he rose again?

src: So long could I Stand by, a looker on.
trg: Either forbear, Quit presently the chapel, or resolve you For more amazement. If you can behold it, I'll make the statue move indeed, descend And take you by the hand;

src: Thou chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline.
trg: For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.

src: Take that, and that: if all this will not do, I'll drown you in the malmsey-butt within.
trg: A bloody deed, and desperately dispatch'd! How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my hands Of this most grievous guilty murder done!

src: My very worthy cousin, fairly met! Our old and faithful friend, we are glad to see you.
trg: Happy return be to your royal grace!

src: So call it: but it does fulfil my vow; I needs must think it honesty.
trg: therefore, I pray you, As you have ever been my father's honour'd friend, When he shall miss me,--as, in faith, I mean not To see him any more,--cast your good counsels Upon his passion;

src: 'Tis well; and hold your own, in any case, With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.
trg: I warrant you. But, sir, here comes your boy; 'Twere good he were school'd.

src: Then, as the manner of our country is, In thy best robes uncover'd on the bier Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie.
trg: In the mean time, against thou shalt awake, Shall Romeo by my letters know our drift, And hither shall he come:

src: Madam wife, they say that I have dream'd And slept above some fifteen year or more.
trg: Ay, and the time seems thirty unto me, Being all this time abandon'd from your bed.

src: The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms.
trg: I am glad on 't: then we shall ha' means to vent Our musty superfluity. See, our best elders.

src: Cannot thy master sleep these tedious nights?
trg: So it should seem by that I have to say. First, he commends him to your noble lordship.

src: To-day, to-day, unhappy day, too late, O'erthrows thy joys, friends, fortune and thy state: For all the Welshmen, hearing thou wert dead. Are gone to Bolingbroke, dispersed and fled.
trg: Comfort, my liege; why looks your grace so pale?

src: Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn, The gallant, young and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter's Church, Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.
trg: Now, by Saint Peter's Church and Peter too, He shall not make me there a joyful bride. I wonder at this haste; that I must wed Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.

src: That's likewise part of my intelligence; but, I fear, the angle that plucks our son thither. Thou shalt accompany us to the place;
trg: where we will, not appearing what we are, have some question with the shepherd; from whose simplicity I think it not uneasy to get the cause of my son's resort thither.

src: Is the day so young?
trg: But new struck nine.

src: One: tell.
trg: When every grief is entertain'd that's offer'd, Comes to the entertainer--

src: I have deserved no better entertainment, In being Coriolanus.
trg: Whence are you, sir? Has the porter his eyes in his head; that he gives entrance to such companions? Pray, get you out.

src: The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb;
trg: What is her burying grave that is her womb, And from her womb children of divers kind We sucking on her natural bosom find, Many for many virtues excellent, None but for some and yet all different.

src: Stars, stars, And all eyes else dead coals! Fear thou no wife; I'll have no wife, Paulina.
trg: Will you swear Never to marry but by my free leave?

src: So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend Which you weep for.
trg: Feeling so the loss, Cannot choose but ever weep the friend.

src: Is the chair empty? is the sword unsway'd? Is the king dead? the empire unpossess'd? What heir of York is there alive but we? And who is England's king but great York's heir?
trg: Then, tell me, what doth he upon the sea?

src: Love give me strength! and strength shall help afford. Farewell, dear father!
trg: So many guests invite as here are writ. Sirrah, go hire me twenty cunning cooks.

src: thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes: what eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?
trg: Thy head is as fun of quarrels as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarrelling:

src: He came with flowers to strew his lady's grave; And bid me stand aloof, and so I did: Anon comes one with light to ope the tomb; And by and by my master drew on him;
trg: And then I ran away to call the watch.

src: I have ta'en a due and wary note upon't: With whispering and most guilty diligence, In action all of precept, he did show me The way twice o'er.
trg: Are there no other tokens Between you 'greed concerning her observance?

src: We are convented Upon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts Inclinable to honour and advance The theme of our assembly.
trg: Which the rather We shall be blest to do, if he remember A kinder value of the people than He hath hereto prized them at.

src: Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow For tender princes, use my babies well! So foolish sorrow bids your stones farewell.
trg: Stand all apart Cousin of Buckingham!

src: Lest I might be too rash: Under your good correction, I have seen, When, after execution, judgment hath Repented o'er his doom.
trg: Go to; let that be mine: Do you your office, or give up your place, And you shall well be spared.

src: But I'll amerce you with so strong a fine That you shall all repent the loss of mine: I will be deaf to pleading and excuses; Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses: Therefore use none:
trg: let Romeo hence in haste, Else, when he's found, that hour is his last. Bear hence this body and attend our will: Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.

src: Meet on the market-place. We'll attend you there: Where, if you bring not Marcius, we'll proceed In our first way.
trg: I'll bring him to you. Let me desire your company: he must come, Or what is worst will follow.

src: O happy vantage of a kneeling knee! Yet am I sick for fear: speak it again; Twice saying 'pardon' doth not pardon twain, But makes one pardon strong.
trg: With all my heart I pardon him.

src: No more than when my daughters call thee mother. Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children; And, by God's mother, I, being but a bachelor, Have other some:
trg: why, 'tis a happy thing To be the father unto many sons. Answer no more, for thou shalt be my queen.

src: and truly I think if all our wits were to issue out of one skull, they would fly east, west, north, south, and their consent of one direct way should be at once to all the points o' the compass.
trg: Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would fly?

src: The parents live, whose children thou hast butcher'd, Old wither'd plants, to wail it with their age. Swear not by time to come; for that thou hast Misused ere used, by time misused o'erpast.
trg: As I intend to prosper and repent, So thrive I in my dangerous attempt Of hostile arms! myself myself confound! Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours! Day, yield me not thy light;

src: Knock, sir! whom should I knock? is there man has rebused your worship?
trg: Villain, I say, knock me here soundly.

src: Two, two; a shirt and a smock.
trg: Peter!

src: My holy sir, none better knows than you How I have ever loved the life removed And held in idle price to haunt assemblies Where youth, and cost, and witless bravery keeps.
trg: I have deliver'd to Lord Angelo, A man of stricture and firm abstinence, My absolute power and place here in Vienna, And he supposes me travell'd to Poland;

src: How is it with our general?
trg: Even so As with a man by his own alms empoison'd, And with his charity slain.

src: And turns the sun to shade; alas! alas! Witness my son, now in the shade of death; Whose bright out-shining beams thy cloudy wrath Hath in eternal darkness folded up.
trg: Your aery buildeth in our aery's nest. O God, that seest it, do not suffer it! As it was won with blood, lost be it so!

src: An if they live, I hope I need not fear. But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart, Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.
trg: Think you, my lord, this little prating York Was not incensed by his subtle mother To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

src: A laughter.
trg: A match!

src: Murdering impossibility, to make What cannot be, slight work.
trg: Thou art my warrior; I holp to frame thee. Do you know this lady?

src: all great doers in our trade, and are now 'for the Lord's sake.'
trg: Sirrah, bring Barnardine hither.

src: Good mother, be content; it is no more Than my poor life must answer.
trg: Thy life answer!

src: Here he comes, and in the gown of humility: mark his behavior. We are not to stay all together, but to come by him where he stands, by ones, by twos, and by threes.
trg: He's to make his requests by particulars; wherein every one of us has a single honour, in giving him our own voices with our own tongues:

src: Why, how now, sons and brother! at a strife? What is your quarrel? how began it first?
trg: No quarrel, but a slight contention.

src: Your guest, then, madam: To be your prisoner should import offending; Which is for me less easy to commit Than you to punish.
trg: Not your gaoler, then, But your kind hostess. Come, I'll question you Of my lord's tricks and yours when you were boys: You were pretty lordings then?

src: Methought their souls, whose bodies Richard murder'd, Came to my tent, and cried on victory: I promise you, my soul is very jocund In the remembrance of so fair a dream.
trg: How far into the morning is it, lords?

src: A footman, sweet sir, a footman.
