trg: Indeed, he should be a footman by the garments he has left with thee: if this be a horseman's coat, it hath seen very hot service. Lend me thy hand, I'll help thee: come, lend me thy hand.

src: Think what you will, we seize into our hands His plate, his goods, his money and his lands.
trg: I'll not be by the while: my liege, farewell: What will ensue hereof, there's none can tell; But by bad courses may be understood That their events can never fall out good.

src: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?
trg: A' has a little gall'd me, I confess; And, as the jest did glance away from me, 'Tis ten to one it maim'd you two outright.

src: Madam, your majesty is too much sad: You promised, when you parted with the king, To lay aside life-harming heaviness And entertain a cheerful disposition.
trg: To please the king I did; to please myself I cannot do it; yet I know no cause Why I should welcome such a guest as grief, Save bidding farewell to so sweet a guest As my sweet Richard:

src: Indeed, no, by your patience; I'll not over the threshold till my lord return from the wars.
trg: Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably: come, you must go visit the good lady that lies in.

src: and what they will inform, Merely in hate, 'gainst any of us all, That will the king severely prosecute 'Gainst us, our lives, our children, and our heirs.
trg: The commons hath he pill'd with grievous taxes, And quite lost their hearts: the nobles hath he fined For ancient quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.

src: What stay had we but Clarence? and he's gone.
trg: What stays had I but they? and they are gone.

src: As with a man busied about decrees: Condemning some to death, and some to exile; Ransoming him, or pitying, threatening the other;
trg: Holding Corioli in the name of Rome, Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash, To let him slip at will.

src: Agreed.
trg: Say, has our general met the enemy?

src: What, what? his choler?
trg: Choler! Were I as patient as the midnight sleep, By Jove, 'twould be my mind!

src: Setting your scorns and your mislike aside, Tell me some reason why the Lady Grey Should not become my wife and England's queen. And you too, Somerset and Montague, Speak freely what you think.
trg: Then this is mine opinion: that King Lewis Becomes your enemy, for mocking him About the marriage of the Lady Bona.

src: Huntsman, what say'st thou? wilt thou go along?
trg: Better do so than tarry and be hang'd.

src: Why, how now, Kate! I hope thou art not mad: This is a man, old, wrinkled, faded, wither'd, And not a maiden, as thou say'st he is.
trg: Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes, That have been so bedazzled with the sun That everything I look on seemeth green: Now I perceive thou art a reverend father;

src: I pray you stand good father to me now, Give me Bianca for my patrimony.
trg: Soft son! Sir, by your leave: having come to Padua To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio Made me acquainted with a weighty cause Of love between your daughter and himself:

src: if die, be brief, That our swift-winged souls may catch the king's; Or, like obedient subjects, follow him To his new kingdom of perpetual rest.
trg: Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow As I had title in thy noble husband! I have bewept a worthy husband's death, And lived by looking on his images:

src: I thank you. Fare you well.
trg: I shall desire you, sir, to give me leave To have free speech with you; and it concerns me To look into the bottom of my place: A power I have, but of what strength and nature I am not yet instructed.

src: My lord it shall be done.
trg: Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himself Upon thy wicked dam, come forth!

src: thoughts are no subjects; Intents but merely thoughts.
trg: Merely, my lord.

src: Why, bishop, is Norfolk dead?
trg: As surely as I live, my lord.

src: Well; what's your suit?
trg: There is a vice that most I do abhor, And most desire should meet the blow of justice; For which I would not plead, but that I must;

src: Past the mid season.
trg: At least two glasses. The time 'twixt six and now Must by us both be spent most preciously.

src: Courageously and with a free desire Attending but the signal to begin.
trg: Sound, trumpets; and set forward, combatants. Stay, the king hath thrown his warder down.

src: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king's fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.
trg: 'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.

src: I shall lack voice: the deeds of Coriolanus Should not be utter'd feebly. It is held That valour is the chiefest virtue, and Most dignifies the haver:
trg: if it be, The man I speak of cannot in the world Be singly counterpoised. At sixteen years, When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought Beyond the mark of others:

src: and they shall strike Your children yet unborn and unbegot, That lift your vassal hands against my head And threat the glory of my precious crown.
trg: Tell Bolingbroke--for yond methinks he stands-- That every stride he makes upon my land Is dangerous treason: he is come to open The purple testament of bleeding war;

src: But now two mirrors of his princely semblance Are crack'd in pieces by malignant death, And I for comfort have but one false glass, Which grieves me when I see my shame in him. Thou art a widow;
trg: yet thou art a mother, And hast the comfort of thy children left thee: But death hath snatch'd my husband from mine arms, And pluck'd two crutches from my feeble limbs, Edward and Clarence.

src: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.
trg: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?

src: The time and my intents are savage-wild, More fierce and more inexorable far Than empty tigers or the roaring sea.
trg: I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.

src: He, sir! a tapster, sir; parcel-bawd; one that serves a bad woman; whose house, sir, was, as they say, plucked down in the suburbs;
trg: and now she professes a hot-house, which, I think, is a very ill house too.

src: Good uncle, help to order several powers To Oxford, or where'er these traitors are: They shall not live within this world, I swear, But I will have them, if I once know where. Uncle, farewell:
trg: and, cousin too, adieu: Your mother well hath pray'd, and prove you true.

src: You taught me language; and my profit on't Is, I know how to curse. The red plague rid you For learning me your language!
trg: Hag-seed, hence! Fetch us in fuel; and be quick, thou'rt best, To answer other business. Shrug'st thou, malice?

src: all corners else o' the earth Let liberty make use of; space enough Have I in such a prison.
Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither; For he was fitter for that place than earth.
trg: And thou unfit for any place but hell.

src: If you affect him, sister, here I swear I'll plead for you myself, but you shall have him.
trg: O then, belike, you fancy riches more: You will have Gremio to keep you fair.

src: The dignity of this act was worth the audience of kings and princes; for by such was it acted.
trg: till, from one sign of dolour to another, she did, with an 'Alas,' I would fain say, bleed tears, for I am sure my heart wept blood. Who was most marble there changed colour;

src: Name of mercy, when was this, boy?
trg: Now, now: I have not winked since I saw these sights: the men are not yet cold under water, nor the bear half dined on the gentleman: he's at it now.

src: I do, my lord.
trg: For this new-married man approaching here, Whose salt imagination yet hath wrong'd Your well defended honour, you must pardon For Mariana's sake:' Haste still pays haste, and leisure answers leisure;

src: If any such be here--as God forbid!-- Let him depart before we need his help.
trg: Women and children of so high a courage, And warriors faint! why, 'twere perpetual shame. O brave young prince! thy famous grandfather Doth live again in thee:

src: To make you understand this in a manifested effect, I crave but four days' respite; for the which you are to do me both a present and a dangerous courtesy.
trg: Pray, sir, in what?

src: What, ho! Abhorson! Where's Abhorson, there?
trg: Do you call, sir?

src: Truly, officer, because he hath some offences in him that thou wouldst discover if thou couldst, let him continue in his courses till thou knowest what they are.
trg: Marry, I thank your worship for it. Thou seest, thou wicked varlet, now, what's come upon thee: thou art to continue now, thou varlet; thou art to continue.

src: Return, good Catesby, to thy lord again;
trg: Tell him, myself, the mayor and citizens, In deep designs and matters of great moment, No less importing than our general good, Are come to have some conference with his grace.

src: O me, O me! My child, my only life, Revive, look up, or I will die with thee! Help, help! Call help.
trg: For shame, bring Juliet forth; her lord is come.

src: Therein thou wrong'st thy children mightily.
trg: Herein your highness wrongs both them and me. But, mighty lord, this merry inclination Accords not with the sadness of my suit: Please you dismiss me either with 'ay' or 'no.'

src: As Hercules Did shake down mellow fruit. You have made fair work!
trg: But is this true, sir?

src: This is unlikely: He and Aufidius can no more atone Than violentest contrariety.
trg: You are sent for to the senate: A fearful army, led by Caius Marcius Associated with Aufidius, rages Upon our territories;

src: No, sir,'twas never my desire yet to trouble the poor with begging.
trg: You must think, if we give you any thing, we hope to gain by you.

src: Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.
trg: But is he gracious in the people's eye?

src: I am a poor fellow, sir.
trg: Why, be so still; here's nobody will steal that from thee: yet for the outside of thy poverty we must make an exchange;

src: Dispatch, I prithee.
trg: Indeed, I have had earnest: but I cannot with conscience take it.

src: Knock at the gate! O heavens! Spake you not these words plain, 'Sirrah, knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly'? And come you now with, 'knocking at the gate'?
trg: Sirrah, be gone, or talk not, I advise you.

src: Vouchsafe a word, young sister, but one word.
trg: What is your will?

src: our then dictator, Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight, When with his Amazonian chin he drove The bristled lips before him:
trg: be bestrid An o'er-press'd Roman and i' the consul's view Slew three opposers: Tarquin's self he met, And struck him on his knee:

src: Bring me to hear them speak, where I may be concealed.
trg: Now, sister, what's the comfort?

src: My poverty, but not my will, consents.
trg: I pay thy poverty, and not thy will.

src: Wine, wine, wine! What service is here! I think our fellows are asleep.
trg: Where's Cotus? my master calls for him. Cotus!

src: But, wrangling pedant, this is The patroness of heavenly harmony: Then give me leave to have prerogative; And when in music we have spent an hour, Your lecture shall have leisure for as much.
trg: Preposterous ass, that never read so far To know the cause why music was ordain'd! Was it not to refresh the mind of man After his studies or his usual pain?

src: Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve.
trg: Your grant, or your denial, shall be mine: Yet I confess that often ere this day, When I have heard your king's desert recounted, Mine ear hath tempted judgment to desire.

src: This same should be the voice of Friar John. Welcome from Mantua: what says Romeo? Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.
trg: So that my speed to Mantua there was stay'd.

src: Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit For your best health and recreation.
trg: I do not like the Tower, of any place. Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

src: And so it is: I wonder what it bodes.
trg: Marry, peace it bodes, and love and quiet life, And awful rule and right supremacy; And, to be short, what not, that's sweet and happy?

src: Chop off his head, man; somewhat we will do: And, look, when I am king, claim thou of me The earldom of Hereford, and the moveables Whereof the king my brother stood possess'd.
trg: I'll claim that promise at your grace's hands.

src: Thou, Richard, shalt to the Duke of Norfolk, And tell him privily of our intent. You Edward, shall unto my Lord Cobham, With whom the Kentishmen will willingly rise: In them I trust;
trg: for they are soldiers, Witty, courteous, liberal, full of spirit.

src: Well, be't so, prithee. Here's such ado to make no stain a stain As passes colouring. Dear gentlewoman, How fares our gracious lady?
trg: As well as one so great and so forlorn May hold together: on her frights and griefs, Which never tender lady hath born greater, She is something before her time deliver'd.

src: Ladies, you deserve To have a temple built you: all the swords In Italy, and her confederate arms, Could not have made this peace.
trg: See you yond coign o' the Capitol, yond corner-stone?

src: Sir, your honour cannot come to that yet.
trg: No, sir, nor I mean it not.

src: Hold; get you gone, be strong and prosperous In this resolve: I'll send a friar with speed To Mantua, with my letters to thy lord.
trg: Love give me strength! and strength shall help afford. Farewell, dear father!

src: Verily, I speak it in the freedom of my knowledge: we cannot with such magnificence--in so rare--I know not what to say.
trg: We will give you sleepy drinks, that your senses, unintelligent of our insufficience, may, though they cannot praise us, as little accuse us.

src: For, by this light, whereby I see thy beauty, Thy beauty, that doth make me like thee well, Thou must be married to no man but me;
trg: For I am he am born to tame you Kate, And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate Conformable as other household Kates. Here comes your father: never make denial;

src: Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost-- Which, I dare vouch, is more than that he hath, By many an ounce--he dropp'd it for his country;
trg: And what is left, to lose it by his country, Were to us all, that do't and suffer it, A brand to the end o' the world.

src: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.
trg: Could you not take some occasion without giving?

src: with him, the portion and sinew of her fortune, her marriage-dowry; with both, her combinate husband, this well-seeming Angelo.
trg: Can this be so? did Angelo so leave her?

src: Here: what's the matter?
trg: The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms.

src: Why, then, thy husband's lands I freely give thee.
trg: I take my leave with many thousand thanks.

src: But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam; But like a foul mis-shapen stigmatic, Mark'd by the destinies to be avoided, As venom toads, or lizards' dreadful stings.
trg: A wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns, To make this shameless callet know herself. Helen of Greece was fairer far than thou, Although thy husband may be Menelaus;

src: The custom of request you have discharged: The people do admit you, and are summon'd To meet anon, upon your approbation.
trg: Where? at the senate-house?

src: Let's all sink with the king.
trg: Let's take leave of him.

src: I' the city of kites and crows.
trg: I' the city of kites and crows! What an ass it is! Then thou dwellest with daws too?

src: Why, true; he means to make a puppet of thee.
trg: She says your worship means to make a puppet of her.

src: Marry. God forbid! Worst in this royal presence may I speak, Yet best beseeming me to speak the truth. Would God that any in this noble presence Were enough noble to be upright judge Of noble Richard!
trg: then true noblesse would Learn him forbearance from so foul a wrong. What subject can give sentence on his king? And who sits here that is not Richard's subject?

src: We are blest in this man, as I may say, even blest.
trg: Let's before as he bids us: he was provided to do us good.

src: Where is the duke my father with his power?
trg: No matter where; of comfort no man speak: Let's talk of graves, of worms, and epitaphs;

src: My father's loss, the weakness which I feel, The wreck of all my friends, nor this man's threats, To whom I am subdued, are but light to me, Might I but through my prison once a day Behold this maid:
trg: all corners else o' the earth Let liberty make use of; space enough Have I in such a prison.

src: But theirs is sweetened with the hope to have The present benefit which I possess; And hope to joy is little less in joy Than hope enjoy'd:
trg: by this the weary lords Shall make their way seem short, as mine hath done By sight of what I have, your noble company.

src: Nay, rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence, Confess who set thee up and pluck'd thee own, Call Warwick patron and be penitent? And thou shalt still remain the Duke of York.
trg: I thought, at least, he would have said the king; Or did he make the jest against his will?

src: But wherefore stay we? 'tis no time to talk.
trg: Huntsman, what say'st thou? wilt thou go along?

src: Mistake me not, my lord; 'tis not my meaning To raze one title of your honour out:
trg: I shall not need transport my words by you; Here comes his grace in person. My noble uncle!

src: Pray, be content: Mother, I am going to the market-place; Chide me no more. I'll mountebank their loves, Cog their hearts from them, and come home beloved Of all the trades in Rome. Look, I am going:
trg: Commend me to my wife. I'll return consul; Or never trust to what my tongue can do I' the way of flattery further.

src: daffodils, That come before the swallow dares, and take The winds of March with beauty; violets dim, But sweeter than the lids of Juno's eyes Or Cytherea's breath;
trg: pale primroses That die unmarried, ere they can behold Bight Phoebus in his strength--a malady Most incident to maids; bold oxlips and The crown imperial;

src: Howsoever you have been his liar, as you say you have, I am one that, telling true under him, must say, you cannot pass. Therefore, go back.
trg: Has he dined, canst thou tell? for I would not speak with him till after dinner.

src: then, even now, I might have look'd upon my queen's full eyes, Have taken treasure from her lips--
trg: And left them More rich for what they yielded.

src: He professes to have received no sinister measure from his judge, but most willingly humbles himself to the determination of justice:
trg: yet had he framed to himself, by the instruction of his frailty, many deceiving promises of life; which I by my good leisure have discredited to him, and now is he resolved to die.

src: By this, I hope, she hath a son for me. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Good day, my lord. What, at your book so hard?

src: I do it not in evil disposition, But from Lord Angelo by special charge.
trg: Thus can the demigod Authority Make us pay down for our offence by weight The words of heaven; on whom it will, it will; On whom it will not, so; yet still 'tis just.

src: Think'st thou I am an executioner?
trg: A persecutor, I am sure, thou art: If murdering innocents be executing, Why, then thou art an executioner.

src: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.
trg: If that thy bent of love be honourable, Thy purpose marriage, send me word to-morrow, By one that I'll procure to come to thee, Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite;

src: Such duty as the subject owes the prince Even such a woman oweth to her husband;
trg: And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour, And not obedient to his honest will, What is she but a foul contending rebel And graceless traitor to her loving lord?

src: Ay, sir; a mystery
trg: Painting, sir, I have heard say, is a mystery; and your whores, sir, being members of my occupation, using painting, do prove my occupation a mystery:

src: but when they weep and kneel, All their petitions are as freely theirs As they themselves would owe them.
trg: I'll see what I can do.

src: My life, sir! how, I pray? for that goes hard.
trg: 'Tis death for any one in Mantua To come to Padua. Know you not the cause?

src: He thinks, nay, with all confidence he swears, As he had seen't or been an instrument To vice you to't, that you have touch'd his queen Forbiddenly.
trg: O, then my best blood turn To an infected jelly and my name Be yoked with his that did betray the Best!

src: Why, madam, so, no doubt, he is.
trg: I hope he is; but yet let mothers doubt.

src: And given unto the house of York such head As thou shalt reign but by their sufferance.
trg: To entail him and his heirs unto the crown, What is it, but to make thy sepulchre And creep into it far before thy time? Warwick is chancellor and the lord of Calais;

src: I say she's dead; I'll swear't. If word nor oath Prevail not, go and see:
trg: if you can bring Tincture or lustre in her lip, her eye, Heat outwardly or breath within, I'll serve you As I would do the gods. But, O thou tyrant!

src: Let me pass The same I am, ere ancient'st order was Or what is now received: I witness to The times that brought them in;
trg: so shall I do To the freshest things now reigning and make stale The glistering of this present, as my tale Now seems to it.

src: Nay, but speak not maliciously.
trg: I say unto you, what he hath done famously, he did it to that end: though soft-conscienced men can be content to say it was for his country he did it to please his mother and to be partly proud;

src: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had! O courteous Tybalt! honest gentleman! That ever I should live to see thee dead!
trg: What storm is this that blows so contrary? Is Romeo slaughter'd, and is Tybalt dead? My dear-loved cousin, and my dearer lord? Then, dreadful trumpet, sound the general doom!

src: I Do come with words as medicinal as true, Honest as either, to purge him of that humour That presses him from sleep.
trg: What noise there, ho?

src: Having no more but thought of what thou wert, To torture thee the more, being what thou art. Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?
trg: Now thy proud neck bears half my burthen'd yoke; From which even here I slip my weary neck, And leave the burthen of it all on thee. Farewell, York's wife, and queen of sad mischance:

src: Vex not yourself, nor strive not with your breath; For all in vain comes counsel to his ear.
trg: O, but they say the tongues of dying men Enforce attention like deep harmony: Where words are scarce, they are seldom spent in vain, For they breathe truth that breathe their words in pain.

src: Art thou my son?
trg: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

src: Ay, fool; is that a shame? Note but this fool. Was not a man my father? Hadst thou foxship To banish him that struck more blows for Rome Than thou hast spoken words?
trg: O blessed heavens!

src: See not your bride in these unreverent robes: Go to my chamber; Put on clothes of mine.
trg: Not I, believe me: thus I'll visit her.

src: Consider this: he has been bred i' the wars Since he could draw a sword, and is ill school'd In bolted language; meal and bran together He throws without distinction.
trg: Give me leave, I'll go to him, and undertake to bring him Where he shall answer, by a lawful form, In peace, to his utmost peril.

src: I am always bound to you.
trg: Very well met, and well come. What is the news from this good deputy?

src: I'll find out your man, And he shall signify from time to time Every good hap to you that chances here: Give me thy hand; 'tis late: farewell; good night.
trg: But that a joy past joy calls out on me, It were a grief, so brief to part with thee: Farewell.

src: My liege, one word.
trg: He does me double wrong That wounds me with the flatteries of his tongue. Discharge my followers: let them hence away, From Richard's night to Bolingbroke's fair day.

src: There was a man--
trg: Nay, come, sit down; then on.
Hope I may choose, sir.

src: Condemn the fault and not the actor of it? Why, every fault's condemn'd ere it be done:
trg: Mine were the very cipher of a function, To fine the faults whose fine stands in record, And let go by the actor.

src: What, my lord?
trg: Ere a fortnight make me elder, I'll send some packing that yet think not on it.

src: The duke's in us; and we will hear you speak: Look you speak justly.
trg: Boldly, at least. But, O, poor souls, Come you to seek the lamb here of the fox? Good night to your redress! Is the duke gone? Then is your cause gone too.

src: Has the old man e'er a son, sir, do you hear. an't like you, sir?
trg: He has a son, who shall be flayed alive; then 'nointed over with honey, set on the head of a wasp's nest; then stand till he be three quarters and a dram dead;

src: You are well met, sir. You denied to fight with me this other day, because I was no gentleman born. See you these clothes? say you see them not and think me still no gentleman born:
trg: you were best say these robes are not gentlemen born: give me the lie, do, and try whether I am not now a gentleman born.

src: Come, you are a tedious fool: to the purpose. What was done to Elbow's wife, that he hath cause to complain of? Come me to what was done to her.
trg: Sir, your honour cannot come to that yet.

src: She it is.
trg: O, let him marry her.

src: Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.
trg: Here is everything advantageous to life.

src: What, my gracious lord?
trg: An if I live until I be a man, I'll win our ancient right in France again, Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.

src: The princes both make high account of you; For they account his head upon the bridge.
trg: I know they do; and I have well deserved it. Come on, come on; where is your boar-spear, man? Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?

src: You are too senseless--obstinate, my lord, Too ceremonious and traditional Weigh it but with the grossness of this age, You break not sanctuary in seizing him.
trg: The benefit thereof is always granted To those whose dealings have deserved the place, And those who have the wit to claim the place: This prince hath neither claim'd it nor deserved it;

src: But this is something odd.
trg: An 'twere to give again,--but 'tis no matter.

src: The aediles, ho! Let him be apprehended.
trg: Go, call the people: in whose name myself Attach thee as a traitorous innovator, A foe to the public weal: obey, I charge thee, And follow to thine answer.

src: Edward and Richard, like a brace of greyhounds Having the fearful flying hare in sight, With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath, And bloody steel grasp'd in their ireful hands, Are at our backs;
trg: and therefore hence amain.

src: Gallop apace, you fiery-footed steeds, Towards Phoebus' lodging: such a wagoner As Phaethon would whip you to the west, And bring in cloudy night immediately.
trg: Spread thy close curtain, love-performing night, That runaway's eyes may wink and Romeo Leap to these arms, untalk'd of and unseen. Lovers can see to do their amorous rites By their own beauties;

src: I think his understanding is bereft. Speak, Clifford, dost thou know who speaks to thee? Dark cloudy death o'ershades his beams of life, And he nor sees nor hears us what we say.
trg: O, would he did! and so perhaps he doth: 'Tis but his policy to counterfeit, Because he would avoid such bitter taunts Which in the time of death he gave our father.

src: Come, sir, leave me your snatches, and yield me a direct answer. To-morrow morning are to die Claudio and Barnardine. Here is in our prison a common executioner, who in his office lacks a helper:
trg: if you will take it on you to assist him, it shall redeem you from your gyves;

src: How now! what news?
trg: The Duke of Norfolk sends you word by me, The queen is coming with a puissant host; And craves your company for speedy counsel.

src: What sport shall we devise here in this garden, To drive away the heavy thought of care?
trg: Madam, we'll play at bowls.

src: Take it up.
trg: I swear to do this, though a present death Had been more merciful. Come on, poor babe: Some powerful spirit instruct the kites and ravens To be thy nurses!

src: Do not swear at all; Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And I'll believe thee.
trg: If my heart's dear love--

src: You are too blunt: go to it orderly.
trg: You wrong me, Signior Gremio: give me leave.

src: You guard like men; 'tis well: but, by your leave, I am an officer of state, and come To speak with Coriolanus.
trg: From whence?

src: Injurious Margaret!
trg: And why not queen?

src: Had our prince, Jewel of children, seen this hour, he had pair'd Well with this lord: there was not full a month Between their births.
trg: Prithee, no more; cease; thou know'st He dies to me again when talk'd of: sure, When I shall see this gentleman, thy speeches Will bring me to consider that which may Unfurnish me of reason.

src: O Warwick, Warwick! that Plantagenet, Which held three dearly as his soul's redemption, Is by the stern Lord Clifford done to death.
trg: Ten days ago I drown'd these news in tears; And now, to add more measure to your woes, I come to tell you things sith then befall'n.

src: they throng who should buy first, as if my trinkets had been hallowed and brought a benediction to the buyer: by which means I saw whose purse was best in picture;
trg: and what I saw, to my good use I remembered.

src: Cousins, indeed; and by their uncle cozen'd Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life. Whose hand soever lanced their tender hearts, Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction:
trg: No doubt the murderous knife was dull and blunt Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart, To revel in the entrails of my lambs.

src: Lest parties, as he is beloved, break out, And sack great Rome with Romans.
trg: If it were so,--

src: Yet give leave, my lord, That we may bring you something on the way.
trg: My haste may not admit it; Nor need you, on mine honour, have to do With any scruple; your scope is as mine own So to enforce or qualify the laws As to your soul seems good. Give me your hand:

src: Are you of fourscore pounds a year?
trg: Yes, an't please you, sir.

src: I had thought, my lord, to have learn'd his health of you.
trg: Why, is he not with the queen?

src: And daily new exactions are devised, As blanks, benevolences, and I wot not what: But what, o' God's name, doth become of this?
trg: Wars have not wasted it, for warr'd he hath not, But basely yielded upon compromise That which his noble ancestors achieved with blows: More hath he spent in peace than they in wars.

src: And shows good husbandry for the Volscian state, Fights dragon-like, and does achieve as soon As draw his sword;
trg: yet he hath left undone That which shall break his neck or hazard mine, Whene'er we come to our account.

src: I will not rise, unless your highness grant.
trg: Then speak at once what is it thou demand'st.
I have lived To see inherited my very wishes And the buildings of my fancy: only There's one thing wanting, which I doubt not but Our Rome will cast upon thee.

src: Do you so, sir? And was the duke a fleshmonger, a fool, and a coward, as you then reported him to be?
trg: You must, sir, change persons with me, ere you make that my report: you, indeed, spoke so of him; and much more, much worse.

src: Still live they and for ever may they last!
trg: O Buckingham, now do I play the touch, To try if thou be current gold indeed Young Edward lives: think now what I would say.

src: That, if you fail in our request, the blame May hang upon your hardness: therefore hear us.
trg: Aufidius, and you Volsces, mark; for we'll Hear nought from Rome in private. Your request?

src: Tedious it were to tell, and harsh to hear: Sufficeth I am come to keep my word, Though in some part enforced to digress;
trg: Which, at more leisure, I will so excuse As you shall well be satisfied withal. But where is Kate? I stay too long from her: The morning wears, 'tis time we were at church.

src: Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!
trg: No more of this; it does offend my heart: Pray now, no more.

src: Alas, poor Clarence! is it for a wife That thou art malcontent? I will provide thee.
trg: In choosing for yourself, you show'd your judgment, Which being shallow, you give me leave To play the broker in mine own behalf; And to that end I shortly mind to leave you.

src: No, in such a case the gods will not be good unto us. When we banished him, we respected not them; and, he returning to break our necks, they respect not us.
trg: Sir, if you'ld save your life, fly to your house:

src: No more words, we beseech you.
trg: How! no more!

src: What is this? Your knees to me? to your corrected son? Then let the pebbles on the hungry beach Fillip the stars; then let the mutinous winds Strike the proud cedars 'gainst the fiery sun;
trg: Murdering impossibility, to make What cannot be, slight work.

src: The nature of our people, Our city's institutions, and the terms For common justice, you're as pregnant in As art and practise hath enriched any That we remember.
trg: There is our commission, From which we would not have you warp. Call hither, I say, bid come before us Angelo. What figure of us think you he will bear?

src: Are you so formal, sir? well, I must wait, And watch withal; for, but I be deceived, Our fine musician groweth amorous.
trg: Madam, before you touch the instrument, To learn the order of my fingering, I must begin with rudiments of art;

src: I have done. Come, you promised me a tawdry-lace and a pair of sweet gloves.
trg: Have I not told thee how I was cozened by the way and lost all my money?

src: Sir, but you shall come to it, by your honour's leave. And, I beseech you, look into Master Froth here, sir; a man of four-score pound a year; whose father died at Hallowmas:
trg: was't not at Hallowmas, Master Froth?

src: And thus I seal my truth, and bid adieu.
trg: Sweet Oxford, and my loving Montague, And all at once, once more a happy farewell.

src: And that is more than I will yield unto: I know I am too mean to be your queen, And yet too good to be your concubine.
trg: You cavil, widow: I did mean, my queen.

src: yet you Pilates Have here deliver'd me to my sour cross, And water cannot wash away your sin.
trg: My lord, dispatch; read o'er these articles.

src: Even he, Biondello.
trg: Hark you, sir; you mean not her to--
Well, let us to the king: there is that in this fardel will make him scratch his beard.

src: 'Tis thought the king is dead; we will not stay. The bay-trees in our country are all wither'd And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven;
trg: The pale-faced moon looks bloody on the earth And lean-look'd prophets whisper fearful change;

src: Think not the king did banish thee, But thou the king. Woe doth the heavier sit, Where it perceives it is but faintly borne. Go, say I sent thee forth to purchase honour And not the king exiled thee;
trg: or suppose Devouring pestilence hangs in our air And thou art flying to a fresher clime: Look, what thy soul holds dear, imagine it To lie that way thou go'st, not whence thou comest:

src: Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.
trg: Pretty! What say you, Hugh Rebeck?

src: Most royal sir, from thence; from him, whose daughter His tears proclaim'd his, parting with her:
trg: thence, A prosperous south-wind friendly, we have cross'd, To execute the charge my father gave me For visiting your highness: my best train I have from your Sicilian shores dismiss'd;

src: Ay, for if Edward repossess the crown, 'Tis like that Richmond with the rest shall down.
trg: It shall be so; he shall to Brittany. Come, therefore, let's about it speedily. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: and how the poor gentleman roared and the bear mocked him, both roaring louder than the sea or weather.
trg: Name of mercy, when was this, boy?

src: Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike betwitched by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love's sweet bait from fearful hooks:
trg: Being held a foe, he may not have access To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear; And she as much in love, her means much less To meet her new-beloved any where:

src: A mad-cup ruffian and a swearing Jack, That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.
trg: Father, 'tis thus: yourself and all the world, That talk'd of her, have talk'd amiss of her: If she be curst, it is for policy, For she's not froward, but modest as the dove;

src: Troth, sir, she hath eaten up all her beef, and she is herself in the tub.
trg: Why, 'tis good; it is the right of it; it must be so: ever your fresh whore and your powdered bawd: an unshunned consequence; it must be so. Art going to prison, Pompey?

src: Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure, If presently you will take horse with him, And with all speed post with him toward the north, To shun the danger that his soul divines.
trg: Go, fellow, go, return unto thy lord;

src: She will not stay the siege of loving terms, Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes, Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:
trg: O, she is rich in beauty, only poor, That when she dies with beauty dies her store.

src: Be Duke of Lancaster; let him be king.
trg: He is both king and Duke of Lancaster; And that the Lord of Westmoreland shall maintain.

src: Had not you come upon your cue, my lord William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part,-- I mean, your voice,--for crowning of the king.
trg: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder; His lordship knows me well, and loves me well.

src: Faith, nothing; but has left me here behind, to expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.
trg: I pray thee, moralize them.

src: They mock thee, Clifford: swear as thou wast wont.
trg: What, not an oath? nay, then the world goes hard When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath. I know by that he's dead;

src: Why, my young cousin, it is good to grow.
trg: Grandam, one night, as we did sit at supper, My uncle Rivers talk'd how I did grow More than my brother: 'Ay,' quoth my uncle Gloucester, 'Small herbs have grace, great weeds do grow apace:

src: seld-shown flamens Do press among the popular throngs and puff To win a vulgar station:
trg: or veil'd dames Commit the war of white and damask in Their nicely-gawded cheeks to the wanton spoil Of Phoebus' burning kisses:

src: 'Tis good; though music oft hath such a charm To make bad good, and good provoke to harm. I pray, you, tell me, hath any body inquired for me here to-day?
trg: much upon this time have I promised here to meet.

src: Ay.
trg: Why, in good time.

src: Why shall we fight, if you pretend no title?
trg: Why, brother, wherefore stand you on nice points?

src: 'Twas odds, belike, when valiant Warwick fled: Oft have I heard his praises in pursuit, But ne'er till now his scandal of retire.
trg: Nor now my scandal, Richard, dost thou hear;

src: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge Myself condemned and myself excused.
trg: Then say at once what thou dost know in this.

src: Therefore your best appointment make with speed; To-morrow you set on.
trg: Is there no remedy?

src: Why give you me this shame? Think you I can a resolution fetch From flowery tenderness? If I must die, I will encounter darkness as a bride, And hug it in mine arms.
trg: There spake my brother; there my father's grave Did utter forth a voice. Yes, thou must die: Thou art too noble to conserve a life In base appliances.

src: 'Tis so with me. Let us withdraw together, And we may soon our satisfaction have Touching that point.
trg: I'll wait upon your honour.

src: Let's not meet her.
trg: Why?

src: Is any woman wrong'd by this lewd fellow, As I have heard him swear himself there's one Whom he begot with child, let her appear, And he shall marry her:
trg: the nuptial finish'd, Let him be whipt and hang'd.

src: Why, then let's home again. Come, sirrah, let's away.
trg: Nay, I will give thee a kiss: now pray thee, love, stay.

src: You were not bid to speak.
trg: No, my good lord; Nor wish'd to hold my peace.

src: I fear it is too choleric a meat. How say you to a fat tripe finely broil'd?
trg: I like it well: good Grumio, fetch it me.

src: I may not, madam: To the contrary I have express commandment.
trg: Here's ado, To lock up honesty and honour from The access of gentle visitors! Is't lawful, pray you, To see her women? any of them? Emilia?

src: Convenient is it. Make a swift return; For I would commune with you of such things That want no ear but yours.
trg: I'll make all speed.

src: You'll leave his lecture when I am in tune?
trg: That will be never: tune your instrument.

src: Richard hath best deserved of all my sons. But is your grace dead, my Lord of Somerset?
trg: Such hope have all the line of John of Gaunt!

src: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business: I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.
trg: Swear, if thou darest.

src: Yonder comes news. A wager they have met.
trg: My horse to yours, no.

src: Have you Ere now denied the asker? and now again Of him that did not ask, but mock, bestow Your sued-for tongues?
trg: He's not confirm'd; we may deny him yet.

src: Accursed be he that seeks to make them foes!
trg: Farewell, my gracious lord; I'll to my castle.

src: He is coming.
trg: When will he be here?

src: I warrant your honour.
trg: The warrants for yourself; take heed to't.

src: Shall remain! Hear you this Triton of the minnows? mark you His absolute 'shall'?
trg: 'Twas from the canon.

src: If the event o' the journey Prove as successful to the queen,--O be't so!-- As it hath been to us rare, pleasant, speedy, The time is worth the use on't.
trg: Great Apollo Turn all to the best! These proclamations, So forcing faults upon Hermione, I little like.

src: 'Tis with cares.
trg: I care not.

src: My liege, the Duke of Buckingham is taken; That is the best news: that the Earl of Richmond Is with a mighty power landed at Milford, Is colder tidings, yet they must be told.
trg: Away towards Salisbury! while we reason here, A royal battle might be won and lost Some one take order Buckingham be brought To Salisbury; the rest march on with me.

src: For I have heard it said There is an art which in their piedness shares With great creating nature.
trg: Say there be; Yet nature is made better by no mean But nature makes that mean: so, over that art Which you say adds to nature, is an art That nature makes.

src: Master, you look'd so longly on the maid, Perhaps you mark'd not what's the pith of all.
trg: O yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face, Such as the daughter of Agenor had, That made great Jove to humble him to her hand. When with his knees he kiss'd the Cretan strand.

src: 'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.
trg: My father's death--

src: There was a friar told me of this man. Sirrah, thou art said to have a stubborn soul. That apprehends no further than this world, And squarest thy life according. Thou'rt condemn'd:
trg: But, for those earthly faults, I quit them all; And pray thee take this mercy to provide For better times to come. Friar, advise him; I leave him to your hand. What muffled fellow's that?

src: My liege, the wound that bred this meeting here Cannot be cured by words; therefore be still.
trg: Then, executioner, unsheathe thy sword: By him that made us all, I am resolved that Clifford's manhood lies upon his tongue.

src: He shall not, Isabel, if you give me love.
trg: I know your virtue hath a licence in't, Which seems a little fouler than it is, To pluck on others.

src: My lord, I know a discontented gentleman, Whose humble means match not his haughty mind: Gold were as good as twenty orators, And will, no doubt, tempt him to any thing.
trg: What is his name?

src: Bound to himself! what doth he with a bond That he is bound to? Wife, thou art a fool. Boy, let me see the writing.
trg: I do beseech you, pardon me; I may not show it.

src: Sweet Duke of York, our prop to lean upon, Now thou art gone, we have no staff, no stay. O Clifford, boisterous Clifford! thou hast slain The flower of Europe for his chivalry;
trg: And treacherously hast thou vanquish'd him, For hand to hand he would have vanquish'd thee. Now my soul's palace is become a prison:

src: 'Tis false.
trg: How! know you where you are?

src: If the king had no son, they would desire to live on crutches till he had one.
trg: Nine changes of the watery star hath been The shepherd's note since we have left our throne Without a burthen: time as long again Would be find up, my brother, with our thanks;

src: How will my mother for a father's death Take on with me and ne'er be satisfied!
trg: How will my wife for slaughter of my son Shed seas of tears and ne'er be satisfied!

src: So you have: but I was a gentleman born before my father; for the king's son took me by the hand, and called me brother; and then the two kings called my father brother;
trg: and then the prince my brother and the princess my sister called my father father; and so we wept, and there was the first gentleman-like tears that ever we shed.

src: It is, it is: hie hence, be gone, away! It is the lark that sings so out of tune, Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps. Some say the lark makes sweet division;
trg: This doth not so, for she divideth us: Some say the lark and loathed toad change eyes, O, now I would they had changed voices too!

src: Away!
trg: How! away!

src: Thou fond mad man, hear me but speak a word.
trg: O, thou wilt speak again of banishment.

src: Away with her, and waft her hence to France. And now what rests but that we spend the time With stately triumphs, mirthful comic shows, Such as befits the pleasure of the court?
trg: Sound drums and trumpets! farewell sour annoy! For here, I hope, begins our lasting joy.

src: I follow you.
trg: Cambio!

src: The heads of the maids?
trg: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads; take it in what sense thou wilt.

src: But think you, lords, that Clifford fled with them?
trg: No, 'tis impossible he should escape, For, though before his face I speak the words Your brother Richard mark'd him for the grave: And wheresoe'er he is, he's surely dead.

src: Peace, wilful boy, or I will charm your tongue.
trg: Untutor'd lad, thou art too malapert.

src: You have put me now to such a part which never I shall discharge to the life.
trg: Come, come, we'll prompt you.

src: But when I came, some minute ere the time Of her awaking, here untimely lay The noble Paris and true Romeo dead. She wakes; and I entreated her come forth, And bear this work of heaven with patience:
trg: But then a noise did scare me from the tomb; And she, too desperate, would not go with me, But, as it seems, did violence on herself. All this I know; and to the marriage Her nurse is privy:

src: Skulking in corners? wishing clocks more swift? Hours, minutes? noon, midnight? and all eyes Blind with the pin and web but theirs, theirs only, That would unseen be wicked? is this nothing?
trg: Why, then the world and all that's in't is nothing; The covering sky is nothing; Bohemia nothing; My wife is nothing; nor nothing have these nothings, If this be nothing.

src: Not I, believe me: you have dancing shoes With nimble soles: I have a soul of lead So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.
trg: You are a lover; borrow Cupid's wings, And soar with them above a common bound.

src: Why, 'tis not amiss, Pompey. Farewell: go, say I sent thee thither. For debt, Pompey? or how?
trg: For being a bawd, for being a bawd.

src: Then, good my lords, bear witness to his oath.
trg: You tempt him over-much.

src: So please you, this friar hath been with him, and advised him for the entertainment of death.
trg: Good even, good father.

src: were he meal'd with that Which he corrects, then were he tyrannous; But this being so, he's just. Now are they come. This is a gentle provost: seldom when The steeled gaoler is the friend of men.
trg: How now! what noise? That spirit's possessed with haste That wounds the unsisting postern with these strokes.

src: but if one present The abhorr'd ingredient to his eye, make known How he hath drunk, he cracks his gorge, his sides, With violent hefts. I have drunk, and seen the spider.
trg: Camillo was his help in this, his pander: There is a plot against my life, my crown; All's true that is mistrusted: that false villain Whom I employ'd was pre-employ'd by him:

src: Why linger we? let us lay hands upon him.
trg: Forbear awhile; we'll hear a little more.

src: And what shall become of those in the city?
trg: They shall stand for seed: they had gone down too, but that a wise burgher put in for them.

src: It lies much in your holding up. Haste you speedily to Angelo: if for this night he entreat you to his bed, give him promise of satisfaction. I will presently to Saint Luke's:
trg: there, at the moated grange, resides this dejected Mariana. At that place call upon me; and dispatch with Angelo, that it may be quickly.

src: We hope to find you our friend; and therefore give you our voices heartily.
trg: You have received many wounds for your country.

src: O my most gracious lord, I hope you will not mock me with a husband.
trg: It is your husband mock'd you with a husband. Consenting to the safeguard of your honour, I thought your marriage fit;

src: I'll be at charges for a looking-glass, And entertain some score or two of tailors, To study fashions to adorn my body: Since I am crept in favour with myself, Will maintain it with some little cost.
trg: But first I'll turn yon fellow in his grave; And then return lamenting to my love. Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass, That I may see my shadow as I pass.

src: We pray with heart and soul and all beside: His weary joints would gladly rise, I know; Our knees shall kneel till to the ground they grow: His prayers are full of false hypocrisy;
trg: Ours of true zeal and deep integrity. Our prayers do out-pray his; then let them have That mercy which true prayer ought to have.

src: Why, is not Oxford here another anchor? And Somerset another goodly mast? The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings?
trg: And, though unskilful, why not Ned and I For once allow'd the skilful pilot's charge?

src: Unless his noble mother, and his wife; Who, as I hear, mean to solicit him For mercy to his country. Therefore, let's hence, And with our fair entreaties haste them on.
trg: Stay: whence are you?

src: I have.
trg: Face not me: thou hast braved many men; brave not me; I will neither be faced nor braved. I say unto thee, I bid thy master cut out the gown; but I did not bid him cut it to pieces: ergo, thou liest.

src: By my heel, I care not.
trg: Follow me close, for I will speak to them. Gentlemen, good den: a word with one of you.

src: I must and will have Katharina to my wife.
trg: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?

src: My conscience tells me he is lawful king.
Now, by my mother's son, and that's myself, It shall be moon, or star, or what I list, Or ere I journey to your father's house. Go on, and fetch our horses back again. Evermore cross'd and cross'd;
trg: nothing but cross'd!

src: My lord, some two days since I saw the prince, And told him of those triumphs held at Oxford.
trg: And what said the gallant?

src: A single thing, as I am now, that wonders To hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me; And that he does I weep:
trg: myself am Naples, Who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheld The king my father wreck'd.

src: How! Away with that audacious lady! Antigonus, I charged thee that she should not come about me: I knew she would.
trg: I told her so, my lord, On your displeasure's peril and on mine, She should not visit you.

src: Ay, in despite of all that shall withstand you.
trg: Why, so! then am I sure of victory. Now therefore let us hence; and lose no hour, Till we meet Warwick with his foreign power. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: This is strange.
trg: Go, get you home, you fragments!

src: I'll to dinner: hie you to the cell.
trg: Hie to high fortune! Honest nurse, farewell.

src: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay, To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away.
trg: Good-morrow, cousin.

src: Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?
trg: Whilst, in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts, Which here we waken to our country's good, This noble isle doth want her proper limbs;

src: Do't! he will do't; for, look you, sir, he has as many friends as enemies;
trg: which friends, sir, as it were, durst not, look you, sir, show themselves, as we term it, his friends whilst he's in directitude.

src: Thy son I kill'd for his presumption.
trg: Hadst thou been kill'd when first thou didst presume, Thou hadst not lived to kill a son of mine. The owl shriek'd at thy birth,--an evil sign; The night-crow cried, aboding luckless time;

src: You would be another Penelope: yet, they say, all the yarn she spun in Ulysses' absence did but fill Ithaca full of moths. Come;
trg: I would your cambric were sensible as your finger, that you might leave pricking it for pity. Come, you shall go with us.

src: And treacherously hast thou vanquish'd him, For hand to hand he would have vanquish'd thee. Now my soul's palace is become a prison:
trg: Ah, would she break from hence, that this my body Might in the ground be closed up in rest! For never henceforth shall I joy again, Never, O never shall I see more joy!

src: Pray, be counsell'd: I have a heart as little apt as yours, But yet a brain that leads my use of anger To better vantage.
trg: Well said, noble woman? Before he should thus stoop to the herd, but that The violent fit o' the time craves it as physic For the whole state, I would put mine armour on, Which I can scarcely bear.

src: I am sorry that such sorrow I procure: And so deep sticks it in my penitent heart That I crave death more willingly than mercy; 'Tis my deserving, and I do entreat it.
trg: Which is that Barnardine?

src: Nay, if thou be that princely eagle's bird, Show thy descent by gazing 'gainst the sun: For chair and dukedom, throne and kingdom say; Either that is thine, or else thou wert not his.
trg: How now, fair lords! What fare? what news abroad?

src: Clarence and Gloucester, love my lovely queen; And kiss your princely nephew, brothers both.
trg: The duty that I owe unto your majesty I seal upon the lips of this sweet babe.

src: Then be it as you will; for 'tis my right, And Henry but usurps the diadem.
trg: Ay, now my sovereign speaketh like himself; And now will I be Edward's champion.

src: Worthy Camillo, What colour for my visitation shall I Hold up before him?
trg: Sent by the king your father To greet him and to give him comforts.

src: See who it is: and, now the battle's ended, If friend or foe, let him be gently used.
trg: Revoke that doom of mercy, for 'tis Clifford;

src: Sir, a word ere you go; Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?
trg: And if I be, sir, is it any offence?

src: And 'twas time for him too, I'll warrant him that: an he had stayed by him, I would not have been so fidiused for all the chests in Corioli, and the gold that's in them.
trg: Is the senate possessed of this?

src: So would you be again to Henry, If he were seated as King Edward is.
trg: We charge you, in God's name, and the king's, To go with us unto the officers.

src: While proud ambitious Edward Duke of York Usurps the regal title and the seat Of England's true-anointed lawful king.
trg: This is the cause that I, poor Margaret, With this my son, Prince Edward, Henry's heir, Am come to crave thy just and lawful aid; And if thou fail us, all our hope is done:

src: I have.
trg: Assemble presently the people hither;

src: The world is not thy friend nor the world's law; The world affords no law to make thee rich; Then be not poor, but break it, and take this.
trg: My poverty, but not my will, consents.

src: The pale-faced moon looks bloody on the earth And lean-look'd prophets whisper fearful change;
trg: Rich men look sad and ruffians dance and leap, The one in fear to lose what they enjoy, The other to enjoy by rage and war: These signs forerun the death or fall of kings. Farewell:

src: And your fair princess,--goddess!--O, alas! I lost a couple, that 'twixt heaven and earth Might thus have stood begetting wonder as You, gracious couple, do:
trg: and then I lost-- All mine own folly--the society, Amity too, of your brave father, whom, Though bearing misery, I desire my life Once more to look on him.

src: But is it true? or else is it your pleasure, Like pleasant travellers, to break a jest Upon the company you overtake?
trg: I do assure thee, father, so it is.

src: I am glad on 't: then we shall ha' means to vent Our musty superfluity. See, our best elders.
trg: Marcius, 'tis true that you have lately told us; The Volsces are in arms.

src: Dear brother, how shall Bona be revenged But by thy help to this distressed queen?
trg: Renowned prince, how shall poor Henry live, Unless thou rescue him from foul despair?

src: And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly. This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.
trg: He is a kinsman to the Montague; Affection makes him false; he speaks not true: Some twenty of them fought in this black strife, And all those twenty could but kill one life.

src: Hence, rotten thing! or I shall shake thy bones Out of thy garments.
trg: Help, ye citizens!

src: Come hither, Isabel. Your friar is now your prince: as I was then Advertising and holy to your business, Not changing heart with habit, I am still Attorney'd at your service.
trg: O, give me pardon, That I, your vassal, have employ'd and pain'd Your unknown sovereignty!

src: She may, my lord, for--
trg: She may, Lord Rivers! why, who knows not so? She may do more, sir, than denying that:

src: fresh horses! And gracious be the issue!
trg: This sessions, to our great grief we pronounce, Even pushes 'gainst our heart: the party tried The daughter of a king, our wife, and one Of us too much beloved.

src: Of all mad matches never was the like.
trg: Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?

src: and one that will either push on or pluck back thy business there: whereupon I command thee to open thy affair.
trg: My business, sir, is to the king.

src: That bucket down and full of tears am I, Drinking my griefs, whilst you mount up on high.
trg: I thought you had been willing to resign.

src: Do, good my lord, your citizens entreat you.
trg: Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffer'd love.

src: then know me not, Lest that thy wives with spits and boys with stones In puny battle slay me. Save you, sir.
trg: And you.

src: Welcome father.
trg: The best and wholesomest spirts of the night Envelope you, good Provost! Who call'd here of late?

src: Not so; even through the hollow eyes of death I spy life peering; but I dare not say How near the tidings of our comfort is.
trg: Nay, let us share thy thoughts, as thou dost ours.

src: Then thus I turn me from my country's light, To dwell in solemn shades of endless night.
trg: Return again, and take an oath with thee. Lay on our royal sword your banish'd hands;

src: Your part in her you could not keep from death, But heaven keeps his part in eternal life. The most you sought was her promotion; For 'twas your heaven she should be advanced:
trg: And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself? O, in this love, you love your child so ill, That you run mad, seeing that she is well:

src: For I have ever verified my friends, Of whom he's chief, with all the size that verity Would without lapsing suffer:
trg: nay, sometimes, Like to a bowl upon a subtle ground, I have tumbled past the throw; and in his praise Have almost stamp'd the leasing: therefore, fellow, I must have leave to pass.

src: The banish'd Bolingbroke repeals himself, And with uplifted arms is safe arrived At Ravenspurgh.
trg: Now God in heaven forbid!

src: Then let us take a ceremonious leave And loving farewell of our several friends.
trg: The appellant in all duty greets your highness, And craves to kiss your hand and take his leave.

src: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.
trg: What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel? And soothe the devil that I warn thee from?

src: Well, what then? what then?
trg: Repent what you have spoke.

src: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!
trg: What stay had I but Edward? and he's gone.

src: Here come the lords of Buckingham and Derby.
trg: Good time of day unto your royal grace!

src: These eyes are not the same I wore in Rome.
trg: The sorrow that delivers us thus changed Makes you think so.

src: If you head and hang all that offend that way but for ten year together, you'll be glad to give out a commission for more heads:
trg: if this law hold in Vienna ten year, I'll rent the fairest house in it after three-pence a bay: if you live to see this come to pass, say Pompey told you so.

src: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.
trg: Nay then, I will not: you shall have the mustard, Or else you get no beef of Grumio.

src: So, lie thou there: die thou, and die our fear; For Warwick was a bug that fear'd us all. Now, Montague, sit fast; I seek for thee, That Warwick's bones may keep thine company.
trg: Ah, who is nigh? come to me, friend or foe, And tell me who is victor, York or Warwick? Why ask I that? my mangled body shows, My blood, my want of strength, my sick heart shows.

src: live, and hereafter say, A madman's mercy bade thee run away.
trg: I do defy thy conjurations, And apprehend thee for a felon here.

src: Not for because Your brows are blacker; yet black brows, they say, Become some women best, so that there be not Too much hair there, but in a semicircle Or a half-moon made with a pen.
trg: Who taught you this?

src: This shall determine that.
trg: Romeo, away, be gone! The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain. Stand not amazed: the prince will doom thee death, If thou art taken: hence, be gone, away!

src: If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep, My dreams presage some joyful news at hand: My bosom's lord sits lightly in his throne;
trg: And all this day an unaccustom'd spirit Lifts me above the ground with cheerful thoughts. I dreamt my lady came and found me dead-- Strange dream, that gives a dead man leave to think!

src: Ay, good my lord, and leave us to our fortune.
trg: Why, that's my fortune too; therefore I'll stay.
Clarence and Gloucester, love my lovely queen; And kiss your princely nephew, brothers both.

src: Grumio, mum! God save you, Signior Gremio.
trg: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio. Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola. I promised to inquire carefully About a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca:

src: I' the city of kites and crows! What an ass it is! Then thou dwellest with daws too?
trg: No, I serve not thy master.

src: Despised, distressed, hated, martyr'd, kill'd! Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now To murder, murder our solemnity? O child! O child! my soul, and not my child! Dead art thou! Alack!
trg: my child is dead; And with my child my joys are buried.

src: which was broke off, Partly for that her promised proportions Came short of composition, but in chief For that her reputation was disvalued In levity:
trg: since which time of five years I never spake with her, saw her, nor heard from her, Upon my faith and honour.

src: Not mad, but bound more than a mad-man is; Shut up in prison, kept without my food, Whipp'd and tormented and--God-den, good fellow.
trg: God gi' god-den. I pray, sir, can you read?

src: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.
trg: That may be must be, love, on Thursday next.

src: Why, then the maid is mine from all the world, By your firm promise: Gremio is out-vied.
trg: I must confess your offer is the best; And, let your father make her the assurance, She is your own; else, you must pardon me, if you should die before him, where's her dower?

src: But for a kingdom any oath may be broken: I would break a thousand oaths to reign one year.
trg: No; God forbid your grace should be forsworn.

src: why do I rail on thee, Since thou, created to be awed by man, Wast born to bear? I was not made a horse; And yet I bear a burthen like an ass, Spurr'd, gall'd and tired by jouncing Bolingbroke.
trg: Fellow, give place; here is no longer stay.

src: Ha, ha! what a fool Honesty is! and Trust, his sworn brother, a very simple gentleman! I have sold all my trumpery;
trg: not a counterfeit stone, not a ribbon, glass, pomander, brooch, table-book, ballad, knife, tape, glove, shoe-tie, bracelet, horn-ring, to keep my pack from fasting:

src: Ay, sir; but she will none, she gives you thanks. I would the fool were married to her grave!
trg: Soft! take me with you, take me with you, wife. How! will she none? doth she not give us thanks? Is she not proud?

src: The king is come: deal mildly with his youth; For young hot colts being raged do rage the more.
trg: How fares our noble uncle, Lancaster?

src: Mark and perform it, see'st thou! for the fail Of any point in't shall not only be Death to thyself but to thy lewd-tongued wife, Whom for this time we pardon.
trg: As by strange fortune It came to us, I do in justice charge thee, On thy soul's peril and thy body's torture, That thou commend it strangely to some place Where chance may nurse or end it.

src: pale primroses That die unmarried, ere they can behold Bight Phoebus in his strength--a malady Most incident to maids; bold oxlips and The crown imperial;
trg: lilies of all kinds, The flower-de-luce being one! O, these I lack, To make you garlands of, and my sweet friend, To strew him o'er and o'er!

src: Is't possible you will away to-night?
trg: I must away to-day, before night come: Make it no wonder; if you knew my business, You would entreat me rather go than stay.

src: Very ready, sir.
trg: How now, Abhorson? what's the news with you?

src: The Countess Richmond, good my Lord of Derby. To your good prayers will scarcely say amen.
trg: Yet, Derby, notwithstanding she's your wife, And loves not me, be you, good lord, assured I hate not you for her proud arrogance.

src: I go.
trg: Son, I'll be your half, Bianca comes.

src: Amen.
trg: To-morrow will it please you to be crown'd?

src: Some dungeon.
trg: Your bed-chamber.

src: Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.
trg: Did ever Dian so become a grove As Kate this chamber with her princely gait? O, be thou Dian, and let her be Kate; And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sportful!

src: Thou shalt be master, Tranio, in my stead, Keep house and port and servants as I should: I will some other be, some Florentine, Some Neapolitan, or meaner man of Pisa. 'Tis hatch'd and shall be so:
trg: Tranio, at once Uncase thee; take my colour'd hat and cloak: When Biondello comes, he waits on thee; But I will charm him first to keep his tongue.
Noble Marcius!

src: Why whisper you, my lords, and answer not?
trg: My conscience tells me he is lawful king.

src: Let it go; there's few or none will entertain it.
trg: How if it come to thee again?

src: Well, we may meet again.
trg: I fear me, never.

src: Romeo.
trg: How long hath he been there?

src: I cannot do't without counters. Let me see; what am I to buy for our sheep-shearing feast? Three pound of sugar, five pound of currants, rice,--what will this sister of mine do with rice?
trg: But my father hath made her mistress of the feast, and she lays it on. She hath made me four and twenty nose-gays for the shearers, three-man-song-men all, and very good ones;

src: Am I your bird? I mean to shift my bush; And then pursue me as you draw your bow. You are welcome all.
trg: She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio. This bird you aim'd at, though you hit her not; Therefore a health to all that shot and miss'd.

src: So just is God, to right the innocent.
trg: O, 'twas the foulest deed to slay that babe, And the most merciless that e'er was heard of!

src: You have no cause.
trg: My gracious lady, go; And thither bear your treasure and your goods. For my part, I'll resign unto your grace The seal I keep: and so betide to me As well I tender you and all of yours!

src: Would he do so, I'ld beg your precious mistress, Which he counts but a trifle.
trg: Sir, my liege, Your eye hath too much youth in't: not a month 'Fore your queen died, she was more worth such gazes Than what you look on now.

src: And I choose Clarence only for protector.
trg: Warwick and Clarence give me both your hands: Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts, That no dissension hinder government:

src: Let him know't.
trg: He shall not.

src: 'Tis passing good: I prithee let me have it.
trg: I fear it is too choleric a meat. How say you to a fat tripe finely broil'd?
To the palace, an it like your worship.

src: Good morrow, Catesby; you are early stirring What news, what news, in this our tottering state?
trg: It is a reeling world, indeed, my lord; And I believe twill never stand upright Tim Richard wear the garland of the realm.

src: I cannot tell: the world is grown so bad, That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch: Since every Jack became a gentleman There's many a gentle person made a Jack.
trg: Come, come, we know your meaning, brother Gloucester; You envy my advancement and my friends': God grant we never may have need of you!

src: I have deliver'd to Lord Angelo, A man of stricture and firm abstinence, My absolute power and place here in Vienna, And he supposes me travell'd to Poland;
trg: For so I have strew'd it in the common ear, And so it is received. Now, pious sir, You will demand of me why I do this?

src: If it be possible for you to displace it with your little finger, there is some hope the ladies of Rome, especially his mother, may prevail with him. But I say there is no hope in't:
trg: our throats are sentenced and stay upon execution.

src: Go, sirrah, trudge about Through fair Verona; find those persons out Whose names are written there, and to them say, My house and welcome on their pleasure stay.
trg: Find them out whose names are written here! It is written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his yard, and the tailor with his last, the fisher with his pencil, and the painter with his nets;

src: I will go darkly to work with her.
trg: That's the way; for women are light at midnight.

src: More direful hap betide that hated wretch, That makes us wretched by the death of thee, Than I can wish to adders, spiders, toads, Or any creeping venom'd thing that lives!
trg: If ever he have child, abortive be it, Prodigious, and untimely brought to light, Whose ugly and unnatural aspect May fright the hopeful mother at the view; And that be heir to his unhappiness!

src: He'll never hear him.
trg: Not?

src: you take your pennyworths now; Sleep for a week; for the next night, I warrant, The County Paris hath set up his rest, That you shall rest but little.
trg: God forgive me, Marry, and amen, how sound is she asleep! I must needs wake her. Madam, madam, madam! Ay, let the county take you in your bed; He'll fright you up, i' faith. Will it not be?

src: Could you not take some occasion without giving?
trg: Mercutio, thou consort'st with Romeo,--

src: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs, And throw them in the entrails of the wolf? When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?
trg: When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.

src: Come your ways, sir; come.
trg: You will not bail me, then, sir?

src: But whether 'twas the coldness of the king, Who look'd full gently on his warlike queen, That robb'd my soldiers of their heated spleen; Or whether 'twas report of her success;
trg: Or more than common fear of Clifford's rigour, Who thunders to his captives blood and death, I cannot judge: but to conclude with truth, Their weapons like to lightning came and went;

src: As rich shall Romeo's by his lady's lie; Poor sacrifices of our enmity!
trg: A glooming peace this morning with it brings; The sun, for sorrow, will not show his head: Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things; Some shall be pardon'd, and some punished:

src: My clown, who wants but something to be a reasonable man, grew so in love with the wenches' song, that he would not stir his pettitoes till he had both tune and words;
trg: which so drew the rest of the herd to me that all their other senses stuck in ears: you might have pinched a placket, it was senseless; 'twas nothing to geld a codpiece of a purse;

src: If your more ponderous and settled project May suffer alteration, on mine honour, I'll point you where you shall have such receiving As shall become your highness;
trg: where you may Enjoy your mistress, from the whom, I see, There's no disjunction to be made, but by-- As heavens forefend!--your ruin;

src: Thou old traitor, I am sorry that by hanging thee I can But shorten thy life one week. And thou, fresh piece Of excellent witchcraft, who of force must know The royal fool thou copest with,--
trg: O, my heart!

src: Soft! take me with you, take me with you, wife. How! will she none? doth she not give us thanks? Is she not proud?
trg: doth she not count her blest, Unworthy as she is, that we have wrought So worthy a gentleman to be her bridegroom?

src: I shall not need transport my words by you; Here comes his grace in person. My noble uncle!
trg: Show me thy humble heart, and not thy knee, Whose duty is deceiveable and false.

src: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what do you think is his name?
trg: His name! as if I knew not his name: I have brought him up ever since he was three years old, and his name is Tranio.

src: What noise is here?
trg: O lamentable day!

src: O! we are spoiled and--yonder he is: deny him, forswear him, or else we are all undone.
My gracious uncle--
trg: Tut, tut! Grace me no grace, nor uncle me no uncle: I am no traitor's uncle; and that word 'grace.' In an ungracious mouth is but profane.

src: Then call them to our presence; face to face, And frowning brow to brow, ourselves will hear The accuser and the accused freely speak:
trg: High-stomach'd are they both, and full of ire, In rage deaf as the sea, hasty as fire.

src: Gentle my lord, You scarce can right me throughly then to say You did mistake.
trg: No; if I mistake In those foundations which I build upon, The centre is not big enough to bear A school-boy's top. Away with her! to prison!

src: Unhappy fortune! by my brotherhood, The letter was not nice but full of charge Of dear import, and the neglecting it May do much danger. Friar John, go hence;
trg: Get me an iron crow, and bring it straight Unto my cell.

src: Me seemeth good, that, with some little train, Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fetch'd Hither to London, to be crown'd our king.
trg: Why with some little train, my Lord of Buckingham?

src: Alas, my liege, my wife is dead to-night; Grief of my son's exile hath stopp'd her breath: What further woe conspires against mine age?
trg: Look, and thou shalt see.

src: And you that do abet him in this kind Cherish rebellion and are rebels all.
trg: The noble duke hath sworn his coming is But for his own; and for the right of that We all have strongly sworn to give him aid; And let him ne'er see joy that breaks that oath!

src: A bawd of eleven years' continuance, may it please your honour.
trg: My lord, this is one Lucio's information against me. Mistress Kate Keepdown was with child by him in the duke's time; he promised her marriage:

src: No, so God help me, they spake not a word; But, like dumb statues or breathing stones, Gazed each on other, and look'd deadly pale. Which when I saw, I reprehended them;
trg: And ask'd the mayor what meant this wilful silence: His answer was, the people were not wont To be spoke to but by the recorder.

src: would he not fall down, Since pride must have a fall, and break the neck Of that proud man that did usurp his back? Forgiveness, horse!
trg: why do I rail on thee, Since thou, created to be awed by man, Wast born to bear? I was not made a horse; And yet I bear a burthen like an ass, Spurr'd, gall'd and tired by jouncing Bolingbroke.

src: 'Tis torture, and not mercy: heaven is here, Where Juliet lives; and every cat and dog And little mouse, every unworthy thing, Live here in heaven and may look on her; But Romeo may not:
trg: more validity, More honourable state, more courtship lives In carrion-flies than Romeo:

src: One that gives out himself Prince Florizel, Son of Polixenes, with his princess, she The fairest I have yet beheld, desires access To your high presence.
trg: What with him? he comes not Like to his father's greatness: his approach, So out of circumstance and sudden, tells us 'Tis not a visitation framed, but forced By need and accident. What train?

src: What satisfaction canst thou have to-night?
trg: The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.

src: myself am Naples, Who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheld The king my father wreck'd.
trg: Alack, for mercy!

src: To the hopeful execution do I leave you Of your commissions.
trg: Yet give leave, my lord, That we may bring you something on the way.

src: Worth six on him.
trg: Nay, not so neither: but I take him to be the greater soldier.

src: Stay: whence are you?
trg: Stand, and go back.

src: Be ruled by me, forget to think of her.
trg: O, teach me how I should forget to think.

src: Great Duke of Lancaster, I come to thee From plume-pluck'd Richard; who with willing soul Adopts thee heir, and his high sceptre yields To the possession of thy royal hand:
trg: Ascend his throne, descending now from him; And long live Henry, fourth of that name!

src: No, not these twenty years.
trg: So long could I Stand by, a looker on.

src: Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?
trg: Ay, my lord; But I had rather kill two enemies.

src: And bid my friend, for joy of this good news, Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.
trg: Good Catesby, go, effect this business soundly.

src: That's soon perform'd, because I am a subject.
trg: Why, then, thy husband's lands I freely give thee.

src: 'Have I no friend?' quoth he: he spake it twice, And urged it twice together, did he not?
trg: He did.

src: Do I speak feelingly now?
trg: I think thou dost; and, indeed, with most painful feeling of thy speech: I will, out of thine own confession, learn to begin thy health; but, whilst I live, forget to drink after thee.

src: There stands the castle, by yon tuft of trees, Mann'd with three hundred men, as I have heard; And in it are the Lords of York, Berkeley, and Seymour; None else of name and noble estimate.
trg: Here come the Lords of Ross and Willoughby, Bloody with spurring, fiery-red with haste.

src: 'Twas not your valour, Clifford, drove me thence.
trg: No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.

src: O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo? Deny thy father and refuse thy name; Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love, And I'll no longer be a Capulet.
Which is that Barnardine?
trg: This, my lord.

src: We will give you sleepy drinks, that your senses, unintelligent of our insufficience, may, though they cannot praise us, as little accuse us.
trg: You pay a great deal too dear for what's given freely.

src: If the man be a bachelor, sir, I can; but if he be a married man, he's his wife's head, and I can never cut off a woman's head.
trg: Come, sir, leave me your snatches, and yield me a direct answer. To-morrow morning are to die Claudio and Barnardine. Here is in our prison a common executioner, who in his office lacks a helper:

src: Thou wast a soldier Even to Cato's wish, not fierce and terrible Only in strokes;
trg: but, with thy grim looks and The thunder-like percussion of thy sounds, Thou madst thine enemies shake, as if the world Were feverous and did tremble.

src: The what?
