trg: The pox of such antic, lisping, affecting fantasticoes; these new tuners of accents! 'By Jesu, a very good blade! a very tall man! a very good whore! O, their bones, their bones!

src: The matter?
trg: Hath he not pass'd the noble and the common?

src: No sleep close up that deadly eye of thine, Unless it be whilst some tormenting dream Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils! Thou elvish-mark'd, abortive, rooting hog!
trg: Thou that wast seal'd in thy nativity The slave of nature and the son of hell! Thou slander of thy mother's heavy womb! Thou loathed issue of thy father's loins! Thou rag of honour! thou detested--
Sir, those cold ways, That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him, And bear him to the rock.

src: Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.
trg: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse Abides in me; I say amen to all.
Yea, noise? then I'll be brief. O happy dagger! This is thy sheath; there rust, and let me die.

src: When we grow stronger, then we'll make our claim: Till then, 'tis wisdom to conceal our meaning.
trg: Away with scrupulous wit! now arms must rule.

src: That's off, that's off; I would you rather had been silent. Please you To hear Cominius speak?
trg: Most willingly; But yet my caution was more pertinent Than the rebuke you give it.

src: That we have been familiar, Ingrate forgetfulness shall poison, rather Than pity note how much. Therefore, be gone. Mine ears against your suits are stronger than Your gates against my force.
trg: Yet, for I loved thee, Take this along; I writ it for thy sake And would have rent it. Another word, Menenius, I will not hear thee speak. This man, Aufidius, Was my beloved in Rome:

src: Well, sir, to do you courtesy, This will I do, and this I will advise you: First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?
trg: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been, Pisa renowned for grave citizens.

src: No matter, then, who see it; I will be satisfied; let me see the writing.
trg: I do beseech your grace to pardon me: It is a matter of small consequence, Which for some reasons I would not have seen.

src: O, sir, Lucentio slipp'd me like his greyhound, Which runs himself and catches for his master.
trg: A good swift simile, but something currish.

src: I have said She's an adulteress; I have said with whom:
trg: No, by my life. Privy to none of this. How will this grieve you, When you shall come to clearer knowledge, that You thus have publish'd me!

src: Where did I leave?
trg: At that sad stop, my lord, Where rude misgovern'd hands from windows' tops Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.

src: To leave frivolous circumstances, I pray you, tell Signior Lucentio that his father is come from Pisa, and is here at the door to speak with him.
trg: Thou liest: his father is come from Padua and here looking out at the window.

src: Why, very well; I telling you then, if you be remembered, that such a one and such a one were past cure of the thing you wot of, unless they kept very good diet, as I told you,--
trg: All this is true.

src: Then I will give you the serving-creature.
trg: Then will I lay the serving-creature's dagger on your pate. I will carry no crotchets: I'll re you, I'll fa you; do you note me?

src: There is, there is.
trg: Then show it me.

src: what of her ensues I list not prophecy; but let Time's news Be known when 'tis brought forth. A shepherd's daughter, And what to her adheres, which follows after, Is the argument of Time.
trg: Of this allow, If ever you have spent time worse ere now; If never, yet that Time himself doth say He wishes earnestly you never may.

src: That face of his the hungry cannibals Would not have touch'd, would not have stain'd with blood: But you are more inhuman, more inexorable, O, ten times more, than tigers of Hyrcania.
trg: See, ruthless queen, a hapless father's tears: This cloth thou dip'dst in blood of my sweet boy, And I with tears do wash the blood away. Keep thou the napkin, and go boast of this:

src: That she's the chosen of Signior Hortensio.
trg: Softly, my masters! if you be gentlemen, Do me this right; hear me with patience. Baptista is a noble gentleman, To whom my father is not all unknown;

src: As I intend to prosper and repent, So thrive I in my dangerous attempt Of hostile arms! myself myself confound! Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours! Day, yield me not thy light;
trg: nor, night, thy rest! Be opposite all planets of good luck To my proceedings, if, with pure heart's love, Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts, I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter!

src: What pleasure was he given to?
trg: Rather rejoicing to see another merry, than merry at any thing which professed to make him rejoice: a gentleman of all temperance.

src: Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your habit, but your words show you a madman. Why, sir, what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.
trg: Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

src: Take honour from me, and my life is done: Then, dear my liege, mine honour let me try; In that I live and for that will I die.
trg: Cousin, throw up your gage; do you begin.

src: Ay, my lord; But I had rather kill two enemies.
trg: Why, there thou hast it: two deep enemies, Foes to my rest and my sweet sleep's disturbers Are they that I would have thee deal upon: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

src: The clock struck nine when I did send the nurse; In half an hour she promised to return. Perchance she cannot meet him: that's not so. O, she is lame!
trg: love's heralds should be thoughts, Which ten times faster glide than the sun's beams, Driving back shadows over louring hills:

src: Prithee, let him.
trg: No, he must not.

src: Take that, and mend the plucking off the other. Be merry, Kate. Some water, here; what, ho! Where's my spaniel Troilus? Sirrah, get you hence, And bid my cousin Ferdinand come hither:
trg: One, Kate, that you must kiss, and be acquainted with. Where are my slippers? Shall I have some water? Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily. You whoreson villain! will you let it fall?

src: Your mother.
trg: Madam, I am here. What is your will?

src: The loss of such a lord includes all harm.
trg: The heavens have bless'd you with a goodly son, To be your comforter when he is gone.

src: Clarence, excuse me to the king my brother; I'll hence to London on a serious matter: Ere ye come there, be sure to hear some news.
trg: What? what?

src: I would they were barbarians--as they are, Though in Rome litter'd--not Romans--as they are not, Though calved i' the porch o' the Capitol--
trg: Be gone; Put not your worthy rage into your tongue; One time will owe another.

src: for all Thy by-gone fooleries were but spices of it. That thou betray'dst Polixenes,'twas nothing; That did but show thee, of a fool, inconstant And damnable ingrateful:
trg: nor was't much, Thou wouldst have poison'd good Camillo's honour, To have him kill a king: poor trespasses, More monstrous standing by:

src: Tell not me: I know this cannot be.
trg: Not possible.

src: To the Capitol, come: We will be there before the stream o' the people; And this shall seem, as partly 'tis, their own, Which we have goaded onward.
trg: Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?

src: I neither care for the world nor your general: for such things as you, I can scarce think there's any, ye're so slight. He that hath a will to die by himself fears it not from another:
trg: let your general do his worst. For you, be that you are, long; and your misery increase with your age! I say to you, as I was said to, Away!

src: They say this Angelo was not made by man and woman after this downright way of creation: is it true, think you?
trg: How should he be made, then?

src: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.
trg: Why, what should you fear?

src: All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights Are spectacled to see him: your prattling nurse Into a rapture lets her baby cry While she chats him:
trg: the kitchen malkin pins Her richest lockram 'bout her reechy neck, Clambering the walls to eye him:

src: Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand That your estate requires and mine can yield.
trg: Henry now lives in Scotland at his ease, Where having nothing, nothing can he lose. And as for you yourself, our quondam queen, You have a father able to maintain you;

src: When you are gentle, you shall have one too, And not till then.
Very sooth, to-morrow.
trg: We'll part the time between's then; and in that I'll no gainsaying.

src: I go. Write to me very shortly. And you shall understand from me her mind.
trg: Bear her my true love's kiss; and so, farewell. Relenting fool, and shallow, changing woman! How now! what news?

src: I thought no less: it is his policy To haste thus fast, to find us unprovided.
trg: But he's deceived; we are in readiness.

src: Ah, whither shall I fly to 'scape their hands? Ah, tutor, look where bloody Clifford comes!
trg: Chaplain, away! thy priesthood saves thy life. As for the brat of this accursed duke, Whose father slew my father, he shall die.
Now, in good time, here comes the Duke of York.

src: She's not well married that lives married long; But she's best married that dies married young. Dry up your tears, and stick your rosemary On this fair corse;
trg: and, as the custom is, In all her best array bear her to church: For though fond nature bids us an lament, Yet nature's tears are reason's merriment.

src: Soft, swain, awhile, beseech you; Have you a father?
trg: I have: but what of him?

src: Wife, mother, child, I know not. My affairs Are servanted to others: though I owe My revenge properly, my remission lies In Volscian breasts.
trg: That we have been familiar, Ingrate forgetfulness shall poison, rather Than pity note how much. Therefore, be gone. Mine ears against your suits are stronger than Your gates against my force.

src: Dispatch; the limit of your lives is out.
trg: O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody prison, Fatal and ominous to noble peers! Within the guilty closure of thy walls Richard the second here was hack'd to death;

src: My brave spirit! Who was so firm, so constant, that this coil Would not infect his reason?
trg: Not a soul But felt a fever of the mad and play'd Some tricks of desperation. All but mariners Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel, Then all afire with me:

src: We thank you both: yet one but flatters us, As well appeareth by the cause you come; Namely to appeal each other of high treason.
trg: Cousin of Hereford, what dost thou object Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?

src: The gods have well prevented it, and Rome Sits safe and still without him.
trg: 'Tis Aufidius, Who, hearing of our Marcius' banishment, Thrusts forth his horns again into the world; Which were inshell'd when Marcius stood for Rome, And durst not once peep out.

src: Now, when the bridegroom in the morning comes To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead:
trg: Then, as the manner of our country is, In thy best robes uncover'd on the bier Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie.

src: I'll in, to urge his hatred more to Clarence, With lies well steel'd with weighty arguments; And, if I fall not in my deep intent, Clarence hath not another day to live:
trg: Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy, And leave the world for me to bustle in! For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter. What though I kill'd her husband and her father?

src: Cease; no more. You smell this business with a sense as cold As is a dead man's nose: but I do see't and feel't As you feel doing thus; and see withal The instruments that feel.
trg: If it be so, We need no grave to bury honesty: There's not a grain of it the face to sweeten Of the whole dungy earth.

src: What is't, knave?
trg: An hour before I came, the duchess died.

src: None, sir; I have no pheasant, cock nor hen.
trg: How blessed are we that are not simple men! Yet nature might have made me as these are, Therefore I will not disdain.

src: He dies for Claudio's death.
trg: Most bounteous sir, Look, if it please you, on this man condemn'd, As if my brother lived: I partly think A due sincerity govern'd his deeds, Till he did look on me: since it is so, Let him not die.

src: And what makes robbers bold but too much lenity? Bootless are plaints, and cureless are my wounds; No way to fly, nor strength to hold out flight: The foe is merciless, and will not pity;
trg: For at their hands I have deserved no pity. The air hath got into my deadly wounds, And much effuse of blood doth make me faint. Come, York and Richard, Warwick and the rest;

src: I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying Tiber in't; said to be something imperfect in favouring the first complaint;
trg: hasty and tinder-like upon too trivial motion; one that converses more with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the morning: what I think I utter, and spend my malice in my breath.

src: Then make your garden rich in gillyvors, And do not call them bastards.
trg: I'll not put The dibble in earth to set one slip of them; No more than were I painted I would wish This youth should say 'twere well and only therefore Desire to breed by me. Here's flowers for you;
Must he needs die?

src: O, a cherubim Thou wast that did preserve me. Thou didst smile. Infused with a fortitude from heaven, When I have deck'd the sea with drops full salt, Under my burthen groan'd;
trg: which raised in me An undergoing stomach, to bear up Against what should ensue.

src: Farewell.
trg: I pray you, daughter, sing; or express yourself in a more comfortable sort:

src: Each part, deprived of supple government, Shall, stiff and stark and cold, appear like death:
trg: And in this borrow'd likeness of shrunk death Thou shalt continue two and forty hours, And then awake as from a pleasant sleep.

src: Part, fools! Put up your swords; you know not what you do.
trg: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds? Turn thee, Benvolio, look upon thy death.

src: I am sorry, one so learned and so wise As you, Lord Angelo, have still appear'd, Should slip so grossly, both in the heat of blood. And lack of temper'd judgment afterward.
trg: I am sorry that such sorrow I procure: And so deep sticks it in my penitent heart That I crave death more willingly than mercy; 'Tis my deserving, and I do entreat it.

src: then if I would Speak that,--
trg: We know your drift: speak what?

src: Ah, sirrah, this unlook'd-for sport comes well. Nay, sit, nay, sit, good cousin Capulet; For you and I are past our dancing days: How long is't now since last yourself and I Were in a mask?
trg: By'r lady, thirty years.

src: My Lord!
trg: Ay, what's o'clock?

src: If but one of his pockets could speak, would it not say he lies?
trg: Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report

src: And shamed life a hateful.
trg: Ay, but to die, and go we know not where; To lie in cold obstruction and to rot; This sensible warm motion to become A kneaded clod;

src: Leave me, or tarry, Edward will be king, And not be tied unto his brother's will.
trg: My lords, before it pleased his majesty To raise my state to title of a queen, Do me but right, and you must all confess That I was not ignoble of descent;

src: Shall we go throw away our coats of steel, And wrap our bodies in black mourning gowns, Numbering our Ave-Maries with our beads?
trg: Or shall we on the helmets of our foes Tell our devotion with revengeful arms? If for the last, say ay, and to it, lords.

src: I beseech you, sir, look in this gentleman's face. Good Master Froth, look upon his honour; 'tis for a good purpose. Doth your honour mark his face?
trg: Ay, sir, very well.

src: O grave and good Paulina, the great comfort That I have had of thee!
trg: What, sovereign sir, I did not well I meant well. All my services You have paid home:

src: Madam, good hope; his grace speaks cheerfully.
trg: God grant him health! Did you confer with him?

src: All this is true.
trg: Why, very well, then,--

src: Now hath my soul brought forth her prodigy, And I, a gasping new-deliver'd mother, Have woe to woe, sorrow to sorrow join'd.
trg: Despair not, madam.

src: Had we pursued that life, And our weak spirits ne'er been higher rear'd With stronger blood, we should have answer'd heaven Boldly 'not guilty;' the imposition clear'd Hereditary ours.
trg: By this we gather You have tripp'd since.

src: Verona, for a while I take my leave, To see my friends in Padua, but of all My best beloved and approved friend, Hortensio; and I trow this is his house. Here, sirrah Grumio; knock, I say.
trg: Knock, sir! whom should I knock? is there man has rebused your worship?

src: if not, you shall have your full time of imprisonment and your deliverance with an unpitied whipping, for you have been a notorious bawd.
trg: Sir, I have been an unlawful bawd time out of mind; but yet I will be content to be a lawful hangman. I would be glad to receive some instruction from my fellow partner.

src: There was a time when all the body's members Rebell'd against the belly, thus accused it: The belly answer'd--
trg: Well, sir, what answer made the belly?

src: I mean to stride your steed, and at all times To undercrest your good addition To the fairness of my power.
trg: So, to our tent; Where, ere we do repose us, we will write To Rome of our success. You, Titus Lartius, Must to Corioli back:

src: Worthy Menenius Agrippa; one that hath always loved the people.
trg: He's one honest enough: would all the rest were so!

src: You?
trg: Is this the promise that you made your mother?

src: Hold thy peace: He that hath suffer'd this disorder'd spring Hath now himself met with the fall of leaf:
trg: The weeds which his broad-spreading leaves did shelter, That seem'd in eating him to hold him up, Are pluck'd up root and all by Bolingbroke, I mean the Earl of Wiltshire, Bushy, Green.

src: Mutually.
trg: Then was your sin of heavier kind than his.

src: Why, then, the champions are prepared, and stay For nothing but his majesty's approach.
trg: Marshal, demand of yonder champion The cause of his arrival here in arms: Ask him his name and orderly proceed To swear him in the justice of his cause.

src: Why, I am glad on't; this is well: stand up: This is as't should be. Let me see the county; Ay, marry, go, I say, and fetch him hither. Now, afore God!
trg: this reverend holy friar, Our whole city is much bound to him.

src: Within my mouth you have engaol'd my tongue, Doubly portcullis'd with my teeth and lips; And dull unfeeling barren ignorance Is made my gaoler to attend on me.
trg: I am too old to fawn upon a nurse, Too far in years to be a pupil now: What is thy sentence then but speechless death, Which robs my tongue from breathing native breath?

src: Why, how now, father! Speak ere thou diest.
trg: I cannot speak, nor think Nor dare to know that which I know. O sir!

src: What, shall we stab him as he sleeps?
trg: No; then he will say 'twas done cowardly, when he wakes.

src: All for our vantage. Then, in God's name, march: True hope is swift, and flies with swallow's wings: Kings it makes gods, and meaner creatures kings.
trg: Here pitch our tents, even here in Bosworth field. My Lord of Surrey, why look you so sad?

src: Your husband, being troubled with a shrew, Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe: And now you know my meaning,
trg: A very mean meaning.

src: Upon his mere request, Being come to knowledge that there was complaint Intended 'gainst Lord Angelo, came I hither, To speak, as from his mouth, what he doth know Is true and false;
trg: and what he with his oath And all probation will make up full clear, Whensoever he's convented. First, for this woman.

src: Amen, say we: we will be witnesses.
trg: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu; I will to Venice; Sunday comes apace: We will have rings and things and fine array; And kiss me, Kate, we will be married o'Sunday.

src: My Lord of Hereford, my message is to you.
trg: My lord, my answer is--to Lancaster; And I am come to seek that name in England; And I must find that title in your tongue, Before I make reply to aught you say.

src: And stint thou too, I pray thee, nurse, say I.
trg: Peace, I have done. God mark thee to his grace! Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed: An I might live to see thee married once, I have my wish.

src: Breathe you, my friends: well fought; we are come off Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands, Nor cowardly in retire: believe me, sirs, We shall be charged again.
trg: Whiles we have struck, By interims and conveying gusts we have heard The charges of our friends. Ye Roman gods!

src: When you have vow'd, you must not speak with men But in the presence of the prioress: Then, if you speak, you must not show your face, Or, if you show your face, you must not speak. He calls again;
trg: I pray you, answer him.

src: O monstrous, monstrous! and so falls it out With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: and so 'twill do With some men else, who think themselves as safe As thou and I;
trg: who, as thou know'st, are dear To princely Richard and to Buckingham.

src: Made him my book wherein my soul recorded The history of all her secret thoughts:
trg: So smooth he daub'd his vice with show of virtue, That, his apparent open guilt omitted, I mean, his conversation with Shore's wife, He lived from all attainder of suspect.

src: repeal daily any wholesome act established against the rich, and provide more piercing statutes daily, to chain up and restrain the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will;
trg: and there's all the love they bear us.

src: O, your desert speaks loud;
trg: and I should wrong it, To lock it in the wards of covert bosom, When it deserves, with characters of brass, A forted residence 'gainst the tooth of time And razure of oblivion.

src: Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.
trg: So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend Which you weep for.

src: Merry or sad shall't be?
trg: As merry as you will.

src: An you re us and fa us, you note us.
trg: Pray you, put up your dagger, and put out your wit.

src: Pompey, you are partly a bawd, Pompey, howsoever you colour it in being a tapster, are you not? come, tell me true: it shall be the better for you.
trg: Truly, sir, I am a poor fellow that would live.

src: He is wise; And, on my lie, hath stol'n him home to bed.
trg: He ran this way, and leap'd this orchard wall: Call, good Mercutio.

src: Who sets me else? by heaven, I'll throw at all: I have a thousand spirits in one breast, To answer twenty thousand such as you.
trg: My Lord Fitzwater, I do remember well The very time Aumerle and you did talk.

src: Thy noble shape is but a form of wax, Digressing from the valour of a man; Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury, Killing that love which thou hast vow'd to cherish; What, rouse thee, man!
trg: thy Juliet is alive, For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead; There art thou happy: Tybalt would kill thee, But thou slew'st Tybalt; there are thou happy too:

src: What shall we do?
trg: Relent, and save your souls.

src: Signior Petruchio, fie! you are to blame. Come, mistress Kate, I'll bear you company.
It is my Lord of Berkeley, as I guess.
trg: My Lord of Hereford, my message is to you.

src: A dog of the house of Montague moves me.
trg: To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand: therefore, if thou art moved, thou runn'st away.

src: Traitors! Will you not push her out? Give her the bastard. Thou dotard! thou art woman-tired, unroosted By thy dame Partlet here. Take up the bastard; Take't up, I say; give't to thy crone.
trg: For ever Unvenerable be thy hands, if thou Takest up the princess by that forced baseness Which he has put upon't!

src: I am not barren to bring forth complaints All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes, That I, being govern'd by the watery moon, May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world!
trg: Oh for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!

src: This will I carry to Rome.
trg: And I this.

src: Upon the stroke of four.
trg: Why, then 'tis time to arm and give direction. More than I have said, loving countrymen, The leisure and enforcement of the time Forbids to dwell upon:

src: I would have ransack'd The pedlar's silken treasury and have pour'd it To her acceptance; you have let him go And nothing marted with him.
trg: If your lass Interpretation should abuse and call this Your lack of love or bounty, you were straited For a reply, at least if you make a care Of happy holding her.

src: He'll beat Aufidius 'head below his knee And tread upon his neck.
trg: My ladies both, good day to you.

src: What shrill-voiced suppliant makes this eager cry?
trg: A woman, and thy aunt, great king; 'tis I. Speak with me, pity me, open the door. A beggar begs that never begg'd before.

src: I' faith, I am sorry that thou art not well. Sweet, sweet, sweet nurse, tell me, what says my love?
trg: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I warrant, a virtuous,--Where is your mother?

src: I speak no treason.
trg: O, God ye god-den.

src: Mistake me not; I speak but as I find. Whence are you, sir? what may I call your name?
trg: Petruchio is my name; Antonio's son, A man well known throughout all Italy.

src: This may prove worse than hanging.
Might but my bending down Reprieve thee from thy fate, it should proceed: I'll pray a thousand prayers for thy death, No word to save thee.
trg: Nay, hear me, Isabel.

src: O yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face, Such as the daughter of Agenor had, That made great Jove to humble him to her hand. When with his knees he kiss'd the Cretan strand.
trg: Saw you no more? mark'd you not how her sister Began to scold and raise up such a storm That mortal ears might hardly endure the din?

src: Woe to the land that's govern'd by a child!
trg: In him there is a hope of government, That in his nonage council under him, And in his full and ripen'd years himself, No doubt, shall then and till then govern well.

src: God save your majesty! and well met, gentlemen: I hope the king is not yet shipp'd for Ireland.
trg: Why hopest thou so? 'tis better hope he is; For his designs crave haste, his haste good hope: Then wherefore dost thou hope he is not shipp'd?

src: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.
trg: Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?

src: What seal is that, that hangs without thy bosom? Yea, look'st thou pale? let me see the writing.
trg: My lord, 'tis nothing.

src: Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave, That feed'st me with the very name of meat: Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you, That triumph thus upon my misery! Go, get thee gone, I say.
trg: How fares my Kate? What, sweeting, all amort?

src: that the time may have all shadow and silence in it; and the place answer to convenience.
trg: This being granted in course,--and now follows all,--we shall advise this wronged maid to stead up your appointment, go in your place;

src: Every letter he hath writ hath disvouched other.
trg: In most uneven and distracted manner. His actions show much like to madness: pray heaven his wisdom be not tainted! And why meet him at the gates, and redeliver our authorities there

src: Back to the Duke of Gloucester, tell him so.
trg: I pray thee, stay a while: I hope my holy humour will change; 'twas wont to hold me but while one would tell twenty.

src: Why, then we shall have a stirring world again. This peace is nothing, but to rust iron, increase tailors, and breed ballad-makers.
trg: Let me have war, say I; it exceeds peace as far as day does night; it's spritely, waking, audible, and full of vent. Peace is a very apoplexy, lethargy; mulled, deaf, sleepy, insensible;

src: Ay, traitor, Marcius!
trg: Marcius!

src: Whate'er it be, be thou still like thyself, And sit thee by our side: Yield not thy neck To fortune's yoke, but let thy dauntless mind Still ride in triumph over all mischance.
trg: Be plain, Queen Margaret, and tell thy grief; It shall be eased, if France can yield relief.

src: Sir, have pity; I'll be his surety.
trg: Silence! one word more Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee. What! An advocate for an imposter! hush! Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he, Having seen but him and Caliban:

src: And patient fools, Whose children he hath slain, their base throats tear With giving him glory.
trg: Therefore, at your vantage, Ere he express himself, or move the people With what he would say, let him feel your sword, Which we will second.

src: Ay, my good lord.
trg: Go play, Mamillius; thou'rt an honest man. Camillo, this great sir will yet stay longer.

src: Ay, as the glasses where they view themselves; Which are as easy broke as they make forms. Women! Help Heaven! men their creation mar In profiting by them. Nay, call us ten times frail;
trg: For we are soft as our complexions are, And credulous to false prints.

src: What! loss of some pitch'd battle against Warwick?
trg: No, but the loss of his own royal person.

src: And ask'd the mayor what meant this wilful silence: His answer was, the people were not wont To be spoke to but by the recorder.
trg: Then he was urged to tell my tale again, 'Thus saith the duke, thus hath the duke inferr'd;' But nothing spake in warrant from himself.

src: Carlisle, this is your doom: Choose out some secret place, some reverend room, More than thou hast, and with it joy thy life; So as thou livest in peace, die free from strife:
trg: For though mine enemy thou hast ever been, High sparks of honour in thee have I seen.

src: More of him anon. There is written in your brow, provost, honesty and constancy: if I read it not truly, my ancient skill beguiles me; but, in the boldness of my cunning, I will lay myself in hazard.
trg: Claudio, whom here you have warrant to execute, is no greater forfeit to the law than Angelo who hath sentenced him.

src: Go sleep, and hear us.
trg: What, all so soon asleep! I wish mine eyes Would, with themselves, shut up my thoughts: I find They are inclined to do so.

src: Here's for my oath, here's for my father's death.
trg: And here's to right our gentle-hearted king.

src: Then set before my face the Lord Aumerle.
trg: Cousin, stand forth, and look upon that man.

src: Within whose circuit is Elysium And all that poets feign of bliss and joy. Why do we finger thus? I cannot rest Until the white rose that I wear be dyed Even in the lukewarm blood of Henry's heart.
trg: Richard, enough; I will be king, or die. Brother, thou shalt to London presently, And whet on Warwick to this enterprise.

src: Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost, To hear the lamentations of Poor Anne, Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughter'd son, Stabb'd by the selfsame hand that made these wounds!
trg: Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life, I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes. Cursed be the hand that made these fatal holes! Cursed be the heart that had the heart to do it!

src: Though sometimes you do blench from this to that, As cause doth minister. Go call at Flavius' house, And tell him where I stay:
trg: give the like notice To Valentinus, Rowland, and to Crassus, And bid them bring the trumpets to the gate; But send me Flavius first.

src: Then is he more beholding to you than I.
trg: He may command me as my sovereign; But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

src: Thou darest not, coward, live to see that day.
trg: Now by my soul, I would it were this hour.

src: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after supper, And thou shalt tell the process of their death. Meantime, but think how I may do thee good, And be inheritor of thy desire. Farewell till soon.
trg: The son of Clarence have I pent up close; His daughter meanly have I match'd in marriage; The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom, And Anne my wife hath bid the world good night.

src: Then, by myself--
trg: Thyself thyself misusest.

src: methinks it were a happy life, To be no better than a homely swain;
trg: To sit upon a hill, as I do now, To carve out dials quaintly, point by point, Thereby to see the minutes how they run, How many make the hour full complete; How many hours bring about the day;

src: And left them More rich for what they yielded.
trg: Thou speak'st truth. No more such wives; therefore, no wife:

src: And we mean well in going to this mask; But 'tis no wit to go.
trg: Why, may one ask?

src: We see the wind sit sore upon our sails, And yet we strike not, but securely perish.
trg: We see the very wreck that we must suffer; And unavoided is the danger now, For suffering so the causes of our wreck.

src: No more evasion: We have with a leaven'd and prepared choice Proceeded to you; therefore take your honours.
trg: Our haste from hence is of so quick condition That it prefers itself and leaves unquestion'd Matters of needful value.

src: Then, tell me, what doth he upon the sea?
trg: Unless for that, my liege, I cannot guess.

src: O, then my best blood turn To an infected jelly and my name Be yoked with his that did betray the Best!
trg: How should this grow?

src: Give me thy hand: I will swear to the prince thou art as honest a true fellow as any is in Bohemia.
trg: You may say it, but not swear it.

src: Please it your honours To call me to your senate, I'll deliver Myself your loyal servant, or endure Your heaviest censure.
trg: Bear from hence his body; And mourn you for him: let him be regarded As the most noble corse that ever herald Did follow to his urn.

src: This oath I willingly take and will perform.
trg: Long live King Henry! Plantagenet embrace him.

src: I would there were no age between sixteen and three-and-twenty, or that youth would sleep out the rest;
trg: for there is nothing in the between but getting wenches with child, wronging the ancientry, stealing, fighting--Hark you now!

src: Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret; I will be master of what is mine own: She is my goods, my chattels;
trg: she is my house, My household stuff, my field, my barn, My horse, my ox, my ass, my any thing; And here she stands, touch her whoever dare;

src: But he, poor soul, by your first order died, And that a winged Mercury did bear: Some tardy cripple bore the countermand, That came too lag to see him buried.
trg: God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, Nearer in bloody thoughts, but not in blood, Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, And yet go current from suspicion!

src: O, did you so? And do you remember what you said of the duke?
trg: Most notedly, sir.

src: And yet the steer, the heifer and the calf Are all call'd neat.--Still virginalling Upon his palm!--How now, you wanton calf! Art thou my calf?
trg: Yes, if you will, my lord.

src: He receives comfort like cold porridge.
trg: The visitor will not give him o'er so.

src: My liege, old Gaunt commends him to your majesty.
trg: What says he?

src: Thanks, dear Isabel.
trg: Be ready, Claudio, for your death tomorrow.

src: From thee, even from thy virtue! What's this, what's this? Is this her fault or mine? The tempter or the tempted, who sins most? Ha! Not she: nor doth she tempt:
trg: but it is I That, lying by the violet in the sun, Do as the carrion does, not as the flower, Corrupt with virtuous season. Can it be That modesty may more betray our sense Than woman's lightness?

src: I could weep, madam, would it do you good.
trg: And I could sing, would weeping do me good, And never borrow any tear of thee. But stay, here come the gardeners: Let's step into the shadow of these trees.

src: More noble blows than ever thou wise words; And for Rome's good. I'll tell thee what; yet go: Nay, but thou shalt stay too:
trg: I would my son Were in Arabia, and thy tribe before him, His good sword in his hand.

src: Ay, sir, they be ready: the oats have eaten the horses.
trg: Nay, then, Do what thou canst, I will not go to-day; No, nor to-morrow, not till I please myself. The door is open, sir; there lies your way; You may be jogging whiles your boots are green;

src: Open Thy gate of mercy, gracious God! My soul flies through these wounds to seek out Thee.
trg: Off with his head, and set it on York gates; So York may overlook the town of York. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: sigh'd forth proverbs, That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat, That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent not Corn for the rich men only:
trg: with these shreds They vented their complainings;

src: That's the way; for women are light at midnight.
trg: Come on, mistress: here's a gentlewoman denies all that you have said.

src: The day frowns more and more: thou'rt like to have A lullaby too rough: I never saw The heavens so dim by day. A savage clamour! Well may I get aboard! This is the chase: I am gone for ever.
trg: I would there were no age between sixteen and three-and-twenty, or that youth would sleep out the rest;

src: Why looks your grace so heavily today?
trg: What was your dream? I long to hear you tell it.

src: Bear the boy hence; he shall not come about her; Away with him! and let her sport herself With that she's big with; for 'tis Polixenes Has made thee swell thus.
trg: But I'ld say he had not, And I'll be sworn you would believe my saying, Howe'er you lean to the nayward.

src: Why, 'twas a commandment to command the captain and all the rest from their functions: they put forth to steal.
trg: There's not a soldier of us all, that, in the thanksgiving before meat, do relish the petition well that prays for peace.

src: Good even, good father.
trg: Bliss and goodness on you!

src: that they have seemed to be together, though absent, shook hands, as over a vast, and embraced, as it were, from the ends of opposed winds. The heavens continue their loves!
trg: I think there is not in the world either malice or matter to alter it. You have an unspeakable comfort of your young prince Mamillius:

src: and, if aught in this Miscarried by my fault, let my old life Be sacrificed, some hour before his time, Unto the rigour of severest law.
trg: We still have known thee for a holy man. Where's Romeo's man? what can he say in this?

src: But the law will not allow it, Pompey; nor it shall not be allowed in Vienna.
trg: Does your worship mean to geld and splay all the youth of the city?

src: I thank you for this comfort. Fare you well, good father.
trg: Nay, if there be no remedy for it, but that you will needs buy and sell men and women like beasts, we shall have all the world drink brown and white bastard.

src: Woe the while! O, cut my lace, lest my heart, cracking it, Break too.
trg: What fit is this, good lady?

src: For me, that I may surely keep mine oath, I will be married to a wealthy widow, Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.
trg: And so farewell, Signior Lucentio. Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks, Shall win my love: and so I take my leave, In resolution as I swore before.

src: he cannot lie with his neighbour's wife, but it detects him: 'tis a blushing shamefast spirit that mutinies in a man's bosom; it fills one full of obstacles:
trg: it made me once restore a purse of gold that I found; it beggars any man that keeps it: it is turned out of all towns and cities for a dangerous thing;

src: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant's life; Who slew to-day a righteous gentleman Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolk.
trg: Have a tongue to doom my brother's death, And shall the same give pardon to a slave? My brother slew no man; his fault was thought, And yet his punishment was cruel death. Who sued to me for him?

src: I do repent me, as it is an evil, And take the shame with joy.
trg: There rest. Your partner, as I hear, must die to-morrow, And I am going with instruction to him. Grace go with you, Benedicite!

src: You shall not be The grave of your deserving; Rome must know The value of her own: 'twere a concealment Worse than a theft, no less than a traducement, To hide your doings;
trg: and to silence that, Which, to the spire and top of praises vouch'd, Would seem but modest:

src: Sir, there lies such secrets in this fardel and box, which none must know but the king; and which he shall know within this hour, if I may come to the speech of him.
trg: Age, thou hast lost thy labour.

src: Unhappily, even so. Whether the tyranny be in his place, Or in his emmence that fills it up, I stagger in:
trg: --but this new governor Awakes me all the enrolled penalties Which have, like unscour'd armour, hung by the wall So long that nineteen zodiacs have gone round And none of them been worn;

src: I saw the wound, I saw it with mine eyes,-- God save the mark!--here on his manly breast: A piteous corse, a bloody piteous corse; Pale, pale as ashes, all bedaub'd in blood, All in gore-blood;
trg: I swounded at the sight.

src: Woe me! for what?
trg: For that which, if myself might be his judge, He should receive his punishment in thanks: He hath got his friend with child.

src: let Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at death With as big heart as thou.
trg: Do as thou list Thy valiantness was mine, thou suck'dst it from me, But owe thy pride thyself.

src: whose loss of his most precious queen and children are even now to be afresh lamented. Say to me, when sawest thou the Prince Florizel, my son?
trg: Kings are no less unhappy, their issue not being gracious, than they are in losing them when they have approved their virtues.

src: Acquaint her with the danger of my state: Implore her, in my voice, that she make friends To the strict deputy; bid herself assay him: I have great hope in that;
trg: for in her youth There is a prone and speechless dialect, Such as move men; beside, she hath prosperous art When she will play with reason and discourse, And well she can persuade.

src: And he's as like to do't as any man I can imagine.
trg: Do't! he will do't; for, look you, sir, he has as many friends as enemies;

src: of the which we being members, should bring ourselves to be monstrous members.
trg: And to make us no better thought of, a little help will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he himself stuck not to call us the many-headed multitude.

src: I have been i' the market-place; and, sir,'tis fit You make strong party, or defend yourself By calmness or by absence: all's in anger.
trg: Only fair speech.

src: Can Oxford, that did ever fence the right, Now buckler falsehood with a pedigree? For shame! leave Henry, and call Edward king.
trg: Call him my king by whose injurious doom My elder brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere, Was done to death?

src: Say as he says, or we shall never go.
trg: Forward, I pray, since we have come so far, And be it moon, or sun, or what you please: An if you please to call it a rush-candle, Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.

src: Is it for him you do envy me so? Nay then you jest, and now I well perceive You have but jested with me all this while: I prithee, sister Kate, untie my hands.
trg: If that be jest, then all the rest was so.

src: Now Margaret's curse is fall'n upon our heads, For standing by when Richard stabb'd her son.
trg: Then cursed she Hastings, then cursed she Buckingham, Then cursed she Richard.

src: What impossible matter will he make easy next?
trg: I think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple.

src: Ay, and more.
trg: A French crown more.

src: Plainly conceive, I love you.
trg: My brother did love Juliet, And you tell me that he shall die for it.

src: Under what title shall I woo for thee, That God, the law, my honour and her love, Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?
trg: Infer fair England's peace by this alliance.

src: I, that have neither pity, love, nor fear. Indeed, 'tis true that Henry told me of; For I have often heard my mother say I came into the world with my legs forward:
trg: Had I not reason, think ye, to make haste, And seek their ruin that usurp'd our right? The midwife wonder'd and the women cried 'O, Jesus bless us, he is born with teeth!' And so I was;

src: Sir, those cold ways, That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him, And bear him to the rock.
trg: No, I'll die here. There's some among you have beheld me fighting: Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me.

src: boys, with women's voices, Strive to speak big and clap their female joints In stiff unwieldy arms against thy crown: The very beadsmen learn to bend their bows Of double-fatal yew against thy state;
trg: Yea, distaff-women manage rusty bills Against thy seat: both young and old rebel, And all goes worse than I have power to tell.

src: Heaven in my mouth, As if I did but only chew his name; And in my heart the strong and swelling evil Of my conception.
trg: The state, whereon I studied Is like a good thing, being often read, Grown fear'd and tedious;

src: Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse: Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.
trg: My words are dull; O, quicken them with thine!

src: For, by the way, I'll sort occasion, As index to the story we late talk'd of, To part the queen's proud kindred from the king.
trg: My other self, my counsel's consistory, My oracle, my prophet! My dear cousin, I, like a child, will go by thy direction. Towards Ludlow then, for we'll not stay behind.

src: Let me put in your minds, if you forget, What you have been ere now, and what you are; Withal, what I have been, and what I am.
trg: A murderous villain, and so still thou art.

src: Will you tell me that? His son was but a ward two years ago.
Nothing of him that doth fade But doth suffer a sea-change Into something rich and strange. Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell Hark! now I hear them,--Ding-dong, bell.
trg: The ditty does remember my drown'd father. This is no mortal business, nor no sound That the earth owes. I hear it now above me.

src: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.
trg: I partly know the man: go, call him hither. The deep-revolving witty Buckingham No more shall be the neighbour to my counsel: Hath he so long held out with me untired, And stops he now for breath?

src: Or shall we on the helmets of our foes Tell our devotion with revengeful arms? If for the last, say ay, and to it, lords.
trg: Why, therefore Warwick came to seek you out; And therefore comes my brother Montague. Attend me, lords.

src: meantime I writ to Romeo, That he should hither come as this dire night, To help to take her from her borrow'd grave, Being the time the potion's force should cease.
trg: But he which bore my letter, Friar John, Was stay'd by accident, and yesternight Return'd my letter back.

src: He hath released him, Isabel, from the world: His head is off and sent to Angelo.
trg: Nay, but it is not so.

src: Fortune speed us! Thus we set on, Camillo, to the sea-side.
trg: The swifter speed the better.

src: Oh, who shall hinder me to wail and weep, To chide my fortune, and torment myself? I'll join with black despair against my soul, And to myself become an enemy.
trg: What means this scene of rude impatience?

src: And I, my lord, will bear him company.
trg: Soldiers, away with him!

src: My lord, she may be a punk; for many of them are neither maid, widow, nor wife.
trg: Silence that fellow: I would he had some cause To prattle for himself.

src: How! caught of me! Make me not sighted like the basilisk: I have look'd on thousands, who have sped the better By my regard, but kill'd none so.
trg: I may not answer.

src: Varlet, thou liest; thou liest, wicked varlet! the time has yet to come that she was ever respected with man, woman, or child.
trg: Sir, she was respected with him before he married with her.

src: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.
trg: Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.

src: 'Fair cousin'? I am greater than a king: For when I was a king, my flatterers Were then but subjects; being now a subject, I have a king here to my flatterer. Being so great, I have no need to beg.
trg: Yet ask.

src: And when I wander here and there, I then do most go right. If tinkers may have leave to live, And bear the sow-skin budget, Then my account I well may, give, And in the stocks avouch it.
trg: My traffic is sheets; when the kite builds, look to lesser linen. My father named me Autolycus; who being, as I am, littered under Mercury, was likewise a snapper-up of unconsidered trifles.

src: Why, be so still; here's nobody will steal that from thee: yet for the outside of thy poverty we must make an exchange;
trg: therefore discase thee instantly, --thou must think there's a necessity in't,--and change garments with this gentleman:

src: but my time Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's proud joy, While I stand fooling here, his Jack o' the clock. This music mads me; let it sound no more;
trg: For though it have holp madmen to their wits, In me it seems it will make wise men mad. Yet blessing on his heart that gives it me! For 'tis a sign of love;

src: I will apprehend him. Stop thy unhallow'd toil, vile Montague! Can vengeance be pursued further than death? Condemned villain, I do apprehend thee: Obey, and go with me; for thou must die.
trg: I must indeed; and therefore came I hither. Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man; Fly hence, and leave me: think upon these gone; Let them affright thee.

src: Say, what art thou that talk'st of kings and queens?
trg: More than I seem, and less than I was born to: A man at least, for less I should not be; And men may talk of kings, and why not I?

src: She will indite him to some supper.
trg: A bawd, a bawd, a bawd! so ho!

src: If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine, Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline: And art thou changed? pronounce this sentence then, Women may fall, when there's no strength in men.
trg: Thou chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline.

src: However God or fortune cast my lot, There lives or dies, true to King Richard's throne, A loyal, just and upright gentleman:
trg: Most mighty liege, and my companion peers, Take from my mouth the wish of happy years: As gentle and as jocund as to jest Go I to fight: truth hath a quiet breast.

src: But he's deceived; we are in readiness.
trg: This cheers my heart, to see your forwardness.

src: To fight on Edward's party for the crown; And for his meed, poor lord, he is mew'd up. I would to God my heart were flint, like Edward's;
trg: Or Edward's soft and pitiful, like mine I am too childish-foolish for this world.

src: And may you prove, sir, master of your art!
trg: While you, sweet dear, prove mistress of my heart!

src: I met the youthful lord at Laurence' cell; And gave him what becomed love I might, Not step o'er the bounds of modesty.
trg: Why, I am glad on't; this is well: stand up: This is as't should be. Let me see the county; Ay, marry, go, I say, and fetch him hither. Now, afore God!

src: I could myself Take up a brace o' the best of them; yea, the two tribunes: But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic; And manhood is call'd foolery, when it stands Against a falling fabric.
trg: Will you hence, Before the tag return? whose rage doth rend Like interrupted waters and o'erbear What they are used to bear.

src: Lift up your countenance, as it were the day Of celebration of that nuptial which We two have sworn shall come.
trg: O lady Fortune, Stand you auspicious!

src: Come, Camillo, And take her by the hand, whose worth and honesty Is richly noted and here justified By us, a pair of kings. Let's from this place. What! look upon my brother:
trg: both your pardons, That e'er I put between your holy looks My ill suspicion. This is your son-in-law, And son unto the king, who, heavens directing, Is troth-plight to your daughter.

src: I'll do't, my lord.
trg: I will seem friendly, as thou hast advised me.

src: What? what?
trg: The Tower, the Tower.

src: May your grace speak of it?
trg: My holy sir, none better knows than you How I have ever loved the life removed And held in idle price to haunt assemblies Where youth, and cost, and witless bravery keeps.

src: Name him.
trg: Plantagenet.

src: For Clarence is well-spoken, and perhaps May move your hearts to pity if you mark him.
trg: Tush! Fear not, my lord, we will not stand to prate; Talkers are no good doers: be assured We come to use our hands and not our tongues.

src: If he were dead, what would betide of me?
trg: No other harm but loss of such a lord.

src: I dare not know, my lord.
trg: How! dare not! do not. Do you know, and dare not? Be intelligent to me: 'tis thereabouts; For, to yourself, what you do know, you must. And cannot say, you dare not.

src: I'll bear thee hence, where I may weep my fill.
trg: These arms of mine shall be thy winding-sheet; My heart, sweet boy, shall be thy sepulchre, For from my heart thine image ne'er shall go; My sighing breast shall be thy funeral bell;

src: By whom, Camillo?
trg: By the king.

src: And, if we thrive, promise them such rewards As victors wear at the Olympian games: This may plant courage in their quailing breasts; For yet is hope of life and victory.
trg: Forslow no longer, make we hence amain. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: O, let us hence; I stand on sudden haste.
trg: Wisely and slow; they stumble that run fast.

src: And by good fortune I have lighted well On this young man, for learning and behavior Fit for her turn, well read in poetry And other books, good ones, I warrant ye.
trg: 'Tis well; and I have met a gentleman Hath promised me to help me to another, A fine musician to instruct our mistress; So shall I no whit be behind in duty To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.

src: And but one word with one of us? couple it with something; make it a word and a blow.
trg: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.

src: But say, what to thine old news?
trg: with two broken points: his horse hipped with an old mothy saddle and stirrups of no kindred; besides, possessed with the glanders and like to mose in the chine;

src: I'll rest betide the chamber where thou liest!
trg: So will it, madam till I lie with you.

src: And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour, And not obedient to his honest will, What is she but a foul contending rebel And graceless traitor to her loving lord?
trg: I am ashamed that women are so simple To offer war where they should kneel for peace; Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway, When they are bound to serve, love and obey.

src: Am I but three inches? why, thy horn is a foot; and so long am I at the least.
trg: But wilt thou make a fire, or shall I complain on thee to our mistress, whose hand, she being now at hand, thou shalt soon feel, to thy cold comfort, for being slow in thy hot office?

src: I am, and by my fancy: if my reason Will thereto be obedient, I have reason; If not, my senses, better pleased with madness, Do bid it welcome.
trg: This is desperate, sir.

src: And many giddy people flock to him.
trg: Let's levy men, and beat him back again.

src: A gentleman of mine I have dispatch'd With letters of your love to her at large.
trg: Thank, gentle uncle. Come, lords, away. To fight with Glendower and his complices: Awhile to work, and after holiday.

src: Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood, Scratching her legs that one shall swear she bleeds, And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep, So workmanly the blood and tears are drawn.
trg: Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord: Thou hast a lady far more beautiful Than any woman in this waning age.

src: Noble Menenius, Be you then as the people's officer. Masters, lay down your weapons.
trg: Go not home.

src: And only in that safety died her brothers.
trg: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.

src: Go fetch them hither: if they deny to come. Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands: Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.
trg: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.

src: reason my son Should choose himself a wife, but as good reason The father, all whose joy is nothing else But fair posterity, should hold some counsel In such a business.
trg: I yield all this; But for some other reasons, my grave sir, Which 'tis not fit you know, I not acquaint My father of this business.

src: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do; They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.
trg: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.

src: I know him for a man divine and holy; Not scurvy, nor a temporary meddler, As he's reported by this gentleman; And, on my trust, a man that never yet Did, as he vouches, misreport your grace.
trg: My lord, most villanously; believe it.

src: 'Zounds, it is even now at my elbow, persuading me not to kill the duke.
trg: Take the devil in thy mind, and relieve him not: he would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.

src: No, mighty King of France: now Margaret Must strike her sail and learn awhile to serve Where kings command. I was, I must confess, Great Albion's queen in former golden days:
trg: But now mischance hath trod my title down, And with dishonour laid me on the ground; Where I must take like seat unto my fortune, And to my humble seat conform myself.

src: Good sooth, even thus; therefore ha' done with words: To me she's married, not unto my clothes:
trg: Could I repair what she will wear in me, As I can change these poor accoutrements, 'Twere well for Kate and better for myself.

src: Bid her send me presently a thousand pound: Hold, take my ring.
trg: My lord, I had forgot to tell your lordship, To-day, as I came by, I called there; But I shall grieve you to report the rest.

src: our throats are sentenced and stay upon execution.
trg: Is't possible that so short a time can alter the condition of a man!

src: No, my good lord; it was by private message.
trg: For which I do discharge you of your office: Give up your keys.

src: Whose hand is that the forest bear doth lick? Not his that spoils her young before her face. Who 'scapes the lurking serpent's mortal sting? Not he that sets his foot upon her back.
trg: The smallest worm will turn being trodden on, And doves will peck in safeguard of their brood. Ambitious York doth level at thy crown, Thou smiling while he knit his angry brows:

src: How fares my noble lord?
trg: Marry, I fare well for here is cheer enough. Where is my wife?

src: Now, the gods crown thee!
trg: And live you yet? O my sweet lady, pardon.

src: Lady, by yonder blessed moon I swear That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops--
trg: O, swear not by the moon, the inconstant moon, That monthly changes in her circled orb, Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.

src: Hold, hold, hold, hold!
trg: My noble masters, hear me speak.

src: therefore, I pray you, As you have ever been my father's honour'd friend, When he shall miss me,--as, in faith, I mean not To see him any more,--cast your good counsels Upon his passion;
trg: let myself and fortune Tug for the time to come. This you may know And so deliver, I am put to sea With her whom here I cannot hold on shore;

src: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.
trg: Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's love Made me exchange my state with Tranio, While he did bear my countenance in the town;

src: Why do you put these sayings upon me?
trg: Because authority, though it err like others, Hath yet a kind of medicine in itself, That skins the vice o' the top. Go to your bosom;

src: Madam!
trg: Nurse?

src: Go, get you to your house; be gone, away! All will be naught else.
trg: Get you gone.

src: when he, Wafting his eyes to the contrary and falling A lip of much contempt, speeds from me and So leaves me to consider what is breeding That changeth thus his manners.
trg: I dare not know, my lord.

src: The game was ne'er so fair, and I am done.
trg: Tut, dun's the mouse, the constable's own word: If thou art dun, we'll draw thee from the mire Of this sir-reverence love, wherein thou stick'st Up to the ears. Come, we burn daylight, ho!

src: And, with thy hand, thy faith irrevocable, That only Warwick's daughter shall be thine.
trg: Yes, I accept her, for she well deserves it; And here, to pledge my vow, I give my hand.

src: She is the fairies' midwife, and she comes In shape no bigger than an agate-stone On the fore-finger of an alderman, Drawn with a team of little atomies Athwart men's noses as they lie asleep;
trg: Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub, Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers.

src: Stanley, I will requite thy forwardness.
trg: But wherefore stay we? 'tis no time to talk.

src: Now, as I live, I will. My nobler friends, I crave their pardons: For the mutable, rank-scented many, let them Regard me as I do not flatter, and Therein behold themselves:
trg: Well, no more.

src: One that I would were here, Friar Lodowick.
trg: A ghostly father, belike. Who knows that Lodowick?

src: Anon, anon! Come, let's away; the strangers all are gone.
trg: Now old desire doth in his death-bed lie, And young affection gapes to be his heir; That fair for which love groan'd for and would die, With tender Juliet match'd, is now not fair.

src: Be it so; go back: the virtue of your name Is not here passable.
trg: I tell thee, fellow, The general is my lover: I have been The book of his good acts, whence men have read His name unparallel'd, haply amplified;

src: Then never man was true.
trg: Well, well, put up your sword.

src: But shall you on your knowledge find this way?
trg: I have ta'en a due and wary note upon't: With whispering and most guilty diligence, In action all of precept, he did show me The way twice o'er.

src: O woe! O woful, woful, woful day! Most lamentable day, most woful day, That ever, ever, I did yet behold! O day! O day! O day! O hateful day! Never was seen so black a day as this:
trg: O woful day, O woful day!

src: It is no other: show your wisdom, daughter, In your close patience.
trg: O, I will to him and pluck out his eyes!

src: What's to do here, Thomas tapster? let's withdraw.
trg: Here comes Signior Claudio, led by the provost to prison; and there's Madam Juliet.

src: What valour were it, when a cur doth grin, For one to thrust his hand between his teeth, When he might spurn him with his foot away? It is war's prize to take all vantages;
trg: And ten to one is no impeach of valour.

src: Making the mother, wife and child to see The son, the husband and the father tearing His country's bowels out. And to poor we Thine enmity's most capital:
trg: thou barr'st us Our prayers to the gods, which is a comfort That all but we enjoy; for how can we, Alas, how can we for our country pray.

src: ' but be 't known, From him that has most cause to grieve it should be, She's an adulteress.
trg: Should a villain say so, The most replenish'd villain in the world, He were as much more villain: you, my lord, Do but mistake.

src: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee, For in Baptista's keep my treasure is:
trg: Therefore this order hath Baptista ta'en, That none shall have access unto Bianca Till Katharina the curst have got a husband.

src: Roundly replied.
trg: Mistress, how mean you that?

src: A woman moved is like a fountain troubled, Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty; And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it.
trg: Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper, Thy head, thy sovereign; And craves no other tribute at thy hands But love, fair looks and true obedience; Too little payment for so great a debt.

src: A whoreson beetle-headed, flap-ear'd knave! Come, Kate, sit down; I know you have a stomach. Will you give thanks, sweet Kate; or else shall I? What's this? mutton?
trg: Ay.

src: This is the matter:--Nurse, give leave awhile, We must talk in secret:--nurse, come back again; I have remember'd me, thou's hear our counsel. Thou know'st my daughter's of a pretty age.
trg: Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.

src: one nail, one nail; Rights by rights falter, strengths by strengths do fail. Come, let's away. When, Caius, Rome is thine, Thou art poor'st of all; then shortly art thou mine.
trg: No, I'll not go: you hear what he hath said Which was sometime his general; who loved him In a most dear particular. He call'd me father: But what o' that? Go, you that banish'd him;

src: For never yet one hour in his bed Have I enjoy'd the golden dew of sleep, But have been waked by his timorous dreams. Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick;
trg: And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.

src: Yea, say you so? There shall not at your father's house these seven years Be born another such.
trg: My good Camillo, She is as forward of her breeding as She is i' the rear our birth.

src: Kill, kill, kill, kill, kill him!
trg: Hold, hold, hold, hold!

src: Arm'd as we are, let's stay within this house.
trg: The bloody parliament shall this be call'd, Unless Plantagenet, Duke of York, be king, And bashful Henry deposed, whose cowardice Hath made us by-words to our enemies.

src: I beseech your honour, ask me.
trg: Well, sir; what did this gentleman to her?

src: No; for he could not so resign his crown But that the next heir should succeed and reign.
trg: Art thou against us, Duke of Exeter?

src: Nay, my good soldier, up; My gentle Marcius, worthy Caius, and By deed-achieving honour newly named,-- What is it?--Coriolanus must I call thee?-- But O, thy wife!
trg: My gracious silence, hail! Wouldst thou have laugh'd had I come coffin'd home, That weep'st to see me triumph? Ay, my dear, Such eyes the widows in Corioli wear, And mothers that lack sons.

src: Is it your will Claudio shall die tomorrow?
trg: Did not I tell thee yea? hadst thou not order? Why dost thou ask again?

src: Sin from thy lips? O trespass sweetly urged! Give me my sin again.
trg: You kiss by the book.

src: I promised we would be contributors And bear his charging of wooing, whatsoe'er.
trg: And so we will, provided that he win her.

src: To keep that oath were more impiety Than Jephthah's, when he sacrificed his daughter. And so, proud-hearted Warwick, I defy thee, And to my brother turn my blushing cheeks.
trg: Pardon me, Edward, I will make amends: And, Richard, do not frown upon my faults, For I will henceforth be no more unconstant.

src: But, for your son,--believe it, O, believe it, Most dangerously you have with him prevail'd, If not most mortal to him. But, let it come.
trg: Aufidius, though I cannot make true wars, I'll frame convenient peace. Now, good Aufidius, Were you in my stead, would you have heard A mother less? or granted less, Aufidius?

src: Ay, while you live, draw your neck out o' the collar.
trg: I strike quickly, being moved.

src: And so are like to do.
trg: That is the way to lay the city flat; To bring the roof to the foundation, And bury all, which yet distinctly ranges, In heaps and piles of ruin.

src: An easy task; 'tis but to love a king.
trg: That's soon perform'd, because I am a subject.

src: Your patience this allowing, I turn my glass and give my scene such growing As you had slept between: and with speed so pace To speak of Perdita, now grown in grace Equal with wondering:
trg: what of her ensues I list not prophecy; but let Time's news Be known when 'tis brought forth. A shepherd's daughter, And what to her adheres, which follows after, Is the argument of Time.

src: But, for those earthly faults, I quit them all; And pray thee take this mercy to provide For better times to come. Friar, advise him; I leave him to your hand. What muffled fellow's that?
trg: This is another prisoner that I saved. Who should have died when Claudio lost his head; As like almost to Claudio as himself.

src: Mi perdonato, gentle master mine, I am in all affected as yourself; Glad that you thus continue your resolve To suck the sweets of sweet philosophy.
trg: Only, good master, while we do admire This virtue and this moral discipline, Let's be no stoics nor no stocks, I pray; Or so devote to Aristotle's cheques As Ovid be an outcast quite abjured:

src: So please your lordship to accept our duty.
trg: With all my heart. This fellow I remember, Since once he play'd a farmer's eldest son: 'Twas where you woo'd the gentlewoman so well: I have forgot your name;

src: Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hair.
trg: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.

src: What though the mast be now blown overboard, The cable broke, the holding-anchor lost, And half our sailors swallow'd in the flood? Yet lives our pilot still. Ah, what a shame!
trg: ah, what a fault were this! Say Warwick was our anchor; what of that? And Montague our topmost; what of him? Our slaughter'd friends the tackles; what of these?

src: thou shalt be pinch'd As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging Than bees that made 'em.
trg: I must eat my dinner. This island's mine, by Sycorax my mother, Which thou takest from me.

src: Stay, officer: he shall not go to prison.
trg: Talk not, Signior Gremio: I say he shall go to prison.

src: Know, good mother, I had rather be their servant in my way, Than sway with them in theirs.
trg: On, to the Capitol!

src: or an old trot with ne'er a tooth in her head, though she have as many diseases as two and fifty horses: why, nothing comes amiss, so money comes withal.
trg: Petruchio, since we are stepp'd thus far in, I will continue that I broach'd in jest.

src: That at her hands which the king's King forbids.
trg: Say, she shall be a high and mighty queen.

src: a man, they say, that from very nothing, and beyond the imagination of his neighbours, is grown into an unspeakable estate.
trg: I have heard, sir, of such a man, who hath a daughter of most rare note: the report of her is extended more than can be thought to begin from such a cottage.

src: Gentle my liege,--
trg: You do but lose your labour. Away with him to death! Now, sir, to you.

src: Go to kennel, Pompey; go. What news, friar, of the duke?
trg: I know none. Can you tell me of any?

src: and my soul aches To know, when two authorities are up, Neither supreme, how soon confusion May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take The one by the other.
trg: Well, on to the market-place.

src: I'll lay fourteen of my teeth,-- And yet, to my teeth be it spoken, I have but four-- She is not fourteen. How long is it now To Lammas-tide?
trg: A fortnight and odd days.

src: That is the way to lay the city flat; To bring the roof to the foundation, And bury all, which yet distinctly ranges, In heaps and piles of ruin.
trg: This deserves death.

src: 'Twere pity they should lose their father's lands.
trg: Be pitiful, dread lord, and grant it then.

src: Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish. Which of you, if you were a prince's son, Being pent from liberty, as I am now, if two such murderers as yourselves came to you, Would not entreat for life?
trg: My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks:

src: and, but infirmity Which waits upon worn times hath something seized His wish'd ability, he had himself The lands and waters 'twixt your throne and his Measured to look upon you;
trg: whom he loves-- He bade me say so--more than all the sceptres And those that bear them living.

src: I cannot say 'tis pity She lacks instructions, for she seems a mistress To most that teach.
trg: Your pardon, sir; for this I'll blush you thanks.

src: Come, come, you wasp; i' faith, you are too angry.
trg: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

src: I dare not, sir My master knows not but I am gone hence; And fearfully did menace me with death, If I did stay to look on his intents.
trg: Stay, then; I'll go alone. Fear comes upon me: O, much I fear some ill unlucky thing.

src: I cannot tell, good sir, for which of his virtues it was, but he was certainly whipped out of the court.
trg: His vices, you would say; there's no virtue whipped out of the court: they cherish it to make it stay there; and yet it will no more but abide.

src: See that Claudio Be executed by nine to-morrow morning: Bring him his confessor, let him be prepared; For that's the utmost of his pilgrimage.
Not to his father's; I spoke with his man.
trg: Ah, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline. Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.

src: I have no superfluous leisure; my stay must be stolen out of other affairs; but I will attend you awhile.
trg: Son, I have overheard what hath passed between you and your sister. Angelo had never the purpose to corrupt her;

src: Your followers I will whisper to the business, And will by twos and threes at several posterns Clear them o' the city.
trg: For myself, I'll put My fortunes to your service, which are here By this discovery lost. Be not uncertain; For, by the honour of my parents, I Have utter'd truth:

src: So, fare you well; Unless you please to enter in the castle And there repose you for this night.
trg: An offer, uncle, that we will accept:

src: for, brother, if thou didst, Thy tears would wash this cold congealed blood That glues my lips and will not let me speak. Come quickly, Montague, or I am dead.
trg: Ah, Warwick! Montague hath breathed his last; And to the latest gasp cried out for Warwick, And said 'Commend me to my valiant brother.

src: By giving liberty unto thine eyes; Examine other beauties.
trg: 'Tis the way To call hers exquisite, in question more: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows Being black put us in mind they hide the fair;

src: Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick! Yet am I arm'd against the worst can happen; And haste is needful in this desperate case.
trg: Pembroke and Stafford, you in our behalf Go levy men, and make prepare for war; They are already, or quickly will be landed: Myself in person will straight follow you.

src: Plantagenet, of thee and these thy sons, Thy kinsman and thy friends, I'll have more lives Than drops of blood were in my father's veins.
trg: Urge it no more; lest that, instead of words, I send thee, Warwick, such a messenger As shall revenge his death before I stir.

src: nor, night, thy rest! Be opposite all planets of good luck To my proceedings, if, with pure heart's love, Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts, I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter!
trg: In her consists my happiness and thine; Without her, follows to this land and me, To thee, herself, and many a Christian soul, Death, desolation, ruin and decay: It cannot be avoided but by this;

src: Groping for trouts in a peculiar river.
trg: What, is there a maid with child by him?

src: To Coriolanus come all joy and honour!
trg: You see how he intends to use the people.

src: And happily I have arrived at the last Unto the wished haven of my bliss. What Tranio did, myself enforced him to; Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.
trg: I'll slit the villain's nose, that would have sent me to the gaol.

src: If therefore you dare trust my honesty, That lies enclosed in this trunk which you Shall bear along impawn'd, away to-night!
trg: Your followers I will whisper to the business, And will by twos and threes at several posterns Clear them o' the city.

src: Now, as fond fathers, Having bound up the threatening twigs of birch, Only to stick it in their children's sight For terror, not to use, in time the rod Becomes more mock'd than fear'd;
trg: so our decrees, Dead to infliction, to themselves are dead; And liberty plucks justice by the nose; The baby beats the nurse, and quite athwart Goes all decorum.

src: Well, Go muster men; but, hear you, leave behind Your son, George Stanley: look your faith be firm. Or else his head's assurance is but frail.
trg: So deal with him as I prove true to you.

src: And, if though canst for blushing, view this face, And bite thy tongue, that slanders him with cowardice Whose frown hath made thee faint and fly ere this!
trg: I will not bandy with thee word for word, But buckle with thee blows, twice two for one.

src: What is't your highness' pleasure I shall do at Salisbury?
trg: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?

src: which, God he knows, Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart. Those uncles which you want were dangerous; Your grace attended to their sugar'd words, But look'd not on the poison of their hearts :
trg: God keep you from them, and from such false friends!

src: Here, sir; as foolish as I was before.
trg: You peasant swain! you whoreson malt-horse drudge! Did I not bid thee meet me in the park, And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?

src: I know none. Can you tell me of any?
trg: Some say he is with the Emperor of Russia; other some, he is in Rome: but where is he, think you?

src: Now breathe we, lords: good fortune bids us pause, And smooth the frowns of war with peaceful looks.
trg: Some troops pursue the bloody-minded queen, That led calm Henry, though he were a king, As doth a sail, fill'd with a fretting gust, Command an argosy to stem the waves.

src: 'Hic ibat,' as I told you before, 'Simois,' I am Lucentio, 'hic est,' son unto Vincentio of Pisa, 'Sigeia tellus,' disguised thus to get your love;
trg: 'Hic steterat,' and that Lucentio that comes a-wooing, 'Priami,' is my man Tranio, 'regia,' bearing my port, 'celsa senis,' that we might beguile the old pantaloon.

src: Ay, by my faith, for a poor earl to give: I'll do thee service for so good a gift.
trg: 'Twas I that gave the kingdom to thy brother.

src: These are the ushers of Marcius: before him he carries noise, and behind him he leaves tears: Death, that dark spirit, in 's nervy arm doth lie; Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die.
trg: Know, Rome, that all alone Marcius did fight Within Corioli gates: where he hath won, With fame, a name to Caius Marcius; these In honour follows Coriolanus. Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!

src: Ourselves, our wives, and children, on our knees, Are bound to pray for you both.
trg: Live, and thrive!

src: which who knows how that may turn back to my advancement? I will bring these two moles, these blind ones, aboard him:
trg: if he think it fit to shore them again and that the complaint they have to the king concerns him nothing, let him call me rogue for being so far officious;

src: If I unwittingly, or in my rage, Have aught committed that is hardly borne By any in this presence, I desire To reconcile me to his friendly peace: 'Tis death to me to be at enmity;
trg: I hate it, and desire all good men's love. First, madam, I entreat true peace of you, Which I will purchase with my duteous service;

src: I pray thee, peace: my soul is full of sorrow.
trg: I will not rise, unless your highness grant.

src: Sirrah, lead these gentlemen To my daughters; and tell them both, These are their tutors: bid them use them well. We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner.
trg: You are passing welcome, And so I pray you all to think yourselves.

src: No, sir; but hear I do that he hath two, The one as famous for a scolding tongue As is the other for beauteous modesty.
trg: Sir, sir, the first's for me; let her go by.

src: You are old enough now, and yet, methinks, you lose. Father, tear the crown from the usurper's head.
trg: Sweet father, do so; set it on your head.

src: Especially in pride.
trg: And topping all others in boasting.

src: Head, and butt! an hasty-witted body Would say your head and butt were head and horn.
trg: Ay, mistress bride, hath that awaken'd you?

src: Who, I, my lord I we know each other's faces, But for our hearts, he knows no more of mine, Than I of yours; Nor I no more of his, than you of mine. Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.
