trg: I thank his grace, I know he loves me well; But, for his purpose in the coronation. I have not sounded him, nor he deliver'd His gracious pleasure any way therein:

src: I'll not meddle with it: it is a dangerous thing: it makes a man a coward: a man cannot steal, but it accuseth him; he cannot swear, but it cheques him;
trg: he cannot lie with his neighbour's wife, but it detects him: 'tis a blushing shamefast spirit that mutinies in a man's bosom; it fills one full of obstacles:

src: What else? and that succession be determined.
trg: Ay, therein Clarence shall not want his part.

src: O, cut my lace in sunder, that my pent heart May have some scope to beat, or else I swoon With this dead-killing news!
trg: Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news!

src: He's not confirm'd; we may deny him yet.
trg: And will deny him: I'll have five hundred voices of that sound.

src: My lord, Is this the daughter of a king?
trg: She is, When once she is my wife.

src: Bliss and goodness on you!
trg: Of whence are you?

src: O God!--O nurse, how shall this be prevented? My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven; How shall that faith return again to earth, Unless that husband send it me from heaven By leaving earth?
trg: comfort me, counsel me. Alack, alack, that heaven should practise stratagems Upon so soft a subject as myself! What say'st thou? hast thou not a word of joy? Some comfort, nurse.

src: Good father, I beseech you on my knees, Hear me with patience but to speak a word.
trg: Hang thee, young baggage! disobedient wretch! I tell thee what: get thee to church o' Thursday, Or never after look me in the face: Speak not, reply not, do not answer me; My fingers itch.

src: Good sister, wrong me not, nor wrong yourself, To make a bondmaid and a slave of me; That I disdain:
trg: but for these other gawds, Unbind my hands, I'll pull them off myself, Yea, all my raiment, to my petticoat; Or what you will command me will I do, So well I know my duty to my elders.

src: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.
trg: My dagger, little cousin? with all my heart.

src: And not a hair upon a soldier's head Which will not prove a whip: as many coxcombs As you threw caps up will he tumble down, And pay you for your voices. 'Tis no matter;
trg: if he could burn us all into one coal, We have deserved it.

src: Ay, and make't manifest where she has lived, Or how stolen from the dead.
trg: That she is living, Were it but told you, should be hooted at Like an old tale: but it appears she lives, Though yet she speak not. Mark a little while. Please you to interpose, fair madam:

src: Her face defaced with scars of infamy, Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants, And almost shoulder'd in the swallowing gulf Of blind forgetfulness and dark oblivion.
trg: Which to recure, we heartily solicit Your gracious self to take on you the charge And kingly government of this your land, Not as protector, steward, substitute, Or lowly factor for another's gain;

src: The gods assist you!
trg: And keep your honours safe!

src: Sir, I shall tell you. even so most fitly As you malign our senators for that They are not such as you.
trg: Your belly's answer? What! The kingly-crowned head, the vigilant eye, The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier, Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter.

src: Good Clarence, do; sweet Clarence, do thou do it.
trg: Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it?

src: Stays here longer.
trg: Ay, but why?

src: let him be furnished with divines, and have all charitable preparation. if my brother wrought by my pity, it should not be so with him.
trg: So please you, this friar hath been with him, and advised him for the entertainment of death.

src: Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter, And, by that knot, looks proudly o'er the crown, To her I go, a jolly thriving wooer.
trg: My lord!

src: if not, use him for the present and dismiss him. He cannot plead his estimation with you; he hath been a bawd.
trg: A bawd, sir? fie upon him! he will discredit our mystery.

src: all I know of it Is that Camillo was an honest man; And why he left your court, the gods themselves, Wotting no more than I, are ignorant.
trg: You knew of his departure, as you know What you have underta'en to do in's absence.

src: God in thy good cause make thee prosperous! Be swift like lightning in the execution; And let thy blows, doubly redoubled, Fall like amazing thunder on the casque Of thy adverse pernicious enemy:
trg: Rouse up thy youthful blood, be valiant and live.

src: Full well hath Clifford play'd the orator, Inferring arguments of mighty force. But, Clifford, tell me, didst thou never hear That things ill-got had ever bad success?
trg: And happy always was it for that son Whose father for his hoarding went to hell? I'll leave my son my virtuous deeds behind; And would my father had left me no more!

src: Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.
trg: She's not fourteen.

src: O momentary grace of mortal men, Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!
trg: Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks, Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast, Ready, with every nod, to tumble down Into the fatal bowels of the deep.

src: Did you perceive He did solicit you in free contempt When he did need your loves, and do you think That his contempt shall not be bruising to you, When he hath power to crush?
trg: Why, had your bodies No heart among you? or had you tongues to cry Against the rectorship of judgment?

src: Because thy father Henry did usurp; And thou no more are prince than she is queen.
trg: Then Warwick disannuls great John of Gaunt, Which did subdue the greatest part of Spain; And, after John of Gaunt, Henry the Fourth, Whose wisdom was a mirror to the wisest;

src: But had he died in the business, madam; how then?
trg: Then his good report should have been my son; I therein would have found issue. Hear me profess sincerely:

src: When you are hearing a matter between party and party, if you chance to be pinched with the colic, you make faces like mummers; set up the bloody flag against all patience;
trg: and, in roaring for a chamber-pot, dismiss the controversy bleeding the more entangled by your hearing: all the peace you make in their cause is, calling both the parties knaves.

src: Two thousand ducats by the year of land! My land amounts not to so much in all: That she shall have; besides an argosy That now is lying in Marseilles' road. What, have I choked you with an argosy?
trg: Gremio, 'tis known my father hath no less Than three great argosies; besides two galliases, And twelve tight galleys: these I will assure her, And twice as much, whate'er thou offer'st next.

src: To, to, to--
trg: To murder me?

src: Your worship is deceived; the gown is made Just as my master had direction: Grumio gave order how it should be done.
trg: I gave him no order; I gave him the stuff.

src: Go you the next way with your findings. I'll go see if the bear be gone from the gentleman and how much he hath eaten: they are never curst but when they are hungry:
trg: if there be any of him left, I'll bury it.

src: No marrying 'mong his subjects?
trg: None, man; all idle: whores and knaves.

src: Up.
trg: Whither?

src: Evermore thanks, the exchequer of the poor; Which, till my infant fortune comes to years, Stands for my bounty. But who comes here?
trg: It is my Lord of Berkeley, as I guess.

src: I take my leave with many thousand thanks.
I know it well, Lord Warwick; blame me not: 'Tis love I bear thy glories makes me speak. But in this troublous time what's to be done?
trg: Shall we go throw away our coats of steel, And wrap our bodies in black mourning gowns, Numbering our Ave-Maries with our beads?

src: Or docks, or mallows.
trg: And were the king on't, what would I do?

src: You, sir, come you hither;
trg: Any thing, my lord, That my ability may undergo And nobleness impose: at least thus much: I'll pawn the little blood which I have left To save the innocent: any thing possible.

src: O gentle Romeo, If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully: Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won, I'll frown and be perverse an say thee nay, So thou wilt woo; but else, not for the world.
trg: In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond, And therefore thou mayst think my 'havior light: But trust me, gentleman, I'll prove more true Than those that have more cunning to be strange.

src: Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crossed me, thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell and she under her horse;
trg: By this reckoning he is more shrew than she.

src: 'Scape being drunk for want of wine.
trg: I' the commonwealth I would by contraries Execute all things; for no kind of traffic Would I admit; no name of magistrate; Letters should not be known; riches, poverty, And use of service, none;

src: Beseech your highness, call the queen again.
trg: Be certain what you do, sir, lest your justice Prove violence; in the which three great ones suffer, Yourself, your queen, your son.

src: Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy, And leave the world for me to bustle in! For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter. What though I kill'd her husband and her father?
trg: The readiest way to make the wench amends Is to become her husband and her father: The which will I;

src: That you might still have worn the petticoat, And ne'er have stol'n the breech from Lancaster.
trg: Let AEsop fable in a winter's night; His currish riddles sort not with this place.

src: but in this case of wooing, A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.
trg: Fiddler, forbear; you grow too forward, sir: Have you so soon forgot the entertainment Her sister Katharina welcomed you withal?

src: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart, My will to her consent is but a part; An she agree, within her scope of choice Lies my consent and fair according voice.
trg: This night I hold an old accustom'd feast, Whereto I have invited many a guest, Such as I love; and you, among the store, One more, most welcome, makes my number more.

src: If Jupiter Should from yond cloud speak divine things, And say 'Tis true,' I'ld not believe them more Than thee, all noble Marcius.
trg: Let me twine Mine arms about that body, where against My grained ash an hundred times hath broke And scarr'd the moon with splinters:

src: These your unusual weeds to each part of you Do give a life: no shepherdess, but Flora Peering in April's front. This your sheep-shearing Is as a meeting of the petty gods, And you the queen on't.
trg: Sir, my gracious lord, To chide at your extremes it not becomes me: O, pardon, that I name them!

src: you were best say these robes are not gentlemen born: give me the lie, do, and try whether I am not now a gentleman born.
trg: I know you are now, sir, a gentleman born.

src: In dreadful war mayst thou be overcome, Or live in peace abandon'd and despised!
trg: Turn this way, Henry, and regard them not.

src: And here's to right our gentle-hearted king.
trg: Open Thy gate of mercy, gracious God! My soul flies through these wounds to seek out Thee.

src: Nay, but, fellow, fellow,--
trg: What's the matter?

src: Go, fellow, go, return unto thy lord;
trg: Bid him not fear the separated councils His honour and myself are at the one, And at the other is my servant Catesby Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us Whereof I shall not have intelligence.

src: No bending knee will call thee Caesar now, No humble suitors press to speak for right, No, not a man comes for redress of thee; For how can I help them, and not myself?
trg: Ay, here's a deer whose skin's a keeper's fee: This is the quondam king; let's seize upon him.

src: come, let me have a bigger.
trg: I'll have no bigger: this doth fit the time, And gentlewomen wear such caps as these

src: I pray now, keep below.
trg: Where is the master, boatswain?

src: Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye, The day to cheer and night's dank dew to dry, I must up-fill this osier cage of ours With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers.
trg: The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb;

src: O princely Buckingham I'll kiss thy hand, In sign of league and amity with thee: Now fair befal thee and thy noble house!
trg: Thy garments are not spotted with our blood, Nor thou within the compass of my curse.

src: The tongue of Isabel. She's come to know If yet her brother's pardon be come hither: But I will keep her ignorant of her good, To make her heavenly comforts of despair, When it is least expected.
trg: Ho, by your leave!

src: Wrath-kindled gentlemen, be ruled by me; Let's purge this choler without letting blood: This we prescribe, though no physician; Deep malice makes too deep incision; Forget, forgive;
trg: conclude and be agreed; Our doctors say this is no month to bleed. Good uncle, let this end where it begun; We'll calm the Duke of Norfolk, you your son.

src: -- To most ignoble stooping.
trg: O the heavens!

src: which so drew the rest of the herd to me that all their other senses stuck in ears: you might have pinched a placket, it was senseless; 'twas nothing to geld a codpiece of a purse;
trg: I could have filed keys off that hung in chains: no hearing, no feeling, but my sir's song, and admiring the nothing of it.

src: Why then 'tis mine, if but by Warwick's gift.
trg: Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight: And weakling, Warwick takes his gift again; And Henry is my king, Warwick his subject.

src: Well, in that hit you miss: she'll not be hit With Cupid's arrow; she hath Dian's wit; And, in strong proof of chastity well arm'd, From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.
trg: She will not stay the siege of loving terms, Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes, Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:

src: My liege, in Kent the Guildfords are in arms; And every hour more competitors Flock to their aid, and still their power increaseth.
trg: My lord, the army of the Duke of Buckingham--

src: Come on, mistress: here's a gentlewoman denies all that you have said.
trg: My lord, here comes the rascal I spoke of; here with the provost.

src: I see no reason but supposed Lucentio Must get a father, call'd 'supposed Vincentio;' And that's a wonder: fathers commonly Do get their children;
trg: but in this case of wooing, A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.

src: Draw, if you be men. Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.
trg: Part, fools! Put up your swords; you know not what you do.

src: By nothing; for this is no oath: The George, profaned, hath lost his holy honour; The garter, blemish'd, pawn'd his knightly virtue; The crown, usurp'd, disgraced his kingly glory.
trg: if something thou wilt swear to be believed, Swear then by something that thou hast not wrong'd.

src: Now the fair goddess, Fortune, Fall deep in love with thee; and her great charms Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman, Prosperity be thy page!
trg: Thy friend no less Than those she placeth highest! So, farewell.

src: his own bastardy, As being got, your father then in France, His resemblance, being not like the duke;
trg: Withal I did infer your lineaments, Being the right idea of your father, Both in your form and nobleness of mind;

src: Though I am satisfied and need no more Than what I know, yet shall the oracle Give rest to the minds of others, such as he Whose ignorant credulity will not Come up to the truth.
trg: So have we thought it good From our free person she should be confined, Lest that the treachery of the two fled hence Be left her to perform. Come, follow us; We are to speak in public;

src: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.
trg: A dog of the house of Montague moves me.

src: Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune! Why strew'st thou sugar on that bottled spider, Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about? Fool, fool! thou whet'st a knife to kill thyself.
trg: The time will come when thou shalt wish for me To help thee curse that poisonous bunchback'd toad.

src: No? you say your husband.
trg: Why, just, my lord, and that is Angelo, Who thinks he knows that he ne'er knew my body, But knows he thinks that he knows Isabel's.

src: Like a dull actor now, I have forgot my part, and I am out, Even to a full disgrace. Best of my flesh, Forgive my tyranny; but do not say For that 'Forgive our Romans.
trg: ' O, a kiss Long as my exile, sweet as my revenge! Now, by the jealous queen of heaven, that kiss I carried from thee, dear; and my true lip Hath virgin'd it e'er since. You gods!

src: Behind the tuft of pines I met them; never Saw I men scour so on their way: I eyed them Even to their ships.
trg: How blest am I In my just censure, in my true opinion! Alack, for lesser knowledge! how accursed In being so blest!

src: My voice is now the king's, my looks mine own.
trg: How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak! Your eyes do menace me: why look you pale? Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come?

src: Ay, with five hundred, father, for a need: A woman's general; what should we fear?
trg: I hear their drums: let's set our men in order, And issue forth and bid them battle straight.

src: My husband bids me; now I will unmask. This is that face, thou cruel Angelo, Which once thou sworest was worth the looking on;
trg: This is the hand which, with a vow'd contract, Was fast belock'd in thine; this is the body That took away the match from Isabel, And did supply thee at thy garden-house In her imagined person.

src: which that it shall, Is all as monstrous to our human reason As my Antigonus to break his grave And come again to me; who, on my life, Did perish with the infant.
trg: 'Tis your counsel My lord should to the heavens be contrary, Oppose against their wills. Care not for issue; The crown will find an heir: great Alexander Left his to the worthiest;

src: Why then it sorts, brave warriors, let's away. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Welcome, my lord, to this brave town of York. Yonder's the head of that arch-enemy That sought to be encompass'd with your crown: Doth not the object cheer your heart, my lord?

src: But didst thou see them dead?
trg: I did, my lord.

src: O nature, what hadst thou to do in hell, When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend In moral paradise of such sweet flesh? Was ever book containing such vile matter So fairly bound?
trg: O that deceit should dwell In such a gorgeous palace!

src: Come, go, good Juliet, I dare no longer stay.
trg: Go, get thee hence, for I will not away. What's here? a cup, closed in my true love's hand? Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end: O churl! drunk all, and left no friendly drop To help me after?

src: Directitude! what's that?
trg: But when they shall see, sir, his crest up again, and the man in blood, they will out of their burrows, like conies after rain, and revel all with him.

src: Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I'll answer him by law: I'll not budge an inch, boy: let him come, and kindly.
trg: Huntsman, I charge thee, tender well my hounds: Brach Merriman, the poor cur is emboss'd; And couple Clowder with the deep--mouth'd brach.

src: That, had he twenty heads to tender down On twenty bloody blocks, he'ld yield them up, Before his sister should her body stoop To such abhorr'd pollution.
trg: Then, Isabel, live chaste, and, brother, die: More than our brother is our chastity. I'll tell him yet of Angelo's request, And fit his mind to death, for his soul's rest.

src: Sweet widow, by my state I swear to thee I speak no more than what my soul intends; And that is, to enjoy thee for my love.
trg: And that is more than I will yield unto: I know I am too mean to be your queen, And yet too good to be your concubine.

src: Thou canst not, son; it is impossible.
trg: An oath is of no moment, being not took Before a true and lawful magistrate, That hath authority over him that swears: Henry had none, but did usurp the place;

src: Now, Richard, I am with thee here alone: This is the hand that stabb'd thy father York; And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland;
trg: And here's the heart that triumphs in their death And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother To execute the like upon thyself; And so, have at thee!

src: So stands this squire Officed with me: we two will walk, my lord, And leave you to your graver steps. Hermione, How thou lovest us, show in our brother's welcome; Let what is dear in Sicily be cheap:
trg: Next to thyself and my young rover, he's Apparent to my heart.

src: That's a brave fellow; but he's vengeance proud, and loves not the common people.
trg: Faith, there had been many great men that have flattered the people, who ne'er loved them; and there be many that they have loved, they know not wherefore:

src: The gods preserve you both!
trg: God-den, our neighbours.

src: Thou hast hit it: come, sit on me.
trg: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

src: Why stay we to be baited With one that wants her wits?
trg: Take my prayers with you. I would the gods had nothing else to do But to confirm my curses! Could I meet 'em But once a-day, it would unclog my heart Of what lies heavy to't.

src: Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from him last night.
trg: Indeed, madam?

src: But, with the first of all your chief affairs, Let me entreat, for I command no more, That Margaret your queen and my son Edward Be sent for, to return from France with speed;
trg: For, till I see them here, by doubtful fear My joy of liberty is half eclipsed.

src: And Hastings as he favours Edward's cause!
trg: Now, brother Richard, will you stand by us?

src: The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch, But that the sea, mounting to the welkin's cheek, Dashes the fire out. O, I have suffered With those that I saw suffer:
trg: a brave vessel, Who had, no doubt, some noble creature in her, Dash'd all to pieces. O, the cry did knock Against my very heart. Poor souls, they perish'd.

src: Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace, Have no delight to pass away the time, Unless to spy my shadow in the sun And descant on mine own deformity:
trg: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover, To entertain these fair well-spoken days, I am determined to prove a villain And hate the idle pleasures of these days.

src: Who now are here, taking their leaves of me, Who am prepared against your territories, Though not for Rome itself.
trg: You bless me, gods!

src: Nor I.
trg: See, they have shut him in.

src: Good Peter, to hide her face; for her fan's the fairer face.
trg: God ye good morrow, gentlemen.

src: Thou liest, malignant thing! Hast thou forgot The foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy Was grown into a hoop? hast thou forgot her?
trg: No, sir.

src: Ah, would she break from hence, that this my body Might in the ground be closed up in rest! For never henceforth shall I joy again, Never, O never shall I see more joy!
trg: I cannot weep; for all my body's moisture Scarce serves to quench my furnace-burning heart: Nor can my tongue unload my heart's great burthen;

src: My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs: By heaven, I will acquaint his majesty With those gross taunts I often have endured.
trg: I had rather be a country servant-maid Than a great queen, with this condition, To be thus taunted, scorn'd, and baited at: Small joy have I in being England's queen.

src: For nought so vile that on the earth doth live But to the earth some special good doth give, Nor aught so good but strain'd from that fair use Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse:
trg: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied; And vice sometimes by action dignified. Within the infant rind of this small flower Poison hath residence and medicine power:

src: No; if I mistake In those foundations which I build upon, The centre is not big enough to bear A school-boy's top. Away with her! to prison!
trg: He who shall speak for her is afar off guilty But that he speaks.

src: The setting sun, and music at the close, As the last taste of sweets, is sweetest last, Writ in remembrance more than things long past:
trg: Though Richard my life's counsel would not hear, My death's sad tale may yet undeaf his ear.

src: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?
trg: Sir, let me be so bold as ask you, Did you yet ever see Baptista's daughter?

src: Though this island seem to be desert,--
trg: Ha, ha, ha! So, you're paid.

src: We'll surety him.
trg: Aged sir, hands off.

src: Lay't so to his charge: He's with the king your father.
trg: Who? Camillo?

src: Hath she had any more than one husband?
trg: Nine, sir; Overdone by the last.

src: not noted, is't, But of the finer natures? by some severals Of head-piece extraordinary? lower messes Perchance are to this business purblind? say.
trg: Business, my lord! I think most understand Bohemia stays here longer.

src: No, say'st me so, friend? What countryman?
trg: Born in Verona, old Antonio's son: My father dead, my fortune lives for me; And I do hope good days and long to see.

src: I take my leave of you.
trg: Good sir, adieu.

src: Nurse, where's my daughter? call her forth to me.
trg: Now, by my maidenhead, at twelve year old, I bade her come. What, lamb! what, ladybird! God forbid! Where's this girl? What, Juliet!

src: And arms her with the boldness of a wife To her allowing husband! Gone already! Inch-thick, knee-deep, o'er head and ears a fork'd one! Go, play, boy, play:
trg: thy mother plays, and I Play too, but so disgraced a part, whose issue Will hiss me to my grave: contempt and clamour Will be my knell. Go, play, boy, play.

src: Where are the vile beginners of this fray?
trg: O noble prince, I can discover all The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl: There lies the man, slain by young Romeo, That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.

src: Yet who's so blind, but says he sees it not? Bad is the world; and all will come to nought, When such bad dealings must be seen in thought.
trg: How now, my lord, what say the citizens?

src: Come between us, good Benvolio; my wits faint.
trg: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs; or I'll cry a match.

src: God bless your grace with health and happy days!
trg: I thank you, good my lord; and thank you all.

src: And is this all? Then, O you blessed ministers above, Keep me in patience, and with ripen'd time Unfold the evil which is here wrapt up In countenance!
trg: Heaven shield your grace from woe, As I, thus wrong'd, hence unbelieved go!

src: Remember, as thou read'st, thy promise pass'd: I do repent me; read not my name there My heart is not confederate with my hand.
trg: It was, villain, ere thy hand did set it down. I tore it from the traitor's bosom, king; Fear, and not love, begets his penitence:

src: The poorest service is repaid with thanks; And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.
trg: I thank you, sir.

src: It shall be to him then as our good wills, A sure destruction.
trg: So it must fall out To him or our authorities. For an end, We must suggest the people in what hatred He still hath held them;

src: That same villain, Romeo.
It is a rupture that you may easily heal: and the cure of it not only saves your brother, but keeps you from dishonour in doing it.
trg: Show me how, good father.

src: Go not home.
trg: Meet on the market-place. We'll attend you there: Where, if you bring not Marcius, we'll proceed In our first way.

src: Why, then resolve me whether you will or no.
trg: Tut, tut, Thou troublest me; am not in the vein.

src: I do protest, I never injured thee, But love thee better than thou canst devise, Till thou shalt know the reason of my love:
trg: And so, good Capulet,--which name I tender As dearly as my own,--be satisfied.

src: One day too late, I fear me, noble lord, Hath clouded all thy happy days on earth: O, call back yesterday, bid time return, And thou shalt have twelve thousand fighting men!
trg: To-day, to-day, unhappy day, too late, O'erthrows thy joys, friends, fortune and thy state: For all the Welshmen, hearing thou wert dead. Are gone to Bolingbroke, dispersed and fled.

src: prepare To see the life as lively mock'd as ever Still sleep mock'd death: behold, and say 'tis well. I like your silence, it the more shows off Your wonder: but yet speak;
trg: first, you, my liege, Comes it not something near?

src: Ah, one that was a woful looker-on When as the noble Duke of York was slain, Your princely father and my loving lord!
trg: O, speak no more, for I have heard too much.

src: A pair of stocks, you rogue!
trg: Ye are a baggage: the Slys are no rogues; look in the chronicles; we came in with Richard Conqueror. Therefore paucas pallabris; let the world slide: sessa!

src: Your enigma?
trg: You have been a scourge to her enemies, you have been a rod to her friends; you have not indeed loved the common people.

src: know'st thou not That when the searching eye of heaven is hid, Behind the globe, that lights the lower world, Then thieves and robbers range abroad unseen In murders and in outrage, boldly here;
trg: Not all the water in the rough rude sea Can wash the balm off from an anointed king; The breath of worldly men cannot depose The deputy elected by the Lord:

src: alas, I rather hate myself For hateful deeds committed by myself! I am a villain: yet I lie. I am not. Fool, of thyself speak well: fool, do not flatter.
trg: My conscience hath a thousand several tongues, And every tongue brings in a several tale, And every tale condemns me for a villain.

src: A bawd, a bawd, a bawd! so ho!
trg: What hast thou found?

src: by this the weary lords Shall make their way seem short, as mine hath done By sight of what I have, your noble company.
trg: Of much less value is my company Than your good words. But who comes here?

src: My gracious lord, I come but for mine own.
trg: Your own is yours, and I am yours, and all.

src: If I should be! I had rather be a pedlar: Far be it from my heart, the thought of it!
trg: As little joy, my lord, as you suppose You should enjoy, were you this country's king, As little joy may you suppose in me. That I enjoy, being the queen thereof.

src: And, after that wise prince, Henry the Fifth, Who by his prowess conquered all France: From these our Henry lineally descends.
trg: Oxford, how haps it, in this smooth discourse, You told not how Henry the Sixth hath lost All that which Henry Fifth had gotten? Methinks these peers of France should smile at that.

src: Mine ear is open and my heart prepared; The worst is worldly loss thou canst unfold. Say, is my kingdom lost? why, 'twas my care And what loss is it to be rid of care?
trg: Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we? Greater he shall not be; if he serve God, We'll serve Him too and be his fellow so: Revolt our subjects? that we cannot mend;

src: My wife, sir, whom I detest before heaven and your honour,--
trg: How? thy wife?

src: For never was a story of more woe Than this of Juliet and her Romeo.
trg: I wonder how the king escaped our hands.

src: After my death the one half of my lands, And in possession twenty thousand crowns.
trg: And, for that dowry, I'll assure her of Her widowhood, be it that she survive me, In all my lands and leases whatsoever:

src: No, never such an oath; nor will not now.
trg: Where did you dwell when I was King of England?

src: he utters them as he had eaten ballads and all men's ears grew to his tunes.
trg: He could never come better; he shall come in. I love a ballad but even too well, if it be doleful matter merrily set down, or a very pleasant thing indeed and sung lamentably.

src: Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.
trg: Talk not to me, for I'll not speak a word: Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.

src: True, Clifford; and that's Richard Duke of York.
trg: And shall I stand, and thou sit in my throne?

src: I am denied to sue my livery here, And yet my letters-patents give me leave: My father's goods are all distrain'd and sold, And these and all are all amiss employ'd. What would you have me do?
trg: I am a subject, And I challenge law: attorneys are denied me; And therefore, personally I lay my claim To my inheritance of free descent.

src: Ah sir! ah sir! Well, death's the end of all.
trg: Spakest thou of Juliet? how is it with her? Doth she not think me an old murderer, Now I have stain'd the childhood of our joy With blood removed but little from her own? Where is she?

src: Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!
trg: He'll beat Aufidius 'head below his knee And tread upon his neck.

src: Now, fair befall you! he deserved his death; And you my good lords, both have well proceeded, To warn false traitors from the like attempts.
trg: I never look'd for better at his hands, After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.

src: For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.
trg: And bad'st me bury love.

src: At the hour of nine.
trg: I will not fail: 'tis twenty years till then. I have forgot why I did call thee back.

src: A horse! a horse! my kingdom for a horse!
trg: Withdraw, my lord; I'll help you to a horse.

src: Richard and Hastings: let them go; here is The duke.
trg: The duke! Why, Warwick, when we parted, Thou call'dst me king.

src: undone! If I might die within this hour, I have lived To die when I desire.
trg: Why look you so upon me? I am but sorry, not afeard; delay'd, But nothing alter'd: what I was, I am; More straining on for plucking back, not following My leash unwillingly.

src: Fie, daughter! when my old wife lived, upon This day she was both pantler, butler, cook, Both dame and servant; welcomed all, served all; Would sing her song and dance her turn;
trg: now here, At upper end o' the table, now i' the middle; On his shoulder, and his; her face o' fire With labour and the thing she took to quench it, She would to each one sip.

src: Tranio, let's go: one thing more rests, that thyself execute, to make one among these wooers: if thou ask me why, sufficeth, my reasons are both good and weighty.
trg: My lord, you nod; you do not mind the play.

src: how these vain weak nails May tear a passage through the flinty ribs Of this hard world, my ragged prison walls, And, for they cannot, die in their own pride.
trg: Thoughts tending to content flatter themselves That they are not the first of fortune's slaves, Nor shall not be the last;

src: O, bid me leap, rather than marry Paris, From off the battlements of yonder tower; Or walk in thievish ways; or bid me lurk Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears;
trg: Or shut me nightly in a charnel-house, O'er-cover'd quite with dead men's rattling bones, With reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls;

src: So looks the pent-up lion o'er the wretch That trembles under his devouring paws; And so he walks, insulting o'er his prey, And so he comes, to rend his limbs asunder.
trg: Ah, gentle Clifford, kill me with thy sword, And not with such a cruel threatening look. Sweet Clifford, hear me speak before I die. I am too mean a subject for thy wrath:

src: I can't say your worships have delivered the matter well, when I find the ass in compound with the major part of your syllables:
trg: and though I must be content to bear with those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they lie deadly that tell you you have good faces.

src: Sweet Oxford, and my loving Montague, And all at once, once more a happy farewell.
trg: Farewell, sweet lords: let's meet at Coventry.

src: What then?
trg: What then! He'ld make an end of thy posterity.

src: We are all undone, unless The noble man have mercy.
trg: Who shall ask it? The tribunes cannot do't for shame; the people Deserve such pity of him as the wolf Does of the shepherds:

src: What is the matter That being pass'd for consul with full voice, I am so dishonour'd that the very hour You take it off again?
trg: Answer to us.

src: Have you importuned him by any means?
trg: Both by myself and many other friends: Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow. We would as willingly give cure as know.

src: No, Warwick, thou art worthy of the sway, To whom the heavens in thy nativity Adjudged an olive branch and laurel crown, As likely to be blest in peace and war;
trg: And therefore I yield thee my free consent.

src: This shows a sound affection.
trg: But, my daughter, Say you the like to him?

src: and, with unattainted eye, Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.
trg: When the devout religion of mine eye Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires; And these, who often drown'd could never die, Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!

src: My prisoner? or my guest? by your dread 'Verily,' One of them you shall be.
trg: Your guest, then, madam: To be your prisoner should import offending; Which is for me less easy to commit Than you to punish.

src: Tush, thou art deceived: Leave me, and do the thing I bid thee do. Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?
trg: No, my good lord.

src: Well, let them rest. Come hither, Catesby. Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend As closely to conceal what we impart: Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way; What think'st thou?
trg: is it not an easy matter To make William Lord Hastings of our mind, For the instalment of this noble duke In the seat royal of this famous isle?

src: Thanks, good friend Escalus, for thy much goodness: There's more behind that is more gratulate. Thanks, provost, for thy care and secrecy: We shill employ thee in a worthier place.
trg: Forgive him, Angelo, that brought you home The head of Ragozine for Claudio's: The offence pardons itself. Dear Isabel, I have a motion much imports your good;

src: And that you not delay the present, but, Filling the air with swords advanced and darts, We prove this very hour.
trg: Though I could wish You were conducted to a gentle bath And balms applied to, you, yet dare I never Deny your asking: take your choice of those That best can aid your action.

src: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret, With them Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.
trg: Who hath committed them?

src: Now is this golden crown like a deep well That owes two buckets, filling one another, The emptier ever dancing in the air, The other down, unseen and full of water:
trg: That bucket down and full of tears am I, Drinking my griefs, whilst you mount up on high.

src: How often have I told you 'twould be thus! How often said, my dignity would last But till 'twere known!
trg: It cannot fail but by The violation of my faith; and then Let nature crush the sides o' the earth together And mar the seeds within! Lift up thy looks: From my succession wipe me, father;

src: yet had he framed to himself, by the instruction of his frailty, many deceiving promises of life; which I by my good leisure have discredited to him, and now is he resolved to die.
trg: You have paid the heavens your function, and the prisoner the very debt of your calling. I have laboured for the poor gentleman to the extremest shore of my modesty:

src: Rage must be withstood: Give me his gage: lions make leopards tame.
trg: Yea, but not change his spots: take but my shame. And I resign my gage. My dear dear lord, The purest treasure mortal times afford Is spotless reputation:

src: Give me no help in lamentation;
trg: I am not barren to bring forth complaints All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes, That I, being govern'd by the watery moon, May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world!

src: Mates, maid! how mean you that? no mates for you, Unless you were of gentler, milder mould.
trg: I'faith, sir, you shall never need to fear: I wis it is not half way to her heart;

src: Ay, if I know the letters and the language.
trg: Ye say honestly: rest you merry!

src: Well, well; there's one yonder arrested and carried to prison was worth five thousand of you all.
trg: Who's that, I pray thee?

src: Marry, I thank your worship for it. Thou seest, thou wicked varlet, now, what's come upon thee: thou art to continue now, thou varlet; thou art to continue.
trg: Where were you born, friend?

src: This is desperate, sir.
trg: So call it: but it does fulfil my vow; I needs must think it honesty.

src: No, my good lord; it is more pleasing stuff.
trg: What, household stuff?

src: Sitting on a bank, Weeping again the king my father's wreck, This music crept by me upon the waters, Allaying both their fury and my passion With its sweet air:
trg: thence I have follow'd it, Or it hath drawn me rather. But 'tis gone. No, it begins again. Full fathom five thy father lies; Of his bones are coral made; Those are pearls that were his eyes:

src: be you judge Of your own cause. Is this the witness, friar? First, let her show her face, and after speak.
trg: Pardon, my lord; I will not show my face Until my husband bid me.

src: Of whence are you?
trg: Not of this country, though my chance is now To use it for my time: I am a brother Of gracious order, late come from the See In special business from his holiness.

src: Prithee, fellow, remember my name is Menenius, always factionary on the party of your general.
trg: Howsoever you have been his liar, as you say you have, I am one that, telling true under him, must say, you cannot pass. Therefore, go back.

src: I would they were, that I might die at once; For now they kill me with a living death. Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears, Shamed their aspect with store of childish drops:
trg: These eyes that never shed remorseful tear, No, when my father York and Edward wept, To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him;

src: I long with all my heart to see the prince: I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.
trg: But I hear, no; they say my son of York Hath almost overta'en him in his growth.

src: 'Then music with her silver sound With speedy help doth lend redress.'
trg: What a pestilent knave is this same!

src: Go, do our bidding; hence!
trg: Beseech your highness, call the queen again.

src: I beseech your grace to pardon me, and withal Forbear your conference with the noble duke.
trg: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.

src: Ay, but thou usest to forswear thyself: 'Twas sin before, but now 'tis charity. What, wilt thou not? Where is that devil's butcher, Hard-favour'd Richard? Richard, where art thou? Thou art not here:
trg: murder is thy alms-deed; Petitioners for blood thou ne'er put'st back.

src: A daughter, and a goodly babe, Lusty and like to live: the queen receives Much comfort in't; says 'My poor prisoner, I am innocent as you.'
trg: I dare be sworn These dangerous unsafe lunes i' the king, beshrew them! He must be told on't, and he shall: the office Becomes a woman best; I'll take't upon me:

src: And therefore let me be thus bold with you To give you over at this first encounter, Unless you will accompany me thither.
trg: I pray you, sir, let him go while the humour lasts. O' my word, an she knew him as well as I do, she would think scolding would do little good upon him:

src: I know you well, sir, and you know me: your name, I think, is Adrian.
trg: It is so, sir: truly, I have forgot you.

src: doubt not of the day, And, that once gotten, doubt not of large pay. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: What counsel, lords? Edward from Belgia, With hasty Germans and blunt Hollanders, Hath pass'd in safety through the narrow seas, And with his troops doth march amain to London;

src: Hang, cur! hang, you whoreson, insolent noisemaker! We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.
trg: I'll warrant him for drowning; though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as an unstanched wench.

src: I thank thee, master.
trg: If thou more murmur'st, I will rend an oak And peg thee in his knotty entrails till Thou hast howl'd away twelve winters.

src: I blame not her, she could say little less; She had the wrong. But what said Henry's queen? For I have heard that she was there in place.
trg: 'Tell him,' quoth she, 'my mourning weeds are done, And I am ready to put armour on.'

src: It is, my lord.
trg: Bid my guard watch; leave me. Ratcliff, about the mid of night come to my tent And help to arm me. Leave me, I say.

src: And for that offence Immediately we do exile him hence: I have an interest in your hate's proceeding, My blood for your rude brawls doth lie a-bleeding;
trg: But I'll amerce you with so strong a fine That you shall all repent the loss of mine: I will be deaf to pleading and excuses; Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses: Therefore use none:

src: O, remember, God To hear her prayers for them, as now for us And for my sister and her princely sons, Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood, Which, as thou know'st, unjustly must be spilt.
trg: Make haste; the hour of death is expiate.

src: For one commanding all, obey'd of none. Thus hath the course of justice wheel'd about, And left thee but a very prey to time;
trg: Having no more but thought of what thou wert, To torture thee the more, being what thou art. Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?

src: Signior Lucentio, Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow Never to woo her no more, but do forswear her, As one unworthy all the former favours That I have fondly flatter'd her withal.
trg: And here I take the unfeigned oath, Never to marry with her though she would entreat: Fie on her! see, how beastly she doth court him!

src: confederates-- So dry he was for sway--wi' the King of Naples To give him annual tribute, do him homage, Subject his coronet to his crown and bend The dukedom yet unbow'd--alas, poor Milan!
trg: -- To most ignoble stooping.

src: Wear it, enjoy it, and make much of it.
trg: Great God of heaven, say Amen to all! But, tell me, is young George Stanley living?
I pray you, sir, is it your will To make a stale of me amongst these mates?

src: Our scouts have found the adventure very easy: I say not, slaughter him, For I intend but only to surprise him. You that will follow me to this attempt, Applaud the name of Henry with your leader.
trg: Why, then, let's on our way in silent sort: For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George! 3 KING HENRY VI

src: Well said: follow me this jest now till thou hast worn out thy pump, that when the single sole of it is worn, the jest may remain after the wearing sole singular.
trg: O single-soled jest, solely singular for the singleness.

src: To Edward, but not to the English king.
trg: Deceitful Warwick! it was thy device By this alliance to make void my suit: Before thy coming Lewis was Henry's friend.

src: My breast can better brook thy dagger's point Than can my ears that tragic history. But wherefore dost thou come? is't for my life?
trg: Think'st thou I am an executioner?

src: Heigh, my hearts! cheerly, cheerly, my hearts! yare, yare! Take in the topsail. Tend to the master's whistle. Blow, till thou burst thy wind, if room enough!
trg: Good boatswain, have care. Where's the master? Play the men.

src: I would not for the wealth of all the town Here in my house do him disparagement: Therefore be patient, take no note of him:
trg: It is my will, the which if thou respect, Show a fair presence and put off these frowns, And ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.

src: Some troops pursue the bloody-minded queen, That led calm Henry, though he were a king, As doth a sail, fill'd with a fretting gust, Command an argosy to stem the waves.
trg: But think you, lords, that Clifford fled with them?

src: Young Romeo is it?
trg: 'Tis he, that villain Romeo.

src: Pray, let us go.
trg: Now, pray, sir, get you gone: You have done a brave deed. Ere you go, hear this:

src: Come, come, he must not. Mark our contract.
trg: Mark your divorce, young sir, Whom son I dare not call; thou art too base To be acknowledged: thou a sceptre's heir, That thus affect'st a sheep-hook!

src: I task the earth to the like, forsworn Aumerle; And spur thee on with full as many lies As may be holloa'd in thy treacherous ear From sun to sun: there is my honour's pawn;
trg: Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.

src: No, no, my lord.
trg: It is; you lie, you lie:

src: But now I see our lances are but straws, Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.
trg: Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot, And place your hands below your husband's foot: In token of which duty, if he please, My hand is ready; may it do him ease.

src: My Lord of York will still be cross in talk: Uncle, your grace knows how to bear with him.
trg: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me: Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me; Because that I am little, like an ape, He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

src: There's fire ready; and therefore, good Grumio, the news.
trg: Why, 'Jack, boy! ho! boy!' and as much news as will thaw.

src: By your renouncement an immortal spirit, And to be talk'd with in sincerity, As with a saint.
trg: You do blaspheme the good in mocking me.

src: yet remember this, God and our good cause fight upon our side; The prayers of holy saints and wronged souls, Like high-rear'd bulwarks, stand before our faces;
trg: Richard except, those whom we fight against Had rather have us win than him they follow: For what is he they follow?  truly, gentlemen, A bloody tyrant and a homicide;

src: My lord, I am more amazed at his dishonour Than at the strangeness of it.
trg: Come hither, Isabel. Your friar is now your prince: as I was then Advertising and holy to your business, Not changing heart with habit, I am still Attorney'd at your service.

src: Tush, tush!
trg: A good demand.

src: What doth our cousin lay to Mowbray's charge? It must be great that can inherit us So much as of a thought of ill in him.
trg: Look, what I speak, my life shall prove it true;

src: Here, Hastings; I will never more remember Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine!
trg: Dorset, embrace him; Hastings, love lord marquess.

src: now 'tis awake Takes note of what is done;
trg: Yet show some pity.

src: Go hence; good night; and here stands all your state: Either be gone before the watch be set, Or by the break of day disguised from hence: Sojourn in Mantua;
trg: I'll find out your man, And he shall signify from time to time Every good hap to you that chances here: Give me thy hand; 'tis late: farewell; good night.

src: I'll stay above the hill, so both may shoot.
trg: That cannot be; the noise of thy cross-bow Will scare the herd, and so my shoot is lost. Here stand we both, and aim we at the best:

src: Lead their successes as we wish our own, That both our powers, with smiling fronts encountering, May give you thankful sacrifice. Thy news?
trg: The citizens of Corioli have issued, And given to Lartius and to Marcius battle: I saw our party to their trenches driven, And then I came away.

src: For God's sake, take away this captive scold.
trg: Nay, take away this scolding crookback rather.

src: Marcius, his name?
trg: By Jupiter! forgot. I am weary; yea, my memory is tired. Have we no wine here?

src: Nor I; my spirits are nimble. They fell together all, as by consent; They dropp'd, as by a thunder-stroke. What might, Worthy Sebastian? O, what might?--No more:
trg: -- And yet me thinks I see it in thy face, What thou shouldst be: the occasion speaks thee, and My strong imagination sees a crown Dropping upon thy head.

src: and I should wrong it, To lock it in the wards of covert bosom, When it deserves, with characters of brass, A forted residence 'gainst the tooth of time And razure of oblivion.
trg: Give me your hand, And let the subject see, to make them know That outward courtesies would fain proclaim Favours that keep within. Come, Escalus, You must walk by us on our other hand;

src: My lord, I dare not: Sir Pierce of Exton, who lately came from the king, commands the contrary.
trg: The devil take Henry of Lancaster and thee! Patience is stale, and I am weary of it.

src: Yes, better, sir.
trg: You lie.

src: Come, sir, I know what I know.
trg: I can hardly believe that, since you know not what you speak. But, if ever the duke return, as our prayers are he may, let me desire you to make your answer before him.

src: He makes a July's day short as December, And with his varying childness cures in me Thoughts that would thick my blood.
trg: So stands this squire Officed with me: we two will walk, my lord, And leave you to your graver steps. Hermione, How thou lovest us, show in our brother's welcome; Let what is dear in Sicily be cheap:

src: All houses in the suburbs of Vienna must be plucked down.
trg: And what shall become of those in the city?

src: Our praises are our wages: you may ride's With one soft kiss a thousand furlongs ere With spur we beat an acre. But to the goal: My last good deed was to entreat his stay: What was my first?
trg: it has an elder sister, Or I mistake you: O, would her name were Grace! But once before I spoke to the purpose: when? Nay, let me have't; I long.

src: This is strange: methinks My favour here begins to warp. Not speak? Good day, Camillo.
trg: Hail, most royal sir!

src: And in this thought they find a kind of ease, Bearing their own misfortunes on the back Of such as have before endured the like. Thus play I in one person many people, And none contented:
trg: sometimes am I king; Then treasons make me wish myself a beggar, And so I am: then crushing penury Persuades me I was better when a king; Then am I king'd again:

src: throw away respect, Tradition, form and ceremonious duty, For you have but mistook me all this while: I live with bread like you, feel want, Taste grief, need friends:
trg: subjected thus, How can you say to me, I am a king?

src: See, how they kiss and court!
trg: Signior Lucentio, Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow Never to woo her no more, but do forswear her, As one unworthy all the former favours That I have fondly flatter'd her withal.

src: I am glad he's come, howsoe'er he comes.
trg: Why, sir, he comes not.

src: Cut me to pieces, Volsces; men and lads, Stain all your edges on me. Boy! false hound!
trg: If you have writ your annals true, 'tis there, That, like an eagle in a dove-cote, I Flutter'd your Volscians in Corioli: Alone I did it. Boy!

src: Kate like the hazel-twig Is straight and slender and as brown in hue As hazel nuts and sweeter than the kernels. O, let me see thee walk: thou dost not halt.
trg: Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.

src: And live you yet? O my sweet lady, pardon.
trg: I know not where to turn: O, welcome home: And welcome, general: and ye're welcome all.
But stay thee, 'tis the fruits of love I mean.

src: The time hath been, Would you have been so brief with him, he would Have been so brief with you, to shorten you, For taking so the head, your whole head's length.
trg: Mistake not, uncle, further than you should.

src: I never long'd to hear a word till now; Say 'pardon,' king; let pity teach thee how: The word is short, but not so short as sweet; No word like 'pardon' for kings' mouths so meet.
trg: Speak it in French, king; say, 'pardonne moi.'

src: Yes, faith, and all his lords; the Duke of Milan And his brave son being twain.
Now am I seated as my soul delights, Having my country's peace and brothers' loves.
trg: What will your grace have done with Margaret? Reignier, her father, to the king of France Hath pawn'd the Sicils and Jerusalem, And hither have they sent it for her ransom.

src: Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace, Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,-- Will they not hear? What, ho! If ever you disturb our streets again, Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.
trg: For this time, all the rest depart away: You Capulet; shall go along with me:

src: Some six miles off the duke is with the soldiers; And for your brother, he was lately sent From your kind aunt, Duchess of Burgundy, With aid of soldiers to this needful war.
trg: 'Twas odds, belike, when valiant Warwick fled: Oft have I heard his praises in pursuit, But ne'er till now his scandal of retire.

src: 'Tis he, my lord. Come hither, goodman baldpate: do you know me?
trg: I remember you, sir, by the sound of your voice: I met you at the prison, in the absence of the duke.

src: Yea, leave that labour to great Hercules; And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.
trg: Sir, understand you this of me in sooth:

src: Say how he died, for I will hear it all.
trg: Environed he was with many foes, And stood against them, as the hope of Troy Against the Greeks that would have enter'd Troy. But Hercules himself must yield to odds;

src: What you have seen him do and heard him speak, Beating your officers, cursing yourselves, Opposing laws with strokes and here defying Those whose great power must try him;
trg: even this, So criminal and in such capital kind, Deserves the extremest death.

src: Your Coriolanus Is not much miss'd, but with his friends: The commonwealth doth stand, and so would do, Were he more angry at it.
trg: All's well; and might have been much better, if He could have temporized.

src: 'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums: How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour, And bring thy news so late?
trg: Spies of the Volsces Held me in chase, that I was forced to wheel Three or four miles about, else had I, sir, Half an hour since brought my report.

src: Why, is not this better now than groaning for love? now art thou sociable, now art thou Romeo; now art thou what thou art, by art as well as by nature:
trg: for this drivelling love is like a great natural, that runs lolling up and down to hide his bauble in a hole.

src: Thanks, noble Clarence; worthy brother, thanks.
trg: And, that I love the tree from whence thou sprang'st, Witness the loving kiss I give the fruit.

src: Shall sweet Bianca practise how to bride it?
trg: She shall, Lucentio. Come, gentlemen, let's go.

src: ' besides, I have stay'd To tire your royalty.
trg: We are tougher, brother, Than you can put us to't.

src: No better.
trg: Well, sir.

src: No, Bolingbroke: if ever I were traitor, My name be blotted from the book of life, And I from heaven banish'd as from hence! But what thou art, God, thou, and I do know;
trg: And all too soon, I fear, the king shall rue. Farewell, my liege. Now no way can I stray; Save back to England, all the world's my way.

src: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give; And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.
trg: A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin.

src: And ten to one is no impeach of valour.
trg: Ay, ay, so strives the woodcock with the gin.

src: Do you not hear me speak?
trg: I do; and surely It is a sleepy language and thou speak'st Out of thy sleep. What is it thou didst say? This is a strange repose, to be asleep With eyes wide open;

src: Like perspectives, which rightly gazed upon Show nothing but confusion, eyed awry Distinguish form:
trg: so your sweet majesty, Looking awry upon your lord's departure, Find shapes of grief, more than himself, to wail; Which, look'd on as it is, is nought but shadows Of what it is not.

src: Turn this way, Henry, and regard them not.
trg: They seek revenge and therefore will not yield.

src: Hail, most royal sir!
trg: What is the news i' the court?

src: Come, gentlemen, let's all go visit him: Pray God we may make haste, and come too late!
trg: Amen.

src: Ah, madam, 'tis too true: and that is worse, The Lord Northumberland, his son young Henry Percy, The Lords of Ross, Beaumond, and Willoughby, With all their powerful friends, are fled to him.
trg: Why have you not proclaim'd Northumberland And all the rest revolted faction traitors?

src: I was; but I do find more pain in banishment Than death can yield me here by my abode. A husband and a son thou owest to me; And thou a kingdom; all of you allegiance:
trg: The sorrow that I have, by right is yours, And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.

src: O Brakenbury, I have done those things, Which now bear evidence against my soul, For Edward's sake; and see how he requites me! O God!
trg: if my deep prayers cannot appease thee, But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds, Yet execute thy wrath in me alone, O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!

src: Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster! Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood!
trg: Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost, To hear the lamentations of Poor Anne, Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughter'd son, Stabb'd by the selfsame hand that made these wounds!

src: Well, what was yours?
trg: That dreamers often lie.

src: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.
trg: My Lord of Norfolk,--

src: Catesby!
trg: My lord?

src: Ay, say you so? the gates shall then be open'd.
trg: A wise stout captain, and soon persuaded!

src: both your pardons, That e'er I put between your holy looks My ill suspicion. This is your son-in-law, And son unto the king, who, heavens directing, Is troth-plight to your daughter.
trg: Good Paulina, Lead us from hence, where we may leisurely Each one demand an answer to his part Perform'd in this wide gap of time since first We were dissever'd: hastily lead away.

src: Good night: Get thee to bed, and rest; for thou hast need.
trg: Farewell! God knows when we shall meet again. I have a faint cold fear thrills through my veins, That almost freezes up the heat of life: I'll call them back again to comfort me: Nurse!

src: None good, my lord, to please you with the hearing; Nor none so bad, but it may well be told.
trg: Hoyday, a riddle! neither good nor bad! Why dost thou run so many mile about, When thou mayst tell thy tale a nearer way? Once more, what news?

src: Unshout the noise that banish'd Marcius, Repeal him with the welcome of his mother; Cry 'Welcome, ladies, welcome!'
trg: Welcome, ladies, Welcome!

src: Ready to go, but never to return. O son! the night before thy wedding-day Hath Death lain with thy wife. There she lies, Flower as she was, deflowered by him. Death is my son-in-law, Death is my heir;
trg: My daughter he hath wedded: I will die, And leave him all; life, living, all is Death's.

src: Then, Isabel, live chaste, and, brother, die: More than our brother is our chastity. I'll tell him yet of Angelo's request, And fit his mind to death, for his soul's rest.
trg: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?

src: A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin.
trg: A greater gift! O, that's the sword to it.

src: Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius?
trg: Against him first: he's a very dog to the commonalty.

src: Great God of heaven, say Amen to all! But, tell me, is young George Stanley living?
trg: He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester town; Whither, if it please you, we may now withdraw us.

src: Lo, now my glory smear'd in dust and blood! My parks, my walks, my manors that I had. Even now forsake me, and of all my lands Is nothing left me but my body's length.
trg: Why, what is pomp, rule, reign, but earth and dust? And, live we how we can, yet die we must.

src: How dost thou feel thyself now?
trg: 'Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.

src: You will! why, happy man be's dole! My brother, Are you so fond of your young prince as we Do seem to be of ours?
trg: If at home, sir, He's all my exercise, my mirth, my matter, Now my sworn friend and then mine enemy, My parasite, my soldier, statesman, all:

src: Never, my lord; therefore prepare to die.
trg: Are you call'd forth from out a world of men To slay the innocent? What is my offence? Where are the evidence that do accuse me? What lawful quest have given their verdict up Unto the frowning judge?

src: The good old man would fain that all were well, So 'twere not 'long of him; but being enter'd, I doubt not, I, but we shall soon persuade Both him and all his brothers unto reason.
trg: So, master mayor: these gates must not be shut But in the night or in the time of war. What! fear not, man, but yield me up the keys;

src: my lady!
trg: What noise is here?

src: What say you to a neat's foot?
trg: 'Tis passing good: I prithee let me have it.
What, resists he? Help him, Lucio.

src: O the heavens!
trg: Mark his condition and the event; then tell me If this might be a brother.

src: You lie.
trg: Draw, if you be men. Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.

src: Then, God be bless'd, it is the blessed sun: But sun it is not, when you say it is not; And the moon changes even as your mind. What you will have it named, even that it is;
trg: And so it shall be so for Katharina.

src: O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear: Go you to him from me.
trg: Ay, so we will.

src: sir, we had but two in the house, which at that very distant time stood, as it were, in a fruit-dish, a dish of some three-pence; your honours have seen such dishes;
trg: they are not China dishes, but very good dishes,--

src: My lord, I hear the Marquis Dorset's fled To Richmond, in those parts beyond the sea Where he abides.
trg: Catesby!

src: Not now, not now.
trg: Not in this heat, sir, now.

src: 'Tis a villain, sir, I do not love to look on.
trg: But, as 'tis, We cannot miss him: he does make our fire, Fetch in our wood and serves in offices That profit us. What, ho! slave! Caliban! Thou earth, thou! speak.

src: Call your executioner, and off with Barnardine's head: I will give him a present shrift and advise him for a better place. Yet you are amazed; but this shall absolutely resolve you. Come away;
trg: it is almost clear dawn.

src: The fitter for the King of heaven, that hath him.
trg: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.

src: O, he is wounded; I thank the gods for't.
trg: So do I too, if it be not too much: brings a' victory in his pocket? the wounds become him.

src: Read o'er this paper while the glass doth come.
trg: Fiend, thou torment'st me ere I come to hell!

src: Be calm, be calm.
trg: It is a purposed thing, and grows by plot, To curb the will of the nobility: Suffer't, and live with such as cannot rule Nor ever will be ruled.

src: Now, by my George, my garter, and my crown,--
trg: Profaned, dishonour'd, and the third usurp'd.

src: When he stands where I am and sees you there.
trg: But say, what to thine old news?

src: And I, that haply take them from him now, May yet ere night yield both my life and them To some man else, as this dead man doth me. Who's this? O God!
trg: it is my father's face, Whom in this conflict I unwares have kill'd. O heavy times, begetting such events! From London by the king was I press'd forth;

src: And seeing thou dost, I here divorce myself Both from thy table, Henry, and thy bed, Until that act of parliament be repeal'd Whereby my son is disinherited.
trg: The northern lords that have forsworn thy colours Will follow mine, if once they see them spread; And spread they shall be, to thy foul disgrace And utter ruin of the house of York.
Dost lack any money? I have a little money for thee.

src: Are there no other tokens Between you 'greed concerning her observance?
trg: No, none, but only a repair i' the dark; And that I have possess'd him my most stay Can be but brief;

src: Were it not that my fellow-school-master Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly, 'Twere good, methinks, to steal our marriage;
trg: Which once perform'd, let all the world say no, I'll keep mine own, despite of all the world.

src: Well, I will for refuge straight to Bristol castle: The Earl of Wiltshire is already there.
trg: Thither will I with you; for little office The hateful commons will perform for us, Except like curs to tear us all to pieces. Will you go along with us?

src: O, let me clip ye In arms as sound as when I woo'd, in heart As merry as when our nuptial day was done, And tapers burn'd to bedward!
trg: Flower of warriors, How is it with Titus Lartius?

src: A wise stout captain, and soon persuaded!
trg: The good old man would fain that all were well, So 'twere not 'long of him; but being enter'd, I doubt not, I, but we shall soon persuade Both him and all his brothers unto reason.

src: Had he none else to make a stale but me? Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow. I was the chief that raised him to the crown, And I'll be chief to bring him down again:
trg: Not that I pity Henry's misery, But seek revenge on Edward's mockery. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: And this is Edward's wife, that monstrous witch, Consorted with that harlot strumpet Shore, That by their witchcraft thus have marked me.
trg: If they have done this thing, my gracious lord--

src: So smile the heavens upon this holy act, That after hours with sorrow chide us not!
trg: Amen, amen! but come what sorrow can, It cannot countervail the exchange of joy That one short minute gives me in her sight:

src: I dream'd a dream to-night.
trg: And so did I.

src: Nurse, will you go with me into my closet, To help me sort such needful ornaments As you think fit to furnish me to-morrow?
trg: No, not till Thursday; there is time enough.

src: Are you in earnest, sir? I smell the trick on't.
trg: Dispatch, I prithee.

src: A little fire is quickly trodden out; Which, being suffer'd, rivers cannot quench.
trg: In Warwickshire I have true-hearted friends, Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in war; Those will I muster up:

src: Well, you have made a simple choice; you know not how to choose a man: Romeo! no, not he; though his face be better than any man's, yet his leg excels all men's;
trg: and for a hand, and a foot, and a body, though they be not to be talked on, yet they are past compare: he is not the flower of courtesy, but, I'll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb.

src: A deadly groan, like life and death's departing.
trg: See who it is: and, now the battle's ended, If friend or foe, let him be gently used.

src: What were I best to say? her father's brother Would be her lord? or shall I say, her uncle? Or, he that slew her brothers and her uncles?
trg: Under what title shall I woo for thee, That God, the law, my honour and her love, Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?

src: Who should that be? belike, unlook'd-for friends.
trg: They are at hand, and you shall quickly know.

src: Let's march without the noise of threatening drum, That from this castle's tatter'd battlements Our fair appointments may be well perused.
trg: Methinks King Richard and myself should meet With no less terror than the elements Of fire and water, when their thundering shock At meeting tears the cloudy cheeks of heaven.

src: That's somewhat madly spoken.
trg: Pardon it; The phrase is to the matter.

src: I thank thee, Varrius; thou hast made good haste: Come, we will walk. There's other of our friends Will greet us here anon, my gentle Varrius.
trg: To speak so indirectly I am loath: I would say the truth; but to accuse him so, That is your part: yet I am advised to do it; He says, to veil full purpose.

src: O brother Montague, give me thy hand: This is my daughter's jointure, for no more Can I demand.
trg: But I can give thee more: For I will raise her statue in pure gold; That while Verona by that name is known, There shall no figure at such rate be set As that of true and faithful Juliet.

src: Or as a bear, encompass'd round with dogs, Who having pinch'd a few and made them cry, The rest stand all aloof, and bark at him. So fared our father with his enemies;
trg: So fled his enemies my warlike father: Methinks, 'tis prize enough to be his son. See how the morning opes her golden gates, And takes her farewell of the glorious sun!

src: Happily met, my lady and my wife!
trg: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.

src: Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster!
trg: Two of thy name, both Dukes of Somerset, Have sold their lives unto the house of York; And thou shalt be the third if this sword hold.

src: Ay, sir, it is too true; God help the while!
trg: Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.

src: Ay, but mildly.
trg: Well, mildly be it then. Mildly!

src: Though in this city he Hath widow'd and unchilded many a one, Which to this hour bewail the injury, Yet he shall have a noble memory. Assist.
trg: Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this sun of York; And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.

src: 'Tis Aufidius, Who, hearing of our Marcius' banishment, Thrusts forth his horns again into the world; Which were inshell'd when Marcius stood for Rome, And durst not once peep out.
trg: Come, what talk you Of Marcius?

src: Now, good my liege Sir, royal sir, forgive a foolish woman: The love I bore your queen--lo, fool again!-- I'll speak of her no more, nor of your children;
trg: I'll not remember you of my own lord, Who is lost too: take your patience to you, And I'll say nothing.

src: He hath a garden circummured with brick, Whose western side is with a vineyard back'd; And to that vineyard is a planched gate, That makes his opening with this bigger key:
trg: This other doth command a little door Which from the vineyard to the garden leads; There have I made my promise Upon the heavy middle of the night To call upon him.

src: You need not fear it, sir:
trg: This child was prisoner to the womb and is By law and process of great nature thence Freed and enfranchised, not a party to The anger of the king nor guilty of, If any be, the trespass of the queen.

src: Whilst, in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts, Which here we waken to our country's good, This noble isle doth want her proper limbs;
trg: Her face defaced with scars of infamy, Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants, And almost shoulder'd in the swallowing gulf Of blind forgetfulness and dark oblivion.

src: O, to what purpose dost thou hoard thy words, That thou return'st no greeting to thy friends?
trg: I have too few to take my leave of you, When the tongue's office should be prodigal To breathe the abundant dolour of the heart.

src: With an eye of green in't.
trg: He misses not much.

src: well, was it fit for a servant to use his master so, being perhaps, for aught I see, two and thirty, a pip out? Whom would to God I had well knock'd at first, Then had not Grumio come by the worst.
trg: A senseless villain! Good Hortensio, I bade the rascal knock upon your gate And could not get him for my heart to do it.

src: Madam, an hour before the worshipp'd sun Peer'd forth the golden window of the east, A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad;
trg: Where, underneath the grove of sycamore That westward rooteth from the city's side, So early walking did I see your son:

src: Within two hours.
trg: Come, officer, away!

src: Hail, virgin, if you be, as those cheek-roses Proclaim you are no less!
trg: Can you so stead me As bring me to the sight of Isabella, A novice of this place and the fair sister To her unhappy brother Claudio?

src: Do, Paulina; For this affliction has a taste as sweet As any cordial comfort. Still, methinks, There is an air comes from her: what fine chisel Could ever yet cut breath?
trg: Let no man mock me, For I will kiss her.

src: For this alliance may so happy prove, To turn your households' rancour to pure love.
trg: O, let us hence; I stand on sudden haste.

src: I think there is not in the world either malice or matter to alter it. You have an unspeakable comfort of your young prince Mamillius:
trg: it is a gentleman of the greatest promise that ever came into my note.

src: Pray, sir, by your good favour,--for surely, sir, a good favour you have, but that you have a hanging look,--do you call, sir, your occupation a mystery?
trg: Ay, sir; a mystery

src: I am joyful to hear of their readiness, and am the man, I think, that shall set them in present action. So, sir, heartily well met, and most glad of your company.
trg: You take my part from me, sir; I have the most cause to be glad of yours.

src: The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.
trg: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it: And yet I would it were to give again.

src: Now York and Lancaster are reconciled.
trg: Accursed be he that seeks to make them foes!

src: She is spread of late Into a goodly bulk: good time encounter her!
trg: What wisdom stirs amongst you? Come, sir, now I am for you again: pray you, sit by us, And tell 's a tale.

src: It needs not, nor it boots thee not, proud queen, Unless the adage must be verified, That beggars mounted run their horse to death. 'Tis beauty that doth oft make women proud;
trg: But, God he knows, thy share thereof is small: 'Tis virtue that doth make them most admired; The contrary doth make thee wonder'd at: 'Tis government that makes them seem divine;

src: Peace, ho! no outrage: peace! The man is noble and his fame folds-in This orb o' the earth. His last offences to us Shall have judicious hearing. Stand, Aufidius, And trouble not the peace.
trg: O that I had him, With six Aufidiuses, or more, his tribe, To use my lawful sword!

src: Madam, in happy time, what day is that?
trg: Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn, The gallant, young and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter's Church, Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.

src: Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we? Greater he shall not be; if he serve God, We'll serve Him too and be his fellow so: Revolt our subjects? that we cannot mend;
trg: They break their faith to God as well as us: Cry woe, destruction, ruin and decay: The worst is death, and death will have his day.

src: I am the son of Henry the Fifth, Who made the Dauphin and the French to stoop And seized upon their towns and provinces.
trg: Talk not of France, sith thou hast lost it all.

src: His answer was, he would unto the stews, And from the common'st creature pluck a glove, And wear it as a favour; and with that He would unhorse the lustiest challenger.
trg: As dissolute as desperate; yet through both I see some sparks of better hope, which elder years May happily bring forth. But who comes here?

src: And I, in such a desperate bay of death, Like a poor bark, of sails and tackling reft, Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.
trg: Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise And dangerous success of bloody wars, As I intend more good to you and yours, Than ever you or yours were by me wrong'd!

src: The lamb.
trg: Ay, to devour him; as the hungry plebeians would the noble Marcius.

src: And, brother, here's the Earl of Wiltshire's blood, Whom I encounter'd as the battles join'd.
trg: Speak thou for me and tell them what I did.

src: what she bade me say, I will keep to myself: but first let me tell ye, if ye should lead her into a fool's paradise, as they say, it were a very gross kind of behavior, as they say:
trg: for the gentlewoman is young; and, therefore, if you should deal double with her, truly it were an ill thing to be offered to any gentlewoman, and very weak dealing.

src: Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours; He should, for that, commit your godfathers: O, belike his majesty hath some intent That you shall be new-christen'd in the Tower.
trg: But what's the matter, Clarence?  may I know?

src: No, good madam; I will not out of doors.
trg: Not out of doors!

src: Is he won yet?
trg: He'll stay my lord.

src: Out--
trg: Of love?

src: Then was this island-- Save for the son that she did litter here, A freckled whelp hag-born--not honour'd with A human shape.
trg: Yes, Caliban her son.

src: No, no, he's gone.
trg: Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss, That would not bless our Europe with your daughter, But rather lose her to an African;

src: I heard him swear, Were he to stand for consul, never would he Appear i' the market-place nor on him put The napless vesture of humility;
trg: Nor showing, as the manner is, his wounds To the people, beg their stinking breaths.

src: Why, how now, kinsman! wherefore storm you so?
trg: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe, A villain that is hither come in spite, To scorn at our solemnity this night.
