src: Well, go with me and be not so discomfited: Proceed in practise with my younger daughter; She's apt to learn and thankful for good turns.
trg: Signior Petruchio, will you go with us, Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you?

src: Heaven shield your grace from woe, As I, thus wrong'd, hence unbelieved go!
trg: I know you'ld fain be gone. An officer! To prison with her! Shall we thus permit A blasting and a scandalous breath to fall On him so near us? This needs must be a practise.

src: Arise; one knocks; good Romeo, hide thyself.
trg: Not I; unless the breath of heartsick groans, Mist-like, infold me from the search of eyes.

src: And this my neighbour too?
trg: And he, and more Than he, and men, the earth, the heavens, and all: for her employ them all; Commend them and condemn them to her service Or to their own perdition.

src: Strangle such thoughts as these with any thing That you behold the while. Your guests are coming:
trg: Lift up your countenance, as it were the day Of celebration of that nuptial which We two have sworn shall come.

src: Yea, are you so brief?
trg: O sir, it is better to be brief than tedious. Show him our commission; talk no more.

src: For so your doctors hold it very meet, Seeing too much sadness hath congeal'd your blood, And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy:
trg: Therefore they thought it good you hear a play And frame your mind to mirth and merriment, Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.

src: My royal father, cheer these noble lords And hearten those that fight in your defence: Unsheathe your sword, good father; cry 'Saint George!'
trg: Now, perjured Henry! wilt thou kneel for grace, And set thy diadem upon my head; Or bide the mortal fortune of the field?

src: No; I will resist such entertainment till Mine enemy has more power.
trg: O dear father, Make not too rash a trial of him, for He's gentle and not fearful.

src: Good madam,--
trg: I have done. Yet, if my lord will marry,--if you will, sir, No remedy, but you will,--give me the office To choose you a queen: she shall not be so young As was your former;

src: Now God in heaven forbid!
trg: Ah, madam, 'tis too true: and that is worse, The Lord Northumberland, his son young Henry Percy, The Lords of Ross, Beaumond, and Willoughby, With all their powerful friends, are fled to him.

src: The very trick on't.
trg: This is unlikely: He and Aufidius can no more atone Than violentest contrariety.

src: O master, if you did but hear the pedlar at the door, you would never dance again after a tabour and pipe; no, the bagpipe could not move you: he sings several tunes faster than you'll tell money;
trg: he utters them as he had eaten ballads and all men's ears grew to his tunes.

src: Why, foolish boy, the king is left behind, And in my loyal bosom lies his power. Now prisoner to the palsy, chastise thee And minister correction to thy fault!
trg: My gracious uncle, let me know my fault: On what condition stands it and wherein?

src: and to silence that, Which, to the spire and top of praises vouch'd, Would seem but modest:
trg: therefore, I beseech you In sign of what you are, not to reward What you have done--before our army hear me.

src: What studied torments, tyrant, hast for me? What wheels? racks? fires? what flaying? boiling? In leads or oils?
trg: what old or newer torture Must I receive, whose every word deserves To taste of thy most worst?

src: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!
trg: Amen.

src: Therefore, my lord,--
trg: Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue!

src: nay, dry your eyes; One of our convent, and his confessor, Gives me this instance:
trg: already he hath carried Notice to Escalus and Angelo, Who do prepare to meet him at the gates, There to give up their power.

src: How couldst thou drain the life-blood of the child, To bid the father wipe his eyes withal, And yet be seen to bear a woman's face? Women are soft, mild, pitiful and flexible;
trg: Thou stern, obdurate, flinty, rough, remorseless. Bids't thou me rage? why, now thou hast thy wish: Wouldst have me weep? why, now thou hast thy will:

src: One word, good citizens.
trg: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good. What authority surfeits on would relieve us:

src: O cheerful colours! see where Oxford comes!
trg: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster!

src: Nay, go not from me; I will follow thee.
trg: Be patient, gentle queen, and I will stay.

src: whilst many fair promotions Are daily given to ennoble those That scarce, some two days since, were worth a noble.
trg: By Him that raised me to this careful height From that contented hap which I enjoy'd, I never did incense his majesty Against the Duke of Clarence, but have been An earnest advocate to plead for him.

src: For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows, Thou bear's thy heavy riches but a journey, And death unloads thee. Friend hast thou none;
trg: For thine own bowels, which do call thee sire, The mere effusion of thy proper loins, Do curse the gout, serpigo, and the rheum, For ending thee no sooner.

src: What Eve, what serpent, hath suggested thee To make a second fall of cursed man? Why dost thou say King Richard is deposed? Darest thou, thou little better thing than earth, Divine his downfall?
trg: Say, where, when, and how, Camest thou by this ill tidings? speak, thou wretch.

src: Hearing thy mildness praised in every town, Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded, Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs, Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.
trg: Moved! in good time: let him that moved you hither Remove you hence: I knew you at the first You were a moveable.

src: the want of which vain dew Perchance shall dry your pities: but I have That honourable grief lodged here which burns Worse than tears drown:
trg: beseech you all, my lords, With thoughts so qualified as your charities Shall best instruct you, measure me; and so The king's will be perform'd!

src: Good my friends, If you have heard your general talk of Rome, And of his friends there, it is lots to blanks, My name hath touch'd your ears it is Menenius.
trg: Be it so; go back: the virtue of your name Is not here passable.

src: And what is Edward but ruthless sea? What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit? And Richard but a ragged fatal rock? All these the enemies to our poor bark. Say you can swim; alas, 'tis but a while!
trg: Tread on the sand; why, there you quickly sink: Bestride the rock; the tide will wash you off, Or else you famish; that's a threefold death.

src: Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.
trg: Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel:

src: If not, that, I being queen, you bow like subjects, Yet that, by you deposed, you quake like rebels? O gentle villain, do not turn away!
trg: Foul wrinkled witch, what makest thou in my sight?

src: God ye good den, fair gentlewoman.
trg: Is it good den?

src: Go, tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return. Simple, plain Clarence! I do love thee so, That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven, If heaven will take the present at our hands.
trg: But who comes here? the new-deliver'd Hastings?

src: Plantagenet, for all the claim thou lay'st, Think not that Henry shall be so deposed.
trg: Deposed he shall be, in despite of all.

src: Mend and charge home, Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave the foe And make my wars on you: look to't: come on;
trg: If you'll stand fast, we'll beat them to their wives, As they us to our trenches followed. So, now the gates are ope: now prove good seconds:

src: Because I cannot flatter and speak fair, Smile in men's faces, smooth, deceive and cog, Duck with French nods and apish courtesy, I must be held a rancorous enemy.
trg: Cannot a plain man live and think no harm, But thus his simple truth must be abused By silken, sly, insinuating Jacks?

src: make your best of it.
trg: I never saw a better-fashion'd gown, More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable: Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

src: To three thousand dolours a year.
trg: Ay, and more.

src: I say thou liest, Camillo, and I hate thee, Pronounce thee a gross lout, a mindless slave, Or else a hovering temporizer, that Canst with thine eyes at once see good and evil, Inclining to them both:
trg: were my wife's liver Infected as her life, she would not live The running of one glass.

src: What comfort is for Claudio?
trg: There's some in hope.

src: So prosper I, as I swear perfect love!
trg: And I, as I love Hastings with my heart!

src: If that be right which Warwick says is right, There is no wrong, but every thing is right.
trg: Whoever got thee, there thy mother stands; For, well I wot, thou hast thy mother's tongue.

src: No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.
trg: Why, then you mean not as I thought you did.

src: I have it, Tranio.
trg: Master, for my hand, Both our inventions meet and jump in one.

src: So, now prosperity begins to mellow And drop into the rotten mouth of death. Here in these confines slily have I lurk'd, To watch the waning of mine adversaries.
trg: A dire induction am I witness to, And will to France, hoping the consequence Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical. Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret: who comes here?

src: That I'll straight do; and, knowing myself again, Repair to the senate-house.
trg: I'll keep you company. Will you along?

src: Nay, but you will?
trg: I may not, verily.

src: And let them die that age and sullens have; For both hast thou, and both become the grave.
trg: I do beseech your majesty, impute his words To wayward sickliness and age in him: He loves you, on my life, and holds you dear As Harry Duke of Hereford, were he here.

src: And so have I, boy.
trg: So you have: but I was a gentleman born before my father; for the king's son took me by the hand, and called me brother; and then the two kings called my father brother;

src: but grace, being the soul of your complexion, shall keep the body of it ever fair. The assault that Angelo hath made to you, fortune hath conveyed to my understanding;
trg: and, but that frailty hath examples for his falling, I should wonder at Angelo. How will you do to content this substitute, and to save your brother?

src: Romeo! Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains The stony entrance of this sepulchre? What mean these masterless and gory swords To lie discolour'd by this place of peace? Romeo! O, pale!
trg: Who else? what, Paris too? And steep'd in blood? Ah, what an unkind hour Is guilty of this lamentable chance! The lady stirs.

src: and, but he's something stain'd With grief that's beauty's canker, thou mightst call him A goodly person: he hath lost his fellows And strays about to find 'em.
trg: I might call him A thing divine, for nothing natural I ever saw so noble.

src: First, heaven be the record to my speech!
trg: In the devotion of a subject's love, Tendering the precious safety of my prince, And free from other misbegotten hate, Come I appellant to this princely presence.

src: They thus directed, we will follow In the main battle, whose puissance on either side Shall be well winged with our chiefest horse. This, and Saint George to boot! What think'st thou, Norfolk?
trg: A good direction, warlike sovereign. This found I on my tent this morning.

src: Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard, look to the plate. Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane; and, as thou lovest me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.
trg: Antony, and Potpan!

src: She, on his left side, craving aid for Henry, He, on his right, asking a wife for Edward. She weeps, and says her Henry is deposed; He smiles, and says his Edward is install'd;
trg: That she, poor wretch, for grief can speak no more; O Margaret, thus 'twill be; and thou, poor soul, Art then forsaken, as thou went'st forlorn!

src: I think not so.
trg: We should by this, to all our lamentation, If he had gone forth consul, found it so.

src: It would seem strange unto him when he waked.
trg: Even as a flattering dream or worthless fancy. Then take him up and manage well the jest: Carry him gently to my fairest chamber And hang it round with all my wanton pictures:

src: Fetch hither Richard, that in common view He may surrender; so we shall proceed Without suspicion.
trg: I will be his conduct.

src: Very well.
trg: And most chirurgeonly.

src: Madam, we'll tell tales.
trg: Of sorrow or of joy?

src: Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray. To have him suddenly convey'd away. Cancel his bond of life, dear God, I prey, That I may live to say, The dog is dead!
trg: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curse That bottled spider, that foul bunch-back'd toad!

src: Nay, I will win my wager better yet And show more sign of her obedience, Her new-built virtue and obedience. See where she comes and brings your froward wives As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.
trg: Katharina, that cap of yours becomes you not: Off with that bauble, throw it under-foot.

src: Your grace hath still been famed for virtuous; And now may seem as wise as virtuous, By spying and avoiding fortune's malice, For few men rightly temper with the stars:
trg: Yet in this one thing let me blame your grace, For choosing me when Clarence is in place.

src: Sir, your company is fairer than honest. Rest you well.
trg: By my troth, I'll go with thee to the lane's end: if bawdy talk offend you, we'll have very little of it. Nay, friar, I am a kind of burr; I shall stick.

src: Ay, but not frighted me; therefore I'll sleep again.
trg: Nay, that you shall not: since you have begun, Have at you for a bitter jest or two!

src: He's irremoveable, Resolved for flight.
trg: Now, good Camillo; I am so fraught with curious business that I leave out ceremony.

src: The other part reserved I by consent, For that my sovereign liege was in my debt Upon remainder of a dear account, Since last I went to France to fetch his queen: Now swallow down that lie.
trg: For Gloucester's death, I slew him not; but to my own disgrace Neglected my sworn duty in that case. This is my fault:

src: My lord, good morrow; good morrow, Catesby: You may jest on, but, by the holy rood, I do not like these several councils, I.
trg: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours; And never in my life, I do protest, Was it more precious to me than 'tis now:

src: My lord, your promise for the earldom,--
trg: Richmond! When last I was at Exeter, The mayor in courtesy show'd me the castle, And call'd it Rougemont:

src: Stay, Edward.
trg: No, wrangling woman, we'll no longer stay: These words will cost ten thousand lives this day. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: My lord, He wonders to what end you have assembled Such troops of citizens to speak with him, His grace not being warn'd thereof before: My lord, he fears you mean no good to him.
trg: Sorry I am my noble cousin should Suspect me, that I mean no good to him: By heaven, I come in perfect love to him; And so once more return and tell his grace.

src: O excellent devise! make a sop of him.
trg: Hark! he stirs: shall I strike?

src: The gods begin to mock me. I, that now Refused most princely gifts, am bound to beg Of my lord general.
trg: Take't; 'tis yours. What is't?

src: Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.
trg: Now let me see if I can construe it: 'Hic ibat Simois,' I know you not, 'hic est Sigeia tellus,' I trust you not;

src: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.
trg: And then?

src: I do beseech you, either not believe The envious slanders of her false accusers;
trg: Or, if she be accused in true report, Bear with her weakness, which, I think proceeds From wayward sickness, and no grounded malice.

src: My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise, For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd; The earldom of Hereford and the moveables The which you promised I should possess.
trg: Stanley, look to your wife; if she convey Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.

src: For which I do discharge you of your office: Give up your keys.
trg: Pardon me, noble lord: I thought it was a fault, but knew it not; Yet did repent me, after more advice;

src: Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.
trg: Come, sir, your passado.

src: With all our harts.
trg: My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince, For God's sake, let not us two be behind;

src: but the last,--O lords, When I have said, cry 'woe!' the queen, the queen, The sweet'st, dear'st creature's dead, and vengeance for't Not dropp'd down yet.
trg: The higher powers forbid!

src: God in heaven bless her! You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.
trg: And why, my lady wisdom? hold your tongue, Good prudence; smatter with your gossips, go.

src: You shall have none ill, sir; for I'll try if they can lick their fingers.
trg: How canst thou try them so?

src: I say, without characters, fame lives long. Thus, like the formal vice, Iniquity, I moralize two meanings in one word.
trg: That Julius Caesar was a famous man; With what his valour did enrich his wit, His wit set down to make his valour live Death makes no conquest of this conqueror;

src: Why, then, though loath, yet must I be content: We'll yoke together, like a double shadow To Henry's body, and supply his place;
trg: I mean, in bearing weight of government, While he enjoys the honour and his ease.

src: What are you?
trg: A gentleman.

src: and it is rumour'd, Cominius, Marcius your old enemy, Who is of Rome worse hated than of you, And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman, These three lead on this preparation Whither 'tis bent:
trg: most likely 'tis for you: Consider of it.'

src: Foul weather?
trg: Very foul.

src: Come on, then, And give't me in mine ear.
trg: Was he met there? his train? Camillo with him?

src: Let him alone; He did inform the truth: but for our gentlemen, The common file--a plague! tribunes for them!-- The mouse ne'er shunn'd the cat as they did budge From rascals worse than they.
trg: But how prevail'd you?

src: O, what more favour can I do to thee, Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain To sunder his that was thine enemy? Forgive me, cousin! Ah, dear Juliet, Why art thou yet so fair?
trg: shall I believe That unsubstantial death is amorous, And that the lean abhorred monster keeps Thee here in dark to be his paramour? For fear of that, I still will stay with thee;

src: Come, ladies, go, To meet at London London's king in woe. What, was I born to this, that my sad look Should grace the triumph of great Bolingbroke?
trg: Gardener, for telling me these news of woe, Pray God the plants thou graft'st may never grow.

src: And happy always was it for that son Whose father for his hoarding went to hell? I'll leave my son my virtuous deeds behind; And would my father had left me no more!
trg: For all the rest is held at such a rate As brings a thousand-fold more care to keep Than in possession and jot of pleasure. Ah, cousin York!

src: Shall I forget myself to be myself?
trg: Ay, if yourself's remembrance wrong yourself.

src: My best Camillo! We must disguise ourselves.
trg: When daffodils begin to peer, With heigh! the doxy over the dale, Why, then comes in the sweet o' the year; For the red blood reigns in the winter's pale.

src: Both by myself and many other friends: Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow. We would as willingly give cure as know.
trg: See, where he comes: so please you, step aside; I'll know his grievance, or be much denied.

src: And here remain with your uncertainty! Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts! Your enemies, with nodding of their plumes, Fan you into despair! Have the power still To banish your defenders;
trg: till at length Your ignorance, which finds not till it feels, Making not reservation of yourselves, Still your own foes, deliver you as most Abated captives to some nation That won you without blows!

src: O Perdita, what have we twain forgot! Pray you, a word.
He had, my lord; and that it was which caused Our swifter composition.
trg: So then the Volsces stand but as at first, Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road. Upon's again.

src: I will trust you. Walk before toward the sea-side; go on the right hand: I will but look upon the hedge and follow you.
trg: We are blest in this man, as I may say, even blest.

src: Thou hadst but power over his mortal body, His soul thou canst not have; therefore be gone.
trg: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.

src: Most strange, but yet most truly, will I speak: That Angelo's forsworn; is it not strange? That Angelo's a murderer; is 't not strange?
trg: That Angelo is an adulterous thief, An hypocrite, a virgin-violator; Is it not strange and strange?

src: Well, I have done: but yet,--
trg: He will be talking.

src: -- Which, without note, here's many else have done,-- You shout me forth In acclamations hyperbolical; As if I loved my little should be dieted In praises sauced with lies.
trg: Too modest are you; More cruel to your good report than grateful To us that give you truly:

src: My crown is in my heart, not on my head; Not decked with diamonds and Indian stones, Nor to be seen: my crown is called content: A crown it is that seldom kings enjoy.
trg: Well, if you be a king crown'd with content, Your crown content and you must be contented To go along with us; for as we think, You are the king King Edward hath deposed;

src: Good even. Friar, where's the provost?
trg: Not within, sir.

src: Stay a little while. You're welcome: what's your will?
trg: I am a woeful suitor to your honour, Please but your honour hear me.

src: I very well agree with you in the hopes of him: it is a gallant child; one that indeed physics the subject, makes old hearts fresh:
trg: they that went on crutches ere he was born desire yet their life to see him a man.

src: I gave him no order; I gave him the stuff.
trg: But how did you desire it should be made?
